
  
Phineas
Finn
Proposes
to
Stand
for
Loughshane
 
Dr.
Finn
,
of
Killaloe
,
in
county
Clare
,
was
as
well
known
in
those
parts
,
 
<EOS>
the
confines
,
that
is
,
of
the
counties
Clare
,
Limerick
,
Tipperary
,
and
Galway
,
 
as
was
the
bishop
himself
who
lived
in
the
same
town
,
and
was
as
much
respected
.
<EOS>
Many
said
that
the
doctor
was
the
richer
man
of
the
two
,
and
the
practice
of
his
profession
was
extended
over
almost
as
wide
a
district
.
<EOS>
Indeed
the
bishop
whom
he
was
privileged
to
attend
,
although
a
Roman
Catholic
,
always
spoke
of
their
dioceses
being
conterminate
.
<EOS>
It
will
therefore
be
understood
that
Dr.
Finn
,
 
Malachi
Finn
was
his
full
name
,
 
had
obtained
a
wide
reputation
as
a
country
practitioner
in
the
west
of
Ireland
.
<EOS>
And
he
was
a
man
sufficiently
well
to
do
,
though
that
boast
made
by
his
friends
,
that
he
was
as
warm
a
man
as
the
bishop
,
had
but
little
truth
to
support
it
.
<EOS>
Bishops
in
Ireland
,
if
they
live
at
home
,
even
in
these
days
,
are
very
warm
men
;
and
Dr.
Finn
had
not
a
penny
in
the
world
for
which
he
had
not
worked
hard
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
moreover
,
a
costly
family
,
five
daughters
and
one
son
,
and
,
at
the
time
of
which
we
are
speaking
,
no
provision
in
the
way
of
marriage
or
profession
had
been
made
for
any
of
them
.
<EOS>
Of
the
one
son
,
Phineas
,
the
hero
of
the
following
pages
,
the
mother
and
five
sisters
were
very
proud
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
was
accustomed
to
say
that
his
goose
was
as
good
as
any
other
man
's
goose
,
as
far
as
he
could
see
as
yet
;
but
that
he
should
like
some
very
strong
evidence
before
he
allowed
himself
to
express
an
opinion
that
the
young
bird
partook
,
in
any
degree
,
of
the
qualities
of
a
swan
.
<EOS>
From
which
it
may
be
gathered
that
Dr.
Finn
was
a
man
of
common
-
sense
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
had
come
to
be
a
swan
in
the
estimation
of
his
mother
and
sisters
by
reason
of
certain
early
successes
at
college
.
<EOS>
His
father
,
whose
religion
was
not
of
that
bitter
kind
in
which
we
in
England
are
apt
to
suppose
that
all
the
Irish
Roman
Catholics
indulge
,
had
sent
his
son
to
Trinity
;
and
there
were
some
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Killaloe
,
 
patients
,
probably
,
of
Dr.
Duggin
,
of
Castle
Connell
,
a
learned
physician
who
had
spent
a
fruitless
life
in
endeavouring
to
make
head
against
Dr.
Finn
,
 
who
declared
that
old
Finn
would
not
be
sorry
if
his
son
were
to
turn
Protestant
and
go
in
for
a
fellowship
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Finn
was
a
Protestant
,
and
the
five
Miss
Finns
were
Protestants
,
and
the
doctor
himself
was
very
much
given
to
dining
out
among
his
Protestant
friends
on
a
Friday
.
<EOS>
Our
Phineas
,
however
,
did
not
turn
Protestant
up
in
Dublin
,
whatever
his
father
's
secret
wishes
on
that
subject
may
have
been
.
<EOS>
He
did
join
a
debating
society
,
to
success
in
which
his
religion
was
no
bar
;
and
he
there
achieved
a
sort
of
distinction
which
was
both
easy
and
pleasant
,
and
<EOS>
which
,
making
its
way
down
to
Killaloe
,
assisted
in
engendering
those
ideas
as
to
swanhood
of
which
maternal
and
sisterly
minds
are
so
sweetly
susceptible
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
half
a
dozen
old
windbags
at
the
present
moment
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
"
who
were
great
fellows
at
debating
clubs
when
they
were
boys
.
"
<EOS>
"
Phineas
is
not
a
boy
any
longer
,
"
said
Mrs.
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
windbags
do
n't
get
college
scholarships
,
"
said
Matilda
Finn
,
the
second
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
papa
always
snubs
Phinny
,
"
said
Barbara
,
the
youngest
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
snub
you
,
if
you
do
n't
take
care
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
taking
Barbara
tenderly
by
the
ear
;
 
for
his
youngest
daughter
was
the
doctor
's
pet
.
  
<EOS>
The
doctor
certainly
did
not
snub
his
son
,
for
he
allowed
him
to
go
over
to
London
when
he
was
twenty
-
two
years
of
age
,
in
order
that
he
might
read
with
an
English
barrister
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
doctor
's
wish
that
his
son
might
be
called
to
the
Irish
Bar
,
and
the
young
man
's
desire
that
he
might
go
to
the
English
Bar
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
so
far
gave
way
,
under
the
influence
of
Phineas
himself
,
and
of
all
the
young
women
of
the
family
,
as
to
pay
the
usual
fee
to
a
very
competent
and
learned
gentleman
in
the
Middle
Temple
,
and
to
allow
his
son
one
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
per
annum
for
three
years
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Finn
,
however
,
was
still
firm
in
his
intention
that
his
son
should
settle
in
Dublin
,
and
take
the
Munster
Circuit
,
 
believing
that
Phineas
might
come
to
want
home
influences
and
home
connections
,
in
spite
of
the
swanhood
which
was
attributed
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
sat
his
terms
for
three
years
,
and
was
duly
called
to
the
Bar
;
but
no
evidence
came
home
as
to
the
acquirement
of
any
considerable
amount
of
law
lore
,
or
even
as
to
much
law
study
,
on
the
part
of
the
young
aspirant
.
<EOS>
The
learned
pundit
at
whose
feet
he
had
been
sitting
was
not
especially
loud
in
praise
of
his
pupil
's
industry
,
though
he
did
say
a
pleasant
word
or
two
as
to
his
pupil
's
intelligence
.
<EOS>
Phineas
himself
did
not
boast
much
of
his
own
hard
work
when
at
home
during
the
long
vacation
.
<EOS>
No
rumours
of
expected
successes
,
 
of
expected
professional
successes
,
 
reached
the
ears
of
any
of
the
Finn
family
at
Killaloe
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
there
came
tidings
which
maintained
those
high
ideas
in
the
maternal
bosom
of
which
mention
has
been
made
,
and
which
were
of
sufficient
strength
to
induce
the
doctor
,
in
opposition
to
his
own
judgment
,
to
consent
to
the
continued
residence
of
his
son
in
London
.
<EOS>
Phineas
belonged
to
an
excellent
club
,
 
the
Reform
Club
,
 
and
went
into
very
good
society
.
<EOS>
He
was
hand
in
glove
with
the
Hon
.
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
,
the
youngest
son
of
Lord
Claddagh
.
<EOS>
He
was
intimate
with
Barrington
Erle
,
who
had
been
private
secretary
,
 
one
of
the
private
secretaries
,
 
to
the
great
Whig
Prime
Minister
who
was
lately
in
but
was
now
out
.
<EOS>
He
had
dined
three
or
four
times
with
that
great
Whig
nobleman
,
the
Earl
of
Brentford
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
been
assured
that
if
he
stuck
to
the
English
Bar
he
would
certainly
do
well
.
<EOS>
Though
he
might
fail
to
succeed
in
court
or
in
chambers
,
he
would
doubtless
have
given
to
him
some
one
of
those
numerous
appointments
for
which
none
but
clever
young
barristers
are
supposed
to
be
fitting
candidates
.
<EOS>
The
old
doctor
yielded
for
another
year
,
although
at
the
end
of
the
second
year
he
was
called
upon
to
pay
a
sum
of
three
hundred
pounds
,
which
was
then
due
by
Phineas
to
creditors
in
London
.
<EOS>
When
the
doctor
's
male
friends
in
and
about
Killaloe
heard
that
he
had
done
so
,
they
said
that
he
was
doting
.
<EOS>
Not
one
of
the
Miss
Finns
was
as
yet
married
;
and
,
after
all
that
had
been
said
about
the
doctor
's
wealth
,
it
was
supposed
that
there
would
not
be
above
five
hundred
pounds
a
year
among
them
all
,
were
he
to
give
up
his
profession
.
<EOS>
But
the
doctor
,
when
he
paid
that
three
hundred
pounds
for
his
son
,
buckled
to
his
work
again
,
though
he
had
for
twelve
months
talked
of
giving
up
the
midwifery
.
<EOS>
He
buckled
to
again
,
to
the
great
disgust
of
Dr.
Duggin
,
who
at
this
time
said
very
ill
-
natured
things
about
young
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
end
of
the
three
years
Phineas
was
called
to
the
Bar
,
and
immediately
received
a
letter
from
his
father
asking
minutely
as
to
his
professional
intentions
.
<EOS>
His
father
recommended
him
to
settle
in
Dublin
,
and
promised
the
one
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
for
three
more
years
,
on
condition
that
this
advice
was
followed
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
absolutely
say
that
the
allowance
would
be
stopped
if
the
advice
were
not
followed
,
but
that
was
plainly
to
be
implied
.
<EOS>
That
letter
came
at
the
moment
of
a
dissolution
of
Parliament
.
<EOS>
Lord
de
Terrier
,
the
Conservative
Prime
Minister
,
who
had
now
been
in
office
for
the
almost
unprecedentedly
long
period
of
fifteen
months
,
had
found
that
he
could
not
face
continued
majorities
against
him
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
and
had
dissolved
the
House
.
<EOS>
Rumour
declared
that
he
would
have
much
preferred
to
resign
,
and
betake
himself
once
again
to
the
easy
glories
of
opposition
;
but
his
party
had
naturally
been
obdurate
with
him
,
and
he
had
resolved
to
appeal
to
the
country
.
<EOS>
When
Phineas
received
his
father
's
letter
,
it
had
just
been
suggested
to
him
at
the
Reform
Club
that
he
should
stand
for
the
Irish
borough
of
Loughshane
.
  
<EOS>
This
proposition
had
taken
Phineas
Finn
so
much
by
surprise
that
when
first
made
to
him
by
Barrington
Erle
it
took
his
breath
away
.
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
he
stand
for
Parliament
,
twenty
-
four
years
old
,
with
no
vestige
of
property
belonging
to
him
,
without
a
penny
in
his
purse
,
as
completely
dependent
on
his
father
as
he
was
when
he
first
went
to
school
at
eleven
years
of
age
!
<EOS>
And
for
Loughshane
,
a
little
borough
in
the
county
Galway
,
for
which
a
brother
of
that
fine
old
Irish
peer
,
the
Earl
of
Tulla
,
had
been
sitting
for
the
last
twenty
years
,
 
a
fine
,
high
-
minded
representative
of
the
thorough
-
going
Orange
Protestant
feeling
of
Ireland
!
<EOS>
And
the
Earl
of
Tulla
,
to
whom
almost
all
Loughshane
belonged
,
 
or
at
any
rate
the
land
about
Loughshane
,
 
was
one
of
his
father
's
staunchest
friends
!
<EOS>
Loughshane
is
in
county
Galway
,
but
the
Earl
of
Tulla
usually
lived
at
his
seat
in
county
Clare
,
not
more
than
ten
miles
from
Killaloe
,
and
always
confided
his
gouty
feet
,
and
the
weak
nerves
of
the
old
countess
,
and
the
stomachs
of
all
his
domestics
,
to
the
care
of
Dr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
How
was
it
possible
that
Phineas
should
stand
for
Loughshane
?
<EOS>
From
whence
was
the
money
to
come
for
such
a
contest
?
<EOS>
It
was
a
beautiful
dream
,
a
grand
idea
,
lifting
Phineas
almost
off
the
earth
by
its
glory
.
<EOS>
When
the
proposition
was
first
made
to
him
in
the
smoking
-
room
at
the
Reform
Club
by
his
friend
Erle
,
he
was
aware
that
he
blushed
like
a
girl
,
and
that
he
was
unable
at
the
moment
to
express
himself
plainly
,
 
so
great
<EOS>
was
his
astonishment
and
so
great
his
gratification
.
<EOS>
But
before
ten
minutes
had
passed
by
,
while
Barrington
Erle
was
still
sitting
over
his
shoulder
on
the
club
sofa
,
and
before
the
blushes
had
altogether
vanished
,
he
had
seen
the
improbability
of
the
scheme
,
and
had
explained
to
his
friend
that
the
thing
could
not
be
done
.
<EOS>
But
to
his
increased
astonishment
,
his
friend
made
nothing
of
the
difficulties
.
<EOS>
Loughshane
,
according
to
Barrington
Erle
,
was
so
small
a
place
,
that
the
expense
would
be
very
little
.
<EOS>
There
were
altogether
no
more
than
307
registered
electors
.
<EOS>
The
inhabitants
were
so
far
removed
from
the
world
,
and
were
so
ignorant
of
the
world
's
good
things
,
that
they
knew
nothing
about
bribery
.
<EOS>
The
Hon
.
<EOS>
George
Morris
,
who
had
sat
for
the
last
twenty
years
,
was
very
unpopular
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
near
the
borough
since
the
last
election
,
he
had
hardly
done
more
than
show
himself
in
Parliament
,
and
had
neither
given
a
shilling
in
the
town
nor
got
a
place
under
Government
for
a
single
son
of
Loughshane
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
has
quarrelled
with
his
brother
,
"
said
Barrington
Erle
.
<EOS>
"
The
devil
he
has
!
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
they
always
swore
by
each
other
.
"
<EOS>
"
It
's
at
each
other
they
swear
now
,
"
said
Barrington
;
<EOS>
"
George
has
asked
the
Earl
for
more
money
,
and
the
Earl
has
cut
up
rusty
.
<EOS>
"
Then
the
negotiator
went
on
to
explain
that
the
expenses
of
the
election
would
be
defrayed
out
of
a
certain
fund
collected
for
such
purposes
,
that
Loughshane
had
been
chosen
as
a
cheap
place
,
and
that
Phineas
Finn
had
been
chosen
as
a
safe
and
promising
young
man
.
<EOS>
As
for
qualification
,
if
any
question
were
raised
,
that
should
be
made
all
right
.
<EOS>
An
Irish
candidate
was
wanted
,
and
a
Roman
Catholic
.
<EOS>
So
much
the
Loughshaners
would
require
on
their
own
account
when
instigated
to
dismiss
from
their
service
that
thorough
-
going
Protestant
,
the
Hon
.
<EOS>
George
Morris
.
<EOS>
Then
"
the
party
,
"
 
by
which
Barrington
Erle
probably
meant
the
great
man
in
whose
service
he
himself
had
become
a
politician
,
 
required
that
the
candidate
should
be
a
safe
man
,
one
who
would
support
"
the
party
,
"
 
not
a
cantankerous
,
red
-
hot
semi
-
Fenian
,
running
about
to
meetings
at
the
Rotunda
,
and
such
-
like
,
with
views
of
his
own
about
tenant
-
right
and
the
Irish
Church
.
"
<EOS>
But
I
have
views
of
my
own
,
"
said
Phineas
,
blushing
again
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
you
have
,
my
dear
boy
,
"
said
Barrington
,
clapping
him
on
the
back
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
come
to
you
unless
you
had
views
.
<EOS>
But
your
views
and
ours
are
the
same
,
and
you
're
just
the
lad
for
Galway
.
<EOS>
You
might
n't
have
such
an
opening
again
in
your
life
,
and
of
course
you
'll
stand
for
Loughshane
.
<EOS>
"
Then
the
conversation
was
over
,
the
private
secretary
went
away
to
arrange
some
other
little
matter
of
the
kind
,
and
Phineas
Finn
was
left
alone
to
consider
the
proposition
that
had
been
made
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
To
become
a
member
of
the
British
Parliament
!
<EOS>
In
all
those
hot
contests
at
the
two
debating
clubs
to
which
he
had
belonged
,
this
had
been
the
ambition
which
had
moved
him
.
<EOS>
For
,
after
all
,
to
what
purpose
of
their
own
had
those
empty
debates
ever
tended
?
<EOS>
He
and
three
or
four
others
who
had
called
themselves
Liberals
had
been
pitted
against
four
or
five
who
had
called
themselves
Conservatives
,
and
night
after
night
they
had
discussed
some
ponderous
subject
without
any
idea
that
one
would
ever
persuade
another
,
or
that
their
talking
would
ever
conduce
to
any
action
or
to
any
result
.
<EOS>
But
each
of
these
combatants
had
felt
,
 
without
daring
to
announce
a
hope
on
the
subject
among
themselves
,
 
that
the
present
arena
was
only
a
trial
-
ground
for
some
possible
greater
amphitheatre
,
for
some
future
debating
club
in
which
debates
would
lead
to
action
,
and
in
which
eloquence
would
have
power
,
even
though
persuasion
might
be
out
of
the
question
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
certainly
had
never
dared
to
speak
,
even
to
himself
,
of
such
a
hope
.
<EOS>
The
labours
of
the
Bar
had
to
be
encountered
before
the
dawn
of
such
a
hope
could
come
to
him
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
gradually
learned
to
feel
that
his
prospects
at
the
Bar
were
not
as
yet
very
promising
.
<EOS>
As
regarded
professional
work
he
had
been
idle
,
and
how
then
could
he
have
a
hope
?
  
<EOS>
And
now
this
thing
,
which
he
regarded
as
being
of
all
things
in
the
world
the
most
honourable
,
had
come
to
him
all
at
once
,
and
was
possibly
within
his
reach
!
<EOS>
If
he
could
believe
Barrington
Erle
,
he
had
only
to
lift
up
his
hand
,
and
he
might
be
in
Parliament
within
two
months
.
<EOS>
And
who
was
to
be
believed
on
such
a
subject
<EOS>
if
not
Barrington
Erle
?
<EOS>
This
was
Erle
's
special
business
,
and
such
a
man
would
not
have
come
to
him
on
such
a
subject
<EOS>
had
he
not
been
in
earnest
,
and
had
he
not
himself
believed
in
success
.
<EOS>
There
was
an
opening
ready
,
an
opening
to
this
great
glory
,
 
if
only
it
might
be
possible
for
him
to
fill
it
!
  
<EOS>
What
would
his
father
say
?
<EOS>
His
father
would
of
course
oppose
the
plan
.
<EOS>
And
if
he
opposed
his
father
,
his
father
would
of
course
stop
his
income
.
<EOS>
And
such
an
income
as
it
was
!
<EOS>
Could
it
be
that
a
man
should
sit
in
Parliament
and
live
upon
a
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
a
year
?
<EOS>
Since
that
payment
of
his
debts
he
had
become
again
embarrassed
,
 
to
a
slight
amount
.
<EOS>
He
owed
a
tailor
a
trifle
,
and
a
bootmaker
a
trifle
,
 
and
something
to
the
man
who
sold
gloves
and
shirts
;
and
yet
he
had
done
his
best
to
keep
out
of
debt
with
more
than
Irish
pertinacity
,
living
very
closely
,
breakfasting
upon
tea
and
a
roll
,
and
dining
frequently
for
a
shilling
at
a
luncheon
-
house
up
a
court
near
Lincoln
's
Inn
.
<EOS>
Where
should
he
dine
if
the
Loughshaners
elected
him
to
Parliament
?
<EOS>
And
then
he
painted
to
himself
a
not
untrue
picture
of
the
probable
miseries
of
a
man
who
begins
life
too
high
up
on
the
ladder
,
 
who
succeeds
in
mounting
before
he
has
learned
how
to
hold
on
when
he
is
aloft
.
<EOS>
For
our
Phineas
Finn
was
a
young
man
not
without
sense
,
 
not
entirely
a
windbag
.
<EOS>
If
he
did
this
thing
the
probability
was
that
he
might
become
utterly
a
castaway
,
and
go
entirely
to
the
dogs
before
he
was
thirty
.
<EOS>
He
had
heard
of
penniless
men
who
had
got
into
Parliament
,
and
to
whom
had
come
such
a
fate
.
<EOS>
He
was
able
to
name
to
himself
a
man
or
two
<EOS>
whose
barks
,
carrying
more
sail
than
they
could
bear
,
had
gone
to
pieces
among
early
breakers
in
this
way
.
<EOS>
But
then
,
would
it
not
be
better
to
go
to
pieces
early
than
never
to
carry
any
sail
at
all
?
<EOS>
And
there
was
,
at
any
rate
,
the
chance
of
success
.
<EOS>
He
was
already
a
barrister
,
and
there
were
so
many
things
open
to
a
barrister
with
a
seat
in
Parliament
!
<EOS>
And
as
he
knew
of
men
who
had
been
utterly
ruined
by
such
early
mounting
,
so
also
did
he
know
of
others
whose
fortunes
had
been
made
by
happy
audacity
when
they
were
young
.
<EOS>
He
almost
thought
that
he
could
die
happy
if
he
had
once
taken
his
seat
in
Parliament
,
 
if
he
had
received
one
letter
with
those
grand
initials
written
after
his
name
on
the
address
.
<EOS>
Young
men
in
battle
are
called
upon
to
lead
forlorn
hopes
.
<EOS>
Three
fall
,
perhaps
,
to
one
who
gets
through
;
but
the
one
who
gets
through
will
have
the
Victoria
Cross
to
carry
for
the
rest
of
his
life
.
<EOS>
This
was
his
forlorn
hope
;
and
as
he
had
been
invited
to
undertake
the
work
,
he
would
not
turn
from
the
danger
.
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
he
again
saw
Barrington
Erle
by
appointment
,
and
then
wrote
the
following
letter
to
his
father
:
    
Reform
Club
,
Feb.
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
MY
DEAR
FATHER
,
  
I
am
afraid
that
the
purport
of
this
letter
will
startle
you
,
but
I
hope
that
when
you
have
finished
it
you
will
think
that
I
am
right
in
my
decision
as
to
what
I
am
going
to
do
.
<EOS>
You
are
no
doubt
aware
that
the
dissolution
of
Parliament
will
take
place
at
once
,
and
that
we
shall
be
in
all
the
turmoil
of
a
general
election
by
the
middle
of
March
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
invited
to
stand
for
Loughshane
,
and
have
consented
.
<EOS>
The
proposition
has
been
made
to
me
by
my
friend
Barrington
Erle
,
Mr.
Mildmay
's
private
secretary
,
and
has
been
made
on
behalf
of
the
Political
Committee
of
the
Reform
Club
.
<EOS>
I
need
hardly
say
that
I
should
not
have
thought
of
such
a
thing
with
a
less
thorough
promise
of
support
than
this
gives
me
,
nor
should
I
think
of
it
<EOS>
now
had
I
not
been
assured
that
none
of
the
expense
of
the
election
would
fall
upon
me
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
could
not
have
asked
you
to
pay
for
it
.
  
<EOS>
But
to
such
a
proposition
,
so
made
,
I
have
felt
that
it
would
be
cowardly
to
give
a
refusal
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
but
regard
such
a
selection
as
a
great
honour
.
<EOS>
I
own
that
I
am
fond
of
politics
,
and
have
taken
great
delight
in
their
study
  
(
"
Stupid
young
fool
!
"
<EOS>
his
father
said
to
himself
as
he
read
this
)
 
<EOS>
and
it
has
been
my
dream
for
years
past
to
have
a
seat
in
Parliament
at
some
future
time
.
<EOS>
(
"
Dream
!
<EOS>
yes
;
I
wonder
whether
he
has
ever
dreamed
what
he
is
to
live
upon
.
"
)
<EOS>
The
chance
has
now
come
to
me
much
earlier
than
I
have
looked
for
it
,
but
I
do
not
think
that
it
should
on
that
account
be
thrown
away
.
<EOS>
Looking
to
my
profession
,
I
find
that
many
things
are
open
to
a
barrister
with
a
seat
in
Parliament
,
and
that
the
House
need
not
interfere
much
with
a
man
's
practice
.
<EOS>
(
"
Not
if
he
has
got
to
the
top
of
his
tree
,
"
said
the
doctor
.
)
  
<EOS>
My
chief
doubt
arose
from
the
fact
of
your
old
friendship
with
Lord
Tulla
,
whose
brother
has
filled
the
seat
for
I
do
n't
know
how
many
years
.
<EOS>
But
it
seems
that
George
Morris
must
go
;
or
,
at
least
,
that
he
must
be
opposed
by
a
Liberal
candidate
.
<EOS>
If
I
do
not
stand
,
some
one
else
will
,
and
I
should
think
that
Lord
Tulla
will
be
too
much
of
a
man
to
make
any
personal
quarrel
on
such
a
subject
.
<EOS>
If
he
is
to
lose
the
borough
,
why
should
not
I
have
it
as
well
as
another
?
  
<EOS>
I
can
fancy
,
my
dear
father
,
all
that
you
will
say
as
to
my
imprudence
,
and
I
quite
confess
that
I
have
not
a
word
to
answer
.
<EOS>
I
have
told
myself
more
than
once
,
since
last
night
,
that
I
shall
probably
ruin
myself
.
<EOS>
(
"
I
wonder
whether
he
has
ever
told
himself
that
he
will
probably
ruin
me
also
,
"
said
the
doctor
.
)
<EOS>
But
I
am
prepared
to
ruin
myself
in
such
a
cause
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
one
dependent
on
me
;
and
,
as
long
as
I
do
nothing
to
disgrace
my
name
,
I
may
dispose
of
myself
as
I
please
.
<EOS>
If
you
decide
on
stopping
my
allowance
,
I
shall
have
no
feeling
of
anger
against
you
.
<EOS>
(
"
How
very
considerate
!
"
said
the
doctor
.
)
<EOS>
And
in
that
case
I
shall
endeavour
to
support
myself
by
my
pen
.
<EOS>
I
have
already
done
a
little
for
the
magazines
.
  
<EOS>
Give
my
best
love
to
my
mother
and
sisters
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
receive
me
during
the
time
of
the
election
,
I
shall
see
them
soon
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
will
be
best
for
me
to
say
that
I
have
positively
decided
on
making
the
attempt
;
that
is
to
say
,
if
the
Club
Committee
is
as
good
as
its
promise
.
<EOS>
I
have
weighed
the
matter
all
round
,
and
I
regard
the
prize
as
being
so
great
,
that
I
am
prepared
to
run
any
risk
to
obtain
it
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
to
me
,
with
my
views
about
politics
,
the
running
of
such
a
risk
is
no
more
than
a
duty
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
keep
my
hand
from
the
work
now
that
the
work
has
come
in
the
way
of
my
hand
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
most
anxious
to
get
a
line
from
you
in
answer
to
this
.
  
<EOS>
Your
most
affectionate
son
,
  
PHINEAS
FINN
.
  
<EOS>
I
question
whether
Dr.
Finn
,
when
he
read
this
letter
,
did
not
feel
more
of
pride
than
of
anger
,
 
whether
he
was
not
rather
gratified
than
displeased
,
in
spite
of
all
that
his
common
-
sense
told
him
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
His
wife
and
daughters
,
when
they
heard
the
news
,
were
clearly
on
the
side
of
the
young
man
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Finn
immediately
expressed
an
opinion
that
Parliament
would
be
the
making
of
her
son
,
and
that
everybody
would
be
sure
to
employ
<EOS>
so
distinguished
a
barrister
.
<EOS>
The
girls
declared
that
Phineas
ought
,
at
any
rate
,
to
have
his
chance
,
and
almost
asserted
that
it
would
be
brutal
in
their
father
to
stand
in
their
brother
's
way
.
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
that
the
doctor
tried
to
explain
that
going
into
Parliament
could
not
help
a
young
barrister
,
whatever
it
might
do
for
one
thoroughly
established
in
his
profession
;
that
Phineas
,
if
successful
at
Loughshane
,
would
at
once
abandon
all
idea
of
earning
any
income
,
 
that
the
proposition
,
coming
from
so
poor
a
man
,
was
a
monstrosity
,
 
that
such
an
opposition
to
the
Morris
family
,
coming
from
a
son
of
his
,
would
be
gross
ingratitude
to
Lord
Tulla
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Finn
and
the
girls
talked
him
down
,
and
the
doctor
himself
was
almost
carried
away
by
something
like
vanity
in
regard
to
his
son
's
future
position
.
  
<EOS>
Nevertheless
he
wrote
a
letter
strongly
advising
Phineas
to
abandon
the
project
.
<EOS>
But
he
himself
was
aware
that
the
letter
which
he
wrote
was
not
one
from
which
any
success
could
be
expected
.
<EOS>
He
advised
his
son
,
but
did
not
command
him
.
<EOS>
He
made
no
threats
as
to
stopping
his
income
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
tell
Phineas
,
in
so
many
words
,
that
he
was
proposing
to
make
an
ass
of
himself
.
<EOS>
He
argued
very
prudently
against
the
plan
,
and
Phineas
,
when
he
received
his
father
's
letter
,
of
course
felt
that
it
was
tantamount
to
a
paternal
permission
to
proceed
with
the
matter
.
<EOS>
On
the
next
day
he
got
a
letter
from
his
mother
full
of
affection
,
full
of
pride
,
 
not
exactly
telling
him
to
stand
for
Loughshane
by
all
means
,
for
Mrs.
Finn
was
not
the
woman
to
run
openly
counter
to
her
husband
in
any
advice
given
by
her
to
their
son
,
 
but
giving
him
every
encouragement
which
motherly
affection
and
motherly
pride
could
bestow
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
you
will
come
to
us
,
"
she
said
,
"
if
you
do
make
up
your
mind
to
be
member
for
Loughshane
.
<EOS>
We
shall
all
of
us
be
so
delighted
to
have
you
!
"
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
had
fallen
into
a
sea
of
doubt
after
writing
to

,
and

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
Is
Elected

Loughshane
 
<EOS>
One

about

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Barrington
Erle
turned
away
in

.
<EOS>
Such
language
was
to
him

.
<EOS>
It
fell
upon
his
ears
as
false
maudlin
sentiment
falls
on

ears
of
the
ordinary
honest
man
of
the
world
.
<EOS>
Barrington
Erle
was
a
man
ordinarily
honest
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
have
been
untrue
to
his
mother
's
brother
,
William
Mildmay
,
the
great
Whig
Minister
of
the
day
,
for
any
earthly

.
<EOS>
He
was
ready
to
work
with
wages
or
without
wages
.
<EOS>
He
was
really
zealous
in
the
cause
,
not
asking
very
much
for
himself
.
<EOS>
He
had
some
undefined
belief
that
it
was
much
better
for
the
country
that
Mr.
Mildmay
should
be
in

than
that
Lord
de
Terrier
should

there
.
<EOS>
He
was
convinced
that
Liberal
politics
were
good
for
Englishmen
,
and
that
Liberal
politics
and
the
Mildmay
party
were
one
and
the
same
thing
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
unfair
to
Barrington
Erle
to
deny
to
him
some
praise
for

.
<EOS>
But
he
hated
the
very
name
of
independence
in

,
and
when

was
told
of
any
man
,
that
that

to

to
measures
and
not
to
men
,
he
regarded
that
man
as
being
both
unstable
as
water
and
dishonest
as
the
wind
.
<EOS>
No
good
could
possibly
come
from
such
a
one
,
and
much
evil
might
and
probably
would
come
.
<EOS>
Such
a

was
a
Greek
to
Barrington
Erle
,
from
whose
hands
he
feared
to
accept
even
the
gift
of
a
vote
.
<EOS>
Parliamentary
hermits
were
distasteful
to
him
,
and
dwellers
in
political

were
regarded
by
him
with

as
being
either
knavish
or
impractical
.
<EOS>
With
a
good
Conservative
opponent
he
could

almost
as

as
with
a
good
Whig
ally
;
but
the
man
who
was
neither
flesh
nor
fowl
was
odious
to
him
.
<EOS>
According
to
his
theory
of
parliamentary
government
,
the
House
of
Commons
should
be
divided
by
a
marked
line
,
and
every

should
be

to

one

.
<EOS>
"
If
not

,

any

,
"

have
said

of
the
people
in

leader

.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
debates
were
good
,
because
of
the
people
outside
,
 
because

served
to

that

hereafter
to

;

,

,
as

result

;

,

.
<EOS>
A

's

,
 
except

,
 
was

.
<EOS>
Such

's

,

,

When

,

<EOS>
But

was

,

.
<EOS>

's

,

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
Phineas
went
to

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

.

"

,

"

.

,

.

.
<EOS>
The

Phineas
Finn
,
 
perhaps

,

<EOS>
There

,

Morris

.
<EOS>
In
the

,
our
hero
,
Phineas
Finn
,
had
been
duly

of
Parliament
for
the
borough
of
Loughshane
.
  
<EOS>
The
Finn
family
could
not
restrain
their
triumphings
at
Killaloe
,
and
I
do
not
know
that

would
have
been
natural
had

.
<EOS>
A
gosling
from
such
a
flock
does
become
something
of
a
real
swan
by
getting
into
Parliament
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
had
his
misgivings
,
 
had
great
misgivings
,
fearful
forebodings
;
but
there
was
the
young
man
elected
,
and
he
could
not
help
it
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
refuse
his
right
hand
to
his
son
or
withdraw

paternal

because
that

had
been
specially

.
<EOS>
So

pulled

what

to

,
 
<EOS>
they
were
not
heavy
,
 
and
undertook
to
allow
Phineas
two
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
a
year
as
long
as
the
session
should
last
.
  
<EOS>
There
was

Flood

,

.
<EOS>

,

Flood

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Flood
Jones
was

at
Killaloe
on

's
jointure
,
 
Floodborough
having
,

,

,
 
and

<EOS>
Mary

was

.
<EOS>
There

,

pretty

.

girl
,
to
see
me
off
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Everybody
was
up
to
see
him
off
in
the
morning
,
to
give
him
coffee
and
good
advice
,
and
kisses
,
and
to
throw
all
manner
of
old
shoes
after
him
as
he
started
on
his
great
expedition
to
Parliament
.
<EOS>
His
father
gave
him
an
extra
twenty
-
pound
note
,
and
begged
him
for
God
's
sake
to
be
careful
about
his
money
.
<EOS>
His
mother
told
him
always
to
have
an
orange
in
his
pocket
when
he
intended
to
speak
longer
than
usual
.
<EOS>
And
Barbara
in
a
last
whisper
begged
him
never
to
forget
dear
Mary
Flood
Jones
.
   
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
Takes
His
Seat
 
<EOS>
Phineas
had
many
serious
,
almost
solemn
thoughts
on
his
journey
towards
London
.
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
I
must
assure
my
female
readers
that
very
few
of
them
had
reference
to
Mary
Flood
Jones
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
however
,
very
carefully
packed
up
the
tress
,
and
could
bring
that
out
for
proper
acts
of
erotic
worship
at
seasons
in
which
his
mind
might
be
less
engaged
with
affairs
of
state
than
it
was
at
present
.
<EOS>
Would
he
make
a
failure
of
this
great
matter
which
he
had
taken
in
hand
?
<EOS>
He
could
not
but
tell
himself
that
the
chances
were
twenty
to
one
against
him
.
<EOS>
Now
that
he
looked
nearer
at
it
all
,
the
difficulties
loomed
larger
than
ever
,
and
the
rewards
seemed
to
be
less
,
more
difficult
of
approach
,
and
more
evanescent
.
<EOS>
How
many
members
were
there
who
could
never
get
a
hearing
!
<EOS>
How
many
who
only
spoke
to
fail
!
<EOS>
How
many
,
who
spoke
well
,
who
could
speak
to
no
effect
as
far
as
their
own
worldly
prospects
were
concerned
!
<EOS>
He
had
already
known
many
members
of
Parliament
to
whom
no
outward
respect
or
sign
of
honour
was
ever
given
by
any
one
;
and
it
seemed
to
him
,
as
he
thought
over
it
,
that
Irish
members
of
Parliament
were
generally
treated
with
more
indifference
than
any
others
.
<EOS>
There
were
O'B---
and
O'C---
and
O'D
 
,
for
whom
no
one
cared
a
straw
,
who
could
hardly
get
men
to
dine
with
them
at
the
club
,
and
yet
they
were
genuine
members
of
Parliament
.
<EOS>
Why
should
he
ever
be
better
than
O'B
 
,
or
O'C
 
,
or
O'D
 
?
<EOS>
And
in
what
way
should
he
begin
to
be
better
?
<EOS>
He
had
an
idea
of
the
fashion
after
which
it
would
be
his
duty
to
strive
that
he
might
excel
those
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
give
any
of
them
credit
for
much
earnestness
in
their
country
's
behalf
,
and
he
was
minded
to
be
very
earnest
.
<EOS>
He
would
go
to
his
work
honestly
and
conscientiously
,
determined
to
do
his
duty
as
best
he
might
,
let
the
results
to
himself
be
what
they
would
.
<EOS>
This
was
a
noble
resolution
,
and
might
have
been
pleasant
to
him
,
 
had
he
not
remembered
that
smile
of
derision
which
had
come
over
his
friend
Erle
's
face
when
he
declared
his
intention
of
doing
his
duty
to
his
country
as
a
Liberal
,
and
not
of
supporting
a
party
.
<EOS>
O'B---
and
O'C---
and
O'D---
were
keen
enough
to
support
their
party
,
only
they
were
sometimes
a
little
astray
at
knowing
which
was
their
party
for
the
nonce
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
Erle
and
such
men
would
despise
him
if
he
did
not
fall
into
the
regular
groove
,
 
and
if
the
Barrington
Erles
despised
him
,
what
would
then
be
left
for
him
?
  
<EOS>
His
moody
thoughts
were
somewhat
dissipated
when
he
found
one
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
,
 
the
Honourable
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
,
 
a
special
friend
of
his
own
,
and
a
very
clever
fellow
,
on
board
the
boat
as
it
steamed
out
of
Kingston
harbour
.
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
had
also
just
been
over
about
his
election
,
and
had
been
returned
as
a
matter
of
course
for
his
father
's
county
.
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
had
sat
in
the
House
for
the
last
fifteen
years
,
and
was
yet
well
-
nigh
as
young
a
man
as
any
in
it
.
<EOS>
And
he
was
a
man
altogether
different
from
the
O'B
 
s
,
O'C
 
s
,
and
O'D
 
s.
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
could
always
get
the
ear
of
the
House
if
he
chose
to
speak
,
and
his
friends
declared
that
he
might
have
been
high
up
in
office
long
since
if
he
would
have
taken
the
trouble
to
work
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
welcome
guest
at
the
houses
of
the
very
best
people
,
and
was
a
friend
of
whom
any
one
might
be
proud
.
<EOS>
It
had
for
two
years
been
a
feather
in
the
cap
of
Phineas
that
he
knew
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
And
yet
people
said
that
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
had
nothing
of
his
own
,
and
men
wondered
how
he
lived
.
<EOS>
He
was
the
youngest
son
of
Lord
Claddagh
,
an
Irish
peer
with
a
large
family
,
who
could
do
nothing
for
Laurence
,
his
favourite
child
,
beyond
finding
him
a
seat
in
Parliament
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Finn
,
my
boy
,
"
said
Laurence
,
shaking
hands
with
the
young
member
on
board
the
steamer
,
"
<EOS>
so
you
've
made
it
all
right
at
Loughshane
.
<EOS>
"
Then
Phineas
was
beginning
to
tell
all
the
story
,
the
wonderful
story
,
of
George
Morris
and
the
Earl
of
Tulla
,
 
how
the
men
of
Loughshane
had
elected
him
without
opposition
;
how
he
had
been
supported
by
Conservatives
as
well
as
Liberals
;
 
how
unanimous
Loughshane
had
been
in
electing
him
,
Phineas
Finn
,
as
its
representative
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Fitzgibbon
seemed
to
care
very
little
about
all
this
,
and
went
so
far
as
to
declare
that
those
things
were
accidents
which
fell
out
sometimes
one
way
and
sometimes
another
,
and
were
altogether
independent
of
any
merit
or
demerit
on
the
part
of
the
candidate
himself
.
<EOS>
And
it
was
marvellous
and
almost
painful
to
Phineas
that
his
friend
Fitzgibbon
should
accept
the
fact
of
his
membership
with
so
little
of
congratulation
,
 
with
absolutely
no
blowing
of
trumpets
<EOS>
whatever
.
<EOS>
Had
he
been
elected
a
member
of
the
municipal
corporation
of
Loughshane
,
instead
of
its
representative
in
the
British
Parliament
,
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
could
not
have
made
less
fuss
about
it
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
disappointed
,
but
he
took
the
cue
from
his
friend
too
quickly
to
show
his
disappointment
.
<EOS>
And
when
,
half
an
hour
after
their
meeting
,
Fitzgibbon
had
to
be
reminded
that
his
companion
was
not
in
the
House
during
the
last
session
,
Phineas
was
able
to
make
the
remark
as
though
he
thought
as
little
about
the
House
as
did
the
old
-
accustomed
member
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
As
far
as
I
can
see
as
yet
,
"
said
Fitzgibbon
,
"
we
are
sure
to
have
seventeen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Seventeen
?
"
said
Phineas
,
not
quite
understanding
the
meaning
of
the
number
quoted
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
majority
of
seventeen
.
<EOS>
There
are
four
Irish
counties
and
three
Scotch
which
have
n't
returned
as
yet
;
but
we
know
pretty
well
what
they
'll
do
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
doubt
about
Tipperary
,
of
course
,
but
whichever
gets
in
of
the
seven
who
are
standing
,
it
will
be
a
vote
on
our
side
.
<EOS>
Now
the
Government
ca
n't
live
against
that
.
<EOS>
The
uphill
strain
is
too
much
for
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
According
to
my
idea
,
nothing
can
justify
them
in
trying
to
live
against
a
majority
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
gammon
.
<EOS>
When
the
thing
is
so
equal
,
anything
is
fair
.
<EOS>
But
you
see
they
do
n't
like
it
.
<EOS>
Of
course
there
are
some
among
them
as
hungry
as
we
are
;
and
Dubby
would
give
his
toes
and
fingers
to
remain
in
.
<EOS>
"
Dubby
was
the
ordinary
name
by
which
,
among
friends
and
foes
,
Mr.
Daubeny
was
known
:
Mr.
Daubeny
,
who
at
that
time
was
the
leader
of
the
Conservative
party
in
the
House
of
Commons
.
"
<EOS>
But
most
of
them
,
"
continued
Mr.
Fitzgibbon
,
"
prefer
the
other
game
,
and
if
you
do
n't
care
about
money
,
upon
my
word
<EOS>
it
's
the
pleasanter
game
of
the
two
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
the
country
gets
nothing
done
by
a
Tory
Government
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
to
that
,
it
's
six
of
one
and
half
a
dozen
of
the
other
.
<EOS>
I
never
knew
a
government
yet
that
wanted
to
do
anything
.
<EOS>
Give
a
government
a
real
strong
majority
,
as
the
Tories
used
to
have
half
a
century
since
,
and
as
a
matter
of
course
it
will
do
nothing
.
<EOS>
Why
should
it
?
<EOS>
Doing
things
,
as
you
call
it
,
is
only
bidding
for
power
,
 
for
patronage
and
pay
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
is
the
country
to
have
no
service
done
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
country
gets
quite
as
much
service
as
it
pays
for
,
 
and
perhaps
a
little
more
.
<EOS>
The
clerks
in
the
offices
work
for
the
country
.
<EOS>
And
the
Ministers
work
too
,
if
they
've
got
anything
to
manage
.
<EOS>
There
is
plenty
of
work
done
;
 
but
of
work
in
Parliament
,
the
less
the
better
,
according
to
my
ideas
.
<EOS>
It
's
very
little
that
ever
is
done
,
and
that
little
is
generally
too
much
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
the
people
 
"
  
"
Come
down
and
have
a
glass
of
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
and
leave
the
people
alone
for
the
present
.
<EOS>
The
people
can
take
care
of
themselves
a
great
deal
better
than
we
can
take
care
of
them
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Fitzgibbon
's
doctrine
as
to
the
commonwealth
was
very
different
from
that
of
Barrington
Erle
,
and
was
still
less
to
the
taste
of
the
new
member
.
<EOS>
Barrington
Erle
considered
that
his
leader
,
Mr.
Mildmay
,
should
be
intrusted
to
make
all
necessary
changes
in
the
laws
,
and
that
an
obedient
House
of
Commons
should
implicitly
obey
that
leader
in
authorising
all
changes
proposed
by
him
;
 
but
according
to
Barrington
Erle
,
such
changes
should
be
numerous
and
of
great
importance
,
and
would
,
if
duly
passed
into
law
at
his

's

,
gradually
produce
such
a
Whig
Utopia
in
England
as
has
never
yet
been
seen
on
the
face
of
the
earth
.
<EOS>
Now
,
according
to
Mr.
Fitzgibbon
,
the
present
Utopia
would
be
good
enough
,
 
if
only
he
himself
might
be
once
more
put
into

of
a
certain
semi
-
political
place
about
the
Court
,
from
which
he
had
heretofore
drawn
£
1,000
per
annum
,
without
any
work
,
much
to
his
comfort
.
<EOS>
He
made
no
secret
of
his
ambition
,
and
was
chagrined
simply
at
the
prospect
of
having
to
return
to
his
electors
before
he
could

those

things
which
he

from
the
undoubted
majority
of
seventeen
,
which
had
been
,
or
would
be
,
achieved
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hate
all
change
as
a
rule
,
"
said
Fitzgibbon
;
"
but
,
upon
my
word
,
we
ought
to
alter
that
.
<EOS>
When
a
fellow
has
got
a
crumb
of
comfort
,
after
waiting
for
it
years
and
years
,
and
perhaps
spending
thousands
in

,
he
has
to
go
back
and
try
his
hand
again
at
the
last
moment
,
merely
in
obedience
to
some
antiquated
prejudice
.
<EOS>
Look
at
poor
Jack
Bond
,
 
the
best
friend
I
ever
had
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
He
was
wrecked
upon
that
rock
for
ever
.
<EOS>
He
spent
every

he
had
in
contesting
Romford
three
times
running
,
 
and
three
times
running
<EOS>
he
got
in
.
<EOS>
Then

Vice
-

,

I
'm
shot
if
he
did
n't

spilt
at
Romford
on
standing

his
re
-
election
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what

of

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
God
knows
.
<EOS>
I
think

heard

married

old
woman

settled
down

.
<EOS>
I
know

never
came

again
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
call

.
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
'm
safe
down
in
Mayo
,
but
there
's
no

what
may

in
these
days
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
they

at
Euston

,

asked
his
friend
some
little

as
to
the

.
<EOS>
Would
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
see
him

the

of
the
oath
-

?
<EOS>
But
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
made
very
little

.
<EOS>
"
Oh
;
 
you
just
come
down
,

,

.
<EOS>
You

an

,

'll

through
.
<EOS>
There
is
n't
time
for
much

after
a

.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
reached
London
early
in
the
morning
,
and
went
home
to
bed
for
an
hour
or
so
.
<EOS>
The
House
was
to
meet
on
that
very
day
,
and
he
intended
to
begin
his
parliamentary
duties
at
once
if
he
should

possible
to
get
some
one
to
accompany
him
;
He
felt
that
he
should
lack
courage
to
go
down
to
Westminster
Hall
alone
,
and
explain
to
the
policeman
and
door
-
keepers
that
he

the
man
who
had
just

elected
member
for
Loughshane
.
<EOS>
So
about
noon
he
went
into
the
Reform
Club
,
and
there
he
found
a
great
crowd
of
men
,
among
whom
there
was
a
plentiful
sprinkling
of
members
.
<EOS>
Erle
saw
him
in
a
moment
,
and
came
to
him
with
congratulations
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
you
're
all
right
,
Finn
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
I
'm
all
right
,
 
I
did
n't
have
much
doubt
about
it
when
I
went
over
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
heard
of
a
fellow
with
such
a
run
of
luck
,
"
said
Erle
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
just
one
of
those
flukes
that
occur
once
in
a
dozen
elections
.
<EOS>
Any
one
on
earth
might
have
got
in
without
spending
a
shilling
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
did
n't
at
all
like
this
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
any
one
could
have
got
in
,
"
said
he
,
"
without
knowing
Lord
Tulla
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Lord
Tulla
was
nowhere
,
my
dear
boy
,
and
could
have
nothing
to
say
to
it
.
<EOS>
But
never
mind
that
.
<EOS>
You
meet
me
in
the
lobby
at
two
.
<EOS>
There
'll
be
a
lot
of
us
there
,
and
we
'll
go
in
together
.
<EOS>
Have
you
seen
Fitzgibbon
?
"
<EOS>
Then
Barrington
Erle
went
off
to
other
business
,
and
Finn
was
congratulated
by
other
men
.
<EOS>
But
it
seemed
to
him
that
the
congratulations
of
his
friends
were
not
hearty
.
<EOS>
He
spoke
to
some
men
,
of
whom
he
thought
that
he
knew
they
would
have
given
their

to
be
in
Parliament
;
 
and
yet
they
spoke
of
his
success
as
being
a
very
ordinary
thing
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
my
boy
,
I
hope
you
like
it
,
"
said
one
middle
-
aged
gentleman
whom
he
had
known
ever
since
he
came
up
to
London
.
<EOS>
"
The
difference
is
between
working
for
nothing
and
working
for
money
.
<EOS>
You
'll
have
to
work
for
nothing
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
about
it
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
say
the
House
is
a
comfortable
club
,
"
said
the
middle
-
aged
friend
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
confess
that
I
should
n't
like
being
rung
away
from
my
dinner
myself
.
"
  
<EOS>
At
two
punctually
Phineas
was
in
the
lobby
at
Westminster
,
and
then
he
found
himself
taken
into
the
House
with
a
crowd
of
other
men
.
<EOS>
The
old
and
young
,
and
they
who
were
neither
old
nor
young
,
were
mingled
together
,
and
there
seemed
to
be
very
little
respect
of
persons
.
<EOS>
On
three
or
four
occasions
there
was
some
cheering
when
a
popular
man
or
a
great
leader
came
in
;
but
the
work
of
the
day
left
but
little
clear
impression
on
the
mind
of
the
young
member
.
<EOS>
He
was
confused
,
half
elated
,
half
disappointed
,
and
had
not
his
wits
about
him
.
<EOS>
He
found
himself
constantly
regretting
that
he
was
there
;
and
as
constantly
telling
himself
that
he
,
hardly
yet
twenty
-
five
,
without
a
shilling
of
his
own
,
had
achieved
an
entrance
into
that
assembly
which
by
the
consent
of
all
men
is
the
greatest
in
the
world
,
and
which
many
of
the
rich
magnates
of
the
country
had
in
vain
spent
heaps
of
treasure
in
their
endeavours
to
open
to
their
own
footsteps
.
<EOS>
He
tried
hard
to
realise
what
he
had
gained
,
but
the
dust
and
the
noise
and
the
crowds
and
the
want
of
something
august
to
the
eye
were
almost
too
strong
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
managed
,
however
,
to
take
the
oath
early
among
those
who
took
it
,
and
heard
the
Queen
's
speech
read
and
the
Address
moved
and
seconded
.
<EOS>
He
was
seated
very
uncomfortably
,
high
up
on
a
back
seat
,
between
two
men
whom
he
did
not
know
;
and
he
found
the
speeches
to
be
very
long
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
in
the
habit
of
seeing
such
speeches
reported
in
about
a
column
,
and
he
thought
that
these
speeches
must
take
at
least
four
columns
each
.
<EOS>
He
sat
out
the
debate
on
the
Address
till
the
House
was
adjourned
,
and
then
he
went
away
to
dine
at
his
club
.
<EOS>
He
did
go
into
the
dining
-
room
of
the
House
,
but
there
was
a
crowd
there
,
and
he
found
himself
alone
,
 
and
to
tell
the
truth
,
he
was
afraid
to
order
his
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
The
nearest
approach
to
a
triumph
which
he
had
in
London
came
to
him
from
the
glory
which
his
election
reflected
upon
his
landlady
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
kindly
good
motherly
soul
,
whose
husband
was
a
journeyman
law
-
stationer
,
and
who
kept
a
very
decent
house
in
Great
Marlborough
Street
.
<EOS>
Here
Phineas
had
lodged
since
he
had
been
in
London
,
and
was
a
great
favourite
.
<EOS>
"
God
bless
my
soul
,
Mr.
Phineas
,
"
said
she
,
"
only
think
of
your
being
a
member
of
Parliament
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
'm
a
member
of
Parliament
,
Mrs.
Bunce
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
'll
go
on
with
the
rooms
the
same
as

?
<EOS>
Well
,
I
never
thought
to
have
a
member
of
Parliament
in
'
em
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bunce
really
had
realised
the
magnitude
of
the
step
which
her
lodger
had
taken
,
and
Phineas
was
grateful
to
her
.
   
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
Standish
 
Phineas
,
in
describing
Lady
Laura
Standish
to
Mary
Flood
Jones
at
Killaloe
,
had
not
painted
her
in
very
glowing
colours
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
he
admired
Lady
Laura
very
much
,
and
she
was
worthy
of
admiration
.
<EOS>
It
was
probably
the
greatest
pride
of
our
hero
's
life
that
Lady
Laura
Standish
was
his
friend
,
and
that
she
had
instigated
him
to
undertake
the
risk
of
parliamentary
life
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
was
intimate
also
with
Barrington
Erle
,
who
was
,
in
some
distant
degree
,
her
cousin
;
and
Phineas
was
not
without
a
suspicion
that
his
selection
for
Loughshane
,
from
out
of
all
the
young
liberal
candidates
,
may
have
been
in
some
degree
owing
to
Lady
Laura
's
influence
with
Barrington
Erle
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
unwilling
that
it
should
be
so
;
for
though
,
as
he
had
repeatedly
told
himself
,
he
was
by
no
means
in
love
with
Lady
Laura
,
 
who
was
,
as
he
imagined
,
somewhat
older
than
himself
,
 
nevertheless
,
he
would
feel
gratified
at
accepting
anything
from
her
hands
,
and
he
felt
a
keen
desire
for
some
increase
to
those
ties
of
friendship
which
bound
them
together
.
<EOS>
No
;
 
he
was
not
in
love
with
Lady
Laura
Standish
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
the
remotest
idea
of
asking
her
to
be
his
wife
.
<EOS>
So
he
told
himself
,
both
before
he
went
over
for
his
election
,
and
after
his
return
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
found
himself
in
a
corner
with
poor
little
Mary
Flood
Jones
,
he
had
kissed
her
as
a
matter
of
course
;
but
he
did
not
think
that
he
could
,
in
any
circumstances
,
be
tempted
to
kiss
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
He
supposed
that
he
was
in
love
with
his
darling
little
Mary
,
 
after
a
fashion
.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
it
could
never
come
to
anything
,
because
of
the
circumstances
of
his
life
,
which
were
so
imperious
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
in
love
with
Lady
Laura
,
and
yet
he
hoped
that
his
intimacy
with
her
might
come
to
much
.
<EOS>
He
had
more
than
once
asked
himself
how
he
would
feel
when
somebody
else
came
to
be
really
in
love
with
Lady
Laura
,
 
for
she
was
by
no
means
a
woman
to
lack
lovers
,
 
when
some
one
else
should
be
in
love
with
her
,
and
be
received
by
her
as
a
lover
;
but
this
question
he
had
never
been
able
to
answer
.
<EOS>
There
were
many
questions
about
himself
which
he
usually
answered
by
telling
himself
that
it
was
his
fate
to
walk
over
volcanoes
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
I
shall
be
blown
into
atoms
some
fine
day
,
"
he
would
say
;
"
but
after
all
,
that
is
better
than
being
slowly
boiled
down
into
pulp
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
House
had
met
on
a
Friday
,
again
on
the
Saturday
morning
,
and
the
debate
on
the
Address
had
been
adjourned
till
the
Monday
.
<EOS>
On
the
Sunday
,
Phineas
determined
that
he
would
see
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
She
professed
to
be
always
at
home
on
Sunday
,
and
from
three
to
four
in
the
afternoon
her
drawing
-
room
would
probably
be
half
full
of
people
.
<EOS>
There
would
,
at
any
rate
,
be
comers
and
goers
,
who
would
prevent
anything
like
real
conversation
between
himself
and
her
.
<EOS>
But
for
a
few
minutes
before
that
he
might
probably
find
her
alone
,
and
he
was
most
anxious
to
see
whether
her
reception
of
him
,
as
a
member
of
Parliament
,
would
be
in
any
degree
warmer
than
that
of
his
other
friends
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
he
had
found
no
such
warmth
since
he
came
to
London
,
excepting
that
which
had
glowed
in
the
bosom
of
Mrs.
Bunce
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
Standish
was
the
daughter
of
the
Earl
of
Brentford
,
and
was
the
only
remaining
lady
of
the
Earl
's
family
.
<EOS>
The
Countess
had
been
long
dead
;
and
Lady
Emily
,
the
younger
daughter
,
who
had
been
the
great
beauty
of
her
day
,
was
now
the
wife
of
a
Russian
nobleman
whom
she
had
persisted
in
preferring
to
any
of
her
English
suitors
,
and
lived
at
St.
Petersburg
.
<EOS>
There
was
an
aunt
,
old
Lady
Laura
,
who
came
up
to
town
about
the
middle
of
May
;
but
she
was
always
in
the
country
except
for
some
six
weeks
in
the
season
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
certain
Lord
Chiltern
,
the
Earl
's
son
and
heir
,
who
did
indeed
live
at
the
family
town
house
in
Portman
Square
;
but
Lord
Chiltern
was
a
man
of
whom
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
's
set
did
not
often
speak
,
and
Phineas
,
frequently
as
he
had
been
at
the
house
,
had
never
seen
Lord
Chiltern
there
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
young
nobleman
of
whom
various
accounts
were
given
by
various
people
;
but
I
fear
that
the
account
most
readily
accepted
in
London
attributed
to
him
a
great
intimacy
with
the
affairs
at
Newmarket
,
and
a
partiality
for
convivial
pleasures
.
<EOS>
Respecting
Lord
Chiltern
Phineas
had
never
as
yet
exchanged
a
word
with
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
With
her
father
he
was
acquainted
,
as
he
had
dined
perhaps
half
a
dozen
times
at
the
house
.
<EOS>
The
point
in
Lord
Brentford
's
character
which
had
more
than
any
other
struck
our
hero
,
was
the
unlimited
confidence
which
he
seemed
to
place
in
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
seemed
to
have
perfect
power
of
doing
what
she
pleased
.
<EOS>
She
was
much
more
mistress
of
herself
than
if
she
had
been
the
wife
instead
of
the
daughter
of
the
Earl
of
Brentford
,
 
and
she
seemed
to
be
quite
as
much
mistress
of
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
had
declared
at
Killaloe
that
Lady
Laura
was
six
feet
high
,
that
she
had
red
hair
,
that
her
figure
was
straggling
,
and
that
her
hands
and
feet
were
large
.
<EOS>
She
was
in
fact
about
five
feet
seven
in
height
,
and
she
carried
her
height
well
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
of
nobility
in
her
gait
,
and
she
seemed
thus
to
be
taller
than
her
inches
.
<EOS>
Her
hair
was
in
truth
red
,
 
of
a
deep
thorough
redness
.
<EOS>
Her
brother
's
hair
was
the
same
;
and
so
had
been
that
of
her
father
,
before
it
had
become
sandy
with
age
.
<EOS>
Her
sister
's
had
been
of
a
soft
auburn
hue
,
and
hers
had
been
said
to
be
the
prettiest
head
of
hair
in
Europe
at
the
time
of
her
marriage
.
<EOS>
But
in
these
days
we
have
got
to
like
red
hair
,
and
Lady
Laura
's
was
not
supposed
to
stand
in
the
way
of
her
being
considered
a
beauty
.
<EOS>
Her
face
was
very
fair
,
though
it
lacked
that
softness
which
we
all
love
in
women
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
,
which
were
large
and
bright
,
and
very
clear
,
never
seemed
to
quail
,
never
rose
and
sunk
or
showed
themselves
to
be
afraid
of
their
own
power
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
Lady
Laura
Standish
had
nothing
of
fear
about
her
.
<EOS>
Her
nose
was
perfectly
cut
,
but
was
rather
large
,
having
the
slightest
possible
tendency
to
be
aquiline
.
<EOS>
Her
mouth
also
was
large
,
but
was
full
of
expression
,
and
her
teeth
were
perfect
.
<EOS>
Her
complexion
was
very
bright
,
but
in
spite
of
its
brightness
she
never
blushed
.
<EOS>
The
shades
of
her
complexion
were
set
and
steady
.
<EOS>
Those
who
knew
her
said
that
her
heart
was
so
fully
under
command
that
nothing
could
stir
her
blood
to
any
sudden
motion
.
<EOS>
As
to
that
accusation
of
straggling
which
had
been
made
against
her
,
it
had
sprung
from
ill
-
natured
observation
of
her
modes
of
sitting
.
<EOS>
She
never
straggled
when
she
stood
or
walked
;
but
she
would
lean
forward
when
sitting
,
as
a
man
does
,
and
would
use
her
arms
in
talking
,
and
would
put
her
hand
over
her
face
,
and
pass
her
fingers
through
her
hair
,
 
after
the
fashion
of
men
rather
than
of
women
;
 
and
she
seemed
to
despise
that
soft
quiescence
of
her
sex
in
which
are
generally
found
so
many
charms
.
<EOS>
Her
hands
and
feet
were
large
,
 
as
was
her
whole
frame
.
<EOS>
Such
was
Lady
Laura
Standish
;
and
Phineas
Finn
had
been
untrue
to
himself
and
to
his
own
appreciation
of
the
lady
when
he
had
described
her
in
disparaging
terms
to
Mary
Flood
Jones
.
<EOS>
But
,
though
he
had
spoken
of
Lady
Laura
in

,
he
had
so
spoken
of
her
as
to
make
Miss
Flood
Jones
quite
understand
that
he
thought
a
great
deal
about
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
,
early
on
the
Sunday
,
he
made
his
way
to
Portman
Square
in
order
that
he
might
learn
whether
there
might
be
any

for
him
there
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
he
had
found
none
.
<EOS>
Everything
had
been
terribly
dry
and
hard
,
and
he
had
gathered
as
yet
none
of
the
fruit
which
he
had
expected
that
his
good
fortune
would
bear
for
him
.
<EOS>
It
is
true
that
he
had
not
as
yet
gone
among
any
friends
,
except
those
of
his
club
,
and
men
who
were
in
the
House
along

;
 
and
at
the
club
it
might
be
that
there
were
some

envied
him
his

,
and
others
who
thought
nothing

it
because
it
had
been
theirs
for
years
.
<EOS>
Now
he
would
try
a
friend
who
,
he

,
could
sympathise
;
and
therefore
he
called
in
Portman
Square
at
about
half
-
past
two
on
the

.
<EOS>
Yes
,
 
Lady
Laura
was
in
the
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
The
hall
-
porter
admitted
as
much
,
but
evidently
seemed
to
think
that
he
had
been
disturbed
from
his

before
his
time
.
<EOS>
Phineas
did
not
care
a
straw
for
the
hall
-
porter
.
<EOS>
If
Lady
Laura
were
not
kind
to
him
,
he
would
never
trouble
that
hall
-
porter
again
.
<EOS>
He
was
especially
sore
at
this
moment
because
a
valued

,
the
barrister
with
whom
he
had
been
reading
for
the

three

,

best

an
hour
that

in
proving
to

that
he
had
as
good
as
ruined

.
<EOS>
"
When
I
first

,

,
"
said

Low
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
inherited
nothing
,
"
Phineas

;
 
"
not
a

;
and
I
never
shall
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Low
had
opened

,
and

,
and
had

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so

,

Finn

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Thanks
,
"

<EOS>
"
I
thought
that

would

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
Faint

,

.
<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

.
<EOS>
It

"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Papa

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
There

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

Not

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

;

<EOS>
Mr.

<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
As

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But

"

<EOS>
"
Do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
I

,
 
or
,

,

.
<EOS>
Supposing

,

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
With

.
<EOS>
With

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
shall

.
"
  
<EOS>
At

room

,
and

man

with

,
came
a

yards

,
and
then

,

.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
with

,
and
an

of
very

.
<EOS>
And
his

was
red
,
 
and
,
as

seemed
to

,
his
very
eyes
.
<EOS>
There

something
in
the

of
the
man
which
struck

almost
with
dread
,
 
something
approaching
to
ferocity
.
  
<EOS>
There
was

pause
a

after

,
and

Laura

.
<EOS>
"
It
was
my
brother
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
that
you
have
ever

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Low
 
<EOS>
That
terrible
apparition
of

red
Lord
Chiltern
had
disturbed

in
the

of
his

as

kind

of
Lady

;
and

had

,

of

.
<EOS>
Lady

had
said
some
word
about
her
brother
,
and

had
replied
that
he
had
never

see
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
Then

had

an

,
and
almost

other

had

.
<EOS>
After

,

Fitzgibbon

,

.
"
<EOS>
Miss
Fitzgibbon
is

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
says

wo

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I
wish

who

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
Phineas
cared
very
little
what
Miss
Fitzgibbon
said
to

.
<EOS>
Everybody
knew
Aspasia
Fitzgibbon
,
and
all
who
knew
her
were
accustomed
to
put
up
with
the
violence
of
her
jokes
and
the
bitterness
of

.
<EOS>
She
was
an
old
maid
,
over
forty
,
very
plain
,
who
,
having
reconciled
herself
to
the
fact
that
she
was
an
old
maid
,
chose
to
take
advantage
of
such
poor
privileges
as
the
position
gave
her
.
<EOS>
Within
the
last
few
years
a
considerable
fortune
had
fallen
into
her
hands
,
some
twenty
-
five
thousand
pounds
,
which
had
come
to
her
unexpectedly
,
 
a
wonderful
windfall
.
<EOS>
And
now
she
was
the
only
one
of
her
family
who
had
money
at
command
.
<EOS>
She
lived
in
a
small
house
by

,
in
one
of
the
smallest
streets
of
May
Fair
,
and
walked
about
sturdily
by
herself
,
and
spoke
her
mind
about
everything
.
<EOS>
She
was
greatly
devoted
to
her
brother
Laurence
,
 
so
devoted
that
there
was
nothing
she
would
not
do
for
him
,
short
of
lending
him
money
.
  
<EOS>
But
Phineas
when
he
found
himself
out
in
the
square
thought
nothing
of
Aspasia
Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
He
had
gone
to
Lady
Laura
Standish
for
sympathy
,
and
she
had
given
it
to
him
in
full
measure
.
<EOS>
She
understood
him
and
his
aspirations
if
no
one
else
did
so
on
the
face
of
the
earth
.
<EOS>
She
rejoiced
in
his
triumph
,
and
was
not
too
hard
to
tell
him
that
she
looked
forward
to
his
success
.
<EOS>
And
in
what
delightful
language
she
had
done
so
!
"
<EOS>
Faint
heart
never
won
fair
lady
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
thus
,
or
almost
thus
,
that
she
had
encouraged
him
.
<EOS>
He
knew
well
that
she
had
in
truth
meant
nothing
more
than
her
words
had
seemed
to
signify
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
for
a
moment
attribute
to
her
aught
else
.
<EOS>
But
might
not
he
get
another
lesson
from
them
?
<EOS>
He
had
often
told
himself
that
he
was
not
in
love
with
Laura
Standish
;
 
but
why
should
he
not
how
tell
himself
that
he
was
in
love
with
her
?
<EOS>
Of
course
there
would
be
difficulty
.
<EOS>
But
was
it
not
the
business
of
his
life
to
overcome
difficulties
?
<EOS>
Had
he
not
already
overcome
one
difficulty
almost
as
great
;
and
why
should
he
be
afraid
of
this
other
?
<EOS>
Faint
heart
never
won
fair
lady
!
<EOS>
And
this
fair
lady
,
 
for
at
this
moment
he
was
ready
to
swear
that
she
was
very
fair
,
 
was
already
half
won
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
have
taken
him
by
the
hand
so
warmly
,
and
looked
into
his
face
so
keenly
,
had
she
not
felt
for
him
something
stronger
than
common
friendship
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
turned
down
Baker
Street
from
the
square
,
and
was
now
walking
towards
the
Regent
's
Park
.
<EOS>
He
would
go
and
see
the
beasts
in
the
Zoological
Gardens
,
and
make
up
his
mind
as
to
his
future
mode
of
life
in
that
delightful
Sunday
solitude
.
<EOS>
There
was
very
much
as
to
which
it
was
necessary
that
he
should
make
up
his
mind
.
<EOS>
If
he
resolved
that
he
would
ask
Lady
Laura
Standish
to
be
his
wife
,
when
should
he
ask
her
,
and
in
what
manner
might
he
propose
to
her
that
they
should
live
?
<EOS>
It
would
hardly
suit
him
to
postpone
his
courtship
indefinitely
,
knowing
,
as
he
did
know
,
that
he
would
be
one
among
many
suitors
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
expect
her
to
wait
for
him
if
he
did
not
declare
himself
.
<EOS>
And
yet
he
could
hardly
ask
her
to
come
and
share
with
him
the
allowance
made
to
him
by
his
father
!
<EOS>
Whether
she
had
much
fortune
of
her
own
,
or
little
,
or
none
at
all
,
he
did
not
in
the
least
know
.
<EOS>
He
did
know
that
the
Earl
had
been
distressed
by
his
son
's
extravagance
,
and
that
there
had
been
some
money
difficulties
arising
from
this
source
.
  
<EOS>
But
his
great
desire
would
be
to
support
his
own
wife
by
his
own
labour
.
<EOS>
At
present
he
was
hardly
in
a
fair
way
to
do
that
,
unless
he
could
get
paid
for
his
parliamentary
work
.
<EOS>
Those
fortunate
gentlemen
who
form
"
The
Government
"
are
so
paid
.
<EOS>
Yes
;
 
there
was
the
Treasury
Bench
open
to
him
,
and
he
must
resolve
that
he
would
seat
himself
there
.
<EOS>
He
would
make
Lady
Laura
understand
this
,
and
then
he
would
ask
his
question
.
<EOS>
It
was
true
that
at
present
his
political
opponents
had
possession
of
the
Treasury
Bench
;
 
but
all
governments
are
mortal
,
and
Conservative
governments
in
this
country
are
especially
prone
to
die
.
<EOS>
It
was
true
that
he
could
not
hold
even
a
Treasury
lordship
with
a
poor
thousand
a
year
for
his
salary
without
having
to
face
the
electors
of
Loughshane
again
before
he
entered
upon
the
enjoyment
of
his
place
;
 
but
if
he
could
only
do
something
to
give
a
grace
to
his
name
,
to
show
that
he
was
a
rising
man
,
the
electors
of
Loughshane
,
who
had
once
been
so
easy
with
him
,
would
surely
not
be
cruel
to
him
when
he
showed
himself
a
second
time
among
them
.
<EOS>
Lord
Tulla
was
his
friend
,
and
he
had
those
points
of
law
in
his
favour
which
possession
bestows
.
<EOS>
And
then
he
remembered
that
Lady
Laura
was
related
to
almost
everybody
who
was
anybody
among
the
high
Whigs
.
<EOS>
She
was
,
he
knew
,
second
cousin
to
Mr.
Mildmay
,
who
for
years
had
been
the
leader
of
the
Whigs
,
and
was
third
cousin
to
Barrington
Erle
.
<EOS>
The
late
President
of
the
Council
,
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
,
and
Lord
Brentford
had
married
sisters
,
and
the
St.
Bungay
people
,
and
the
Mildmay
people
,
and
the
Brentford
people
had
all
some
sort
of
connection
with
the
Palliser
people
,
of
whom
the
heir
and
coming
chief
,
Plantagenet
Palliser
,
would
certainly
be
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
in
the
next
Government
.
<EOS>
Simply
as
an
introduction
into
official
life
nothing
could
be
more
conducive
to
chances
of
success
than
a
matrimonial
alliance
with
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
Not
that
he
would
have
thought
of
such
a
thing
on
that
account
!
<EOS>
No
;
 
he
thought
of
it
because
he
loved
her
;
honestly
because
he
loved
her
.
<EOS>
He
swore
to
that
half
a
dozen
times
,
for
his
own
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
But
,
loving
her
as
he
did
,
and
resolving
that
in
spite
of
all
difficulties
she
should
become
his
wife
,
there
could
be
no
reason
why
he
should
not
,
 
on
her
account
as
well
as
on
his
own
,
 
take
advantage
of
any
circumstances
that
there
might
be
in
his
favour
.
  
<EOS>
As
he
wandered
among
the
unsavoury
beasts
,
elbowed
on
every
side
by
the
Sunday
visitors
to
the
garden
,
he
made
up
his
mind
that
he
would
first
let
Lady
Laura
understand
what
were
his
intentions
with
regard
to
his
future
career
,
and
then
he
would
ask
her
to
join
her
lot
to
his
.
<EOS>
At
every
turn
the
chances
would
of
course
be
very
much
against
him
;
 
ten
to
one
against
him
,
perhaps
,
on
every
point
;
but
it
was
his
lot
in
life
to
have
to
face
such
odds
.
<EOS>
Twelve
months
since
it
had
been
much
more
than
ten
to
one
against
his
getting
into
Parliament
;
and
yet
he
was
there
.
<EOS>
He
expected
to
be
blown
into
fragments
,
 
to
sheep
-
skinning
in
Australia
,
or
packing
preserved
meats
on
the
plains
of
Paraguay
;
but
when
the
blowing
into
atoms
should
come
,
he
was
resolved
that
courage
to
bear
the
ruin
should
not
be
wanting
.
<EOS>
Then
he
quoted
a
line
or
two
of
a
Latin
poet
,
and
felt
himself
to
be
comfortable
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
,
here
you
are
again
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
said
a
voice
in
his
ear
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Miss
Fitzgibbon
;
here
I
am
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
fancied
you
members
of
Parliament
had
something
else
to
do
besides
looking
at
wild
beasts
.
<EOS>
I
thought
you
always
spent
Sunday
in
arranging
how
you
might
most
effectually
badger
each
other
on
Monday
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
got
through
all
that
early
this
morning
,
Miss
Fitzgibbon
,
while
you
were
saying
your
prayers
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Here
is
Mr.
Kennedy
too
;
 
you
know
him
I
daresay
.
<EOS>
He
also
is
a
member
;
but
then
he
can
afford
to
be
idle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
it
so
happened
that
Phineas
did
not
know
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
consequently
there
was
some
slight
form
of
introduction
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
I
am
to
meet
you
at
dinner
on
Wednesday
,
"
 
said
Phineas
,
 
"
at
Lord
Brentford
's
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
me
too
,
"
said
Miss
Fitzgibbon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Which
will
be
the
greatest
possible
addition
to
our
pleasure
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
,
who
seemed
to
be
afflicted
with
some
difficulty
in
speaking
,
and
whose
bow
to
our
hero
had
hardly
done
more
than
produce
the
slightest
possible
motion
to
the
top
of
his
hat
,
hereupon
muttered
something
which
was
taken
to
mean
an
assent
to
the
proposition
as
to
Wednesday
's
dinner
.
<EOS>
Then
he
stood
perfectly
still
,
with
his
two
hands
fixed
on
the
top
of
his
umbrella
,
and
gazed
at
the
great
monkeys
'
cage
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
clear
that
he
was
not
looking
at
any
special
monkey
,
for
his
eyes
never
wandered
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
ever
see
such
a
contrast
in
your
life
?
"
said
Miss
Fitzgibbon
to
Phineas
,
 
hardly
in
a
whisper
.
  
<EOS>
"
Between
what
?
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Between
Mr.
Kennedy
and
a
monkey
.
<EOS>
The
monkey
has
so
much
to
say
for
himself
,
and
is
so
delightfully
wicked
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
suppose
that
Mr.
Kennedy
ever
did
anything
wrong
in
his
life
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
was
a
man
who
had
very
little
temptation
to
do
anything
wrong
.
<EOS>
He
was
possessed
of
over
a
million
and
a
half
of
money
,
which
he
was
mistaken
enough
to
suppose
he
had
made
himself
;
whereas
it
may
be
doubted
whether
he
had
ever
earned
a
penny
.
<EOS>
His
father
and
his
uncle
had
created
a
business
in
Glasgow
,
and
that
business
now
belonged
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
his
father
and
his
uncle
,
who
had
toiled
through
their
long
lives
,
had
left
behind
them
servants
who
understood
the
work
,
and
the
business
now
went
on
prospering
almost
by
its
own
momentum
.
<EOS>
The
Mr.
Kennedy
of
the
present
day
,
the
sole
owner
of
the
business
,
though
he
did
occasionally
go
to
Glasgow
,
certainly
did
nothing
towards
maintaining
it
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
magnificent
place
in
Perthshire
,
called
Loughlinter
,
and
he
sat
for
a
Scotch
group
of
boroughs
,
and
he
had
a
house
in
London
,
and
a
stud
of
horses
in
Leicestershire
,
which
he
rarely
visited
,
and
was
unmarried
.
<EOS>
He
never
spoke
much
to
any
one
,
although
he
was
constantly
in
society
.
<EOS>
He
rarely
did
anything
,
although
he
had
the
means
of
doing
everything
.
<EOS>
He
had
very
seldom
been
on
his
legs
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
though
he
had
sat
there
for
ten
years
.
<EOS>
He
was
seen
about
everywhere
,
sometimes
with
one
acquaintance
and
sometimes
with
another
;
 
but
it
may
be
doubted
whether
he
had
any
friend
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
doubted
whether
he
had
ever
talked
enough
to
any
man
to
make
that
man
his
friend
.
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
tried
him
for
one
season
,
and
after
a
month
or
two
asked
for
a
loan
of
a
few
hundred
pounds
.
<EOS>
"
I
never
lend
money
to
any
one
under
any
circumstances
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
it
was
the
longest
speech
which
had
ever
fallen
from
his
mouth
in
the
hearing
of
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
But
though
he
would
not
lend
money
,
he
gave
a
great
deal
,
 
and
he
would
give
it
for
almost
every
object
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Robert
Kennedy
,
M.P.
,
Loughlinter
,
£
105
,
"
appeared
on
almost
every
charitable
list
that
was
advertised
.
<EOS>
No
one
ever
spoke
to
him
as
to
this
expenditure
,
nor
did
he
ever
speak
to
any
one
.
<EOS>
Circulars
came
to
him
and
the
cheques
were
returned
.
<EOS>
The
duty
was
a
very
easy
one
to
him
,
and
he
performed
it
willingly
.
<EOS>
Had
any
amount
of
inquiry
been
necessary
,
it
is
possible
that
the
labour
would
have
been
too
much
for
him
.
<EOS>
Such
was
Mr.
Robert
Kennedy
,
as
to
whom
Phineas
had
heard
that
he
had
during
the
last
winter
entertained
Lord
Brentford
and
Lady
Laura
,
with
very
many
other
people
of
note
,
at
his
place
in
Perthshire
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
very
much
prefer
the
monkey
,
"
said
Phineas
to
Miss
Fitzgibbon
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
would
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Like
to
like
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
You
have
both
of
you
the
same
aptitude
for
climbing
.
<EOS>
But
the
monkeys
never
fall
,
they
tell
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
knowing
that
he
could
gain
nothing
by
sparring
with
Miss
Fitzgibbon
,
raised
his
hat
and
took
his
leave
.
<EOS>
Going
out
of
a
narrow
gate
he
found
himself
again
brought
into
contact
with
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
"
What
a
crowd
there
is
here
,
"
he
said
,
finding
himself
bound
to
say
something
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
,
who
was
behind
him
,
answered
him
not
a
word
.
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
made
up
his
mind
that
Mr.
Kennedy
was
insolent
with
the
insolence
of
riches
,
and
that
he
would
hate
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
engaged
to
dine
on
this
Sunday
with
Mr.
Low
,
the
barrister
,
with
whom
he
had
been
reading
for
the
last
three
years
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
had
taken
a
strong
liking
to
Phineas
,
as
had
also
Mrs.
Low
,
and
the
tutor
had
more
than
once
told
his
pupil
that
success
in
his
profession
was
certainly
open
to
him
if
he
would
only
stick
to
his
work
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
was
himself
an
ambitious
man
,
looking
forward
to
entering
Parliament
at
some
future
time
,
when
the
exigencies
of
his
life
of
labour
might
enable
him
to
do
so
;
but
he
was
prudent
,
given
to
close
calculation
,
and
resolved
to
make
the
ground
sure
beneath
his
feet
in
every
step
that
he
took
forward
.
<EOS>
When
he
first
heard
that
Finn
intended
to
stand
for
Loughshane
he
was
stricken
with
dismay
,
and
strongly
dissuaded
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
electors
may
probably
reject
him
.
<EOS>
That
's
his
only
chance
now
,
"
Mr.
Low
had
said
to
his
wife
,
when
he
found
that
Phineas
was
,
as
he
thought
,
foolhardy
.
<EOS>
But
the
electors
of
Loughshane
had
not
rejected
Mr.
Low
's
pupil
,
and
Mr.
Low
was
now
called
upon
to
advise
what
Phineas
should
do
in
his
present
circumstances
.
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
to
prevent
the
work
of
a
Chancery
barrister
being
done
by
a
member
of
Parliament
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
most
successful
barristers
are
members
of
Parliament
.
<EOS>
But
Phineas
Finn
was
beginning
at
the
wrong
end
,
and
Mr.
Low
knew
that
no
good
would
come
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Only
think
of
your
being
in
Parliament
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
said
Mrs.
Low
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
wonderful
,
is
n't
it
?
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
took
us
so
much
by
surprise
!
"
said
Mrs.
Low
.
<EOS>
"
As
a
rule
one
never
hears
of
a
barrister
going
into
Parliament
till
after
he
's
forty
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
'm
only
twenty
-
five
.
<EOS>
I
do
feel
that
I
've
disgraced
myself
.
<EOS>
I
do
,
indeed
,
Mrs.
Low
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
;
 
you
've
not
disgraced
yourself
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
The
only
question
is
,
whether
it
's
prudent
.
<EOS>
I
hope
it
will
all
turn
out
for
the
best
,
most
heartily
.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Low
was
a
very
matter
-
of
-
fact
lady
,
four
or
five
years
older
than
her
husband
,
who
had
had
a
little
money
of
her
own
,
and
was
possessed
of
every
virtue
under
the
sun
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
she
did
not
quite
like
the
idea
of
her
husband
's
pupil
having
got
into
Parliament
.
<EOS>
If
her
husband
and
Phineas
Finn
were
dining
anywhere
together
,
Phineas
,
who
had
come
to
them
quite
a
boy
,
would
walk
out
of
the
room
before
her
husband
.
<EOS>
This
could
hardly
be
right
!
<EOS>
Nevertheless
she
helped
Phineas
to
the
nicest
bit
of
fish
she
could
find
,
and
had
he
been
ill
,
would
have
nursed
him
with
the
greatest
care
.
  
<EOS>
After
dinner
,
when
Mrs.
Low
had
gone
up
-
stairs
,
there
came
the
great
discussion
between
the
tutor
and
the
pupil
,
for
the
sake
of
which
this
little
dinner
had
been
given
.
<EOS>
When
Phineas
had
last
been
with
Mr.
Low
,
 
on
the
occasion
of
his
showing
himself
at
his
tutor
's
chambers
after
his
return
from
Ireland
,
 
he
had
not
made
up
his
mind
so
thoroughly
on
certain
points
as
he
had
done
since
he
had
seen
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
The
discussion
could
hardly
be
of
any
avail
now
,
 
but
it
could
not
be
avoided
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Phineas
,
and
what
do
you
mean
to
do
?
"
said
Mr.
Low
.
<EOS>
Everybody
who
knew
our
hero
,
or
nearly
everybody
,
called
him
by
his
Christian
name
.
<EOS>
There
are
men
who
seem
to
be
so
treated
by
general
consent
in
all
societies
.
<EOS>
Even
Mrs.
Low
,
who
was
very
prosaic
,
and
unlikely
to
be
familiar
in
her
mode
of
address
,
had
fallen
into
the
way
of
doing
it
before
the
election
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
dropped
it
,
when
the
Phineas
whom
she
used
to
know
became
a
member
of
Parliament
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
question
;
 
is
n't
it
?
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
'll
stick
to
your
work
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
;
 
to
the
Bar
?
"
  
"
Yes
;
 
to
the
Bar
.
"
  
"
I
am
not
thinking
of
giving
it
up
permanently
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Giving
it
up
,
"
said
Mr.
Low
,
raising
his
hands
in
surprise
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
give
it
up
,
how
do
you
intend
to
live
?
<EOS>
Men
are
not
paid
for
being
members
of
Parliament
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
exactly
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
said
before
,
I
am
not
thinking
of
giving
it
up
,
 
permanently
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
n't
give
it
up
at

,
 
not
for
a
day
;
that

,
if

ever
mean

any
good
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
I
think
that
perhaps
you
may
be
wrong
,
Low
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
be
wrong
?
<EOS>
Did
a

of

ever

?
<EOS>
And

,
that
continuous

is
more

in
our

than

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
<EOS>
you
do

,
Phineas
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
simply
this
.
<EOS>
Here
I
am
in
Parliament
.
<EOS>
We
must
take

as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
if

be

,

.
<EOS>
Even
you
would
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
;
 
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
My

,
though
I
do
not

give
you
pain
,
if

come
to
me
<EOS>
I
can

.
<EOS>
My

is
to

-

.
<EOS>
Men

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
do

,
"
said
Phineas
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
;
 
then
let

,
"
said

Low
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
wo
n't

,
the
next

will
be
to
take

that

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,
 
that

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
but
that
.
<EOS>
Why
,
the
thing
is
a
study
in

.
<EOS>
As

in
a
year
,
that
is
out

.
<EOS>
But
I
am

that
if
a
man

to
be

member

Parliament
,
he

make

study

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
do
you
mean
to
live
in
the
meantime
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
,
who
was
an
energetic
man
,
had
assumed
almost
an
angry
tone
of
voice
.
<EOS>
Phineas
for
awhile
sat
silent
;
 
not
that
he
felt
himself
to
be
without
words
for
a
reply
,
but
that
he
was
thinking
in
what
fewest
words
he
might
best
convey

ideas
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
very
modest
allowance
from
your
father
,
on
which
you
have
never
been
able
to
keep
yourself
free
from
debt
,
"
continued
Mr.
Low
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
increased
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
will
it
satisfy
you
to
live
here
,
in
what
will
turn
out
to
be
parliamentary
club
idleness
,
on
the
savings
of
his
industrious
life
?
<EOS>
I
think
you
will
find
yourself
unhappy
if
you
do
that
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
my
dear
fellow
,
as
far
as
I
have
as
yet
been
able
to
see
the
world
,
men
do
n't
begin
either
very
good
or
very
bad
.
<EOS>
They
have
generally
good
aspirations
with
infirm
purposes
;
 
or
,
as
we
may
say
,
strong
bodies
with
weak
legs
to
carry
them
.
<EOS>
Then
,
because
their
legs
are
weak
,
they
drift
into
idleness
and
ruin
.
<EOS>
During
all
this
drifting
they
are
wretched
,
and
when
they
have
thoroughly
drifted
they
are
still
wretched
.
<EOS>
The
agony
of
their
old
disappointment
still
clings
to
them
.
<EOS>
In
nine
cases
out
of
ten
<EOS>
it
is
some
one
small
unfortunate
event
that
puts
a
man
astray
at
first
.
<EOS>
He
sees
some
woman
and
loses
himself
with
her
;
 
or
he
is
taken
to
a
racecourse
and
unluckily
wins
money
;
 
or
some
devil
in
the
shape
of
a
friend
lures
him
to
tobacco
and
brandy
.
<EOS>
Your
temptation
has
come
in
the
shape
of
this
accursed
seat
in
Parliament
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
had
never
said
a
soft
word
in
his
life
to
any
woman
but
the
wife
of
his
bosom
,
had
never
seen
a
racehorse
,
always
confined
himself
to
two
glasses
of
port
after

,
and
looked
upon
smoking
as
the
darkest
of
all
the
vices
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
made
up

mind
,
then
,
that
I

to
be
idle
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
made
up
my
mind
that
your
time
will
be
wholly

,
 
if
you
do
as

say

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
do
not

;

.
"
<EOS>
Then

Low

,
and
Phineas
explained

,
 
saying
,

,
nothing
of
his

Lady
Laura
,
but
giving
Mr.
Low
to

and

some

,
 
a

,
 
on

,
by
the

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
heard
him
without
a

.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
after
the
first
year
my
time
will
not

fully

,

succeed
.
<EOS>
And

I
fail

,
 
for
,
of

,
I
may
fail
altogether
 
"
  
"
It
is
possible
,
"

Low
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
are

to
turn
yourself
against
me
,
I
must
not

,
"
said
Phineas
,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Turn
myself
against
you
!
<EOS>
I
would
turn
myself
any
way
so
that
I
might
save
you
from
the
sort

life
which
you
are

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Even

,
what

?
<EOS>
You
will

the

some

,
not

.
<EOS>
You
are
to
make

by

whenever

is

,
and
by

.
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
Some

,

!
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
was

,

.
<EOS>
"
That

,

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I
live
upon

I

,
like

,
and

.
<EOS>
After

,

,

,

;
the

.
<EOS>
I

to

that
the
cake
is
more

.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
did
not

up
-
stairs
into

Low
's

on

,

.
<EOS>
He

to

,
 
to

much

,

,

would

.
<EOS>
But

he
must
never

Lady
Laura
Standish
again
.
   
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
's
Dinner
 
No
;
 
in
such
case
as
that
,
 
should

of
his
old

Mr.
Low
,
Phineas
Finn
must
make
up

never
to
see
Lady
Laura
Standish
again
!
<EOS>
And
he
was
in
love
with
Lady
Laura
Standish
;
 
and
,
for
aught
he
knew
,
Lady
Laura
Standish
might
be

love
with

.
<EOS>
As
he

home
from
Mr.
Low
's
house
in
Bedford
Square
,
he
was
by
no

.
<EOS>
There
had
been
much
more
said
between

and
Mr.
Low
than
could

laid
before
the
reader
in

last

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
had
urged
him
again
and
again
,
and
had
prevailed
so
far
that
Phineas
,
before

left
the
house
,
had
promised
to
consider
that
suicidal
expedient
of
the
Chiltern
Hundreds
.
<EOS>
What
a
by
-
word
he
would
become
if
he
were
to
give
up
Parliament
,
having
sat
there
for
about
a
week
!
<EOS>
But
such
immediate
giving
up
was
one
of
the
necessities
of
Mr.
Low
's

.
<EOS>
According
to
Mr.
Low
's
teaching
,
a
single
year
passed
amidst
the
miasma
of
the
House
of
Commons
would
be
altogether
fatal
to
any
chance
of
professional
success
.
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Low
had
at
any
rate
succeeded
in
making
Phineas
believe
that
he
was
right
in
this
lesson
.
<EOS>
There
was
his
profession
,
as
to
which
Mr.
Low
assured
him
that
success
was
within
his
reach
;
and
there
was
Parliament
on
the
other
side
,
<EOS>
as
to
which
he
knew
that
the
chances
were
all
against
him
,
in
spite
of
his
advantage
of
a
seat
.
<EOS>
That
he
could
not
combine
the
two
,
beginning
with
Parliament
,
he
did
believe
.
<EOS>
Which
should
it
be
?
<EOS>
That
was
the
question
which
he
tried
to
decide
as
he
walked
home
from
Bedford
Square
to
Great
Marlborough
Street
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
answer
the
question
satisfactorily
,
and
went
to
bed
an
unhappy
man
.
  
<EOS>
He
must
at
any
rate
go
to
Lord
Brentford
's
dinner
on
Wednesday
,
and
,
to
enable
him
to
join
in
the
conversation
there
,
must
attend
the
debates
on
Monday
and
Tuesday
.
<EOS>
The
reader
may
perhaps
be
best
made
to
understand
how
terrible
was
our
hero
's
state
of
doubt
by
being
told
that
for
awhile
he
thought
of
absenting
himself
from
these
debates
,
as
being
likely
to
weaken
his
purpose
of
withdrawing
altogether
from
the
House
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
very
often
that
so
strong
a
fury
rages
between
party
and
party
at
the
commencement
of
the
session
that
a
division
is
taken
upon
the
Address
.
<EOS>
It
is
customary
for
the
leader
of
the
opposition
on
such
occasions
to
express
his
opinion
in
the
most
courteous
language
,
that
his
right
honourable
friend
,
sitting
opposite
to
him
on
the
Treasury
bench
,
has
been
,
is
,
and
will
be
wrong
in
everything
that
he
thinks
,
says
,
or
does
in
public
life
;
but
that
,
as
anything
like
factious
opposition
is
never
adopted
on
that
side
of
the
House
,
the
Address
to
the
Queen
,
in
answer
to
that
most
fatuous
speech
which
has
been
put
into
her
Majesty
's
gracious
mouth
,
shall
be
allowed
to
pass
unquestioned
.
<EOS>
Then
the
leader
of
the
House
thanks
his
adversary
for
his
consideration
<EOS>
,
explains
to
all
men
how
happy
the
country
ought
to
be
that
the
Government
has
not
fallen
into
the
disgracefully
incapable
hands
of
his
right
honourable
friend
opposite
;
and
after
that
the
Address
is
carried
amidst
universal
serenity
.
<EOS>
But
such
was
not
the
order
of
the
day
on
the
present
occasion
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
,
the
veteran
leader
of
the
liberal
side
of
the
House
,
had
moved
an
amendment
to
the
Address
,
and
had
urged
upon
the
House
,
in
very
strong
language
,
the
expediency
of
showing
,
at
the
very
commencement
of
the
session
,
that
the
country
had
returned
to
Parliament
a
strong
majority
determined
not
to
put
up
with
Conservative
inactivity
.
<EOS>
"
I
conceive
it
to
be
my
duty
,
"
Mr.
Mildmay
had
said
,
"
at
once
to
assume
that
the
country
is
unwilling
that
the
right

gentlemen
opposite
should
keep
their
seats
on
the
bench
upon
which
they
sit
,
and
in
the
performance
of
that
duty
I
am
called
upon
to
divide

House
upon
the
Address
to
her
Majesty
.
"
<EOS>
And
if
Mr.
Mildmay
used
strong
language
,
the
reader
may
be
sure
that
Mr.
Mildmay
's
followers
used
language
much
stronger
.
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Daubeny
,
who
was
the
present
leader
of
the
House
,
and

of

,
 
Lord
de

,

,

,

to
