to
pass
by
without
adequate
replies
.
<EOS>
He
and
his
friends
were
very
strong
in
sarcasm
,
if
they
failed
in
argument
,
and
lacked
nothing
for
words
,
though
it
might
perhaps
be
proved
that
they
were
short
in
numbers
.
<EOS>
It
was
considered
that
the
speech
in
which
Mr.
Daubeny
reviewed
the
long
political
life
of
Mr.
Mildmay
,
and
showed
that
Mr.
Mildmay
had
been
at
one
time
a
bugbear
,
and
then
a
nightmare
,
and
latterly
simply
a
fungus
,
was
one
of
the
severest
attacks
,
if
not
the
most
severe
,
that
had
been
heard
in
that
House
since
the
Reform
Bill
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
,
the
while
,
was
sitting
with
his
hat
low
down
over
his
eyes
,
and
many
men
said
that
he
did
not
like
it
.
<EOS>
But
this
speech
was
not
made
till
after
that
dinner
at
Lord
Brentford
's
,
of
which
a
short
account
must
be
given
.
  
<EOS>
Had
it
not
been
for
the
overwhelming
interest
of
the
doings
in
Parliament
at
the
commencement
of
the
session
,
Phineas
might
have
perhaps
abstained
from
attending
,
in
spite
of
the
charm
of
novelty
.
<EOS>
For
,
in
truth
,
Mr.
Low
's
words
had
moved
him
much
.
<EOS>
But
if
it
was
to
be
his
fate
to
be
a
member
of
Parliament
only
for
ten
days
,
surely
it
would
be
well
that
he
should
take
advantage
of
the
time
to
hear
such
a
debate
as
this
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
a
thing
to
talk
of
to
his
children
in
twenty
years
'
time
,
or
to
his
grandchildren
in
fifty
;
 
and
it
would
be
essentially
necessary
that
he
should
be
able
to
talk
of
it
to
Lady
Laura
Standish
.
<EOS>
He
did
,
therefore
,
sit
in
the
House
till
one
on
the
Monday
night
,
and
till
two
on
the
Tuesday
night
,
and
heard
the
debate
adjourned
till
the
Thursday
.
<EOS>
On
the
Thursday
Mr.
Daubeny
was
to
make
his
great
speech
,
and
then
the
division
would
come
.
  
<EOS>
When
Phineas
entered
Lady
Laura
's
drawing
-
room
on
the
Wednesday
before
dinner
,
he
found
the
other
guests
all
assembled
.
<EOS>
Why
men
should
have
been
earlier
in
keeping
their
dinner
engagements
on
that
day
than
on
any
other
he
did
not
understand
;
but
it
was
the
fact
,
probably
,
that
the
great
anxiety
of
the
time
made
those
who
were
at
all
concerned
in
the
matter
very
keen
to
hear
and
to
be
heard
.
<EOS>
During
these
days
everybody
was
in
a
hurry
,
 
everybody
was
eager
;
and
there
was
a
common
feeling
that
not
a
minute
was
to
be
lost
.
<EOS>
There
were
three
ladies
in
the
room
,
 
Lady
Laura
,
Miss
Fitzgibbon
,
and
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
The
latter
was
the
wife
of
a
gentleman
who
had
been
a
junior
Lord
of
the
Admiralty
in
the
late
Government
,
and
who
lived
in
the
expectation
of
filling
,
perhaps
,
some
higher
office
in
the
Government
which
,
as
he
hoped
,
was
soon
to
be
called
into
existence
.
<EOS>
There
were
five
gentlemen
besides
Phineas
Finn
himself
,
 
Mr.
Bonteen
,
Mr.
Kennedy
,
Mr.
Fitzgibbon
,
Barrington
Erle
,
who
had
been
caught
in
spite
of
all
that
Lady
Laura
had
said
as
to
the
difficulty
of
such
an
operation
,
and
Lord
Brentford
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
quick
to
observe
that
every
male
guest
was
in
Parliament
,
and
to
tell
himself
that
he
would
not
have
been
there
unless
he
also
had
had
a
seat
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
all
here
now
,
"
said
the
Earl
,
ringing
the
bell
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
've
not
kept
you
waiting
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
why
we
are
in
such
a
hurry
.
<EOS>
And
how
many
do
you
say
it
will
be
,
Mr.
Finn
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Seventeen
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
More
likely
twenty
-
two
,
"
said
Mr.
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
Colcleugh
so
ill
they
ca
n't
possibly
bring
him
up
,
and
young
Rochester
is
at
Vienna
,
and
Gunning
is
sulking
about
something
,
and
Moody
has
lost
his
eldest
son
.
<EOS>
By
George
!
<EOS>
they
pressed
him
to
come
up
,
although
Frank
Moody
wo
n't
be
buried
till
Friday
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
it
,
"
said
Lord
Brentford
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
ask
some
of
the
Carlton
fellows
,
and
they
'll
own
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
'd
lost
every
relation
I
had
in
the
world
,
"
said
Fitzgibbon
,
"
I
'd
vote
on
such
a
question
as
this
.
<EOS>
Staying
away
wo
n't
bring
poor
Frank
Moody
back
to
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
there
's
a
decency
in
these
matters
,
is
there
not
,
Mr.
Fitzgibbon
?
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
they
had
thrown
all
that
kind
of
thing
overboard
long
ago
,
"
said
Miss
Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
better
that
they
should
have
no
veil
,
than
squabble
about
the
thickness
of
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
dinner
was
announced
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
walked
off
with
Miss
Fitzgibbon
,
Barrington
Erle
took
Mrs.
Bonteen
,
and
Mr.
Fitzgibbon
took
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
bet
four
pounds
to
two
<EOS>
it
's
over
nineteen
,
"
said
Mr.
Bonteen
,
as
he
passed
through
the
drawing
-
room
door
.
<EOS>
The
remark
seemed
to
have
been
addressed
to
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
Phineas
therefore
made
no
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
daresay
it
will
,
"
said
Kennedy
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
never
bet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
vote
 
sometimes
,
I
hope
,
"
said
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sometimes
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
is
the
most
odious
man
that
ever
I
set
my
eyes
on
,
"
said
Phineas
to
himself
as
he
followed
Mr.
Kennedy
into
the
dining
-
room
.
<EOS>
He
had
observed
that
Mr.
Kennedy
had
been
standing
very
near
to
Lady
Laura
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
that
Lady
Laura
had
said
a
few
words
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
more
determined
than
ever
that
he
would
hate
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
would
probably
have
been
moody
and
unhappy
throughout
the
whole
dinner
had
not
Lady
Laura
called
him
to
a
chair
at
her
left
hand
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
generous
of
her
;
and
the
more
so
,
as
Mr.
Kennedy
had
,
in
a
half
-
hesitating
manner
,
prepared
to
seat
himself
in
that
very
place
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
Phineas
and
Mr.
Kennedy
were
neighbours
,
but
Phineas
had
the
place
of
honour
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
will
not
speak
during
the
debate
?
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
?
<EOS>
I
?
<EOS>
Certainly
not
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
I
could
not
get
a
hearing
,
and
,
in
the
next
place
,
I
should
not
think
of
commencing
on
such
an
occasion
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
that
I
shall
ever
speak
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
you
will
.
<EOS>
You
are
just
the
sort
of
man
who
will
succeed
with
the
House
.
<EOS>
What
I
doubt
is
,
whether
you
will
do
as
well
in
office
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
might
have
the
chance
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
can
have
the
chance
if
you
try
for
it
.
<EOS>
Beginning
so
early
,
and
being
on
the
right
side
,
 
and
,
if
you
will
allow
me
to
say
so
,
among
the
right
set
,
 
there
can
be
no
doubt
that
you
may
take
office
if
you
will
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
sure
that
you
will
be
tractable
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
begin
,
you
know
,
by
being
Prime
Minister
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
enough
to
realise
that
already
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
only
keep
that
little
fact
steadily
before
your
eyes
,
there
is
nothing
you
may
not
reach
in
official
life
.
<EOS>
But
Pitt
was
Prime
Minister
at
four
-
and
-
twenty
,
and
that
precedent
has
ruined
half
our
young
politicians
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
has
not
affected
me
,
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
far
as
I
can
see
,
there
is
no
great
difficulty
in
government
.
<EOS>
A
man
must
learn
to
have
words
at
command
when
he
is
on
his
legs
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
in
the
same
way
as
he
would
if
he
were
talking
to
his
own
servants
.
<EOS>
He
must
keep
his
temper
;
and
he
must
be
very
patient
.
<EOS>
As
far
as
I
have
seen
Cabinet
Ministers
,
they
are
not
more
clever
than
other
people
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
there
are
generally
one
or
two
men
of
ability
in
the
Cabinet
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
,
of
fair
ability
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
is
a
good
specimen
.
<EOS>
There
is
not
,
and
never
was
,
anything
brilliant
in
him
.
<EOS>
He
is
not
eloquent
,
nor
,
as
far
as
I
am
aware
,
did
he
ever
create
anything
.
<EOS>
But
he
has
always
been
a
steady
,
honest
,
persevering
man
,
and
circumstances
have
made
politics
come
easy
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Think
of
the
momentous
questions
which
he
has
been
called
upon
to
decide
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Every
question
so
handled
by
him
has
been
decided
rightly
according
to
his
own
party
,
and
wrongly
according
to
the
party
opposite
.
<EOS>
A
political
leader
is
so
sure
of
support
<EOS>
and
so
sure
of
attack
,
that
it
is
hardly
necessary
for
him
to
be
even
anxious
to
be
right
.
<EOS>
For
the
country
's
sake
,
he
should
have
officials
under
him
who
know
the
routine
of
business
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
think
very
badly
then
of
politics
as
a
profession
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
think
of
them
very

.
<EOS>
It
must
be
better
to
deal
with
the

of
laws
than
the

of

.
<EOS>
But
all

is
papa
's

,
not
mine
.
<EOS>
Papa
has
never
been
in
the
Cabinet
yet
,
and
therefore
of
course
he
is
a
little
caustic
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
was
quite
right
,
"
said
Barrington
Erle
stoutly
.
<EOS>
He
spoke
so
stoutly
that
everybody
at
the
table
listened
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
exactly
see
the

such

just

,
"
said

Brentford
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
must

do
,
"

.
"
<EOS>
Lord
de
Terrier
took
office
knowing

.
<EOS>
We
had

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
We
could

,

.
<EOS>
For

,

Terrier
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
 
hollow
,
"
said

Fitzgibbon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why

de
Terrier

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A

,
"

Brentford
.
<EOS>
"
He
must

Queen
's

.
<EOS>
It

chance
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Just
so
.
<EOS>
It
is
,
as
you
say
,
his
only
chance
,
and
it
is
his
right
.
<EOS>
His
very

of
power
will
give
him
near
a
score
of
votes
,
and
if
he
thinks
that
he
has

chance
,
let
him

.
<EOS>
We
maintain
that
he
had
no
chance
,
and
that
he
must
have
known
that
he
had
none
;
 
that
if
he
could

late

,

.
<EOS>
We
let

own

as

.
<EOS>
We
had
failed
last
summer
,
and

was

.
<EOS>
But
he
could
not
get
along
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
say
I

,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
And

are

upon

as

as
we

.
<EOS>
He
practically
lost
nine

by
his

.
<EOS>
Look
at
Loughshane
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;
look
at
Loughshane
,
"
said
Miss
Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
"
The
country
at
any
rate
has
gained
something
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
an
ill
wind
that
blows
nobody
any

,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
said
the
Earl
.
  
<EOS>
"
What

is

?
"
said

Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
"
I
wonder

.
<EOS>
George
was
n't
a
bad
sort

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Roby
used
to
think
that

was

,
"
said

Bonteen
.
<EOS>
"
Roby

trying
to
catch
him
.
<EOS>
"
It
may

as
well

Mr.
Roby
was
a

,

.

"

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
Upon

I

.
<EOS>
All

<EOS>
And

up
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Sir
Everard

ca

,

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Ratler
was
in

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>

ca
n't

.
<EOS>
But

is

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
same

went
on

,
and
became
,
if
anything
,
more

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
made
but
one

,
and
then
he
observed
that
as
far

he
could
see
a

of

would

as

as

.
<EOS>
This
he
said
in
a
very

,
and
in

that
was
intended

be
expressive
of

;
but
in
spite

his
humility
Barrington
Erle
flew
at
him
almost
savagely
,
 
as
though
a
liberal
member
of
the
House
of
Commons
was
disgraced
by
<EOS>
so
mean
a
spirit
;
and
Phineas
found

despising
the
man
for
his

of

.
  
<EOS>
"
If

to
beat

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Let

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
It
will
kill

,
no

,

I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
;
Llanwrwsth
is

,
"
said
Barrington
,
in

to

Lord

's

.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
went
up
into
the
drawing
-
room
for
a

minutes
after

,
and
was
eagerly
desirous
of
saying
a
few
more
words
,
 
<EOS>
he
knew
not
what
words
,
 
to
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
and
Mr.
Bonteen
had
left
the
dining
-
room
first
,
and
Phineas
again
found
Mr.
Kennedy
standing
close
to
Lady
Laura
's

.
<EOS>
Could
it
be
possible
that
there
was
anything
in
it
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
was
an
unmarried
man
,
with
an
immense
fortune
,
a
magnificent
place
,
a
seat
in
Parliament
,
and
was
not
perhaps
above
forty
years
of
age
.
<EOS>
There
could
be
no
reason
why
he
should
not
ask
Lady
Laura
to
be
his
wife
,
 
except
,
indeed
,
that
he
did
not
seem
to
have
sufficient
words
at
command
to
ask
anybody
for
anything
.
<EOS>
But
could
it
be
that
such
a
woman
as
Lady
Laura
could
accept
such
a
man
as
Mr.
Kennedy
because
of
his
wealth
,
and
because
of
his
fine
place
,
 
a
man
who
had
not
a
word
to
throw
to
a
dog
,
who
did
not
seem
to
be
possessed
of
an
idea
,
who
hardly
looked
like
a
gentleman
;
 
so
Phineas
told
himself
.
<EOS>
But
in
truth
Mr.
Kennedy
,
though
he
was
a
plain
,
unattractive
man
,
with
nothing
in
his
personal
appearance
to
call
for

,
was
not
unlike
a
gentleman
in
his
usual
demeanour
.
<EOS>
Phineas
himself
,
it
may
be
here
said
,
was
six
feet
high
,
and
very
handsome
,
with
bright
blue
eyes
,
and
brown
wavy
hair
,
and
light

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Low
had
told
her
husband
more
than
once
that
he
was
much
too
handsome
to
do
any

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
,
however
,
had
replied
that
young
Finn
had
never
shown

to

conscious
of

own
personal

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
'll
learn

soon
enough
,
"
said

Low
.
<EOS>
"
Some
woman
will
tell

,
and
then
he
'll

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
that
Phineas
depended
much
as
yet
on
his
own
good
looks
,
but
he
felt
that
Mr.
Kennedy
ought
to
be
despised
by

as
Lady
Laura
Standish
,
because
his

not

.
<EOS>
And
she
must
despise

!
<EOS>
It
could
not

that
a

so
full

should
be

put

a
man

.
<EOS>
And
yet

was

there
,

?
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
began
to
feel

to
be

.
  
<EOS>
But
Lady
Laura
had
the

of

.
<EOS>
She
had

effectually
in

by

,

,

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
No

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

"

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
not

.
<EOS>
But

some

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

;
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

;
 
but

all

.
<EOS>
I
think

that
in
the
early

there

the

Liberals

;

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
You

,

to

,

!
<EOS>
Well
;
 
good

;
and

.
<EOS>
You

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

your

;
 
though

's

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
went
away
,
and
walked
down
to
Pall
Mall
with
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
preferred
to
take
his
walk
alone
,
but
he
could
not
get
rid
of
his
affectionate
countryman
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
to
think
over
what
had
taken
place
during
the
evening
;
and
,
indeed
,
he
did
so
in
spite
of
his
friend
's
conversation
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
,
when
she
first
saw
him
after
his
return
to
London
,
had
told
him
how
anxious
her
father
was
to
congratulate
him
on
his
seat
,
but
the
Earl
had
not
spoken
a
word
to
him
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
had
been
courteous
,
as
hosts
customarily
are
,
but
had
been
in
no
way
specially
kind
to
him
.
<EOS>
And
then
Mr.
Kennedy
!
<EOS>
As
to
going
to
Loughlinter
,
he
would
not
do
such
a
thing
,
 
not
though
the
success
of
the
liberal
party
were
to
depend
on
it
.
<EOS>
He
declared
to
himself
that
there
were
some
things
which
a
man
could
not
do
.
<EOS>
But
although
he
was
not
altogether
satisfied
with
what
had
occurred
in
Portman
Square
,
he
felt
as
he
walked
down
arm
-
in
-
arm
with
Fitzgibbon
that
Mr.
Low
and
Mr.
Low
's
counsels
must
be
scattered
to
the
winds
.
<EOS>
He
had
thrown
the
die
in
consenting
to
stand
for
Loughshane
,
and
must
stand
the
hazard
of
the
cast
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bedad
,
Phin
,
my
boy
,
I
do
n't
think
you
're

to

all
,
"

Laurence
Fitzgibbon
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
listening

,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
if
I
have

go
down

the
ould
country
again
this

,
you
'll

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
my
boy
!
<EOS>
And
it
's
I
that
hope
you
'll

the
chance
.
<EOS>
What
's
the
good
of
turning
these
fellows
out
if
one
is
n't
to
get
something
for
one
's
trouble
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Bunce
 
<EOS>
It
was
three
o'clock
on
the
Thursday
night
before
Mr.
Daubeny
's
speech
was
finished
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
that
there
was
any
truth
in
the
allegation
made
at
the
time
,
that
he
continued
on
his
legs
an
hour
longer
than
the
necessities
of
his
speech
required
,
in
order
that
five
or
six
<EOS>
very
ancient
Whigs
might
be
wearied
out
and
shrink
to
their
beds
.
<EOS>
Let
a
Whig
have
been
ever
so
ancient
and
ever
so
weary
,
he
would
not
have
been
allowed
to
depart
from
Westminster
Hall
that
night
.
<EOS>
Sir
Everard
Powell
was
there
in
his
bath
-
chair
at
twelve
,
with
a
doctor
on
one
side
of
him
and
a
friend
on
the
other
,
in
some
purlieu
of
the
House
,
and
did
his
duty
like
a
fine
old
Briton
as
he
was
.
<EOS>
That
speech
of
Mr.
Daubeny
's
will
never
be
forgotten
by
any
one
who
heard
it
.
<EOS>
Its
studied
bitterness
had
perhaps
never
been
equalled
,
and
yet
not
a
word
was
uttered
for
the
saying
of
which
he
could
be
accused
of
going
beyond
the
limits
of
parliamentary
antagonism
.
<EOS>
It
is
true
that
personalities
could
not
have
been
closer
,
that
accusations
of
political
dishonesty
and
of
almost
worse
than
political
cowardice
and
falsehood
could
not
have
been
clearer
,
that
no
words
in
the
language
could
have
attributed
meaner
motives
or
more
unscrupulous
conduct
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
Mr.
Daubeny
in
all
that
he
said
was
parliamentary
,
and
showed
himself
to
be
a
gladiator
thoroughly
well
trained
for
the
arena
in
which
he
had
descended
to
the
combat
.
<EOS>
His
arrows
were
poisoned
,
and
his
lance
was
barbed
,
and
his
shot
was
heated
red
,
 
because
such
things
are
allowed
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
poison
his
enemies
'
wells
or
use
Greek
fire
,
because
those
things
are
not
allowed
.
<EOS>
He
knew
exactly
the
rules
of
the
combat
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
sat
and
heard
him
without
once
raising
his
hat
from
his
brow
,
or
speaking
a
word
to
his
neighbour
.
<EOS>
Men
on
both
sides
of
the
House
said
that
Mr.
Mildmay
suffered
terribly
;
but
as
Mr.
Mildmay
uttered
no
word
of
complaint
to
any
one
,
and
was
quite
ready
to
take
Mr.
Daubeny
by
the
hand
the
next
time
they
met
in
company
,
I
do
not
know
that
any
one
was
able
to
form
a
true
idea
of
Mr.
Mildmay
's
feelings
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
was
an
impassive
man
who
rarely
spoke
of
his
own
feelings
,
and
no
doubt
sat
with
his
hat
low
down
over
his
eyes
in
order
that
no
man
might
judge
of
them
on
that
occasion
by
the
impression
on
his
features
.
<EOS>
"
If
he
could
have
left
off
half
an
hour
earlier
it
would
have
been
perfect
as
an
attack
,
"
said
Barrington
Erle
in
criticising
Mr.
Daubeny
's
speech
,
"
but
he
allowed
himself
to
sink
into
comparative
weakness
,
and
the
glory
of
it
was
over
before
the
end
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Then
came
the
division
.
<EOS>
The
Liberals
had
333
votes
to
314
for
the
Conservatives
,
and
therefore
counted
a
majority
of
19
.
<EOS>
It
was
said
that
so
large
a
number
of
members
had
never
before
voted
at
any
division
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
own
I
'm
disappointed
,
"
said
Barrington
Erle
to
Mr.
Ratler
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
there
would
be
twenty
,
"
said
Mr.
Ratler
.
<EOS>
"
I
never
went
beyond
that
.
<EOS>
I
knew
they
would
have
old
Moody
up
,
but
I
thought
Gunning
would
have
been
too
hard
for
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
say
they
've
promised
them
both
peerages
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;
 
if
they
remain
in
.
<EOS>
But
they
know
they
're
going
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
must
go
,
with
such
a
majority
against
them
,
"
said
Barrington
Erle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
they
must
,
"
said
Mr.
Ratler
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Lord
de
Terrier
wants
nothing
better
,
but
it
is
rather
hard
upon
poor
Daubeny
.
<EOS>
I
never
saw
such
an
unfortunate
old
Tantalus
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
gets
a
good
drop
of
real
water
now
and
again
,
and
I
do
n't
pity
him
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
He
's
clever
of
course
,
and
has
made
his
own
way
,
but
I
've
always
a
feeling
that
he
has
no
business
where
he
is
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
we
shall
know
all
about
it
at
Brooks
's
by
one
o'clock
to
-
morrow
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
though
it
had
been
past
five
before
he
went
to
bed
,
 
for
there
had
been
much
triumphant
talking
to
be
done
among
liberal
members
after
the
division
,
 
was
up
at
his
breakfast
at
Mrs.
Bunce
's
lodgings
by
nine
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
matter
which
he
was
called
upon
to
settle
immediately
in
which
Mrs.
Bunce
herself
was
much
interested
,
and
respecting
which
he
had
promised
to
give
an
answer
on
this
very
morning
.
<EOS>
A
set
of
very
dingy
chambers
up
two
pairs
of
stairs
at
No
.
9
,
Old
Square
,
Lincoln
's
Inn
,
to
which
Mr.
Low
had
recommended
him
to
transfer
himself
and
all
his
belongings
,
were
waiting
his
occupation
,
should
he
resolve
upon
occupying
them
.
<EOS>
If
he
intended
to
commence
operations
as
a
barrister
,
it
would
be
necessary
that
he
should
have
chambers
and
a
clerk
;
and
before
he
had
left
Mr.
Low
's
house
on
Sunday
evening
<EOS>
he
had
almost
given
that
gentleman
authority
to
secure
for
him
these
rooms
at
No
.
9
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Whether
you
remain
in
Parliament
or
no
,
you
must
make
a
beginning
,
"
Mr.
Low
had
said
;
"
and
how
are
you
even
to
pretend
to
begin
if
you
do
n't
have
chambers
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
hoped
that
he
might
be
able
to
wean
Phineas
away
from
his
Parliament
bauble
;
 
that
he
might
induce
the
young
barrister
to
give
up
his
madness
,
if
not
this
session
or
the
next
,
at
any
rate
before
a
third
year
had
commenced
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
was
a
persistent
man
,
liking
very
much
when
he
did
like
,
and
loving
very
strongly
when
he
did
love
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
many
a
tug
for
Phineas
Finn
before
he
would
allow
that
false
Westminster
Satan
to
carry
off
the
prey
as
altogether
his
own
.
<EOS>
If
he
could
only
get
Phineas
into
the
dingy
chambers
he
might
do
much
!
  
<EOS>
But
Phineas
had
now
become
so
imbued
with
the
atmosphere
of
politics
,
had
been
so
breathed
upon
by
Lady
Laura
and
Barrington
Erle
,
that
he
could
no
longer
endure
the
thought
of
any
other
life
than
that
of
a
life
spent
among
the
lobbies
.
<EOS>
A
desire
to
help
to
beat
the
Conservatives
had
fastened
on
his
very
soul
,
and
almost
made
Mr.
Low
odious
in
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
He
was
afraid
of
Mr.
Low
,
and
for
the
nonce
would
not
go
to
him
any
more
;
 
but
he
must
see
the
porter
at
Lincoln
's
Inn
,
he
must
write
a
line
to
Mr.
Low
,
and
he
must
tell
Mrs.
Bunce
that
for
the
present
he
would
still
keep
on
her
rooms
.
<EOS>
His
letter
to
Mr.
Low
was
as
follows
:
    
<EOS>
Great
Marlborough
Street
,
May
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
MY
DEAR
LOW
,
  
I
have
made
up
my
mind
against
taking
the
chambers
,
and
am
now
off
to
the
Inn
to
say
that
I
shall
not
want
them
.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
I
know
what
you
will
think
of
me
,
and
it
is
very
grievous
to
me
to
have
to
bear
the
hard
judgment
of
a
man
whose
opinion
I
value
so
highly
;
but
,
in
the
teeth
of
your
terribly
strong
arguments
,
I
think
that
there
is
something
to
be
said
on
my
side
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
This
seat
in
Parliament
has
come
in
my
way
by
chance
,
and
I
think
it
would
be
pusillanimous
in
me
to
reject
it
,
feeling
,
as
I
do
,
that
a
seat
in
Parliament
confers
very
great
honour
.
<EOS>
I
am
,
too
,
very
fond
of
politics
,
and
regard
legislation
as
the
finest
profession
going
.
<EOS>
Had
I
any
one
dependent
on
me
,
I
probably
might
not
be
justified
in
following
the
bent
of
my
inclination
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
all
alone
in
the
world
,
and
therefore
have
a
right
to
make
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
If
,
after
a
trial
of
one
or
two
sessions
,
I
should
fail
in
that
which
I
am
attempting
,
it
will
not
even
then
be
too
late
to
go
back
to
the
better
way
.
<EOS>
I
can
assure
you
that
at
any
rate
it
is
not
my
intention
to
be
idle
.
  
<EOS>
I
know
very
well
how
you
will
fret
and
fume
over
what
I
say
,
and
how
utterly
I
shall
fail
in
bringing
you
round
to
my
way
of
thinking
;
but
as
I
must
write
to
tell
you
of
my
decision
,
I
can
not
refrain
from
defending
myself
to
the
best
of
my
ability
.
  
<EOS>
Yours
always
faithfully
,
  
PHINEAS
FINN
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
received
this
letter
at
his
chambers
,
and
when
he
had
read
it
,
he
simply
pressed
his
lips
closely
together
,
placed
the
sheet
of
paper
back
in
its
envelope
,
and
put
it
into
a
drawer
at
his
left
hand
.
<EOS>
Having
done
this
,
he
went
on
with
what
work
he
had
before
him
,
as
though
his
friend
's
decision
were
a
matter
of
no
consequence
to
him
.
<EOS>
As
far
as
he
was
concerned
the
thing
was
done
,
and
there
should
be
an
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
So
he
told
himself
;
but
nevertheless
his
mind
was
full
of
it
all
day
;
and
,
though
he
wrote
not
a
word
of
answer
to
Phineas
,
he
made
a
reply
within
his
own
mind
to
every
one
of
the
arguments
used
in
the
letter
.
"
<EOS>
Great
honour
!
<EOS>
How
can
there
be
honour
in
what
comes
,
as
he
says
,
by
chance
?
<EOS>
He
has
n't
sense
enough
to
understand
that
the
honour
comes
from
the
mode
of
winning
it
,
and
from
the
mode
of
wearing
it
;
and
that
the
very
fact
of
his
being
member
for
Loughshane
at
this
instant
simply
proves
that
Loughshane
should
have
had
no
privilege
to
return
a
member
!
<EOS>
No
one
dependent
on
him
!
<EOS>
Are
not
his
father
and
his
mother
and
his
sisters
dependent
on
him
as
long
as
he
must
eat
their
bread
till
he
can
earn
bread
of
his
own
?
<EOS>
He
will
never
earn
bread
of
his
own
.
<EOS>
He
will
always
be
eating
bread
that
others
have
earned
.
<EOS>
"
In
this
way
,
before
the
day
was
over
,
Mr.
Low
became
very
angry
,
and
swore
to
himself
that
he
would
have
nothing
more
to
say
to
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
But
yet
he
found
himself
creating
plans
for
encountering
and
conquering
the
parliamentary
fiend
who
was
at
present
so
cruelly
potent
with
his
pupil
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
till
the
third
evening
that
he
told
his
wife
that
Finn
had
made
up
his
mind
not
to
take
chambers
.
<EOS>
"
Then
I
would
have
nothing
more
to
say
to
him
,
"
said
Mrs.
Low
,
savagely
.
<EOS>
"
For
the
present
I
can
have
nothing
more
to
say
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
"
But
neither
now
nor
ever
,
"
said
Mrs.
Low
,
with
great
emphasis
;
"
he
has
been
false
to
you
.
"
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr.
Low
,
who
was
a
man
thoroughly
and
thoughtfully
just
at
all
points
;
"
he
has
not
been
false
to
me
.
<EOS>
He
has
always
meant
what
he
has
said
,
when
he
was
saying
it
.
<EOS>
But
he
is
weak
and
blind
,
and
flies
like
a
moth
to
the
candle
;
one
pities
the
poor
moth
,
and
would
save
him
a
stump
of
his
wing
if
it
be
possible
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
when
he
had
written
his
letter
to
Mr.
Low
,
started
off
for
Lincoln
's
Inn
,
making
his
way
through
the
well
-
known
dreary
streets
of
Soho
,
and
through
St.
Giles
's
,
to
Long
Acre
.
<EOS>
He
knew
every
corner
well
,
for
he
had
walked
the
same
road
almost
daily
for
the
last
three
years
.
<EOS>
He
had
conceived
a
liking
for
the
route
,
which
he
might
easily
have
changed
without
much
addition
to
the
distance
,
by
passing
through
Oxford
Street
and
Holborn
;
but
there
was
an
air
of
business
on
which
he
prided
himself
in
going
by
the
most
direct
passage
,
and
he
declared
to
himself
very
often
that
things
dreary
and
dingy
to
the
eye
might
be
good
in
themselves
.
<EOS>
Lincoln
's
Inn
itself
is
dingy
,
and
the
Law
Courts
therein
are
perhaps
the
meanest
in
which
Equity
ever
disclosed
herself
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
's
three
rooms
in
the
Old
Square
,
each
of
them
brown
with
the
binding
of
law
books
and
with
the
dust
collected
on
law
papers
,
and
with
furniture
that
had
been
brown
always
,
and
had
become
browner
with
years
,
<EOS>
were
perhaps
as
unattractive
to
the
eye
of
a
young
pupil
as
any
rooms
which
were
ever
entered
.
<EOS>
And
the
study
of
the
Chancery
law
itself
is
not
an
alluring
pursuit
till
the
mind
has
come
to
have
some
insight
into
the
beauty
of
its
ultimate
object
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
during
his
three
years
'
course
of
reasoning
on
these
things
,
had
taught
himself
to
believe
that
things
ugly
on
the
outside
might
be
very
beautiful
within
;
and
had
therefore
come
to
prefer
crossing
Poland
Street
and
Soho
Square
,
and
so
continuing
his
travels
by
the
Seven
Dials
and
Long
Acre
.
<EOS>
His
morning
walk
was
of
a
piece
with
his
morning
studies
,
and
he
took
pleasure
in
the
gloom
of
both
.
<EOS>
But
now
the
taste
of
his
palate
had
been
already
changed
by
the
glare
of
the
lamps
in
and
about
palatial
Westminster
,
and
he
found
that
St.
Giles
's
was
disagreeable
.
<EOS>
The
ways
about
Pall
Mall
and
across
the
Park
to
Parliament
Street
,
or
to
the
Treasury
,
were
much
pleasanter
,
and
the
new
offices
in
Downing
Street
,
already
half
built
,
absorbed
all
that
interest
which
he
had
hitherto
been
able
to
take
in
the
suggested
but
uncommenced
erection
of
new
Law
Courts
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Lincoln
's
Inn
.
<EOS>
As
he
made
his
way
to
the
porter
's
lodge
under
the
great
gateway
of
Lincoln
's
Inn
,
he
told
himself
that
he
was
glad
that
he
had
escaped
,
at
any
rate
for
a
while
,
from
a
life
so
dull
and
dreary
.
<EOS>
If
he
could
only
sit
in
chambers
at
the
Treasury
instead
of
chambers
in
that
old
court
,
how
much
pleasanter
it
would
be
!
<EOS>
After
all
,
as
regarded
that
question
of
income
,
it
might
well
be
that
the
Treasury
chambers
should
be
the
more
remunerative
,
and
the
more
quickly
remunerative
,
of
the
two
.
<EOS>
And
,
as
he
thought
,
Lady
Laura
might
be
compatible
with
the
Treasury
chambers
and
Parliament
,
but
could
not
possibly
be
made
compatible
with
Old
Square
,
Lincoln
's
Inn
.
  
<EOS>
But
nevertheless
there
came
upon
him
a
feeling
of
sorrow
when
the
old
man
at
the
lodge
seemed
to
be
rather
glad
than
otherwise
that
he
did
not
want
the
chambers
.
<EOS>
"
Then
Mr.
Green
can
have
them
,
"
said
the
porter
;
"
that
'll
be
good
news
for
Mr.
Green
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
the
gen'lemen
'll
do
for
chambers
if
things
goes
on
as
they
're
going
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Green
was
welcome
to
the
chambers
as
far
as
Phineas
was
concerned
;
but
Phineas
felt
nevertheless
a
certain
amount
of
regret
that
he
should
have
been
compelled
to
abandon
a
thing
which
was
regarded
both
by
the
porter
and
by
Mr.
Green
as
being
so
desirable
.
<EOS>
He
had
however
written
his
letter
to
Mr.
Low
,
and
made
his
promise
to
Barrington
Erle
,
and
was
bound
to
Lady
Laura
Standish
;
and
he
walked
out
through
the
old
gateway
into
Chancery
Lane
,
resolving
that
he
would
not
even
visit
Lincoln
's
Inn
again
for
a
year
.
<EOS>
There
were
certain
books
,
 
law
books
,
 
which
he
would
read
at
such
intervals
of
leisure
as
politics
might
give
him
;
but
within
the
precincts
of
the
Inns
of
Court
he
would
not
again
put
his
foot
for
twelve
months
,
let
learned
pundits
of
the
law
,
 
such
for
instance
as
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Low
<EOS>
,
 
say
what
they
might
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
told
Mrs.
Bunce
,
before
he
left
his
home
after
breakfast
,
that
he
should
for
the
present
remain
under
her
roof
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
much
gratified
,
not
simply
because
lodgings
in
Great
Marlborough
Street
are
less
readily
let
than
chambers
in
Lincoln
's
Inn
,
but
also
because
it
was
a
great
honour
to
her
to
have
a
member
of
Parliament
in
her
house
.
<EOS>
Members
of
Parliament
are
not
so
common
about
Oxford
Street
as
they
are
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Pall
Mall
and
St.
James
's
Square
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Bunce
,
when
he
came
home
to
his
dinner
,
did
not
join
as
heartily
as
he
should
have
done
in
his
wife
's
rejoicing
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bunce
was
in
the
employment
of
certain
copying
law
-
stationers
in
Carey
Street
,
and
had
a
strong
belief
in
the
law
as
a
profession
;
 
but
he
had
none
whatever
in
the
House
of
Commons
.
<EOS>
"
And
he
's
given
up
going
into
chambers
?
"
said
Mr.
Bunce
to
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
Given
it
up
altogether
for
the
present
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bunce
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
he
do
n't
mean
to
have
no
clerk
?
"
said
Mr.
Bunce
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
unless
it
is
for
his
Parliament
work
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
ai
n't
no
clerks
wanted
for
that
,
and
what
's
worse
,
there
ai
n't
no
fees
to
pay
'em
.
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
what
it
is
,
Jane
;
 
if
you
do
n't
look
sharp
there
wo
n't
be
nothing
to
pay
you
before
long
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
he
in
Parliament
,
Jacob
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
ai
n't
no
salary
for
being
in
Parliament
.
<EOS>
There
are
scores
of
them
<EOS>
Parliament
gents
ai
n't
got
so
much
as'll
pay
their
dinners
for
"
em
.
<EOS>
And
then
if
anybody
does
trust
'em
,
there
's
no
getting
at
'em
to
make
'em
pay
as
there
is
at
other
folk
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
our
Mr.
Phineas
will
ever
be
like
that
,
Jacob
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
gammon
,
Jane
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
way
as
women
gets
themselves
took
in
always
.
<EOS>
Our
Mr.
Phineas
!
<EOS>
Why
should
our
Mr.
Phineas
be
better
than
anybody
else
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
always
acted
handsome
,
Jacob
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
was
one
time
he
could
not
pay
his
lodgings
for
wellnigh
nine
months
,
till
his
governor
come
down
with
the
money
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
whether
that
was
handsome
.
<EOS>
It
knocked
me
about
terrible
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
He
always
meant
honest
,
Jacob
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
I
care
much
for
a
man
's
meaning
when
he
runs
short
of
money
.
<EOS>
How
is
he
going
to
see
his
way
,
with
his
seat
in
Parliament
,
and
this
giving
up
of
his
profession
?
<EOS>
He
owes
us
near
a
quarter
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
paid
me
two
months
this
morning
,
Jacob
;
so
he
do
n't
owe
a
farthing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
;
 
so
much
the
better
for
us
.
<EOS>
I
shall
just
have
a
few
words
with
Mr.
Low
,
and
see
what
he
says
to
it
.
<EOS>
For
myself
I
do
n't
think
half
so
much
of
Parliament
folk
as
some
do
.
<EOS>
They
're
for
promising
everything
before
they
's
elected
;
but
not
one
in
twenty
of
'em
is
as
good
as
his
word
when
he
gets
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Bunce
was
a
copying
journeyman
,
who
spent
ten
hours
a
day
in
Carey
Street
with
a
pen
between
his
fingers
;
and
after
that
he
would
often
spend
two
or
three
hours
of
the
night
with
a
pen
between
his
fingers
in
Marlborough
Street
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
thoroughly
hard
-
working
man
,
doing
pretty
well
in
the
world
,
for
he
had
a
good
house
over
his
head
,
and
always
could
find
raiment
and
bread
for
his
wife
and
eight
children
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
he
was
an
unhappy
man
because
he
suffered
from
political
grievances
,
or
,
I
should
more
correctly
say
,
that
his
grievances
were
semi
-
political
and
semi
-
social
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
vote
,
not
being
himself
the
tenant
of
the
house
in
Great
Marlborough
Street
.
<EOS>
The
tenant
was
a
tailor
who
occupied
the
shop
,
whereas
Bunce
occupied
the
whole
of
the
remainder
of
the
premises
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
lodger
,
and
lodgers
were
not
as
yet
trusted
with
the
franchise
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
ideas
,
which
he
himself
admitted
to
be
very
raw
,
as
to
the
injustice
of
the
manner
in
which
he
was
paid
for
his
work
.
<EOS>
So
much
a
folio
,
without
reference
to
the
way
in
which
his
work
was
done
,
without
regard
to
the
success
of
his
work
,
with
no
questions
asked
of
himself
,
was
,
as
he
thought
,
no
proper
way
of
remunerating
a
man
for
his
labours
.
<EOS>
He
had
long
since
joined
a
Trade
Union
,
and
for
two
years
past
had
paid
a
subscription
of
a
shilling
a
week
towards
its
funds
.
<EOS>
He
longed
to
be
doing
some
battle
against
his
superiors
,
and
to
be
putting
himself
in
opposition
to
his
employers
;
 
not
that
he
objected
personally
to
Messrs.
Foolscap
,
Margin
,
and
Vellum
,
who
always
made
much
of
him
as
a
useful
man
;
 
but
because
some
such
antagonism
would
be
manly
,
and
the
fighting
of
some
battle
would
be
the
right
thing
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
If
Labour
do
n't
mean
to
go
to
the
wall
himself
,
"
Bunce
would
say
to
his
wife
,
"
Labour
must
look
alive
,
and
put
somebody
else
there
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bunce
was
a
comfortable
motherly
woman
,
who
loved
her
husband
but
hated
politics
.
<EOS>
As
he
had
an
aversion
to
his
superiors
in
the
world
because
they
were
superiors
,
so
had
she
a
liking
for
them
for
the
same
reason
.
<EOS>
She
despised
people
poorer
than
herself
,
and
thought
it
a
fair
subject
for
boasting
that
her
children
always
had
meat
for
dinner
.
<EOS>
If
it
was
ever
so
small
a
morsel
,
she
took
care
that
they
had
it
,
in
order
that
the
boast
might
be
maintained
.
<EOS>
The
world
had
once
or
twice
been
almost
too
much
for
her
,
 
when
,
for
instance
,
her
husband
had
been
ill
;
and
again
,
to
tell
the
truth
,
for
the
last
three
months
of
that
long
period
in
which
Phineas
had
omitted
to
pay
his
bills
;
but
she
had
kept
a
fine
brave
heart
during
those
troubles
,
and
could
honestly
swear
that
the
children
always
had
a
bit
of
meat
,
though
she
herself
had
been
occasionally
without
it
for
days
together
.
<EOS>
At
such
times
she
would
be
more
than
ordinarily
meek
to
Mr.
Margin
,
and
especially
courteous
to
the
old
lady
who
lodged
in
her
first
-
floor
drawing
-
room
,
 
for
Phineas
lived
up
two
pairs
of
stairs
,
 
and
she
would
excuse
such
servility
by
declaring
that
there
was
no
knowing
how
soon
she
might
want
assistance
.
<EOS>
But
her
husband
,
in
such
emergencies
,
would
become
furious
and
quarrelsome
,
and
would
declare
that
Labour
was
going
to
the
wall
,
and
that
something
very
strong
must
be
done
at
once
.
<EOS>
That
shilling
which
Bunce
paid
weekly
to
the
Union
she
regarded
as
being
absolutely
thrown
away
,
 
as
much
so
as
though
he
cast
it
weekly
into
the
Thames
.
<EOS>
And
she
had
told
him
so
,
over
and
over
again
,
making
heart
-
piercing
allusions
to
the
eight
children
and
to
the
bit
of
meat
.
<EOS>
He
would
always
endeavour
to
explain
to
her
that
there
was
no
other
way
under
the
sun
for
keeping
Labour
from
being
sent
to
the
wall
;
 
but
he
would
do
so
hopelessly
and
altogether
ineffectually
,
and
she
had
come
to
regard
him
as
a
lunatic
to
the
extent
of
that
one
weekly
shilling
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
a
woman
's
instinctive
partiality
for
comeliness
in
a
man
,
and
was
very
fond
of
Phineas
Finn
because
he
was
handsome
.
<EOS>
And
now
she
was
very
proud
of
him
because
he
was
a
member
of
Parliament
.
<EOS>
She
had
heard
,
 
from
her
husband
,
who
had
told
her
the
fact
with
much
disgust
,
 
that
the
sons
of
Dukes
and
Earls
go
into
Parliament
,
and
she
liked
to
think
that
the
fine
young
man
to
whom
she
talked
more
or
less
every
day
should
sit
with
the
sons
of
Dukes
and
Earls
.
<EOS>
When
Phineas
had
really
brought
distress
upon
her
by
owing
her
some
thirty
or
forty
pounds
,
she
could
never
bring
herself
to
be
angry
with
him
,
 
because
he
was
handsome
and
because
he
dined
out
with
Lords
.
<EOS>
And
she
had
triumphed
greatly
over
her
husband
,
who
had
desired
to
be
severe
upon
his
aristocratic
debtor
,
when
the
money
had
all
been
paid
in
a
lump
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
he
's
any
great
catch
,
"
Bunce
had
said
,
when
the
prospect
of
their
lodger
's
departure
had
been
debated
between
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
Jacob
,
"
said
his
wife
,
"
I
do
n't
think
you
feel
it
when
you
've
got
people
respectable
about
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
only
respectable
man
I
know
<EOS>
,
"
said
Jacob
,
"
is
the
man
as
earns
his
bread
;
and
Mr.
Finn
,
as
I
take
it
,
is
a
long
way
from
that
yet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
returned
to
his
lodgings
before
he
went
down
to
his
club
,
and
again
told
Mrs.
Bunce
that
he
had
altogether
made
up
his
mind
about
the
chambers
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
you
'll
keep
me
I
shall
stay
here
for
the
first
session
I
daresay
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
we
shall
be
only
too
proud
,
Mr.
Finn
;
and
though
it
may
n't
perhaps
be
quite
the
place
for
a
member
of
Parliament
 
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
I
think
it
is
quite
the
place
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
good
of
you
to
say
so
,
Mr.
Finn
,
and
we
'll
do
our
very
best
to
make
you
comfortable
.
<EOS>
Respectable
we
are
,
I
may
say
;
and
though
Bunce
is
a
bit
rough
sometimes
 
"
  
"
Never
to
me
,
Mrs.
Bunce
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
is
rough
,
 
and
silly
,
too
,
with
his
radical
nonsense
,
paying
a
shilling
a
week
to
a
nasty
Union
just
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
Still
he
means
well
,
and
there
ai
n't
a
man
who
works
harder
for
his
wife
and
children
;
 
that
I
will
say
of
him
.
<EOS>
And
if
he
do
talk
politics
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
I
like
a
man
to
talk
politics
,
Mrs.
Bunce
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
For
a
gentleman
in
Parliament
of
course
it
's
proper
;
but
I
never
could
see
what
good
it
could
do
to
a
law
-
stationer
;
and
when
he
talks
of
Labour
going
to
the
wall
,
I
always
ask
him
whether
he
did
n't
get
his
wages
regular
last
Saturday
.
<EOS>
But
,
Lord
love
you
,
Mr.
Finn
,
when
a
man
as
is
a
journeyman
has
took
up
politics
and
joined
a
Trade
Union
,
he
ai
n't
no
better
than
a
milestone
for
his
wife
to
take
and
talk
to
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
After
that
Phineas
went
down
to
the
Reform
Club
,
and
made
one
of
those
who
were
buzzing
there
in
little
crowds
and
uttering
their
prophecies
as
to
future
events
.
<EOS>
Lord
de
Terrier
was
to
go
out
.
<EOS>
That
was
certain
.
<EOS>
Whether
Mr.
Mildmay
was
to
come
in
was
uncertain
.
<EOS>
That
he
would
go
to
Windsor
<EOS>
to
-
morrow
morning
was
not
to
be
doubted
;
but
it
was
thought
very
probable
that
he
might
plead
his
age
,
and
decline
to
undertake
the
responsibility
of
forming
a
Ministry
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
then
?
"
said
Phineas
to
his
friend
Fitzgibbon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
there
will
be
a
choice
out
of
three
.
<EOS>
There
is
the
Duke
,
who
is
the
most
incompetent
man
in
England
;
there
is
Monk
,
who
is
the
most
unfit
;
and
there
is
Gresham
,
who
is
the
most
unpopular
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
conceive
it
possible
to
find
a
worse
Prime
Minister
than
either
of
the
three
;
 
but
the
country

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

would
Mildmay
name
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All

,
 
one

,
so
as

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That

's

;
but

that

<EOS>
The
News
about
Mr.
Mildmay
and
Sir
Everard

,

,

"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Such

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
No

,

.

<EOS>

.

Lady

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
It

;

?
"
<EOS>
he

,

.
<EOS>
But

very

,

might

with

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

,
"

;

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
A

,

.

's

,

,

<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

"

,

"

;

,

;

.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas

,

Then

.
"
<EOS>
And

?
"
<EOS>

.

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
 
I

?
"

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

Wait

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
liked

called

Irish
boy
,
and

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

;
"
and

,

,

,
 
to

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Am

nothing

?
<EOS>
To

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

,
 
for

.
<EOS>
I

Kennedy

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
you
did
.
<EOS>
You
knocked
down
my
little
house
,
and
I
must
build
it
all
up
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
trouble
yourself
,
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
a
great
deal
of
trouble
,
 
a
great
deal
,
indeed
;
but
I
shall
take

.
<EOS>
I
mean
you
to
be
very
intimate
with
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
to
shoot
his

,
and
to
stalk

,

.
<EOS>
I

,
as

,
that
he

go

some

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
;
 
I
understand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
believe
that
you
do
understand
at
all
,
but
I
must
endeavour
to
make

do

by

.
<EOS>
If
you
are
to
be
my
political

,
you
must
at
any
rate
be

.
<EOS>
The
next

you
meet
Mr.
Kennedy
,

his

telling

your
own
.
<EOS>
He
has
been
in
Parliament
twelve
years
,
and
he
was
a

than
you
when
he

.
<EOS>
"
At
this

a
side

was

,
and
the
red

,
red

man
whom

had
seen
before
entered

.
<EOS>
He
hesitated
a

,
as

,
and
then
began
to
pull

,

.
<EOS>
And
he
would

had
not

Laura

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oswald
,
"
she

,
"

Finn
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
,
I
do
not

,

Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
Then

.
<EOS>
"
Do

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
Here

Finn

all

.
<EOS>
He

papa
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

is

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of

,
"

,
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
did
,
"
said

,
 
"
with

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
did
,
 
<EOS>
and
I
never

,
for
all
your

.
<EOS>
It
's
the
meanest
trade
going
<EOS>
I
think
,
<EOS>
and
I
'm
sure

's
the
most

.
<EOS>
They
talk
of
legs
on

,
and

;
but

to
the

?
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I

;

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your

.
<EOS>
Of

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
However
,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

Finn

"

<EOS>
"

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
They

,

best

in

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
,
"
said

Laura
,
in

.
<EOS>
"
Oblige

.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
was
engaged
to
dine
with
one
of
the
Vice
-
Chancellors
on
the
day
named
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
before
dined
at
the
house
of
this
great
law
luminary
,
whose
acquaintance
he
had
made
through
Mr.
Low
,
and
he
had
thought
a
great
deal
of
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Freemantle
had
sent
him
the
invitation
nearly
a
fortnight
ago
,
and
he
understood
there
was
to
be
an
elaborate
dinner
party
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
know
it
for
a
fact
,
but
he
was
in
hopes
of
meeting
the
expiring
Lord
Chancellor
.
<EOS>
He
considered
it
to
be
his
duty
never
to
throw
away
such
a
chance
.
<EOS>
He
would
in
all
respects
have
preferred
Mr.
Freemantle
's
dinner
in
Eaton
Place
,
dull
and
heavy
though
it
might
probably
be
,
to
the
chance
of
Lord
Chiltern
's
companions
at
Moroni
's
.
<EOS>
Whatever
might
be
the
faults
of
our
hero
,
he
was
not
given
to
what
is
generally
called
dissipation
by
the
world
at
large
,
 
by
which
the
world
means
self
-
indulgence
.
<EOS>
He
cared
not
a
brass
farthing
for
Moroni
's
Château
Yquem
,
nor
for
the
wondrously
studied
repast
which
he
would
doubtless
find
prepared
for
him
at
that
celebrated
establishment
in
St.
James
's
Street
;
 
not
a
farthing
as
compared
with
the
chance
of
meeting
so
great
a
man
as
Lord
Moles
.
<EOS>
And
Lord
Chiltern
's
friends
might
probably
be
just
the
men
whom
he
would
not
desire
to
know
.
<EOS>
But
Lady
Laura
's
request
overrode
everything
with
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
asked
him
to
oblige
her
,
and
of
course
he
would
do
so
.
<EOS>
Had
he
been
going
to
dine
with
the
incoming
Prime
Minister
,
he
would
have
put
off
his
engagement
at
her
request
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
quick
enough
to
make
an
answer
without
hesitation
;
but
after
a
moment
's
pause
he
said
he
should
be
most

to
dine
with
Lord
Chiltern
at
Moroni
's
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
;
7.30
sharp
,
 
<EOS>
only
I
can
tell
you
you
wo
n't
meet
any
other
members
.
<EOS>
"
Then
the
servant
announced
more
visitors
,
and
Lord
Chiltern
escaped
out
of
the
room
before
he
was
seen
by

new

.
<EOS>
These
were
Mrs.
Bonteen
and
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
,
and
then
Mr.
Bonteen
,
 
and

Mr.
Ratler
,
the
Whip
,
who
was
in

,
and
did

there
a

,

Barrington
Erle
and
young
Lord
James
Fitz
-
Howard
,
the
youngest

of

Duke
of
St.
Bungay
.
<EOS>
In
twenty
or
thirty
minutes
there
was
a

of
liberal

notabilities
in
Lady
Laura
's
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
There
were
two
great
pieces
of
news
by

they
were
all

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
would
not
be
Prime
Minister
,
and
Sir
Everard
Powell
was
 
dead
.
<EOS>
Of
course
nothing
quite
positive
could
be
known
about
Mr.
Mildmay
.
<EOS>
He
was
to
be
with
the
Queen
at
Windsor
on
the
morrow
at
eleven
o'clock
,
and
it
was
improbable
that
he
would
tell

to

before

to
her
Majesty
.
<EOS>
But

that
he
had

"
the
Duke
,
"
 
<EOS>
so

called
by
Lord
James
,
 
to
go
down

with

,
that

.
<EOS>
"
I
have

at
home
,
"
said
Lord
James
,
who
had
just

news
from
his

,
who
had

the

.
<EOS>
Lord
James
was
delighted
with

to

by
his
father
's

.
<EOS>
From
this
,
and

,

was

that
Mr.
Mildmay
would
decline
the
task

to

.
<EOS>
This
,
nevertheless
,
was
only
a
surmise
,
 
whereas

with

Sir
Everard
was
fully

.
<EOS>
The

had

to

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
 
yes
;
as

,
"
said

Ratler
,
who
at

,
however
,

ladies

.
<EOS>
And
then
he
rubbed
his

,
and

as

he
were
delighted
.
<EOS>
And
he
was
delighted
,
 
not
because
his
old
friend
Sir
Everard
was
dead
,
but
by
the

of

.
<EOS>
"
Having

,
"

Fitzgibbon
,
"
we

.
"
<EOS>
"
I

's

,

,
"

Bonteen
;
"
if

is
I
do

.
"
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"

Ratler
.
<EOS>
"
If
a
fellow
dies

we
do
n't

anything
of

.
<EOS>
Sir
Everard
's
vote
was
of
more

than

.
"
<EOS>
But

Mr.
Ratler
was
somewhat
in

,
should

's

Everard
.
  
<EOS>
While

was

Lady
Laura
took

apart
for

.
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
much

to
you
;
I
am

,
"
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
nonsense
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
whether
it
's
nonsense
or

;
 
but
I
am
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
explain
it
all

,
but
I
do
so

you
to
know

brother
.
<EOS>
You
may

,
 
of

.
<EOS>
He
is

.
<EOS>
In
many

is
very

,
 
very
good
.
<EOS>
And
he
is
very

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
I
will
think
and

no
ill
of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Just
so
;
 
do
not
believe
evil
of
him
,
 
not

evil
than
you
see
.
<EOS>
I
am
so
anxious
,
 
so
very

to

him
on

,
and
I

.
<EOS>
Papa
will

,
 
because
of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
is
friends

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I

.
<EOS>
I

how

was
to

to

;
 
and

were

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
One
can
always
get
off
those
sort

things
if

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
just
so
.
<EOS>
And
the
object
was
to
oblige
me
;
 
was
it
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
was
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
go
now
.
<EOS>
We
are
to
hear
Daubeny
's
statement
at
four
,
and
I
would
not
miss

for
worlds
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whether
you
would
go
abroad
with
my
brother
in
the
autumn
?
<EOS>
But
I
have
no
right
to
think
of
such
a
thing
;
 
have
I
?
<EOS>
At
any
rate
I
will
not
think
of
it
yet
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
 
<EOS>
I
shall
see
you
perhaps
on
Sunday
if
you
are
in
town
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
walked
down
to
Westminster
with
his
mind
very
full
of
Lady
Laura
and
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
What
did
she
mean
by
her
affectionate
manner
to
himself
,
and
what
did
she
mean
by
the
continual
praises
which
she
lavished
upon
Mr.
Kennedy
?
<EOS>
Of
whom
was
she
thinking
most
,
of
Mr.
Kennedy
,
or
of
him
?
<EOS>
She
had
called
herself
his
mentor
.
<EOS>
Was
the
description
of
her
feelings
towards
himself
,
as
conveyed
in
that
name
,
of
a
kind
to
be
gratifying
to
him
?
<EOS>
No
;
 
he
thought
not
.
<EOS>
But
then
might
it
not
be
within
his
power
to
change
the
nature
of
those
feelings
?
<EOS>
She
was
not
in
love
with
him
at
present
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
make
any
boast
to
himself
on
that
head
.
<EOS>
But
it
might
be
within
his
power
to
compel
her
to
love
him
.
<EOS>
The
female
mentor
might
be
softened
.
<EOS>
That
she
could
not
love
Mr.
Kennedy
,
he
thought
that
he
was
quite
sure
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
like
love
in
her
manner
to
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
As
to
Lord
Chiltern
,
Phineas
would
do
whatever
might
be
in
his
power
.
<EOS>
All
that
he
really
knew
of
Lord
Chiltern
was
that
he
had
gambled
and
that
he
had
drunk
.
   
<EOS>
The
New
Government
 
<EOS>
In
the
House
of
Lords
that
night
,
and
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
the
outgoing
Ministers
made
their
explanations
.
<EOS>
As
our
business
at
the
present
moment
is
with
the
Commons
,
we
will
confine
ourselves
to
their
chamber
,
and
will
do
so
the
more
willingly
because
the
upshot
of
what
was
said
in
the
two
places
was
the
same
.
<EOS>
The
outgoing
ministers
were
very
grave
,
very
self
-
laudatory
,
and
very
courteous
.
<EOS>
In
regard
to
courtesy
it
may
be
declared
that
no
stranger
to
the
ways
of
the
place
could
have
understood
how
such
soft
words
could
be
spoken
by
Mr.
Daubeny
,
beaten
,
so
quickly
after
the
very
sharp
words
which
he
had
uttered
when
he
only
expected
to
be
beaten
.
<EOS>
He
announced
to
his
fellow
-
commoners
that
his
right
honourable
friend
and
colleague
Lord
de
Terrier
had
thought
it
right
to
retire
from
the
Treasury
.
<EOS>
Lord
de
Terrier
,
in
constitutional
obedience
to
the
vote
of
the
Lower
House
,
had
resigned
,
and
the
Queen
had
been
graciously
pleased
to
accept
Lord
de
Terrier
's
resignation
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Daubeny
could
only
inform
the
House
that
her
Majesty
had
signified
her
pleasure
that
Mr.
Mildmay
should
wait
upon
her
to
-
morrow
at
eleven
o'clock
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
,
 
so
Mr.
Daubeny
understood
,
 
would
be
with
her
Majesty
to
-
morrow
at
that
hour
.
<EOS>
Lord
de
Terrier
had
found
it
to
be
his
duty
to
recommend
her
Majesty
to
send
for
Mr.
Mildmay
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
real
import
of
Mr.
Daubeny
's
speech
.
<EOS>
That
further
portion
of
it
in
which
he
explained
with
blandest
,
most
beneficent
,
honey
-
flowing
words
that
his
party
would
have
done
everything
that
the
country
could
require
of
any
party
,
had
the
House
allowed
it
to
remain
on
the
Treasury
benches
for
a
month
or
two
,
 
and
explained
also
that
his
party
would
never
recriminate
,
would
never
return
evil
for
evil
,
would
in
no
wise
copy
the
factious
opposition
of
their
adversaries
;
that
his
party
would
now
,
as
it
ever
had
done
,
carry
itself
with
the
meekness
of
the
dove
,
and
the
wisdom
of
the
serpent
,
 
all
this
,
I
say
,
was
so
generally
felt
by
gentlemen
on
both
sides
of
the
House
to
be
"
leather
and
prunella
"
that
very
little
attention
was
paid
to
it
.
<EOS>
The
great
point
was
that
Lord
de
Terrier
had
resigned
,
and
that
Mr.
Mildmay
had
been
summoned
to
Windsor
.
  
<EOS>
The
Queen
had
sent
for
Mr.
Mildmay
in
compliance
with
advice
given
to
her
by
Lord
de
Terrier
.
<EOS>
And
yet
Lord
de
Terrier
and
his
first
lieutenant
had
used
all
the
most
practised
efforts
of
their
eloquence
for
the
last
three
days
in
endeavouring
to
make
their
countrymen
believe
that
no
more
unfitting
Minister
than
Mr.
Mildmay
ever
attempted
to
hold
the
reins
of
office
!
<EOS>
Nothing
had
been
too
bad
for
them
to
say
of
Mr.
Mildmay
,
 
and
yet
,
in
the
very
first
moment
in
which
they
found
themselves
unable
to
carry
on
the
Government
themselves
,
they
advised
the
Queen
to
send
for
that
most
incompetent
and
baneful
statesman
!
<EOS>
We
who
are
conversant
with
our
own
methods
of
politics
,
see
nothing
odd
in
this
,
because
we
are
used
to
it
;
but
surely
in
the
eyes
of
strangers
our
practice
must
be
very
singular
.
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
like
it
in
any
other
country
,
 
nothing
as
yet
.
<EOS>
Nowhere
else
is
there
the
same
good
-
humoured
,
affectionate
,
prize
-
fighting
ferocity
in
politics
.
<EOS>
The
leaders
of
our
two
great
parties
are
to
each
other
exactly
as
are
the
two
champions
of
the
ring
who
knock
each
other
about
for
the
belt
and
for
five
hundred
pounds
a
side
once
in
every
two
years
.
<EOS>
How
they
fly
at
each
other
,
striking
as
though
each
blow
should
carry
death
if
it
were
but
possible
!
<EOS>
And
yet
there
is
no
one
whom
the
Birmingham
Bantam
respects
so
highly
as
he
does
<EOS>
Bill
Burns
the
Brighton
Bully
,
or
with
whom
he
has
so
much
delight
in
discussing
the
merits
of
a
pot
of
half
-
and
-
half
.
<EOS>
And
so
it
was
with
Mr.
Daubeny
and
Mr.
Mildmay
.
<EOS>
In
private
life
Mr.
Daubeny
almost
adulated
his
elder
rival
,
 
and
Mr.
Mildmay
never
omitted
an
opportunity
of
taking
Mr.
Daubeny
warmly
by
the
hand
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
so
in
the
United
States
.
<EOS>
There
the
same
political
enmity
exists
,
but
the
political
enmity
produces
private
hatred
.
<EOS>
The
leaders
of
parties
there
really
mean
what
they
say
when
they
abuse
each
other
,
and
are
in
earnest
when
they
talk
as
though
they
were
about
to
tear
each
other
limb
from
limb
.
<EOS>
I
doubt
whether
Mr.
Daubeny
would
have
injured
a
hair
of
Mr.
Mildmay
's
venerable
head
,
even
for
an
assurance
of
six
continued
months
in
office
.
  
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Daubeny
had
completed
his
statement
,
Mr.
Mildmay
simply
told
the
House
that
he
had
received
and
would
obey
her
Majesty
's
commands
.
<EOS>
The
House
would
of
course
understand
that
he
by
no
means
meant
to
aver
that
the
Queen
would
even
commission
him
to
form
a
Ministry
.
<EOS>
But
if
he
took
no
such
command
from
her
Majesty
it
would
become
his
duty
to
recommend
her
Majesty
to
impose
the
task
upon
some
other
person
.
<EOS>
Then
everything
was
said
that
had
to
be
said
,
and
members
returned
to
their
clubs
.
<EOS>
A
certain
damp
was
thrown
over
the
joy
of
some
excitable
Liberals
by
tidings
which
reached
the
House
during
Mr.
Daubeny
's
speech
.
<EOS>
Sir
Everard
Powell
was
no
more
dead
than
was
Mr.
Daubeny
himself
.
<EOS>
Now
it
is
very
unpleasant
to
find
that
your
news
is
untrue
,
when
you
have
been
at
great
pains
to
disseminate
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
he
is
dead
,
"
said
Mr.
Ratler
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Lady
Powell
assured
me
half
an
hour
ago
,
"
said
Mr.
Ratler
's
opponent
,
"
that
he
was
at
that
moment
a
great
deal
better
than
he
had
been
for
the
last
three
months
.
<EOS>
The
journey
down
to
the
House
did
him
a
world
of
good
.
"
<EOS>
"
Then
we
'll
have
him
down
for
every
division
,
"
said
Mr.
Ratler
.
  
<EOS>
The
political
portion
of
London
was
in
a
ferment
for
the
next
five
days
.
<EOS>
On
the
Sunday
morning
it
was
known
that
Mr.
Mildmay
had
declined
to
put
himself
at
the
head
of
a
liberal
Government
.
<EOS>
He
and
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
,
and
Mr.
Plantagenet
Palliser
,
had
been
in
conference
so
often
,
and
so
long
,
that
it
may
almost
be
said
they
lived
together
in
conference
.
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Gresham
had
been
with
Mr.
Mildmay
,
 
and
Mr.
Monk
also
.
<EOS>
At
the
clubs
it
was
said
by
many
that
Mr.
Monk
had
been
with
Mr.
Mildmay
;
but
it
was
also
said
very
vehemently
by
others
that
no
such
interview
had
taken
place
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
was
a
Radical
,
much
admired
by
the
people
,
sitting
in
Parliament
for
that
most
Radical
of
all
constituencies
,
the
Pottery
Hamlets
,
who
had
never
as
yet
been
in
power
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
great
question
of
the
day
whether
Mr.
Mildmay
would
or
would
not
ask
Mr.
Monk
to
join
him
;
and
it
was
said
by
those
who
habitually
think
at
every
period
of
change
that
the
time
has
now
come
in
which
the
difficulties
to
forming
a
government
will
at
last
be
found
to
be
insuperable
,
that
Mr.
Mildmay
could
not
succeed
either
with
Mr.
Monk
or
without
him
.
<EOS>
There
were
at
the
present
moment
two
sections
of
these
gentlemen
,
 
the
section
which
declared
that
Mr.
Mildmay
had
sent
for
Mr.
Monk
,
and
the
section
which
declared
that
he
had
not
.
<EOS>
But
there
were
others
,
who
perhaps
knew
better
what
they
were
saying
,
by
whom
it
was
asserted
that
the
whole
difficulty
lay
with
Mr.
Gresham
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
was
willing
to
serve
with
Mr.
Mildmay
,
 
with
certain
stipulations
as
to
the
special
seat
in
the
Cabinet
which
he
himself
was
to
occupy
,
and
as
to
the
introduction
of
certain
friends
of
his
own
;
but
,
 
so
said
these
gentlemen
who
were
supposed
really
to
understand
the
matter
,
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
was
not
willing
to
serve
with
the
Duke
and
with
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
Now
,
everybody
who
knew
anything
knew
that
the
Duke
and
Mr.
Palliser
were
indispensable
to
Mr.
Mildmay
.
<EOS>
And
a
liberal
Government
,
with
Mr.
Gresham
in
the
opposition
,
could
not
live
half
through
a
session
!
<EOS>
All
Sunday
and
Monday
these
things
were
discussed
;
and
on
the
Monday
Lord
de
Terrier
absolutely
stated
to
the
Upper
House
that
he
had
received
her
Majesty
's
commands
to
form
another
government
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Daubeny
,
in
half
a
dozen
most
modest
words
,
 
in
words
hardly
audible
,
and
most
unlike
himself
,
 
made
his
statement
in
the
Lower
House
to
the
same
effect
.
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Ratler
,
and
Mr.
Bonteen
,
and
Mr.
Barrington
Erle
,
and
Mr.
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
aroused
themselves
and
swore
that
such
things
could
not
be
.
<EOS>
Should
the
prey
which
they
had
won
for
themselves
,
the
spoil
of
their
bows
and
arrows
,
be
snatched
from
out
of
their
very
mouths
by
treachery
?
<EOS>
Lord
de
Terrier
and
Mr.
Daubeny
could
not
venture
even
to
make
another
attempt
unless
they
did
so
in
combination
with
Mr.
Gresham
.
<EOS>
Such
a
combination
,
said
Mr.
Barrington
Erle
,
would
be
disgraceful
to
both
parties
,
but
would
prove
Mr.
Gresham
to
be
as
false
as
Satan
himself
.
<EOS>
Early
on
the
Tuesday
morning
,
when
it
was
known
that
Mr.
Gresham
had
been
at
Lord
de
Terrier
's
house
,
Barrington
Erle
was
free
to
confess
that
he
had
always
been
afraid
of
Mr.
Gresham
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
felt
for
years
,
"
said
he
,
"
that
if
anybody
could
break
up
the
party
it
would
be
Mr.
Gresham
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
On
that
Tuesday
morning
Mr.
Gresham
certainly
was
with
Lord
de
Terrier
,
but
nothing
came
of
it
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
was
either
not
enough
like
Satan
for
the
occasion
,
or
else
he
was
too
closely
like
him
.
<EOS>
Lord
de
Terrier
did
not
bid
high
enough
,
or
else
Mr.
Gresham
did
not
like
biddings
from
that
quarter
.
<EOS>
Nothing
then
came
from
this
attempt
,
and
on
the
Tuesday
afternoon
the
Queen
again
sent
for
Mr.
Mildmay
.
<EOS>
On
the
Wednesday
morning
the
gentlemen
who
thought
that
the
insuperable
difficulties
had
at
length
arrived
,
began
to
wear
their
longest
faces
,
and
to
be
triumphant
with
melancholy
forebodings
.
<EOS>
Now
at
last
there
was
a
dead
lock
.
<EOS>
Nobody
could
form
a
government
.
<EOS>
It
was
asserted
that
Mr.
Mildmay
had
fallen
at
her
Majesty
's
feet
dissolved
in
tears
,
and
had
implored
to
be
relieved
from
further
responsibility
.
<EOS>
It
was
well
known
to
many
at
the
clubs
that
the
Queen
had
on
that
morning
telegraphed
to
Germany
for
advice
.
<EOS>
There
were
men
so
gloomy
as
to
declare
that
the
Queen
must
throw
herself
into
the
arms
of
Mr.
Monk
,
unless
Mr.
Mildmay
would
consent
to
rise
from
his
knees
and
once
more
buckle
on
his
ancient
armour
.
<EOS>
"
Even
that
would
be
better
than
Gresham
,
"
said
Barrington
Erle
,
in
his
anger
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
it
is
,
"
said
Ratler
,
"
we
shall
have
Gresham
and
Monk
together
,
and
you
and
I
shall
have
to
do
their
biddings
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Barrington
Erle
's
reply
to
that
suggestion
I
may
not
dare
to
insert
in
these
pages
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
Wednesday
night
,
however
,
it
was
known
that
everything
had
been
arranged
,
and
before
the
Houses
met
on
the
Thursday
every
place
had
been
bestowed
,
either
in
reality
or
in
imagination
.
<EOS>
The
_
Times
_
,
in
its
second
edition
on
the
Thursday
,
gave
a
list
of
the
Cabinet
,
in
which
four
places
out
of
fourteen
were
rightly
filled
.
<EOS>
On
the
Friday
it
named
ten
places
aright
,
and
indicated
the
law
officers
,
with
only
one
mistake
in
reference
to
Ireland
;
and
on
the
Saturday
it
gave
a
list
of
the
Under
Secretaries
of
State
,
and
Secretaries
and
Vice
-
Presidents
generally
,
with
wonderful
correctness
as
to
the
individuals
,
though
the
offices
were
a
little
jumbled
.
<EOS>
The
Government
was
at
last
formed
in
a
manner
which
everybody
had
seen
to
be
the
only
possible
way
in
which
a
government
could
be
formed
.
<EOS>
Nobody
was
surprised
,
and
the
week
's
work
was
regarded
as
though
the
regular
routine
of
government
making
had
simply
been
followed
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
was
Prime
Minister
;
Mr.
Gresham
was
at
the
Foreign
Office
;
Mr.
Monk
was
at
the
Board
of
Trade
;
the
Duke
was
President
of
the
Council
;
the
Earl
of
Brentford
was
Privy
Seal
;
and
Mr.
Palliser
was
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
.
<EOS>
Barrington
Erle
made
a
step
up
in
the
world
,
and
went
to
the
Admiralty
as
Secretary
;
Mr.
Bonteen
was
sent
again
to
the
Admiralty
;
and
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
became
a
junior
Lord
of
the
Treasury
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Ratler
was
,
of
course
,
installed
as
Patronage
Secretary
to
the
same
Board
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Ratler
was
perhaps
the
only
man
in
the
party
as
to
whose
destination
there
could
not
possibly
be
a
doubt
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Ratler
had
really
qualified
himself
for
a
position
in
such
a
way
as
to
make
all
men
feel
that
he
would
,
as
a
matter

course
,
be
called
upon
to
fill

.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
whether
as
much
could
be
said
on
behalf
of
any
other
man
in
the
new
Government
.
  
<EOS>
During
all

,
and
through
all

movements
,
Phineas
Finn
felt
himself
to
be
left
more
and
more
out
in
the
cold
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
such
a

as
to
suppose
that
any

would

to

.
<EOS>
He
had
never

such

thing
to
his
one

friend
,
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
He
had
not

in

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
when
the
new

was
formed
he
had
not

for
above

.
<EOS>
Of
course
nothing
could
be
done
for
him
as
yet
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
he
felt
himself
to
be
out
in
the
cold
.
<EOS>
The
very
men
who
had
discussed
with

the

the

,
 
who
had

because

was

of
any

,
 
did

.
<EOS>
He
,
at
any
rate
,
could
not

.
<EOS>
He
,
at
any
rate
,
could

.
<EOS>
He
could

nor

.
<EOS>
He

not

,
 
because
he
could
not
himself

.
<EOS>
The

more

,
 
not

,

,

one

,
 
to

.
<EOS>

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
He
would
have

the

.
<EOS>
Robert
Kennedy
for

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas

Kennedy
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
There

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

"
  
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

"

;

.
<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>
Then

<EOS>

The

"

"

,

.
<EOS>
"

;

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
If

,

Kennedy
.
"
   
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
 
<EOS>
It
was
now
the
middle
of
May
,
and
a
month
had
elapsed
since
the
terrible
difficulty
about
the
Queen
's
Government
had
been
solved
.
<EOS>
A
month
had
elapsed
,
and
things
had
shaken
themselves
into
their
places
with
more
of
ease
and
apparent
fitness
than
men
had
given
them
credit
for
possessing
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
,
Mr.
Gresham
,
and
Mr.
Monk
were
the
best
friends
in
the
world
,
swearing
by
each
other
in
their
own
house
,
and
supported
in
the
other
by
as
gallant
a
phalanx
of
Whig
peers
as
ever
were
got
together
to
fight
against
the
instincts
of
their
own
order
in
compliance
with
the
instincts
of
those
below
them
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
's
father
was
in
the
Cabinet
,
to
Lady
Laura
's
infinite
delight
.
<EOS>
It
was
her
ambition
to
be
brought
as
near
to
political
action
as
was
possible
for
a
woman
without
surrendering
any
of
the
privileges
of
feminine
inaction
.
<EOS>
That
women
should
even
wish
to
have
votes
at
parliamentary
elections
was
to
her
abominable
,
and
the
cause
of
the
Rights
of
Women
generally
was
odious
to
her
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
for
herself
,
she
delighted
in
hoping
that
she
too
might
be
useful
,
 
in
thinking
that
she
too
was
perhaps
,
in
some
degree
,
politically
powerful
;
and
she
had
received
considerable
increase
to
such
hopes
when
her
father
accepted
the
Privy
Seal
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
himself
was
not
an
ambitious
man
,
and
,
but
for
his
daughter
,
would
have
severed
himself
altogether
from
political
life
before
this
time
.
<EOS>
He
was
an
unhappy
man
;
 
being
an
obstinate
man
,
and
having
in
his
obstinacy
quarrelled
with
his
only
son
.
<EOS>
In
his
unhappiness
he
would
have
kept
himself
alone
,
living
in
the
country
,
brooding
over
his
wretchedness
,
were
it
not
for
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
On
her
behalf
,
and
in
obedience
to
her
requirements
,
he
came
yearly
up
to
London
,
and
,
perhaps
in
compliance
with
her
persuasion
,
had
taken
some
part
in
the
debates
of
the
House
of
Lords
.
<EOS>
It
is
easy
for
a
peer
to
be
a
statesman
,
if
the
trouble
of
the
life
be
not
too
much
for
him
.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
was
now
a
statesman
,
if
a
seat
in
the
Cabinet
be
proof
of
statesmanship
.
  
<EOS>
At
this
time
,
in
May
,
there
was
staying
with
Lady
Laura
in
Portman
Square
a
very
dear
friend
of
hers
,
by
name
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
was
an
orphan
,
an
heiress
,
and
a
beauty
;
with
a
terrible
aunt
,
one
Lady
Baldock
,
who
was
supposed
to
be
the
dragon
who
had
Violet
,
as
a
captive
maiden
,
in
charge
.
<EOS>
But
as
Miss
Effingham
was
of
age
,
and
was
mistress
of
her
own
fortune
,
Lady
Baldock
was
,
in
truth
,
not
omnipotent
as
a
dragon
should
be
.
<EOS>
The
dragon
,
at
any
rate
,
was
not
now
staying
in
Portman
Square
,
and
the
captivity
of
the
maiden
was
therefore
not
severe
at
the
present
moment
.
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
was
very
pretty
,
but
could
hardly
be
said
to
be
beautiful
.
<EOS>
She
was
small
,
with
light
crispy
hair
,
which
seemed
to
be
ever
on
the
flutter
round
her
brows
,
and
which
yet
was
never
a
hair
astray
.
<EOS>
She
had
sweet
,
soft
grey
eyes
,
which
never
looked
at
you
long
,
hardly
for
a
moment
,
 
but
which
yet
,
in
that
half
moment
,
nearly
killed
you
by
the
power
of
their
sweetness
.
<EOS>
Her
cheek
was
the
softest
thing
in
nature
,
and
the
colour
of
it
,
when
its
colour
was
fixed
enough
to
be
told
,
was
a
shade
of
pink
so
faint
and
creamy
that
you
would
hardly
dare
to
call
it
by
its
name
.
<EOS>
Her
mouth
was
perfect
,
not
small
enough
to
give
that
expression
of
silliness
which
is
so
common
,
but
almost
divine
,
with
the
temptation
of
its
full
,
rich
,
ruby
lips
.
<EOS>
Her
teeth
,
which
she
but
seldom
showed
,
were
very
even
and
very
white
,
and
there
rested
on
her
chin
the
dearest
dimple
that
ever
acted
as
a
loadstar
to
mens
's
eyes
.
<EOS>
The
fault
of
her
face
,
if
it
had
a
fault
,
was
in
her
nose
,
 
which
was
a
little
too
sharp
,
and
perhaps
too
small
.
<EOS>
A
woman
who
wanted
to
depreciate
Violet
Effingham
had
once
called
her
a
pug
-
nosed
puppet
;
but
I
,
as
her
chronicler
,
deny
that
she
was
pug
-
nosed
,
 
and
<EOS>
all
the
world
who
knew
her
soon
came
to
understand
that
she
was
no
puppet
.
<EOS>
In
figure
she
was
small
,
but
not
so
small
as
she
looked
to
be
.
<EOS>
Her
feet
and
hands
were
delicately
fine
,
and
there
was
a
softness
about
her
whole
person
,
an
apparent
compressibility
,
which
seemed
to
indicate
that
she
might
go
into
very
small
compass
.
<EOS>
Into
what
compass
and
<EOS>
how
compressed
,
there
were
very
many
men
who
held
very
different
opinions
.
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
was
certainly
no
puppet
.
<EOS>
She
was
great
at
dancing
,
 
as
perhaps
might
be
a
puppet
,
 
<EOS>
but
she
was
great
also
at
archery
,
great
at
skating
,
 
and
great
,
too
,
at
hunting
.
<EOS>
With
reference
to
that
last
accomplishment
,
she
and
Lady
Baldock
had
had
more
than
one
terrible
tussle
,
not
always
with
advantage
to
the
dragon
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
aunt
,
"
she
had
said
once
during
the
last
winter
,
"
I
am
going
to
the
meet
with
George
,
"
 
George
was
her
cousin
,
Lord
Baldock
,
and
was
the
dragon
's
son
,
 
"
and
there
,
let
there
be
an
end
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
"
And
you
will
promise
me
that
you
will
not
go
further
,
"
said
the
dragon
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
promise
nothing
to
-
day
to
any
man
or
to
any
woman
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
What
was
to
be
said
to
a
young
lady
who
spoke
in
this
way
,
and
who
had
become
of
age
only
a
fortnight
since
?
<EOS>
She
rode
that
day
the
famous
run
from
Bagnall
's
Gorse
to
Foulsham
Common
,
and
was
in
at
the
death
.
  
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
was
now
sitting
in
conference
with
her
friend
Lady
Laura
,
and
they
were
discussing
matters
of
high
import
,
 
of
very
high
import
,
indeed
,
 
to
the
interests
of
both
of
them
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
ask
you
to
accept
him
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
lucky
,
"
said
the
other
,
"
as
he
has
never
asked
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
done
much
the
same
.
<EOS>
You
know
that
he
loves
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
,
 
or
fancy
that
I
know
,
 
that
so
many
men
love
me
!
<EOS>
But
,
after
all
,
what
sort
of
love
is
it
?
<EOS>
It
is
just
as
when
you
and
I
,
when
we
see
something
nice
in
a
shop
,
call
it
a
dear

of
a
thing
,
and
tell

to
go
and
buy

,
let
the
price
be
ever
so
extravagant
.
<EOS>
I
know
my
own
position
,
Laura
.
<EOS>
I
'm
a
dear
duck
of
a
thing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

or
I

<EOS>
have
already
,

.
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"

Do

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Then

.
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham

<EOS>

this

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

;
 
<EOS>

It

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

Well

"

?
<EOS>
I

;

House
,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
When
I
was
a
child
they
used
to
be
always
telling
me
to
mind
myself
.
<EOS>
It
seems
to
me
that
a
child
and
a
man
need
not
mind
themselves
.
<EOS>
Let
them
do
what
they
may
,
they
can
be
set
right
again
.
<EOS>
Let
them
fall
as
they
will
,
you
can
put
them
on
their
feet
.
<EOS>
But
a
woman
has
to
mind
herself
;
 
and
very
hard
work
<EOS>
it
is
when
she
has
a
dragon
of
her
own
driving
her
ever
the
wrong
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
take
you
from
the
dragon
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;
 
and
to
hand
me
over
to
a
griffin
.
"
  
"
The
truth
is
,
Violet
,
that
you
do
not
know
Oswald
.
<EOS>
He
is
not
a
griffin
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
mean
to
be
uncomplimentary
.
<EOS>
Take
any
of
the
dangerous
wild
beasts
you
please
.
<EOS>
I
merely
intend
to
point
out
that
he
is
a
dangerous
wild
beast
.
<EOS>
I
daresay
he
is
noble
-
minded
,
and
I
will
call
him
a
lion
if
you
like
it
better
.
<EOS>
But
even
with
a
lion
there
is
risk
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
there
will

risk
.
<EOS>
There

risk
with
every
man
,
 
unless
you
will
be
contented
with
the
prig
you
described
.
<EOS>
Of
course
there
would
be
risk
with
my
brother
.
<EOS>
He
has
been
a
gambler
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
say
he
is
one
still
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
given
it
up
in
part
,
and
would
entirely
at
your

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
they
say
other

of
him
,
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
true
.
<EOS>
He
has
had
paroxysms
of
evil
life
which
have
well
-
nigh

him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
these
paroxysms
are
so
dangerous
!
<EOS>
Is
he
not
in
debt
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
,
 
but
not
deeply
.
<EOS>
Every
shilling
that
he
owes
would
be
paid
;
 
every

.
<EOS>
Mind
,
I
know
all

,
and
I
give
you
my
word
that
every
shilling
should
be
paid
.
<EOS>
He
has
never
lied
,
 
and
he
has
told
me
everything
.
<EOS>
His
father
could
not
leave
an
acre
away
from
him
if
he
would
,
and
would
not
if
he
could
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
ask
as
fearing
that
.
<EOS>
I
spoke
only
of
a
dangerous
habit
.
<EOS>
A

of
spending
money
is
apt
to

.
<EOS>
And
then
 
"
  
"
Well
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

I

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not

.
<EOS>
People

.
<EOS>
The
dragon
says

.
<EOS>
And
as
I
always
find
her

to

,
I
suppose

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
see
,
if
I
am
to
be
his
wife
,
it
is
 
rather

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Still
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Laura
,
you
know
I
do
not

.
<EOS>
You
know
I
love
you
for
what

.
<EOS>
Would

,
and
fight

him
down

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

want

Oswald
's
wife
;
 
because
I
know
that
you
would
fight

him
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
true
that
he
is
a
 
drunkard
.
<EOS>
Look

hand
,
which
is
as

.
<EOS>
Look

.
<EOS>
Is
there

sign
of
it
?
<EOS>
He
has
been
drunk
,
once

,

,
 
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
never

man

.
<EOS>
I
believe

that

,

.

"
  
<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of

.
<EOS>
Is

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
men
in
the
city
would
call
this
double
-
dangerous
,
I
think
,
"
said
