.
<EOS>
Then
the
door
was
opened
,
and
the
man
of
whom
they
were
speaking
entered
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
 
<EOS>
The
reader
has
been
told
that
Lord
Chiltern
was
a
red
man
,
and
that
peculiarity
of
his
personal
appearance
was
certainly
the
first
to
strike
a
stranger
.
<EOS>
It
imparted
a
certain
look
of
ferocity
to
him
,
which
was
apt
to
make
men
afraid
of
him
at
first
sight
.
<EOS>
Women
are
not
actuated
in
the
same
way
,
and
are
accustomed
to
look
deeper
into
men
at
the
first
sight
than
other
men
will
trouble
themselves
to
do
.
<EOS>
His
beard
was
red
,
and
was
clipped
,
so
as
to
have
none
of
the
softness
of
waving
hair
.
<EOS>
The
hair
on
his
head
also
was
kept
short
,
and
was
very
red
,
 
and
the
colour
of
his
face
was
red
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
he
was
a
handsome
man
,
with
well
-
cut
features
,
not
tall
,
but
very
strongly
built
,
and
with
a
certain
curl
in
the
corner
of
his
eyelids
which
gave
to
him
a
look
of
resolution
,
 
which
perhaps
he
did
not
possess
.
<EOS>
He
was
known
to
be
a
clever
man
,
and
when
very
young
had
had
the
reputation
of
being
a
scholar
.
<EOS>
When
he
was
three
-
and
-
twenty
grey
-
haired
votaries
of
the
turf
declared
that
he
would
make
his
fortune
on
the
race
-
course
,
 
so
clear
-
headed
was
he
as
to
odds
,
so
excellent
a
judge
of
a
horse
's
performances
,
and
so
gifted
with
a
memory
of
events
.
<EOS>
When
he
was
five
-
and
-
twenty
<EOS>
he
had
lost
every
shilling
of
a
fortune
of
his
own
,
had
squeezed
from
his
father
more
than
his
father
ever
chose
to
name
in
speaking
of
his
affairs
to
any
one
,
and
was
known
to
be
in
debt
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
sacrificed
himself
on
one
or
two
memorable
occasions
in
conformity
with
turf
laws
of
honour
,
and
men
said
of
him
,
either
that
he
was
very
honest
or
very
chivalric
,
 
in
accordance
with
the
special
views
on
the
subject
of
the
man
who
was
speaking
.
<EOS>
It
was
reported
now
that
he
no
longer
owned
horses
on
the
turf
;
 
but
this
was
doubted
by
some
who
could
name
the
animals
which
they
said
that
he
owned
,
and
which
he
ran
in
the
name
of
Mr.
Macnab
,
 
<EOS>
said
some
;
of
Mr.
Pardoe
,
 
said
others
;
of
Mr.
Chickerwick
<EOS>
,
 
said
a
third
set
of
informants
.
<EOS>
The
fact
was
that
Lord
Chiltern
at
this
moment
had
no
interest
of
his
own
in
any
horse
upon
the
turf
.
  
<EOS>
But
all
the
world
knew
that
he
drank
.
<EOS>
He
had
taken
by
the
throat
a
proctor
's
bull
-
dog
when
he
had
been
drunk
at
Oxford
,
had
nearly
strangled
the
man
,
and
had
been
expelled
.
<EOS>
He
had
fallen
through
his
violence
into
some
terrible
misfortune
at
Paris
,
had
been
brought
before
a
public
judge
,
and
his
name
and
his
infamy
had
been
made
notorious
in
every
newspaper
in
the
two
capitals
.
<EOS>
After
that
he
had
fought
a
ruffian
at
Newmarket
,
and
had
really
killed
him
with
his
fists
.
<EOS>
In
reference
to
this
latter
affray
it
had
been
proved
that
the
attack
had
been
made
on
him
,
that
he
had
not
been
to
blame
,
and
that
he
had
not
been
drunk
.
<EOS>
After
a
prolonged
investigation
he
had
come
forth
from
that
affair
without
disgrace
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
done
so
,
at
least
,
if
he
had
not
been
heretofore
disgraced
.
<EOS>
But
we
all
know
how
the
man
well
spoken
of
may
steal
a
horse
,
while
he
who
is
of
evil
repute
may
not
look
over
a
hedge
.
<EOS>
It
was
asserted
widely
by
many
who
were
supposed
to
know
all
about
everything
that
Lord
Chiltern
was
in
a
fit
of
delirium
tremens
when
he
killed
the
ruffian
at
Newmarket
.
<EOS>
The
worst
of
that
latter
affair
was
that
it
produced
the
total
estrangement
which
now
existed
between
Lord
Brentford
and
his
son
.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
would
not
believe
that
his
son
was
in
that
matter
more
sinned
against
than
sinning
.
<EOS>
"
Such
things
do
not
happen
to
other
men
's
sons
,
"
he
said
,
when
Lady
Laura
pleaded
for
her
brother
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
could
not
induce
her
father
to
see
his
son
,
but
so
far
prevailed
that
no
sentence
of
banishment
was
pronounced
against
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
to
prevent
the
son
sitting
at
his
father
's
table
if
he
so
pleased
.
<EOS>
He
never
did
so
please
,
 
but
nevertheless
he
continued
to
live
in
the
house
in
Portman
Square
;
and
when
he
met
the
Earl
,
in
the
hall
,
perhaps
,
or
on
the
staircase
,
would
simply
bow
to
him
.
<EOS>
Then
the
Earl
would
bow
again
,
and
shuffle
on
,
 
and
look
very
wretched
,
as
no
doubt
he
was
.
<EOS>
A
grown
-
up
son
must
be
the
greatest
comfort
a
man
can
have
,
 
if
he
be
his
father
's
best
friend
;
but
otherwise
he
can
hardly
be
a
comfort
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
in
this
house
,
the
son
was
a
constant
thorn
in
his
father
's
side
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
does
he
do
when
we
leave
London
?
"
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
once
said
to
his
daughter
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
stays
here
,
papa
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
hunts
still
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
he
hunts
,
 
and
he
has
a
room
somewhere
at
an
inn
,
 
down
in
Northamptonshire
.
<EOS>
But
he
is
mostly
in
London
.
<EOS>
They
have
trains
on
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
life
for
my
son
!
"
said
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
a
life
!
<EOS>
Of
course
no
decent
person
will
let
him
into
his
house
.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
did
not
know
what
to
say
to
this
,
for
in
truth
Lord
Chiltern
was
not
fond
of
staying
at
the
houses
of
persons
whom
the
Earl
would
have
called
decent
.
  
<EOS>
General
Effingham
,
the
father
of
Violet
,
and
Lord
Brentford
had
been
the
closest
and
dearest
of
friends
.
<EOS>
They
had
been
young
men
in
the
same
regiment
,
and
through
life
each
had
confided
in
the
other
.
<EOS>
When
the
General
's
only
son
,
then
a
youth
of
seventeen
,
was
killed
in
one
of
our
grand
New
Zealand
wars
,
the
bereaved
father
and
the
Earl
had
been
together
for
a
month
in
their
sorrow
.
<EOS>
At
that
time
Lord
Chiltern
's
career
had
still
been
open
to
hope
,
 
and
the
one
man
had
contrasted
his
lot
with
the
other
.
<EOS>
General
Effingham
lived
long
enough
to
hear
the
Earl
declare
that
his
lot
was
the
happier
of
the
two
.
<EOS>
Now
the
General
was
dead
,
and
Violet
,
the
daughter
of
a
second
wife
,
was
all
that
was
left
of
the
Effinghams
.
<EOS>
This
second
wife
had
been
a
Miss
Plummer
,
a
lady
from
the
city
with
much
money
,
whose
sister
had
married
Lord
Baldock
.
<EOS>
Violet
in
this
way
had
fallen
to
the
care
of
the
Baldock
people
,
and
not
into
the
hands
of
her
father
's
friends
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
the
reader
will
have
surmised
,
she
had
ideas
of
her
own
of
emancipating
herself
from
Baldock
thraldom
.
  
<EOS>
Twice
before
that
last
terrible
affair
at
Newmarket
,
before
the
quarrel
between
the
father
and
the
son
had
been
complete
,
Lord
Brentford
had
said
a
word
to
his
daughter
,
 
merely
a
word
,
 
of
his
son
in
connection
with
Miss
Effingham
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
he
thinks
of
it
I
shall
be
glad
to
see
him
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
You
may
tell
him
so
.
<EOS>
"
That
had
been
the
first
word
.
<EOS>
He
had
just
then
resolved
that
the
affair
in
Paris
should
be
regarded
as
condoned
,
 
as
among
the
things
to
be
forgotten
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
too
good
for
him
;
but
if
he
asks
her
let
him
tell
her
everything
.
<EOS>
"
That
had
been
the
second
word
,
and
had
been
spoken
immediately
subsequent
to
a
payment
of
twelve
thousand
pounds
made
by
the
Earl
towards
the
settlement
of
certain
Doncaster
accounts
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
in
negotiating
for
the
money
had
been
very
eloquent
in
describing
some
honest
,
 
or
shall
we
say
chivalric
,
 
sacrifice
which
had
brought
her
brother
into
this
special
difficulty
.
<EOS>
Since
that
the
Earl
had
declined
to
interest
himself
in
his
son
's
matrimonial
affairs
;
and
when
Lady
Laura
had
once
again
mentioned
the
matter
,
declaring
her
belief
that
it
would
be
the
means
of
saving
her
brother
Oswald
,
the
Earl
had
desired
her
to
be
silent
.
"
<EOS>
Would
you
wish
to
destroy
the
poor
child
?
<EOS>
"
he
had
said
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
Lady
Laura
felt
sure
that
if
she
were
to
go
to
her
father
with
a
positive
statement
that
Oswald
and
Violet
were
engaged
,
he
would
relent
and
would
accept
Violet
as
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
As
for
the
payment
of
Lord
Chiltern
's
present
debts
;
 
she
had
a
little
scheme
of
her
own
about
that
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Effingham
,
who
had
been
already
two
days
in
Portman
Square
,
had
not
as
yet
seen
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
he
lived
in
the
house
,
that
is
,
that
he
slept
there
,
and
probably
eat
his
breakfast
in
some
apartment
of
his
own
;
 
but
she
knew
also
that
the
habits
of
the
house
would
not
by
any
means
make
it
necessary
that
they
should
meet
.
<EOS>
Laura
and
her
brother
probably
saw
each
other
daily
,
 
but
they
never
went
into
society
together
,
and
did
not
know
the
same
sets
of
people
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
announced
to
Lady
Baldock
her
intention
of
spending
the
first
fortnight
of
her
London
season
with
her
friend
Lady
Laura
<EOS>
,
Lady
Baldock
had
as
a
matter
of
course
 
"
jumped
upon
her
,
"
as
Miss
Effingham
would
herself
call
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
going
to
the
house
of
the
worst
reprobate
in
all
England
,
"
said
Lady
Baldock
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
;
 
dear
old
Lord
Brentford
,
whom
papa
loved
so
well
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
Lord
Chiltern
,
who
,
only
last
year
,
 
murdered
a
man
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
not
true
,
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
worse
than
that
,
 
much
worse
.
<EOS>
He
is
always
 
tipsy
,
and
always
gambling
,
and
always---
<EOS>
But
it
is
quite
unfit
that
I
should
speak
a

about
such
a
man
as
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
His
name
ought

to

mentioned
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
did
you
mention

,
aunt
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
's
process
of
jumping
upon
her
niece
,
 
in
which
I
think
the
aunt
had
generally
the
worst
of
the
exercise
<EOS>
,
 
went

some

,
but
Violet
of

her
point
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
she
marries
him
there
will
be
an
end

,
"
said
Lady
Baldock
to

Augusta
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
has

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

has
any

,
"
said
Lady
Baldock
;
 
"
not
in

least
.
<EOS>
I
do
wish
my
poor
sister
had
lived
;
 
I
do
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
was
now
in

room
with
Violet
,
 
immediately
upon
that
conversation
between
Violet
and
his
sister
as
to
the

of
Violet

his
wife
.
<EOS>
Indeed

had

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
Miss

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
came

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Here

,
as

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Laura

the

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

a

's

had

.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
's
hand
was
like
the

any

,
but
there
was
something
in

eye
that

.
<EOS>
It

would

round
,

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

.
<EOS>
No
;
 
she

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

;

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

?
"

<EOS>
He

.
"
<EOS>
Because

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

Blink

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
His

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,

,

,
"

Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Failing
our

of

,
I

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
were

Miss
Effingham
then
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
 
not
as
yet
.
<EOS>
These
disagreeable

of
life
grow
upon

;

?
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
I

's

now
.
<EOS>
And
Miss
Blink
the
mild

for
Lady

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
And
so

see
everything
is
changed
as
well
as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Everything
is
not

,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
,
getting

from

.
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
changed
,
 
at
least

in
this
,
that

loved
you
better
than
any

,
 
better

Laura
there
,
 
so
do
I

you
now

best

.
<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>
You

;
 
and

.
<EOS>
There

among

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
Lord
Chiltern
,
 
"
said
Miss
Effingham
,
rising
also
to

,
and
then

,
not

answer

.
<EOS>
There
had
been
a

in
his
mode
of
addressing
her
which
had
,
so
to
say
,
almost
taken

;
and
then
to

told
by
a
man
of
his

was
in

,
to

,
a

,
that
none

came
at
her
command
which
will

,
as
though

,
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
known

always
,
"

,
as
though

were

.
  
<EOS>
"
Lord
Chiltern
,
"
she

,
"
you
must

me
if
I
say
that
you
are
,
at
the
least
,
very

.
<EOS>
I

I
was

so

to

that
you
would
turn

on

in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
said
nothing
that
ought
to

,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Only
because

has

.
<EOS>
Lord

,
I

.
<EOS>
As

old

I
have
always

you
,
and
I
hope
that
I
may
always
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
Then
she
got
up
and
left
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
were
you
so
sudden
with
her
,
 
so
abrupt
,
 
so
loud
?
"
said
his
sister
,
coming
up
to

and
taking

by

arm
almost
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
make
no
difference
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
She
does
not
care
for
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
makes
all

difference
in
the
world
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
Such
a
woman
as
Violet

not

after
that
fashion
.
<EOS>
You
must
begin
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
begun
and
ended
,
"
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
nonsense
.
<EOS>
Of
course
you
will
persist
.
<EOS>
It
was
madness
to
speak
in

to
-
day
.
<EOS>
You
may

this
,

,
that

than

.
<EOS>
You
must

that
you
have

much
to

any
girl

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

now
to
make

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

else

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Am
I
to
tell

a
lie
?
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
,
looking
his
sister
full
in
the
face
.
<EOS>
Then
he
turned
upon
his
heel
and
left
her
.
   
<EOS>
Autumnal
Prospects
 
<EOS>
The
session
went
on
very
calmly
after
the
opening
battle
which
ousted
Lord
de
Terrier
and
sent
Mr.
Mildmay
back
to
the
Treasury
,
 
so
calmly
that
Phineas
Finn
was
unconsciously
disappointed
,
as
lacking
that
excitement
of
contest
to
which
he
had
been
introduced
in
the
first
days
of
his
parliamentary
career
.
<EOS>
From
time
to
time
certain
waspish
attacks
were
made
by
Mr.
Daubeny
,
now
on
this
Secretary
of
State
and
now
on
that
;
but
they
were
felt
by
both
parties
to
mean
nothing
;
and
as
no
great
measure
was
brought
forward
,
nothing
which
would
serve
by
the
magnitude
of
its
interests
to
divide
the
liberal
side
of
the
House
into
fractions
,
Mr.
Mildmay
's
Cabinet
was
allowed
to
hold
its
own
in
comparative
peace
and
quiet
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
July
,
 
the
middle
of
July
,
 
and
the
member
for
Loughshane
had
not
yet
addressed
the
House
.
<EOS>
How
often
had
he
meditated
doing
so
;
how
he
had
composed
his
speeches
walking
round
the
Park
on
his
way
down
to
the
House
;
how
he
got
his
subjects
up
,
 
only
to
find
on
hearing
them
discussed
that
he
really
knew
little
or
nothing
about
them
;
how
he
had
his
arguments
and
almost
his
very
words
taken
out
of
his
mouth
by
some
other
member
;
and
lastly
,
how
he
had
actually
been
deterred
from
getting
upon
his
legs
by
a
certain
tremor
of
blood
<EOS>
round
his
heart
when
the
moment
for
rising
had
come
,
 
of
all
this
<EOS>
he
never
said
a
word
to
any
man
.
<EOS>
Since
that
last
journey
to
county
Mayo
,
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
had
been
his
most
intimate
friend
,
but
he
said
nothing
of
all
this
even
to
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
To
his
other
friend
,
Lady
Laura
Standish
,
he
did
explain
something
of
his
feelings
,
not
absolutely
describing
to
her
the
extent
of
hindrance
to
which
his
modesty
had
subjected
him
,
but
letting
her
know
that
he
had
his
qualms
as
well
as
his
aspirations
.
<EOS>
But
as
Lady
Laura
always
recommended
patience
,
and
more
than
once
expressed
her
opinion
that
a
young
member
would
be
better
to
sit
in
silence
at
least
for
one
session
,
he
was
not
driven
to
the
mortification
of
feeling
that
he
was
incurring
her
contempt
by
his
bashfulness
.
<EOS>
As
regarded
the
men
among
whom
he
lived
,
I
think
he
was
almost
annoyed
at
finding
that
no
one
seemed
to
expect
that
he
should
speak
.
<EOS>
Barrington
Erle
,
when
he
had
first
talked
of
sending
Phineas
down
to
Loughshane
,
had
predicted
for
him
all
manner
of
parliamentary
successes
,
and
had
expressed
the
warmest
admiration
of
the
manner
in
which
Phineas
had
discussed
this
or
that
subject
at
the
Union
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
not
above
one
or
two
men
in
the
House
who
can
do
that
kind
of
thing
,
"
Barrington
Erle
had
once
said
.
<EOS>
But
now
no
allusions
whatever
were
made
to
his
powers
of
speech
,
and
Phineas
in
his
modest
moments
began
to
be
more
amazed
than
ever
that
he
should
find
himself
seated
in
that
chamber
.
  
<EOS>
To
the
forms
and
technicalities
of
parliamentary
business
he
did
give
close
attention
,
and
was
unremitting
in
his
attendance
.
<EOS>
On
one
or
two
occasions
he
ventured
to
ask
a
question
of
the
Speaker
,
and
as
the
words
of
experience
fell
into
his
ears
,
he
would
tell
himself
that
he
was
going
through
his
education
,
 
that
he
was
learning
to
be
a
working
member
,
and
perhaps
to
be
a
statesman
.
<EOS>
But
his
regrets
with
reference
to
Mr.
Low
and
the
dingy
chambers
in
Old
Square
were
very
frequent
;
and
had
it
been
possible
for
him
to
undo
all
that
he
had
done
,
he
would
often
have
abandoned
to
some
one
else
the
honour
of
representing
the
electors
of
Loughshane
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
was
supported
in
all
his
difficulties
by
the
kindness
of
his
friend
,
Lady
Laura
Standish
.
<EOS>
He
was
often
in
the
house
in
Portman
Square
,
and
was
always
received
with
cordiality
,
and
,
as
he
thought
,
almost
with
affection
.
<EOS>
She
would
sit
and
talk
to
him
,
sometimes
saying
a
word
about
her
brother
and
sometimes
about
her
father
,
as
though
there
were
more
between
them
than
the
casual
intimacy
of
London
acquaintance
.
<EOS>
And
in
Portman
Square
he
had
been
introduced
to
Miss
Effingham
,
and
had
found
Miss
Effingham
to
be
 
very
nice
.
<EOS>
Miss
Effingham
had
quite
taken
to
him
,
and
he
had
danced
with
her
at
two
or
three
parties
,
talking
always
,
as
he
did
so
,
about
Lady
Laura
Standish
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
declare
,
Laura
,
I
think
your
friend
Mr.
Finn
is
in
love
with
you
,
"
said
Violet
to
Lady
Laura
one
night
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
that
.
<EOS>
He
is
fond
of
me
,
and
so
am
I
of
him
.
<EOS>
He
is
so
honest
,
and
so
naïve
without
being
awkward
!
<EOS>
And
then
he
is
undoubtedly
clever
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
so
uncommonly
handsome
,
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
that
makes
much

,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
does
if
a
man
looks
like
a
gentleman
as
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Finn
certainly
looks
like
a
gentleman
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
no
doubt
is
one
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whether
he
has
got
any
money
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
penny
,
I
should
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
does
such
a
man
manage
to
live
?
<EOS>
There
are
so
many
men
like
that
,
and
they
are
always
mysteries
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
he
'll
have
to
marry
an
heiress
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whoever
gets
him
will
not
have
a
bad
husband
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
Standish
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
during
the
summer
had
very
often
met
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
They
sat
on
the
same
side
of
the
House
,
they
belonged
to
the
same
club
,
they

together
more
than
once
in
Portman
Square
,
and
on
one

Phineas
had
accepted
an
invitation
to
dinner
sent
to
him
by
Mr.
Kennedy
himself
.
"
<EOS>
A
slower
affair
I
never
saw
in
my
life
<EOS>
,
"
he
said
afterwards
to
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
"
Though
there
were
two

three
men
there
who
talk
everywhere
else
,
they
could
not
talk
at

.
"
<EOS>
"
He
gave
you
good
wine
,
I
should
say
,
"
said
Fitzgibbon
,
"
and
let
me
tell
you
that
that
covers
a
multitude
of

.
<EOS>
"
In
spite
,
however
,
of
all
these
opportunities
for
intimacy
,
now
,
nearly
at
the
end
of
the
session
,
Phineas
had
hardly
spoken
a
dozen
words
to
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
really
knew
nothing
whatsoever
of
the
man
,
as
one
friend
,
 
or
even
as
one
acquaintance
knows
another
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
had
desired
him
to
be
on
good
terms
with
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
for
that
reason
he
had
dined
with
him
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
he
disliked
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
felt
quite
sure
that
Mr.
Kennedy
disliked
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
therefore
rather
surprised
when
he
received
the
following
note
:
    
Albany
,
Z
3
,
July
17
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
MY
DEAR
MR
.
<EOS>
FINN
,
  
<EOS>
I
shall
have
some
friends
at
Loughlinter
next
month
,
and
should
be
very

if
you
will

.
<EOS>
I
will
name
the
16th
August
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
whether
you
shoot
,
but
there
are
grouse
and
deer
.
  
<EOS>
Yours
truly
,
  
ROBERT
KENNEDY
.
  
<EOS>
What
was
he
to
do
?
<EOS>
He
had
already
begun
to
feel
rather
uncomfortable
at
the
prospect
of
being
separated
from
all
his
new
friends
as
soon
as
the
session
should
be
over
.
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibhon
had
asked
him
to
make
another
visit
to
county
Mayo
,
but
that
he
had
declined
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
had
said
something
to
him
about
going
abroad
with
her
brother
,
and
since
that
there
had
sprung
up
a
sort
of
intimacy
between
him
and
Lord
Chiltern
;
but
nothing
had
been
fixed
about
this
foreign
trip
,
and
there
were
pecuniary
objections
to
it
which
put
it
almost
out
of
his
power
.
<EOS>
The
Christmas
holidays
he
would
of
course
pass
with
his
family
at
Killaloe
,
but
he
hardly
liked
the
idea
of
hurrying
off
to
Killaloe
immediately
the
session
should
be
over
.
<EOS>
Everybody
around
him
seemed
to
be
looking
forward
to
pleasant
leisure
doings
in
the
country
.
<EOS>
Men
talked
about
grouse
,
and
of
the
ladies
at
the
houses
to
which
they
were
going
and
of
the
people
whom
they
were
to
meet
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
had
said
nothing
of
her
own
movements
for
the
early
autumn
,
and
no
invitation
had
come
to
him
to
go
to
the
Earl
's
country
house
.
<EOS>
He
had
already
felt
that
every
one
would
depart
and
that
he
would
be
left
,
 
and
this
had
made
him
uncomfortable
.
<EOS>
What
was
he
to
do
with
the
invitation
from
Mr.
Kennedy
?
<EOS>
He
disliked
the
man
,
and
had
told
himself
half
a
dozen
times
that
he
despised
him
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
must
refuse
it
.
<EOS>
Even
for
the
sake
of
the
scenery
,
and
the
grouse
,
and
the
pleasant
party
,
and
the
feeling
that
going
to
Loughlinter
in
August
would
be
the
proper
sort
of
thing
to
do
,
he
must
refuse
it
!
<EOS>
But
it
occurred
to
him
at
last
that
he
would
call
in
Portman
Square
before
he
wrote
his
note
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
will
go
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
in
her
most

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
the
first
place
it
is
civil
in
him
to
ask
you
,
and
why
should
you

uncivil
in

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
uncivil
in
not

a
man
's

,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
going
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
can
only
say
that
I
shall

not
go
too
.
<EOS>
Both
Mr.
Gresham
and
Mr.
Monk
will

,

I

have
never

before
.
<EOS>
I

no

are
a

the
House
who
would
give

to

.
<EOS>
Of

will
go
.
"
  
<EOS>
Of
course
he
did
go
.
<EOS>
The
note
accepting
Mr.
Kennedy
's
invitation
was
written
at
the
Reform
Club
within

of

leaving

.
<EOS>
He
was
very
careful
in
writing
to
be
not
more

civil
than
Mr.
Kennedy
had
been
to

,
and
then
he
signed
himself
"
<EOS>
Yours
truly
,
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
another
proposition
was
made
to
him
,
and
a
most
charming
proposition
,
during
the
few

that

in
Portman
Square
.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said

Laura
,
"

Saulsby

.
<EOS>
Till

fixed
I

n't

Saulsby
for

;
and
there
wo
n't

room

Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas

but

,

.
"
<EOS>
Very

;
come

13th

.
<EOS>
You

15th
,

.
<EOS>
And

,
Mr.
Finn
,
we

at
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
declared
that
he
did
not

a
straw
for

.
  
<EOS>
There
was
another
little
occurrence
which
happened
before
Phineas
left
London
,
and
which
was
not
altogether
so

as
his

at
Saulsby

.
<EOS>
Early
in

,
when
the
session
was
still

,
he

with
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
at
the
Reform
Club
.
<EOS>
Laurence
had
specially
invited
him
to
do

,
and
made

much
of
him
on

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
George
,
my
dear
fellow
,
"
Laurence
said
to
him
that
morning
,
"
nothing
has
happened
to
me
this
session
that
has
given
me
so
much
pleasure
as
your
being
in
the
House
.
<EOS>
Of
course
there
are
fellows
with
whom
one
is
very
intimate
and
of
whom
one
is
very
fond
,
 
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
.
<EOS>
But
most
of
these
Englishmen
on
our
side
are
such
cold
fellows
;
or
else
they
are
like
Ratler
and
Barrington
Erle
,
thinking
of
nothing
but
politics
.
<EOS>
And
then
as
to
our
own
men
,
there
are
so
many
of
them
one
can
hardly
trust
!
<EOS>
That
's
the
truth
of
it
.
<EOS>
Your
being
in
the
House
has
been
such
a
comfort
to
me
!
"
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
really
liked
his
friend
Laurence
,
expressed
himself
very
warmly
in
answer
to
this
,
and
became
affectionate
,
and
made
sundry
protestations
of
friendship
which
were
perfectly
sincere
.
<EOS>
Their
sincerity
was
tested
after
dinner
,
when
Fitzgibbon
,
as
they
two
were
seated
on
a
sofa
in
the
corner
of
the
smoking
-
room
,
asked
Phineas
to
put
his
name
to
the
back
of
a
bill
for
two
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
at
six
months
'
date
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
dear
Laurence
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
two
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
is
a
sum
of
money
utterly
beyond
my
reach
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Exactly
,
my
dear
boy
,
and
that
's
why
I
've
come
to
you
.
<EOS>
D'ye
think
I
'd
have
asked
anybody
who
by
any
impossibility
might
have
been
made
to
pay
anything
for
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
what
's
the
use
of
it
then
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
the
use
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
It
's
for
me
to
judge
of
the
use
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
Why
,
d'ye
think
I
'd
ask
it
if
it
was
n't
any
use
?
<EOS>
I
'll
make
it
of
use
,
my
boy
.
<EOS>
And
take
my
word
,

.
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
I

till

that
we

at

for
six
months
to
come
.
"
<EOS>
Then

.
   
<EOS>
Saulsby
Wood
 
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

.
<EOS>
Upon

,

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.

<EOS>
Phineas
was
rather
unhappy
about
the
bill
;
but
there

so

in
his
cup
at
the

,
that
he
resolved
,
as

,
to

bitter
of
that
one

.
<EOS>
He
was
a

.
<EOS>
He
would

with

;
but
he
had
no
servant
,
and
felt

to
hire
one
for
the

.
<EOS>
And
then
he
was
in
trouble
about
a
gun
,
and
the
paraphernalia
of

.
<EOS>
He
was
not
a
bad
shot
at
snipe
in
the
bogs
of
county
Clare
,
but
he
had
never
even
seen
a
gun
used
in
England
.
<EOS>
However
,
he
bought
himself
a
gun
,
 
with

,
and
took
a

for
himself
,
and
then

over
the

to

.
<EOS>
And

he
hired
a

for

.
<EOS>
He
was
intensely

of
himself
when
he
had
done
so
,
hating

,
and
telling

that
he
was

to

.
<EOS>
And
why
had
he
done

?
<EOS>
Not

Laura
would

,

.
<EOS>
She

nothing
of

.
<EOS>
But

about

would
know
,
and
he
was
foolishly

.
  
<EOS>
Then

Low

.

,
"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Why

.
<EOS>
It

;

At

.

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;
 
I

.
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
On

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Among

,

.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
,
whose

was
,
as

,
Chancellor
of

,
and
who

,

,

taken

to

,

.
<EOS>
"
What

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

.
<EOS>
The

Mildmay

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Poor

!
"

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

"

.
  
<EOS>
They

Effingham
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Ratler

.
<EOS>
Now
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
something

own

.
<EOS>
You
men

Parliament
are
so
much
like
sheep
!
<EOS>
If

,
all

,
 
and

,
and

,
and

.
<EOS>
I
wish
I
were
in
Parliament
.
<EOS>
I
'd
get
up

and
make
such

.
<EOS>
You
all
seem

me
to
be
so

that
you
do

quite
dare
to
speak
out
.
<EOS>
Do
you
see
that
cottage
there
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
a

it

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
is

?
<EOS>
Twelve

took

and

in

,

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
Oswald
Standish

.
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
Do

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lord

;
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

;

"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
,

?
"
  
"

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Very

.
<EOS>
That

,

.
<EOS>
You

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
now
,
 
not
particularly
.
<EOS>
I
hardly
ever
see
him
.
<EOS>
But
his
sister
is
the
best
friend
I
have
,
and
I
used
to
like
him
so
much
when
he
was
a
boy
!
<EOS>
I
have
not
seen
that
cottage
since
that
day
,
and
I
remember
it
as
though
it
were
yesterday
.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
is
quite
changed
,
is
he
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Changed
,
 
in
what
way
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
used
to
say
that
he
was
 
unsteady
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
is
changed
.
<EOS>
But
Chiltern
is
at
heart
a
Bohemian
.
<EOS>
It
is
impossible
not
to
see
that
at
once
.
<EOS>
He
hates
the
decencies
of
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
he
does
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
ought
to
marry
.
<EOS>
If
he
were
married
,
that
would
all
be
cured
;
 
do
n't
you
think
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
fancy
him
with
a
wife
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
There
is
a
savagery
about
him
which
would
make
him
an
uncomfortable
companion
for
a
woman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
would
love
his
wife
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
as
he
does
his
horses
.
<EOS>
And
he
would
treat
her
well
,
 
as
he
does
his
horses
.
<EOS>
But
he
expects
every
horse
he
has
to
do
anything
that
any
horse
can
do
;
and
he
would
expect
the
same
of
his
wife
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
had
no
idea
how
deep
an
injury
he
might
be
doing
his
friend
by
this
description
,
nor
did
it
once
occur
to
him
that
his
companion
was
thinking
of
herself
as
the
possible
wife
of
this
Red
Indian
.
<EOS>
Miss
Effingham
rode
on
in
silence
for
some
distance
,
and
then
she
said
<EOS>
but
one
word
more
about
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
was
so
good
to
me
in
that
cottage
.
"
  
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
the
party
at
Saulsby
was
broken
up
,
and
there
was
a
regular
pilgrimage
towards
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
Phineas
resolved
upon
sleeping
a
night
at
Edinburgh
on
his
way
,
and
he
found
himself
joined
in
the
bands
of
close
companionship
with
Mr.
Ratler
for
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
The
evening
was
by
no
means
thrown
away
,
for
he
learned
much
of
his
trade
from
Mr.
Ratler
.
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Ratler
was
heard
to
declare
afterwards
at
Loughlinter
that
Mr.
Finn
was
a
pleasant
young
man
.
  
<EOS>
It
soon
came
to
be
admitted
by
all
who
knew
Phineas
Finn
that
he
had
a
peculiar
power
of
making
himself
agreeable
which
no
one
knew
how
to
analyse
or
define
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
is
because
he
listens
so
well
,
"
said
one
man
.
<EOS>
"
But
the
women
would
not
like
him
for
that
,
"
said
another
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
has
studied
when
to
listen
and
when
to
talk
,
"
said
a
third
.
<EOS>
The
truth
,
however
,
was
,
that
Phineas
Finn
had
made
no
study
in
the
matter
at
all
.
<EOS>
It
was
simply
his
nature
to
be
pleasant
.
   
<EOS>
Loughlinter
 
Phineas
Finn
reached
Loughlinter
together
with
Mr.
Ratler
in
a
post
-
chaise
from
the
neighbouring
town
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Ratler
,
who
had
done
this
kind
of
thing
very
often
before
,
travelled
without
impediments
,
but
the
new
servant
of
our
hero
's
was
stuck
outside
with
the
driver
,
and
was
in
the
way
.
<EOS>
"
I
never
bring
a
man
with
me
,
"
said
Mr.
Ratler
to
his
young
friend
.
<EOS>
"
The
servants
of
the
house
like
it
much
better
,
because
they
get
fee'd
;
you
are
just
as
well
waited
on
,
and
it
do
n't
cost
half
as
much
.
"
<EOS>
Phineas
blushed
as
he
heard
all
this
;
but
there
was
the
impediment
,
not
to
be
got
rid
of
for
the
nonce
,
and
Phineas
made
the
best
of
his
attendant
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
one
of
those
points
,
"
said
he
,
"
<EOS>
as
to
which
a
man
never
quite
makes
up
his
mind
.
<EOS>
If
you
bring
a
fellow
,
you
wish
you
had
n't
brought
him
;
and
if
you
do
n't
,
you
wish
you
had
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
great
deal
more
decided
in
my
ways
that
that
,
"
said
Mr.
Ratler
.
  
<EOS>
Loughlinter
,
as
they
approached
it
,
seemed
to
Phineas
to
be
a
much
finer
place
than
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
And
so
it
was
,
except
that
Loughlinter
wanted
that
graceful
beauty
of
age
which
Saulsby
possessed
.
<EOS>
Loughlinter
was
all
of
cut
stone
,
but
the
stones
had
been
cut
only
yesterday
.
<EOS>
It
stood
on
a
gentle
slope
,
with
a
greensward
falling
from
the
front
entrance
down
to
a
mountain
lake
.
<EOS>
And
on
the
other
side
of
the
Lough
there
rose
a
mighty
mountain
to
the
skies
,
Ben
Linter
.
<EOS>
At
the
foot
of
it
,
and
all
round
to
the
left
,
there
ran
the
woods
of
Linter
,
stretching
for
miles
through
crags
and
bogs
and
mountain
lands
.
<EOS>
No
better
ground
for
deer
than
the
side
of
Ben
Linter
was
there
in
all
those
highlands
.
<EOS>
And
the
Linter
,
rushing
down
into
the
Lough
through
rocks
which
,
in
some
places
,
almost
met
together
above
its
waters
,
ran
so
near
to
the
house
that
the
pleasant
noise
of
its
cataracts
could
be
heard
from
the
hall
door
.
<EOS>
Behind
the
house
the
expanse
of
drained
park
land
seemed
to
be
interminable
;
and
then
,
again
,
came
the
mountains
.
<EOS>
There
were
Ben
Linn
and
Ben
Lody
;
 
and
the
whole
territory
belonging
to
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
He
was
laird
of
Linn
and
laird
of
Linter
,
as
his
people
used
to
say
.
<EOS>
And
yet
his
father
had
walked
into
Glasgow
as
a
little
boy
,
 
no
doubt
with
the
normal
half
-
crown
in
his
breeches
pocket
.
  
<EOS>
"
Magnificent
;
 
is
it
not
?
"
said
Phineas
to
the
Treasury
Secretary
,
as
they
were
being
driven
up
to
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
grand
;
 
but
the
young
trees
show
the
new
man
.
<EOS>
A
new
man
may
buy
a
forest
;
but
he
ca
n't
get
park
trees
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
at
the
moment
,
was
thinking
how
far
all
these
things
which
he
saw
,
the
mountains
stretching
everywhere
around
him
,
the
castle
,
the
lake
,
the
river
,
the
wealth
of
it
all
,
and
,
more
than
the
wealth
,
the
nobility
of
the
beauty
,
might
act
as
temptations
to
Lady
Laura
Standish
.
<EOS>
If
a
woman
were
asked
to
have
the
half
of
all
this
,
would
it
be
possible
that
she
should
prefer
to
take
the
half
of
his
nothing
?
<EOS>
He
thought
it
might
be
possible
for
a
girl
who
would
confess
,
or
seem
to
confess
,
that
love
should
be
everything
.
<EOS>
But
it
could
hardly
be
possible
for
a
woman
who
looked
at
the
world
almost
as
a
man
looked
at
it
,
 
as
an
oyster
to
be
opened
with
such
weapon
as
she
could
find
ready
to
her
hand
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
professed
to
have
a
care
for
all
the
affairs
of
the
world
.
<EOS>
She
loved
politics
,
and
could
talk
of
social
science
,
and
had
broad
ideas
about
religion
,
and
was
devoted
to
certain
educational
views
.
<EOS>
Such
a
woman
would
feel
that
wealth
was
necessary
to
her
,
and
would
be
willing
,
for
the
sake
of
wealth
,
to
put
up
with
a
husband
without
romance
.
<EOS>
Nay
;
might
it
not
be
that
she
would
prefer
a
husband
without
romance
?
<EOS>
Thus
Phineas
was
arguing
to
himself
as
he
was
driven
up
to
the
door
of
Loughlinter
Castle
,
while
Mr.
Ratler
was
eloquent
on
the
beauty
of
old
park
trees
.
<EOS>
"
After
all
,
a
Scotch
forest
is
a
very
scrubby
sort
of
thing
,
"
said
Mr.
Ratler
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
nobody
in
the
house
,
 
at
least
,
they
found
nobody
;
and
within
half
an
hour
Phineas
was
walking
about
the
grounds
by
himself
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Ratler
had
declared
himself
to
be
delighted
at
having
an
opportunity
of
writing
letters
,
 
and
<EOS>
no
doubt
was
writing
them
by
the
dozen
,
all
dated
from
Loughlinter
,
and
all
detailing
the
facts
that
Mr.
Gresham
,
and
Mr.
Monk
,
and
Plantagenet
Palliser
,
and
Lord
Brentford
were
in
the
same
house
with
him
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
no
letters
to
write
,
and
therefore
rushed
down
across
the
broad
lawn
to
the
river
,
of
which
he
heard
the
noisy
tumbling
waters
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
the
air
which
immediately
filled
him
with
high
spirits
;
and
,
in
his
desire
to
investigate
the
glories
of
the
place
,
he
forgot
that
he
was
going
to
dine
with
four
Cabinet
Ministers
in
a
row
.
<EOS>
He
soon
reached
the
stream
,
and
began
to
make
his
way
up
it
through
the
ravine
.
<EOS>
There
was
waterfall
over
waterfall
,
and
there
were
little
bridges
here
and
there
which
looked
to
be
half
natural
and
half
artificial
,
and
a
path
which
required
that
you
should
climb
,
but
which
was
yet
a
path
,
and
all
was
so
arranged
that
not
a
pleasant
splashing
rush
of
the
waters
was
lost
to
the
visitor
.
<EOS>
He
went
on
and
on
,
up
the
stream
,
till
there
was
a
sharp
turn
in
the
ravine
,
and
then
,
looking
upwards
,
he
saw
above
his
head
a
man
and
a
woman
standing
together
on
one
of
the
little
half
-
made
wooden
bridges
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
were
sharp
,
and
he
saw
at
a
glance
that
the
woman
was
Lady
Laura
Standish
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
recognised
the
man
,
but
he
had
very
little
doubt
that
it
was
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
Of
course
it
was
Mr.
Kennedy
,
because
he
would
prefer
that
it
should
be
any
other
man
under
the
sun
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
turned
back
at
once
if
he
had
thought
that
he
could
have
done
so
without
being
observed
;
but
he
felt
sure
that
,
standing
as
they
were
,
they
must
have
observed
him
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
like
to
join
them
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
intrude
himself
.
<EOS>
So
he
remained
still
,
and
began
to
throw
stones
into
the
river
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
not
thrown
above
a
stone
or
two
when
he
was
called
from
above
.
<EOS>
He
looked
up
,
and
then
he
perceived
that
the
man
who
called
him
was
his
host
.
<EOS>
Of
course
it
was
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
Thereupon
he
ceased
to
throw
stones
,
and
went
up
the
path
,
and
joined
them
upon
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
stepped
forward
,
and
bade
him
welcome
to
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
His
manner
was
less
cold
,
and
he
seemed
to
have
more
words
at
command
than
was
usual
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
been
long
,
"
he
said
,
"
in
finding
out
the
most
beautiful
spot
about
the
place
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
lovely
?
"
said
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
not
been
here
an
hour
yet
,
and
Mr.
Kennedy
insisted
on
bringing
me
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
wonderfully
beautiful
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
this
very
spot
where
we
now
stand
that
made
me
build
the
house
where
it
is
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
,
"
and
I
was
only
eighteen
when
I
stood
here
and
made
up
my
mind
.
<EOS>
That
is
just
twenty
-
five
years
ago
.
"
<EOS>
"
So
he
is
forty
-
three
,
"
said
Phineas
to
himself
,
thinking
how
glorious
it
was
to
be
only
twenty
-
five
.
"
<EOS>
And
within
twelve
months
,
"
continued
Mr.
Kennedy
,
"
the
foundations
were
being
dug
and
the
stone
-
cutters
were
at
work
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
good
-
natured
man
your
father
must
have
been
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
had
nothing
else
to
do
with
his
money
but
to
pour
it
over
my
head
,
as
it
were
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
he
had
any
other
enjoyment
of
it
himself
.
<EOS>
Will
you
go
a
little
higher
,
Lady
Laura
?
<EOS>
We
shall
get
a
fine
view
over
to
Ben
Linn
just
now
.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
declared
that
she
would
go
as
much
higher
as
he
chose
to
take
her
,
and
Phineas
was
rather
in
doubt
as
to
what
it
would
become
him
to
do
.
<EOS>
He
would
stay
where
he
was
,
or
go
down
,
or
make
himself
to
vanish
after
any
most
acceptable
fashion
;
but
if
he
were
to
do
so
abruptly
it
would
seem
as
though
he
were
attributing
something
special
to
the
companionship
of
the
other
two
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
saw
his
doubt
,
and
asked
him
to
join
them
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
as
well
come
on
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
We
do
n't
dine
till
eight
,
and
it
is
not
much
past
six
yet
.
<EOS>
The
men
of
business
are
all
writing
letters
,
and
the
ladies
who
have
been
travelling
are
in
bed
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
all
of
them
,
Mr.
Kennedy
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
Then
they
went
on
with
their
walk
very
pleasantly
,
and
the
lord
of
all
that
they
surveyed
took
them
from
one
point
of
vantage
to
another
,
till
they
both
swore
that
of
all
spots
upon
the
earth
<EOS>
Loughlinter
was
surely
the
most
lovely
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
delight
in
it
,
I
own
,
"
said
the
lord
.
<EOS>
"
When
I
come
up
here
alone
,
and
feel
that
in
the
midst
of
this
little
bit
of
a
crowded
island
I
have
all
this
to
myself
,
 
all
this
with
which
no
other
man
's
wealth
can
interfere
,
 
I
grow
proud
of
my
own
,
till
I
become
thoroughly
ashamed
of
myself
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
I
believe
it
is
better
to
dwell
in
cities
than
in
the
country
,
 
better
,
at
any
rate
,
for
a
rich
man
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
had
now
spoken
more
words
than
Phineas
had
heard
to
fall
from
his
lips
during
the
whole
time
that
they
had
been
acquainted
with
each
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
so
too
,
"
said
Laura
,
"
if
one
were
obliged
to
choose
between
the
two
.
<EOS>
For
myself
,
I
think
that
a
little
of
both
is
good
for
man
and
woman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
doubt
about
that
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
as
far
as
enjoyment
goes
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
He
took
them
up
out
of
the
ravine
on
to
the
side
of
the
mountain
,
and
then
down
by
another
path
through
the
woods
to
the
back
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
As
they
went
he
relapsed
into
his
usual
silence
,
and
the
conversation
was
kept
up
between
the
other
two
.
<EOS>
At
a
point
not
very
far
from
the
castle
,
 
just
so
far
that
one
could
see
by
the
break
of
the
ground
where
the
castle
stood
,
Kennedy
left
them
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
will
take
you
back
in
safety
,
I
am
sure
,
"
said
he
,
"
and
,
as
I
am
here
,
I
'll
go
up
to
the
farm
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
If
I
do
n't
show
myself
now
and
again
when
I
am
here
,
they
think
I
'm
indifferent
about
the
"
bestials
'
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Now
,
Mr.
Kennedy
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
"
you
are
going
to
pretend
to
understand
all
about
sheep
and
oxen
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
,
owning
that
it
was
so
,
went
away
to
his
farm
,
and
Phineas
with
Lady
Laura
returned
towards
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
upon
the
whole
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
"
that
that
is
as
good
a
man
as
I
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
he
is
an
idle
one
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
doubt
that
.
<EOS>
He
is
,
perhaps
,
neither
zealous
nor
active
.
<EOS>
But
he
is
thoughtful
and
high
-
principled
,
and
has
a
method
and
a
purpose
in
the
use
which
he
makes
of
his
money
.
<EOS>
And
you
see
that
he
has
poetry
in
his
nature
too
,
if
you
get
him
upon
the
right
string
.
<EOS>
How
fond
he
is
of
the
scenery
of
this
place
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Any
man
would
be
fond
of
that
.
<EOS>
I
'm
ashamed
to
say
that
it
almost
makes
me
envy
him
.
<EOS>
I
certainly
never
have
wished
to
be
Mr.
Robert
Kennedy
in
London
,
but
I
should
like
to
be
the
Laird
of
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
"
Laird
of
Linn
and
Laird
of
Linter
,
 
Here
in
summer
,
gone
in
winter
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
some
ballad
about
the
old
lairds
;
but
that
belongs
to
a
time
when
Mr.
Kennedy
had
not
been
heard
of
,
when
some
branch
of
the
Mackenzies
lived
down
at
that
wretched
old
tower
which
you
see
as
you
first
come
upon
the
lake
.
<EOS>
When
old
Mr.
Kennedy
bought
it
there
were
hardly
a
hundred
acres
on
the
property
under
cultivation
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
it
belonged
to
the
Mackenzies
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;
 
to
the
Mackenzie
of
Linn
,
as
he
was
called
.
<EOS>
It
was
Mr.
Kennedy
,
the
old
man
,
who
was
first
called
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
That
is
Linn
Castle
,
and
they
lived
there
for
hundreds
of
years
.
<EOS>
But
these
Highlanders
,
with
all
that
is
said
of
their
family
pride
,
have
forgotten
the
Mackenzies
already
,
and
are
quite
proud
of
their
rich
landlord
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
unpoetical
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
but
then
poetry
is
so
usually
false
.
<EOS>
I
doubt
whether
Scotland
would
not
have
been
as
prosaic
a
country
as
any
under
the
sun
but
for
Walter
Scott
;
 
and
I
have
no
doubt
that
Henry
V
owes
the
romance
of
his
character
altogether
to
Shakspeare
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
sometimes
think
you
despise
poetry
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
it
is
false
I
do
.
<EOS>
The
difficulty
is
to
know
when
it
is
false
and
when
it
is
true
.
<EOS>
Tom
Moore
was
always
false
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
so
false
as
Byron
,
"
said
Phineas
with
energy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Much
more
so
,
my
friend
.
<EOS>
But
we
will
not
discuss
that
now
.
<EOS>
Have
you
seen
Mr.
Monk
since
you
have
been
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
no
one
.
<EOS>
I
came
with
Mr.
Ratler
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
with
Mr.
Ratler
?
<EOS>
You
can
not
find
Mr.
Ratler
a
companion
much
to
your

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Chance
brought
us
together
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Ratler
is
a
man
of
sense
,
Lady
Laura
,
and
is
not
to
be
despised
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
always
seems
to
me
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
"
that
nothing
is
to
be
gained
in
politics
by
sitting
at
the
feet
of
the
little
Gamaliels
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
the
great
Gamaliels
will
not
have
a
novice
on
their
footstools
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Then
sit
at
no
man
's
feet
.
<EOS>
Is
it
not
astonishing
that
the
price
generally
put
upon
any
article
by
the
world
is
that
which
the
owner
puts
on
it
?
 
<EOS>
and
that
this
is
specially
true
of
a
man
's
own
self
?
<EOS>
If
you
herd
with
Ratler
,
men
will
take
it
for
granted
that
you
are
a
Ratlerite
,
and
no
more
.
<EOS>
If
you
consort
with
Greshams
and
Pallisers
,
you
will
equally
be
supposed
to
know
your
own
place
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
knew
a
Mentor
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
so
apt
as
you
are
to
fill
his
Telemachus
with
pride
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
because
I
do
not
think
your
fault
lies
that
way
.
<EOS>
If
it
did
,
or
if
I
thought
so
,
my
Telemachus
,
you
may
be
sure
that
I
should
resign
my
position
as
Mentor
.
<EOS>
Here
are
Mr.
Kennedy
and
Lady
Glencora
and
Mrs.
Gresham
on
the
steps
.
"
<EOS>
Then
they
went
up
through
the
Ionic
columns
on
to
the
broad
stone
terrace
before
the
door
,
and
there
they
found
a
crowd
of
men
and
women
.
<EOS>
For
the
legislators
and
statesmen
had
written
their
letters
,
and
the
ladies
had
taken
their
necessary
rest
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
as
he
was
dressing
,
considered
deeply
all
that
Lady
Laura
had
said
to
him
,
 
not
so
much
with
reference
to
the
advice
which
she
had
given
him
,
though
that
also
was
of
importance
,
as
to
the
fact
that
it
had
been
given
by
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
first
called
herself
his
Mentor
;
but
he
had
accepted
the
name
and
had
addressed
her
as
her
Telemachus
.
<EOS>
And
yet
he
believed
himself
to
be
older
than
she
,
 
if
,
indeed
,
there
was
any
difference
in
their
ages
.
<EOS>
And
was
it
possible
that
a
female
Mentor
should
love
her
<EOS>
Telemachus
,
 
should
love
him
as
Phineas
desired
to
be
loved
by
Lady
Laura
?
<EOS>
He
would
not
say
that
it
was
impossible
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
there
had
been
mistakes
between
them
;
 
a
mistake
in
his
manner
of
addressing
her
,
and
another
in
hers
of
addressing
him
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
old
bachelor
of
forty
-
three
was
not
thinking
of
a
wife
.
<EOS>
Had
this
old
bachelor
of
forty
-
three
been
really
in
love
with
Lady
Laura
,
would
he
have
allowed
her
to
walk
home
alone
with
Phineas
,
leaving
her
with
some
flimsy
pretext
of
having
to
look
at
his
sheep
?
<EOS>
Phineas
resolved
that
he
must
at
any
rate
play
out
his
game
,
 
whether
he
were
to
lose
it
or
to
win
it
;
and
in
playing
it
he
must
,
if
possible
,
drop
something
of
that
Mentor
and
Telemachus
style
of
conversation
.
<EOS>
As
to
the
advice
given
him
of
herding
with
Greshams
and
Pallisers
,
instead
of
with
Ratlers
and
Fitzgibbons
,
 
he
must
use
that
as
circumstances
might
direct
.
<EOS>
To
him
,
himself
,
as
he
thought
of
it
all
,
it
was
sufficiently
astonishing
that
even
the
Ratlers
and
Fitzgibbons
should
admit
him
among
them
as
one
of
themselves
.
<EOS>
"
When
I
think
of
my
father
and
of
the
old
house
at
Killaloe
,
and
remember
that
hitherto
I
have
done
nothing
myself
,
I
can
not
understand
how
it
is
that
I
should
be
at
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
only
one
way
of
understanding
it
.
<EOS>
If
Lady
Laura
really
loved
him
,
the
riddle
might
be
read
.
  
<EOS>
The
rooms
at
Loughlinter
were
splendid
,
much
larger
and
very
much
more
richly
furnished
than
those
at
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
a
certain
stiffness
in
the
movement
of
things
,
and
perhaps
in
the
manner
of
some
of
those
present
,
which
was
not
felt
at
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
Phineas
at
once
missed
the
grace
and
prettiness
and
cheery
audacity
of
Violet
Effingham
,
and
felt
at
the
same
time
that
Violet
Effingham
would
be
out
of
her
element
at
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
At
Loughlinter
they
were
met
for
business
.
<EOS>
It
was
at
least
a
semi
-
political
,
or
perhaps
rather
a
semi
-
official
gathering
,
and
he
became
aware
that
he
ought
not
to
look
simply
for
amusement
.
<EOS>
When
he
entered
the
drawing
-
room
before
dinner
,
Mr.
Monk
and
Mr.
Palliser
,
and
Mr.
Kennedy
and
Mr.
Gresham
,
with
sundry
others
,
were
standing
in
a
wide
group
before
the
fireplace
,
and
among
them
were
Lady
Glencora
Palliser
and
Lady
Laura
and
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
As
he
approached
them
it
seemed
as
though
a
sort
of
opening
was
made
for
himself
;
but
he
could
see
,
though
others
did
not
,
that
the
movement
came
from
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
,
Mr.
Monk
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
"
that
you
and
I
are
the
only
two
in
the
whole
party
who
really
know
what
we
would
be
at
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
must
be
divided
from
so
many

my
friends
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
,
"
I
am
happy
to
go
astray
in
the
company
of
Lady
Glencora
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
might
I
ask
,
"
said
Mr.
Gresham
,
with
a
peculiar
smile
for
which
he
was
famous
,
"
what
it
is
that
you
and
Mr.
Monk
are
really
at
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Making
men
and
women
all
equal
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
That
I
take
to
be
the
gist
of
our
political
theory
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Lady
Glencora
,
I
must
cry
off
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
If
I
were
in
the
Cabinet
myself
I
should
not
admit
so
much
.
<EOS>
There
are
reticences
,
 
of
course
.
<EOS>
And
there
is
an
official
discretion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
do
n't
mean
to
say
,
Lady
Glencora
,
that
you
would
really
advocate
equality
?
"
said
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
mean
to
say
so
,
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
And
I
mean
to
go
further
,
and
to
tell
you
that
you
are
no
Liberal
at
heart
unless
you
do
so
likewise
;
unless
that
is
the
basis
of
your
political
aspirations
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
let
me
speak
for
myself
,
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
By
no
means
,
 
not
when
you
are
criticising
me
and
my
politics
.
<EOS>
Do
you
not
wish
to
make
the
lower
orders
comfortable
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
educated
,
and
happy
and
good
?
"
  
"
Undoubtedly
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
make
them
as
comfortable
and
as
good
as
yourself
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Better
if
possible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
'm
sure
you
wish
to
make
yourself
as
good
and
as
comfortable
as
anybody
else
,
 
as
those
above
you
,
if
anybody
is
above
you
?
<EOS>
You
will
admit
that
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
 
if
I
understand
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
have
admitted
everything
,
and
are
an
advocate
for
general
equality
,
 
just
as
Mr.
Monk
is
,
and
as
I
am
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
getting
out
of
it
;
 
is
there
,
Mr.
Kennedy
?
"
<EOS>
Then
dinner
was
announced
,
and
Mr.
Kennedy
walked
off
with
the
French
Republican
on
his
arm
.
<EOS>
As
she
went
,
she
whispered
into
Mr.
Kennedy
's
ear
,
"
You
will
understand
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
saying
that
people
are
equal
;
but
that
the
tendency
of
all
law
-
making
and
of
all
governing
should
be
to
reduce
the
inequalities
.
"
<EOS>
In
answer
to
which
Mr.
Kennedy
said
not
a
word
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
's
politics
were
too
fast
and
furious
for
his
nature
.
  
<EOS>
A
week
passed
by
at
Loughlinter
,
at
the
end
of
which
Phineas
found
himself
on
terms
of
friendly
intercourse
with
all
the
political
magnates
assembled
in
the
house
,
but
especially
with
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
He
had
determined
that
he
would
not
follow
Lady
Laura
's
advice
as
to
his
selection
of
companions
,
if
in
doing
so
he
should
be
driven
even
to
a
seeming
of
intrusion
.
<EOS>
He
made
no
attempt
to
sit
at
the
feet
of
anybody
,
and
would
stand
aloof
when
bigger
men
than
himself
were
talking
,
and
was
content
to
be
less
,
 
as
indeed
he
was
less
,
 
than
Mr.
Bonteen
or
Mr.
Ratler
.
<EOS>
But
at
the
end
of
a
week
he
found
that
,
without
any
effort
on
his
part
,
 
almost
in
opposition
to
efforts
on
his
part
,
 
he
had
fallen
into
an
easy
pleasant
way
with
these
men
which
was
very
delightful
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
killed
a
stag
in
company
with
Mr.
Palliser
,
and
had
stopped
beneath
a
crag
to
discuss
with
him
a
question
as
to
the
duty
on
Irish
malt
.
<EOS>
He
had
played
chess
with
Mr.
Gresham
,
and
had
been
told
that
gentleman
's
opinion
on
the
trial
of
Mr.
Jefferson
Davis
.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
had
 
at
last
 
called
him
Finn
,
and
had
proved
to
him
that
nothing
was
known
in
Ireland
about
sheep
.
<EOS>
But
with
Mr.
Monk
he
had
had
long
discussions
on
abstract
questions
in
politics
,
 
and
before
the
week
was
over
was
almost
disposed
to
call
himself
a
disciple
,
or
,
at
least
,
a
follower
of
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
Why
not
of
Mr.
Monk
as
well
as
of
any
one
else
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
was
in
the
Cabinet
,
and
of
all
the
members
of
the
Cabinet
was
the
most
advanced
Liberal
.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
was
not
so
far
wrong
the
other
night
,
"
Mr.
Monk
said
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
Equality
is
an
ugly
word
and
should
n't
be
used
.
<EOS>
It
misleads
,
and
frightens
,
and
is
a
bugbear
.
<EOS>
And
she
,
in
using
it
,
had
not
perhaps
a
clearly
defined
meaning
for
it
in
her
own
mind
.
<EOS>
But
the
wish
of
every
honest
man
should
be
to
assist
in
lifting
up
those
below
him
,
till
they
be
something
nearer
his
own
level
than
he
finds
them
.
"
<EOS>
To
this
Phineas
assented
,
 
and
by
degrees
he
found
himself
assenting
to
a
great
many
things
that
Mr.
Monk
said
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
was
a
thin
,
tall
,
gaunt
man
,
who
had
devoted
his
whole
life
to
politics
,
hitherto
without
any
personal
reward
beyond
that
which
came
to
him
from
the
reputation
of
his
name
,
and
from
the
honour
of
a
seat
in
Parliament
.
<EOS>
He
was
one
of
four
or
five
brothers
,
 
and
all
besides
him
were
in
trade
.
<EOS>
They
had
prospered
in
trade
,
whereas
he
had
prospered
solely
in
politics
;
and
men
said
that
he
was
dependent
altogether
on
what
his
relatives
supplied
for
his
support
.
<EOS>
He
had
now
been
in
Parliament
for
more
than
twenty
years
,
and
had
been
known
not
only
as
a
Radical
but
as
a
Democrat
.
<EOS>
Ten
years
since
,
when
he
had
risen
to
fame
,
but
not
to
repute
,
among
the
men
who
then
governed
England
,
nobody
dreamed
that
Joshua
Monk
would
ever
be
a
paid
servant
of
the
Crown
.
<EOS>
He
had
inveighed
against
one
minister
after
another
as
though
they
all
deserved
impeachment
.
<EOS>
He
had
advocated
political
doctrines
which
at
that
time
seemed
to
be
altogether
at
variance
with
any
possibility
of
governing
according
to
English
rules
of
government
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
regarded
as
a
pestilent
thorn
in
the
sides
of
all
ministers
.
<EOS>
But
now
he
was
a
member
of
the
Cabinet
,
and
those
whom
he
had
terrified
in
the
old
days
began
to
find
that
he
was
not
so
much
unlike
other
men
.
<EOS>
There
are
but
few
horses
which
you
can
not
put
into
harness
,
and
those
of
the
highest
spirit
will
generally
do
your
work
the
best
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
had
his
eyes
about
him
,
thought
that
he
could
perceive
that
Mr.
Palliser
did
not
shoot
a
deer
with
Mr.
Ratler
,
and
that
Mr.
Gresham
played
no
chess
with
Mr.
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
Bonteen
,
indeed
,
was
a
noisy
pushing
man
whom
nobody
seemed
to
like
,
and
Phineas
wondered
why
he
should
be
at
Loughlinter
,
and
why
he
should
be
in
office
.
<EOS>
His
friend
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
had
indeed
once
endeavoured
to
explain
this
.
"
<EOS>
A
man
who
can
vote
hard
,
as
I
call
it
;
and
who
will
speak
a
few
words
now
and
then
as
they
're
wanted
,
without
any
ambition
that
way
,
may
always
have
his
price
.
<EOS>
And
if
he
has
a
pretty
wife
into
the
bargain
,
he
ought
to
have
a
pleasant
time
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Ratler
no
doubt
was
a
very
useful
man
,
who
thoroughly
knew
his
business
;
but
yet
,
as
it
seemed
to
Phineas
,
no
very
great
distinction
was
shown
to
Mr.
Ratler
at
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
got
as
high
as
that
,
"
he
said
to
himself
,
"
I
should
think
myself
a
miracle
of
luck
.
<EOS>
And
yet
nobody
seems
to
think
anything
of
Ratler
.
<EOS>
It
is
all
nothing
unless
one
can
go
to
the
very
top
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
I
did
right
to
accept
office
,
"
Mr.
Monk
said
to
him
one
day
,
as
they
sat
together
on
a
rock
close
by
one
of
the
little
bridges
over
the
Linter
.
"
<EOS>
Indeed
,
unless
a
man
does
so
when
the
bonds
of
the
office
tendered
to
him
are
made
compatible
with
his
own
views
,
he
declines
to
proceed
on
the
open
path
towards
the
prosecution
of
those
views
.
<EOS>
A
man
who
is
combating
one
ministry
after
another
,
and
striving
to
imbue
those
ministers
with
his
convictions
,
can
hardly
decline
to
become
a
minister
himself
when
he
finds
that
those
convictions
of
his
own
are
henceforth
,
 
or
at
least
for
some
time
to
come
,
 
to
be
the
ministerial
convictions
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
Do
you
follow
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Very
clearly
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
You
would
have
denied
your
own
children
had
you
refused
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Unless
indeed
a
man
were
to
feel
that
he
was
in
some
way
unfitted
for
office
work
.
<EOS>
I
very
nearly
provided
for
myself
an
escape
on
that
plea
;
 
but
when
I
came
to
sift
it
,
I
thought
that
it
would
be
false
.
<EOS>
But
let
me
tell
you
that
the
delight
of
political
life
is
altogether
in
opposition
.
<EOS>
Why
,
it
is
freedom
against
slavery
,
fire
against
clay
,
movement
against
stagnation
!
<EOS>
The
very
inaccuracy
which
is
permitted
to
opposition
is
in
itself
a
charm
worth
more
than
all
the
patronage
and
all
the
prestige
of
ministerial
power
.
<EOS>
You
'll
try
them
both
,
and
then
say
if
you
do
not
agree
with
me
.
<EOS>
Give
me
the
full
swing
of
the
benches
below
the
gangway
,
where
I
needed
to
care
for
no
one
,
and
could
always
enjoy
myself
on
my
legs
as
long
as
I
felt
that
I
was
true
to
those
who
sent
me
there
!
<EOS>
That
is
all
over
now
.
<EOS>
They
have
got
me
into
harness
,
and
my
shoulders
are
sore
.
<EOS>
The
oats
,
however
,
are
of
the
best
,
and
the
hay
is
unexceptionable
.
"
   
<EOS>
Donald
Bean
's
Pony
 
Phineas
liked
being
told
that
the
pleasures
of
opposition
and
the
pleasures
of
office
were
both
open
to
him
,
 
and
he
liked
also
to
be
the
chosen
receptacle
of
Mr.
Monk
's
confidence
.
<EOS>
He
had
come
to
understand
that
he
was
expected
to
remain
ten
days
at
Loughlinter
,
and
that
then
there
was
to
be
a
general
movement
.
<EOS>
Since
the
first
day
he
had
seen
but
little
of
Mr.
Kennedy
,
but
he
had
found
himself
very
frequently
with
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
And
then
had
come
up
the
question
of
his
projected
trip
to
Paris
with
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
He
had
received
a
letter
from
Lord
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
DEAR
FINN
,
  
Are
you
going
to
Paris
with
me
?
  
<EOS>
Yours
,
C.
  
<EOS>
There
had
been
not
a
word
beyond
this
,
and
before
he
answered
it
he
made
up
his
mind
to
tell
Lady
Laura
the
truth
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
go
to
Paris
because
he
had
no
money
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
just
got
that
from
your
brother
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
like
Oswald
.
<EOS>
He
writes
to
me
perhaps
three
times
in
the
year
,
and
his
letters
are
just
the
same
.
<EOS>
You
will
go
<EOS>
I
hope
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
;
 
no
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
for
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whether
I
may
tell
you
the
real
reason
,
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nay
;
 
I
can
not
answer
that
;
but
unless
it
be
some
political
secret
between
you
and
Mr.
Monk
,
I
should
think
you
might
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
afford
to
go
to
Paris
this
autumn
.
<EOS>
It
seems
to
be
a
shocking
admission
to
make
,
 
though
I
do
n't
know
why
it
should
be
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
I
;
 
<EOS>
but
,
Mr.
Finn
,
I
like
you
<EOS>
all
the
better
for
making
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
very
sorry
,
for
Oswald
's
sake
.
<EOS>
It
's
so
hard
to
find
any
companion
for
him
whom
he
would
like
and
whom
<EOS>
we
,
 
that
is
I
,
 
should
think
altogether
 
;
you
know
what
I
mean
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
wish
that
I
should
go
with
him
is
a
great
compliment
,
and
I
thoroughly
wish
that
I
could
do
it
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
I
must
go
to
Killaloe
and
retrieve
my
finances
.
<EOS>
I
daresay
,
Lady
Laura
,
you
can
hardly
conceive
how
very
poor
a
man
I
am
.
"
<EOS>
There
was
a
melancholy
tone
about
his
voice
as
he
said
this
,
which
made
her
think
for
the
moment
whether
or
no
he
had
been
right
in
going
into
Parliament
,
and
whether
she
had
been
right
in
instigating
him
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
too
late
to
recur
to
that
question
now
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
climb
into
office
early
,
and
forego
those
pleasures
of
opposition
which
are
so
dear
to
Mr.
Monk
,
"
she
said
,
smiling
.
<EOS>
"
After
all
,
money
is
an
accident
which
does
not
count
nearly
so
high
as
do
some
other
things
.
<EOS>
You
and
Mr.
Kennedy
have
the
same
enjoyment
of
everything
around
you
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
while
it
lasts
.
"
  
"
And
Lady
Glencora
and
I
stand
pretty
much
on
the
same
footing
,
in
spite
of
all
her
wealth
,
 
except
that
she
is
a
married
woman
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
what
she
is
worth
,
 
something
not
to
be
counted
;
and
I
am
worth
,
 
just
what
papa
chooses
to
give
me
.
<EOS>
A
ten
-
pound
note
at
the
present
moment
I
should
look
upon
as
great
riches
.
<EOS>
"
This
was
the
first
time
she
had
ever
spoken
to
him
of
her
own
position
as
regards
money
;
but
he
had
heard
,
or
thought
that
he
had
heard
,
that
she
had
been
left
a
fortune
altogether
independent
of
her
father
.
  
<EOS>
The
last
of
the
ten
days
had
now
come
,
and
Phineas
was
discontented
and
almost
unhappy
.
<EOS>
The
more
he
saw
of
Lady
Laura
the
more
he
feared
that
it
was
impossible
that
she
should
become
his
wife
.
<EOS>
And
yet
from
day
to
day
his
intimacy
with
her
became
more
close
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
made
love
to
her
,
nor
could
he
discover
that
it
was
possible
for
him
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
be
a
woman
for
whom
all
the
ordinary
stages
of
love
-
making
were
quite
unsuitable
,
Of
course
he
could
declare
his
love
and
ask
her
to
be
his
wife
on
any
occasion
on
which
he
might
find
himself
to
be
alone
with
her
.
<EOS>
And
on
this
morning
he
had
made
up
his
mind
that
he
would
do
so
before
the
day
was
over
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
possible
that
she
would
never
speak
to
him
again
;
 
that
all
the
pleasures
and
ambitious
hopes
to
which
she
had
introduced
him
might
be
over
as
soon
as
that
rash
word
should
have
been
spoken
!
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
he
would
speak
it
.
  
<EOS>
On
this
day
there
was
to
be
a
grouse
-
shooting
party
,
and
the
shooters
were
to
be
out
early
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
talked
of
for
some
day
or
two
past
,
and
Phineas
knew
that
he
could
not
escape
it
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
some
rivalry
between
him
and
Mr.
Bonteen
,
and
there
was
to
be
a
sort
of
match
as
to
which
of
the
two
would
kill
most
birds
before
lunch
.
<EOS>
But
there
had
also
been
some
half
promise
on
Lady
Laura
's
part
that
she
would
walk
with
him
up
the
Linter
and
come
down
upon
the
lake
,
taking
an
opposite
direction
from
that
by
which
they
had
returned
with
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
be
shooting
all
day
,
"
she
said
,
when
he
proposed
it
to
her
as
they
were
starting
for
the
moor
.
<EOS>
The
waggonet
that
was
to
take
them
was
at
the
door
,
and
she
was
there
to
see
them
start
.
<EOS>
Her
father
was
one
of
the
shooting
party
,
and
Mr.
Kennedy
was
another
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
undertake
to
be
back
in
time
,
if
you
will
not
think
it
too
hot
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
see
you
again
till
we
meet
in
town
next
year
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
certainly
will
go
with
you
,
 
<EOS>
that
is
to
say
,
if
you
are
here
.
<EOS>
But
you
can
not
return
without
the
rest
of
the
party
,
as
you
are
going
so
far
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
get
back
somehow
,
"
said
Phineas
,
who
was
resolved
that
a
few
miles
more
or
less
of
mountain
should
not
detain
him
from
the
prosecution
of
a
task
so
vitally
important
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
If
we
start
at
five
that
will
be
early
enough
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
early
enough
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
went
off
to
the
mountains
,
and
shot
his
grouse
,
and
won
his
match
,
and
eat
his
luncheon
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bonteen
,
however
,
was
not
beaten
by
much
,
and
was
in
consequence
somewhat
ill
-
humoured
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
I
'll
do
,
"
said
Mr.
Bonteen
,
"
I
'll
back
myself
for
the
rest
of
the
day
for
a
ten
-
pound
note
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
there
had
been
no
money
staked
on
the
match
at
all
,
 
but
it
had
been
simply
a
trial
of
skill
,
as
to
which
would
kill
the
most
birds
in
a
given
time
.
<EOS>
And
the
proposition
for
that
trial
had
come
from
Mr.
Bonteen
himself
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
think
of
shooting
for
money
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
why
not
?
<EOS>
A
bet
is
the
only
way
to
decide
these
things
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Partly
because
I
'm
sure
I
should
n't
hit
a
bird
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
and
partly
because
I
have
n't
got
any
money
to
lose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hate
bets
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
to
him
afterwards
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
annoyed
when
Bonteen
offered
the
wager
.
<EOS>
I
felt
sure
,
however
,
you
would
not
accept
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
such
bets
are
very
common
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
men
ought
to
propose
them
unless
they
are
quite
sure
of
their
company
.
<EOS>
Maybe
I
'm
wrong
,
and
I
often
feel
that
I
am
strait
-
laced
about
such
things
.
<EOS>
It
is
so
odd
to
me
that
men
can
not
amuse
themselves
without
pitting
themselves
against
each
other
.
<EOS>
When
a
man
tells
me
that
he
can
shoot
better
than
I
,
I
tell
him
that
my
keeper
can
shoot
better
than
he
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
the
same
,
it
's
a
good
thing
to
excel
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
so
sure
of
that
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
"
A
man
who
can
kill
more
salmon
than
anybody
else
,
can
rarely
do
anything
else
.
<EOS>
Are
you
going
on
with
your
match
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
'm
going
to
make
my
way
to
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
alone
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
over
nine
miles
.
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
walk
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
looked
at
his
watch
,
and
found
that
it
was
now
two
o'clock
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
broiling
day
in
August
,
and
the
way
back
to
Loughlinter
,
for
six
or
seven
out
of
the
nine
miles
,
would
be
along
a
high
road
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
do
it
all
the
same
,
"
said
he
,
preparing
for
a
start
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
an
engagement
with
Lady
Laura
Standish
;
and
as
this
is
the
last
day
that
I
shall
see
her
,
I
certainly
do
not
mean
to
break
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
An
engagement
with
Lady
Laura
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
"
Why
did
you
not
tell
me
,
that
I
might
have
a
pony
ready
?
<EOS>
But
come
along
.
<EOS>
Donald
Bean
has
a
pony
.
<EOS>
He
's
not
much
bigger
than
a
dog
,
but
he
'll
carry
you
to
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
walk
it
,
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
and
think
of
the
state
in
which
you
'd
reach
Loughlinter
!
<EOS>
Come
along
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
ca
n't
take
you
off
the
mountain
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
must
allow
me
to
take
you
off
.
"
  
<EOS>
So
Mr.
Kennedy
led
the
way
down
to
Donald
Bean
's
cottage
,
and
before
three
o'clock
Phineas
found
himself
mounted
on
a
shaggy
steed
,
which
,
in
sober
truth
,
was
not
much
bigger
than
a
large
dog
.
<EOS>
"
If
Mr.
Kennedy
is
really
my
rival
,
"
said
Phineas
to
himself
,
as
he
trotted
along
,
"
I
almost
think
that
I
am
doing
an
unhandsome
thing
in
taking
the
pony
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
At
five
o'clock
he
was
under
the
portico
before
the
front
door
,
and
there
he
found
Lady
Laura
waiting
for
him
,
 
waiting
for
him
,
or
at
least
ready
for
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
on
her
hat
and
gloves
and
light
shawl
,
and
her
parasol
was
in
her
hand
.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
he
had
never
seen
her
look
so
young
,
so
pretty
,
and
so
fit
to
receive
a
lover
's
vows
.
<EOS>
But
at
the
same
moment
it
occurred
to
him
that
she
was
Lady
Laura
Standish
,
the
daughter
of
an
Earl
,
the
descendant
of
a
line
of
Earls
,
 
and
that
he
was
the
son
of
a
simple
country
doctor
in
Ireland
.
<EOS>
Was
it
fitting
that
he
should
ask
such
a
woman
to
be
his
wife
?
<EOS>
But
then
Mr.
Kennedy
was
the
son
of
a
man
who
had
walked
into
Glasgow
with
half
-
a
-
crown
in
his
pocket
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
's
grandfather
had
been
,
 
<EOS>
Phineas
thought
that
he
had
heard
that
Mr.
Kennedy
's
grandfather
had
been
a
Scotch
drover
;
whereas
his
own
grandfather
had
been
a
little
squire
near
Ennistimon
,
in
county
Clare
,
and
his
own
first
cousin
once
removed
still
held
the
paternal
acres
at
Finn
Grove
.
<EOS>
His
family
was
supposed
to
be
descended
from
kings
in
that
part
of
Ireland
.
<EOS>
It
certainly
did
not
become
him
to
fear
Lady
Laura
on
the
score
of
rank
,
if
it
was
to
be
allowed
to
Mr.
Kennedy
to
proceed
without
fear
on
that
head
.
<EOS>
As
to
wealth
,
Lady
Laura
had
already
told
him
that
her
fortune
was
no
greater
than
his
.
<EOS>
Her
statement
to
himself
on
that
head
made
him
feel
that
he
should
not
hesitate
on
the
score
of
money
.
<EOS>
They
neither
had
any
,
and
he
was
willing
to
work
for
both
.
<EOS>
If
she
feared
the
risk
,
let
her
say
so
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
thus
that
he
argued
with
himself
;
but
yet
he
knew
,
 
knew
as
well
as
the
reader
will
know
,
 
that
he
was
going
to
do
that
which
he
had
no
right
to
do
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
very
well
for
him
to
wait
,
 
presuming
him
to
be
successful
in
his
love
,
 
for
the
opening
of
that
oyster
with
his
political
sword
,
that
oyster
on
which
he
proposed
that
they
should
both
live
;
but
such
waiting
could
not
well
be
to
the
taste
of
Lady
Laura
Standish
.
<EOS>
It
could
hardly
be
pleasant
to
her
to
look
forward
to
his
being
made
a
junior
lord
or
an
assistant
secretary
before
she
could
establish
herself
in
her
home
.
<EOS>
So
he
told
himself
.
<EOS>
And
yet
he
told
himself
at
the
same
time
that
it
was
incumbent
on
him
to
persevere
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
expect
you
in
the
least
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
I
spoke
very
positively
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
there
are
things
as
to
which
a
man
may
be
very
positive
,
and
yet
may
be
allowed
to
fail
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
how
on
earth
did
you
get
home
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Kennedy
got
me
a
pony
,
 
Donald
Bean
's
pony
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
told
him
,
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I
told
him
why
I
was
coming
,
and
that
I
must
be
here
.
<EOS>
Then
he
took
the
trouble
to
come
all
the
way
off
the
mountain
to
persuade
Donald
to
lend
me
his
pony
.
<EOS>
I
must
acknowledge
that
Mr.
Kennedy
has
conquered
me
at
last
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
glad
of
that
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
he
would
,
 
unless
it
were
your
own
fault
.
"
  
<EOS>
They
went
up
the
path
by
the
brook
,
from
bridge
to
bridge
,
till
they
found
themselves
out
upon
the
open
mountain
at
the
top
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
resolved
that
he
would
not
speak
out
his
mind
till
he
found
himself
on
that
spot
;
that
then
he
would
ask
her
to
sit
down
,
and
that
while
she
was
so
seated
he
would
tell
her
everything
.
<EOS>
At
the
present
moment
he
had
on
his
head
a
Scotch
cap
with
a
grouse
's
feather
in
it
,
and
he
was
dressed
in
a
velvet
shooting
-
jacket
and
dark
knickerbockers
;
and
was
certainly
,
in
this
costume
,
as
handsome
a
man
as
any
woman
would
wish
to
see
.
<EOS>
And
there
was
,
too
,
a
look
of
breeding
about
him
which
had
come
to
him
,
no
doubt
,
from
the
royal
Finns
of
old
,
which
ever
served
him
in
great
stead
.
<EOS>
He
was
,
indeed
,
only
Phineas
Finn
,
and
was
known
by
the
world
to
be
no
more
;
but
he
looked
as
though
he
might
have
been
anybody
,
 
a
royal
Finn
himself
.
<EOS>
And
then
he
had
that
special
grace
of
appearing
to
be
altogether
unconscious
of
his
own
personal
advantages
.
<EOS>
And
I
think
that
in
truth
he
was
barely
conscious
of
them
;
that
he
depended
on
them
very
little
,
if
at
all
;
that
there
was
nothing
of
personal
vanity
in
his
composition
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
indulged
in
any
hope
that
Lady
Laura
would
accept
him
because
he
was
a
handsome
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
After
all
that
climbing
,
"
he
said
,
"
will
you
not
sit
down
for
a
moment
?
"
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
to
her
she
looked
at
him
and
told
herself
that
he
was
as
handsome
as
a
god
.
<EOS>
"
Do
sit
down
for
one
moment
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
something
that
I
desire
to
say
to
you
,
and
to
say
it
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
she
said
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
also
have
something
to
tell
you
,
and
will
say
it
while
I
am
yet
standing
.
<EOS>
Yesterday
I
accepted
an
offer
of
marriage
from
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
am
too
late
,
"
said
Phineas
,
and
putting
his
hands
into
the
pockets
of
his
coat
,
he
turned
his
back
upon
her
,
and
walked
away
across
the
mountain
.
  
<EOS>
What
a
fool
he
had
been
to
let
her
know
his
secret
when
her
knowledge
of
it
could
be
of
no
service
to
him
,
 
when
her
knowledge
of
it
could
only
make
him
appear
foolish
in
her
eyes
!
<EOS>
But
for
his
life
he
could
not
have
kept
his
secret
to
himself
.
<EOS>
Nor
now
could
he
bring
himself
to
utter
a
word
of
even
decent
civility
.
<EOS>
But
he
went
on
walking
as
though
he
could
thus
leave
her
there
,
and
never
see
her
again
.
<EOS>
What
an
ass
he
had
been
in
supposing
that
she
cared
for
him
!
<EOS>
What
a
fool
to
imagine
that
his
poverty
could
stand
a
chance
against
the
wealth
of
Loughlinter
!
<EOS>
But
why
had
she
lured
him
on
?
<EOS>
How
he
wished
that
he
were
now
grinding
,
hard
at
work
in
Mr.
Low
's
chambers
,
or
sitting
at
home
at
Killaloe
with
the
hand
of
that
pretty
little
Irish
girl
within
his
own
!
  
<EOS>
Presently
he
heard
a
voice
behind
him
,
 
calling
him
gently
.
<EOS>
Then
he
turned
and
found
that
she
was
very
near
him
.
<EOS>
He
himself
had
then
been
standing
still
for
some
moments
,
and
she
had
followed
him
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;
 
yes
:
what
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
And
turning
round
he
made
an
attempt
to
smile
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
not
wish
me
joy
,
or
say
a
word
of
congratulation
?
<EOS>
Had
I
not
thought
much
of
your
friendship
,
I
should
not
have
been
so
quick
to
tell
you
of
my
destiny
.
<EOS>
No
one
else
has
been
told
,
except
papa
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
hope
you
will
be
happy
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
do
.
<EOS>
No
wonder
he
lent
me
the
pony
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
forget
all
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Forget
what
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
 
nothing
.
<EOS>
You
need
forget
nothing
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
"
<EOS>
for
nothing
has
been
said
that
need
be
regretted
.
<EOS>
Only
wish
me
joy
,
and
all
will
be
pleasant
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lady
Laura
,
I
do

you
joy
,
with
all

,
 
but
that
will
not

all

pleasant
.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
no

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

,

.
<EOS>
I
,
poor
,

,

,
Lady
Laura
Standish
;

I

my

.
<EOS>
And

I

done
on

that

.
<EOS>
Tell

,

"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

spoken

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

I

has

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Because
Loughlinter
 
<EOS>
"
  
"

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Phineas

.

It

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

<EOS>

Why

"

<EOS>

"

.

I

.
  
<EOS>
On
the

six

,

.
<EOS>
There

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Laura

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
Returns
to
Killaloe
 
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
's
first
session
of
Parliament
was
over
,
 
his
first
session
with
all
its
adventures
.
<EOS>
When
he
got
back
to
Mrs.
Bunce
's
house
,
 
for
Mrs.
Bunce
received
him
for
a
night
in
spite
of
her
husband
's
advice
to
the
contrary
,
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
he
almost
felt
that
Mrs.
Bunce
and
her
rooms
were
beneath
him
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
was
very
unhappy
,
 
as
wretched
as
a
man
can
be
;
there
were
moments
in
which
he
thought
that
it
would
hardly
become
him
to
live
unless
he
could
do
something
to
prevent
the
marriage
of
Lady
Laura
and
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
he
had
his
consolations
.
<EOS>
These
were
reflections
which
had
in
them
much
of
melancholy
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
despised
by
the
woman
to
whom
he
had
told
his
love
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
shown
him
that
she
thought
him
to
be
unworthy
of
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
regarded
his
love
as
an
offence
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
she
had
almost
told
him
that
prudence
alone
had
forbidden
her
to
return
his
passion
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
kissed
her
,
and
had
afterwards
parted
from
her
as
a
dear
friend
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
why
there
should
have
been
a
flavour
of
exquisite
joy
in
the
midst
of
his
agony
as
he
thought
of
this
;
 
but
it
was
so
.
<EOS>
He
would
never
kiss
her
again
.
<EOS>
All
future
delights
of
that
kind
would
belong
to
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
he
had
no
real
idea
of
interfering
with
that
gentleman
in
the
fruition
of
his
privileges
.
<EOS>
But
still
there
was
the
kiss
,
 
an
eternal
fact
.
<EOS>
And
then
,
in
all
respects
except
that
of
his
love
,
his
visit
to
Loughlinter
had
been
pre
-
eminently
successful
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
had
become
his
friend
,
and
had
encouraged
him
to
speak
during
the
next
session
,
 
setting
before
him
various
models
,
and
prescribing
for
him
a
course
of
reading
.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
had
become
intimate
with
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
on
pleasant
terms
with
Mr.
Palliser
and
Mr.
Gresham
.
<EOS>
And
as
for
Mr.
Kennedy
,
 
he
and
Mr.
Kennedy
were
almost
bosom
friends
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
him
that
he
had
quite
surpassed
the
Ratlers
,
Fitzgibbons
,
and
Bonteens
in
that
politico
-
social
success
which
goes
so
far
towards
downright
political
success
,
and
which
in
itself
is
so
pleasant
.
<EOS>
He
had
surpassed
these
men
in
spite
of
their
offices
and
their
acquired
positions
,
and
could
not
but
think
that
even
Mr.
Low
,
if
he
knew
it
all
,
would
confess
that
he
had
been
right
.
  
<EOS>
As
to
his
bosom
friendship
with
Mr.
Kennedy
,
that
of
course
troubled
him
.
<EOS>
Ought
he
not
to
be
driving
a
poniard
into
Mr.
Kennedy
's
heart
?
<EOS>
The
conventions
of
life
forbade
that
;
and
therefore
the
bosom
friendship
was
to
be
excused
.
<EOS>
If
not
an
enemy
to
the
death
,
then
there
could
be
no
reason
why
he
should
not
be
a
bosom
friend
.
  
<EOS>
He
went
over
to
Ireland
,
staying
but
one
night
with
Mrs.
Bunce
,
and
came
down
upon
them
at
Killaloe
like
a
god
out
of
the
heavens
.
<EOS>
Even
his
father
was
well
-
nigh
overwhelmed
by
admiration
,
and
his
mother
and
sisters
thought
themselves
only
fit
to
minister
to
his
pleasures
.
<EOS>
He
had
learned
,
if
he
had
learned
nothing
else
,
to
look
as
though
he
were
master
of
the
circumstances
around
him
,
and
was
entirely
free
from
internal

.
<EOS>
When
his
father
spoke
to
him
about
his
legal

,
he
did
not
exactly

at
his
father
's
ignorance
,
but
he
recapitulated
to
his
father
so
much
of
Mr.
Monk
's
wisdom
at
second
hand
,
 
showing
plainly
that
it
was
his
business
to
study
the
arts
of
speech
and
the

of
the
House
,
and
not
to
study
law
,
 
that
his
father
had
nothing
further
to
say
.
<EOS>
He
had
become
a
man
of
such
dimensions
that
an
ordinary
father
could
hardly
dare
to
inquire
into
his

;
and
as

an
ordinary

,
 
such

Mrs.
Finn
certainly
was
,
 
she
could
do
no

than

after
her
son
's
linen
with
awe
.
  
<EOS>
Mary
Flood
Jones
,
 
the
reader
I
hope
will
not
quite
have
forgotten
Mary
Flood
Jones
,
 
was
in
a

when

.
<EOS>
She
had
been
somewhat

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
But
Miss

Jones
in

had
never

.
<EOS>
And

,

,
 
that

.
<EOS>
Mary
,

,

,
but
she

.
<EOS>
Could

he
wore
that

?
<EOS>
Mary
had
received
from
Barbara
Finn
certain

supposed

the

Phineas
,
and
these
she

near

.
<EOS>
And

Elias
Bodkin
<EOS>
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Good

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,

Barbara
the

?
<EOS>
Of

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

.
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,
 
oh
,

,

.
<EOS>
He

that

wo

.
<EOS>
But

smiles

;

,

's

.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
a

,

,

,

Lady
Laura
Standish
was

,

Mary
Flood

in

.
  
<EOS>
He
remained
for

at

,
and
I

.
<EOS>
Some

books
recommended

by
Mr.
Monk
he

,
and
was

.
<EOS>
I
fear

there

a

about

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

;
"

.
"
<EOS>
"
Pray

.
<EOS>
We

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
"
<EOS>
"
He

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
Mary

;

that

,

,

,
 
in

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
About
<EOS>
Christmas
time
there
came

discussion
between
Phineas
and
his
father
about
money
.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

the
doctor
,
who
thought

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"

,
 
who
was
less

father
than

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
had

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

is
much
more

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

;
 
whether

<EOS>
"

"

"
  
"
Not

.
<EOS>
It

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

"
  
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

,

"
<EOS>

.

"
And

<EOS>
"

"
  
"
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

.
"
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
He

;

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas

,

.
<EOS>
It

that

told

of

for
Laurence

.
  
<EOS>
At
last
came

time
which
called

again
to
London

of
London

,
 
to

,

,

,

;

,

,
and

's

.
<EOS>
During

idleness

the

he
had
resolved
at
any
rate
upon
this
,
 
that
a
month
of
the
session
should
not
have
passed
by
before
he
had
been
seen
upon
his
legs
in
the
House
,
 
had
been
seen
and
heard
.
<EOS>
And
many
a
time
as
he
had

alone
,
with
his
gun
,
across
the
bogs
which
lie
on
the
other
side
of
the
Shannon
from
Killaloe
,
he
had
practised
the
sort
of
address
which
he
would
make
to
the
House
.
<EOS>
He
would
be
short
,
 
always
short
;
and
he
would
eschew
all
action
and
gesticulation
;
Mr.
Monk
had
been
very
urgent
in
his
instructions
to
him
on
that
head
;
but
he
would
be
especially
careful
that
no
words
should
escape
him
which
had
not
in
them
some
purpose
.
<EOS>
He
might
be
wrong
in
his
purpose
,
but
purpose
there
should
be
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
twitted
more
than
once
at
Killaloe
with
his
silence
;
 
for
it
had
been
conceived
by
his
fellow
-
townsmen
that
he
had
been
sent

on
the

ground
of
his

.
<EOS>
They
should
twit
him
no
more
on
his
next
return
.
<EOS>
He
would
speak
and
would
carry
the
House
with
him
if
a
human
effort
might
prevail
.
  
<EOS>
So
he
packed
up
his
things
,
and
started
again
for
London
in
the
beginning
of
February
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
Mary
<EOS>
,
"
he
said
with
his
sweetest
smile
.
