<EOS>
But
on
this
occasion
there
was
no
kiss
,
and
no
culling
of
locks
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
he
can
not
help
it
,
"
said
Mary
to
herself
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
his
position
.
<EOS>
But
whether
it
be
for
good
or
evil
,
I
will
be
true
to
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
you
are
unhappy
,
"
Babara
Finn
said
to
her
on
the
next
morning
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
am
not
unhappy
,
 
not
at
all
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
deal
to
make
me
happy
and
proud
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mean
to
be
a
bit
unhappy
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
she
turned
away
and
cried
heartily
,
and
Barbara
Finn
cried
with
her
for
company
.
   
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
Returns
to
London
 
<EOS>
Phineas
had
received
two
letters
during
his
recess
at
Killaloe
from
two
women
who
admired
him
much
,
which
,
as
they
were
both
short
,
shall
be
submitted
to
the
reader
.
<EOS>
The
first
was
as
follows
:
    
Saulsby
,
October
20
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
MY
DEAR
MR
.
<EOS>
FINN
,
  
<EOS>
I
write
a
line
to
tell
you
that
our
marriage
is
to
be
hurried
on
as
quickly
as
possible
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
does
not
like
to
be
absent
from
Parliament
;
nor
will
he
be
content
to
postpone
the
ceremony
till
the
session
be
over
.
<EOS>
The
day
fixed
is
the
3rd
of
December
,
and
we
then
go
at
once
to
Rome
,
and
intend
to
be
back
in
London
by
the
opening
of
Parliament
.
  
<EOS>
Yours
most
sincerely
,
  
LAURA
STANDISH
.
  
<EOS>
Our
London
address
will
be
No
.
52
,
Grosvenor
Place
.
  
<EOS>
To
this
he
wrote
an
answer
as
short
,
expressing
his
ardent
wishes
that
those
winter
hymeneals
might
produce
nothing
but
happiness
,
and
saying
that
he
would
not
be
in
town
many
days
before
he
knocked
at
the
door
of
No
.
52
,
Grosvenor
Place
.
  
<EOS>
And
the
second
letter
was
as
follows
:
    
<EOS>
Great
Marlborough
Street
,
December
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
DEAR
AND
HONOURED
SIR
<EOS>
,
  
Bunce
is
getting
ever
so
anxious
about
the
rooms
,
and
says
as
how
he
has
a
young
Equity
draftsman
and
wife
and
baby
as
would
take
the
whole
house
,
and
all
because
Miss
Pouncefoot
said
a
word
about
her
port
wine
,
which
any
lady
of
her
age
might
say
in
her
tantrums
,
and
mean
nothing
after
all
.
<EOS>
Me
and
Miss
Pouncefoot
's
knowed
each
other
for
seven
years
,
and
what
's
a
word
or
two
<EOS>
as
is
n't
meant
after
that
?
<EOS>
But
,
honoured
sir
,
it
's
not
about
that
as
I
write
to
trouble
you
,
but
to
ask
if
I
may
say
for
certain
that
you
'll
take
the
rooms
again
in
February
.
<EOS>
It
's
easy
to
let
them
for
the
month
after
Christmas
,
because
of
the
pantomimes
.
<EOS>
Only
say
at
once
,
because
Bunce
is
nagging
me
day
after
day
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
nobody
's
wife
and
baby
to
have
to
do
for
,
and
'd
sooner
have
a
Parliament
gent
like
yourself
than
any
one
else
.
  
<EOS>
Yours
umbly
and
respectful
,
  
JANE
BUNCE
.
  
<EOS>
To
this
he
replied
that
he
would
certainly
come
back
to
the
rooms
in
Great
Marlborough
Street
,
should
he
be
lucky
enough
to
find
them
vacant
,
and
he
expressed
his
willingness
to
take
them
on
and
from
the
1st
of
February
.
<EOS>
And
on
the
3rd
of
February
he
found
himself
in
the
old
quarters
,
Mrs.
Bunce
having
contrived
,
with
much
conjugal
adroitness
,
both
to
keep
Miss
Pouncefoot
and
to
stave
off
the
Equity
draftsman
's
wife
and
baby
.
<EOS>
Bunce
,
however
,
received
Phineas
very
coldly
,
and
told
his
wife
the
same
evening
that
as
far
as
he
could
see
their
lodger
would
never
turn
up
to
be
a
trump
in
the
matter
of
the
ballot
.
<EOS>
"
If
he
means
well
,
why
did
he
go
and
stay
with
them
lords
down
in
Scotland
?
<EOS>
I
knows
all
about
it
.
<EOS>
I
knows
a
man
when
I
sees
him
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
,
who
's
looking
out
to
be
a
Tory
judge
some
of
these
days
,
is
a
deal
better
;
 
because
he
knows
what
he
's
after
.
"
  
<EOS>
Immediately
on
his
return
to
town
,
Phineas
found
himself
summoned
to
a
political
meeting
at
Mr.
Mildmay
's
house
in
St.
James
's
Square
.
<EOS>
"
We
're
going
to
begin
in
earnest
this
time
,
"
Barrington
Erle
said
to
him
at
the
club
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
of
that
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
heard
all
about
it
down
at
Loughlinter
?
"
  
<EOS>
Now
,
in
truth
,
Phineas
had
heard
very
little
of
any
settled
plan
down
at
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
He
had
played
a
game
of
chess
with
Mr.
Gresham
,
and
had
shot
a
stag
with
Mr.
Palliser
,
and
had
discussed
sheep
with
Lord
Brentford
,
but
had
hardly
heard
a
word
about
politics
from
any
one
of
those
influential
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
From
Mr.
Monk
he
had
heard
much
of
a
coming
Reform
Bill
;
but
his
communications
with
Mr.
Monk
had
rather
been
private
discussions
,
 
in
which
he
had
learned
Mr.
Monk
's
own
views
on
certain
points
,
 
than
revelations
on
the
intention
of
the
party
to
which
Mr.
Monk
belonged
.
<EOS>
"
I
heard
of
nothing
settled
,
"
said
Phineas
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
suppose
we
are
to
have
a
Reform
Bill
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
a
matter
of
course
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
suppose
we
are
not
to
touch
the
question
of
ballot
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
difficulty
,
"
said
Barrington
Erle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
of
course
we
sha
n't
touch
it
as
long
as
Mr.
Mildmay
is
in
the
Cabinet
.
<EOS>
He
will
never
consent
to
the
ballot
as
First
Minister
of
the
Crown
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
would
Gresham
,
or
Palliser
,
"
said
Phineas
,
who
did
not
choose
to
bring
forward
his
greatest
gun
at
first
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
about
Gresham
.
<EOS>
It
is
impossible
to
say
what
Gresham
might
bring
himself
to
do
.
<EOS>
Gresham
is
a
man
who
may
go
any
lengths
before
he
has
done
.
<EOS>
Planty
Pall
,
"
 
for
such
was
the
name
by
which
Mr.
Plantagenet
Palliser
was
ordinarily
known
among
his
friends
,
 
"
would
of
course
go
with
Mr.
Mildmay
and
the
Duke
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
Monk
is
opposed
to
the
ballot
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
that
's
the
question
.
<EOS>
No
doubt
he
has
assented
to
the
proposition
of
a
measure
without
the
ballot
;
but
if
there
should
come
a
row
,
and
men
like
Turnbull
demand
it
,
and
the
London
mob
kick
up
a
shindy
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
know
how
far
Monk
would
be
steady
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whatever
he
says
,
he
'll
stick
to
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
your
leader
,
then
?
"
asked
Barrington
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
I
have
a
leader
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
leads
our
side
;
and
if
anybody
leads
me
,
he
does
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
great
faith
in
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
one
who
would
go
for
the
ballot
to
-
morrow
,
if
it
were
brought
forward
stoutly
,
"
said
Barrington
Erle
to
Mr.
Ratler
a
few
minutes
afterwards
,
pointing
to
Phineas
as
he
spoke
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
much
of
that
young
man
,
"
said
Ratler
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Bonteen
and
Mr.
Ratler
had
put
their
heads
together
during
that
last
evening
at
Loughlinter
,
and
had
agreed
that
they
did
not
think
much
of
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
Why
did
Mr.
Kennedy
go
down
off
the
mountain
to
get
him
a
pony
?
<EOS>
And
why
did
Mr.
Gresham
play
chess
with
him
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Ratler
and
Mr.
Bonteen
may
have
been
right
in
making
up
their
minds
to
think
<EOS>
but
little
of
Phineas
Finn
,
but
Barrington
Erle
had
been
quite
wrong
when
he
had
said
that
Phineas
would
"
go
for
the
ballot
"
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
made
up
his
mind
very
strongly
that
he
would
always
oppose
the
ballot
.
<EOS>
That
he
would
hold
the
same
opinion
throughout
his
life
,
no
one
should
pretend
to
say
;
but
in
his
present
mood
,
and
under
the
tuition
which
he
had
received
from
Mr.
Monk
,
he
was
prepared
to
demonstrate
,
out
of
the
House
and
in
it
,
that
the
ballot
was
,
as
a
political
measure
,
unmanly
,
ineffective
,
and
enervating
.
<EOS>
Enervating
had
been
a
great
word
with
Mr.
Monk
,
and
Phineas
had
clung
to
it
with
admiration
.
  
<EOS>
The
meeting
took
place
at
Mr.
Mildmay
's
on
the
third
day
of
the
session
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
of
course
heard
of
such
meetings
before
,
but
had
never
attended
one
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
there
had
been
no
such
gathering
when
Mr.
Mildmay
's
party
came
into
power
early
in
the
last
session
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
and
his
men
had
then
made
their
effort
in
turning
out
their
opponents
,
and
had
been
well
pleased
to
rest
awhile
upon
their
oars
.
<EOS>
Now
,
however
,
they
must
go
again
to
work
,
and
therefore
the
liberal
party
was
collected
at
Mr.
Mildmay
's
house
,
in
order
that
the
liberal
party
might
be
told
what
it
was
that
Mr.
Mildmay
and
his
Cabinet
intended
to
do
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
was
quite
in
the
dark
as
to
what
would
be
the
nature
of
the
performance
on
this
occasion
,
and
entertained
some
idea
that
every
gentleman
present
would
be
called
upon
to
express
individually
his
assent
or
dissent
in
regard
to
the
measure
proposed
.
<EOS>
He
walked
to
St.
James
's
Square
with
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
;
but
even
with
Fitzgibbon
was
ashamed
to
show
his
ignorance
by
asking
questions
.
<EOS>
"
After
all
,
"
said
Fitzgibbon
,
"
this
kind
of
thing
means
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
know
as
well
as
possible
,
and
so
do
you
,
what
Mr.
Mildmay
will
say
,
 
<EOS>
and
then
Gresham
will
say
a
few
words
;
and
then
Turnbull
will
make
a
murmur
,
and
then
we
shall
all
assent
,
 
to
anything
or
to
nothing
;
 
and
then
it
will
be
over
.
"
<EOS>
Still
Phineas
did
not
understand
whether
the
assent
required
would
or
would
not
be
an
individual
personal
assent
.
<EOS>
When
the
affair
was
over
he
found
that
he
was
disappointed
,
and
that
he
might
almost
as
well
have
stayed
away
from
the
meeting
,
 
except
that
he
had
attended
at
Mr.
Mildmay
's
bidding
,
and
had
given
a
silent
adhesion
to
Mr.
Mildmay
's
plan
of
reform
for
that
session
.
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
had
been
very
nearly
correct
in
his
description
of
what
would
occur
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
made
a
long
speech
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
,
the
great
Radical
of
the
day
,
 
the
man
who
was
supposed
to
represent
what
many
called
the
Manchester
school
of
politics
,
 
asked
half
a
dozen
questions
.
<EOS>
In
answer
to
these
Mr.
Gresham
made
a
short
speech
.
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Mildmay
made
another
speech
,
and
then
all
was
over
.
<EOS>
The
gist
of
the
whole
thing
was
,
that
there
should
be
a
Reform
Bill
,
 
very
generous
in
its
enlargement
of
the
franchise
,
 
but
no
ballot
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
expressed
his
doubt
whether
this
would
be
satisfactory
to
the
country
;
but
even
Mr.
Turnbull
was
soft
in
his
tone
and
complaisant
in
his
manner
.
<EOS>
As
there
was
no
reporter
present
,
 
<EOS>
that
plan
of
turning
private
meetings
at
gentlemen
's
houses
into
public
assemblies
not
having
been
as
yet
adopted
,
 
there
could
be
no
need
for
energy
or
violence
.
<EOS>
They
went
to
Mr.
Mildmay
's
house
to
hear
Mr.
Mildmay
's
plan
,
 
and
they
heard
it
.
  
<EOS>
Two
days
after
this
Phineas
was
to
dine
with
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
had
asked
him
in
the
lobby
of
the
House
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
give
dinner
parties
,
"
he
said
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
should
like
you
to
come
and
meet
Mr.
Turnbull
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
accepted
the
invitation
as
a
matter
of
course
.
<EOS>
There
were
many
who
said
that
Mr.
Turnbull
was
the
greatest
man
in
the
nation
,
and
that
the
nation
could
be
saved
only
by
a
direct
obedience
to
Mr.
Turnbull
's
instructions
.
<EOS>
Others
said
that
Mr.
Turnbull
was
a
demagogue
and
at
heart
a
rebel
;
that
he
was
un
-
English
,
false
and
very
dangerous
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
rather
inclined
to
believe
the
latter
statement
;
and
as
danger
and
dangerous
men
are
always
more
attractive
than
safety
and
safe
men
,
he
was
glad
to
have
an
opportunity
of
meeting
Mr.
Turnbull
at
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
he
went
to
call
on
Lady
Laura
,
whom
he
had
not
seen
since
the
last
evening
which
he
spent
in
her
company
at
Loughlinter
,
 
<EOS>
whom
,
when
he
was
last
speaking
to
her
,
he
had
kissed
close
beneath
the
falls
of
the
Linter
.
<EOS>
He
found
her
at
home
,
and
with
her
was
her
husband
.
<EOS>
"
Here
is
a
Darby
and
Joan
meeting
,
is
it
not
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
getting
up
to
welcome
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
seen
Mr.
Kennedy
before
,
and
had
been
standing
close
to
him
during
the
meeting
at
Mr.
Mildmay
's
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
to
find
you
both
together
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
Robert
is
going
away
this
instant
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Has
he
told
you
of
our
adventures
at
Rome
?
"
  
"
Not
a
word
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
must
tell
you
;
 
but
not
now
.
<EOS>
The
dear
old
Pope
was
so
civil
to
us
.
<EOS>
I
came
to
think
it
quite
a
pity
that
he
should
be
in
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
be
off
,
"
said
the
husband
,
getting
up
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
shall
meet
you
at
dinner
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
you
dine
at
Mr.
Monk
's
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
am
asked
expressly
to
hear
Turnbull
make
a
convert
of
you
.
<EOS>
There
are
only
to
be
us
four
.
<EOS>
Au
revoir
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Kennedy
went
,
and
Phineas
found
himself
alone
with
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
He
hardly
knew
how
to
address
her
,
and
remained
silent
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
prepared
himself
for
the
interview
as
he
ought
to
have
done
,
and
felt
himself
to
be
awkward
.
<EOS>
She
evidently
expected
him
to
speak
,
and
for
a
few
seconds
sat
waiting
for
what
he
might
say
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
she
found
that
it
was
incumbent
on
her
to
begin
.
<EOS>
"
Were
you
surprised
at
our
suddenness
when
you
got
my
note
?
"
  
"
A
little
.
<EOS>
You
had
spoken
of
waiting
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
had
never
imagined
that
he
would
have
been
impetuous
.
<EOS>
And
he
seems
to
think
that
even
the
business
of
getting
himself
married
would
not
justify
him
staying
away
from
Parliament
.
<EOS>
He
is
a
rigid
martinet
in
all
matters
of
duty
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
wonder
that
he
should
be
in
a
hurry
,
but
that
you
should
submit
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
that
I
should
do
just
what
the
wise
people
told
me
.
<EOS>
I
asked
papa
,
and
he
said
that
it
would
be
better
.
<EOS>
So
the
lawyers
were
driven
out
of
their
minds
,
and
the
milliners
out
of
their
bodies
,
and
the
thing
was
done
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
was
there
at
the
marriage
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oswald
was
not
there
.
<EOS>
That
I
know
is
what
you
mean
to
ask
.
<EOS>
Papa
said
that
he
might
come
if
he
pleased
.
<EOS>
Oswald
stipulated
that
he
should
be
received
as
a
son
.
<EOS>
Then
my
father
spoke
the
hardest
word
that
ever
fell
from
his
mouth
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
did
he
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
will
not
repeat
it
,
 
not
altogether
.
<EOS>
But
he
said
that
Oswald
was
not
entitled
to
a
son
's
treatment
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
sore
about
my
money
,
because
Robert
was
so
generous
as
to
his
settlement
.
<EOS>
So
the
breach
between
them
is
as
wide
as
ever
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
where
is
Chiltern
now
?
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Down
in
Northamptonshire
,
staying
at
some
inn
from
whence
he
hunts
.
<EOS>
He
tells
me
that
he
is
quite
alone
,
 
that
he
never
dines
out
,
never
has
any
one
to
dine
with
him
,
that
he
hunts
five
or
six
days
a
week
,
 
and
reads
at
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
not
a
bad
sort
of
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
if
the
reading
is
any
good
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
not
bear
that
he
should
be
so
solitary
.
<EOS>
And
if
he
breaks
down
in
it
,
then
his
companions
will
not
be
fit
for
him
.
<EOS>
Do
you
ever
hunt
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
 
at
home
in
county
Clare
.
<EOS>
All
Irishmen
hunt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
would
go
down
to
him
and
see
him
.
<EOS>
He
would
be
delighted
to
have
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
thought
over
the
proposition
before
he
answered
it
,
and
then
made
the
reply
that
he
had
made
once
before
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
do
so
,
Lady
Laura
,
 
but
that
I
have
no
money
for
hunting
in
England
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Alas
,
alas
!
"
said
she
,
smiling
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
that
hits
one
on
every
side
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
might
manage
it
,
 
for
a
couple
of
days
,
 
in
March
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
do
what
you
think
you
ought
not
to
do
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
certainly
.
<EOS>
But
I
should
like
it
,
and
if
I
can
I
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
could
mount
you
,
I
have
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
He
has
no
other
expense
now
,
and
keeps
a
stable
full
of
horses
.
<EOS>
I
think
he
has
seven
or
eight
.
<EOS>
And
now
tell
me
,
Mr.
Finn
;
when
are
you
going
to
charm
the
House
?
<EOS>
Or
is
it
your
first
intention
to
strike
terror
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
blushed
,
 
he
knew
that
he
blushed
as
he
answered
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
suppose
I
shall
make
some
sort
of
attempt
before
long
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
bear
the
idea
of
being
a
bore
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
ought
to
speak
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
about
that
,
but
I
certainly
mean
to
try
.
<EOS>
There
will
be
lots
of
opportunities
about
the
new
Reform
Bill
.
<EOS>
Of
course
you
know
that
Mr.
Mildmay
is
going
to
bring
it
in
at
once
.
<EOS>
You
hear
all
that
from
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
papa
has
told
me
.
<EOS>
I
still
see
papa
almost
every
day
.
<EOS>
You
must
call
upon
him
.
<EOS>
Mind
you
do
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
said
that
he
certainly
would
.
<EOS>
"
Papa
is
very
lonely
now
,
and
I
sometimes
feel
that
I
have
been
almost
cruel
in
deserting
him
.
<EOS>
And
I
think
that
he
has
a
horror
of
the
house
,
 
especially
later
in
the
year
,
 
always
fancying
that
he
will
meet
Oswald
.
<EOS>
I
am
so
unhappy
about
it
all
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
does
n't
your
brother
marry
?
"
said
Phineas
,
knowing
nothing
as
yet
of
Lord
Chiltern
and
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
"
If
he
were
to
marry
well
,
that
would
bring
your
father
round
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
 
it
would
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
why
should
he
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
paused
before
she
answered
;
and
then
she
told
the
whole
story
.
"
<EOS>
He
is
violently
in
love
,
and
the
girl
he
loves
has
refused
him
twice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
with
Miss
Effingham
?
"
asked
Phineas
,
guessing
the
truth
at
once
,
and
remembering
what
Miss
Effingham
had
said
to
him
when
riding
in
the
wood
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
 
with
Violet
Effingham
;
my
father
's
pet
,
his
favourite
,
whom
he
loves
next
to
myself
,
 
almost
as
well
as
myself
;
whom
he
would
really
welcome
as
a
daughter
.
<EOS>
He
would
gladly
make
her
mistress
of
his
house
,
and
of
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
Everything
would
then
go
smoothly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
she
does
not
like
Lord
Chiltern
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
she
loves
him
in
her
heart
;
but
she
is
afraid
of
him
.
<EOS>
As
she
says
herself
,
a
girl
is
bound
to
be
so
careful
of
herself
.
<EOS>
With
all
her
seeming
frolic
,
Violet
Effingham
is
very
wise
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
though
not
conscious
of
anything
akin
to
jealousy
,
was
annoyed
at
the
revelation
made
to
him
.
<EOS>
Since
he
had
heard
that
Lord
Chiltern
was
in
love
with
Miss
Effingham
,
he
did
not
like
Lord
Chiltern
quite
as
well
as
he
had
done
before
.
<EOS>
He
himself
had
simply
admired
Miss
Effingham
,
and
had
taken
pleasure
in
her
society
;
but
,
though
this
had
been
all
,
he
did
not
like
to
hear
of
another
man
wanting
to
marry
her
,
and
he
was
almost
angry
with
Lady
Laura
for
saying
that
she
believed
Miss
Effingham
loved
her
brother
.
<EOS>
If
Miss
Effingham
had
twice
refused
Lord
Chiltern
,
that
ought
to
have
been
sufficient
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
Phineas
was
in
love
with
Miss
Effingham
himself
.
<EOS>
As
he
was
still
violently
in
love
with
Lady
Laura
,
any
other
love
was
of
course
impossible
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
there
was
something
offensive
to
him
in
the
story
as
it
had
been
told
.
<EOS>
"
If
it
be
wisdom
on
her
part
,
"
said
he
,
answering
Lady
Laura
's
last
words
<EOS>
,
"
you
can
not
find
fault
with
her
for
her
decision
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
find
no
fault
;
 
but
<EOS>
I
think
my
brother
would
make
her
happy
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
,
when
she
was
left
alone
,
at
once
reverted
to
the
tone
in
which
Phineas
Finn
had
answered
her
remarks
about
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
very
ill
able
to
conceal
his
thoughts
,
and
wore
his
heart
almost
upon
his
sleeve
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Can
it
be
possible
that
he
cares
for
her
himself
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That
was
the
nature
of
Lady
Laura
's
first
question
to
herself
upon
the
matter
.
<EOS>
And
in
asking
herself
that
question
,
she
thought
nothing
of
the
disparity
in
rank
or
fortune
between
Phineas
Finn
and
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
Nor
did
it
occur
to
her
as
at
all
improbable
that
Violet
might
accept
the
love
of
him
who
had
so
lately
been
her
own
lover
.
<EOS>
But
the
idea
grated
against
her
wishes
on
two
sides
.
<EOS>
She
was
most
anxious
that
Violet
should
ultimately
become
her
brother
's
wife
,
 
<EOS>
and
she
could
not
be
pleased
that
Phineas
should
be
able
to
love
any
woman
.
  
<EOS>
I
must
beg
my
readers
not
to
be
carried
away
by
those
last
words
into
any
erroneous
conclusion
.
<EOS>
They
must
not
suppose
that
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
,
the
lately
married
bride
,
indulged
a
guilty
passion
for
the
young
man
who
had
loved
her
.
<EOS>
Though
she
had
probably
thought
often
of
Phineas
Finn
since
her
marriage
,
her
thoughts
had
never
been
of
a
nature
to
disturb
her
rest
.
<EOS>
It
had
never
occurred
to
her
even
to
think
that
she
regarded
him
with
any
feeling
that
was
an
offence
to
her
husband
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
hated
herself
had
any
such
idea
presented
itself
to
her
mind
.
<EOS>
She
prided
herself
on
being
a
pure
high
-
principled
woman
,
who
had
kept
so
strong
a
guard
upon
herself
as
to
be
nearly
free
from
the
dangers
of
those
rocks
upon
which
other
women
made
shipwreck
of
their
happiness
.
<EOS>
She
took
pride
in
this
,
and
would
then
blame
herself
for
her
own
pride
.
<EOS>
But
though
she
so
blamed
herself
,
it
never
occurred
to
her
to
think
that
to
her
there
might
be
danger
of
such
shipwreck
.
<EOS>
She
had
put
away
from
herself
the
idea
of
love
when
she
had
first
perceived
that
Phineas
had
regarded
her
with
more
than
friendship
,
and
had
accepted
Mr.
Kennedy
's
offer
with
an
assured
conviction
that
by
doing
so
she
was
acting
best
for
her
own
happiness
and
for
that
of
all
those
concerned
.
<EOS>
She
had
felt
the
romance
of
the
position
to
be
sweet
when
Phineas
had
stood
with
her
at
the
top
of
the
falls
of
the
Linter
,
and
had
told
her
of
the
hopes
which
he
had
dared
to
indulge
.
<EOS>
And
when
at
the
bottom
of
the
falls
he
had
presumed
to
take
her
in
his
arms
,
she
had
forgiven
him
without
difficulty
to
herself
,
telling
herself
that
that
would
be
the
alpha
and
the
omega
of
the
romance
of
her
life
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
felt
herself
bound
to
tell
Mr.
Kennedy
of
what
had
occurred
,
 
but
she
had
felt
that
he
could
hardly
have
been
angry
<EOS>
even
had
he
been
told
.
<EOS>
And
she
had
often
thought
of
her
lover
since
,
and
of
his
love
,
 
telling
herself
that
she
too
had
once
had
a
lover
,
never
regarding
her
husband
in
that
light
;
but
her
thoughts
had
not
frightened
her
as
guilty
thoughts
will
do
.
<EOS>
There
had
come
a
romance
which
had
been
pleasant
,
and
it
was
gone
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
soon
banished
,
 
but
it
had
left
to
her
a
sweet
flavour
,
of
which
she
loved
to
taste
the
sweetness
though
she
knew
that
it
was
gone
.
<EOS>
And
the
man
should
be
her
friend
,
but
especially
her
husband
's
friend
.
<EOS>
It
should
be
her
care
to
see
that
his
life
was
successful
,
 
and
especially
her
husband
's
care
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
delight
to
her
to
know
that
her
husband
liked
the
man
.
<EOS>
And
the
man
would
marry
,
and
the
man
's
wife
should
be
her
friend
.
<EOS>
All
this
had
been
very
pure
and
very
pleasant
.
<EOS>
Now
an
idea
had
flitted
across
her
brain
that
the
man
was
in
love
with
some
one
else
,
 
and
she
did
not
like
it
!
  
<EOS>
But
she
did
not
therefore
become
afraid
of
herself
,
or
in
the
least
realise
at
once
the
danger
of
her
own
position
.
<EOS>
Her
immediate
glance
at
the
matter
did
not
go
beyond
the
falseness
of
men
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
so
,
as
she
suspected
,
 
if
Phineas
had
in
truth
transferred
his
affections
to
Violet
Effingham
,
of
how
little
value
was
the
love
of
such
a
man
!
<EOS>
It
did
not
occur
to
her
at
this
moment
that
she
also
had
transferred
hers
to
Robert
Kennedy
,
or
that
,
if
not
,
she
had
done
worse
.
<EOS>
But
she
did
remember
that
in
the
autumn
this
young
Phoebus
among
men
had
turned
his
back
upon
her
out
upon
the
mountain
that
he
might
hide
from
her
the
agony
of
his
heart
when
he
learned
that
she
was
to
be
the
wife
of
another
man
;
and
that
now
,
before
the
winter
was
over
,
he
could
not
hide
from
her
the
fact
that
his
heart
was
elsewhere
!
<EOS>
And
then
she
speculated
,
and
counted
up
facts
,
and
satisfied
herself
that
Phineas
could
not
even
have
seen
Violet
Effingham
since
they
two
had
stood
together
upon
the
mountain
.
<EOS>
How
false
are
men
!
 
<EOS>
how
false
and
how
weak
of
heart
!
  
<EOS>
"
Chiltern
and
Violet
Effingham
!
"
said
Phineas
to
himself
,
as
he
walked
away
from
Grosvenor
Place
.
<EOS>
"
Is
it
fair
that
she
should
be
sacrificed
because
she
is
rich
,
and
because
she
is
so
winning
and
so
fascinating
that
Lord
Brentford
would
receive
even
his
son
for
the
sake
of
receiving
also
such
a
daughter
-
in
-
law
?
"
<EOS>
Phineas
also
liked
Lord
Chiltern
;
had
seen
or
fancied
that
he
had
seen
fine
things
in
him
;
had
looked
forward
to
his
regeneration
,
hoping
,
perhaps
,
that
he
might
have
some
hand
in
the
good
work
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
recognise
the
propriety
of
sacrificing
Violet
Effingham
even
for
work
so
good
as
this
.
<EOS>
If
Miss
Effingham
had
refused
Lord
Chiltern
twice
,
surely
that
ought
to
be
sufficient
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
occur
to
him
that
the
love
of
such
a
girl
as
Violet
would
be
a
great
treasure
 
to
himself
.
<EOS>
As
regarded
himself
,
he
was
still
in
love
,
 
hopelessly
in
love
,
with
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
!
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
Wednesday
evening
and
there
was
no
House
;
 
and
at
seven
o'clock
<EOS>
Phineas
was
at
Mr.
Monk
's
hall
door
.
<EOS>
He
was
the
first
of
the
guests
,
and
he
found
Mr.
Monk
alone
in
the
dining
-
room
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
doing
butler
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
,
who
had
a
brace
of
decanters
in
his
hands
,
which
he
proceeded
to
put
down
in
the
neighbourhood
of
the
fire
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
finished
,
and
now
we
will
go
up
-
stairs
to
receive
the
two
great
men
properly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
for
coming
too
early
,
"
said
Finn
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
minute
too
early
.
<EOS>
Seven
is
seven
,
and
it
is
I
who
am
too
late
.
<EOS>
But
,
Lord
bless
you
<EOS>
,
you
do
n't
think
I
'm
ashamed
of
being
found
in
the
act
of
decanting
my
own
wine
!
<EOS>
I
remember
Lord
Palmerston
saying
before
some
committee
about
salaries
,
five
or
six
years
ago
now
,
I
daresay
,
that
it
would
n't
do
for
an
English
Minister
to
have
his
hall
door
opened
by
a
maid
-
servant
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
'm
an
English
Minister
,
and
I
've
got
nobody
but
a
maid
-
servant
to
open
my
hall
door
,
and
I
'm
obliged
to
look
after
my
own
wine
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
it
's
improper
?
<EOS>
I
should
n't
like
to
be
the
means
of
injuring
the
British
Constitution
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
if
you
resign
soon
,
and
if
nobody
follows
your
example
,
grave
evil
results
may
be
avoided
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
sincerely
hope
so
,
for
I
do
love
the
British
Constitution
;
and
I
love
also
the
respect
in
which
members
of
the
English
Cabinet
are
held
.
<EOS>
Now
Turnbull
,
who
will
be
here
in
a
moment
,
hates
it
all
;
but
he
is
a
rich
man
,
and
has
more
powdered
footmen
hanging
about
his
house
than
ever
Lord
Palmerston
had
himself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
still
in
business
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
;
 
and
makes
his
thirty
thousand
a
year
.
<EOS>
Here
he
is
.
<EOS>
How
are
you
,
Turnbull
?
<EOS>
We
were
talking
about
my
maid
-
servant
.
<EOS>
I
hope
she
opened
the
door
for
you
properly
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly
,
 
as
far
as
I
perceived
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
,
who
was
better
at
a
speech
than
a
joke
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
very
respectable
young
woman
I
should
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
not
one
more
so
in
all
London
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
;
"
but
Finn
seems
to
think
that
I
ought
to
have
a
man
in
livery
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
matter
of
perfect
indifference
to
me
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
one
of
those
who
never
think
of
such
things
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
I
either
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
Then
the
laird
of
Loughlinter
was
announced
,
and
they
all
went
down
to
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
was
a
good
-
looking
robust
man
about
sixty
,
with
long
grey
hair
and
a
red
complexion
,
with
hard
eyes
,
a
well
-
cut
nose
,
and
full
lips
.
<EOS>
He
was
nearly
six
feet
high
,
stood
quite
upright
,
and
always
wore
a
black
swallow
-
tail
coat
,
black
trousers
,
and
a
black
silk
waistcoat
.
<EOS>
In
the
House
,
at
least
,
he
was
always
so
dressed
,
and
at
dinner
tables
.
<EOS>
What
difference
there
might
be
in
his
costume
<EOS>
when
at
home
at
Staleybridge
few
of
those
who
saw
him
in
London
had
the
means
of
knowing
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
in
his
face
to
indicate
special
talent
.
<EOS>
No
one
looking
at
him
would
take
him
to
be
a
fool
;
but
there
was
none
of
the
fire
of
genius
in
his
eye
,
nor
was
there
in
the
lines
of
his
mouth
any
of
that
play
of
thought
or
fancy
which
is
generally
to
be
found
in
the
faces
of
men
and
women
who
have
made
themselves
great
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
had
certainly
made
himself
great
,
and
could
hardly
have
done
so
without
force
of
intellect
.
<EOS>
He
was
one
of
the
most
popular
,
if
not
the
most
popular
politician
in
the
country
.
<EOS>
Poor
men
believed
in
him
,
thinking
that
he
was
their
most
honest
public
friend
;
and
men
who
were
not
poor
believed
in
his
power
,
thinking
that
his
counsels
must
surely
prevail
.
<EOS>
He
had
obtained
the
ear
of
the
House
and
the
favour
of
the
reporters
,
and
opened
his
voice
at
no
public
dinner
,
on
no
public
platform
,
without
a
conviction
that
the
words
spoken
by
him
would
be
read
by
thousands
.
<EOS>
The
first
necessity
for
good
speaking
is
a
large
audience
;
and
of
this
advantage
Mr.
Turnbull
had
made
himself
sure
.
<EOS>
And
yet
it
could
hardly
be
said
that
he
was
a
great
orator
.
<EOS>
He
was
gifted
with
a
powerful
voice
,
with
strong
,
and
I
may
,
perhaps
,
call
them
broad
convictions
,
with
perfect
self
-
reliance
,
with
almost
unlimited
powers
of
endurance
,
with
hot
ambition
,
with
no
keen
scruples
,
and
with
a
moral
skin
of
great
thickness
.
<EOS>
Nothing
said
against
him
pained
him
,
no
attacks
wounded
him
,
no
raillery
touched
him
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
There
was
not
a
sore
spot
about
him
,
and
probably
his
first
thoughts
on
waking
every
morning
told
him
that
he
,
at
least
,
was
totus
teres
atque
rotundus
.
<EOS>
He
was
,
of
course
,
a
thorough
Radical
,
 
and
so
was
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Monk
's
first
waking
thoughts
were
probably
exactly
the
reverse
of
those
of
his
friend
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
was
a
much
hotter
man
in
debate
than
Mr.
Turnbull
;
 
but
Mr.
Monk
was
ever
doubting
of
himself
,
and
never
doubted
of
himself
so
much
as
when
he
had
been
most
violent
,
and
also
most
effective
,
in
debate
.
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Monk
jeered
at
himself
for
being
a
Cabinet
Minister
and
keeping
no
attendant
grander
than
a
parlour
-
maid
,
there
was
a
substratum
of
self
-
doubt
under
the
joke
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
was
certainly
a
great
Radical
,
and
as
such
enjoyed
a
great
reputation
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
that
high
office
in
the
State
had
ever
been
offered
to
him
;
but
things
had
been
said
which
justified
him
,
or
seemed
to
himself
to
justify
him
,
in
declaring
that
in
no
possible
circumstances
would
he
serve
the
Crown
.
<EOS>
"
I
serve
the
people
,
"
he
had
said
,
"
and
much
as
I
respect
the
servants
of
the
Crown
<EOS>
,
I
think
that
my
own
office
is
the
higher
.
"
<EOS>
He
had
been
greatly
called
to
task
for
this
speech
;
and
Mr.
Mildmay
,
the
present
Premier
,
had
asked
him
whether
he
did
not
recognise
the
so
-
called
servants
of
the
Crown
as
the
most
hard
-
worked
and
truest
servants
of
the
people
.
<EOS>
The
House
and
the
press
had
supported
Mr.
Mildmay
,
but
to
all
that
Mr.
Turnbull
was
quite
indifferent
;
and
when
an
assertion
made
by
him
before
three
or
four
thousand
persons
at
Manchester
,
to
the
effect
that
he
,
 
he
specially
,
 
was
the
friend
and
servant
of
the
people
,
was
received
with
acclamation
,
he
felt
quite
satisfied
that
he
had
gained
his
point
.
<EOS>
Progressive
reform
in
the
franchise
,
of
which
manhood
suffrage
should
be
the
acknowledged
and
not
far
distant
end
,
equal
electoral
districts
,
ballot
,
tenant
right
for
England
as
well
as
Ireland
,
reduction
of
the
standing
army
till
there
should
be
no
standing
army
to
reduce
,
utter
disregard
of
all
political
movements
in
Europe
,
an
almost
idolatrous
admiration
for
all
political
movements
in
America
,
free
trade
in
everything
except
malt
,
and
an
absolute
extinction
of
a
State
Church
,
 
<EOS>
these
were
among
the
principal
articles
in
Mr.
Turnbull
's
political
catalogue
.
<EOS>
And
I
think
that
when
once
he
had
learned
the
art
of
arranging
his
words
as
he
stood
upon
his
legs
,
and
had
so
mastered
his
voice
as
to
have
obtained
the
ear
of
the
House
,
the
work
of
his
life
was
not
difficult
.
<EOS>
Having
nothing
to
construct
,
he
could
always
deal
with
generalities
.
<EOS>
Being
free
from
responsibility
,
he
was
not
called
upon
either
to
study
details
or
to
master
even
great
facts
.
<EOS>
It
was
his
business
to
inveigh
against
existing
evils
,
and
perhaps
there
is
no
easier
business
when
once
the
privilege
of
an
audience
has
been
attained
.
<EOS>
It
was
his
work
to
cut
down
forest
-
trees
,
and
he
had
nothing
to
do
with
the
subsequent
cultivation
of
the
land
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
had
once
told
Phineas
Finn
how
great
were
the
charms
of
that
inaccuracy
which
was
permitted
to
the
Opposition
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
no
doubt
enjoyed
these
charms
to
the
full
,
though
he
would
sooner
have
put
a
padlock
on
his
mouth
for
a
month
than
have
owned
as
much
.
<EOS>
Upon
the
whole
,
Mr.
Turnbull
was
no
doubt
right
in
resolving
that
he
would
not
take
office
,
though
some
reticence
on
that
subject
might
have
been
more
becoming
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
conversation
at
dinner
,
though
it
was
altogether
on
political
subjects
,
had
in
it
nothing
of
special
interest
as
long
as
the
girl
was
there
to
change
the
plates
;
but
when
she
was
gone
,
and
the
door
was
closed
,
it
gradually
opened
out
,
and
there
came
on
to
be
a
pleasant
sparring
match
between
the
two
great
Radicals
,
 
the
Radical
who
had
joined
himself
to
the
governing
powers
,
and
the
Radical
who
stood
aloof
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
barely
said
a
word
now
and
then
,
and
Phineas
was
almost
as
silent
as
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
He
had
come
there
to
hear
some
such
discussion
,
and
was
quite
willing
to
listen
while
guns
of
such
great
calibre
were
being
fired
off
for
his
amusement
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
Mr.
Mildmay
is
making
a
great
step
forward
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
is
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
believe
that
he
would
ever
live
to
go
so
far
.
<EOS>
It
will
hardly
suffice
even
for
this
year
;
but
still
coming
from
him
,
it
is
a
great
deal
.
<EOS>
It
only
shows
how
far
a
man
may
be
made
to
go
,
if
only
the
proper
force
be
applied
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
it
matters
very
little
who
are
the
Ministers
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
what
I
have
always
declared
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
little
indeed
.
<EOS>
We
do
n't
mind
whether
it
be
Lord
de
Terrier
,
or
Mr.
Mildmay
,
or
Mr.
Gresham
,
or
you
yourself
,
if
you
choose
to
get
yourself
made
First
Lord
of
the
Treasury
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
such
ambition
,
Turnbull
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
thought
you
had
.
<EOS>
If
I
went
in
for
that
kind
of
thing
myself
,
I
should
like
to
go
to
the
top
of
the
ladder
.
<EOS>
I
should
feel
that
if
I
could
do
any
good
at
all
by
becoming
a
Minister
,
I
could
only
do
it
by
becoming
first
Minister
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
You
would
n't
doubt
your
own
fitness
for
such
a
position
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
doubt
my
fitness
for
the
position
of
any
Minister
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
mean
that
on
other
grounds
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
it
on
every
ground
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
,
rising
on
his
legs
and
standing
with
his
back
to
the
fire
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
am
not
fit
to
have
diplomatic
intercourse
with
men
who
would
come
to
me
simply
with
the
desire
of
deceiving
me
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
am
unfit
to
deal
with
members
of
Parliament
who
would
flock
around
me
because
they
wanted
places
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
am
unfit
to
answer
every
man
's
question
so
as
to
give
no
information
to
any
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Could
you
not
answer
them
so
as
to
give
information
?
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Turnbull
was
so
intent
on
his
speech
that
it
may
be
doubted
whether
he
heard
this
interruption
.
<EOS>
He
took
no
notice
of
it
as
he
went
on
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
am
unfit
to
maintain
the
proprieties
of
a
seeming
confidence
between
a
Crown
all
-
powerless
and
a
people
all
-
powerful
.
<EOS>
No
man
recognises
his
own
unfitness
for
such
work
more
clearly
than
I
do
,
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
But
if
I
took
in
hand
such
work
at
all
,
I
should
like
to
be
the
leader
,
and
not
the
led
.
<EOS>
Tell
us
fairly
,
now
,
what
are
your
convictions
worth
in
Mr.
Mildmay
's
Cabinet
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
a
question
which
a
man
may
hardly
answer
himself
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
question
which
a
man
should
at
least
answer
for
himself
before
he
consents
to
sit
there
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
,
in
a
tone
of
voice
which
was
almost
angry
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
reason
have
you
for
supposing
that
I
have
omitted
that
duty
?
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
  
<EOS>
"
Simply
this
,
 
that
I
can
not
reconcile
your
known
opinions
with
the
practices
of
your
colleagues
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
tell
you
what
my
convictions
may
be
worth
in
Mr.
Mildmay
's
Cabinet
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
take
upon
myself
to
say
that
they
are
worth
the
chair
on
which
I
sit
when
I
am
there
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
tell
you
what
my
aspirations
were
when
I
consented
to
fill
that
chair
,
and
you
shall
judge
of
their
worth
.
<EOS>
I
thought
that
they
might
possibly
leaven
the
batch
of
bread
which
we
have
to
bake
,
 
giving
to
the
whole
batch
more
of
the
flavour
of
reform
than
it
would
have
possessed
<EOS>
had
I
absented
myself
.
<EOS>
I
thought
that
when
I
was
asked
to
join
Mr.
Mildmay
and
Mr.
Gresham
,
the
very
fact
of
that
request
indicated
liberal
progress
,
and
that
if
I
refused
the
request
I
should
be
declining
to
assist
in
good
work
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
could
have
supported
them
,
if
anything
were
proposed
worthy
of
support
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
but
I
could
not
have
been
so
effective
in
taking
care
that
some
measure
be
proposed
worthy
of
support
as
I
may
possibly
be
now
.
<EOS>
I
thought
a
good
deal
about
it
,
and
I
believe
that
my
decision
was
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
you
were
right
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
can
be
no
juster
object
of
ambition
than
a
seat
in
the
Cabinet
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
I
must
dispute
that
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
,
turning
round
upon
our
hero
.
<EOS>
"
I
regard
the
position
of
our
high
Ministers
as
most
respectable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
for
so
much
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
But
the
orator
went
on
again
,
regardless
of
the
interruption
:
    
"
The
position
of
gentlemen
in
inferior
offices
,
 
of
gentlemen
who
attend
rather
to
the
nods
and
winks
of
their
superiors
in
Downing
Street
than
to
the
interest
of
their
constituents
,
 
I
do
not
regard
as
being
highly
respectable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
man
can
not
begin
at
the
top
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Our
friend
Mr.
Monk
has
begun
at
what
you
are
pleased
to
call
the
top
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
will
not
profess
to
think
that
even
he
has
raised
himself
by
going
into
office
.
<EOS>
To
be
an
independent
representative
of
a
really
popular
commercial
constituency
is
,
in
my
estimation
,
the
highest
object
of
an
Englishman
's
ambition
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
why
commercial
,
Mr.
Turnbull
?
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
the
commercial
constituencies
really
do
elect
their
own
members
in
accordance
with
their
own
judgments
,
whereas
the
counties
and
the
small
towns
are
coerced
either
by
individuals
or
by
a
combination
of
aristocratic
influences
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
yet
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
,
"
there
are
not
half
a
dozen
Conservatives
returned
by
all
the
counties
in
Scotland
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Scotland
is
very
much
to
be
honoured
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
was
the
first
to
take
his
departure
,
and
Mr.
Turnbull
followed
him
very
quickly
.
<EOS>
Phineas
got
up
to
go
at
the
same
time
,
but
stayed
at
his
host
's
request
,
and
sat
for
awhile
smoking
a
cigar
.
  
<EOS>
"
Turnbull
is
a
wonderful
man
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
  
<EOS>
"
Does
he
not
domineer
too
much
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
His
fault
is
not
arrogance
,
so
much
as
ignorance
that
there
is
,
or
should
be
,
a
difference
between
public
and
private
life
.
<EOS>
In
the
House
of
Commons
a
man
in
Mr.
Turnbull
's
position
must
speak
with
dictatorial
assurance
.
<EOS>
He
is
always
addressing
,
not
the
House
only
,
but
the
country
at
large
,
and
the
country
will
not
believe
in
him
unless
he
believe
in
himself
.
<EOS>
But
he
forgets
that
he
is
not
always
addressing
the
country
at
large
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
what
sort
of
a
time
Mrs.
Turnbull
and
the
little
Turnbulls
have
of
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
as
he
went
home
,
made
up
his
mind
that
Mrs.
Turnbull
and
the
little
Turnbulls
must
probably
have
a
bad
time
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
Rides
<EOS>
His
Horse
Bonebreaker
 
<EOS>
It
was
known
that
whatever
might
be
the
details
of
Mr.
Mildmay
's
bill
,
the
ballot
would
not
form
a
part
of
it
;
and
<EOS>
as
there
was
a
strong
party
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
and
a
very
numerous
party
out
of
it
,
who
were
desirous
that
voting
by
ballot
should
be
made
a
part
of
the
electoral
law
,
it
was
decided
that
an
independent
motion
should
be
brought
on
in
anticipation
of
Mr.
Mildmay
's
bill
.
<EOS>
The
arrangement
was
probably
one
of
Mr.
Mildmay
's
own
making
;
so
that
he
might
be
hampered
by
no
opposition
on
that
subject
by
his
own
followers
if
,
 
as
he
did
not
doubt
,
 
the
motion
should
be
lost
.
<EOS>
It
was
expected
that
the
debate
would
not
last
over
one
night
,
and
Phineas
resolved
that
he
would
make
his
maiden
speech
on
this
occasion
.
<EOS>
He
had
very
strong
opinions
as
to
the
inefficacy
of
the
ballot
for
any
good
purposes
,
and
thought
that
he
might
be
able
to
strike
out
from
his
convictions
some
sparks
of
that
fire
which
used
to
be
so
plentiful
with
him
at
the
old
debating
clubs
.
<EOS>
But
even
at
breakfast
that
morning
his
heart
began
to
beat
quickly
at
the
idea
of
having
to
stand
on
his
legs
before
so
critical
an
audience
.
  
<EOS>
He
knew
that
it
would
be
well
that
he
should
if
possible
get
the
subject
off
his
mind
during
the
day
,
and
therefore
went
out
among
the
people
who
certainly
would
not
talk
to
him
about
the
ballot
.
<EOS>
He
sat
for
nearly
an
hour
in
the
morning
with
Mr.
Low
,
and
did
not
even
tell
Mr.
Low
that
it
was
his
intention
to
speak
on
that
day
.
<EOS>
Then
he
made
one
or
two
other
calls
,
and
at
about
three
went
up
to
Portman
Square
to
look
for
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
nearly
the
end
of
February
,
and
Phineas
had
often
seen
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
seen
her
brother
,
but
had
learned
from
his
sister
that
he
had
been
driven
up
to
London
by
the
frost
,
He
was
told
by
the
porter
at
Lord
Brentford
's
that
Lord
Chiltern
was
in
the
house
,
and
as
he
was
passing
through
the
hall
he
met
Lord
Brentford
himself
.
<EOS>
He
was
thus
driven
to
speak
,
and
felt
himself
called
upon
to
explain
why
he
was
there
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
come
to
see
Lord
Chiltern
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
Lord
Chiltern
in
the
house
?
"
said
the
Earl
,
turning
to
the
servant
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
lord
;
his
lordship
arrived
last
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
You
will
find
him
upstairs
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
myself
I
know
nothing
of
him
.
"
<EOS>
He
spoke
in
an
angry
tone
,
as
though
he
resented
the
fact
that
any
one
should
come
to
his
house
to
call
upon
his
son
;
and
turned
his
back
quickly
upon
Phineas
.
<EOS>
But
he
thought
better
of
it
before
he
reached
the
front
door
,
and
turned
again
.
<EOS>
"
By
-
the
-
bye
,
"
said
he
,
"
what
majority
shall
we
have
to
-
night
,
Finn
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Pretty
nearly
as
many
as
you
please
to
name
,
my
lord
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;
 
yes
;
I
suppose
we
are
tolerably
safe
.
<EOS>
You
ought
to
speak
upon
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
may
,
"
said
Phineas
,
feeling
that
he
blushed
as
he
spoke
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
,
"
said
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
Do
.
<EOS>
If
you
see
Lord
Chiltern
will
you
tell
him
from
me
that
I
should
be
glad
to
see
him
before
he
leaves
London
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
at
home
till
noon
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
,
much
astonished
at
the
commission
given
to
him
,
of
course
said
that
he
would
do
as
he
was
desired
,
and
then
passed
on
to
Lord
Chiltern
's
apartments
.
  
<EOS>
He
found
his
friend
standing
in
the
middle
of
the
room
,
without
coat
and
waistcoat
,
with
a
pair
of
dumb
-
bells
in
his
hands
.
<EOS>
"
When
there
's
no
hunting
I
'm
driven
to
this
kind
of
thing
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
it
's
good
exercise
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
it
gives
me
something
to
do
.
<EOS>
When
I
'm
in
London
I
feel
like
a
gipsy
in
church
,
till
the
time
comes
for
prowling
out
at
night
.
<EOS>
I
've
no
occupation
for
my
days
<EOS>
whatever
,
and
no
place
to
which
I
can
take
myself
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
stand
in
a
club
window
as
some
men
do
,
and
I
should
disgrace
any
decent
club
if
I
did
stand
there
.
<EOS>
I
belong
to
the
Travellers
,
but
I
doubt
whether
the
porter
would
let
me
go
in
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
pique
yourself
on
being
more
of
an
outer
Bohemian
than
you
are
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
pique
myself
on
this
,
that
whether
Bohemian
or
not
,
I
will
go
nowhere
that
I
am
not
wanted
.
<EOS>
Though
,
 
for
the
matter
of
that
,
I
suppose
I
'm
not
wanted
here
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
gave
him
the
message
from
his
father
.
"
<EOS>
He
wishes
to
see
me
to
-
morrow
morning
?
<EOS>
"
continued
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
Let
him
send
me
word
what
it
is
he
has
to
say
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
choose
to
be
insulted
by
him
,
though
he
is
my
father
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
certainly
go
,
if
I
were
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
doubt
it
very
much
,
if
all
the
circumstances
were
the
same
.
<EOS>
Let
him
tell
me
what
he
wants
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
can
not
ask
him
,
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
he
wants
very
well
.
<EOS>
Laura
has
been
interfering
and
doing
no
good
.
<EOS>
You
know
Violet
Effingham
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
I
know
her
,
"
said
Phineas
,
much
surprised
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
want
her
to
marry
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
do
not
wish
to
marry
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
say
that
.
<EOS>
But
do
you
think
that
such
a
girl
as
Miss
Effingham
would
marry
such
a
man
as
I
am
?
<EOS>
She
would
be
much
more
likely
to
take
you
.
<EOS>
By
George
,
she
would
!
<EOS>
Do
you
know
that
she
has
three
thousand
a
year
of
her
own
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
she
has
money
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
about
the
tune
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
would
take
her
without
a
shilling
to
-
morrow
,
if
she
would
have
me
,
 
because
I
like
her
.
<EOS>
She
is
the
only
girl
I
ever
did
like
.
<EOS>
But
what
is
the
use
of
my
liking
her
?
<EOS>
They
have
painted
me
so
black
among
them
,
especially
my
father
,
that
no
decent
girl
would
think
of
marrying
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
father
ca
n't
be
angry
with
you
if
you
do
your
best
to
comply
with
his
wishes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
a
straw
whether
he
be
angry
or
not
.
<EOS>
He
allows
me
eight
hundred
a
year
,
and
he
knows
that
if
he
stopped
it
I
should
go
to
the
Jews
the
next
day
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
help
myself
.
<EOS>
He
ca
n't
leave
an
acre
away
from
me
,
and
yet
he
wo
n't
join
me
in
raising
money
for
the
sake
of
paying
Laura
her
fortune
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lady
Laura
can
hardly
want
money
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
detestable
prig
whom
she
has
chosen
to
marry
,
and
whom
I
hate
with
all
my
heart
,
is
richer
than
ever
Croesus
was
;
but
nevertheless
Laura
ought
to
have
her
own
money
.
<EOS>
She
shall
have
it
some
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
see
Lord
Brentford
,
if
I
were
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
think
about
it
.
<EOS>
Now
tell
me
about
coming
down
to
Willingford
.
<EOS>
Laura
says
you
will
come
some
day
in
March
.
<EOS>
I
can
mount
you
for
a
couple
of
days
and
should
be
delighted
to
have
you
.
<EOS>
My
horses
all
pull
like
the
mischief
,
and
rush
like
devils
,
and
want
a
deal
of
riding
;
but
an
Irishman
likes
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
dislike
it
particularly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
like
it
.
<EOS>
I
prefer
to
have
something
to
do
on
horseback
.
<EOS>
When
a
man
tells
me
that
a
horse
is
an
armchair
,
I
always
tell
him
to
put
the
brute
into
his
bedroom
.
<EOS>
Mind
you
come
.
<EOS>
The
house
I
stay
at
is
called
the
Willingford
Bull
,
and
it
's
just
four
miles
from
Peterborough
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
swore
that
he
would
go
down
and
ride
the
pulling
horses
,
and
then
took
his
leave
,
earnestly
advising
Lord
Chiltern
,
as
he
went
,
to
keep
the
appointment
proposed
by
his
father
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
morning
came
,
at
half
-
past
eleven
,
the
son
,
who
had
been
standing
for
half
an
hour
with
his
back
to
the
fire
in
the
large
gloomy
dining
-
room
,
suddenly
rang
the
bell
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Tell
the
Earl
,
"
he
said
to
the
servant
,
"
that
I
am
here
and
will
go
to
him
if
he
wishes
it
.
"
<EOS>
The
servant
came
back
,
and
said
that
the
Earl
was
waiting
.
<EOS>
Then
Lord
Chiltern
strode
after
the
man
into
his
father
's
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oswald
,
"
said
the
father
,
"
I
have
sent
for
you
because
I
think
it
may
be
as
well
to
speak
to
you
on
some
business
.
<EOS>
Will
you
sit
down
?
"
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
sat
down
,
but
did
not
answer
a
word
.
<EOS>
"
I
feel
very
unhappy
about
your
sister
's
fortune
,
"
said
the
Earl
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
do
I
,
 
very
unhappy
.
<EOS>
We
can
raise
the
money
between
us
,
and
pay
her
to
-
morrow
,
if
you
please
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
in
opposition
to
my
advice
that
she
paid
your
debts
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
in
opposition
to
mine
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
told
her
that
I
would
not
pay
them
,
and
were
I
to
give
her
back
to
-
morrow
,
as
you
say
,
the
money
that
she
has
so
used
,
I
should
be
stultifying
myself
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
do
so
on
one
condition
.
<EOS>
I
will
join
with
you
in
raising
the
money
for
your
sister
,
on
one
condition
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Laura
tells
me
,
 
indeed
she
has
told
me
often
,
 
that
you
are
attached
to
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
Violet
Effingham
,
my
lord
,
is
unhappily
not
attached
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
how
that
may
be
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
can
not
say
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
taken
the
liberty
of
interrogating
her
upon
the
subject
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Even
you
,
my
lord
,
could
hardly
have
done
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
that
?
<EOS>
I
say
that
I
never
have
,
"
said
the
Earl
,
angrily
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
simply
mean
that
even
you
could
hardly
have
asked
Miss
Effingham
such
a
question
.
<EOS>
I
have
asked
her
,
and
she
has
refused
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
girls
often
do
that
,
and
yet
accept
afterwards
the
men
whom
they
have
refused
.
<EOS>
Laura
tells
me
that
she
believes
that
Violet
would
consent
if
you
pressed
your
suit
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Laura
knows
nothing
about
it
,
my
lord
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
you
are
probably
wrong
.
<EOS>
Laura
and
Violet
are
very
close
friends
,
and
have
no
doubt
discussed
this
matter
between
them
.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
it
may
be
as
well
that
you
should
hear
what
I
have
to
say
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
shall
not
interfere
myself
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
ground
on
which
I
can
do
so
with
propriety
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
None
whatever
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
The
Earl
became
very
angry
,
and
nearly
broke
down
in
his
anger
.
<EOS>
He
paused
for
a
moment
,
feeling
disposed
to
tell
his
son
to
go
and
never
to
see
him
again
.
<EOS>
But
he
gulped
down
his
wrath
,
and
went
on
with
his
speech
.
<EOS>
"
My
meaning
,
sir
,
is
this
;
 
that
I
have
so
great
faith
in
Violet
Effingham
,
that
I
would
receive
her
acceptance
of
your
hand
as
the
only
proof
which
would
be
convincing
to
me
of
amendment
in
your
mode
of
life
.
<EOS>
If
she
were
to
do
so
,
I
would
join
with
you
in
raising
money
to
pay
your
sister
,
would
make
some
further
sacrifice
with
reference
to
an
income
for
you
and
your
wife
,
and
 
would
make
you
both
welcome
to
Saulsby
,
 
if
you
chose
to
come
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Earl
's
voice
hesitated
much
and
became
almost
tremulous
as
he
made
the
last
proposition
.
<EOS>
And
his
eyes
had
fallen
away
from
his
son
's
gaze
,
and
he
had
bent
a
little
over
the
table
,
and
was
moved
.
<EOS>
But
he
recovered
himself
at
once
,
and
added
,
with
all
proper
dignity
,
"
If
you
have
anything
to
say
I
shall
be
glad
to
hear
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
your
offers
would
be
nothing
,
my
lord
,
if
I
did
not
like
the
girl
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
ask
you
to
marry
a
girl
if
you
did
not
like
her
,
as
you
call
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
as
to
Miss
Effingham
,
it
happens
that
our
wishes
jump
together
.
<EOS>
I
have
asked
her
,
and
she
has
refused
me
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
even
know
where
to
find
her
to
ask
her
again
.
<EOS>
If
I
went
to
Lady
Baldock
's
house
the
servants
would
not
let
me
in
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
whose
fault
is
that
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yours
partly
,
my
lord
.
<EOS>
You
have
told
everybody
that
I
am
the
devil
,
and
now
all
the
old
women
believe
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
told
anybody
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
I
'll
do
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
down
to
Lady
Baldock
's
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
she
is
at
Baddingham
.
<EOS>
And
if
I
can
get
speech
of
Miss
Effingham
 
"
  
"
Miss
Effingham
is
not
at
Baddingham
.
<EOS>
Miss
Effingham
is
staying
with
your
sister
in
Grosvenor
Place
.
<EOS>
I
saw
her
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
in
London
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
that
I
saw
her
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
my
lord
.
<EOS>
Then
I
will
do
the
best
I
can
.
<EOS>
Laura
will
tell
you
of
the
result
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
father
would
have
given
the
son
some
advice
as
to
the
mode
in
which
he
should
put
forward
his
claim
upon
Violet
's
hand
,
but
the
son
would
not
wait
to
hear
it
.
<EOS>
Choosing
to
presume
that
the
conference
was
over
,
he
went
back
to
the
room
in
which
he
had
kept
his
dumb
-
bells
,
and
for
a
minute
or
two
went
to
work
at
his
favourite
exercise
.
<EOS>
But
he
soon
put
the
dumb
-
bells
down
,
and
began
to
prepare
himself
for
his
work
.
<EOS>
If
this
thing
was
to
be
done
,
it
might
as
well
be
done
at
once
.
<EOS>
He
looked
out
of
his
window
,
and
saw
that
the
streets
were
in
a
mess
of
slush
.
<EOS>
White
snow
was
becoming
black
mud
,
as
it
will
do
in
London
;
and
the
violence
of
frost
was
giving
way
to
the
horrors
of
thaw
.
<EOS>
All
would
be
soft
and
comparatively
pleasant
in
Northamptonshire
on
the
following
morning
,
and
if
everything
went
right
he
would
breakfast
at
the
Willingford
Bull
.
<EOS>
He
would
go
down
by
the
hunting
train
,
and
be
at
the
inn
by
ten
.
<EOS>
The
meet
was
only
six
miles
distant
,
and
all
would
be
pleasant
.
<EOS>
He
would
do
this
whatever
might
be
the
result
of
his
work
to
-
day
;
 
but
in
the
meantime
he
would
go
and
do
his
work
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
cab
called
,
and
within
half
an
hour
of
the
time
at
which
he
had
left
his
father
,
he
was
at
the
door
of
his
sister
's
house
in
Grosvenor
Place
.
<EOS>
The
servants
told
him
that
the
ladies
were
at
lunch
.
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
eat
lunch
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Tell
them
that
I
am
in
the
drawing
-
room
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
come
to
see
you
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
as
soon
as
the
servant
had
left
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
not
say
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
say
it
.
<EOS>
I
hope
he
has
not
come
to
see
me
;
 
that
is
,
not
to
see
me
specially
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
can
not
pretend
not
to
know
what
you
mean
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
may
think
it
civil
to
call
if
he
has
heard
that
you
are
in
town
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
after
a
pause
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
it
be
only
that
,
I
will
be
civil
in
return
;
 
as
sweet
as
May
to
him
.
<EOS>
If
it
be
really
only
that
,
and
if
I
were
sure
of
it
,
I
should
be
really
glad
to
see
him
.
"
<EOS>
Then
they
finished
their
lunch
,
and
Lady
Laura
got
up
and
led
the
way
to
the
drawing
-
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
remember
,
"
said
she
,
gravely
,
"
that
you
might
be
a
saviour
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
believe
in
girls
being
saviours
to
men
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
man
who
should
be
the
saviour
to
the
girl
.
<EOS>
If
I
marry
at
all
,
I
have
the
right
to
expect
that
protection
shall
be
given
to
me
,
 
not
that
I
shall
have
to
give
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Violet
,
you
are
determined
to
misrepresent
what
I
mean
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
was
walking
about
the
room
,
and
did
not
sit
down
when
they
entered
.
<EOS>
The
ordinary
greetings
took
place
,
and
Miss
Effingham
made
some
remark
about
the
frost
.
"
<EOS>
But
it
seems
to
be
going
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
I
suppose
that
you
will
soon
be
at
work
again
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
I
shall
hunt
to
-
morrow
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
the
next
day
,
and
the
next
,
and
the
next
,
"
said
Violet
,
"
till
about
the
middle
of
April
;
 
and
then
your
period
of
misery
will
begin
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Exactly
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
but
hunting
that
I
can
call
an
occupation
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
n't
you
make
one
?
"
said
his
sister
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
to
do
so
,
if
it
be
possible
.
<EOS>
Laura
,
would
you
mind
leaving
me
and
Miss
Effingham
alone
for
a
few
minutes
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
got
up
,
and
so
also
did
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
"
For
what
purpose
?
"
said
the
latter
.
<EOS>
"
It
can
not
be
for
any
good
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
I
wish
it
,
and
I
will
not
harm
you
.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
was
now
going
,
but
paused
before
she
reached
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
Laura
,
will
you
do
as
I
ask
you
?
"
said
the
brother
.
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Laura
went
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
that
I
feared
you
would
harm
me
,
Lord
Chiltern
,
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
I
know
it
was
not
.
<EOS>
But
what
I
say
is
always
said
awkwardly
.
<EOS>
An
hour
ago
I
did
not
know
that
you
were
in
town
,
but
when
I
was
told
the
news
I
came
at
once
.
<EOS>
My
father
told
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
glad
that
you
see
your
father
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
spoken
to
him
for
months
before
,
and
probably
may
not
speak
to
him
for
months
again
.
<EOS>
But
there
is
one
point
,
Violet
,
on
which
he
and
I
agree
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
there
will
soon
be
many
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
possible
,
 
but
<EOS>
I
fear
not
probable
.
<EOS>
Look
here
,
Violet
,
"
 
and
he
looked
at
her
with
all
his
eyes
,
till
it
seemed
to
her
that
he
was
all
eyes
,
<EOS>
so
great
was
the
intensity
of
his
gaze
;
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
scorn
myself
were
I
to
permit
myself
to
come
before
you
with
a
plea
for
your
favour
founded
on
my
father
's
whims
.
<EOS>
My
father
is
unreasonable
,
and
has
been
very
unjust
to
me
.
<EOS>
He
has
ever
believed
evil
of
me
,
and
has
believed
it
often
when
all
the
world
knew
that
he
was
wrong
.
<EOS>
I
care
little
for
being
reconciled
to
a
father
who
has
been
so
cruel
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
loves
me
dearly
,
and
is
my
friend
.
<EOS>
I
would
rather
that
you
should
not
speak
against
him
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
understand
,
at
least
,
that
I
am
asking
nothing
from
you
because
he
wishes
it
.
<EOS>
Laura
probably
has
told
you
that
you
may
make
things
straight
by
becoming
my
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
,
 
certainly
,
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
an
argument
that
she
should
never
have
used
.
<EOS>
It
is
an
argument
to
which
you
should
not
listen
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
Make
things
straight
indeed
!
<EOS>
Who
can
tell
?
<EOS>
There
would
be
very
little
made
straight
by
such
a
marriage
,
if
it
were
not
that
I
loved
you
.
<EOS>
Violet
,
that
is
my
plea
,
and
my
only
one
.
<EOS>
I
love
you
so
well
that
I
do
believe
that
if
you
took
me
I
should
return
to
the
old
ways
,
and
become
as
other
men
are
,
and
be
in
time
as
respectable
,
as
stupid
,
 
and
perhaps
as
ill
-
natured
as
old
Lady
Baldock
herself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
poor
aunt
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
she
says
worse
things
of
me
than
that
.
<EOS>
Now
,
dearest
,
you
have
heard
all
that
I
have
to
say
to
you
.
"
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
he
came
close
to
her
,
and
put
out
his
hand
,
 
<EOS>
but
she
did
not
touch
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
other
argument
to
use
,
 
not
a
word
more
to
say
.
<EOS>
As
I
came
here
in
the
cab
I
was
turning
it
over
in
my
mind
that
I
might
find
what
best
I
should
say
.
<EOS>
But
,
after
all
,
there
is
nothing
more
to
be
said
than
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
words
make
no
difference
,
"
she
replied
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
unless
they
be
so
uttered
as
to
force
a
belief
.
<EOS>
I
do
love
you
.
<EOS>
I
know
no
other
reason
but
<EOS>
that
why
you
should
be
my
wife
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
other
excuse
to
offer
for
coming
to
you
again
.
<EOS>
You
are
the
one
thing
in
the
world
that
to
me
has
any
charm
.
<EOS>
Can
you
be
surprised
that
I
should
be
persistent
in
asking
for
it
?
"
<EOS>
He
was
looking
at
her
still
with
the
same
gaze
,
and
there
seemed
to
be
a
power
in
his
eye
from
which
she
could
not
escape
.
<EOS>
He
was
still
standing
with
his
right
hand
out
,
as
though
expecting
,
or
at
least
hoping
,
that
her
hand
might
be
put
into
his
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
am
I
to
answer
you
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
With
your
love
,
if
you
can
give
it
to
me
.
<EOS>
Do
you
remember
how
you
swore
once
that
you
would
love
me
for
ever
and
always
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
not
remind
me
of
that
.
<EOS>
I
was
a
child
then
,
 
a
naughty
child
,
"
she
added
,
smiling
;
"
and
was
put
to
bed
for
what
I
did
on
that
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Be
a
child
still
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
if
we
but
could
!
"
  
"
And
have
you
no
other
answer
to
make
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
must
answer
you
.
<EOS>
You
are
entitled
to
an
answer
.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
,
I
am
sorry
that
I
can
not
give
you
the
love
for
which
you
ask
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
?
"
  
"
Never
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
myself
personally
,
or
what
you
have
heard
of
me
,
that
is
so
hateful
to
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
is
hateful
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
spoken
of
hate
.
<EOS>
I
shall
always
feel
the
strongest
regard
for
my
old
friend
and
playfellow
.
<EOS>
But
there
are
many
things
which
a
woman
is
bound
to
consider
before
she
allows
herself
so
to
love
a
man
that
she
can
consent
to
become
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Allow
herself
!
<EOS>
Then
it
is
a
matter
entirely
of
calculation
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
there
should
be
some
thought
in
it
,
Lord
Chiltern
.
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
now
a
pause
,
and
the
man
's
hand
was
at
last
allowed
to
drop
,
as
there
came
no
response
to
the
proffered
grasp
.
<EOS>
He
walked
once
or
twice
across
the
room
before
he
spoke
again
,
and
then
he
stopped
himself
closely
opposite
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
try
again
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
better
so
,
"
she
replied
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
something
to
me
unmanly
in
a
man
's
persecuting
a
girl
.
<EOS>
Just
tell
Laura
,
will
you
,
that
it
is
all
over
;
and
she
may
as
well
tell
my
father
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
then
tendered
her
hand
to
him
,
but
he
did
not
take
it
,
 
probably
did
not
see
it
,
and
at
once
left
the
room
and
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
I
believe
you
love
him
,
"
Lady
Laura
said
to
her
friend
in
her
anger
,
when
they
discussed
the
matter
immediately
on
Lord
Chiltern
's
departure
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
right
to
say
that
,
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
right
to
my
belief
,
and
I
do
believe
it
.
<EOS>
I
think
you
love
him
,
and
that
you
lack
the
courage
to
risk
yourself
in
trying
to
save
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
a
woman
bound
to
marry
a
man
if
she
love
him
?
"
  
"
Yes
,
she
is
,
"
replied
Lady
Laura
impetuously
,
without
thinking
of
what
she
was
saying
;
"
that
is
,
if
she
be
convinced
that
she
also
is
loved
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whatever
be
the
man
's
character
;
 
whatever
be
the
circumstances
?
<EOS>
Must
she
do
so
<EOS>
,
whatever
friends
may
say
to
the
contrary
?
<EOS>
Is
there
to
be
no
prudence
in
marriage
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
may
be
a
great
deal
too
much
prudence
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
true
.
<EOS>
There
is
certainly
too
much
prudence
if
a
woman
marries
prudently
,
but
without
love
.
"
<EOS>
Violet
intended
by
this
no
attack
upon
her
friend
,
 
had
not
had
present
in
her
mind
at
the
moment
any
idea
of
Lady
Laura
's
special
prudence
in
marrying
Mr.
Kennedy
;
but
Lady
Laura
felt
it
keenly
,
and
knew
at
once
that
an
arrow
had
been
shot
which
had
wounded
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
get
nothing
,
"
she
said
,
"
by
descending
to
personalities
with
each
other
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
meant
none
,
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
it
is
always
hard
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
"
for
any
one
person
to
judge
altogether
of
the
mind
of
another
.
<EOS>
If
I
have
said
anything
severe
of
your
refusal
of
my
brother
,
I
retract
it
.
<EOS>
I
only
wish
that
it
could
have
been
otherwise
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
,
when
he
left
his
sister
's
house
,
walked
through
the
slush
and
dirt
to
a
haunt
of
his
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Covent
Garden
,
and
there
he
remained
through
the
whole
afternoon
and
evening
.
<EOS>
A
certain
Captain
Clutterbuck
joined
him
,
and
dined
with
him
.
<EOS>
He
told
nothing
to
Captain
Clutterbuck
of
his
sorrow
,
but
Captain
Clutterbuck
could
see
that
he
was
unhappy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
's
have
another
bottle
of
"
cham
,
"
"
said
Captain
Clutterbuck
,
when
their
dinner
was
nearly
over
.
"
<EOS>
"
Cham
"
is
the
only
thing
to
screw
one
up
when
one
is
down
a
peg
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
have
what
you
like
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
;
"
but
I
shall
have
some
brandy
-
and
-
water
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
worst
of
brandy
-
and
-
water
is
,
that
one
gets
tired
of
it
before
the
night
is
over
,
"
said
Captain
Clutterbuck
.
  
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
Lord
Chiltern
did
go
down
to
Peterborough
the
next
day
by
the
hunting
train
,
and
rode
his
horse
Bonebreaker
so
well
in
that
famous
run
from
Sutton
springs
to
Gidding
that
after
the
run
young
Piles
,
 
of
the
house
of
Piles
,
Sarsnet
,
and
Gingham
,
 
offered
him
three
hundred
pounds
for
the
animal
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
n't
worth
above
fifty
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
'll
give
you
the
three
hundred
,
"
said
Piles
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
could
n't
ride
him
if
you
'd
got
him
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
could
n't
I
!
"
said
Piles
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Piles
did
not
continue
the
conversation
,
contenting
himself
with
telling
his
friend
Grogram
that
that
red
devil
Chiltern
was
as
drunk
as
a
lord
.
   
<EOS>
The
Debate
on
the
Ballot
 
Phineas
took
his
seat
in
the
House
with
a
consciousness
of
much
inward
trepidation
of
heart
on
that
night
of
the
ballot
debate
.
<EOS>
After
leaving
Lord
Chiltern
he
went
down
to
his
club
and
dined
alone
.
<EOS>
Three
or
four
men
came
and
spoke
to
him
;
but
he
could
not
talk
to
them
at
his
ease
,
nor
did
he
quite
know
what
they
were
saying
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
going
to
do
something
which
he
longed
to
achieve
,
but
the
very
idea
of
which
,
now
that
it
was
so
near
to
him
,
was
a
terror
to
him
.
<EOS>
To
be
in
the
House
and
not
to
speak
would
,
to
his
thinking
,
be
a
disgraceful
failure
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
could
not
continue
to
keep
his
seat
unless
he
spoke
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
put
there
that
he
might
speak
.
<EOS>
He
would
speak
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
would
speak
.
<EOS>
Had
he
not
already
been
conspicuous
almost
as
a
boy
orator
?
<EOS>
And
yet
,
at
this
moment
he
did
not
know
whether
he
was
eating
mutton
or
beef
,
or
who
was
standing
opposite
to
him
and
talking
to
him
,
<EOS>
so
much
was
he
in
dread
of
the
ordeal
which
he
had
prepared
for
himself
.
<EOS>
As
he
went
down
to
the
House
after
dinner
,
he
almost
made
up
his
mind
that
it
would
be
a
good
thing
to
leave
London
by
one
of
the
night
mail
trains
.
<EOS>
He
felt
himself
to
be
stiff
and
stilted
as
he
walked
,
and
that
his
clothes
were
uneasy
to
him
.
<EOS>
When
he
turned
into
Westminster
Hall
he
regretted
more
keenly
than
ever
he
had
done
that
he
had
seceded
from
the
keeping
of
Mr.
Low
.
<EOS>
He
could
,
he
thought
,
have
spoken
very
well
in
court
,
and
would
there
have
learned
that
self
-
confidence
which
now
failed
him
so
terribly
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
however
,
too
late
to
think
of
that
.
<EOS>
He
could
only
go
in
and
take
his
seat
.
  
<EOS>
He
went
in
and
took
his
seat
,
and
the
chamber
seemed
to
him
to
be
mysteriously
large
,
as
though
benches
were
crowded
over
benches
,
and
galleries
over
galleries
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
long
enough
in
the
House
to
have
lost
the
original
awe
inspired
by
the
Speaker
and
the
clerks
of
the
House
,
by
the
row
of
Ministers
,
and
by
the
unequalled
importance
of
the
place
.
<EOS>
On
ordinary
occasions
he
could
saunter
in
and
out
,
and
whisper
at
his
ease
to
a
neighbour
.
<EOS>
But
on
this
occasion
he
went
direct
to
the
bench
on
which
he
ordinarily
sat
,
and
began
at
once
to
rehearse
to
himself
his
speech
.
<EOS>
He
had
in
truth
been
doing
this
all
day
,
in
spite
of
the
effort
that
he
had
made
to
rid
himself
of
all
memory
of
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
collecting
the
heads
of
his
speech
while
Mr.
Low
had
been
talking
to
him
,
and
refreshing
his
quotations
in
the
presence
of
Lord
Chiltern
and
the
dumb
-
bells
.
<EOS>
He
had
taxed
his
memory
and
his
intellect
with
various
tasks
,
which
,
as
he
feared
,
would
not
adjust
themselves
one
with
another
.
<EOS>
He
had
learned
the
headings
of
his
speech
,
 
so
that
one
heading
might
follow
the
other
,
and
nothing
be
forgotten
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
learned
verbatim
the
words
which
he
intended
to
utter
under
each
heading
,
 
with
a
hope
that
if
any
one
compact
part
should
be
destroyed
or
injured
in
its
compactness
by
treachery
of
memory
,
or
by
the
course
of
the
debate
,
each
other
compact
part
might
be
there
in
its
entirety
,
ready
for
use
;
 
or
at
least
so
many
of
the
compact
parts
as
treachery
of
memory
and
the
accidents
of
the
debate
might
leave
to
him
;
so
that
his
speech
might
be
like
a
vessel
,
watertight
in
its
various
compartments
<EOS>
,
that
would
float
by
the
buoyancy
of
its
stern
and
bow
,
even
though
the
hold
should
be
waterlogged
.
<EOS>
But
this
use
of
his
composed
words
,
even
though
he
should
be
able
to
carry
it
through
,
would
not
complete
his
work
;
 
<EOS>
for
it
would
be
his
duty
to
answer
in
some
sort
those
who
had
gone
before
him
,
and
in
order
to
do
this
he
must
be
able
to
insert
,
without
any
prearrangement
of
words
or
ideas
,
little
intercalatory
parts
between
those
compact
masses
of
argument
with
which
he
had
been
occupying
himself
for
many
laborious
hours
.
<EOS>
As
he
looked
round
upon
the
House
and
perceived
that
everything
was
dim
before
him
,
that
all
his
original
awe
of
the
House
had
returned
,
and
with
it
a
present
quaking
fear
that
made
him
feel
the
pulsations
of
his
own
heart
,
he
became
painfully
aware
that
the
task
he
had
prepared
for
himself
was
too
great
.
<EOS>
He
should
,
on
this
the
occasion
of
his
rising
to
his
maiden
legs
,
have
either
prepared
for
himself
a
short
general
speech
,
which
could
indeed
have
done
little
for
his
credit
in
the
House
,
but
which
might
have
served
to
carry
off
the
novelty
of
the
thing
,
and
have
introduced
him
to
the
sound
of
his
own
voice
within
those
walls
,
 
or
he
should
have
trusted
to
what
his
wit
and
spirit
would
produce
for
him
on
the
spur
of
the
moment
,
and
not
have
burdened
himself
with
a
huge
exercise
of
memory
.
<EOS>
During
the
presentation
of
a
few
petitions
he
tried
to
repeat
to
himself
the
first
of
his
compact
parts
,
 
a
compact
part
on
which
,
as
it
might
certainly
be
brought
into
use
let
the
debate
have
gone
as
it
might
,
he
had
expended
great
care
.
<EOS>
He
had
flattered
himself
that
there
was
something
of
real
strength
in
his
words
as
he
repeated
them
to
himself
in
the
comfortable
seclusion
of
his
own
room
,
and
he
had
made
them
so
ready
to
his
tongue
that
he
thought
it
to
be
impossible
that
he
should
forget
even
an
intonation
.
<EOS>
Now
he
found
that
he
could
not
remember
the
first
phrases
without
unloosing
and
looking
at
a
small
roll
of
paper
which
he
held
furtively
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
What
was
the
good
of
looking
at
it
?
<EOS>
He
would
forget
it
again
in
the
next
moment
.
<EOS>
He
had
intended
to
satisfy
the
most
eager
of
his
friends
,
and
to
astound
his
opponents
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
no
one
would
be
satisfied
,
 
and
none
astounded
but
they
who
had
trusted
in
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
debate
began
,
and
if
the
leisure
afforded
by
a
long
and
tedious
speech
could
have
served
him
,
he
might
have
had
leisure
enough
.
<EOS>
He
tried
at
first
to
follow
all
that
this
advocate
for
the
ballot
might
say
,
hoping
thence
to
acquire
the
impetus
of
strong
interest
;
but
he
soon
wearied
of
the
work
,
and
began
to
long
that
the
speech
might
be
ended
,
although
the
period
of
his
own
martyrdom
would
thereby
be
brought
nearer
to
him
.
<EOS>
At
half
-
past
seven
<EOS>
so
many
members
had
deserted
their
seats
,
that
Phineas
began
to
think
that
he
might
be
saved
all
further
pains
by
a
"
count
out
.
"
<EOS>
He
reckoned
the
members
present
and
found
that
they
were
below
the
mystic
forty
,
 
first
by
two
,
then
by
four
,
by
five
,
by
seven
,
and
at
one
time
by
eleven
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
for
him
to
ask
the
Speaker
to
count
the
House
,
but
he
wondered
that
no
one
else
should
do
so
.
<EOS>
And
yet
,
as
the
idea
of
this
termination
to
the
night
's
work
came
upon
him
,
and
as
he
thought
of
his
lost
labour
,
he
almost
took
courage
again
,
 
almost
dreaded
rather
than
wished
for
the
interference
of
some
malicious
member
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
malicious
member
then
present
,
or
<EOS>
else
it
was
known
that
Lords
of
the
Treasury
and
Lords
of
the
Admiralty
would
flock
in
during
the
Speaker
's
ponderous
counting
,
 
and
thus
the
slow
length
of
the
ballot
-
lover
's
verbosity
was
permitted
to
evolve
itself
without
interruption
.
<EOS>
At
eight
o'clock
he
had
completed
his
catalogue
of
illustrations
,
and
immediately
Mr.
Monk
rose
from
the
Treasury
bench
to
explain
the
grounds
on
which
the
Government
must
decline
to
support
the
motion
before
the
House
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
was
aware
that
Mr.
Monk
intended
to
speak
,
and
was
aware
also
that
his
speech
would
be
very
short
.
<EOS>
"
My
idea
is
,
"
he
had
said
to
Phineas
,
"
that
every
man
possessed
of
the
franchise
should
dare
to
have
and
to
express
a
political
opinion
of
his
own
;
that
otherwise
the
franchise
is
not
worth
having
;
and
that
men
will
learn
that
when
all
so
dare
,
no
evil
can
come
from
such
daring
.
<EOS>
As
the
ballot
would
make
any
courage
of
that
kind
unnecessary
,
I
dislike
the
ballot
.
<EOS>
I
shall
confine
myself
to
that
,
and
leave
the
illustration
to
younger
debaters
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
also
had
been
informed
that
Mr.
Turnbull
would
reply
to
Mr.
Monk
,
with
the
purpose
of
crushing
Mr.
Monk
into
dust
,
and
Phineas
had
prepared
his
speech
with
something
of
an
intention
of
subsequently
crushing
Mr.
Turnbull
.
<EOS>
He
knew
,
however
,
that
he
could
not
command
his
opportunity
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
chapter
of
accidents
to
which
he
must
accommodate
himself
;
but
such
had
been
his
programme
for
the
evening
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
made
his
speech
,
 
and
though
he
was
short
,
he
was
very
fiery
and
energetic
.
<EOS>
Quick
as
lightning
words
of
wrath
and
scorn
flew
from
him
,
in
which
he
painted
the
cowardice
,
the
meanness
,
the
falsehood
of
the
ballot
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
ballot
-
box
,
"
he
said
,
"
was
the
grave
of
all
true
political
opinion
.
<EOS>
"
Though
he
spoke
hardly
for
ten
minutes
,
he
seemed
to
say
more
than
enough
,
ten
times
enough
,
to
slaughter
the
argument
of
the
former
speaker
.
<EOS>
At
every
hot
word
as
it
fell
Phineas
was
driven
to
regret
that
a
paragraph
of
his
own
was
taken
away
from
him
,
and
that
his
choicest
morsels
of
standing
ground
were
being
cut
from
under
his
feet
.
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Monk
sat
down
,
Phineas
felt
that
Mr.
Monk
had
said
all
that
he
,
Phineas
Finn
,
had
intended
to
say
.
  
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Turnbull
rose
slowly
from
the
bench
below
the
gangway
.
<EOS>
With
a
speaker
so
frequent
and
so
famous
as
Mr.
Turnbull
no
hurry
is
necessary
.
<EOS>
He
is
sure
to
have
his
opportunity
.
<EOS>
The
Speaker
's
eye
is
ever
travelling
to
the
accustomed
spots
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
rose
slowly
and
began
his
oration
very
mildly
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
nothing
,
"
he
said
,
"
that
he
admired
so
much
as
the
poetic
imagery
and
the
high
-
flown
sentiment
of
his
right
honourable
friend
the
member
for
West
Bromwich
,
"
 
Mr.
Monk
sat
for
West
Bromwich
,
 
"
unless
it
were
the
stubborn
facts
and
unanswered
arguments
of
his
honourable
friend
who
had
brought
forward
this
motion
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Turnbull
proceeded
after
his
fashion
to
crush
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
prosaic
,
very
clear
both
in
voice
and
language
,
very
harsh
,
and
very
unscrupulous
.
<EOS>
He
and
Mr.
Monk
had
been
joined
together
in
politics
for
over
twenty
years
;
 
but
one
would
have
thought
,
from
Mr.
Turnbull
's
words
,
that
they
had
been
the
bitterest
of
enemies
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
was
taunted
with
his
office
,
taunted
with
his
desertion
of
the
liberal
party
,
taunted
with
his
ambition
,
 
and
taunted
with
his
lack
of
ambition
.
<EOS>
"
I
once
thought
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
,
 
"
nay
,
not
long
ago
I
thought
,
that
he
and
I
would
have
fought
this
battle
for
the
people
,
shoulder
to
shoulder
,
and
knee
to
knee
;
 
but
he
has
preferred
that
the
knee
next
to
his
own
shall
wear
a
garter
,
and
that
the
shoulder
which
supports
him
shall
be
decked
with
a
blue
ribbon
,
 
as
shoulders
,
I
presume
,
are
decked
in
those
closet
conferences
which
are
called
Cabinets
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Just
after
this
,
while
Mr.
Turnbull
was
still
going
on
with
a
variety
of
illustrations
drawn
from
the
United
States
,
Barrington
Erle
stepped
across
the
benches
up
to
the
place
where
Phineas
was
sitting
,
and
whispered
a
few
words
into
his
ear
.
<EOS>
"
Bonteen
is
prepared
to
answer
Turnbull
,
and
wishes
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
I
told
him
that
I
thought
you
should
have
the
opportunity
,
if
you
wish
it
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
was
not
ready
with
a
reply
to
Erle
at
the
spur
of
the
moment
.
<EOS>
"
Somebody
told
me
,
"
continued
Erle
,
"
that
you
had
said
that
you
would
like
to
speak
to
-
night
.
"
  
"
So
I
did
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
tell
Bonteen
that
you
will
do
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
chamber
seemed
to
swim
round
before
our
hero
's
eyes
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
was
still
going
on
with
his
clear
,
loud
,
unpleasant
voice
,
but
there
was
no
knowing
how
long
he
might
go
on
.
<EOS>
Upon
Phineas
,
if
he
should
now
consent
,
might
devolve
the
duty
,
within
ten
minutes
,
within
three
minutes
,
of
rising
there
before
a
full
House
to
defend
his
great
friend
,
Mr.
Monk
,
from
a
gross
personal
attack
.
<EOS>
Was
it
fit
that
such
a
novice
as
he
should
undertake
such
a
work
as
that
?
<EOS>
Were
he
to
do
so
,
all
that
speech
which
he
had
prepared
,
with
its
various
self
-
floating
parts
,
must
go
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
The
task
was
exactly
that
which
,
of
all
tasks
,
he
would
best
like
to
have
accomplished
,
and
to
have
accomplished
well
.
<EOS>
But
if
he
should
fail
!
<EOS>
And
he
felt
that
he
would
fail
.
<EOS>
For
such
work
a
man
should
have
all
his
senses
about
him
,
 
his
full
courage
,
perfect
confidence
,
something
almost
approaching
to
contempt
for
listening
opponents
,
and
nothing
of
fear
in
regard
to
listening
friends
.
<EOS>
He
should
be
as
a
cock
in
his
own
farmyard
,
master
of
all
the
circumstances
around
him
.
<EOS>
But
Phineas
Finn
had
not
even
as
yet
heard
the
sound
of
his
own
voice
in
that
room
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
,
so
confused
was
he
,
that
he
did
not
know
where
sat
Mr.
Mildmay
,
and
where
<EOS>
Mr.
Daubeny
.
<EOS>
All
was
confused
,
and
there
arose
as
it
were
a
sound
of
waters
in
his
ears
,
and
a
feeling
as
of
a
great
hell
around
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
had
rather
wait
,
"
he
said
at
last
.
<EOS>
"
Bonteen
had
better
reply
.
"
Barrington
Erle
looked
into
his
face
,
and
then
stepping
back
across
the
benches
,
told
Mr.
Bonteen
that
the
opportunity
was
his
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
continued
speaking
quite
long
enough
to
give
poor
Phineas
time
for
repentance
;
but
repentance
was
of
no
use
.
<EOS>
He
had
decided
against
himself
,
and
his
decision
could
not
be
reversed
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
left
the
House
,
only
it
seemed
to
him
that
had
he
done
so
every
one
would
look
at
him
.
<EOS>
He
drew
his
hat
down
over
his
eyes
,
and
remained
in
his
place
,
hating
Mr.
Bonteen
,
hating
Barrington
Erle
,
hating
Mr.
Turnbull
,
 
but
hating
no
one
so
much
as
he
