hated
himself
.
<EOS>
He
had
disgraced
himself
for
ever
and
could
never
recover
the
occasion
which
he
had
lost
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Bonteen
's
speech
was
in
no
way
remarkable
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
,
he
said
,
had
done
the
State
good
service
by
adding
his
wisdom
and
patriotism
to
the
Cabinet
.
<EOS>
The
sort
of
argument
which
Mr.
Bonteen
used
to
prove
that
a
man
who
has
gained
credit
as
a
legislator
should
in
process
of
time
become
a
member
of
the
executive
,
is
trite
and
common
,
and
was
not
used
by
Mr.
Bonteen
with
any
special
force
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bonteen
was
glib
of
tongue
and
possessed
that
familiarity
with
the
place
which
poor
Phineas
had
lacked
so
sorely
.
<EOS>
There
was
one
moment
,
however
,
which
was
terrible
to
Phineas
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
Mr.
Bonteen
had
shown
the
purpose
for
which
he
was
on
his
legs
,
Mr.
Monk
looked
round
at
Phineas
,
as
though
in
reproach
.
<EOS>
He
had
expected
that
this
work
should
fall
into
the
hands
of
one
who
would
perform
it
with
more
warmth
of
heart
than
could
be
expected
from
Mr.
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Bonteen
ceased
,
two
or
three
other
short
speeches
were
made
and
members
fired
off
their
little
guns
.
<EOS>
Phineas
having
lost
so
great
an
opportunity
,
would
not
now
consent
to
accept
one
that
should
be
comparatively
valueless
.
<EOS>
Then
there
came
a
division
.
<EOS>
The
motion
was
lost
by
a
large
majority
,
 
by
any
number
you
might
choose
to
name
,
as
Phineas
had
said
to
Lord
Brentford
;
but
in
that
there
was
no
triumph
to
the
poor
wretch
who
had
failed
through
fear
,
and
who
was
now
a
coward
in
his
own
esteem
.
  
<EOS>
He
left
the
House
alone
,
carefully
avoiding
all
speech
with
any
one
.
<EOS>
As
he
came
out
he
had
seen
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
in
the
lobby
,
but
he
had
gone
on
without
pausing
a
moment
,
so
that
he
might
avoid
his
friend
.
<EOS>
And
when
he
was
out
in
Palace
Yard
,
where
was
he
to
go
next
?
<EOS>
He
looked
at
his
watch
,
and
found
that
it
was
just
ten
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
dare
to
go
to
his
club
,
and
it
was
impossible
for
him
to
go
home
and
to
bed
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
miserable
,
and
nothing
would
comfort
him
but
sympathy
.
<EOS>
Was
there
any
one
who
would
listen
to
his
abuse
of
himself
,
and
would
then
answer
him
with
kindly
apologies
for
his
own
weakness
?
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bunce
would
do
it
if
she
knew
how
,
but
sympathy
from
Mrs.
Bunce
would
hardly
avail
.
<EOS>
There
was
but
one
person
in
the
world
to
whom
he
could
tell
his
own
humiliation
with
any
hope
of
comfort
,
and
that
person
was
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
Sympathy
from
any
man
would
have
been
distasteful
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
thought
for
a
moment
of
flinging
himself
at
Mr.
Monk
's
feet
and
telling
all
his
weakness
;
 
but
he
could
not
have
endured
pity
even
from
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
to
be
endured
from
any
man
.
  
<EOS>
He
thought
that
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
would
be
at
home
,
and
probably
alone
.
<EOS>
He
knew
,
at
any
rate
,
that
he
might
be
allowed
to
knock
at
her
door
,
even
at
that
hour
.
<EOS>
He
had
left
Mr.
Kennedy
in
the
House
,
and
there
he
would
probably
remain
for
the
next
hour
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
man
more
constant
than
Mr.
Kennedy
in
seeing
the
work
of
the
day
,
 
or
of
the
night
,
 
to
its
end
.
<EOS>
So
Phineas
walked
up
Victoria
Street
,
and
from
thence
into
Grosvenor
Place
,
and
knocked
at
Lady
Laura
's
door
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
Lady
Laura
was
at
home
;
and
alone
.
"
<EOS>
He
was
shown
up
into
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
there
he
found
Lady
Laura
waiting
for
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
the
great
debate
is
over
,
"
she
said
,
with
as
much
of
irony
as
she
knew
how
to
throw
into
the
epithet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
it
is
over
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
what
have
they
done
,
 
those
leviathans
of
the
people
?
"
  
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
told
her
what
was
the
majority
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
there
anything
the
matter
with
you
,
Mr.
Finn
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
looking
at
him
suddenly
.
"
<EOS>
Are
you
not
well
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I
am
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Will
you
not
sit
down
?
<EOS>
There
is
something
wrong
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
What
is
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
simply
been
the
greatest
idiot
,
the
greatest
coward
,
the
most
awkward
ass
that
ever
lived
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
why
I
should
come
to
tell
you
of
it
at
this
hour
at
night
,
but
I
have
come
that
I
might
tell
you
.
<EOS>
Probably
because
there
is
no
one
else
in
the
whole
world
who
would
not
laugh
at
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
I
shall
not
laugh
at
you
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
despise
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
I
am
sure
I
shall
not
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
help
it
.
<EOS>
I
despise
myself
.
<EOS>
For
years
I
have
placed
before
myself
the
ambition
of
speaking
in
the
House
of
Commons
;
 
for
years
I
have
been
thinking
whether
there
would
ever
come
to
me
an
opportunity
of
making
myself
heard
in
that
assembly
,
which
I
consider
to
be
the
first
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
To
-
day
the
opportunity
has
been
offered
to
me
,
 
and
,
though
the
motion
was
nothing
,
the
opportunity
was
great
.
<EOS>
The
subject
was
one
on
which
I
was
thoroughly
prepared
.
<EOS>
The
manner
in
which
I
was
summoned
was
most
flattering
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
was
especially
called
on
to
perform
a
task
which
was
most
congenial
to
my
feelings
;
 
and
I
declined
because
I
was
afraid
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
had
thought
too
much
about
it
,
my
friend
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Too
much
or
too
little
,
what
does
it
matter
?
"
<EOS>
replied
Phineas
,
in
despair
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
the
fact
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
do
it
.
<EOS>
Do
you
remember
the
story
of
Conachar
in
the
"
Fair
Maid
of
Perth
;
"
 
how
his
heart
refused
to
give
him
blood
enough
to
fight
?
<EOS>
He
had
been
suckled
with
the
milk
of
a
timid
creature
,
and
,
though
he
could
die
,
there
was
none
of
the
strength
of
manhood
in
him
.
<EOS>
It
is
about
the
same
thing
with
me
,
I
take
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
you
are
at
all
like
Conachar
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
equally
disgraced
,
and
I
must
perish
after
the
same
fashion
.
<EOS>
I
shall
apply
for
the
Chiltern
Hundreds
in
a
day
or
two
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
do
nothing
of
the
kind
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
getting
up
from
her
chair
and
coming
towards
him
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
leave
this
room
till
you
have
promised
me
that
you
will
do
nothing
of
the
kind
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
as
yet
<EOS>
what
has
occurred
to
-
night
;
but
I
do
know
that
that
modesty
which
has
kept
you
silent
is
more
often
a
grace
than
a
disgrace
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
the
kind
of
sympathy
which
he
wanted
,
She
drew
her
chair
nearer
to
him
,
and
then
he
explained
to
her
as
accurately
as
he
could
what
had
taken
place
in
the
House
on
this
evening
,
 
how
he
had
prepared
his
speech
,
how
he
had
felt
that
his
preparation
was
vain
,
how
he
perceived
from
the
course
of
the
debate
that
if
he
spoke
at
all
his
speech
must
be
very
different
from
what
he
had
first
intended
;
how
he
had
declined
to
take
upon
himself
a
task
which
seemed
to
require
so
close
a
knowledge
of
the
ways
of
the
House
and
of
the
temper
of
the
men
,
as
the
defence
of
such
a
man
as
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
In
accusing
himself
he
,
unconsciously
,
excused
himself
,
and
his
excuse
,
in
Lady
Laura
's
ears
,
was
more
valid
than
his
accusation
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
would
give
it
all
up
for
that
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
I
think
I
ought
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
very
little
doubt
but
that
you
were
right
in
allowing
Mr.
Bonteen
to
undertake
such
a
task
.
<EOS>
I
should
simply
explain
to
Mr.
Monk
that
you
felt
too
keen
an
interest
in
his
welfare
to
stand
up
as
an
untried
member
in
his
defence
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
,
I
think
,
the
work
for
a
man
who
is
not
at
home
in
the
House
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
Mr.
Monk
will
feel
this
,
and
I
am
quite
certain
that
Mr.
Kennedy
will
think
that
you
have
been
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
care
what
Mr.
Kennedy
may
think
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
say
that
,
Mr.
Finn
?
<EOS>
That
is
not
courteous
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Simply
because
I
care
so
much
what
Mr.
Kennedy
's
wife
may
think
.
<EOS>
Your
opinion
is
all
in
all
to
me
,
 
only
that
I
know
you
are
too
kind
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
would
not
be
too
kind
to
you
.
<EOS>
He
is
never
too
kind
to
any
one
.
<EOS>
He
is
justice
itself
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
as
he
heard
the
tones
of
her
voice
,
could
not
but
feel
that
there
was
in
Lady
Laura
's
words
something
of
an
accusation
against
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hate
justice
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
justice
would
condemn
me
.
<EOS>
But
love
and
friendship
know
nothing
of
justice
.
<EOS>
The
value
of
love
is
that
it
overlooks
faults
,
and
forgives
even
crimes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
,
at
any
rate
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
"
will
forgive
the
crime
of
your
silence
in
the
House
.
<EOS>
My
strong
belief
in
your
success
will
not
be
in
the
least
affected
by
what
you
tell
me
of
your
failure
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
You
must
await
another
opportunity
;
and
,
if
possible
,
you
should
be
less
anxious
as
to
your
own
performance
.
<EOS>
There
is
Violet
.
"
<EOS>
As
Lady
Laura
spoke
the
last
words
,
there
was
a
sound
of
a
carriage
stopping
in
the
street
,
and
the
front
door
was
immediately
opened
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
staying
here
,
but
has
been
dining
with
her
uncle
,
Admiral
Effingham
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Violet
Effingham
entered
the
room
,
rolled
up
in
pretty
white
furs
,
and
silk
cloaks
,
and
lace

.
<EOS>
"
Here
is
Mr.
Finn
,
come
to
tell
us
of
the
debate
about
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
twopence
about
the
ballot
,
"
said
Violet
,
as
she
put
out
her
hand
to
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
Are
we
going
to
have
a
new
iron
fleet
built
?
<EOS>
That
's
the
question
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
Simeon
has
come
out
strong
to
-
night
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
political
question
of
any
importance
except
the
question
of
the
iron
fleet
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
sure
of
that
,
and
so
,
if
Mr.
Finn
can
tell
me
nothing
about
the
iron
fleet
,
I
'll
go
to
bed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Kennedy
will
tell
you
everything
when
he
comes
home
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Kennedy
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
never
tells
one
anything
.
<EOS>
I
doubt
whether
Mr.
Kennedy
thinks
that
any
woman
knows
the
meaning
of
the
British
Constitution
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
what
it
means
,
Violet
?
"
asked
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
I
do
.
<EOS>
It
is
liberty
to
growl
about
the
iron
fleet
,
or
the
ballot
,
or
the
taxes
,
or
the
peers
,
or
the
bishops
,
 
or
anything
else
,
except
the
House
of
Commons
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
British
Constitution
.
<EOS>
Good
-
night
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
beautiful
creature
she
is
!
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
indeed
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
full
of
wit
and
grace
and
pleasantness
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
wonder
at
your
brother
's
choice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
will
be
remembered
that
this
was
said
on
the
day
before
Lord
Chiltern
had
made
his
offer
for
the
third
time
.
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
Oswald
!
<EOS>
he
does
not
know
as
yet
that
she
is
in
town
.
"
  
<EOS>
After
that
Phineas
went
,
not
wishing
to
await
the
return
of
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
He
had
felt
that
Violet
Effingham
had
come
into
the
room
just
in
time
to
remedy
a
great
difficulty
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
wish
to
speak
of
his
love
to
a
married
woman
,
 
to
the
wife
of
the
man
who
called
him
friend
,
 
to
a
woman
who
he
felt
sure
would
have
rebuked
him
.
<EOS>
But
he
could
hardly
have
restrained
himself
had
not
Miss
Effingham
been
there
.
  
<EOS>
But
as
he
went
home
he
thought
more
of
Miss
Effingham
than
he
did
of
Lady
Laura
;
and
I
think
that
the
voice
of
Miss
Effingham
had
done
almost
as
much
towards
comforting
him
as
had
the
kindness
of
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
he
had
been
comforted
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
be
punctual
"
 
<EOS>
On
the
very
morning
after
his
failure
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
when
Phineas
was
reading
in
the
_
Telegraph
_
,
 
he
took
the
_
Telegraph
_
not
from
choice
but
for
economy
,
 
the
words
of
that
debate
which
he
had
heard
and
in
which
he
should
have
taken
a
part
,
a
most
unwelcome
visit
was
paid
to
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
near
eleven
,
and
the
breakfast
things
were
still
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
He
was
at
this
time
on
a
Committee
of
the
House
with
reference
to
the
use
of
potted
peas
in
the
army
and
navy
,
at
which
he
had
sat
once
,
 
at
a
preliminary
meeting
,
 
and
in
reference
to
which
he
had
already
resolved
that
as
he
had
failed
so
frightfully
in
debate
,
he
would
certainly
do
his
duty
to
the
utmost
in
the
more
easy
but
infinitely
more
tedious
work
of
the
Committee
Room
.
<EOS>
The
Committee
met
at
twelve
,
and
he
intended
to
walk
down
to
the
Reform
Club
,
and
then
to
the
House
.
<EOS>
He
had
just
completed
his
reading
of
the
debate
and
of
the
leaders
in
the
_
Telegraph
_
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
He
had
told
himself
how
little
the
writer
of
the
article
knew
about
Mr.
Turnbull
,
how
little
about
Mr.
Monk
,
and
how
little
about
the
people
,
 
such
being
his
own
ideas
as
to
the
qualifications
of
the
writer
of
that
leading
article
,
 
and
was
about
to
start
.
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Bunce
arrested
him
by
telling
him
that
there
was
a
man
below
who
wanted
to
see
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
sort
of
a
man
,
Mrs.
Bunce
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
ai
n't
a
gentleman
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
he
give
his
name
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
did
not
,
sir
;
<EOS>
but
I
know
it
's
about
money
.
<EOS>
I
know
the
ways
of
them
<EOS>
so
well
.
<EOS>
I
've
seen
this
one
's
face
before
somewhere
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
show
him
up
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
He
knew
well
the
business
on
which
the
man
was
come
.
<EOS>
The
man
wanted
money
for
that
bill
which
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
had
sent
afloat
,
and
which
Phineas
had
endorsed
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
never
as
yet
fallen
so
deeply
into
troubles
of
money
as
to
make
it
necessary
that
he
need
refuse
himself
to
any
callers
on
that
score
,
and
he
did
not
choose
to
do
so
now
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
he
most
heartily
wished
that
he
had
left
his
lodgings
for
the
club
before
the
man
had
come
.
<EOS>
This
was
not
the
first
he
had
heard
of
the
bill
being
overdue
and
unpaid
.
<EOS>
The
bill
had
been
brought
to
him
noted
a
month
since
,
and
then
he
had
simply
told
the
youth
who
brought
it
that
he
would
see
Mr.
Fitzgibbon
and
have
the
matter
settled
.
<EOS>
He
had
spoken
to
his
friend
Laurence
,
and
Laurence
had
simply
assured
him
that
all
should
be
made
right
in
two
days
,
 
or
,
at
furthest
,
by
the
end
of
a
week
.
<EOS>
Since
that
time
he
had
observed
that
his
friend
had
been
somewhat
shy
of
speaking
to
him
when
no
others
were
with
them
.
<EOS>
Phineas
would
not
have
alluded
to
the
bill
had
he
and
Laurence
been
alone
together
;
but
he
had
been
quick
enough
to
guess
from
his
friend
's
manner
that
the
matter
was
not
settled
.
<EOS>
Now
,
no
doubt
,
serious
trouble
was
about
to
commence
.
  
<EOS>
The
visitor
was
a
little
man
with
grey
hair
and
a
white
cravat
,
some
sixty
years
of
age
,
dressed
in
black
,
with
a
very
decent
hat
,
 
which
,
on
entering
the
room
,
he
at
once
put
down
on
the
nearest
chair
,
 
with
reference
to
whom
,
any
judge
on
the
subject
would
have
concurred
at
first
sight
in

pronounced
by
Mrs.
Bunce
,
though
none
but
a
judge
very
well
used
to
sift
the
causes
of
his
own

could
have
given
the
reasons
for
that
early

.
"
<EOS>
He
ai
n't
a
gentleman
,
"
Mrs.
Bunce
had
said
.
<EOS>
And
the
man
certainly
was
not
a
gentleman
.
<EOS>
The
old
man
in
the
white
cravat
was
very
neatly
dressed
,
and
carried
himself
without
any
of
that
humility
which
betrays
one
class
of
uncertified
aspirants
to
gentility
,
or
of
that
assumed
arrogance
which
is
at
once
fatal
to
another
class
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
Mrs.
Bunce
had
seen
at
a
glance
that
he
was
not
a
gentleman
,
 
had
seen
,
moreover
,
that
such
a
man
could
have
come
only
upon
one
mission
.
<EOS>
She
was
right
there
too
.
<EOS>
This
visitor
had
come
about
money
.
  
<EOS>
"
About
this
bill
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
said
the
visitor
,
proceeding
to
take
out
of
his
breast
coat
-
pocket
a
rather

case
,
as
he
advanced
up

.
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Clarkson
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
If

may

so
far
,
I
'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly
,
Mr.
Clarkson
,
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Thankye
,
Mr.
Finn
,
thankye
.
<EOS>
We
shall
be
more

business
sitting
,
sha

?
"
<EOS>
Whereupon
the
horrid
little
man
drew
himself
close
in
to

fire
,
and
spreading
out

leathern
case
upon

,
began

turn

suspicious

paper
after
another
,
as

were
uncertain
in
what
part

this

was
seeking
.
<EOS>
He
seemed

be
quite
at

,
and
to
feel
that

was
no
ground
whatever
for
hurry
in
such

.
<EOS>
Phineas
hated
him
at
once
,
 
with
a
hatred
altogether
unconnected
with
the
difficulty
which
his
friend
Fitzgibbon
had
brought
upon

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
it
is
,
"
said
Mr.
Clarkson
at

.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

me
,

!
<EOS>
the
third

,
and
here
we
are
in
March
!
<EOS>
I
did

;

.
<EOS>
This
is
very

,
 
very

!
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

.
  
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There

,

no

.
<EOS>
Could

,
the
man
would
of

gone
;
but
failing

,
Phineas
could
not

out
.
<EOS>
There
was
a

's

,
and
great

at

heart
,
 
against
Fitzgibbon
rather

.
"
<EOS>
Sir
,
"

,

.
<EOS>

,

.

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

another
in
that
way
.
<EOS>
Let
me
see
.
<EOS>
I
daresay
you
're
not
particular
.
<EOS>
Suppose
I
say
Sunday
morning
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Really
,
I
could
not
see
you
on
Sunday
morning
,
Mr.
Clarkson
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Parliament
gents
ai
n't
generally
particular
,
 
"
speciaily
not
among
the
Catholics
,
"
pleaded
Mr.
Clarkson
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
always
engaged
on
Sundays
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Suppose
we
say
Monday
,
 
or
Tuesday
.
<EOS>
Tuesday
morning
at
eleven
.
<EOS>
And
do
be
punctual
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
At
Tuesday
morning
I
'll
come
,
and
then
no
doubt
I
shall
find
you
ready
.
"
<EOS>
Whereupon
Mr.
Clarkson
slowly
put
up
his
bills
within
his
portfolio
,
and
then
,
before
Phineas
knew
where
he
was
,
had
warmly
shaken
that
poor
dismayed
member
of
Parliament
by
the
hand
.
<EOS>
"
Only
do
be
punctual
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
made
his
way
down
the
stairs
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
now
twelve
,
and
Phineas
rushed
off
to
a
cab
.
<EOS>
He
was
in
such
a
fervour
of
rage
and
misery
that
he
could
hardly
think
of
his
position
,
or
what
he
had
better
do
,
till
he
got
into
the
Committee
Room
;
and
when
there
he
could
think
of
nothing
else
.
<EOS>
He
intended
to
go
deeply
into
the
question
of
potted
peas
,
holding
an
equal
balance
between
the
assailed
Government
offices
on
the
one
hand
,
and
the
advocates
of
the
potted
peas
on
the
other
.
<EOS>
The
potters
of
the
peas
,
who
wanted
to
sell
their
article
to
the
Crown
,
declared
that
an
extensive
,
 
perhaps
we
may
say
,
an
unlimited
,
 
use
of
the
article
would
save
the
whole
army
and
navy
from
the
scourges
of
scurvy
,
dyspepsia
,
and
rheumatism
,
would
be
the
best
safeguard
against
typhus
and
other
fevers
,
and
would
be
an
invaluable
aid
in
all
other
maladies
to
which
soldiers
and
sailors
are
peculiarly
subject
.
<EOS>
The
peas
in
question
were
grown
on
a
large
scale
in
Holstein
,
and
their
growth
had
been
fostered
with
the
special
object
of
doing
good
to
the
British
army
and
navy
.
<EOS>
The
peas
were
so
cheap
that
there
would
be
a
great
saving
in
money
,
 
and
it
really
had
seemed
to
many
that
the
officials
of
the
Horse
Guards
and
the
Admiralty
had
been
actuated
by
some
fiendish
desire
to
deprive
their
men
of
salutary
fresh
vegetables
,
simply
because
they
were
of
foreign
growth
.
<EOS>
But
the
officials
of
the
War
Office
and
the
Admiralty
declared
that
the
potted
peas
in
question
were
hardly
fit
for
swine
.
<EOS>
The
motion
for
the
Committee
had
been
made
by
a
gentleman
of
the
opposition
,
and
Phineas
had
been
put
upon
it
as
an
independent
member
.
<EOS>
He
had
resolved
to
give
it
all
his
mind
,
and
,
as
far
as
he
was
concerned
,
to
reach
a
just
decision
,
in
which
there
should
be
no
favour
shown
to
the
Government
side
.
<EOS>
New
brooms
are
proverbial
for
thorough
work
,
and
in
this
Committee
work
Phineas
was
as
yet
a
new
broom
.
<EOS>
But
,
unfortunately
,
on
this
day
his
mind
was
so
harassed
that
he
could
hardly
understand
what
was
going
on
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
,
perhaps
,
much
signify
,
as
the
witnesses
examined
were
altogether
agricultural
.
<EOS>
They
only
proved
the
production
of
peas
in
Holstein
,
 
a
fact
as
to
which
Phineas
had
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
The
proof
was
naturally
slow
,
as
the
evidence
was
given
in
German
,
and
had
to
be
translated
into
English
.
<EOS>
And
the
work
of
the
day
was
much
impeded
by
a
certain
member
who
unfortunately
spoke
German
,
who
seemed
to
be
fond
of
speaking
German
before
his
brethren
of
the
Committee
,
and
who
was
curious
as
to
agriculture
in
Holstein
generally
.
<EOS>
The
chairman
did
not
understand
German
,
and
there
was
a
difficulty
in
checking
this
gentleman
,
and
in
making
him
understand
that
his
questions
were
not
relevant
to
the
issue
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
could
not
keep
his
mind
during
the
whole
afternoon
from
the
subject
of
his
misfortune
.
<EOS>
What
should
he
do
if
this
horrid
man
came
to
him
once
or
twice
a
week
?
<EOS>
He
certainly
did
owe
the
man
the
money
.
<EOS>
He
must
admit
that
to
himself
.
<EOS>
The
man
no
doubt
was
a
dishonest
knave
who
had
discounted
the
bill
probably
at
fifty
per
cent
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
Phineas
had
made
himself
legally
responsible
for
the
amount
.
<EOS>
The
privilege
of
the
House
prohibited
him
from
arrest
.
<EOS>
He
thought
of
that
very
often
,
but
the
thought
only
made
him
the
more
unhappy
.
<EOS>
Would
it
not
be
said
,
and
might
it
not
be
said
truly
,
that
he
had
incurred
this
responsibility
,
 
a
responsibility
which
he
was
altogether
unequal
to
answer
,
 
because
he
was
so
protected
?
<EOS>
He
did
feel
that
a
certain
consciousness
of
his
privilege
had
been
present
to
him
when
he
had
put
his
name
across
the
paper
,
and
there
had
been
dishonesty
in
that
very
consciousness
.
<EOS>
And
of
what
service
would
his
privilege
be
to
him
,
if
this
man
could
harass
every
hour
of
his
life
?
<EOS>
The
man
was
to
be
with
him
again
in
a
day
or
two
,
and
when
the
appointment
had
been
proposed
,
he
,
Phineas
,
had
not
dared
to
negative
it
.
<EOS>
And
how
was
he
to
escape
?
<EOS>
As
for
paying
the
bill
,
that
with
him
was
altogether
impossible
.
<EOS>
The
man
had
told
him
,
 
and
he
had
believed
the
man
,
 
that
payment
by
Fitzgibbon
was
out
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
And
yet
Fitzgibbon
was
the
son
of
a
peer
,
whereas
he
was
only
the
son
of
a
country
doctor
!
<EOS>
Of
course
Fitzgibbon
must
make
some
effort
,
 
some
great
effort
,
 
and
have
the
thing
settled
.
<EOS>
Alas
,
alas
!
<EOS>
He
knew
enough
of
the
world
already
to
feel
that
the
hope
was
vain
.
  
<EOS>
He
went
down
from
the
Committee
Room
into
the
House
,
and
he
dined
at
the
House
,
and
remained
there
until
eight
or
nine
at
night
;
but
Fitzgibbon
did
not
come
.
<EOS>
He
then
went
to
the
Reform
Club
,
but
he
was
not
there
.
<EOS>
Both
at
the
club
and
in
the
House
many
men
spoke
to
him
about
the
debate
of
the
previous
night
,
expressing
surprise
that
he
had
not
spoken
,
 
making
him
more
and
more
wretched
.
<EOS>
He
saw
Mr.
Monk
,
but
Mr.
Monk
was
walking
arm
in
arm
with
his
colleague
,
Mr.
Palliser
,
and
Phineas
could
do
no
more
than
just
speak
to
them
.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
Mr.
Monk
's
nod
of
recognition
was
very
cold
.
<EOS>
That
might
be
fancy
,
but
it
certainly
was
a
fact
that
Mr.
Monk
only
nodded
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
would
tell
Mr.
Monk
the
truth
,
and
then
,
if
Mr.
Monk
chose
to
quarrel
with
him
,
he
at
any
rate
would
take
no
step
to
renew
their
friendship
.
  
<EOS>
From
the
Reform
Club
he
went
to
the
Shakspeare
,
a
smaller
club
to
which
Fitzgibbon
belonged
,
 
and
of
which
Phineas
much
wished
to
become
a
member
,
 
and
to
which
he
knew
that
his
friend
resorted
when
he
wished
to
enjoy
himself
thoroughly
,
and
to
be
at
ease
in
his
inn
.
<EOS>
Men
at
the
Shakspeare
could
do
as
they
pleased
.
<EOS>
There
were
no
politics
there
,
no
fashion
,
no
stiffness
,
and
no
rules
,
 
so
men
said
;
but
that
was
hardly
true
.
<EOS>
Everybody
called
everybody
by
his
Christian
name
,
and
members
smoked
all
over
the
house
.
<EOS>
They
who
did
not
belong
to
the
Shakspeare
thought
it
an
Elysium
upon
earth
;
and
they
who
did
,
believed
it
to
be
among
Pandemoniums
the
most
pleasant
.
<EOS>
Phineas
called
at
the
Shakspeare
,
and
was
told
by
the
porter
that
Mr.
Fitzgibbon
was
up
-
stairs
.
<EOS>
He
was
shown
into
the
strangers
room
,
and
in
five
minutes
his
friend
came
down
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
want
you
to
come
down
to
the
Reform
with
me
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
By
jingo
,
my
dear
fellow
,
I
'm
in
the
middle
of
a
rubber
of
whist
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
has
been
a
man
with
me
about
that
bill
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
;
 
Clarkson
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Clarkson
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
mind
him
,
"
said
Fitzgibbon
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
nonsense
.
<EOS>
How
am
I
to
help
minding
him
?
<EOS>
I
must
mind
him
.
<EOS>
He
is
coming
to
me
again
on
Tuesday
morning
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
see
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
help
seeing
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Make
them
say
you
're
not
at
home
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
made
an
appointment
.
<EOS>
He
has
told
me
that
he
'll
never
leave
me
alone
.
<EOS>
He
'll
be
the
death
of
me
if
this
is
not
settled
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
shall
be
settled
,
my
dear
fellow
.
<EOS>
I
'll
see
about
it
.
<EOS>
I
'll
see
about
it
and
write
you
a
line
.
<EOS>
You
must
excuse
me
now
,
because
those
fellows
are
waiting
.
<EOS>
I
'll
have
it
all
arranged
.
"
  
<EOS>
Again
as
Phineas
went
home
he
thoroughly
wished
that
he
had
not
seceded
from
Mr.
Low
.
   
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
at
Home
 
<EOS>
About
the
middle
of
March
Lady
Baldock
came
up
from
Baddingham
to
London
,
coerced
into
doing
so
,
as
Violet
Effingham
declared
,
in
thorough
opposition
to
all
her
own
tastes
,
by
the
known
wishes
of
her
friends
and
relatives
.
<EOS>
Her
friends
and
relatives
,
so
Miss
Effingham
insinuated
,
were
unanimous
in
wishing
that
Lady
Baldock
should
remain
at
Baddingham
Park
,
and
therefore
,
 
that
wish
having
been
indiscreetly
expressed
,
 
she
had
put
herself
to
great
inconvenience
,
and
had
come
to
London
in
March
.
<EOS>
"
Gustavus
will
go
mad
,
"
said
Violet
to
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
The
Gustavus
in
question
was
the
Lord
Baldock
of
the
present
generation
,
Miss
Effingham
's
Lady
Baldock
being
the
peer
's
mother
.
<EOS>
"
Why
does
not
Lord
Baldock
take
a
house
himself
?
"
asked
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
know
,
my
dear
,
"
Violet
answered
,
"
how
much
we
Baddingham
people
think
of
money
?
<EOS>
We
do
n't
like
being
vexed
and
driven
mad
,
but
even
that
is
better
than
keeping
up
two
households
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
regarded
Violet
,
the
injury
arising
from
Lady
Baldock
's
early
migration
was
very
great
,
for
she
was
thus
compelled
to
move
from
Grosvenor
Place
to
Lady
Baldock
's
house
in
Berkeley
Square
.
<EOS>
"
As
you
are
so
fond
of
being
in
London
,
Augusta
<EOS>
and
I
have
made
up
our
minds
to
come
up
before
Easter
,
"
Lady
Baldock
had
written
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
go
to
her
now
,
<EOS>
"
Violet
had
said
to
her
friend
,
"
because
I
have
not
quite
made
up
my
mind
as
to
what
I
will
do
for
the
future
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Marry
Oswald
,
and
be
your
own
mistress
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
to
be
my
own
mistress
without
marrying
Oswald
,
though
I
do
n't
see
my
way
quite
clearly
as
yet
.
<EOS>
I
think
I
shall
set
up
a
little
house
of
my
own
,
and
let
the
world
say
what
it
pleases
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
they
could
n't
make
me
out
to
be
a
lunatic
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
wonder
if
they
were
to
try
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
could
not
prevent
me
in
any
other
way
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
in
the
dark
as
yet
,
and
so
I
shall
be
obedient
and
go
to
my
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Effingham
went
to
Berkeley
Square
,
and
Phineas
Finn
was
introduced
to
Lady
Baldock
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
often
in
Grosvenor
Place
,
and
had
seen
Violet
frequently
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
gave
periodical
dinners
,
 
once
a
week
,
 
to
which
everybody
went
who
could
get
an
invitation
;
and
Phineas
had
been
a
guest
more
than
once
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
in
spite
of
his
miseries
he
had
taken
to
dining
out
a
good
deal
,
and
was
popular
as
an
eater
of
dinners
.
<EOS>
He
could
talk
when
wanted
,
and
did
not
talk
too
much
,
was
pleasant
in
manners
and
appearance
,
and
had
already
achieved
a
certain
recognised
position
in
London
life
.
<EOS>
Of
those
who
knew
him
intimately
,
not
one
in
twenty
were
aware
from
whence
<EOS>
he
came
,
what
was
his
parentage
,
or
what
his
means
of
living
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
member
of
Parliament
,
a
friend
of
Mr.
Kennedy
's
,
was
intimate
with
Mr.
Monk
,
though
an
Irishman
did
not
as
a
rule
herd
with
other
Irishmen
,
and
was
the
right
sort
of
person
to
have
at
your
house
.
<EOS>
Some
people
said
he
was
a
cousin
of
Lord
Brentford
's
,
and
others
declared
that
he
was
Lord
Chiltern
's
earliest
friend
.
<EOS>
There
he
was
,
however
,
with
a
position
gained
,
and
even
Lady
Baldock
asked
him
to
her
house
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
had
evenings
.
<EOS>
People
went
to
her
house
,
and
stood
about
the
room
and
on

stairs
,
talked
to

other
for
half

,
and
went

.
<EOS>
In
these

days
there
was
no

,
but
still
there

always
enough
of
people
there
to
show
that
Lady
Baldock
was

.
<EOS>
Why

should
have
gone
to
Lady
Baldock
's
<EOS>
I
can
not

;
 
but

without

.
<EOS>
Phineas
received
a
little
card

him
to
go
,
and
he
always

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

ca

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

have

with
the
Standishes
,
"
said
Violet
;
"
that
Laura
is
to
me
a
sister
,
and
that
Oswald
used
to
be
almost
a
brother
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
not
you
speak
to
Lord
Brentford
;
 
you
who
are
his
favourite
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
are
reasons
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
how
can
any
girl
come
forward
and
say
that
she
knows
the
disposition
of
any
man
?
<EOS>
You
can
live
with
Lord
Chiltern
,
and
see
what
he
is
made
of
,
and
know
his
thoughts
,
and
learn
what
is
good
in
him
,
and
also
what
is
bad
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
how
is
any
girl
really
to
know
anything
of
a
man
's
life
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
can
do
anything
,
Miss
Effingham
,
I
will
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
then
we
shall
all
of
us
be
so
grateful
to
you
,
"
said
Violet
,
with
her
sweetest
smile
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
retreating
from
this
conversation
,
stood
for
a
while
alone
,
thinking
of
it
.
<EOS>
Had
she
spoken
thus
of
Lord
Chiltern
because
she
did
love
him
or
because
she
did
not
?
<EOS>
And
the
sweet
commendations
which
had
fallen
from
her
lips
upon
him
,
 
him
,
Phineas
Finn
,
 
were
they
compatible
with
anything
like
a
growing
partiality
for
himself
,
or
were
they
incompatible
with
any
such
feeling
?
<EOS>
Had
he
most
reason
to
be
comforted
or
to
be
discomfited
by
what
had
taken
place
?
<EOS>
It
seemed
hardly
possible
to
his
imagination
that
Violet
Effingham
should
love
such
a
nobody
as
he
.
<EOS>
And
yet
he
had
had
fair
evidence
that
one
standing
as
high
in
the
world
as
Violet
Effingham
would
fain
have
loved
him
<EOS>
could
she
have
followed
the
dictates
of
her
heart
.
<EOS>
He
had
trembled
when
he
had
first
resolved
to
declare
his
passion
to
Lady
Laura
,
 
fearing
that
she
would
scorn
him
as
being
presumptuous
.
<EOS>
But
there
had
been
no
cause
for
such
fear
as
that
.
<EOS>
He
had
declared
his
love
,
and
she
had
not
thought
him
to
be
presumptuous
.
<EOS>
That
now
was
ages
ago
,
 
eight
months
since
;
and
Lady
Laura
had
become
a
married
woman
.
<EOS>
Since
he
had
become
so
warmly
alive
to
the
charms
of
Violet
Effingham
he
had
determined
,
with
stern
propriety
,
that
a
passion
for
a
married
woman
was
disgraceful
.
<EOS>
Such
love
was
in
itself
a
sin
,
even
though
it
was
accompanied
by
the
severest
forbearance
and
the
most
rigid
propriety
of
conduct
.
<EOS>
No
;
 
Lady
Laura
had
done
wisely
to
check
the
growing
feeling
of
partiality
which
she
had
admitted
;
and
now
that
she
was
married
,
he
would
be
as
wise
as
she
.
<EOS>
It
was
clear
to
him
that
,
as
regarded
his
own
heart
,
the
way
was
open
to
him
for
a
new
enterprise
.
<EOS>
But
what
if
he
were
to
fail
again
,
and
be
told
by
Violet
,
when
he
declared
his
love
,
that
she
had
just
engaged
herself
to
Lord
Chiltern
!
  
<EOS>
"
What
were
you
and
Violet
talking
about
so
eagerly
?
"
said
Lady
Laura
to
him
,
with
a
smile
that
,
in
its
approach
to
laughter
,
almost
betrayed
its
mistress
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
were
talking
about
your
brother
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
going
to
him
,
are
you
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I
leave
London
on
Sunday
night
;
 
but
only
for
a
day
or
two
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Has
he
any
chance
there
,
do
you
think
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
with
Miss
Effingham
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;
 
with
Violet
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
think
she
loves
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
say
?
<EOS>
In
such
a
matter
you
can
judge
better
than
I
can
do
.
<EOS>
One
woman
with
reference
to
another
can
draw
the
line
between
love
and
friendship
.
<EOS>
She
certainly
likes
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
believe
she
loves
him
.
<EOS>
I
do
indeed
.
<EOS>
But
she
fears
him
.
<EOS>
She
does
not
quite
understand
how
much
there
is
of
tenderness
with
that
assumed
ferocity
.
<EOS>
And
Oswald
is
so
strange
,
so
unwise
,
so
impolitic
,
that
though
he
loves
her
better
than
all
the
world
beside
,
he
will
not
sacrifice
even
a
turn
of
a
word
to
win
her
.
<EOS>
When
he
asks
her
to
marry
him
,
he
almost
flies
at
her
throat
,
as
an
angry
debtor
who
applies
for
instant
payment
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
,
Mr.
Finn
,
never
to
give
it
over
;
 
and
teach
him
that
he
should
be
soft
with
her
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
,
also
,
that
in
her
heart
she
likes
him
.
<EOS>
One
woman
,
as
you
say
,
knows
another
woman
;
and
I
am
certain
he
would
win
her
if
he
would
only
be
gentle
with
her
.
"
<EOS>
Then
,
again
,
before
they
parted
,
Lady
Laura
told
him
that
this
marriage
was
the
dearest
wish
of
her
heart
,
and
that
there
would
be
no
end
to
her
gratitude
if
Phineas
could
do
anything
to
promote
it
.
<EOS>
All
which
again
made
our
hero
unhappy
.
   
<EOS>
Sunday
in
Grosvenor
Place
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
,
though
he
was
a
most
scrupulously
attentive
member
of
Parliament
,
was
a
man
very
punctual
to
hours
and
rules
in
his
own
house
,
 
and
liked
that
his
wife
should
be
as
punctual
as
himself
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
,
who
in
marrying
him
had
firmly
resolved
that
she
would
do
her
duty
to
him
in
all
ways
,
even
though
the
ways
might
sometimes
be
painful
,
 
and
had
been
perhaps
more
punctilious
in
this
respect
than
she
might
have
been
had
she
loved
him
heartily
,
 
was
not
perhaps
quite
so
fond
of
accurate
regularity
as
her
husband
;
and
thus
,
by
this
time
,
certain
habits
of
his
had
become
rather
bonds
than
habits
to
her
.
<EOS>
He
always
had
prayers
at
nine
,
and
breakfasted
at
a
quarter
past
nine
,
let
the
hours
on
the
night
before
have
been
as
late
as
they
might
before
the
time
for
rest
had
come
.
<EOS>
After
breakfast
he
would
open
his
letters
in
his
study
,
but
he
liked
her
to
be
with
him
,
and
desired
to
discuss
with
her
every
application
he
got
from
a
constituent
.
<EOS>
He
had
his
private
secretary
in
a
room
apart
,
but
he
thought
that
everything
should
be
filtered
to
his
private
secretary
through
his
wife
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
anxious
that
she
herself
should
superintend
the
accounts
of
their
own
private
expenditure
,
and
had
taken
some
trouble
to
teach
her
an
excellent
mode
of
book
-
keeping
.
<EOS>
He
had
recommended
to
her
a
certain
course
of
reading
,
 
which
was
pleasant
enough
;
ladies
like
to
receive
such
recommendations
;
but
Mr.
Kennedy
,
having
drawn
out
the
course
,
seemed
to
expect
that
his
wife
should
read
the
books
he
had
named
,
and
,
worse
still
,
that
she
should
read
them
in
the
time
he
had
allocated
for
the
work
.
<EOS>
This
,
I
think
,
was
tyranny
.
<EOS>
Then
the
Sundays
became
very
wearisome
to
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
Going
to
church
twice
,
she
had
learnt
,
would
be
a
part
of
her
duty
;
and
though
in
her
father
's
household
attendance
at
church
had
never
been
very
strict
,
she
had
made
up
her
mind
to
this
cheerfully
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Kennedy
expected
also
that
he
and
she
should
always
dine
together
on
Sundays
,
that
there
should
be
no
guests
,
and
that
there
should
be
no
evening
company
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
the
demand
was
not
very
severe
,
but
yet
she
found
that
it
operated
injuriously
upon
her
comfort
.
<EOS>
The
Sundays
were
very
wearisome
to
her
,
and
made
her
feel
that
her
lord
and
master
was
 
her
lord
and
master
.
<EOS>
She
made
an
effort
or
two
to
escape
,
but
the
efforts
were
all
in
vain
.
<EOS>
He
never
spoke
a
cross
word
to
her
.
<EOS>
He
never
gave
a
stern
command
.
<EOS>
But
yet
he
had
his
way
.
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
say
that
reading
a
novel
on
a
Sunday
is
a
sin
,
"
he
said
;
"
but
we
must
at
any
rate
admit
that
it
is
a
matter
on
which
men
disagree
,
that
many
of
the
best
of
men
are
against
such
occupation
on
Sunday
,
and
that
to
abstain
is
to
be
on
the
safe
side
.
"
<EOS>
So
the
novels
were
put
away
,
and
Sunday
afternoon
with
the
long
evening
became
rather
a
stumbling
-
block
to
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
Those
two
hours
,
moreover
,
with
her
husband
in
the
morning
became
very
wearisome
to
her
.
<EOS>
At
first
she
had
declared
that
it
would
be
her
greatest
ambition
to
help
her
husband
in
his
work
,
and
she
had
read
all
the
letters
from
the
MacNabs
and
MacFies
,
asking
to
be
made
gaugers
and
landing
-
waiters
,
with
an
assumed
interest
.
<EOS>
But
the
work
palled
upon
her
very
quickly
.
<EOS>
Her
quick
intellect
discovered
soon
that
there
was
nothing
in
it
which
she
really
did
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
form
and
verbiage
,
and
pretence
at
business
.
<EOS>
Her
husband
went
through
it
all
with
the
utmost
patience
,
reading
every
word
,
giving
orders
as
to
every
detail
,
and
conscientiously
doing
that
which
he
conceived
he
had
undertaken
to
do
.
<EOS>
But
Lady
Laura
wanted
to
meddle
with
high
politics
,
to
discuss
reform
bills
,
to
assist
in
putting
up
Mr.
This
and
putting
down
my
Lord
That
.
<EOS>
Why
should
she
waste
her
time
in
doing
that
which
the
lad
in
the
next
room
,
who
was
called
a
private
secretary
,
could
do
as
well
?
  
<EOS>
Still
she
would
obey
.
<EOS>
Let
the
task
be
as
hard
as
it
might
,
she
would
obey
.
<EOS>
If
he
counselled
her
to
do
this
or
that
,
she
would
follow
his
counsel
,
 
because
she
owed
him
so
much
.
<EOS>
If
she
had
accepted
the
half
of
all
his
wealth
without
loving
him
,
she
owed
him
the
more
on
that
account
.
<EOS>
But
she
knew
,
 
<EOS>
she
could
not
<EOS>
but
know
,
 
that
her
intellect
was
brighter
than
his
;
and
might
it
not
be
possible
for
her
to
lead
him
?
<EOS>
Then
she
made
efforts
to
lead
her
husband
,
and
found
that
he
was
as
stiff
-
necked
as
an
ox
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
was
not
,
perhaps
,
a
clever
man
;
but
he
was
a
man
who
knew
his
own
way
,
and
who
intended
to
keep
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
got
a
headache
,
Robert
,
"
she
said
to
him
one
Sunday
after
luncheon
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
will
not
go
to
church
this
afternoon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
serious
,
I
hope
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
no
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
know
how
one
feels
sometimes
that
one
has
got
a
head
?
<EOS>
And
when
that
is
the
case
one
's
armchair
is
the
best
place
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
sure
of
that
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
went
to
church
<EOS>
I
should
not
attend
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
fresh
air
would
do
you
more
good
than
anything
else
,
and
we
could
walk
across
the
park
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
;
 
I
wo
n't
go
out
again
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
This
she
said
with
something
almost
of
crossness
in
her
manner
,
and
Mr.
Kennedy
went
to
the
afternoon
service
by
himself
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
when
she
was
left
alone
began
to
think
of
her
position
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
more
than
four
or
five
months
married
,
and
she
was
becoming
very
tired
of
her
life
.
<EOS>
Was
it
not
also
true
that
she
was
becoming
tired
of
her
husband
?
<EOS>
She
had
twice
told
Phineas
Finn
that
of
all
men
in
the
world
she
esteemed
Mr.
Kennedy
the
most
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
esteem
him
less
now
.
<EOS>
She
knew
no
point
or
particle
in
which
he
did
not
do
his
duty
with
accuracy
.
<EOS>
But
no
person
can
live
happily
with
another
,
 
not
even
with
a
brother
or
a
sister
or
a
friend
,
 
simply
upon
esteem
.
<EOS>
All
the
virtues
in
the
calendar
,
though
they
exist
on
each
side
,
will
not
make
a
man
and
woman
happy
together
,
unless
there
be
sympathy
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
was
beginning
to
find
out
that
there
was
a
lack
of
sympathy
between
herself
and
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
She
thought
of
this
till
she
was
tired
of
thinking
of
it
,
and
then
,
wishing
to
divert
her
mind
,
she
took
up
the
book
that
was
lying
nearest
to
her
hand
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
volume
of
a
new
novel
which
she
had
been
reading
on
the
previous
day
,
and
now
,
without
much
thought
about
it
,
she
went
on
with
her
reading
.
<EOS>
There
came
to
her
,
no
doubt
,
some
dim
,
half
-
formed
idea
that
,
as
she
was
freed
from
going
to
church
by
the
plea
of
a
headache
,
she
was
also
absolved
by
the
same
plea
from
other
Sunday
hindrances
.
<EOS>
A
child
,
when
it
is
ill
,
has
buttered
toast
and
a
picture
-
book
instead
of
bread
-
and
-
milk
and
lessons
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
,
Lady
Laura
conceived
herself
to
be
entitled
to
her
novel
.
  
<EOS>
While
she
was
reading
it
,
there
came
a
knock
at
the
door
,
and
Barrington
Erle
was
shown
upstairs
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
had
given
no
orders
against
Sunday
visitors
,
but
had
simply
said
that
Sunday
visiting
was
not
to
his
taste
.
<EOS>
Barrington
,
however
,
was
Lady
Laura
's
cousin
,
and
people
must
be
very
strict
if
they
ca
n't
see
their
cousins
on
Sunday
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
soon
lost
her
headache
altogether
in
the
animation
of
discussing
the
chances
of
the
new
Reform
Bill
with
the
Prime
Minister
's
private
secretary
;
and
had
left
her
chair
,
and
was
standing
by
the
table
with
the
novel
in
her
hand
,
protesting
this
and
denying
that
,
expressing
infinite
confidence
in
Mr.
Monk
,
and
violently
denouncing
Mr.
Turnbull
,
when
her
husband
returned
from
church
and
came
up
into
the
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
had
forgotten
her
headache
altogether
,
and
had
in
her
composition
none
of
that
thoughtfulness
of
hypocrisy
which
would
have
taught
her
to
moderate
her
political
feeling
at
her
husband
's
return
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
declare
,
"
she
said
,
"
that
if
Mr.
Turnbull
opposes
the
Government
measure
now
,
because
he
ca
n't
have
his
own
way
in
everything
,
I
will
never
again
put
my
trust
in
any
man
who
calls
himself
a
popular
leader
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
never
should
,
"
said
Barrington
Erle
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
very
well
for
you
,
Barrington
,
who
are
an
aristocratic
Whig
of
the
old
official
school
,
and
who
call
yourself
a
Liberal
simply
because
Fox
was
a
Liberal
a
hundred
years
ago
.
<EOS>
My
heart
's
in
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Heart
should
never
have
anything
to
do
with
politics
;
should
it
?
"
said
Erle
,
turning
round
to
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
did
not
wish
to
discuss
the
matter
on
a
Sunday
,
nor
yet
did
he
wish
to
say
before
Barrington
Erle
that
he
thought
it
wrong
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
And
he
was
desirous
of
treating
his
wife
in
some
way
as
though
she
were
an
invalid
,
 
that
she
thereby
might
be
,
as
it
were
,
punished
;
but
he
did
not
wish
to
do
this
in
such
a
way
that
Barrington
should
be
aware
of
the
punishment
.
  
<EOS>
"
Laura
had
better
not
disturb
herself
about
it
now
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
is
a
person
to
help
being
disturbed
?
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
laughing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
;
we
wo
n't
mind
all
that
now
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
,
turning
away
.
<EOS>
Then
he
took
up
the
novel
which
Lady
Laura
had
just
laid
down
from
her
hand
,
and
,
having
looked
at
it
,
carried
it
aside
,
and
placed
it
on
a
book
-
shelf
which
was
remote
from
them
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
watched
him
as
he
did
this
,
and
the
whole
course
of
her
husband
's
thoughts
on
the
subject
was
open
to
her
at
once
.
<EOS>
She
regretted
the
novel
,
and
she
regretted
also
the
political
discussion
.
<EOS>
Soon
afterwards
Barrington
Erle
went
away
,
and
the
husband
and
wife
were
alone
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
that
your
head
is
so
much
better
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
intend
to
be
severe
,
but
he
spoke
with
a
gravity
of
manner
which
almost
amounted
to
severity
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
it
is
,
"
she
said
,
"
Barrington
's
coming
in
cheered
me
up
.
"
  
"
I
am
sorry
that
you
should
have
wanted
cheering
.
"
  
"
Do
n't
you
know
what
I
mean
,
Robert
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
;
I
do
not
think
that
I
do
,
exactly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
your
head
is
stronger
.
<EOS>
You
do
not
get
that
feeling
of
dazed
,
helpless
imbecility
of
brain
,
which
hardly
amounts
to
headache
,
but
which
yet
 
is
almost
as
bad
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Imbecility
of
brain
may
be
worse
than
headache
,
but
I
do
n't
think
it
can
produce
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
;
 
I
do
n't
know
how
to
explain
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Headache
comes
,
I
think
,
always
from
the
stomach
,
even
when
produced
by
nervous
affections
.
<EOS>
But
imbecility
of
the
brain
 
"
  
"
Oh
,
Robert
,
I
am
so
sorry
that
I
used
the
word
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
see
that
it
did
not
prevent
your
reading
,
"
he
said
,
after
a
pause
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
such
reading
as
that
.
<EOS>
I
was
up
to
nothing
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
there
was
another
pause
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
deny
that
it
may
be
a
prejudice
,
"
he
said
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
confess
that
the
use
of
novels
in
my
own
house
on
Sundays
is
a
pain
to
me
.
<EOS>
My
mother
's
ideas
on
the
subject
are
very
strict
,
and
I
can
not
think
that
it
is
bad
for
a
son
to
hang
on
to
the
teaching
of
his
mother
.
<EOS>
"
This
he
said
in
the
most
serious
tone
which
he
could
command
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
why
I
took
it
up
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Simply
,
I
believe
,
because
it
was
there
.
<EOS>
I
will
avoid
doing
so
for
the
future
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
husband
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
obliged
and
grateful
if
you
will
remember
what
I
have
said
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
left
her
,
and
she
sat
alone
,
first
in
the
dusk
and
then
in
the
dark
,
for
two
hours
,
doing
nothing
.
<EOS>
Was
this
to
be
the
life
which
she
had
procured
for
herself
by
marrying
Mr.
Kennedy
of
Loughlinter
?
<EOS>
If
it
was
harsh
and
unendurable
in
London
,
what
would
it
be
in
the
country
?
   
<EOS>
The
Willingford
Bull
 
Phineas
left
London
by
a
night
mail
train
on
Easter
Sunday
,
and
found
himself
at
the
Willingford
Bull
about
half
an
hour
after
midnight
.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
was
up
and
waiting
for
him
,
and
supper
was
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
The
Willingford
Bull
was
an
English
inn
of
the
old
stamp
,
which
had
now
,
in
these
latter
years
of
railway
travelling
,
ceased
to
have
a
road
business
,
 
for
there
were
no
travellers
on
the
road
,
and
but
little
posting
 
but
had
acquired
a
new
trade
as
a
dépôt
for
hunters
and
hunting
men
.
<EOS>
The
landlord
let
out
horses
and
kept
hunting
stables
,
and
the
house
was
generally
filled
from
the
beginning
of
November
till
the
middle
of
April
.
<EOS>
Then
it
became
a
desert
in
the
summer
,
and
no
guests
were
seen
there
,
till
the
pink
coats
flocked
down
again
into
the
shires
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
many
days
do
you
mean
to
give
us
?
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
,
as
he
helped
his
friend
to
a
devilled
leg
of
turkey
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
go
back
on
Wednesday
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
means
Wednesday
night
.
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
what
we
'll
do
.
<EOS>
We
've
the
Cottesmore
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
We
'll
get
into
Tailby
's
country
on
Tuesday
,
and
Fitzwilliam
will
be
only
twelve
miles
off
on
Wednesday
.
<EOS>
We
shall
be
rather
short
of
horses
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
let
me
put
you
out
.
<EOS>
I
can
hire
something
here
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
You
wo
n't
put
me
out
at
all
.
<EOS>
There
'll
be
three
between
us
each
day
,
and
we
'll
run
our
luck
.
<EOS>
The
horses
have
gone
on
to
Empingham
for
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Tailby
is
rather
a
way
off
,
 
at
Somerby
;
but
we
'll
manage
it
.
<EOS>
If
the
worst
comes
to
the
worst
,
we
can
get
back
to
Stamford
by
rail
.
<EOS>
On
Wednesday
we
shall
have
everything
very
comfortable
.
<EOS>
They
're
out
beyond
Stilton
and
will
draw
home
our
way
.
<EOS>
I
've
planned
it
all
out
.
<EOS>
I
've
a
trap
with
a
fast
stepper
,
and
if
we
start
to
-
morrow
at
half
-
past
nine
,
we
shall
be
in
plenty
of
time
.
<EOS>
You
shall
ride
Meg
Merrilies
,
and
if
she
do
n't
carry
you
,
you
may
shoot
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
she
one
of
the
pulling
ones
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
heavy
in
hand
if
you
are
heavy
at
her
,
but
leave
her
mouth
alone
and
she
'll
go
like
flowing
water
.
<EOS>
You
'd
better
not
ride
more
in
a
crowd
than
you
can
help
.
<EOS>
Now
what
'll
you
drink
?
"
  
<EOS>
They
sat
up
half
the
night
smoking
and
talking
,
and
Phineas
learned
more
about
Lord
Chiltern
then
than
ever
he
had
learned
before
.
<EOS>
There
was
brandy
and
water
before
them
,
but
neither
of
them
drank
.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
,
indeed
,
had
a
pint
of
beer
by
his
side
from
which
he
sipped
occasionally
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
taken
to
beer
,
"
he
said
,
"
as
being
the
best
drink
going
.
<EOS>
When
a
man
hunts
six
days
a
week
he
can
afford
to
drink
beer
.
<EOS>
I
'm
on
an
allowance
,
 
three
pints
a
day
.
<EOS>
That
's
not
too
much
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
drink
nothing
else
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
when
I
'm
alone
,
 
except
a
little
cherry
-
brandy
when
I
'm
out
.
<EOS>
I
never
cared
for
drink
;
 
never
in
my
life
.
<EOS>
I
do
like
excitement
,
and
have
been
less
careful
than
I
ought
to
have
been
as
to
what
it
has
come
from
.
<EOS>
I
could
give
up
drink
to
-
morrow
,
without
a
struggle
,
 
if
it
were
worth
my
while
to
make
up
my
mind
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
And
it
's
the
same
with
gambling
.
<EOS>
I
never
do
gamble
now
,
because
I
've
got
no
money
;
but
I
own
I
like
it
better
than
anything
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
While
you
are
at
it
,
there
is
life
in
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
take
to
politics
,
Chiltern
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
would
have
done
so
,
but
my
father
would
not
help
me
.
<EOS>
Never
mind
,
we
will
not
talk
about
him
.
<EOS>
How
does
Laura
get
on
with
her
husband
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Very
happily
,
I
should
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
it
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Her
temper
is
too
much
like
mine
to
allow
her
to
be
happy
with
such
a
log
of
wood
as
Robert
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
It
is
such
men
as
he
who
drive
me
out
of
the
pale
of
decent
life
.
<EOS>
If
that
is
decency
,
I
'd
sooner
be
indecent
.
<EOS>
You
mark
my
words
.
<EOS>
They
'll
come
to
grief
.
<EOS>
She
'll
never
be
able
to
stand
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
she
had
her
own
way
in
everything
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
.
<EOS>
Though
he
's
a
prig
,
he
's
a
man
;
and
she
will
not
find
it
easy
to
drive
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
she
may
bend
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
an
inch
;
 
that
is
if
I
understand
his
character
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
see
a
good
deal
of
them
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
 
pretty
well
.
<EOS>
I
'm
not
there
so
often
as
I
used
to
be
in
the
Square
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
get
sick
of
it
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
I
should
.
<EOS>
Do
you
see
my
father
often
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Only
occasionally
.
<EOS>
He
is
always
very
civil
when
I
do
see
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
the
very
pink
of
civility
when
he
pleases
,
but
the
most
unjust
man
I
ever
met
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
have
thought
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
he
is
,
"
said
the
Earl
's
son
,
"
and
all
from
lack
of
judgment
to
discern
the
truth
.
<EOS>
He
makes
up
his
mind
to
a
thing
on
insufficient
proof
,
and
then
nothing
will
turn
him
.
<EOS>
He
thinks
well
of
you
,
 
would
probably
believe
your
word
on
any
indifferent
subject
without
thought
of
a
doubt
;
but
if
you
were
to
tell
him
that
I
did
n't
get
drunk
every
night
of
my
life
and
spend
most
of
my
time
in
thrashing
policemen
,
he
would
not
believe
you
.
<EOS>
He
would
smile
incredulously
and
make
you
a
little
bow
.
<EOS>
I
can
see
him
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
too
hard
on
him
,
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
been
too
hard
on
me
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
Is
Violet
Effingham
still
in
Grosvenor
Place
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
she
's
with
Lady
Baldock
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
old
grandmother
of
evil
has
come
to
town
,
 
has
she
?
<EOS>
Poor
Violet
!
<EOS>
When
we
were
young
together
we
used
to
have
such
fun
about
that
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
old
woman
is
an
ally
of
mine
now
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
make
allies
everywhere
.
<EOS>
You
know
Violet
Effingham
of
course
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
.
<EOS>
I
know
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
think
her
very
charming
?
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
"
Exceedingly
charming
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
asked
that
girl
to
marry
me
three
times
,
and
I
shall
never
ask
her
again
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
point
beyond
which
a
man
should
n't
go
.
<EOS>
There
are
many
reasons
why
it
would
be
a
good
marriage
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
her
money
would
be
serviceable
.
<EOS>
Then
it
would
heal
matters
in
our
family
,
for
my
father
is
as
prejudiced
in
her
favour
as
he
is
against
me
.
<EOS>
And
I
love
her
dearly
.
<EOS>
I
've
loved
her
all
my
life
,
 
since
I
used
to
buy
cakes
for
her
.
<EOS>
But
I
shall
never
ask
her
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
if
I
were
you
,
"
said
Phineas
,
 
hardly
knowing
what
it
might
be
best
for

to
say
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
never
will
.
<EOS>
But
I
'll
tell
you
what
.
<EOS>
I
shall
get
into
some

scrape
about
her
.
<EOS>
Of
course
she
'll
marry
,
and
that
soon
.
<EOS>
Then
I
shall
make
a

.
<EOS>
When
I

that
she
is
engaged
I
shall

man
,
and
kick

,
 
or
get
kicked
.
<EOS>
All
the
world
will
turn
against

,
and
I
shall

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
dog
in
the
manger
is
what
you

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Exactly
;
 
but
how

man

?
<EOS>
If

girl

?
"
<EOS>
Phineas

course
that
he

.
<EOS>
"
It
is
as
though
he
were
to

.
<EOS>
Though

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Of

.
<EOS>
Light

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Phineas

,

.
<EOS>
He

if

.
<EOS>
He

and

,
and

a

would

.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,

.
<EOS>
He

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

Chiltern
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
You
rush

as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She

,

.
<EOS>
Not

what
you

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
But

no

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
And
I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
It

,

.

<EOS>
Phineas
,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
On

<EOS>
But

Chiltern
drove

,

.
<EOS>
They
had
a

's

;
and
Phineas
,
though

found
that
Meg
Merrilies
did

,
went
through
his
day
's

with

.
<EOS>
He
had
been

since
he

,
as
is

custom
with
all
boys
in
Munster
,
and
had
an
Irishman
's

.
<EOS>
When

back
to

Willingford
Bull
he

and

.
<EOS>
"
It
was

fast
,

,
"

,
"
and
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Besides
,
Meg

.
<EOS>
You

ride
Bonebreaker
to

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bonebreaker
?
<EOS>
Have

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

!
<EOS>
you

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

I

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
I
ca

.
<EOS>
When

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Bonebreaker
,

sha

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

's

was
in
Leicestershire
,

,

.
<EOS>
Phineas
,

,

.
<EOS>
He
had

nor

,

.
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

,
"

"
i

,

;

rum

.
"
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Just

"

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
Phineas

<EOS>
"

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>
And

went
away
to
Pickwell

.
  
<EOS>
There
were
over
two
hundred
men
out
,
and
Phineas
began
to
think
that
it
might
not
be
so

.
<EOS>
A
crowd
in
a
fast
run
no
doubt
quickly
becomes
small
by
degrees
and
beautifully
less
;
but
it
is
very
difficult
,
especially
for
a

,
to
free

from
the
rush

the

.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
's
horse
plunged

,
as

side

,
that

,

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

Chiltern
,
"
we
ca
n't
be
better
than
we

here
.
<EOS>
If
he
goes
up
wind
,
he
must
turn
before
long
,

we
shall

.
"
<EOS>
As

an

opened

,
 
an

whom
all

pack
believed
,
 
and

.
<EOS>
"
There

,
"

,
"

ca

.
<EOS>
Did

?
<EOS>
But
I
feel

'll
go

when

.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
was
too
much

with

own
horse
to

Chiltern

.
<EOS>
Bonebreaker
,

's

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
He
's

<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Give

,

.
<EOS>
"

that

would

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

,
 
up

.
<EOS>
"
It

"

Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
vixen
in
cub
never
went
away
like
that
yet
.
<EOS>
Now
then
,
Finn
,
my
boy
,
keep
to
the
right
.
"
<EOS>
And
Lord
Chiltern
,
with
the
horse
out
of
Lincolnshire
,
went
away
across
the
brow
of
the
hill
,
leaving
the
hounds
to
the
left
,
and
selected
,
as
his
point
of
exit
into
the
next
field
,
a
stiff
rail
,
which
,
had
there
been
an
accident
,
must
have
put

very
wide
margin

ground
between
the
rider
and
his
horse
.
<EOS>
"
Go
hard
at
your
fences
,
and
then
you
'll
fall

,
"
he
had
said
to
Phineas
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't

,
however
,
that
he
would
have
ridden
at
the
rail
as
he
did
,
but
that
there

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
brute
began
in
his
own
way
,
and
carried
on
after
in
the
same
fashion
all
through
,
"
he

.
<EOS>
Phineas
took
the
fence
a
little
lower
down
,
and
what
it
was
at
which
he
rode
he
never

.
<EOS>
Bonebreaker
sailed
over
it
,
whatever
it
was
,
and
he
soon
found
himself
by
his
friend
's
side
.
  
<EOS>
The
ruck
of
the
men
were
lower
down
than
our

heroes
,
and
there
were
others
far
away
to
the
left
,
and
others
,
again
,
who
had

,

.
<EOS>
Our
friends
were
not
near

hounds
,
not
within
two

,
but
the
hounds
were
below

,
and
therefore

.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
in
a
hurry
,
and
they
'll
be
round
upon

,
"
Lord
Chiltern
said
.
<EOS>
"
How
the
deuce
is
one
to
help
being
in
a
hurry
?
"
said
Phineas
,
who
was
doing
his
very
best
to
ride
Bonebreaker
with
the
snaffle
,
but
had
already
began
to
feel
that
Bonebreaker
cared
nothing
for
that
weak
instrument
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
George
,
I
should
like
to
change
with
you
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
The
Lincolnshire
horse
was
going
along
with
his
head
very
low
,
boring
as
he
galloped
,
but
throwing
his
neck
up
at
his
fences
,
just
when
he
ought
to
have
kept

.
<EOS>
After
this
,
though
Phineas
kept
near
Lord
Chiltern
throughout

run
,
they
were
not
again
near
enough
to
exchange
words
;
and
,
indeed
,
they
had
but
<EOS>
little
breath
for
such
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
rode
still
a
little
in
advance
,
and
Phineas
,
knowing
his
friend
's
partiality
for
solitude
when

,
kept
a
little
to
his
left
.
<EOS>
He
began
to
find
that
Bonebreaker
knew
pretty
well
what
he
was
about
.
<EOS>
As
for
not
using
the
gag

,
that
was
impossible
.
<EOS>
When

horse

what
strength

against
a
man

,
a
man
must
put
out
what
strength
he
has
against
the
horse
's
mouth
.
<EOS>
But
Bonebreaker
was
cunning
,
and
had
had
a
gag
rein
on
before
.
<EOS>
He
contracted
his
lip
here
,
and
bent

there
,
till
he
had

,
and
then
went
away
after
his
own

.
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
have
a
passion
for

through
big
,

-

ox
-

,
and
by
degrees
his
rider
came
to
feel
that
if
there
was

,
the
fun
was
not

.
  
<EOS>
The
fox
ran
up
wind
for
a

or

,
as
Lord
Chiltern
had
prophesied
,
and
then

,
 
not

,
as

,
but

,
 
so
that
they
were

to

through
the
ruck
of

before
they
could
place

again
.
<EOS>
Phineas
found
himself
crossing
a
road
,
in
and
out
of
it
,
before
he
knew
where
he
was
,
and
for
a

lost

Chiltern
.
<EOS>
But
in
truth
he
was
leading
now
,
whereas
Lord
Chiltern
had
led
before
.
<EOS>
The
two

having
been
together
all

,
and

previous

,
were
willing

to

,

.
<EOS>
They
both
crossed
the
road
,
not

,

in

out
amidst
a

,
and

again
placed
well
,
now
having
the
hunt
on

right
,
whereas

.
<EOS>
They

over

,
and
Phineas
began

that
as

Bonebreaker
would
be

go
through
the
thick

-

,
all

be
right
.
<EOS>
Now

,
a

that
had
been
cut
and
laid
,
and
these

not

.
<EOS>
Force
was
not
sufficient
for
them
,
and
they
admitted
of
a

.
<EOS>
But
the
horse
,
though
he
would
rush
at
them

,
took
them
when

came
without

.
<EOS>
It
might
be
all
right
yet
,
 
unless
the
beast
should

;
and
then
,
Phineas
thought
,
a

.
<EOS>
He

,
as

flew

,
that

rode
a

.
<EOS>
At
the
end

forty
-
five
minutes
Bonebreaker
also
might

.
  
<EOS>
The
hounds
were
running
well
in
sight
to
their
right
,
and
Phineas
began
to
feel
some

that
pride
which
a
man
indulges
when

that
he
has

,
has

,

.
<EOS>
There

men
nearer

hounds
than
he

,
but
he
was
near
enough
even
for

.
<EOS>
There
had
already

enough
of
the
run
to
make
him
sure
that
it
would
be
a
"
good
thing
"
,
and
enough
to
make
him
aware
also
that
probably
it
might
be
too
good
.
<EOS>
When
a
run
is
over
,
men
are
very
apt
to
regret
the
termination
,
who
a
minute
or
two
before
were
anxiously
longing
that
the
hounds
might

.
<EOS>
To
finish
well
is
everything
in

.
<EOS>
To

for
over
an
hour
is
nothing
,
let

and
country
have
been
what

,

.
<EOS>
Therefore

is
that
those
behind
hope
that

fox
may
make
this
or
that
cover
,
while
the
forward
men
long
to
see
him
turned

.
<EOS>
To

to
hounds
is
very

;
but
to
have

more

.
<EOS>
They
had
now

another

,
and
a
larger

,
and
had

.
<EOS>
The

were
not

,

were

.
<EOS>
Phineas
got

moment

,
and
saw
Lord
Chiltern
riding

.
<EOS>
He
was
very
red

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

to

,
and

had
too

.
<EOS>
He

,
a

,

,

Chiltern
as

;
but

only

.
  
<EOS>
There
were

in

.
<EOS>
The
river
Eye
forms

thereabouts
,
or

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
Phineas

;
but
Bonebreaker
had

,
and
now
that
there
came
a
third
in
the
way
<EOS>
,

was
to

he

.
<EOS>
Phineas
,

any

,

.
<EOS>
As

the

go

with

he

;
but
he
had

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,

,

was

.
<EOS>
He

,
and
there
was
Chiltern
close

,
still

horse
;
 
but
the

had
turned
away
.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
Chiltern
nodded
to
him
,
as
much
as
to

to
go

.
<EOS>
On
he
went

any
rate
.
<EOS>
The
brook
,

he

to

,
seemed

,

.
<EOS>
The

were
quite

,
and
just

he

to

.
<EOS>
It
was
too
late
to
think

anything
.
<EOS>
He
stuck
his

his

,
 
and
in
a

was
on
the
other
side
.
<EOS>
The
brute
,
who
had
taken
off
a
yard
before
the

,
knowing
well
the
danger
of
striking
it
with

,
came
down
with

,
and
did
,
I
think
,
begin
to
feel

weight
of
that
extra
stone
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
as

as
he
was

,
looked
back
,
and

Lord
Chiltern
's
horse
in

,
 
higher

the

,
where

was

.
<EOS>
At
that

Phineas
could
see
that
Lord
Chiltern
was
wild

rage
against
the
beast
.
<EOS>
But
whether
he
wished
to
take
the
leap
or
wished
to
avoid
it
,
there
was
no

left
to

.
<EOS>
The
animal
rushed
at
the
brook
,
and
in
a
moment
the
horse
and
horseman
were
lost
to
sight
.
<EOS>
It
was
well
then
that
that
extra
stone
should
tell
,
as
it
enabled
Phineas
to
arrest
his
horse
and
to
come
back
to
his
friend
.
  
<EOS>
The
Lincolnshire
horse
had
chested
the
further
bank
,
and
of
course
had
fallen
back
into
the
stream
.
<EOS>
When
Phineas
got
down
he
found
that
Lord
Chiltern
was
wedged
in
between
the
horse
and
the
bank
,
which
was
better
,
at
any
rate
,
than
being
under
the
horse
in
the
water
.
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
old
fellow
<EOS>
,
"
he
said
,
with
a
smile
,
when
he
saw
Phineas
.
"
You
go
on
;
it
's
too
good
to
lose
.
"
<EOS>
But
he
was
very
pale
,
and
seemed
to
be
quite
helpless
where
he
lay
.
<EOS>
The
horse
did
not
move
,
 
and
never
did
move
again
.
<EOS>
He
had
smashed
his
shoulder
to
pieces
against
a
stump
on
the
bank
,
and
was
afterwards
shot
on
that
very
spot
.
  
<EOS>
When
Phineas
got
down
he
found
that
there
was
but
little
water
where
the
horse
lay
.
<EOS>
The
depth
of
the
stream
had
been
on
the
side
from
which
they
had
taken
off
,
and
the
thick
black
mud
lay
within
a
foot
of
the
surface
,
close
to
the
bank
against
which
Lord
Chiltern
was

.
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
worst
one
I
ever
was
on
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
;
"
but
<EOS>
I
think
he
's
gruelled
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
hurt
?
"
  
"
Well
;
 
I
fancy
there
is
something
amiss
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
move
my
arms
;
and
I
catch
my
breath
.
<EOS>
My
legs
are
all
right
if
I
could
get
away
from
this
accursed
brute
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
so
,
"
said
the
farmer
,
coming
and
looking
down
upon
them
from
the
bank
.
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
so
,
but
you
would
n't
be
said
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
too
got
down
,
and
between
them
both
they
extricated
Lord
Chiltern
from
his
position
,
and
got
him
on
to
the
bank
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
un
's
a
dead
un
,
"
said
the
farmer
,
pointing
to
the
horse
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
better
,
"
said
his
lordship
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Give
us
a
drop
of
sherry
,
Finn
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
broken
his
collar
-
bone
and
three
of
his
ribs
.
<EOS>
They
got
a
farmer
's
trap
from
Wissindine
and
took
him
into
Oakham
.
<EOS>
When
there
,
he
insisted
on
being
taken
on
through
Stamford
to
the
Willingford
Bull
before
he
would
have
his
bones
set
,
 
picking
up
,
however
,
a
surgeon
at
Stamford
.
<EOS>
Phineas
remained
with
him
for
a
couple
of
days
,
losing
his
run
with
the
Fitzwilliams
and
a
day
at
the
potted
peas
,
and
became
very
fond
of
his
patient
as
he
sat
by
