.
  
<EOS>
"
That
was
a
good
run
,
though
,
was
n't
it
?
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
as
Phineas
took
his
leave
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,
by
George
,
Phineas
,
you
rode
Bonebreaker
<EOS>
so
well
,
that
you
shall
have
him
as
often
as
you
'll
come
down
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
it
is
,
but
you
Irish
fellows
always
ride
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
's
Carriage
Stops
the
Way
 
When
Phineas
got
back
to
London
,
a
day
after
his
time
,
he
found
that
there
was
already
a
great
political
commotion
in
the
metropolis
.
<EOS>
He
had
known
that
on
Easter
Monday
and
Tuesday
there
was
to
be
a
gathering
of
the
people
in
favour
of
the
ballot
,
and
that
on
Wednesday
there
was
to
be
a
procession
with
a
petition
which
Mr.
Turnbull
was
to
receive
from
the
hands
of
the
people
on
Primrose
Hill
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
at
first
intended
that
Mr.
Turnbull
should
receive
the
petition
at
the
door
of
Westminster
Hall
on
the
Thursday
;
but
he
had
been
requested
by
the
Home
Secretary
to
put
aside
this
intention
,
and
he
had
complied
with
the
request
made
to
him
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
was
to
move
the
second
reading
of
his
Reform
Bill
on
that
day
,
the
preliminary
steps
having
been
taken
without
any
special
notice
;
but
the
bill
of
course
included
no
clause
in
favour
of
the
ballot
;
and
this
petition
was
the
consequence
of
that
omission
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
had
predicted
evil
consequences
,
both
in
the
House
and
out
of
it
,
and
was
now
doing
the
best
in
his
power
to
bring
about
the
verification
of
his
own
prophecies
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
reached
his
lodgings
late
on
the
Thursday
,
found
that
the
town
had
been
in
a
state
of
ferment
for
three
days
,
that
on
the
Wednesday
forty
or
fifty
thousand
persons
had
been
collected
at
Primrose
Hill
,
and
that
the
police
had
been
forced
to
interfere
,
 
and
that
worse
was
expected
on
the
Friday
.
<EOS>
Though
Mr.
Turnbull
had
yielded
to
the
Government
as
to
receiving
the
petition
,
the
crowd
was
resolved
that
they
would
see
the
petition
carried
into
the
House
.
<EOS>
It
was
argued
that
the
Government
would
have
done
better
to
have
refrained
from
interfering
as
to
the
previously
intended
arrangement
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
easier
to
deal
with
a
procession
than
with
a
mob
of
men
gathered
together
without
any
semblance
of
form
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
had
been
asked
to
postpone
the
second
reading
of
his
bill
;
but
the
request
had
come
from
his
opponents
,
and
he
would
not
yield
to
it
.
<EOS>
He
said
that
it
would
be
a
bad
expedient
to
close
Parliament
from
fear
of
the
people
.
<EOS>
Phineas
found
at
the
Reform
Club
on
the
Thursday
evening
that
members
of
the
House
of
Commons
were
requested
to
enter
on
the
Friday
by
the
door
usually
used
by
the
peers
,
and
to
make
their
way
thence
to
their
own
House
.
<EOS>
He
found
that
his
landlord
,
Mr.
Bunce
,
had
been
out
with
the
people
during
the
entire
three
days
;
 
and
Mrs.
Bunce
,
with
a
flood
of
tears
,
begged
Phineas
to
interfere
as
to
the
Friday
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
's
that
headstrong
that
he
'll
be
took
if
anybody
's
took
;
and
they
say
that
all
Westminster
is
to
be
lined
with
soldiers
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
on
the
Friday
morning
did
have
some
conversation
with
his
landlord
;
but
his
first
work
on
reaching
London
was
to
see
Lord
Chiltern
's
friends
,
and
tell
them
of
the
accident
.
  
<EOS>
The
potted
peas
Committee
sat
on
the
Thursday
,
and
he
ought
to
have
been
there
.
<EOS>
His
absence
,
however
,
was
unavoidable
,
as
he
could
not
have
left
his
friend
's
bed
-
side
so
soon
after
the
accident
.
<EOS>
On
the
Wednesday
he
had
written
to
Lady
Laura
,
and
on
the
Thursday
evening
he
went
first
to
Portman
Square
and
then
to
Grosvenor
Place
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
he
will
kill
himself
some
day
,
"
said
the
Earl
,
 
with
a
tear
,
however
,
in
each
eye
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
my
lord
.
<EOS>
He
is
a
magnificent
horseman
;
but
accidents
of
course
will
happen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
many
of
his
bones
are
there
not
broken
,
I
wonder
?
"
said
the
father
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
useless
to
talk
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
You
think
he
is
not
in
danger
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
should
fear
that
he
would
be
so
liable
to
inflammation
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
doctor
says
that
there
is
none
.
<EOS>
He
has
been
taking
an
enormous
deal
of
exercise
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
and
drinking
no
wine
.
<EOS>
All
that
is
in
his
favour
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
does
he
drink
,
then
?
"
asked
the
Earl
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
.
<EOS>
I
rather
think
,
my
lord
,
you
are
mistaken
a
little
about
his
habits
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
fancy
he
ever
drinks
unless
he
is
provoked
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Provoked
!
<EOS>
Could
anything
provoke
you
to
make
a
brute
of
yourself
?
<EOS>
But
I
am
glad
that
he
is
in
no
danger
.
<EOS>
If
you
hear
of
him
,
let
me
know
how
he
goes
on
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
was
of
course
full
of
concern
.
<EOS>
"
I
wanted
to
go
down
to
him
,
"
she
said
,
"
but
Mr.
Kennedy
thought
that
there
was
no
occasion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
is
there
any
;
 
I
mean
in
regard
to
danger
.
<EOS>
He
is
very
solitary
there
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
go
to
him
again
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
will
not
let
me
go
unless
I
can
say
that
there
is
danger
.
<EOS>
He
seems
to
think
that
because
Oswald
has
had
accidents
before
,
it
is
nothing
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
can
not
leave
London
without
his
leave
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
brother
makes
very
little
of
it
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
;
 
he
would
make
little
of
anything
.
<EOS>
But
if
I
were
ill
he
would
be
in
London
by
the
first
train
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Kennedy
would
let
you
go
if
you
asked
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
advises
me
not
to
go
.
<EOS>
He
says
my
duty
does
not
require
it
,
unless
Oswald
be
in
danger
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
know
,
Mr.
Finn
,
how
hard
it
is
for
a
wife
not
to
take
advice
when
it
is
so
given
?
"
<EOS>
This
she
said
,
within
six
months
of
her
marriage
,
to
the
man
who
had
been
her
husband
's
rival
!
  
<EOS>
Phineas
asked
her
whether
Violet
had
heard
the
news
,
and
learned
that
she
was
still
ignorant
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
got
your
letter
only
this
morning
,
and
I
have
not
seen
her
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
am
so
angry
with
her
that
I
hardly
wish
to
see
her
.
"
<EOS>
Thursday
was
Lady
Baldock
's
night
,
and
Phineas
went
from
Grosvenor
Place
to
Berkeley
Square
.
<EOS>
There
he
saw
Violet
,
and
found
that
she
had
heard
of
the
accident
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
glad
to
see
you
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
Do
tell
me
;
 
is
it
much
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Much
in
inconvenience
,
certainly
;
but
not
much
in
danger
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
Laura
was
so
unkind
not
to
send
me
word
!
<EOS>
I
only
heard
it
just
now
.
<EOS>
Did
you
see
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
close
to
him
,
and
helped
him
up
.
<EOS>
The
horse
jumped
into
a
river
with
him
,
and
crushed
him
up
against
the
bank
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
lucky
that
you
should
be
there
!
<EOS>
Had
you
jumped
the
river
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
almost
unintentionally
,
for
my
horse
was
rushing
so
that
I
could
not
hold
him
.
<EOS>
Chiltern
was
riding
a
brute
that
no
one
should
have
ridden
.
<EOS>
No
one
will
again
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
he
destroy
himself
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
had
to
be
killed
afterwards
.
<EOS>
He
broke
his
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
very
lucky
that
you
should
have
been
near
him
,
 
and
,
again
,
how
lucky
that
you
should
not
have
been
hurt
yourself
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
likely
that
we
should
both
come
to
grief
at
the
same
fence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
might
have
been
you
.
<EOS>
And
you
think
there
is
no
danger
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
None
whatever
,
 
if
I
may
believe
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
His
hunting
is
done
for
this
year
,
and
he
will
be
very
desolate
.
<EOS>
I
shall
go
down
again
to
him
in
a
few
days
,
and
try
to
bring
him
up
to
town
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
;
 
do
.
<EOS>
If
he
is
laid
up
in
his
father
's
house
,
his
father
must
see
him
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
had
not
looked
at
the
matter
in
that
light
;
but
he
thought
that
Miss
Effingham
might
probably
be
right
.
  
<EOS>
Early
on
the
next
morning
he
saw
Mr.
Bunce
,
and
used
all
his
eloquence
to
keep
that
respectable
member
of
society
at
home
;
 
but
in
vain
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
good
do
you
expect
to
do
,
Mr.
Bunce
?
<EOS>
"
he
said
,
with
perhaps
some
little
tone
of
authority
in
his
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
carry
my
point
,
"
said
Bunce
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
is
your
point
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
present
point
is
the
ballot
,
as
a
part
of
the
Government
measure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
expect
to
carry
that
by
going
out
into
the
streets
with
all
the
roughs
of
London
,
and
putting
yourself
in
direct
opposition
to
the
authority
of
the
magistrates
?
<EOS>
Do
you
really
believe
that
the
ballot
will
become
the
law
of
the
land
any
sooner
because
you
incur
this
danger
and
inconvenience
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Look
here
,
Mr.
Finn
;
I
do
n't
believe
the
sea
will
become
any
fuller
because
the
Piddle
runs
into
it
out
of
the
Dorsetshire
fields
;
but
I
do
believe
that
the
waters
from
all
the
countries
is
what
makes
the
ocean
.
<EOS>
I
shall
help
;
and
it
's
my
duty
to
help
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
your
duty
as
a
respectable
citizen
,
with
a
wife
and
family
,
to
stay
at
home
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
everybody
with
a
wife
and
family
was
to
say
so
,
there
'd
be
none
there
but
roughs
,
and
then
where
should
we
be
?
<EOS>
What
would
the
Government
people
say
to
us
then
?
<EOS>
If
every
man
with
a
wife
and
family
was
to
show
hisself
in
the
streets
to
-
night
,
we
should
have
the
ballot
before
Parliament
breaks
up
,
and
if
none
of
'em
do
n't
do
it
,
we
shall
never
have
the
ballot
.
<EOS>
Ai
n't
that
so
?
<EOS>
"
Phineas
,
who
intended
to
be
honest
,
was
not
prepared
to
dispute
the
assertion
on
the
spur
of
the
moment
.
<EOS>
"
If
that
's
so
,
"
said
Bunce
,
triumphantly
,
"
a
man
's
duty
's
clear
enough
.
<EOS>
He
ought
to
go
,
though
he
'd
two
wives
and
families
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
went
.
  
<EOS>
The
petition
was
to
be
presented
at
six
o'clock
,
but
the
crowd
,
who
collected
to
see
it
carried
into
Westminster
Hall
,
began
to
form
itself
by
noon
.
<EOS>
It
was
said
afterwards
that
many
of
the
houses
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Palace
Yard
and
the
Bridge
were
filled
with
soldiers
;
but
if
so
,
the
men
did
not
show
themselves
.
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
the
evening
three
or
four
companies
of
the
Guards
in
St.
James
's
Park
did
show
themselves
,
and
had
some
rough
work
to
do
,
for
many
of
the
people
took
themselves
away
from
Westminster
by
that
route
.
<EOS>
The
police
,
who
were
very
numerous
in
Palace
Yard
,
had
a
hard
time
of
it
all
the
afternoon
,
and
it
was
said
afterwards
that
it
would
have
been
much
better
to
have
allowed
the
petition
to
have
been
brought
up
by
the
procession
on
Wednesday
.
<EOS>
A
procession
,
let
it
be
who
it
will
that
proceeds
,
has
in
it
,
of
its
own
nature
something
of
order
.
<EOS>
But
now
there
was
no
order
.
<EOS>
The
petition
,
which
was
said
to
fill
fifteen
cabs
,
 
though
the
absolute
sheets
of
signatures
were
carried
into
the
House
by
four
men
,
 
was
being
dragged
about
half
the
day
and
it
certainly
would
have
been
impossible
for
a
member
to
have
made
his
way
into
the
House
through
Westminster
Hall
between
the
hours
of
four
and
six
.
<EOS>
To
effect
an
entrance
at
all
they
were
obliged
to
go
round
at
the
back
of
the
Abbey
,
as
all
the
spaces
round
St.
Margaret
's
Church
and
Canning
's
monument
were
filled
with
the
crowd
.
<EOS>
Parliament
Street
was
quite
impassable
at
five
o
clock
,
and
there
was
no
traffic
across
the
bridge
from
that
hour
till
after
eight
.
<EOS>
As
the
evening
went
on
,
the
mob
extended
itself
to
Downing
Street
and
the
front
of
the
Treasury
Chambers
,
and
before
the
night
was
over
<EOS>
all
the
hoardings
round
the
new
Government
offices
had
been
pulled
down
.
<EOS>
The
windows
also
of
certain
obnoxious
members
of
Parliament
were
broken
,
when
those
obnoxious
members
lived
within
reach
.
<EOS>
One
gentleman
who
unfortunately
held
a
house
in
Richmond
Terrace
,
and
who
was
said
to
have
said
that
the
ballot
was
the
resort
of
cowards
,
fared
very
badly
;
 
for
his
windows
were
not
only
broken
,
but
his
furniture
and
mirrors
were
destroyed
by
the
stones
that
were
thrown
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
,
I
say
,
was
much
blamed
.
<EOS>
But
after
all
,
it
may
be
a
doubt
whether
the
procession
on
Wednesday
might
not
have
ended
worse
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
was
heard
to
say
afterwards
that
the
number
of
people
collected
would
have
been
much
greater
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
moved
the
second
reading
of
his
bill
,
and
made
his
speech
.
<EOS>
He
made
his
speech
with
the
knowledge
that
the
Houses
of
Parliament
were
surrounded
by
a
mob
,
and
I
think
that
the
fact
added
to
its
efficacy
.
<EOS>
It
certainly
gave
him
an
appropriate
opportunity
for
a
display
which
was
not
difficult
.
<EOS>
His
voice
faltered
on
two
or
three
occasions
,
and
faltered
through
real
feeling
;
but
this
sort
of
feeling
,
though
it
be
real
,
is
at
the
command
of
orators
on
certain
occasions
,
and
does
them
yeoman
's
service
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
was
an
old
man
,
nearly
worn
out
in
the
service
of
his
country
,
who
was
known
to
have
been
true
and
honest
,
and
to
have
loved
his
country
well
,
 
though
there
were
of
course
they
who
declared
that
his
hand
had
been
too
weak
for
power
,
and
that
his
services
had
been
naught
;
 
and
on
this
evening
his
virtues
were
remembered
.
<EOS>
Once
when
his
voice
failed
him
the
whole
House
got
up
and
cheered
.
<EOS>
The
nature
of
a
Whig
Prime
Minister
's
speech
on
such
an
occasion
will
be
understood
by
most
of
my
readers
without
further
indication
.
<EOS>
The
bill
itself
had
been
read
before
,
and
it
was
understood
that
no
objection
would
be
made
to
the
extent
of
the
changes
provided
in
it
by
the
liberal
side
of
the
House
.
<EOS>
The
opposition
coming
from
liberal
members
was
to
be
confined
to
the
subject
of
the
ballot
.
<EOS>
And
even
as
yet
it
was
not
known
whether
Mr.
Turnbull
and
his
followers
would
vote
against
the
second
reading
,
or
whether
they
would
take
what
was
given
,
and
declare
their
intention
of
obtaining
the
remainder
on
a
separate
motion
.
<EOS>
The
opposition
of
a
large
party
of
Conservatives
was
a
matter
of
certainty
;
but
to
this
party
Mr.
Mildmay
did
not
conceive
himself
bound
to
offer
so
large
an
amount
of
argument
as
he
would
have
given
<EOS>
had
there
been
at
the
moment
<EOS>
no
crowd
in
Palace
Yard
.
<EOS>
And
he
probably
felt
that
that
crowd
would
assist
him
with
his
old
Tory
enemies
.
<EOS>
When
,
in
the
last
words
of
his
speech
,
he
declared
that
under
no
circumstances
would
he
disfigure
the
close
of
his
political
career
by
voting
for
the
ballot
,
 
not
though
the
people
,
on
whose
behalf
he
had
been
fighting
battles
all
his
life
,
should
be
there
in
any
number
to
coerce
him
,
 
there
came
another
round
of
applause
from
the
opposition
benches
,
and
Mr.
Daubeny
began
to
fear
that
some
young
horses
in
his
team
might
get
loose
from
their
traces
.
<EOS>
With
great
dignity
Mr.
Daubeny
had
kept
aloof
from
Mr.
Turnbull
and
from
Mr.
Turnbull
's
tactics
;
but
he
was
not
the
less
alive
to
the
fact
that
Mr.
Turnbull
,
with
his
mob
and
his
big
petition
,
might
be
of
considerable
assistance
to
him
in
this
present
duel
between
himself
and
Mr.
Mildmay
.
<EOS>
I
think
Mr.
Daubeny
was
in
the
habit
of
looking
at
these
contests
as
duels
between
himself
and
the
leader
on
the
other
side
of
the
House
,
 
in
which
assistance
from
any
quarter
might
be
accepted
if
offered
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
's
speech
did
not
occupy
much
over
an
hour
,
and
at
half
-
past
seven
Mr.
Turnbull
got
up
to
reply
.
<EOS>
It
was
presumed
that
he
would
do
so
,
and
not
a
member
left
his
place
,
though
that
time
of
the
day
is
an
interesting
time
,
and
though
Mr.
Turnbull
was
accustomed
to
be
long
.
<EOS>
There
soon
came
to
be
but
little
ground
for
doubting
what
would
be
the
nature
of
Mr.
Turnbull
's
vote
on
the
second
reading
.
<EOS>
"
How
may
I
dare
,
"
said
he
,
"
to
accept
so
small
a
measure
of
reform
as
this
with
such
a
message
from
the
country
as
is
now
conveyed
to
me
through
the
presence
of
fifty
thousand
of
my
countrymen
,
who
are
at
this
moment
demanding
their
measure
of
reform
just
beyond
the
frail
walls
of
this
chamber
?
<EOS>
The
right
honourable
gentleman
has
told
us
that
he
will
never
be
intimidated
by
a
concourse
of
people
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
that
there
was
any
need
that
he
should
speak
of
intimidation
.
<EOS>
No
one
has
accused
the
right
honourable
gentleman
of
political
cowardice
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
he
has
so
said
,
I
will
follow
in
his
footsteps
.
<EOS>
Neither
will
I
be
intimidated
by
the
large
majority
which
this
House
presented
the
other
night
against
the
wishes
of
the
people
.
<EOS>
I
will
support
no
great
measure
of
reform
which
does
not
include
the
ballot
among
its
clauses
.
"
<EOS>
And
so
Mr.
Turnbull
threw
down
the
gauntlet
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
spoke
for
two
hours
,
and
then
the
debate
was
adjourned
till
the
Monday
.
<EOS>
The
adjournment
was
moved
by
an
independent
member
,
who
,
as
was
known
,
would
support
the
Government
,
and
at
once
received
Mr.
Turnbull
's
assent
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
great
hurry
with
the
bill
,
and
it
was
felt
that
it
would
be
well
to
let
the
ferment
subside
.
<EOS>
Enough
had
been
done
for
glory
when
Mr.
Mildmay
moved
the
second
reading
,
and
quite
enough
in
the
way
of
debate
,
 
with
such
an
audience
almost
within
hearing
,
 
when
Mr.
Turnbull
's
speech
had
been
made
.
<EOS>
Then
the
House
emptied
itself
at
once
.
<EOS>
The
elderly
,
cautious
members
made
their
exit
through
the
peers
'
door
.
<EOS>
The
younger
men
got
out
into
the
crowd
through
Westminster
Hall
,
and
were
pushed
about
among
the
roughs
for
an
hour
or
so
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
made
his
way
through
the
hall
with
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
,
found
Mr.
Turnbull
's
carriage
waiting
at
the
entrance
with
a
dozen
policemen
round
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
he
wo
n't
get
home
to
dinner
before
midnight
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
understands
all
about
it
,
"
said
Laurence
.
<EOS>
"
He
had
a
good
meal
at
three
,
before
he
left
home
,
and
you
'd
find
sandwiches
and
sherry
in
plenty
if
you
were
to
search
his
carriage
.
<EOS>
He
knows
how
to
remedy
the
costs
of
mob
popularity
.
"
  
<EOS>
At
that
time
poor
Bunce
was
being
hustled
about
in
the
crowd
in
the
vicinity
of
Mr.
Turnbull
's
carriage
.
<EOS>
Phineas
and
Fitzgibbon
made
their
way
out
,
and
by
degrees
worked
a
passage
for
themselves
into
Parliament
Street
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
had
been
somewhat
behind
them
in
coming
down
the
hall
,
and
had
not
been
without
a
sense
of
enjoyment
in
the
ovation
which
was
being
given
to
him
.
<EOS>
There
can
be
no
doubt
that
he
was
wrong
in
what
he
was
doing
.
<EOS>
That
affair
of
the
carriage
was
altogether
wrong
,
and
did
Mr.
Turnbull
much
harm
for
many
a
day
afterwards
.
<EOS>
When
he
got
outside
the
door
,
where
were
the
twelve
policemen
guarding
his
carriage
,
a
great
number
of
his
admirers
endeavoured
to
shake
hands
with
him
.
<EOS>
Among
them
was
the
devoted
Bunce
.
<EOS>
But
the
policemen
seemed
to
think
that
Mr.
Turnbull
was
to
be
guarded
,
even
from
the
affection
of
his
friends
,
and
were
as
careful
that
he
should
be
ushered
into
his
carriage
untouched
,
as
though
he
had
been
the
favourite
object
of
political
aversion
for
the
moment
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
himself
,
when
he
began
to
perceive
that
men
were
crowding
close
upon
the
gates
,
and
to
hear
the
noise
,
and
to
feel
,
as
it
were
,
the
breath
of
the
mob
,
stepped
on
quickly
into
his
carriage
.
<EOS>
He
said
a
word
or
two
in
a
loud
voice
.
"
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
my
friends
.
<EOS>
I
trust
you
may
obtain
all
your
just
demands
.
"
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
pause
to
speak
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
could
hardly
have
done
so
,
as
the
policemen
were
manifestly
in
a
hurry
.
<EOS>
The
carriage
was
got
away
at
a
snail
's
pace
;
 
but
there
remained
in
the
spot
where
the
carriage
had
stood
the
makings
of
a
very
pretty
street
row
.
  
<EOS>
Bunce
had
striven
hard
to
shake
hands
with
his
hero
,
 
Bunce
and
some
other
reformers
as
ardent
and
as
decent
as
himself
.
<EOS>
The
police
were
very
determinate
that
there
should
be
no
such
interruption
to
their
programme
for
getting
Mr.
Turnbull
off
the
scene
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bunce
,
who
had
his
own
ideas
as
to
his
right
to
shake
hands
with
any
gentleman
at
Westminster
Hall
who
might
choose
to
shake
hands
with
him
,
became
uneasy
under
the
impediments
that
were
placed
in
his
way
,
and
expressed
himself
warmly
as
to
his
civil
rights
.
<EOS>
Now
a
London
policeman
in
a
political
row
is
,
I
believe
,
the
most
forbearing
of
men
.
<EOS>
So
long
as
he
meets
with
no
special
political
opposition
,
ordinary
ill
-
usage
does
not
even
put
him
out
of
temper
.
<EOS>
He
is
paid
for
rough
work
among
roughs
,
and
takes
his
rubs
gallantly
.
<EOS>
But
he
feels
himself
to
be
an
instrument
for
the
moment
of
despotic
power
as
opposed
to
civil
rights
,
and
he
wo
n't
stand
what
he
calls
"
jaw
.
<EOS>
"
Trip
up
a
policeman
in
such
a
scramble
,
and
he
will
take
it
in
good
spirit
;
but
mention
the
words
"
Habeas
Corpus
,
"
and
he
'll
lock
you
up
if
he
can
.
<EOS>
As
a
rule
,
his
instincts
are
right
;
for
the
man
who
talks
about
"
Habeas
Corpus
"
in
a
political
crowd
will
generally
do
more
harm
than
can
be
effected
by
the
tripping
up
of
any
constable
.
<EOS>
But
these
instincts
may
be
the
means
of
individual
injustice
.
<EOS>
I
think
they
were
so
when
Mr.
Bunce
was
arrested
and
kept
a
fast
prisoner
.
<EOS>
His
wife
had
shown
her
knowledge
of
his
character
when
she
declared
that
he
'd
be
"
took
"
if
any
one
was
"
took
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bunce
was
taken
into
custody
with
some
three
or
four
others
like
himself
,
 
decent
men
,
who
meant
no
harm
,
but
who
thought
that
as
men
they
were
bound
to
show
their
political
opinions
,
perhaps
at
the
expense
of
a
little
martyrdom
,
 
and
was
carried
into
a
temporary
stronghold
,
which
had
been
provided
for
the
necessities
of
the
police
,
under
the
clock
-
tower
.
  
<EOS>
"
Keep
me
,
at
your
peril
!
"
said
Bunce
,
indignantly
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
means
it
,
"
said
the
sergeant
who
had
him
in
custody
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
done
no
ha'porth
to
break
the
law
,
"
said
Bunce
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
was
breaking
the
law
when
you
was
upsetting
my
men
,
as
I
saw
you
,
"
said
the
sergeant
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
upset
nobody
,
"
said
Bunce
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
rejoined
the
sergeant
;
"
you
can
say
it
all
before
the
magistrate
,
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
am
I
to
be
locked
up
all
night
?
"
said
Bunce
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
afraid
you
will
,
"
replied
the
sergeant
.
  
<EOS>
Bunce
,
who
was
not
by
nature
a
very
talkative
man
,
said
no
more
;
but
he
swore
in
his
heart
that
there
should
be
vengeance
.
<EOS>
Between
eleven
and
twelve
he
was
taken
to
the
regular
police
-
station
,
and
from
thence
he
was
enabled
to
send
word
to
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bunce
has
been
taken
,
"
said
she
,
with
something
of
the
tragic
queen
,
and
something
also
of
the
injured
wife
in
the
tone
of
her
voice
,
as
soon
as
Phineas
let
himself
in
with
the
latchkey
between
twelve
and
one
.
<EOS>
And
then
,
mingled
with
,
and
at
last
dominant
over
,
those
severer
tones
,
came
the
voice
of
the
loving
woman
whose
beloved
one
was
in
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
how
it
'd
be
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
Did
n't
I
?
<EOS>
And
what
must
we
do
?
<EOS>
I
do
n't
suppose
he
'd
had
a
bit
to
eat
from
the
moment
he
went
out
;
 
and
as
for
a
drop
of
beer
,
he
never
thinks
of
it
,
except
what
I
puts
down
for
him
at
his
meals
.
<EOS>
Them
nasty
police
always
take
the
best
.
<EOS>
That
's
why
I
was
so
afeard
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
said
all
that
he
could
to
comfort
her
,
and
promised
to
go
to
the
police
-
office
early
in
the
morning
and
look
after
Bunce
.
<EOS>
No
serious
evil
would
,
he
thought
,
probably
come
of
it
;
but
still
Bunce
had
been
wrong
to
go
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
might
have
been
took
yourself
,
"
argued
Mrs.
Bunce
,
"
just
as
well
as
he
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
explained
that
he
had
gone
forth
in
the
execution
of
a
public
duty
.
<EOS>
"
You
might
have
been
took
,
all
the
same
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bunce
,
"
for
I
'm
sure
Bunce
did
n't
do
nothing
amiss
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
First
Speech
"
 
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
,
which
was
Saturday
,
Phineas
was
early
at
the
police
-
office
at
Westminster
looking
after
the
interests
of
his
landlord
;
but
there
had
been
a
considerable
number
of
men
taken
up
during
the
row
,
and
our
friend
could
hardly
procure
that
attention
for
Mr.
Bunce
's
case
to
which
he
thought
the
decency
of
his
client
and
his
own
position
as
a
member
of
Parliament
were
entitled
.
<EOS>
The
men
who
had
been
taken
up
were
taken
in
batches
before
the
magistrates
;
but
as
the
soldiers
in
the
park
had
been
maltreated
,
and
a
considerable
injury
had
been
done
in
the
neighbourhood
of
Downing
Street
,
there
was
a
good
deal
of
strong
feeling
against
the
mob
,
and
the
magistrates
were
disposed
to
be
severe
.
<EOS>
If
decent
men
chose
to
go
out
among
such
companions
,
and
thereby
get
into
trouble
,
decent
men
must
take
the
consequences
.
<EOS>
During
the
Saturday
and
Sunday
a
very
strong
feeling
grew
up
against
Mr.
Turnbull
.
<EOS>
The
story
of
the
carriage
was
told
,
and
he
was
declared
to
be
a
turbulent
demagogue
,
only
desirous
of
getting
popularity
.
<EOS>
And
together
with
this
feeling
there
arose
a
general
verdict
of
"
Serve
them
right
"
against
all
who
had
come
into
contact
with
the
police
in
the
great
Turnbull
row
;
and
thus
it
came
to
pass
that
Mr.
Bunce
had
not
been
liberated
up
to
the
Monday
morning
.
<EOS>
On
the
Sunday
Mrs.
Bunce
was
in
hysterics
,
and
declared
her
conviction
that
Mr.
Bunce
would
be
imprisoned
for
life
.
<EOS>
Poor
Phineas
had
an
unquiet
time
with
her
on
the
morning
of
that
day
.
<EOS>
In
every
ecstasy
of
her
grief
she
threw
herself
into
his
arms
,
either
metaphorically
or
materially
,
according
to
the
excess
of
her
agony
at
the
moment
,
and
expressed
repeatedly
an
assured
conviction
that
all
her
children
would
die
of
starvation
,
and
that
she
herself
would
be
picked
up
under
the
arches
of
one
of
the
bridges
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
was
soft
-
hearted
,
did
what
he
could
to
comfort
her
,
and
allowed
himself
to
be
worked
up
to
strong
parliamentary
anger
against
the
magistrates
and
police
.
<EOS>
"
When
they
think
that
they
have
public
opinion
on
their
side
,
there
is
nothing
in
the
way
or
arbitrary
excess
which
is
too
great
for
them
.
<EOS>
"
This
he
said
to
Barrington
Erle
,
who
angered
him
and
increased
the
warmth
of
his
feeling
by
declaring
that
a
little
close
confinement
would
be
good
for
the
Bunces
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
"
If
we
do
n't
keep
the
mob
down
,
the
mob
will
keep
us
down
,
"
said
the
Whig
private
secretary
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
no
opportunity
of
answering
this
,
but
declared
to
himself
that
Barrington
Erle
was
no
more
a
Liberal
at
heart
than
was
Mr.
Daubeny
.
<EOS>
"
He
was
born
on
that
side
of
the
question
,
and
has
been
receiving
Whig
wages
all
his
life
.
<EOS>
That
is
the
history
of
his
politics
!
"
  
<EOS>
On
the
Sunday
afternoon
Phineas
went
to
Lord
Brentford
's
in
Portman
Square
,
intending
to
say
a
word
or
two
about
Lord
Chiltern
,
and
meaning
also
to
induce
,
if
possible
,
the
Cabinet
Minister
to
take
part
with
him
against
the
magistrates
,
 
having
a
hope
also
,
in
which
he
was
not
disappointed
,
that
he
might
find
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
with
her
father
.
<EOS>
He
had
come
to
understand
that
Lady
Laura
was
not
to
be
visited
at
her
own
house
on
Sundays
.
<EOS>
So
much
indeed
she
had
told
him
in
so
many
words
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
come
to
understand
also
,
without
any
plain
telling
,
that
she
rebelled
in
heart
against
this
Sabbath
tyranny
,
 
and
that
she
would
escape
from
it
when
escape
was
possible
.
<EOS>
She
had
now
come
to
talk
to
her
father
about
her
brother
,
and
had
brought
Violet
Effingham
with
her
.
<EOS>
They
had
walked
together
across
the
park
after
church
,
and
intended
to
walk
back
again
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
did
not
like
to
have
any
carriage
out
on
a
Sunday
,
and
to
this
arrangement
his
wife
made
no
objection
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
had
received
a
letter
from
the
Stamford
surgeon
,
and
was
able
to
report
favourably
of
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
The
man
says
that
he
had
better
not
be
moved
for
a
month
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
that
means
nothing
.
<EOS>
They
always
say
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Will
it
not
be
best
for
him
to
remain
where
he
is
?
"
said
the
Earl
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
not
a
soul
to
speak
to
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
were
with
him
,
"
said
his
sister
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
,
of
course
,
out
of
the
question
,
"
said
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
They
know
him
at
that
inn
,
and
it
really
seems
to
me
best
that
he
should
stay
there
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
he
would
be
so
much
at
his
ease
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
dreadful
for
a
man
to
be
confined
to
his
room
without
a
creature
near
him
,
except
the
servants
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
frowned
,
but
said
nothing
further
.
<EOS>
They
all
perceived
that
as
soon
as
he
had
learned
that
there
was
no
real
danger
as
to
his
son
's
life
,
he
was
determined
that
this
accident
should
not
work
him
up
to
any
show
of
tenderness
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
so
hope
he
will
come
up
to
London
,
"
continued
Violet
,
who
was
not
afraid
of
the
Earl
,
and
was
determined
not
to
be
put
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
what
you
are
talking
about
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Lord
Brentford
.
  
<EOS>
After
this
Phineas
found
it
very
difficult
to
extract
any
sympathy
from
the
Earl
on
behalf
of
the
men
who
had
been
locked
up
.
<EOS>
He
was
moody
and
cross
,
and
could
not
be
induced
to
talk
on
the
great
subject
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
declared
that
she
did
not
care
how
many
Bunces
were
locked
up
;
nor
for
how
long
,
 
adding
,
however
,
a
wish
that
Mr.
Turnbull
himself
had
been
among
the
number
of
the
prisoners
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
was
somewhat
softer
than
this
,
and
consented
to
express
pity
in
the
case
of
Mr.
Bunce
himself
;
but
Phineas
perceived
that
the
pity
was
awarded
to
him
and
not
to
the
sufferer
.
<EOS>
The
feeling
against
Mr.
Turnbull
was
at
the
present
moment
so
strong
among
all
the
upper
classes
,
that
Mr.
Bunce
and
his
brethren
might
have
been
kept
in
durance
for
a
week
without
commiseration
from
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
hard
certainly
on
a
man
like
Mr.
Bunce
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
did
not
Mr.
Bunce
stay
at
home
and
mind
his
business
?
"
said
the
Earl
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
spent
the
remainder
of
that
day
alone
,
and
came
to
a
resolution
that
on
the
coming
occasion
he
certainly
would
speak
in
the
House
.
<EOS>
The
debate
would
be
resumed
on
the
Monday
,
and
he
would
rise
to
his
legs
on
the
very
first
moment
that
it
became
possible
for
him
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
And
he
would
do
nothing
towards
preparing
a
speech
;
 
<EOS>
nothing
whatever
.
<EOS>
On
this
occasion
he
would
trust
entirely
to
such
words
as
might
come
to
him
at
the
moment
;
 
ay
,
and
to
such
thoughts
.
<EOS>
He
had
before
burdened
his
memory
with
preparations
,
and
the
very
weight
of
the
burden
had
been
too
much
for
his
mind
.
<EOS>
He
had
feared
to
trust
himself
to
speak
,
because
he
had
felt
that
he
was
not
capable
of
performing
the
double
labour
of
saying
his
lesson
by
heart
,
and
of
facing
the
House
for
the
first
time
.
<EOS>
There
should
be
nothing
now
for
him
to
remember
.
<EOS>
His
thoughts
were
full
of
his
subject
.
<EOS>
He
would
support
Mr.
Mildmay
's
bill
with
all
his
eloquence
,
but
he
would
implore
Mr.
Mildmay
,
and
the
Home
Secretary
,
and
the
Government
generally
,
to
abstain
from
animosity
against
the
populace
of
London
,
because
they
desired
one
special
boon
which
Mr.
Mildmay
did
not
think
that
it
was
his
duty
to
give
them
.
<EOS>
He
hoped
that
ideas
and
words
would
come
to
him
.
<EOS>
Ideas
and
words
had
been
free
enough
with
him
in
the
old
days
of
the
Dublin
debating
society
.
<EOS>
If
they
failed
him
now
,
he
must
give
the
thing
up
,
and
go
back
to
Mr.
Low
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
Monday
morning
Phineas
was
for
two
hours
at
the
police
-
court
in
Westminster
,
and
at
about
one
on
that
day
Mr.
Bunce
was
liberated
.
<EOS>
When
he
was
brought
up
before
the
magistrate
,
Mr.
Bunce
spoke
his
mind
very
freely
as
to
the
usage
he
had
received
,
and
declared
his
intention
of
bringing
an
action
against
the
sergeant
who
had
detained
him
.
<EOS>
The
magistrate
,
of
course
,
took
the
part
of
the
police
,
and
declared
that
,
from
the
evidence
of
two
men
who
were
examined
,
Bunce
had
certainly
used
such
violence
in
the
crowd
as
had
justified
his
arrest
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
used
no
violence
,
"
said
Bunce
.
  
<EOS>
"
According
to
your
own
showing
,
you
endeavoured
to
make
your
way
up
to
Mr.
Turnbull
's
carriage
,
"
said
the
magistrate
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
close
to
the
carriage
before
the
police
even
saw
me
,
"
said
Bunce
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
tried
to
force
your
way
round
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
used
no
force
till
a
man
had
me
by
the
collar
to
push
me
back
;
and
I
was
n't
violent
,
not
then
.
<EOS>
I
told
him
I
was
doing
what
I
had
a
right
to
do
,
 
and
<EOS>
it
was
that
as
made
him
hang
on
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
not
doing
what
you
had
a
right
to
do
.
<EOS>
You
were
assisting
to
create
a
riot
,
"
said
the
magistrate
,
with
that
indignation
which
a
London
magistrate
should
always
know
how
to
affect
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
however
,
was
allowed
to
give
evidence
as
to
his
landlord
's
character
,
and
then
Bunce
was
liberated
.
<EOS>
But
before
he
went
he
again
swore
that
that
should
not
be
the
last
of
it
,
and
he
told
the
magistrate
that
he
had
been
ill
-
used
.
<EOS>
When
liberated
,
he
was
joined
by
a
dozen
sympathising
friends
,
who
escorted
him
home
,
and
among
them
were
one
or
two
literary
gentlemen
,
employed
on
those
excellent
penny
papers
,
the
_
People
's
Banner
_
and
the
_
Ballot
-
box
_
.
<EOS>
It
was
their
intention
that
Mr.
Bunce
's
case
should
not
be
allowed
to
sleep
.
<EOS>
One
of
these
gentlemen
made
a
distinct
offer
to
Phineas
Finn
of
unbounded
popularity
during
life
and
of
immortality
afterwards
,
if
he
,
as
a
member
of
Parliament
,
would
take
up
Bunce
's
case
with
vigour
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
not
quite
understanding
the
nature
of
the
offer
,
and
not
as
yet
knowing
the
profession
of
the
gentleman
,
gave
some
general
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
come
out
strong
,
Mr.
Finn
,
and
we
'll
see
that
you
are
properly
reported
.
<EOS>
I
'm
on
the
_
Banner
_
,
sir
,
and
I
'll
answer
for
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
had
been
somewhat
eager
in
expressing
his
sympathy
with
Bunce
,
and
had
not
given
very
close
attention
to
the
gentleman
who
was
addressing
him
,
was
still
in
the
dark
.
<EOS>
The
nature
of
the
_
Banner
_
,
which
the
gentleman
was
on
,
did
not
at
once
come
home
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Something
ought
to
be
done
,
certainly
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
take
it
up
strong
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
"
and
we
shall
be
happy
to
have
you
among
us
.
<EOS>
You
'll
find
,
Mr.
Finn
,
that
in
public
life
there
's
nothing
like
having
a
horgan
to
back
you
.
<EOS>
What
is
the
most
you
can
do
in
the
'
ouse
?
<EOS>
Nothing
,
if
you
're
not
reported
.
<EOS>
You
're
speaking
to
the
country
;
 
ai
n't
you
?
<EOS>
And
you
ca
n't
do
that
without
a
horgan
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
You
come
among
us
on
the
_
Banner
_
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
do
better
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
understood
the
nature
of
the
offer
made
to
him
.
<EOS>
As
they
parted
,
the
literary
gentleman
gave
our
hero
his
card
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
much
was
printed
.
<EOS>
Then
,
on
the
corner
of
the
card
was
written
,
"
_
Banner
_
Office
,
137
,
Fetter
Lane
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
was
a
young
man
,
under
thirty
,
not
remarkable
for
clean
linen
,
and
who
always
talked
of
the
"
'
ouse
.
<EOS>
"
But
he
was
a
well
-
known
and
not
undistinguished
member
of
a
powerful
class
of
men
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
a
reporter
,
and
as
such
knew
the
"
'
ouse
"
well
,
and
was
a
writer
for
the
press
.
<EOS>
And
,
though
he
talked
of
"
'
Ouses
"
and
"
horgans
"
,
he
wrote
good
English
with
great
rapidity
,
and
was
possessed
of
that
special
sort
of
political
fervour
which
shows
itself
in
a
man
's
work
rather
than
in
his
conduct
.
<EOS>
It
was
Mr.
Slide
's
taste
to
be
an
advanced
reformer
,
and
in
all
his
operations
on
behalf
of
the
_
People
's
Banner
_
he
was
a
reformer
very
much
advanced
.
<EOS>
No
man
could
do
an
article
on
the
people
's
indefeasible
rights
with
more
pronounced
vigour
than
Mr.
Slide
.
<EOS>
But
it
had
never
occurred
to
him
as
yet
that
he
ought
to
care
for
anything
else
than
the
fight
,
 
than
the
advantage
of
having
a
good
subject
on
which
to
write
slashing
articles
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slide
was
an
energetic
but
not
a
thoughtful
man
;
but
in
his
thoughts
on
politics
,
as
far
as
they
went
with
him
,
he
regarded
the
wrongs
of
the
people
as
being
of
infinitely
greater
value
than
their
rights
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
he
was
insincere
in
all
that
he
was
daily
saying
;
 
but
simply
that
he
never
thought
about
it
.
<EOS>
Very
early
in
life
he
had
fallen
among
"
people
's
friends
,
"
and
an
opening
on
the
liberal
press
had
come
in
his
way
.
<EOS>
To
be
a
"
people
's
friend
"
suited
the
turn
of
his
ambition
,
and
he
was
a
"
people
's
friend
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
his
business
to
abuse
Government
,
and
to
express
on
all
occasions
an
opinion
that
as
a
matter
of
course
the
ruling
powers
were
the
"
people
's
enemies
.
"
<EOS>
Had
the
ruling
powers
ceased
to
be
the
"
people
's
enemies
,
"
Mr.
Slide
's
ground
would
have
been
taken
from
under
his
feet
.
<EOS>
But
such
a
catastrophe
was
out
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
That
excellent
old
arrangement
that
had
gone
on
since
demagogues
were
first
invented
was
in
full
vigour
.
<EOS>
There
were
the
ruling
powers
and
there
were
the
people
,
 
devils
on
one
side
and
angels
on
the
other
,
 
and
as
long
as
a
people
's
friend
had
a
pen
in
his
hand
<EOS>
all
was
right
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
when
he
left
the
indignant
Bunce
to
go
among
his
friends
,
walked
to
the
House
thinking
a
good
deal
of
what
Mr.
Slide
had
said
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
potted
peas
Committee
was
again
on
,
and
he
had
intended
to
be
in
the
Committee
Room
by
twelve
punctually
:
but
he
had
been
unable
to
leave
Mr.
Bunce
in
the
lurch
,
and
it
was
now
past
one
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
had
,
from
one
unfortunate
circumstance
after
another
,
failed
hitherto
in
giving
to
the
potted
peas
that
resolute
attention
which
the
subject
demanded
.
<EOS>
On
the
present
occasion
his
mind
was
full
of
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
and
the
_
People
's
Banner
_
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
was
there
not
something
in
Mr.
Slide
's
proposition
?
<EOS>
He
,
Phineas
,
had
come
into
Parliament
as
it
were
under
the
wing
of
a
Government
pack
,
and
his
friendships
,
which
had
been
very
successful
,
had
been
made
with
Ministers
,
and
with
the
friends
of
Ministers
.
<EOS>
He
had
made
up
his
mind
to
be
Whig
Ministerial
,
and
to
look
for
his
profession
in
that
line
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
specially
fortified
in
this
resolution
by
his
dislike
to
the
ballot
,
 
which
dislike
had
been
the
result
of
Mr.
Monk
's
teaching
.
<EOS>
Had
Mr.
Turnbull
become
his
friend
instead
<EOS>
,
it
may
well
be
that
he
would
have
liked
the
ballot
.
<EOS>
On
such
subjects
men
must
think
long
,
and
be
sure
that
they
have
thought
in
earnest
,
before
they
are
justified
in
saying
that
their

are
the
results
of
their
own

.
<EOS>
But
now
he
began
to
reflect
how
far

profession
would
suit
him
.
<EOS>
Would
it
be
much
to
be
a
Lord

,

the

of
Mr.
Ratler
?
<EOS>
Such
lordship
and
such

would
be
the
result
of

.
<EOS>
He
told
himself
that
he
was
at
heart

true
Liberal
.
<EOS>
Would
it
not

better
for

to

,
and
go
among

on

_

's

_
?
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
But

Violet
Effingham

_
People
's

_

Quintus

?
<EOS>
And

have
liked
the
_
Banner
_
<EOS>
better

Slide

the
'
ouse
.
  
<EOS>
From
the
Committee
Room
,
in
which
,
alas
!
<EOS>
he
took
no
active
part
in
reference
to
the
potted
peas
,
he
went
down
to
the
House
,
and
was
present
when
the

was

.
<EOS>
Not
unnaturally
,
one
speaker
after
another
made
some
allusion
to
the
row
in

,
and
the
work
which
had
fallen
to
the
lot
of

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
had
declared
that
he

vote
against

of
Mr.
Mildmay
's

,
and
had

because

Bill
which

.
<EOS>
The

fashioned

after
this

of
Mr.
Turnbull
's
,
and
turned
again
very
much
upon
the
ballot
,
 
although
it
had

thought
that
the
late

had
settled

.
<EOS>
One
or
two
of
Mr.
Turnbull
's

declared
that
they
also
would
vote
against
the
bill
,
 
of
course
,
as
not
going
far
enough
;
and
one
or
two
gentlemen
from
the
Conservative

extended
a
spoken

to

new

.
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Palliser
got
up
and
addressed
the
House
for
an

,
struggling
hard
to
bring
back
the
real

,
and
to
make

House
understand
that
the
ballot
,
whether
good

,
had
been
knocked
on

head
,
and
that
members
had
no

at
the
present

to
consider
anything
but

or

of
so
much
Reform
as
Mr.
Mildmay
presented
to

in

present

.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
was
determined
to
speak
,
and
to
speak
on
this
evening
if
he
could
catch
the
Speaker
's
eye
.
<EOS>
Again
the
scene
before
him
was
going
round
before
him
;
again
things
became
dim
,
and
again
he
felt
his
blood
beating
hard
at
his
heart
.
<EOS>
But
things
were
not
so
bad
with
him
as
they
had
been
before
,
because
he
had
nothing
to
remember
.
<EOS>
He
hardly
knew
,
indeed
,
what
he
intended
to
say
.
<EOS>
He
had
an
idea
that
he
was
desirous
of
joining
in
earnest
support
of
the
measure
,
with
a
vehement
protest
against
the
injustice
which
had
been

to

,
and
to
Mr.
Bunce
in

.
<EOS>
He
had
firmly
resolved
that
no

with

Government
should
induce
him
to
hold
his

as
to

.
<EOS>
Sooner
than
do
<EOS>
so
he
would
certainly
"
go
among
them
"
at
the
_
Banner
_
office
.
  
<EOS>
He
started
up
,
wildly
,
when
Mr.
Palliser
had
completed

speech
;
but
the
Speaker
's
eye
,
not
unnaturally
,
had
travelled
to
the
other
side
of
the
House
,
and
there
was
a
Tory
of
the
old
school
upon
his
legs
,
 
Mr.
Western
,
the
member
for
East
Barsetshire
,
one

gallant
few
who
dared
to
vote
against
Sir
Robert
Peel
's
bill
for

the

Laws
in

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Western
spoke
with
a
slow
,
ponderous
,
unimpressive
,
but
very
audible

,
for
some

,
disdaining
to

to
Mr.
Turnbull
and
his

,
but
pleading
against
any
Reform
,
with
all

old
arguments
.
<EOS>
Phineas
did
not
hear
a
word
that
he
said
;
 
did
not
attempt
to
hear
.
<EOS>
He
was
keen
in
his
resolution
to
make
another
attempt
at
the
Speaker
's
eye
,
and
at
the
present
moment
was
thinking
of
that
,
and
of
that
only
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
even
give
himself
a
moment
's
reflection
as
to
what
his
own
speech
should
be
.
<EOS>
He
would
dash
at
it
and
take
his
chance
,
resolved
that
at
least
he
would
not
fail
in
courage
.
<EOS>
Twice
he
was
on
his
legs
before
Mr.
Western
had
finished
his
slow
harangue
,
and
twice
he
was
compelled
to
reseat
himself
,
 
thinking
that
he
had
subjected
himself
to
ridicule
.
<EOS>
At
last
the
member
for
East
Barset
sat
down
,
and
Phineas
was
conscious
that
he
had
lost
a
moment
or
two
in
presenting
himself
again
to
the
Speaker
.
  
<EOS>
He
held
his
ground
,
however
,
though
he
saw
that
he
had
various
rivals
for
the
right
of
speech
.
<EOS>
He
held
his
ground
,
and
was
instantly
aware
that
he
had
gained
his
point
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
slight
pause
,
and
as
some
other
urgent
member
did
not
reseat
himself
,
Phineas
heard
the
president
of
that
august
assembly
call
upon
himself
to
address
the
House
.
<EOS>
The
thing
was
now
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
There
he
was
with
the
House
of
Commons
at
his
feet
,
 
a
crowded
House
,
bound
to
be
his
auditors
as
long
as
he
should
think
fit
to
address
them
,
and
reporters
by
tens
and
twenties
in
the
gallery
ready
and
eager
to
let
the
country
know
what
the
young
member
for
Loughshane
would
say
in
this
his
maiden
speech
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
had
sundry
gifts
,
a
powerful
and
pleasant
voice
,
which
he
had
learned
to
modulate
,
a
handsome
presence
,
and
a
certain
natural
mixture
of
modesty
and
self
-
reliance
,
which
would
certainly
protect
him
from
the
faults
of
arrogance
and
pomposity
,
and
which
,
perhaps
,
might
carry
him
through
the
perils
of
his
new
position
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
also
the
great
advantage
of
friends
in
the
House
who
were
anxious
that
he
should
do
well
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
not
that
gift
of
slow
blood
which
on
the
former
occasion
would
have
enabled
him
to
remember
his
prepared
speech
,
and
which
would
now
have
placed
all
his
own
resources
within
his
own
reach
.
<EOS>
He
began
with
the
expression
of
an
opinion
that
every
true
reformer
ought
to
accept
Mr.
Mildmay
's
bill
,
even
if
it
were
accepted
only
as
an
instalment
,
 
but
before
he
had
got
through
these
sentences
,
he
became
painfully
conscious
that
he
was
repeating
his
own
words
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
cheered
almost
from
the
outset
,
and
yet
he
knew
as
he
went
on
that
he
was
failing
.
<EOS>
He
had
certain
arguments
at
his
fingers
'
ends
,
 
points
with
which
he
was
,
in
truth
,
so
familiar
that
he
need
hardly
have
troubled
himself
to
arrange
them
for
special
use
,
 
and
he
forgot
even
these
.
<EOS>
He
found
that
he
was
going
on
with
one
platitude
after
another
as
to
the
benefit
of
reform
,
in
a
manner
that
would
have
shamed
him
six
or
seven
years
ago
at
a
debating
club
.
<EOS>
He
pressed
on
,
fearing
that
words
would
fail
him
altogether
if
he
paused
;
 
but
he
did
in
truth
speak
very
much
too
fast
,
knocking
his
words
together
so
that
no
reporter
could
properly
catch
them
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
nothing
to
say
for
the
bill
except
what
hundreds
had
said
before
,
and
hundreds
would
say
again
.
<EOS>
Still
he
was
cheered
,
and
still
he
went
on
;
and
as
he
became
more
and
more
conscious
of
his
failure
there
grew
upon
him
the
idea
,
 
the
dangerous
hope
,
that
he
might
still
save
himself
from
ignominy
by
the
eloquence
of
his
invective
against
the
police
.
  
<EOS>
He
tried
it
,
and
succeeded
thoroughly
in
making
the
House
understand
that
he
was
very
angry
,
 
but
he
succeeded
in
nothing
else
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
catch
the
words
to
express
the
thoughts
of
his
mind
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
explain
his
idea
that
the
people
out
of
the
House
had
as
much
right
to
express
their
opinion
in
favour
of
the
ballot
as
members
in
the
House
had
to
express
theirs
against
it
;
and
that
animosity
had
been
shown
to
the
people
by
the
authorities
because
they
had
so
expressed
their
opinion
.
<EOS>
Then
he
attempted
to
tell
the
story
of
Mr.
Bunce
in
a
light
and
airy
way
,
failed
,
and
sat
down
in
the
middle
of
it
.
<EOS>
Again
he
was
cheered
by
all
around
him
,
 
cheered
as
a
new
member
is
usually
cheered
,
 
and
in
the
midst
of
the
cheer
would
have
blown
out
his
brains
<EOS>
had
there
been
a
pistol
there
ready
for
such
an
operation
.
  
<EOS>
That
hour
with
him
was
very
bad
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
know
how
to
get
up
and
go
away
,
or
how
to
keep
his
place
.
<EOS>
For
some
time
he
sat
with
his
hat
off
,
forgetful
of
his
privilege
of
wearing
it
;
and
then
put
it
on
hurriedly
,
as
though
the
fact
of
his
not
wearing
it
must
have
been
observed
by
everybody
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
at
about
two
,
the
debate
was
adjourned
,
and
then
as
he
was
slowly
leaving
the
House
,
thinking
how
he
might
creep
away
without
companionship
,
Mr.
Monk
took
him
by
the
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
to
walk
?
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
"
,
said
Phineas
;
"
I
shall
walk
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
we
may
go
together
as
far
as
Pall
Mall
.
<EOS>
Come
along
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
had
no
means
of
escape
,
and
left
the
House
hanging
on
Mr.
Monk
's
arm
,
without
a
word
.
<EOS>
Nor
did
Mr.
Monk
speak
till
they
were
out
in
Palace
Yard
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
much
amiss
,
"
said

Monk
;
"
<EOS>
but
you
'll
do
better
than
that
yet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Monk
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
I
have
made
an
ass
of
myself
so
thoroughly
,
that
there
will
at
any
rate
be
this
good
result
,
that
I
shall
never
make
an
ass
of
myself
again
after

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
I
thought
you
had
some
such
feeling
as
that
,
and
therefore
I
was
determined
to
speak
to

.
<EOS>
You
may
be
sure
,
Finn
,
that
I
do
not
care
to
flatter
you
,
and
I
think
you
ought
to
know
that
,
as
far
as
I
am
able
,
I
will
tell
you
the
truth
.
<EOS>
Your
speech
,
which
was
certainly
nothing
great
,
was
about
on
a
par
with
other
maiden
speeches
in
the
House
of
Commons
.
<EOS>
You
have
done
yourself
neither
good
nor
harm
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
it
desirable
that
you
should
.
<EOS>
My
advice
to
you
now
is
,
never
to
avoid
speaking
on
any
subject
that
interests
you
,
but
never
to
speak
for
above
three
minutes
till
you
find
yourself
as
much
at
home
on
your
legs
as
you
are
when
sitting
.
<EOS>
But
do
not
suppose
that
you
have
made
an
ass
of
yourself
,
 
that
is
,
in
any
special
degree
.
<EOS>
Now
,
good
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Phineas
Discussed
 
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
heard
two
accounts
of
her
friend
's
speech
,
 
and
both
from
men
who
had
been
present
.
<EOS>
Her
husband
was
in
his
place
,
in
accordance
with
his
constant
practice
,
and
Lord
Brentford
had
been
seated
,
perhaps
unfortunately
,
in
the
peers
'
gallery
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
think
it
was
a
failure
?
"
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
said
to
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
certainly
was
not
a
success
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
particular
about
it
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
good
deal
of
it
you
could
hardly
hear
.
"
  
<EOS>
After
that
she
got
the
morning
newspapers
,
and
turned
with
great
interest
to
the
report
.
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
had
been
,
as
it
were
,
adopted
by
her
as
her
own
political
offspring
,
 
or
at
any
rate
as
her
political
godchild
.
<EOS>
She
had
made
promises
on
his
behalf
to
various
personages
of
high
political
standing
,
 
to
her
father
,
to
Mr.
Monk
,
to
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
,
and
even
to
Mr.
Mildmay
himself
.
<EOS>
She
had
thoroughly
intended
that
Phineas
Finn
should
be
a
political
success
from
the
first
;
and
since
her
marriage
,
she
had
,
I
think
,
been
more
intent
upon
it
than
before
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
there
was
a
feeling
on
her
part
that
having
wronged
him
in
one
way
,
she
would
repay
him
in
another
.
<EOS>
She
had
become
so
eager
for
his
success
,
 
for
a
while
scorning
to
conceal
her
feeling
,
 
that
her
husband
had
unconsciously
begun
to
entertain
a
dislike
to
her
eagerness
.
<EOS>
We
know
how
quickly
women
arrive
at
an
understanding
of
the
feelings
of
those
with
whom
they
live
;
and
now
,
on
that
very
occasion
,
Lady
Laura
perceived
that
her
husband
did
not
take
in
good
part
her
anxiety
on
behalf
of
her
friend
.
<EOS>
She
saw
that
it
was
so
as
she
turned
over
the
newspaper
looking
for
the
report
of
the
speech
.
<EOS>
It
was
given
in
six
lines
,
and
at
the
end
of
it
there
was
an
intimation
,
 
expressed
in
the
shape
of
advice
,
 
that
the
young
orator
had
better
speak
more
slowly
if
he
wished
to
be
efficacious
either
with
the
House
or
with
the
country
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
seems
to
have
been
cheered
a
good
deal
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
All
members
are
cheered
at
their
first
speech
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
no
doubt
he
'll
do
well
yet
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
likely
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
Then
he
turned
to
his
newspaper
,
and
did
not
take
his
eyes
off
it
as
long
as
his
wife
remained
with
him
.
  
<EOS>
Later
in
the
day
Lady
Laura
saw
her
father
,
and
Miss
Effingham
was
with
her
at
the
time
.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
said
something
which
indicated
that
he
had
heard
the
debate
on
the
previous
evening
,
and
Lady
Laura
instantly
began
to
ask
him
about
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
less
said
the
better
,
"
was
the
Earl
's
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
that
it
was
so
bad
as
that
?
"
asked
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
very
bad
at
first
;
 
though
indeed
nobody
could
say
it
was
very
good
.
<EOS>
But
he
got
himself
into
a
mess
about
the
police
and
the
magistrates
before
he
had
done
,
and
nothing
but
the
kindly
feeling
always
shown
to
a
first
effort
saved
him
from
being
coughed
down
.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
had
not
a
word
more
to
say
about
Phineas
to
her
father
;
but
,
womanlike
,
she
resolved
that
she
would
not
abandon
him
.
<EOS>
How
many
first
failures
in
the
world
had
been
the
precursors
of
ultimate
success
!
"
<EOS>
Mildmay
will
lose
his
bill
,
"
said
the
Earl
,
sorrowfully
.
<EOS>
"
There
does
not
seem
to
be
a
doubt
about
that
.
"
  
"
And
what
will
you
all
do
?
"
asked
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
must
go
to
the
country
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
the
Earl
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
use
?
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
have
a
more
liberal
House
than
you
have
now
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
may
have
one
less
liberal
,
 
or
rather
less
radical
,
 
with
fewer
men
to
support
Mr.
Turnbull
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
see
what
else
we
can
do
.
<EOS>
They
say
that
there
are
no
less
than
twenty
-
seven
men
on
our
side
of
the
House
who
will
either
vote
with
Turnbull
against
us
,
or
will
decline
to
vote
at
all
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Every
one
of
them
ought
to
lose
his
seat
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
what
can
we
do
?
<EOS>
How
is
the
Queen
's
Government
to
be
carried
on
?
<EOS>
"
We
all
know
the
sad
earnestness
which
impressed
itself
on
the
Earl
's
brow
as
he
asked
these
momentous
questions
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
suppose
that
Mr.
Turnbull
can
form
a
Ministry
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
With
Mr.
Daubeny
as
whipper
-
in
,
perhaps
he
might
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
will
Mr.
Finn
lose
his
seat
?
"
asked
Violet
Effingham
.
"
<EOS>
Most
probably
,
"
said
the
Earl
.
"
<EOS>
He
only
got
it
by
an

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
find
him
a
seat
somewhere
in
England
,
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
might
be
difficult
,
"
said
the
Earl
,
who
then
left
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
The
two
women
remained
together
for
some
quarter
of
an
hour
before
they
spoke
again
.
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Laura
said
something
about
her
brother
.
<EOS>
"
If
there
be
a
dissolution
,
I
hope
Oswald
will
stand
for
Loughton
.
<EOS>
"
Loughton
was
a
borough
close
to
Saulsby
,
in
which
,
as
regarded
its
political
interests
,
Lord
Brentford
was
supposed
to
have
considerable
influence
.
<EOS>
To
this
Violet
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
quite
time
,
"
continued
Lady
Laura
,
"
that
old
Mr.
Standish
should
give
way
.
<EOS>
He
has
had
the
seat
for
twenty
-
five
years
,
and
has
never
done
anything
,
and
he
seldom
goes
to
the
House
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
not
your
uncle
,
is
he
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
he
is
papa
's
cousin
;
but
he
is
ever
so
much
older
than
papa
;
 
nearly
eighty
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Would
not
that
be
just
the
place
for
Mr.
Finn
?
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Laura
became
very
serious
.
<EOS>
"
Oswald
would
of
course
have
a
better
right
to
it
than
anybody
else
.
"
  
"
But
would
Lord
Chiltern
go
into
Parliament
?
<EOS>
I
have
heard
him
declare
that
he
would
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
we
could
get
papa
to
ask
him
,
I
think
he
would
change
his
mind
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
again
silence
for
a
few
moments
,
after
which
Violet
returned
to
the
original
subject
of
their
conversation
.
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
a
thousand
pities
that
Mr.
Finn
should
be
turned
out
into
the
cold
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
,
for
one
,
should
be
very
sorry
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
should
I
,
 
and
the
more
so
from
what
Lord
Brentford
says
about
his
not
speaking
well
last
night
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
that
it
is
very
much
of
an
accomplishment
for
a
gentleman
to
speak
well
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
,
I
suppose
,
speaks
well
;
and
they
say
that
that
horrid
man
,
Mr.
Bonteen
,
can
talk
by
the
hour
together
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
that
it
shows
a
man
to
be
clever
at
all
.
<EOS>
But
I
believe
Mr.
Finn
would
do
it
,
if
he
set
his
mind
to
it
,
and
I
shall
think
it
a
great
shame
if
they
turn
him
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
depend
very
much
,
I

,
on
Lord
Tulla
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
anything
about
Lord
Tulla
,
"
said
Violet
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
'm
quite
sure
that
he
might
have
Loughton
,
if
we

.
<EOS>
Of

Lord
Chiltern
should
have

if
he
wants

,
but
I
do
n't
think
he
will
stand
in
Mr.
Finn
's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
afraid
it
's
out
of
the
question
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
gravely
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Papa
thinks
so
much
about
the
borough
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
reader
will
remember
that
both
Lord
Brentford
and
his
daughter
were
thorough
reformers
!
<EOS>
The
use
of
a
little
borough
of
his
own
,
however
,
is
a
convenience
to
a
great
peer
.
  
<EOS>
"
Those
difficult
things
have
always
to
be
talked
of
for
a
long

,
and
then
they
become
easy
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
I
believe
if
you
were
to

Kennedy
to

to

and

,

'd

after

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

not

,
at
any

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Because
you
do
n't
want
to

to
New
Zealand
;
 
but
you
might
try
about
Loughton
for
poor
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Violet
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
after

's
pause
;
 
and
she
spoke

;
"
Violet
,
I
believe
you
are
in
love
with
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
just
like
you
,
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
made
such
an

against
you
before
,
or

anybody
else
that
I
can
remember
.
<EOS>
But
I
do
begin
to
believe
that
you
are
in
love

Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
n't
I
be
in
love
with

,
if
I
like
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
nothing
about

;
 
only
he
has
not
got

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
,
my

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
doubt
whether
you
have
any

for

that
he
is

with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
would
be
my

,
my

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
are
in
love
with
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
my
affair
also
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
shrugged
her
shoulders
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
is
;
and
if
you
tell
me
to
hold
my
tongue
,
of
course
I
will
do

.
<EOS>
If

whether

,

I

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
tell
you
to
hold
your

,
and
I
do
n't

you
what
you
think
about
the
match
.
<EOS>
You
are
quite

to

;
 
but
as

Mr.
Phineas
Finn
,
you
have
no

to

anything
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
talk
to
anybody
but
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
growing
to
be
quite
indifferent
as
to
what
people
say
.
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
asked
me
the
other
day
whether
I
was
going
to
throw
myself
away
on
Mr.
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
she
did
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
did
you
answer
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
told
her
that
it
was
not
quite
settled
;
but
that
as
I
had
only
spoken
to
him
once
during
the
last
two
years
,
and
then
for
not
more
than
half
a

,
and
as
I
was
n't
sure
whether
I
knew
him
by
sight
,
and
as
I
had
reason
to
suppose
he
did
n't
know
my
name
,
there
might
,
perhaps
,
be
a
delay
of
a
week
or
two
before
the
thing
came
off
.
<EOS>
Then
she
flounced
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
what
made
her
ask
about
Mr.
Fitzgibbon
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Somebody
had
been
hoaxing
her
.
<EOS>
I
am
beginning
to
think
that
Augusta
does
it
for
her
private
amusement
.
<EOS>
If
so
,
I
shall
think
more
highly
of
my
dear
cousin
than
I
have
hitherto
done
.
<EOS>
But
,
Laura
,
as
you
have
made
a
similar
accusation
against
me
,
and
as
I
can
not
get
out
of
it
with
you
as
I
do
with
my
aunt
,
I
must
ask
you
to
hear
my
protestation
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
in
love
with
Mr.
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
Heaven
help
me
;
 
as
far
as
I
can
tell
,
I
am
not
in
love
with
any
one
,
and
never
shall
be
.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
looked
pleased
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
"
continued
Violet
,
"
that
I
think
I
could
be
in
love
with
Mr.
Phineas
Finn
,
if
I
could
be
in
love
with
anybody
?
"
Then
Lady
Laura
looked
displeased
.
<EOS>
"
In
the
first
place
,
he
is
a
gentleman
,
"
continued
Violet
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
is
a
man
of
spirit
.
<EOS>
And
then
he
has
not
too
much
spirit
;
 
not
that
kind
of
spirit
which
makes
some
men
think
that
they
are
the
finest
things
going
.
<EOS>
His
manners
are
perfect
;
 
not
Chesterfieldian
,
and
yet
never
offensive
.
<EOS>
He
never
browbeats
any
one
,
and
never
toadies
any
one
.
<EOS>
He
knows
how
to
live
easily
with
men
of
all
ranks
,
without
any
appearance
of
claiming
a
special
status
for
himself
.
<EOS>
If
he
were
made
Archbishop
of
Canterbury
to
-
morrow
,
I
believe
he
would
settle
down
into
the
place
of
the
first
subject
in
the
land
without
arrogance
,
and
without
false
shame
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
his
eulogist
with
a
vengeance
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
his
eulogist
;
but
I
am
not
in
love
with
him
.
<EOS>
If
he
were
to
ask
me
to
be
his
wife
to
-
morrow
,
I
should
be
distressed
,
and
should
refuse
him
.
<EOS>
If
he
were
to
marry
my
dearest
friend
in
the
world
,
I
should
tell
him
to
kiss
me
and
be
my
brother
.
<EOS>
As
to
Mr.
Phineas
Finn
,
 
those
are
my
sentiments
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
you
say
is
very
odd
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
odd
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Simply
because
mine
are
the
same
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
they
the
same
?
<EOS>
I
once
thought
,
Laura
,
that
you
did
love
him
;
 
that
you
meant
to
be
his
wife
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
sat
for
a
while
without
making
any
reply
to
this
.
<EOS>
She
sat
with
her
elbow
on
the
table
and
with
her
face
leaning
on
her
hand
,
 
thinking
how
far
it
would
tend
to
her
comfort
if
she
spoke
in
true
confidence
.
<EOS>
Violet
during
the
time
never
took
her
eyes
from
her
friend
's
face
,
but
remained
silent
as
though
waiting
for
an
answer
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
very
explicit
as
to
her
feelings
.
<EOS>
Would
Laura
Kennedy
be
equally
explicit
?
<EOS>
She
was
too
clever
to
forget
that
such
plainness
of
speech
would
be
,
must
be
more
difficult
to
Lady
Laura
than
to
herself
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
was
a
married
woman
;
but
she
felt
that
her
friend
would
have
been
wrong
to
search
for
secrets
,
unless
she
were
ready
to
tell
her
own
.
<EOS>
It
was
probably
some
such
feeling
which
made
Lady
Laura
speak
at
last
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I
did
,
nearly
 
"
said
Lady
Laura
;
"
very
nearly
.
<EOS>
You
told
me
just
now
that
you
had
money
,
and
could
therefore
do
as
you
pleased
.
<EOS>
I
had
no
money
,
and
could
not
do
as
I
pleased
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
told
me
also
that
I
had
no
reason
for
thinking
that
he
cared
for
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
?
<EOS>
Well
;
 
I
suppose
you
have
no
reason
.
<EOS>
He
did
care
for
me
.
<EOS>
He
did
love
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
told
you
so
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
he
told
me
so
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
did
you
answer
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
had
that
very
morning
become
engaged
to
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
That
was
my
answer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
did
he
say
when
you
told
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
remember
.
<EOS>
But
he
behaved
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
 
if
he
were
to
love
me
,
you
would
grudge
me
his
love
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
for
that
reason
,
 
not
if
I
know
myself
.
<EOS>
Oh
no
!
<EOS>
I
would
not
be
so
selfish
as
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For
what
reason
then
?
"
  
"
Because
I
look
upon
it
as
written
in
heaven
that
you
are
to
be
Oswald
's
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Heaven
's
writings
then
are
false
,
"
said
Violet
,
getting
up
and
walking
away
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
Phineas
was
very
wretched
at
home
.
<EOS>
When
he
reached
his
lodgings
after
leaving
the
House
,
 
after
his
short
conversation
with
Mr.
Monk
,
 
he
tried
to
comfort
himself
with
what
that
gentleman
had
said
to
him
.
<EOS>
For
a
while
,
while
he
was
walking
,
there
had
been
some
comfort
in
Mr.
Monk
's
words
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
had
much
experience
,
and
doubtless
knew
what
he
was
saying
,
 
and
there
might
yet
be
hope
.
<EOS>
But
all
this
hope
faded
away
when
Phineas
was
in
his
own
rooms
.
<EOS>
There
came
upon
him
,
as
he
looked
round
them
,
an
idea
that
he
had
no
business
to
be
in
Parliament
,
that
he
was
an
impostor
,
that
he
was
going
about
the
world
under
false
pretences
,
and
that
he
would
never
set
himself
aright
,
even
unto
himself
,
till
he
had
gone
through
some
terrible
act
of
humiliation
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
a
cheat
even
to
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
of
the
_
Banner
_
,
in
accepting
an
invitation
to
come
among
them
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
a
cheat
to
Lady
Laura
,
in
that
he
had
induced
her
to
think
that
he
was
fit
to
live
with
her
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
cheat
to
Violet
Effingham
,
in
assuming
that
he
was
capable
of
making
himself
agreeable
to
her
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
cheat
to
Lord
Chiltern
when
riding
his
horses
,
and
pretending
to
be
a
proper
associate
for
a
man
of
fortune
.
<EOS>
Why
,
 
what
was
his
income
?
<EOS>
What
his
birth
?
<EOS>
What
his
proper
position
?
<EOS>
And
now
he
had
got
the
reward
which
all
cheats
deserve
.
<EOS>
Then
he
went
to
bed
,
and
as
he
lay
there
,
he
thought
of
Mary
Flood
Jones
.
<EOS>
Had
he
plighted
his
troth
to
Mary
,
and
then
worked
like
a
slave
under
Mr.
Low
's
auspices
,
 
<EOS>
he
would
not
have
been
a
cheat
.
  
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
him
that
he
had
hardly
been
asleep
when
the
girl
came
into
his
room
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
she
,
"
there
's
that
gentleman
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
gentleman
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
old
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
knew
that
Mr.
Clarkson
was
in
his
sitting
-
room
,
and
that
he
would
not
leave
it
till
he
had
seen
the
owner
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
 
Phineas
was
pretty
sure
that
Mr.
Clarkson
would
come
into
the
bedroom
,
if
he
were
kept
long
waiting
.
<EOS>
"
Damn
the
old
gentleman
,
"
said
Phineas
in
his
wrath
;
 
and
the
maid
-
servant
heard
him
say
so
.
  
<EOS>
In
about
twenty
minutes
he
went
out
into
the
sitting
-
room
,
with
his
slippers
on
and
in
his
dressing
-
gown
.
<EOS>
Suffering
under
the
circumstances
of
such
an
emergency
,
how
is
any
man
to
go
through
the
work
of
dressing
and
washing
with
proper
exactness
?
<EOS>
As
to
the
prayers
which
he
said
on
that
morning
,
I
think
that
no
question
should
be
asked
.
<EOS>
He
came
out
with
a
black
cloud
on
his
brow
,
and
with
his
mind
half
made
up
to
kick
Mr.
Clarkson
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Clarkson
,
when
he
saw
him
,
moved
his
chin
round
within
his
white
cravat
,
as
was
a
custom
with
him
,
and
put
his
thumb
and
forefinger
on
his
lips
,
and
then
shook
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
bad
,
Mr.
Finn
;
very
bad
indeed
;
very
bad
,
ai
n't
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
coming
here
in
this
way
at
all
times
in
the
day
is
very
bad
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
where
would
you
have
me
go
?
<EOS>
Would
you
like
to
see
me
down
in
the
lobby
of
the
House
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
tell
you
the
truth
,
Mr.
Clarkson
,
I
do
n't
want
to
see
you
anywhere
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
;
yes
;
I
daresay
!
<EOS>
And
that
's
what
you
call
honest
,
being
a
Parliament
gent
!
<EOS>
You
had
my
money
,
and
then
you
tell
me
you
do
n't
want
to
see
me
any
more
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
had
your
money
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
let
me
tell
you
,
"
continued
Mr.
Clarkson
,
"
that
I
want
to
see
you
;
 
and
shall
go
on
seeing
you
till
the
money
is
paid
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
not
had
any
of
your
money
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Clarkson
again
twitched
his
chin
about
on
the
top
of
his
cravat
and
smiled
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
,
"
said
he
,
showing
the
bill
,
"
is
that
your
name
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
want
my
money
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
money
to
give
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
be
punctual
now
.
<EOS>
Why
ai
n't
you
punctual
?
<EOS>
I
'd
do
anything
for
you
if
you
were
punctual
.
<EOS>
I
would
indeed
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Clarkson
,
as
he
said
this
,
sat
down
in
the
chair
which
had
been
placed
for
our
hero
's
breakfast
,
and
cutting
a
slice
off
the
loaf
,
began
to
butter
it
with
great
composure
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Clarkson
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
I
can
not
ask
you
to
breakfast
here
.
<EOS>
I
am
engaged
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
just
take
a
bit
of
bread
and
butter
all
the
same
,
"
said
Clarkson
.
<EOS>
"
Where
do
you
get
your
butter
?
<EOS>
Now
I
could
tell
you
a
woman
who
'd
give
it
you
cheaper
and
a
deal
better
than
this
.
<EOS>
This
is
all
lard
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
send
her
to
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
tea
ready
,
and
therefore
Mr.
Clarkson
emptied
the
milk
into
a
cup
and
drank
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
After
this
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
I
must
beg
,
Mr.
Clarkson
,
that
you
will
never
come
to
my
room
any
more
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
be
at
home
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
lobby
of
the
House
is
the
same
thing
to
me
,
"
said
Mr.
Clarkson
.
<EOS>
"
They
know
me
there
well
.
<EOS>
I
wish
you
'd
be
punctual
,
and
then
we
'd
be
the
best
of
friends
.
<EOS>
"
After
that
Mr.
Clarkson
,
having
finished
his
bread
and
butter
,
took
his
leave
.
   
<EOS>
The
Second
Reading
Is
Carried
 
<EOS>
The
debate
on
the
bill
was
prolonged
during
the
whole
of
that
week
.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
,
who
loved
his
seat
in
the
Cabinet
and
the
glory
of
being
a
Minister
,
better
even
than
he
loved
his
borough
,
had
taken
a
gloomy
estimate
when
he
spoke
of
twenty
-
seven
defaulters
,
and
of
the
bill
as
certainly
lost
.
<EOS>
Men
who
were
better
able
than
he
to
make
estimates
,
 
the
Bonteens
and
Fitzgibbons
on
each
side
of
the
House
,
and
above
all
,
the
Ratlers
and
Robys
,
produced
lists
from
day
to
day
which
varied
now
by
three
names
in
one
direction
,
then
by
two
in
another
,
and
which
fluctuated
at
last
by
units
only
.
<EOS>
They
all
concurred
in
declaring
that
it
would
be
a
very
near
division
.
<EOS>
A
great
effort
was
made
to
close
the
debate
on
the
Friday
,
but
it
failed
,
and
the
full
tide
of
speech
was
carried
on
till
the
following
Monday
.
<EOS>
On
that
morning
Phineas
heard
Mr.
Ratler
declare
at
the
club
that
,
as
far
as
his
judgment
went
,
the
division
at
that
moment
was
a
fair
subject
for
a
bet
.
<EOS>
"
There
are
two
men
doubtful
in
the
House
,
"
said
Ratler
,
"
and
if
one
votes
on
one
side
and
one
on
the
other
,
or
if
neither
votes
at
all
,
it
will
be
a
tie
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Roby
,
however
,
the
whip
on
the
other
side
,
was
quite
sure
that
one
at
least
of
these
gentlemen
would
go
into
his
lobby
,
and
that
the
other
would
not
go
into
Mr.
Ratler
's
lobby
.
<EOS>
I
am
inclined
to
think
that
the
town
was
generally
inclined
to
put
more
confidence
in
the
accuracy
of
Mr.
Roby
than
in
that
of
Mr.
Ratler
;
and
among
betting
men
there
certainly
was
a
point
given
by
those
who
backed
the
Conservatives
.
<EOS>
The
odds
,
however
,
were
lost
,
for
on
the
division
the
numbers
in
the
two
lobbies
were
equal
,
and
the
Speaker
gave
his
casting
vote
in
favour
of
the
Government
.
<EOS>
The
bill
was
read
a
second
time
,
and
was
lost
,
as
a
matter
of
course
,
in
reference
to
any
subsequent
action
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Roby
declared
that
even
Mr.
Mildmay
could
not
go
on
with
nothing
but
the
Speaker
's
vote
to
support
him
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
had
no
doubt
felt
that

could
not
go

with
his
bill
from
the

Turnbull
had
declared

;
but
he
could
not
with

in

to
Mr.
Turnbull
's

.
  
<EOS>
During
the
week
Phineas
had
had
his
hands
sufficiently
full
.
<EOS>
Twice
he
had
gone
to
the
potted

inquiry
;
but
he
had
been
at
the
office

the
_
People
's

_
more

.
<EOS>
Bunce
had
been
very

in
his
determination
to
bring
an
action
against
the
police
for
false

,
even
though
he
spent
every

in

.
<EOS>
And
when

wife
,

,

that
bygones
might

bygones
,
reminding

that
spilt

could
not

,
he
called
her
a
mean
-
spirited
woman
.
<EOS>
Then
Mrs.
Bunce
wept
a

of

,
and
told
her
favourite

that
for

all
comfort
in
this

was
over
.
"
<EOS>
Drat
the
reformers
<EOS>
,
I
say
.
<EOS>
And
I
wish

no
Parliament
;
so

do
.
<EOS>
What

all

,

?
<EOS>
"
Phineas
by

his

in
his

spirit
,
advising

rather
to

in

,
and

the
_
Banner
_
,
 
which
would

,

,

.
<EOS>
But
Bunce
,

delighted
in

_
Banner
_
,
and
showed

Mr.
Quintus
Slide
,
would

at
law
;
 
in

resolution
Mr.
Slide
did
,
I
fear
,

him
behind

his

,

.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
went
with

to

Low
's

,
 
for

Low
had
in

law
-

's

,
 
and

.
"
<EOS>
Have

,

?
"

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

had

.
<EOS>
His

was
redress
.
<EOS>
"
In

,
"

.
<EOS>
No
;

.
<EOS>
The
redress
wanted
was

to

.
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"

.
<EOS>
No
;

,

.
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

;
"

,

"
  
<EOS>

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

;

,

,

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Thank

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Maybe

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

;
 
"
looking

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
If

,

;

"
  
"
There
ai

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
  
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
When

.
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
And

!
<EOS>
It
has
always
been
the
same
way
with
'em
.
<EOS>
If

man
shows
a
spark

public

,
it
's
all
hambition
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't

no

.
<EOS>
I

bread
peaceable
,
and
to

when
I
'm
about

.
<EOS>
I
pays
rates
for

,

haul

for
days

,
who

has

.
"
<EOS>
After

,

went
to

,
to

business
at

's

,
and

visited

_

's

_
.
<EOS>
There

about

's

,
for

in

.
<EOS>
After

,

_
People
's

_

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slide
,

,

_

_

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

;

,

.
<EOS>
"
We

,

,
"

<EOS>

Finn

_

_
Office
.
<EOS>
Phineas
stoutly

,
 
and
was

in

_

_
.
<EOS>
This

,

,

about

.
<EOS>
A

is

now

,

.
<EOS>
Get

,

,

_
People
's
Banners
<EOS>
_

,

.
<EOS>
Phineas

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

Slide

"

"

,

.
<EOS>

,

'

.
<EOS>

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>

,
 
that

"
undred

.

<EOS>

,

,

.

;

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Would

,

,

,

Slide
?
  
<EOS>
On
the
last

of
the
debate
,
at
a
few

before
four

,
Phineas
encountered
another

.
<EOS>
He
had
been
at
the
potted
peas
since

,
and
had
on
this

targed
two

three

very

with
questions
respecting

and

,
and
had

did
not

while

men
had

.
<EOS>
I

had
been

up
to
this

by
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
,
and
that

made

.
<EOS>
There
was
,
however
,
so
much
nastiness
of
the
kind
going
,
that
his
little
effort
made
no
great
difference
.
<EOS>
The
conservative
members
of
the
Committee
,
on
whose

House
the

had

,
did

all

to

whom
,

themselves
in

,
they

be
bound

and
would
support
with

.
<EOS>
About
a

four
the

of

Committee
had

last
witness
for
the
day
,
being

of
not

their
chance
of
seats
on
so

,
and
hurried
down

,
 
so
that
they
might
enter

House
before

.
<EOS>
Phineas
here
was
button
-
holed
by
Barrington
Erle
,
who
said
something
to
him
as
to
the
approaching
division
.
<EOS>
They
were
standing
in
front
of
the
door
of
the
House
,
almost
in
the
middle

the

,
with

around

,
 
on
a
spot
which
,
as
frequenters
know
,
is
hallowed
ground
,
and
must
not
be
trodden
by

.
<EOS>
He
was
in
the
act
of
answering
Erle
,
when
he
was
touched
on
the
arm
,
and
on

,
saw
Mr.
Clarkson
.
<EOS>
"
About
that
little
bill
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
said
the
horrible
man
,
turning
his
chin
round
over

.
<EOS>
"
They
always
tell
me
at
your
lodgings
that
you
ai
n't
at
home
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
this
time
a

was
explaining
to
Mr.
Clarkson
with
gentle
violence
that
he
must
not
stand
there
,
 
that
he
must
go
aside
into
one

the

.
<EOS>
"
I
know
all
that
,
"
said
Mr.
Clarkson
,

.
<EOS>
"
Of

do
.
<EOS>
But
what
is

man
to
do
when
a
gent
wo
n't
see
him
at
home
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Clarkson
stood
aside
in
his
corner
quietly
,
giving
the

no
occasion
for
further
action
against

;
but
in

he
spoke
loud
,
and
there
was
a
lull
of
voices
around
,
and
twenty
members
at
least
had
heard
what
had
been
said
.
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
no
doubt
had
his
privilege
,
but
Mr.
Clarkson
was
determined
that
the
privilege
should
avail
him
as
little
as
possible
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
very
hard
.
<EOS>
The
real
offender
,
the
Lord
of
the
Treasury
,
the
peer
's
son
,
with
a
thousand
a
year
paid
by
the
country
was
not
treated
with
this
cruel
persecution
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
in
truth
never
taken
a
farthing
from
any
one
but
his
father
;
and
though
doubtless
he
owed
something
at
this
moment
,
he
had
no
creditor
of
his
own
that
was
even
angry
with
him
.
<EOS>
As
the
world
goes
he
was
a
clear
man
,
 
but
for
this
debt
of
his
friend
Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
He
left
Barrington
Erle
in
the
lobby
,
and
hurried
into
the
House
,
blushing
up
to
the
eyes
.
<EOS>
He
looked
for
Fitzgibbon
in
his
place
,
but
the
Lord
of
the
Treasury
was
not
as
yet
there
.
<EOS>
Doubtless
he
would
be
there
for
the
division
,
and
Phineas
resolved
that
he
would
speak
a
bit
of
his
mind
before
he
let
his
friend
out
of
his
sight
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
some
great
speeches
made
on
that
evening
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
delivered
an
oration
of
which
men
said
that
it
would
be
known
in
England
as
long
as
there
were
any
words
remaining
of
English
eloquence
.
<EOS>
In
it
he
taunted
Mr.
Turnbull
with
being
a
recreant
to
the
people
,
of
whom
he
called
himself
so
often
the
champion
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Turnbull
was
not
in
the
least
moved
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
knew
well
enough
that
Mr.
Turnbull
was
not
to
be
moved
by
any
words
;
 
but
the
words
were
not
the
less
telling
to
the
House
and
to
the
country
.
<EOS>
Men
,
who
heard
it
,
said
that
Mr.
Gresham
forgot
himself
in
that
speech
,
forgot
his
party
,
forgot
his
strategy
,
forgot
his
long
-
drawn
schemes
,
 
even
his
love
of
applause
,
and
thought
only
of
his
cause
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Daubeny
replied
to
him
with
equal
genius
,
and
with
equal
skill
,
 
if
not
with
equal
heart
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
had
asked
for
the
approbation
of
all
present
and
of
all
future
reformers
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Daubeny
denied
him
both
,
 
the
one
because
he
would
not
succeed
,
and
the
other
because
he
would
not
have
deserved
success
.
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Mildmay
made
his
reply
,
getting
up
at
about
three
o'clock
,
and
uttered
a
prayer
,
 
a
futile
prayer
,
 
that
this
his
last
work
on
behalf
of
his
countrymen
might
be
successful
.
<EOS>
His
bill
was
read
a
second
time
,
as
I
have
said
before
,
in
obedience
to
the
casting
vote
of
the
Speaker
,
 
but
a
majority
such
as
that
was
tantamount
to
a
defeat
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
,
of
course
,
on
that
night
no
declaration
as
to
what
ministers
would
do
.
<EOS>
Without
a
meeting
of
the
Cabinet
,
and
without
some
further
consideration
,
though
each
might
know
that
the
bill
would
be
withdrawn
,
they
could
not
say
in
what
way
they
would
act
.
<EOS>
But
late
as
was
the
hour
,
there
were
many
words
on
the
subject
before
members
were
in
their
beds
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
and
Mr.
Monk
left
the
House
together
,
and
perhaps
no
two
gentlemen
in
it
had
in
former
sessions
been
more
in
the
habit
of
walking
home
arm
-
in
-
arm
and
discussing
what
each
had
heard
and
what
each
had
said
in
that
assembly
.
<EOS>
Latterly
these
two
men
had
gone
strangely
asunder
in
their
paths
,
 
very
strangely
for
men
who
had
for
years
walked
so
closely
together
.
<EOS>
And
this
separation
had
been
marked
by
violent
words
spoken
against
each
other
,
 
by
violent
words
,
at
least
,
spoken
against
him
in
office
by
the
one
who
had
never
contaminated
his
hands
by
the
Queen
's
shilling
.
<EOS>
And
yet
,
on
such
an
occasion
as
this
,
they
were
able
to
walk
away
from
the
House
arm
-
in
-
arm
,
and
did
not
fly
at
each
other
's
throat
by
the
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
Singular
enough
,
is
it
not
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
,
"
that
the
thing
should
have
been
so
close
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
odd
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
;
"
but
men
have
said
that
it
would
be
so
all
the
week
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gresham
was
very
fine
,
"
said

Turnbull
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
fine
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
I
never
have
heard
anything
like
it
before
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Daubeny
was
very
powerful

,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
The
occasion
was
great
,
and
he
answered
to
the
spur
.
<EOS>
But
Gresham
's
was
the
speech
of
the
debate
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Well
;
 
yes
;
perhaps
it
was
,
"
said
Mr.
Turnbull
,
who
was
thinking
of
his
own
flight
the
other
night
,
and
who
among
his
special
friends
had
been
much
praised
for
what
he
had
then

.
<EOS>
But
of
course
he
made
no
allusion
to
his
own
doings
,
 
or
to
those
of
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
they
conversed
for
some
twenty
minutes
,
till
they
parted
;
but
neither
of
them
interrogated
the
other
as
to
what

might

called
upon
to
do
in

of
the
division
which
had
just

.
<EOS>
They
might
still
be
intimate
friends
,
but
the
days
of
confidence
between
them
were
passed
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
had
seen
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
enter
the
House
,
 
which
he
did
quite
late
in
the
night
,
so
as
to
be
in
time
for
the
division
.
<EOS>
No
doubt
he
had
dined
in
the
House
,
and
had
been
all
the
evening
in
the
library
,
 
or
in
the
smoking
-
room
.
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Mildmay
was
on
his
legs
making
his
reply
,
Fitzgibbon
had
sauntered
in
,
not
choosing
to
wait
till
he
might
be
rung
up
by
the
bell
at
the
last
moment
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
near
him
as
they
passed
by
the
tellers
,
near
him
in
the
lobby
,
and
near
him
again
as
they
all
passed
back
into
the
House
.
<EOS>
But
at
the
last
moment
he
thought
that
he
would
miss
his
prey
.
<EOS>
In
the
crowd
as
they
left
the
House
he
failed
to
get
his
hand
upon
his
friend
's
shoulder
.
<EOS>
But
he
hurried
down
the
members
'
passage
,
and
just
at
the
gate
leading
out
into
Westminster
Hall
he
overtook
Fitzgibbon
walking
arm
-
in
-
arm
with
Barrington
Erle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Laurence
,
"
he
said
,
taking
hold
of
his
countryman
's
arm
with
a
decided

,
"
I
want
to
speak
to
you
for
a
moment
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Speak
away
,
"
said
Laurence
.
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
,
looking
up
into
his
face
,
knew
very
well
that
he
had
been
 
what
the
world
calls
,
dining
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
remembered
at
the
moment
that
Barrington
Erle
had
been
close
to
him
when
the
odious
money
-
lender
had
touched
his
arm
and
made
his

about
that
"
little
bill
.
"
<EOS>
He
much
wished
to
make
Erle
understand
that
the
debt
was
not
his
own
,
 
that
he
was
not
in
the
hands
of
usurers
in
reference
to
his
own
