.
<EOS>
But
there
was
a
feeling
within
him
that
he
still
,
 
even
still
,
 
owed
something
to
his
friendship
to
Fitzgibbon
.
"
<EOS>
Just
give
me
your
arm
,
and
come
on
with
me
for
a
minute
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
Erle
will
excuse
us
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
blazes
!
<EOS>
"
said
Laurence
,
"
what
is
it
<EOS>
you
're
after
?
<EOS>
I
ai
n't
good
at
private
conferences
at
three
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
We
're
all
out
,
and
is
n't
that
enough
for
ye
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
dreadfully
annoyed
to
-
night
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
and
I
wished
to
speak
to
you
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bedad
,
Finn
,
my
boy
,
and
there
are
a
good
many
of
us
<EOS>
are
annoyed
;
 
eh
,
Barrington
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
perceived
clearly
that
though
Fitzgibbon
had
been
dining
,
there
was
as
much
of
cunning
in
all
this
as
of
wine
,
and
he
was
determined
not
to
submit
to
such
unlimited
ill
-
usage
.
<EOS>
"
My
annoyance
comes
from
your
friend
,
Mr.
Clarkson
,
who
had
the
impudence
to
address
me
in
the
lobby
of
the
House
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
serve
you
right
,
too
,
Finn
,
my
boy
.
<EOS>
Why
the
devil
did
you
sport
your
oak
to
him
?
<EOS>
He
has
told
me
all
about
it
.
<EOS>
There
ai
n't
such
a
patient
little
fellow
as
Clarkson
anywhere
,
if
you
'll
only
let
him
have
his
own
way
.
<EOS>
He
'll
look
in
,
as
he
calls
it
,
three
times
a
week
for
a
whole
season
,
and
do
nothing
further
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
do
n't
like
to
be
locked
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
the
gentleman
with
whom
the
police
interfered
in

lobby
?
"
<EOS>
Erle
inquired
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
confounded
bill
discounter
to
whom
our
friend
here
has
introduced
me
,
 
for
his
own

,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
very
gentleman
-
like

,
"
said
Laurence
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Barrington
knows
him
,
I
daresay
.
<EOS>
Look
here
,
Finn
,
my
boy
,
take

.
<EOS>
Ask
him
to
breakfast
,
and
let
him

that
the
house
will
always

open
to

.
"
<EOS>
After
this
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
and
Barrington
Erle
got
into
a
cab
together
,
and
were
driven
away
.
   
<EOS>
A
Cabinet
Meeting
 
<EOS>
And
now
will
the
Muses
assist
me
while
I
sing
an
altogether
new
song
?
<EOS>
On
the
Tuesday
the
Cabinet
met
at
the
First
Lord
's
official
residence
in
Downing
Street
,
and
I
will
attempt
to
describe
what
,
according
to
the
bewildered
brain
of
a
poor
fictionist
,
was
said
or
might
have
been
said
,
what
was
done
or
might
have
been
done
,
on
so
august
an
occasion
.
  
<EOS>
The
poor
fictionist
very
frequently
finds
himself
to
have
been
wrong
in
his
description
of
things
in
general
,
and
is
told
so
,
roughly
by
the
critics
,
and
tenderly
by
the
friends
of
his
bosom
.
<EOS>
He
is
moved
to
tell
of
things
of
which
he
omits
to
learn
the
nature
before
he
tells
of
them
 
as
should
be
done
by
a
strictly
honest
fictionist
.
<EOS>
He
catches
salmon
in
October
;
or
shoots
his
partridges
in
March
.
<EOS>
His
dahlias
bloom
in
June
,
and
his
birds
sing
in
the
autumn
.
<EOS>
He
opens
the
opera
-
houses
before
Easter
,
and
makes
Parliament
sit
on
a
Wednesday
evening
.
<EOS>
And
then
those
terrible
meshes
of
the
Law
!
<EOS>
How
is
a
fictionist
,
in
these
excited
days
,
to
create
the
needed
biting
interest
without
legal
difficulties
;
and
how
again
is
he
to
steer
his
little
bark
clear
of
so
many
rocks
,
 
when
the
rocks
and
the
shoals
have
been
purposely
arranged
to
make
the
taking
of
a
pilot
on
board
a
necessity
?
<EOS>
As
to
those
law
meshes
,
a
benevolent
pilot
will
,
indeed
,
now
and
again
give
a
poor
fictionist
a
helping
hand
,
 
not
used
,
however
,
generally
,
with
much
discretion
.
<EOS>
But
from
whom
is
any
assistance
to
come
in
the
august
matter
of
a
Cabinet
assembly
?
<EOS>
There
can
be
no
such
assistance
.
<EOS>
No
man
can
tell
aught
but
they
who
will
tell
nothing
.
<EOS>
But
then
,
again
,
there
is
this
safety
<EOS>
,
that
let
the
story
be
ever
so
mistold
,
 
let
the
fiction
be
ever
so
far
removed
from
the
truth
,
no
critic
short
of
a
Cabinet
Minister
himself
can
convict
the
narrator
of
error
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
large
dingy
room
,
covered
with
a
Turkey
carpet
,
and
containing
a
dark
polished
mahogany
dinner
-
table
,
on
very
heavy
carved
legs
,
which
an
old
messenger
was
preparing
at
two
o'clock
in
the
day
for
the
use
of
her
Majesty
's
Ministers
.
<EOS>
The
table
would
have
been
large
enough
for
fourteen
guests
,
and
along
the
side
further
from
the
fire
,
there
were
placed
some
six
heavy
chairs
,
good
comfortable
chairs
,
stuffed
at
the
back
as
well
as
the
seat
,
 
but
on
the
side
nearer
to
the
fire
the
chairs
were
placed
irregularly
;
and
there
were
four
armchairs
,
 
two
on
one
side
and
two
on
the
other
.
<EOS>
There
were
four
windows
to
the
room
,
which
looked
on
to
St.
James
's
Park
,
and
the
curtains
of
the
windows
were
dark
and
heavy
,
 
as
became
the
gravity
of
the
purposes
to
which
that
chamber
was
appropriated
.
<EOS>
In
old
days
it
had
been
the
dining
-
room
of
one
Prime
Minister
after
another
.
<EOS>
To
Pitt
it
had
been
the
abode
of
his
own
familiar
prandial
Penates
,
and
Lord
Liverpool
had
been
dull
there
among
his
dull
friends
for
long
year
after
year
.
<EOS>
The
Ministers
of
the
present
day
find
it
more
convenient
to
live
in
private
homes
,
and
,
indeed
,
not
unfrequently
carry
their
Cabinets
with
them
.
<EOS>
But
,
under
Mr.
Mildmay
's
rule
,
the
meetings
were
generally
held
in
the
old
room
at
the
official
residence
.
<EOS>
Thrice
did
the
aged
messenger
move
each
armchair
,
now
a
little
this
way
<EOS>
and
now
a
little
that
,
and
then
look
at
them
as
though
something
of
the
tendency
of
the
coming
meeting
might
depend
on
the
comfort
of
its
leading
members
.
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Mildmay
should
find
himself
to
be
quite
comfortable
,
so
that
he
could
hear
what
was
said
without
a
struggle
to
his
ear
,
and
see
his
colleagues
'
faces
clearly
,
and
feel
the
fire
without
burning
his
shins
,
it
might
be
possible
that
he
would
not
insist
upon
resigning
.
<EOS>
If
this
were
so
,
how
important
was
the
work
now
confided
to
the
hands
of
that
aged
messenger
!
<EOS>
When
his
anxious
eyes
had
glanced
round
the
room
<EOS>
some
half
a
dozen
times
,
when
he
had
touched
each
curtain
,
laid
his
hand
upon
every
chair
,
and
dusted
certain
papers
which
lay
upon
a
side
-
table
,
 
and
which
had
been
lying
there
for
two
years
,
and
at
which
no
one
ever
looked
or
would
look
,
 
he
gently
crept
away
and
ensconced
himself
in
an
easy
chair
not
far
from
the
door
of
the
chamber
.
<EOS>
For
it
might
be
necessary
to
stop
the
attempt
of
a
rash
intruder
on
those
secret
counsels
.
  
<EOS>
Very
shortly
there
was
heard
the
ring
of
various
voices
in
the
passages
,
 
the
voices
of
men
speaking
pleasantly
,
the
voices
of
men
with
whom
it
seemed
,
from
their
tone
,
that
things
were
doing
well
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
And
then
a
cluster
of
four
or
five
gentlemen
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
At
first
sight
they
seemed
to
be
as
ordinary
gentlemen
as
you
shall
meet
anywhere
about
Pall
Mall
on
an
afternoon
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
about
their
outward
appearance
of
the
august
wiggery
of
statecraft
,
nothing
of
the
ponderous
dignity
of
ministerial
position
.
<EOS>
That
little
man
in
the
square
-
cut
coat
,
 
<EOS>
we
may
almost
call
it
a
shooting
-
coat
,
 
swinging
an
umbrella
and
wearing
no
gloves
,
is
no
less
a
person
than
the
Lord
Chancellor
,
 
Lord
Weazeling
,
 
who
made
a
hundred
thousand
pounds
as
Attorney
-
General
,
and
is
supposed
to
be
the
best
lawyer
of
his
age
.
<EOS>
He
is
fifty
,
but
he
looks
to
be
hardly
over
forty
,
and
one
might
take
him
to
be
,
from
his
appearance
,
 
perhaps
a
clerk
in
the
War
Office
,
well
-
to
-
do
,
and
popular
among
his
brother
-
clerks
.
<EOS>
Immediately
with
him
is
Sir
Harry
Coldfoot
,
also
a
lawyer
by
profession
,
though
he
has
never
practised
.
<EOS>
He
has
been
in
the
House
for
nearly
thirty
years
,
and
is
now
at
the
Home
Office
.
<EOS>
He
is
a
stout
,
healthy
,
grey
-
haired
gentleman
,
who
certainly
does
not
wear
the
cares
of
office
on
his
face
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
however
,
no
minister
gets
more
bullied
than
he
by
the
press
,
and
men
say
that
he
will
be
very
willing
to
give
up
to
some
political
enemy
the
control
of
the
police
,
and
the
onerous
duty
of
judging
in
all
criminal
appeals
.
<EOS>
Behind
these
come
our
friend
Mr.
Monk
,
young
Lord
Cantrip
from
the
colonies
next
door
,
than
whom
no
smarter
young
peer
now
does
honour
to
our
hereditary
legislature
,
and
Sir
Marmaduke
Morecombe
,
the
Chancellor
of
the
Duchy
of
Lancaster
.
<EOS>
Why
Sir
Marmaduke
has
always
been
placed
in
Mr.
Mildmay
's
Cabinets
nobody
ever
knew
.
<EOS>
As
Chancellor
of
the
Duchy
he
has
nothing
to
do
,
 
and
were
there
anything
,
he
would
not
do
it
.
<EOS>
He
rarely
speaks
in
the
House
,
and
then
does
not
speak
well
.
<EOS>
He
is
a
handsome
man
,
or
would
be
but
for
an
assumption
of
grandeur
in
the
carriage
of
his
eyes
,
giving
to
his
face
a
character
of
pomposity
which
he
himself
well
deserves
.
<EOS>
He
was
in
the
Guards
when
young
,
and
has
been
in
Parliament
since
he
ceased
to
be
young
.
<EOS>
It
must
be
supposed
that
Mr.
Mildmay
has
found
something
in
him
,
for
he
has
been
included
in
three
successive
liberal
Cabinets
.
<EOS>
He
has
probably
the
virtue
of
being
true
to
Mr.
Mildmay
,
and
of
being
duly
submissive
to
one
whom
he
recognises
as
his
superior
.
  
<EOS>
Within
two
minutes
afterwards
the
Duke
followed
,
with
Plantagenet
Palliser
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
,
as
all
the
world
knows
,
was
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
,
the
very
front
and
head
of
the
aristocratic
old
Whigs
of
the
country
,
 
a
man
who
has
been
thrice
spoken
of
as
Prime
Minister
,
and
who
really
might
have
filled
the
office
had
he
not
known
himself
to
be
unfit
for
it
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
has
been
consulted
as
to
the
making
of
Cabinets
for
the
last
five
-
and
-
thirty
years
,
and
is
even
now
not
an
old
man
in
appearance
;
 
a
fussy
,
popular
,
clever
,
conscientious
man
,
whose
digestion
has
been
too
good
to
make
politics
a
burden
to
him
,
but
who
has
thought
seriously
about
his
country
,
and
is
one
who
will
be
sure
to
leave
memoirs
behind
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
born
in
the
semi
-
purple
of
ministerial
influences
,
and
men
say
of
him
that
he
is
honester
than
his
uncle
,
who
was
Canning
's
friend
,
but
not
so
great
a
man
as
his
grandfather
,
with
whom
Fox
once
quarrelled
,
and
whom
Burke
loved
.
<EOS>
Plantagenet
Palliser
,
himself
the
heir
to
a
dukedom
,
was
the
young
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
,
of
whom
some
statesmen
thought
much
as
the
rising
star
of
the
age
.
<EOS>
If
industry
,
rectitude
of
purpose
,
and
a
certain
clearness
of
intellect
may
prevail
,
Planty
Pall
,
as
he
is
familiarly
called
,
may
become
a
great
Minister
.
  
<EOS>
Then
came
Viscount
Thrift
by
himself
;
 
the
First
Lord
of
the
Admiralty
,
with
the
whole
weight
of
a
new
iron
-
clad
fleet
upon
his
shoulders
.
<EOS>
He
has
undertaken
the
Herculean
task
of
cleansing
the
dockyards
,
 
and
with
it
the
lesser
work
of
keeping
afloat
a
navy
that
may
be
esteemed
by
his
countrymen
to
be
the
best
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
And
he
thinks
that
he
will
do
both
,
if
only
Mr.
Mildmay
will
not
resign
;
 
an
industrious
,
honest
,
self
-
denying
nobleman
,
who
works
without
ceasing
from
morn
to
night
,
and
who
hopes
to
rise
in
time
to
high
things
,
 
to
the
translating
of
Homer
,
perhaps
,
and
the
wearing
of
the
Garter
.
  
<EOS>
Close
behind
him
<EOS>
there
was
a
ruck
of
Ministers
,
with
the
much
-
honoured
grey
-
haired
old
Premier
in
the
midst
of
them
.
<EOS>
There
was
Mr.
Gresham
,
the
Foreign
Minister
,
<EOS>
said
to
be
the
greatest
orator
in
Europe
,
on
whose
shoulders
it
was
thought
that
the
mantle
of
Mr.
Mildmay
would
fall
,
 
to
be
worn
<EOS>
,
however
,
quite
otherwise
than
Mr.
Mildmay
had
worn
it
.
<EOS>
For
Mr.
Gresham
is
a
man
with
no
feelings
for
the
past
,
void
of
historical
association
,
hardly
with
memories
,
 
living
altogether
for
the
future
which
he
is
anxious
to
fashion
anew
out
of
the
vigour
of
his
own
brain
.
<EOS>
Whereas
,
with
Mr.
Mildmay
,
even
his
love
of
reform
is
an
inherited
passion
for
an
old
-
world
Liberalism
.
<EOS>
And
there
was
with
them
<EOS>
Mr.
Legge
Wilson
,
the
brother
of
a
peer
,
Secretary
at
War
,
a
great
scholar
and
a
polished
gentleman
,
very
proud
of
his
position
as
a
Cabinet
Minister
,
but
conscious
that
he
has
hardly
earned
it
by
political
work
.
<EOS>
And
Lord
Plinlimmon
is
with
them
,
the
Comptroller
of
India
,
 
of
all
working
lords
the
most
jaunty
,
the
most
pleasant
,
and
the
most
popular
,
very
good
at
taking
chairs
at
dinners
,
and
making
becoming
speeches
at
the
shortest
notice
,
a
man
apparently
very
free
and
open
in
his
ways
of
life
,
 
but
cautious
enough
in
truth
as
to
every
step
,
knowing
well
how
hard
it
is
to
climb
and
how
easy
to
fall
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
entered
the
room
leaning
on
Lord
Plinlimmon
's
arm
,
and
when
he
made
his
way
up
among
the
armchairs
upon
the
rug
before
the
fire
,
the
others
clustered
around
him
with
cheering
looks
and
kindly
questions
.
<EOS>
Then
came
the
Privy
Seal
,
our
old
friend
Lord
Brentford
,
last
,
 
<EOS>
and
I
would
say
least
,
but
that
the
words
of
no
councillor
could
go
for
less
in
such
an
assemblage
than
will
those
of
Sir
Marmaduke
Morecombe
,
the
Chancellor
of
the
Duchy
of
Lancaster
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
was
soon
seated
in
one
of
the
armchairs
,
while
Lord
Plinlimmon
leaned
against
the
table
close
at
his
elbow
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
stood
upright
at
the
corner
of
the
chimney
-
piece
furthest
from
Mr.
Mildmay
,
and
Mr.
Palliser
at
that
nearest
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
took
the
armchair
close
at
Mr.
Mildmay
's
left
hand
.
<EOS>
Lord
Plinlimmon
was
,
as
I
have
said
,
leaning
against
the
table
,
but
the
Lord
Chancellor
,
who
was
next
to
him
,
sat
upon
it
.
<EOS>
Viscount
Thrift
and
Mr.
Monk
occupied
chairs
on
the
further
side
of
the
table
,
near
to
Mr.
Mildmay
's
end
,
and
Mr.
Legge
Wilson
placed
himself
at
the
head
of
the
table
,
thus
joining
them
as
it
were
into
a
body
.
<EOS>
The
Home
Secretary
stood
before
the
Lord
Chancellor
screening
him
from
the
fire
,
and
the
Chancellor
of
the
Duchy
,
after
waiting
for
a
few
minutes
as
though
in
doubt
,
took
one
of
the
vacant
armchairs
.
<EOS>
The
young
lord
from
the
Colonies
stood
a
little
behind
the
shoulders
of
his
great
friend
from
the
Foreign
Office
;
and
the
Privy
Seal
,
after
moving
about
for
a
while
uneasily
,
took
a
chair
behind
the
Chancellor
of
the
Duchy
.
<EOS>
One
armchair
was
thus
left
vacant
,
but
there
was
no
other
comer
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
so
bad
as
I
thought
it
would
be
,
"
said
the
Duke
,
speaking
aloud
,
but
nevertheless
addressing
himself
specially
to
his
chief
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
bad
enough
,
"
said
Mr.
Mildmay
,
laughing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bad
enough
indeed
,
"
said
Sir
Marmaduke
Morecombe
,
without
any
laughter
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
such
a
good
bill
lost
,
"
said
Lord
Plinlimmon
.
<EOS>
"
The
worst
of
these
failures
is
,
that
the
same
identical
bill
can
never
be
brought
in
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
So
that
if
the
lost
bill
was
best
,
the
bill
that
will
not
be
lost
can
only
be
second
best
,
"
said
the
Lord
Chancellor
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
did
think
that
after
the
debate
before
Easter
we
should
not
have
come
to
shipwreck
about
the
ballot
,
"
said
Mr.
Mildmay
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
brewing
for
us
all
along
,
"
said
Mr.
Gresham
,
who
then
with
a
gesture
of
his
hand
and
a
pressure
of
his
lips
withheld
words
which
he
was
nearly
uttering
,
and
which
would
not
,
probably
,
have
been
complimentary
to
Mr.
Turnbull
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
he
turned
half
round
and
said
something
to
Lord
Cantrip
which
was
not
audible
to
any
one
else
in
the
room
.
<EOS>
It
was
worthy
of
note
,
however
,
that
Mr.
Turnbull
's
name
was
not
once
mentioned
aloud
at
that
meeting
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
it
was
brewing
all
along
,
"
said
Sir
Marmaduke
Morecombe
gravely
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
gentlemen
,
we
must
take
it
as
we
get
it
,
"
said
Mr.
Mildmay
,
still
smiling
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
now
we
must
consider
what
we
shall
do
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
paused
as
though
expecting
that
counsel
would
come
to
him
first
from
one
colleague
and
then
from
another
.
<EOS>
But
no
such
counsel
came
,
and
probably
Mr.
Mildmay
did
not
in
the
least
expect
that
it
would
come
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
can
not
stay
where
we
are
,
of
course
,
"
said
the
Duke
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
was
privileged
to
say
as
much
as
that
.
<EOS>
But
though
every
man
in
the
room
knew
that
it
must
be
so
,
no
one
but
the
Duke
would
have
said
it
,
before
Mr.
Mildmay
had
spoken
plainly
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr.
Mildmay
;
"
I
suppose
that
we
can
hardly
stay
where
we
are
.
<EOS>
Probably
none
of
us
wish
it
,
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
looked
round
upon
his
colleagues
,
and
there
came
a
sort
of
an
assent
,
though
there
were
no
spoken
words
.
<EOS>
The
sound
from
Sir
Marmaduke
Morecombe
was
louder
than
that
from
the
others
;
 
but
yet
from
him
it
was
no
more
than
an
attesting
grunt
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
two
things
to
consider
,
"
continued
Mr.
Mildmay
,
 
and
though
he
spoke
in
a
very
low
voice
,
every
word
was
heard
by
all
present
,
 
"
two
things
chiefly
,
that
is
;
the
work
of
the
country
and
the
Queen
's
comfort
.
<EOS>
I
propose
to
see
her
Majesty
this
afternoon
at
five
,
 
that
is
,
in
something
less
than
two
hours
'
time
,
and
I
hope
to
be
able
to
tell
the
House
by
seven
what
has
taken
place
between
her
Majesty
and
me
.
<EOS>
My
friend
,
his
Grace
,
will
do
as
much
in
the
House
of
Lords
.
<EOS>
If
you
agree
with
me
,
gentlemen
,
I
will
explain
to
the
Queen
that
it
is
not
for
the
welfare
of
the
country
that
we
should
retain
our
places
,
and
I
will
place
your
resignations
and
my
own
in
her
Majesty
's
hands
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
advise
her
Majesty
to
send
for
Lord
de
Terrier
,
"
said
Mr.
Gresham
.
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
;
 
there
will
be
no
other
course
open
to
me
.
"
  
"
Or
to
her
,
"
said
Mr.
Gresham
.
<EOS>
To
this
remark
from
the
rising
Minister
of
the
day
,
no
word
of
reply
was
made
;
but
of
those
present
in
the
room
three
or
four
of
the
most
experienced
servants
of
the
Crown
felt
that
Mr.
Gresham
had
been
imprudent
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
,
who
had
.
<EOS>
ever
been
afraid
of
Mr.
Gresham
,
told
Mr.
Palliser
afterwards
that
such
an
observation
should
not
have
been
made
;
and
Sir
Harry
Coldfoot
pondered
upon
it
uneasily
,
and
Sir
Marmaduke
Morecombe
asked
Mr.
Mildmay
what
he
thought
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
Times
change
so
much
,
and
with
the
times
the
feelings
of
men
,
"
said
Mr.
Mildmay
.
<EOS>
But
I
doubt
whether
Sir
Marmaduke
quite
understood
him
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
silence
in
the
room
for
a
moment
or
two
after
Mr.
Gresham
had
spoken
,
and
then
Mr.
Mildmay
again
addressed
his
friends
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
may
be
possible
that
my
Lord
de
Terrier
may
foresee
difficulties
,
or
may
find
difficulties
which
will
oblige
him
,
either
at
once
,
or
after
an
attempt
has
been
made
,
to
decline
the
task
which
her
Majesty
will
probably
commit
to
him
.
<EOS>
All
of
us
,
no
doubt
,
know
that
the
arrangement
of
a
government
is
not
the
most
easy
task
in
the
world
;
and
that
it
is
not
made
the
more
easy
by
an
absence
of
a
majority
in
the
House
of
Commons
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
He
would
dissolve
,
I
presume
,
"
said
the
Duke
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
say
so
,
"
continued
Mr.
Mildmay
.
<EOS>
"
But
it
may
not
improbably
come
to
pass
that
her
Majesty
will
feel
herself
obliged
to
send
again
for
some
one
or
two
of
us
,
that
we
may
tender
to
her
Majesty
the
advice
which
we
owe
to
her
;
 
for
me
,
for
instance
,
or
for
my
friend
the
Duke
.
<EOS>
In
such
a
matter
she
would
be
much
guided
probably
by
what
Lord
de
Terrier
might
have
suggested
to
her
.
<EOS>
Should
this
be
so
,
and
should
I
be
consulted
,
my
present
feeling
is
that
we
should
resume
our
offices
so
that
the
necessary
business
of
the
session
should
be

,
and
that

then

Parliament
,
and
thus

opinion
of
the
country
.
<EOS>
In
such
case
,
however
,
we
should
of
course
meet
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
quite
think
that
the
course
proposed
by
Mr.
Mildmay
will
be
the
best
,
"
said
the
Duke
,
who
had
no

already
discussed

matter
with
his
friend

Prime

in

.
<EOS>
No
one
else
said
a
word
either
of
argument
or
disagreement
,
and
the
Cabinet
Council
was
broken

.
<EOS>
The
old

,
who
had

,

as

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
as
much
idea
of

,
"

Cantrip

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

not

that

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
For

future
fame
.
<EOS>
They

and
have

always
lost

.
<EOS>
Cincinnatus
was

,
and
Charles
V.
is
felt

have

.
<EOS>
The

of

of

have

in

;
 
or

.
<EOS>
"
They

probably
of
Mr.
Mildmay
,

,

,
that

to

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.

,

,

<EOS>
But

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
's
Luck
 
<EOS>
After
the
holding
of
that
Cabinet
Council
of
which
the
author
has
dared
to
attempt
a
slight
sketch
in
the
last
chapter
,
there
were
various
visits
made
to
the
Queen
,
first
by
Mr.
Mildmay
,
and
then
by
Lord
de
Terrier
,
afterwards
by

together
,
and
then
again
by
Lord
de
Terrier
;
and
there

various

made
to
Parliament
in
each
House
,
and
rivals
were
very
courteous
to
each
other
,
promising

;
 
and
at
the
end
of
it
the
old
men
held
their
seats
.
<EOS>
The
only
change
made
was
effected
by

of
Sir
Marmaduke
Morecombe
,
who
was
raised
to
the

,
and
by
the
selection
of
 
Mr.
Kennedy
to
fill

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
during

late

had
made

,
few

far

,
by

created
for

;
but
,

,

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
am

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
His

must

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
hard
to

.
<EOS>
There

by

wear
their

,

my

.
<EOS>

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
men
held
their
seats
,
but
they
did
so
as
it
were
only
upon
further
trial
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
took
the
course
which
he
had
indicated
to
his
colleagues
at
the
Cabinet
meeting
.
<EOS>
Before
all
the
explanations
and
journeyings
were
completed
,
April
was
over
,
and
the
much
-
needed
Whitsuntide
holidays
were
coming
on
.
<EOS>
But
little
of
the
routine
work
of
the
session
had
been
done
;
and
,
as
Mr.
Mildmay
told

House
more

,
the
country
would
suffer
were
the
Queen
to
dissolve
Parliament
at
this
period
of
the
year
.
<EOS>
The
old
Ministers
would
go
on
with
the
business
of
the
country
,
Lord
de
Terrier
with
his
followers
having
declined
to
take
affairs
into
their
hands
;
and
at
the
close
of
the
session
,
which
should

made
as
short

,

should

issued
for

.
<EOS>
This
was
Mr.
Mildmay
's
programme
,
and
it
was
one
of
which
no
one
dared
to
complain
very
loudly
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
,
indeed
,
did
speak
a
word
of
caution
.
<EOS>
He
told
Mr.
Mildmay
that
he
had
lost
his
bill
,
good
in
other
respects
,
because
he
had
refused
to
introduce
the
ballot
into
his
measure
.
<EOS>
Let
him
promise
to
be
wiser
for
the
future
,
and
to
obey
the
manifested
wishes
of
the
country
,
and
then
all
would
be
well
with
him
.
<EOS>
In

,
Mr.
Mildmay
declared
that
to
the
best
of
his
power
of
reading
the
country
,
his
countrymen
had
manifested

;

,

it

the

was
in
truth
desired
,
he

at

leave
the

their

to
abler

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
expressed
himself
perfectly

with
the

's

,
and
said
that
the
coming
election
would
show
whether
he

Mr.
Mildmay
were
right
.
  
<EOS>
Many
men
,
and

,

.
"
<EOS>
No

,
"

;
 
"
<EOS>
that

,
to

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
There

_

_

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But

was
something
less

Quintus
Slide
than

,

.
<EOS>
This

was
given
to

about

,
and

Lord
Chiltern
was

in

.
<EOS>
Miss
Pouncefoot
had

,

Lord

.
<EOS>
"
I

n't

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>

,

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There

many

of

Chiltern
up

,

.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
had
thought
that

son
had
better

Willingford
Bull
;
and
although

said

's

should

,
still

that

,

to
Willingford
,
could
not

that

.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
shall

,
"
Lord
Chiltern

.
"
<EOS>
My
father
annoys
me
by

and

,
and
I
annoy

by
saying

nothing
.
"
<EOS>
Then
there
came

to
him
from
Lady
Laura
and

Kennedy
.
<EOS>
Would
he
come
to
Grosvenor
Place
?
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
pressed
this
very
much
,
though
in
truth
Mr.
Kennedy
had
hardly

than

.
<EOS>
But
Lord
Chiltern
would
not
hear

.
<EOS>
"
There
is
some
reason
for
my
going
to
my
father
's

,
"
said

,
"
though

;
but

for

man
I

I

Robert
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
"
The
matter
was
settled
in
the
manner
told
above
.
<EOS>
Miss
Pouncefoot
's
rooms
were
prepared
for
him
at
Mr.
Bunce
's
house
,
and
Phineas
Finn
went
down
to
Willingford
and
brought
him
up
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
sold
Bonebreaker
,
"
he
said
,
 
"
to
a
young
fellow
whose
neck
will
certainly
be
the
sacrifice
if
he
attempts
to
ride
him
.
<EOS>
I
'd
have
given
him
to
you
,
Phineas
,
only
you
would
n't

known
what
to
do

him
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
when
he
came
up
to
London
was
still
in
bandages
,
though
,
as
the
surgeon
said
,
his
bones
seemed
to
have
been
made
to
be
broken
and
set

;
and
his

of
course
were
a
sufficient
excuse
for
his
visiting
the
house
neither
of
his
father
nor
his
brother
-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
But
Lady
Laura
went
to
him
frequently
,
and
thus
became
acquainted
with
our
hero
's
home
and

Mrs.
Bunce
.
<EOS>
And
there
were
messages
taken
from
Violet
to
the
man
in
bandages
<EOS>
,
some
of
which
lost
nothing
in
the
carrying
.
<EOS>
Once
Lady
Laura
tried
to
make
Violet
think
that

would
be
right
,
or
rather
not
wrong
,
that
they
two
should
go
together
to
Lord
Chiltern
's
rooms
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
would
you
have
me
tell
my
aunt
,
or
would
you
have
me
not

her
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Violet
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
have
you
do
just
as
you
pleased
,
"
Lady
Laura
answered
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
shall
,
"
Violet
replied
,
"
but
I
will
do
nothing
that
I
should
be
ashamed
to
tell
any
one
.
<EOS>
Your
brother
professes
to
be
in

with
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
in
love
with
you
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
Even
you
do
not
pretend
to
doubt
his
faith
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Very
well
.
<EOS>
In
those
circumstances
a
girl
should
not
go
to
a
man
's
rooms
unless
she
means
to
consider
herself
as
engaged
to
him
,
even
with
his
sister
;
 
not
though
he
had
broken
every
bone
in
his
skin
.
<EOS>
I
know
what
I
may
do
,
Laura
,
and
I

I
may
n't
;
and
I
wo
n't
be
led
either
by
you
or

my

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
give
him
your

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
because
you
'll
give
it
in
a
wrong
spirit
.
<EOS>
He
knows
well
enough
that
I
wish
him
well
;
 
but
you
may
tell
him
that
from
me
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
He
has
from
me
all
those
wishes
which
one
friend
owes
to
another
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
there
were
other
messages
sent
from
Violet
through
Phineas
Finn
which
she
worded
with
more
show
of

,
 
perhaps
as
much
for
the

of

as
for

Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
Tell

to
take

,
"
said
Violet
,
"
and
bid
him
not
to
have

more
of
those
wild
brutes
that
are
not
fit
for
any
Christian
to
ride
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
that
I
say
so
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
great
thing
to
be
brave
;
but
what
's
the
use
of
being
foolhardy
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
session
was
to
be
closed
at
the
end
of
June
,
to
the
great
dismay
of
London
tradesmen
and
of
young
ladies
who
had
not
been
entirely
successful
in
the
early
season
.
<EOS>
But
before
the
old
Parliament
was
closed
,
and
the
writs
for
the
new
election
were
despatched
,
there
occurred
an
incident
which
was
of
very
much
importance
to
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
Near
the
end
of
June
,
when
the
remaining
days
of
the
session
were
numbered
by
three
or
four
,
he
had
been
dining
at
Lord
Brentford
's
house
in
Portman
Square
in
company
with
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
But
Lady
Laura
had
not
been
there
.
<EOS>
At
this
time
he
saw
Lord
Brentford
not
unfrequently
,
and
there
was
always
a
word
said
about
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
The
father
would
ask
how
the
son
occupied
himself
,
and
Phineas
would
hope
,
 
though
hitherto
he
had
hoped
in
vain
,
 
that
he
would
induce
the
Earl
to
come
and
see
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
could
never
be
brought
to
that
;
but
it
was
sufficiently
evident
that
he
would
have
done
so
,
had
he
not
been
afraid
to
descend
so
far
from
the
altitude
of
his
paternal
wrath
.
<EOS>
On
this
evening
,
at
about
eleven
,
Mr.
Kennedy
and
Phineas
left
the
house
together
,
and
walked
from
the
Square
through
Orchard
Street
into
Oxford
Street
.
<EOS>
Here
their
ways
parted
,
but
Phineas
crossed
the
road
with
Mr.
Kennedy
,
as
he
was
making
some
reply
to
a
second
invitation
to
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
considering
what
had
been
said
before
on
the
subject
,
thought
that
the
invitation
came
late
,
and
that
it
was
not
warmly
worded
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
therefore
,
declined
it
,
and
was
in
the
act
of
declining
it
,
when
he
crossed
the
road
with
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
In
walking
down
Orchard
Street
from
the
Square
he
had
seen
two
men
standing
in
the
shadow
a
few
yards
up
a
mews
or
small
alley
that
was
there
,
but
had
thought
nothing
of
them
.
<EOS>
It
was
just
that
period
of
the
year
when
there
is
hardly
any
of
the
darkness
of
night
;
but
at
this
moment
there
were
symptoms
of
coming
rain
,
and
heavy
drops
began
to
fall
;
and
there
were
big
clouds
coming
and
going
before
the
young
moon
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
had
said
that
he
would
get
a
cab
,
but
he
had
seen
none
as
he
crossed
Oxford
Street
,
and
had
put
up
his
umbrella
as
he
made
his
way
towards
Park
Street
.
<EOS>
Phineas
as
he
left
him
distinctly
perceived
the
same
two
figures
on
the
other
side
of
Oxford
Street
,
and
then
turning
into
the
shadow
of
a
butcher
's
porch
,
he
saw
them
cross
the
street
in
the
wake
of
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
raining
in
earnest
,
and
the
few
passengers
who
were
out
were
scudding
away
quickly
,
this
way
and
that
.
  
<EOS>
It
hardly
occurred
to
Phineas
to
think
that
any
danger
was
imminent
to
Mr.
Kennedy
from
the
men
,
but
it
did
occur
to
him
that
he
might
as
well
take
some
notice
of
the
matter
.
<EOS>
Phineas
knew
that
Mr.
Kennedy
would
make
his
way
down
Park
Street
,
that
being
his
usual
route
from
Portman
Square
towards
his
own
home
,
and
knew
also
that
he
himself
could
again
come
across
Mr.
Kennedy
's
track
by
going
down
North
Audley
Street
to
the
corner
of
Grosvenor
Square
,
and
thence
by
Brook
Street
into
Park
Street
.
<EOS>
Without
much
thought
,
therefore
,
he
went
out
of
his
own
course
down
to
the
corner
of
the
Square
,
hurrying
his
steps
till
he
was
running
,
and
then
ran
along
Brook
Street
,
thinking
as
he
went
of
some
special
word
that
he
might
say
to
Mr.
Kennedy
as
an
excuse
,
should
he
again
come
across
his
late
companion
.
<EOS>
He
reached
the
corner
of
Park
Street
before
that
gentleman
could
have
been
there
unless
he
also
had
run
;
but
just
in
time
to
see
him
as
he
was
coming
on
,
 
and
also
to
see
in
the
dark
glimmering
of
the
slight
uncertain
moonlight
that
the
two
men
were
behind
him
.
<EOS>
He
retreated
a
step
backwards
in
the
corner
,
resolving
that
when
Mr.
Kennedy
came
up
,
they
two
would
go
on
together
;
for
now
it
was
clear
that
Mr.
Kennedy
was
followed
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Kennedy
did
not
reach
the
corner
.
<EOS>
When
he
was
within
two
doors
of
it
,
one
of
the
men
had
followed
him
up
quickly
,
and
had
thrown
something
round
his
throat
from
behind
him
.
<EOS>
Phineas
understood
well
now
that
his
friend
was
in
the
act
of
being
garrotted
,
and
that
his
instant
assistance
was
needed
.
<EOS>
He
rushed
forward
,
and
as
the
second
ruffian
had
been
close
upon
the
footsteps
of
the
first
,
there
was
almost
instantaneously
a
concourse
of
the
four
men
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
fight
.
<EOS>
The
man
who
had
already
nearly
succeeded
in
putting
Mr.
Kennedy
on
to
his
back
,
made
no
attempt
to
seize
his
prey
when
he
found
that
so
unwelcome
an
addition
had
joined
the
party
,
but
instantly
turned
to
fly
.
<EOS>
His
companion
was
turning
also
,
but
Phineas
was
too
quick
for
him
,
and
having
seized
on
to
his
collar
,
held
to
him
with
all
his
power
.
<EOS>
"
Dash
it
all
,
"
said
the
man
,
"
did
n't
yer
see
as
how
I
was
a
-
hurrying
up
to
help
the
gen'leman
myself
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
,
however
,
had
n't
seen
this
,
and
held
on
gallantly
,
and
in
a
couple
of
minutes
the
first
ruffian
was
back
again
upon
the
spot
in
the
custody
of
a
policeman
.
<EOS>
"
You
've
done
it
uncommon
neat
,
sir
,
"
said
the
policeman
,
complimenting
Phineas
upon
his
performance
.
<EOS>
"
If
the
gen'leman
ai
n't
none
the
worst
for
it
,
it
'll
have
been
a
very
pretty
evening
's
amusement
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
was
now
leaning
against
the
railings
,
and
hitherto
had
been
unable
to
declare
whether
he
was
really
injured
or
not
,
and
it
was
not
till
a
second
policeman
came
up
that
the
hero
of
the
night
was
at
liberty
to
attend
closely
to
his
friend
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
,
when
he
was
able
to
speak
,
declared
that
for
a
minute
or
two
he
had
thought
that
his
neck
had
been
broken
;
and
he
was
not
quite
convinced
till

found
himself
in

own
house
,
that
nothing
more
serious
had
really
happened
to
him
than
certain
bruises
round
his

.
<EOS>
The
policeman
was
for
a
while
anxious
that
at
any
rate
Phineas
should
go
with
him
to
the
police
-
office
;
but
at
last
consented
to
take
the
addresses
of
the
two
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
When
he
found
that
Mr.
Kennedy
was
a
member
of
Parliament
,
and
that
he
was
designated
as
Right
Honourable
,
his
respect
for
the
garrotter
became
more
great
,
and
he
began
to
feel
that
the
night
was
indeed
a
night
of
great
importance
.
<EOS>
He
expressed
unbounded
admiration
at
Mr.
Finn
's
success
in
his
own
line
,
and
made
repeated
promises
that
the
men
should
be
forthcoming
on
the
morrow
.
<EOS>
Could
a
cab
be
got
?
<EOS>
Of
course
a
cab
could
be
got
.
<EOS>
A
cab
was
got
,
and
within
a
quarter
of
an
hour
of
the
making
of
the
attack
,
the
two
members
of
Parliament
were
on
their
way
to
Grosvenor
Place
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
hardly
a
word
spoken
in
the
cab
,
for
Mr.
Kennedy
was
in
pain
.
<EOS>
When
,
however
,
they
reached
the
door
in
Grosvenor
Place
,
Phineas
wanted
to
go
,
and
leave
his
friend
with
the
servants
,
but
this
the
Cabinet
Minister
would
not
allow
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
must
see
my
wife
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
So
they
went
up
-
stairs
into
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
then
upon
the
stairs
,
by
the
lights
of
the
house
,
Phineas
could
perceive
that
his
companion
's
face
was
bruised
and
black

,
and
that
his

was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
garrotted
,
"
said
the
Cabinet
Minister
to
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Simply
that
;
 
or
should
have
been
,
if
he
had
not
been
there
.
<EOS>
How
he
came
there
,
God
only
knows
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
wife
's
anxiety
,
and
then
her

,
need
hardly

described
,
 
nor

of

,
which
by
no

decreased
on

,
at
the
opportune
re
-
appearance
in
the
nick
of
time
of
the
man
whom
three
minutes
before
the
attack
he
had
left
in

of
going
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
had
seen
the
men
,
and
thought
it
best
to
run
round
by
the
corner
of
Grosvenor
Square
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
May
God
bless
you
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Amen
,
"
said
the
Cabinet
Minister
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
was
born
to
be
my
friend
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
The
Cabinet
Minister
said
nothing
more
that
night
.
<EOS>
He
was
never
given
to
much
talking
,
and
the
little
accident
which
had
just
occurred
to
him
did
not
tend
to
make
words
easy
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
he
pressed
our
hero
's
hand
,
and
Lady
Laura
said
that
of
course
Phineas
would
come
to
them
on
the
morrow
.
<EOS>
Phineas
remarked
that
his
first
business
must
be
to
go
to
the
police
-
office
,
but
he
promised
that
he
would
come
down
to
Grosvenor
Place
immediately
afterwards
.
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Laura
also
pressed
his
hand
,
and
looked
 
;
she
looked
,
I
think
,
as
though
she
thought
that
Phineas
would
only
have
done
right
had
he
repeated
the
offence
which
he
had

under

.
  
<EOS>
"
Garrotted
!
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
,
when
Phineas

him
the
story
before
they
went
to
bed
that
night
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
smoking
,

brandy
-
and
-
water
,
and
waiting
for
Finn
's
return
.
"
<EOS>
Robert
Kennedy
garrotted
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
fellow
was
in
the
act
of
doing
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
stopped
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
I
got
there
just
in
time
.
<EOS>
Was
n't
it
lucky
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
ought
to
be
garrotted
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
lent
the
man
<EOS>
a
hand
had
I
been
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
you
say
anything
so
horrible
?
<EOS>
But
you
are
drinking
too
much
,
old
fellow
,
and
I
shall
lock

up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
there
were
no
one
in
London
drank
more
than
I

,
the
wine

would
have
a

.
<EOS>
And
so
the
new
Cabinet
Minister
has
been
garrotted
in

.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
'm

for
poor
Laura
's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Luckily
he
's
not

;
 
only

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder

's

the
cards
he

;
 
worse
,
except

,

.
<EOS>
However
,

's

-

,
I
'm

to

for

.
<EOS>
Come
,
I
'll
go
to
bed
.
<EOS>
I
must

,
if
he
was
to
be
garrotted
I
should
like
to
have

there
to

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That
was
the
manner
in
which
Lord
Chiltern
received
the
tidings
of
the
terrible
accident
which
had
occurred
to
his
near
relative
.
   
<EOS>
Finn
for
Loughton
 
<EOS>
By
three
o'clock
in
the
day
after
the
little
accident
which
was
told
in
the
last
chapter
,
all
the
world
knew
that
Mr.
Kennedy
,
the
new
Cabinet
Minister
,
had
been
garrotted
,
or
half

,
and
that
that
child
of
fortune
,
Phineas
Finn
,
had
dropped
upon
the
scene
out
of
heaven
at
the
exact
moment
of
time
,
had
taken
the
two
garrotters
prisoners
,
and
saved
the
Cabinet
Minister
's
neck
and
valuables
,
 
if
not
his
life
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Bedad
,
"
said
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
,
when
he
came
to
hear
this
,
"
that
fellow'll
marry
an
heiress
,
and
be
Secretary
for
Oireland
yet
.
<EOS>
"
A
good
deal
was
said
about
it
to

at
the

,
but
a
word

two
that

by
Violet
Effingham
was
worth
all

rest
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
a
Paladin
you
are
!
<EOS>
But
you
succour
men
in
distress
instead
of
maidens
.
"
<EOS>
"
That
's
my
bad
luck
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
The
other
will
come
no
doubt
in
time
,
"
Violet

;
"
and
then
you
'll
get

reward
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
knew
that
such
words
from
a
girl
mean
nothing
,
 
especially

such
a
girl
as
Violet
Effingham
;
but
nevertheless

were
very
pleasant

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
will
come
to
us
at
Loughlinter
when
Parliament
is
up
?
"
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
said
the
same
day
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
really
.
<EOS>
You
see
I
must
go
over
to
Ireland
about
my
re
-
election
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
has
that
to
do

?
<EOS>
You
are
only
making
out

.
<EOS>
We
go
down
on
the
first

July
,
and
the
English
elections
wo
n't
begin
till
the
middle

the
month
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
August
before
the
men
of
Loughshane
are
ready
for
you
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
tell
you
the
truth
,
Lady
Laura
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
I
doubt
whether
the
men
of
Loughshane
,
 
or
rather
the
man
of
Loughshane
,
will
have
anything
more
to
say
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
man
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lord
Tulla
.
<EOS>
He
was
in
a
passion
with
his
brother
before
,
and
I
got
the
advantage
of
it
.
<EOS>
Since
that
he
has
paid
his
brother
's
debts
for
the
fifteenth
time
,
and
of
course
is
ready
to
fight
any
battle
for
the
forgiven
prodigal
.
<EOS>
Things
are
not
as
they
were
,
and
my
father
tells
me
that
he
thinks
I
shall
be
beaten
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
bad
news
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
what
I
have
a
right
to
expect
.
"
  
<EOS>
Every
word
of
information
that
had
come
to
Phineas
about
Loughshane
since
Mr.
Mildmay
had
decided
upon
a
dissolution
,
had
gone
towards
making
him
feel
at
first
that
there
was
a
great
doubt
as
to
his
re
-
election
,
and
at
last
that
there
was
almost
a
certainty
against
him
.
<EOS>
And
as
these
tidings
reached
him
they
made
him
very
unhappy
.
<EOS>
Since
he
had
been
in
Parliament
he
had
very
frequently
regretted
that
he
had
left
the
shades
of
the
Inns
of
Court
for
the
glare
of
Westminster
;
and
he
had
more
than
once
made
up
his
mind
that
he
would
desert
the
glare
and
return
to
the
shade
.
<EOS>
But
now
,
when
the
moment
came
in
which
such
desertion
seemed
to
be
compulsory
on
him
,
when
there
would
be
no
longer
a
choice
,
the
seat
in
Parliament
was
dearer
to
him
than
ever
.
<EOS>
If
he
had
gone
of
his
own
free
will
,
 
so
he
told
himself
,
 
there
would
have
been
something
of
nobility
in
such
going
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
would
have
respected
him
,
and
even
Mrs.
Low
might
have
taken
him
back
to
the
friendship
of
her
severe
bosom
.
<EOS>
But
he
would
go
back
now
as
a
cur
with
his
tail
between
his
legs
,
 
kicked
out
,
as
it
were
,
from
Parliament
.
<EOS>
Returning
to
Lincoln
's
Inn
soiled
with
failure
,
having
accomplished
nothing
,
having
broken
down
on
the
only
occasion
on
which
he
had
dared
to
show
himself
on
his
legs
,
not
having
opened
a
single
useful
book
during
the
two
years
in
which
he
had
sat
in
Parliament
,
burdened
with
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
's
debt
,
and
not
quite
free
from
debt
of
his
own
,
how
could
he
start
himself
in
any
way
by
which
he
might
even
hope
to
win

?
<EOS>
He
must
,
he
told

,
give
up
all
thought
of
practising
in
London
and
betake
himself
to
Dublin
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
dare
to
face
his
friends
in
London
as
a
young
briefless
barrister
.
  
<EOS>
On
this

,
the

to
that
on
which
Mr.
Kennedy
had
been
attacked
,

was

in

of

,
and
there

on
a

as
to
a
certain

for

.
<EOS>
It
had
been
known
that

;
and
Mr.
Monk
having
heard
from

a

now

again
about

,
had
recommended

to

.
<EOS>
Phineas
did
so

,
having

in
the
Committee
Room
up

to

of

from
Holstein
would
not

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

had
made

without
the

to
the
former
failure
,
 
just
as

were
a
practised

three

.
<EOS>
"
If
I

,
I
will
,
"
said
Phineas
,
taking

just

.
  
<EOS>
Soon
after
prayers
,
a

in

House
as

ill
-

.
<EOS>
Mr.

had

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

;
but
that

,
 
<EOS>
and

<EOS>
,

;
 
"
<EOS>
As

,
"

,

;
 
<EOS>
"
By

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Then

"
name
;
"
and
Mr.
Mildmay
of
course
named

Loughshane
.
<EOS>
It
so
happened
that
Phineas
was
not
in
the
House
,
but
he
heard

all
when
he
came
down
to

and

.
  
<EOS>
Then
came
on
the
discussion
about
provisions
in
the
army
,
the
subject
being
mooted
by
one

Mr.
Turnbull
's

.
<EOS>
The

on
the

who
had

Potted

Committee
,
was
silent
on
the

,
having
felt
that

result
of
that
committee
had
not

.
<EOS>
The
evidence
respecting
such
of
the
Holstein
potted
peas
as
had
been
used
in
this
country
was
not
very

to

.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
the
rebound
from
that
committee
,
 
the

that
such
a
committee
had
been
made
to
sit
,
 
gave

for
a
hostile
attack
.
<EOS>
To
attack
is
so
easy
,
when
a
complete
refutation
barely
suffices
to
save
the
Minister
<EOS>
attacked
,
 
does
not

to
save
him
from
future
dim

of
something
having
been
wrong
,
 
and
brings
down
no

whatsoever
on
the
promoter
of
the
false
charge
.
<EOS>
The
promoter
of
the
false
charge
simply
expresses
his
gratification
at
finding
that
he
had
been
misled
by
erroneous
information
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
customary
for
him
to
express
gratification
at
the
fact
,
that
out
of
all
the
mud
which
he
has
thrown
,
some
will
probably
stick
!
<EOS>
Phineas
,
when
the
time
came
,
did
get
on
his
legs
,
and
spoke
perhaps
two
or
three
dozen
words
.
<EOS>
The
doing
so
seemed
to
come
to
him
quite
naturally
.
<EOS>
He
had
thought
very
little
about
it
beforehand
,
 
having
resolved
not
to
think
of
it
.
<EOS>
And
indeed
the
occasion
was
one
of
no
great
importance
.
<EOS>
The
Speaker
was
not
in
the
chair
,
and
the
House
was
thin
,
and
he
intended
to
make
no
speech
,
 
merely
to
say
something
which
he
had
to
say
.
<EOS>
Till
he
had
finished
he
hardly
remembered
that
he
was
doing
that
,
in
attempting
to
do
which
he
had
before
failed
so
egregiously
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
till
he
sat
down
that
he
began
to
ask
himself
whether
the
scene
was
swimming
before
his
eyes
as

had
done
on
former
occasions
;
as
it
had
done
even
when
he
had
so
much
as

of
making

.
<EOS>
Now
he
was
astonished
at
the
easiness
of
the
thing
,
and
as
he
left
the
House
told
himself
that
he
had
overcome
the
difficulty
just
when
the
victory
could
be
of
no
avail
to
him
.
<EOS>
Had
he
been
more
eager
,
more
constant
in
his
purpose
,
he
might
at
any
rate
have
shown
the
world
that
he
was
fit
for
the
place
which
he
had
presumed
to
take
before
he
was
cast
out
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
next
morning
he
received
a
letter
from
his
father
.
<EOS>
Dr.
Finn
had
seen
Lord
Tulla
,
having
been
sent
for
to
relieve
his
lordship
in
a
fit
of
the
gout
,
and
had
been
informed
by
the
Earl
that
he
meant
to
fight
the
borough
to
the
last
man
;
 
<EOS>
had
he
said
to
the
last
shilling
he
would
have
spoken
with
perhaps
more
accuracy
.
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
doctor
,
your
son
has
had
it
for
two
years
,
as
you
may
say
for
nothing
,
and
I

ought

.
<EOS>
He
ca
n't
expect
that
he
's
to
go
on
there
as

own
.
"
<EOS>
And

his

,

of

come

,
expressed

with

.
<EOS>
The
old
doctor
behaved
with
much
spirit
.
<EOS>
"
I
told
the
Earl
,
"
he

,
"
that
I

not

to

;
but
that

you
had
come
forward

first

,
I
could

.
<EOS>
He
asked
me
if
I
should
support
you
with

;
I
said
that
I

to
a

.
"
<EOS>
By
G
 
,
"
said
the
Earl
,
"
a
moderate
extent
will
go
a

little
way
,
I

.
"
<EOS>
Since
that
he
has
had
Duggin
with

;
so
,
I

,
I
shall
not

.
<EOS>
You

do
as
you
please
now
;
but
,
from
what
I
hear
,
I
fear
you
will
have
no
chance
.
"
<EOS>
Then
with
much
bitterness
of
spirit
Phineas
resolved
that
he
would
not
interfere
with
Lord
Tulla
at
Loughshane
.
<EOS>
He
would
go
at
once
to
the
Reform
Club
and
explain
his
reasons
to
Barrington
Erle
and
others
there
who
would
be
interested
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
first
went
to
Grosvenor
Place
.
<EOS>
Here
he
was
shown
up
into
Mr.
Kennedy
's
room
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
was
up
and
seated
in
an
arm
-
chair
by
an
open
window
looking
over
into
the
Queen
's
garden
;
but
he
was
in
his
dressing
-
gown
,
and
was
to
be
regarded
as
an
invalid
.
<EOS>
And
indeed
as
he
could
not
turn
his
neck
,
or
thought
that
he
could
not
do
so
<EOS>
,
he
was
not
very
fit
to
go
out
about
his
work
.
<EOS>
Let
us
hope
that
the
affairs
of
the
Duchy
of
Lancaster
did
not
suffer

by
his

.
<EOS>
We
may
take
it
for
granted
that
<EOS>
with
a
man
so
sedulous
as
to
all
his
duties
there
was
no
arrear
of
work
when
the
accident
took
place
.
<EOS>
He
put
out
his
hand
to
Phineas
,
and
said
some
word
in
a

,
 
some
word
or
two
among
which
Phineas
caught
the
sound
of
"
potted
peas
,
"
 
and
then
continued
to
look
out
of
the
window
.
<EOS>
There
are
men
who
are
utterly
prostrated
by
any
bodily
ailment
,
and
it
seemed
that
Mr.
Kennedy
was
one
of
them
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
was
full
of
his
own
bad
news
,
had
intended
to
tell
his
sad
story
at
once
.
<EOS>
But
he
perceived
that
the
neck
of
the
Chancellor
of
the
Duchy
was
too
stiff
to
allow
of
his
taking
any
interest
in
external

,
and
so
he
refrained
.
<EOS>
"
What
does
the
doctor
say
about
it
?
"
said
Phineas
,
perceiving
that
just
for
the
present
there
could

only
one

for

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
was
beginning
to
describe
in
a
long

what
the
doctor
did
think
about
it
,
when
Lady
Laura
came
into

.
  
<EOS>
Of
course
they
began
at
first
to
talk
about
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
It
would
not
have
been
kind
to
him
not
to

.
<EOS>
And
Lady
Laura
made
much
of
the
injury
,
as
it
behoves
a
wife
to
do
in
such
circumstances
for
the
sake
both
of
the
sufferer
and
of
the
hero
.
<EOS>
She
declared
her
conviction
<EOS>
that
had
Phineas
been
a
moment
later
her
husband
's
neck
would
have
been
irredeemably
broken
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
they
ever
do
kill
the
people
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
they
do
n't

to
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
they
did
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
fancy
not
,
"
said
Phineas
,
eager
in
the
cause
of
truth
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
this
man
was
very
clumsy
,
"
whispered
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
he
was
a
beginner
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
and
that
may
make
a
difference
.
<EOS>
If
so
,
I
'm
afraid
we
have
interfered
with
his
education
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
,
by
degrees
,
the
conversation
got
away
to
other
things
,
and
Lady
Laura
asked
him
after
Loughshane
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
made
up
my
mind
to
give
it
up
,
"
said
he
,
smiling
as
he
spoke
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
afraid
there
was
but
a
bad
chance
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
smiling
also
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
father
has
behaved
so
well
!
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
He
has
written
to
say
he
'll
find
the
money
,
if
I
determine
to
contest
the
borough
.
<EOS>
I
mean
to
write
to
him
by
to
-
night
's
post
to
decline
the
offer
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
right
to
spend
the
money
,
and
I
should
n't
succeed
if
I
did
spend
it
.
<EOS>
Of
course
it
makes
me
a
little
down
in
the
mouth
.
"
<EOS>
And
then
he
smiled
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
got
a
plan
of
my
own
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
plan
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Or
rather
it
is
n't
mine
,
but
papa
's
.
<EOS>
Old
Mr.
Standish
is
going
to
give
up
Loughton
,
and
papa
wants
you
to
come
and
try
your
luck
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lady
Laura
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
n't
quite
a
certainty
,
you
know
,
but
I
suppose
it
's
as
near
a
certainty
as
anything
left
.
"
<EOS>
And
this
came
from
a
strong
Radical
Reformer
!
  
<EOS>
"
Lady
Laura
,
I
could
n't
accept
such
a
favour
from
your
father
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Kennedy
nodded
his
head
very

and
whispered
,
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
think
of
it
,
"
said
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
right
to
such
a
favour
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
a
matter
entirely
for
papa
's
consideration
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
with
an
affectation
of

in

.
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
has
always
been

that
any

may

as

when

,

.
<EOS>
My

to

with

in
the
borough
,
and
therefore

comes
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
n't
that
,
"
said
Phineas
,
somewhat
rudely
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
private
feelings
have
their
weight
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
probable
that
papa
would
have
gone
to
a
perfect

.
<EOS>
And
perhaps
,
Mr.
Finn
,
I
may

Mr.
Kennedy

,
and
that
that

on
our

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
'll
stand
?
"
whispered
Mr.
Kennedy
,
still
looking
straight
out
of
the
window
,
as
though
the
slightest
attempt
to
turn
his
neck
would
be

danger
to
himself
and
the
Duchy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Papa
has
desired
me
to
ask
you
to
call
upon
him
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
suppose
there
is
very
much
to
be
said
,
as
each
of
you
know
<EOS>
so
well
the
other
's
way
of
thinking
.
<EOS>
But
you
had
better
see
him
to
-
day
or
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Of
course
Phineas
was
persuaded
before
he
left
Mr.
Kennedy
's
room
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
when
he
came
to
think
of
it
,
there
appeared
to
him
to
be
no
valid
reason
why
he
should
not
sit
for
Loughton
.
<EOS>
The
favour
was
of
a
kind
that
had
prevailed
from
time
out
of
mind
in
England
,
between
the
most
respectable
of
the
great
land
magnates
,
and
young
rising
liberal
politicians
.
<EOS>
Burke
,
Fox
,
and
Canning
had
all
been
placed
in
Parliament
by
similar
influence
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
,
Phineas
Finn
,
desired
earnestly
,
 
longed
in
his
very
heart
of
hearts
,
 
to
extinguish
all
such
Parliamentary
influence
,
to
root
out
for
ever
the
last
vestige
of
close
borough
nominations
;
but
while
the
thing
remained
it
was
better
that
the
thing
should
contribute
to
the
liberal
than
to
the
conservative
strength
of
the
House
,
 
and
if
to
the
liberal
<EOS>
,
how
was
this
to
be
achieved
but
by
the
acceptance
of
such
influence
by
some
liberal
candidate
?
<EOS>
And
if
it
were
right
that
it
should
be
accepted
by
any
liberal
candidate
,
 
then
,
why
not
by
him
?
<EOS>
The
logic
of
this
argument
seemed
to
him
to
be
perfect
.
<EOS>
He
felt
something
like
a
sting
of
reproach
as
he
told
himself
that
in
truth
this
great
offer
was
made
to
him
,
not
on
account
of
the
excellence
of
his
politics
,
but
because
he
had
been
instrumental
in
saving
Lord
Brentford
's
son
-
in
-
law
from
the
violence
of
garrotters
.
<EOS>
But
he
crushed
these
qualms
of
conscience
as
being
over
-
scrupulous
,
and
,
as
he
told
himself
,
not
practical
.
<EOS>
You
must
take
the
world
as
you
find
it
,
with
a
struggle
to
be
something
more
honest
than
those
around
you
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
as
he
preached
to
himself
this
sermon
,
declared
to
himself
that
they
who
attempted
more
than
this
flew
too
high
in
the
clouds
to
be
of
service
to
men
and
women
upon
earth
.
  
<EOS>
As
he
did
not
see
Lord
Brentford
that
day
he
postponed
writing
to
his
father
for
twenty
-
four
hours
.
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
he
found
the
Earl
at
home
in
Portman
Square
,
having
first
discussed
the
matter
fully
with
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
Do
not
scruple
about
me
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
;
"
you
are
quite
welcome
to
the
borough
for
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
if
I
did
not
stand
,
would
you
do
so
?
<EOS>
There
are
so
many
reasons
which
ought
to
induce
you
to
accept
a
seat
in
Parliament
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whether
that
be
true
or
not
,
Phineas
,
I
shall
not
accept
my
father
's
interest
at
Loughton
,
unless
it
be
offered
to
me
in
a
way
in
which
it
never
will
be
offered
.
<EOS>
You
know
me
well
enough
to
be
sure
that
I
shall
not
change

.
<EOS>
Nor
will
he
.
<EOS>
And
,
therefore
,
you
may
go
down
to
Loughton
with
a
pure
conscience
as
far
as
I
am
concerned
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
had
his
interview
with
the
Earl
,
and
in
ten
minutes
everything
was
settled
.
<EOS>
On
his
way
to
Portman
Square
there
had
come
across
his
mind
the
idea
of
a
grand
effort
of
friendship
.
<EOS>
What
if
he
could
persuade
the
father
so
to
conduct
himself
towards
his
son
,
that
the
son
should
consent
to
be
a
member
for
the
borough
?
<EOS>
And
he
did
say
a
word
or
two
to
this
effect
,
setting
forth
that
Lord
Chiltern
would
condescend
to
become
a

,
if
only

father
would
condescend
to
acknowledge
his
son
's
fitness
for
such
work
without
any
comments
on
the
son
's
past
life
.
<EOS>
But
the
Earl
simply
waived
the
subject
away
with
his
hand
.
<EOS>
He
could
be
as
obstinate
as
his
son
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
had
been
the
Mercury
between
them
on
this
subject
,
and
Lady
Laura
had
failed
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
now
consent
to
employ
another
Mercury
.
<EOS>
Very
little
,
 
hardly
a
word
<EOS>
indeed
,
 
was
said
between
the
Earl
and
Phineas
about
politics
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
to
be
the
Saulsby
candidate
at
Loughton
for
the
next
election
,
and
was
to
come
to
Saulsby
with
the
Kennedys
from
Loughlinter
,
 
either
with
the
Kennedys
or
somewhat
in

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
say
that
there
will

no

,
"
said
the
Earl
,
"
but
I
expect
none
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
was
very
courteous
,
 
nay
,
he
was
kind
,
feeling
doubtless
that
his
family
owed
a
great
debt
of

to
the
young
man
with

was

;
but
,

,
there

a

that

which
,

,
might
be
thought
to
become
the
Earl
,
the
Cabinet

,
and
the
great
borough

.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
was
sensitive
,
felt
this
and
winced
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
quite
liked
Lord
Brentford
,
and
could
not
bring
himself
to
do
so
now
in
spite
of
the
kindness
which
the
Earl
was
showing

.
  
<EOS>
But
he
was
very
happy
when
he
sat
down
to
write
to
his
father
from
the
club
.
<EOS>
His
father
had
told

that
the
money
should
be
forthcoming
for
the
election
at
Loughshane
,
if
he
resolved
to
stand
,
but
that
the
chance
of
success
would
be
very
slight
,
 
indeed
that
,
in
his
opinion
,
there
would
be
no
chance
of
success
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
his
father
had
evidently
believed
,
when
writing
,
that
Phineas
would
not
abandon
his
seat
without
a
useless
and
expensive
contest
.
<EOS>
He
now
thanked
his
father
with
many

of
gratitude
,
 
declared
his
conviction
that
his
father
was
right
about
Lord
Tulla
,
and
then
,
in
the
most
modest
language
that
he
could
use
,
went
on
to
say
that
he
had
found
another
borough
open
to
him
in
England
.
<EOS>
He
was
going
to
stand
for
Loughton
,
with
the
assistance
of
Lord
Brentford
,
and
thought
that
the
election
would
probably
not
cost
him
above
a
couple
of
hundred
pounds
at
the
outside
.
<EOS>
Then
he
wrote
a
very
pretty
note
to
Lord
Tulla
,
thanking
him
for
his
former
kindness
,
and
telling
the
Irish
Earl
that
it
was
not
his
intention
to
interfere
with
the
borough
of
Loughshane
at
the
next
election
.
  
<EOS>
A
few
days
after
this
Phineas
was
very
much
surprised
at
a
visit
that
was
made
to
him
at
his
lodgings
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Clarkson
,
after
that
scene
in
the
lobby
of
the
House
,
called
again
in
Great
Marlborough
Street
,
 
and
was
admitted
.
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
let
him
sit
in
your
armchair
for
half
an
hour
or
so
,
"
Fitzgibbon
had
said
;
and
Phineas
almost
believed
that
it
would
be
better
.
<EOS>
The
man
was
a
terrible
nuisance
to
him
,
and
he
was
beginning
to
think
that
he
had
better
undertake
to
pay
the
debt
by
degrees
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
he
knew
,
quite
on
the
cards
that
Mr.
Clarkson
should
have
him
arrested
while
at
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
Since
that
scene
in
the
lobby
Mr.
Clarkson
had
been
with
him
twice
,
and
there
had
been
a
preliminary
conversation
as
to
real
payment
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Clarkson
wanted
a
hundred
pounds
down
,
and
another
bill
for
two
hundred
and
twenty
at
three
months
'
date
.
<EOS>
"
Think
of
my
time
and
trouble
in
coming
here
,
"
Mr.
Clarkson
had
urged
when
Phineas
had
objected
to
these
terms
.
<EOS>
"
Think
of
my
time
and
trouble
,
and
do
be
punctual
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
had
offered
him
ten
pounds
a
quarter
,
the
payments
to
be
marked
on
the
back
of
the
bill
,
a
tender
which
Mr.
Clarkson
had
not
seemed
to
regard
as
strong
evidence
of
punctuality
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
angry
,
but
had
simply
expressed
his
intention
of
calling
again
,
 
giving
Phineas
to
understand
that
business
would
probably
take
him
to
the
west
of
Ireland
in
the
autumn
.
<EOS>
If
only
business
might
not
take
him
down
either
to
Loughlinter
or
to
Saulsby
!
<EOS>
But
the
strange
visitor
who
came
to
Phineas
in
the
midst
of
these
troubles
put
an
end
to
them
all
.
  
<EOS>
The
strange
visitor
was
Miss
Aspasia
Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
"
You
'll
be
very
much
surprised
at
my
coming
to
your
chambers
,
no
doubt
,
"
she
said
,
as
she
sat
down
in
the
chair
which
Phineas
placed
for
her
.
<EOS>
Phineas
could
only
say
that
he
was
very
proud
to
be
so
highly
honoured
,
and
that
he
hoped
she
was
well
.
"
<EOS>
Pretty
well
,
I
thank
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
just
come
about
a
little
business
,
Mr.
Finn
,
and
I
hope
you
'll
excuse
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
quite
sure
that
there
is
no
need
for

,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Laurence
,
when
he
hears
about
it
,
will
say
that
I
've
been
an
impertinent
old
fool
;
but
I
never
care
what
Laurence
says
,
either
this
way
or
that
.
<EOS>
I
've
been
to
that
Mr.
Clarkson
,
Mr.
Finn
,
and
I
've
paid
him
the
money
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
have
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
I
happened
to
hear
what
occurred
that
night
at
the
door
of
the
House
of
Commons
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
told
you
,
Miss
Fitzgibbon
?
"
  
"
Never
mind
who
told
me
.
<EOS>
I
heard
it
.
<EOS>
I
knew
before
that
you
had
been
foolish
enough
to
help
Laurence
about
money
,
and
so
I
put
two
and
two
together
.
<EOS>
It
is
n't
the
first

I
have
had
to
do

Mr.
Clarkson
.
<EOS>
So
I
sent
to
him
,
and
I
've
bought
the
bill
.
<EOS>
There
it
is
.
"
<EOS>
And
Miss
Fitzgibbon
produced
the
document
which
bore
the
name
of
Phineas
Finn
across
the
front
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
did
you
pay
him
two
hundred
and
fifty
pounds
for

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
quite
.
<EOS>
I
had
a
very
hard
tussle
,
and
got
it
at
last
for
two
hundred
and
twenty
pounds
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
did
you
do
it
yourself
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
All
myself
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
employed
a
lawyer
I
should
have
had
to
pay
two

and
forty
pounds
and
five
pounds
for
