.
<EOS>
And
now
,
Mr.
Finn
,
I
hope
you
wo
n't
have
any
more
money
engagements
with
my
brother
Laurence
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
said
that
he
thought
he
might
promise
that
he
would
have
no
more
.
"
<EOS>
Because
,
if
you
do
,
I
sha
n't
interfere
.
<EOS>
If
Laurence
began
to
find
that
he
could
get
money
out
of
me
in
that
way
,
there
would
be
no
end
to
it
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Clarkson
would
very
soon
be
spending
his
spare
time
in
my
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
If
Laurence
says
anything
,
just
tell
him
that
he
'd
better
come
to
me
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
was
left
looking
at
the
bill
.
<EOS>
It
was
certainly
a
great
relief
to
him
,
 
that
he
should
be
thus
secured
from
the
domiciliary
visits
of
Mr.
Clarkson
;
a
great
relief
to
him
to
be
assured
that
Mr.
Clarkson
would
not
find
him
out
down
at
Loughton
;
but
nevertheless
,
he
had
to
suffer
a
pang
of
shame
as
he
felt
that
Miss
Fitzgibbon
had
become
acquainted
with
his
poverty
and
had
found
herself
obliged
to
satisfy
his
pecuniary
liabilities
.
   
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
's
Headache
 
Phineas
went
down
to
Loughlinter
early
in
July
,
taking
Loughton
in
his
way
.
<EOS>
He
stayed
there
one
night
at
the
inn
,
and
was
introduced
to
sundry
influential
inhabitants
of
the
borough
by
Mr.
Grating
,
the
ironmonger
,
who
was
known
by
those
who
knew
Loughton
to
be
a
very
strong
supporter
of
the
Earl
's
interest
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grating
and
about
half
a
dozen
others
of
the
tradesmen
of
the
town
came
to
the
inn
,
and
met
Phineas
in
the
parlour
.
<EOS>
He
told
them
he
was
a
good
sound
Liberal
and
a
supporter
of
Mr.
Mildmay
's
Government
,
of
which
their
neighbour
the
Earl
was
so
conspicuous
an
ornament
.
<EOS>
This
was
almost
all
that
was
said
about
the
Earl
out
loud
;
but
each
individual
man
of
Loughton
then
present
took
an
opportunity
during
the
meeting
of
whispering
into
Mr.
Finn
's
ear
a
word
or
two
to
show
that
he
also
was
admitted
to
the
secret
councils
of
the
borough
,
 
that
he
too
could
see
the
inside
of
the
arrangement
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
we
must
support
the
Earl
,
"
one
said
.
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
what
you
hear
about
a
Tory
candidate
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
whispered
a
second
;
"
the
Earl
can
do
what
he
pleases
here
.
"
<EOS>
And
it
seemed
to
Phineas
that
it
was
thought
by
them
all
to
be
rather
a
fine
thing
to
be
thus
held
in
the
hand
by
an
English
nobleman
.
<EOS>
Phineas
could
not
but
reflect
much
upon
this
as
he
lay
in
his
bed
at
the
Loughton
inn
.
<EOS>
The
great
political
question
on
which
the
political
world
was
engrossed
up
in
London
was
the
enfranchisement
of
Englishmen
,
 
of
Englishmen
down
to
the
rank
of
artisans
and
labourers
;
 
and
yet
when
he
found
himself
in
contact
with
individual
Englishmen
,
with
men
even
very
much
above
the
artisan
and
the
labourer
,
he
found
that
they
rather
liked
being
bound
hand
and
foot
,
and
being
kept
as
tools
in
the
political
pocket
of
a
rich
man
.
<EOS>
Every
one
of
those
Loughton
tradesmen
was
proud
of
his
own
personal
subjection
to
the
Earl
!
  
<EOS>
From
Loughton
he
went
to
Loughlinter
,
having
promised
to
be
back
in
the
borough
for
the
election
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grating
would
propose
him
,
and
he
was
to
be
seconded
by
Mr.
Shortribs
,
the
butcher
and
grazier
.
<EOS>
Mention
had
been
made
of
a
Conservative
candidate
,
and
Mr.
Shortribs
had
seemed
to
think
that
a
good
stand
-
up
fight
upon
English
principles
,
with
a
clear
understanding
,
of
course
,
that
victory
should
prevail
on
the
liberal
side
,
would
be
a
good
thing
for
the
borough
.
<EOS>
But
the
Earl
's
man
of
business
saw
Phineas
on
the
morning
of
his
departure
,
and
told
him
not
to
regard
Mr.
Shortribs
.
<EOS>
"
They
'd
all
like
it
,
"
said
the
man
of
business
;
"
<EOS>
and
I
daresay
they
'll
have
enough
of
it
when
this
Reform
Bill
is
passed
;
but
at
present
no
one
will
be
fool
enough
to
come
and
spend
his
money
here
.
<EOS>
We
have
them
all
in
hand
too
well
for
that
,
Mr.
Finn
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
found
the
great
house
at
Loughlinter
nearly
empty
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
's
mother
was
there
,
and
Lord
Brentford
was
there
,
and
Lord
Brentford
's
private
secretary
,
and
Mr.
Kennedy
's
private
secretary
.
<EOS>
At
present
that
was
the
entire
party
.
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
was
expected
there
,
with
her
daughter
and
Violet
Effingham
;
but
,
as
well
as
Phineas
could
learn
,
they
would
not
be
at
Loughlinter
until
after
he
had
left
it
.
<EOS>
There
had
come
up
lately
a
rumour
that
there
would
be
an
autumn
session
,
 
that
the
Houses
would
sit
through
October
and
a
part
of
November
,
in
order
that
Mr.
Mildmay
might
try
the
feeling
of
the
new
Parliament
.
<EOS>
If
this
were
to
be
so
,
Phineas
had
resolved
that
,
in
the
event
of
his
election
at
Loughton
,
he
would
not
return
to
Ireland
till
after
this
autumn
session
should
be
over
.
<EOS>
He
gave
an
account
to
the
Earl
,
in
the
presence
of
the
Earl
's
son
-
in
-
law
,
of
what
had
taken
place
at
Loughton
,
and
the
Earl
expressed
himself
as
satisfied
.
<EOS>
It
was
manifestly
a
great
satisfaction
to
Lord
Brentford
that
he
should
still
have
a
borough
in
his
pocket
,
and
the
more
so
because
there
were
<EOS>
so
very
few
noblemen
left
who
had
such
property
belonging
to
them
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
careful
in
his
speech
,
never
saying
in
so
many
words
that
the
privilege
of
returning
a
member
was
his
own
;
but
his
meaning
was
not
the
less
clear
.
  
<EOS>
Those
were
dreary
days
at
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
There
was
fishing
,
 
if
Phineas
chose
to
fish
;
and
he
was
told
that
he
could
shoot
a
deer
if
he
was
minded
to
go
out
alone
.
<EOS>
But
it
seemed
as
though
it
were
the
intention
of
the
host
that
his
guests
should
spend
their
time
profitably
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
himself
was
shut
up
with
books
and
papers
all
the
morning
,
and
always
took
up
a
book
after
dinner
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
also
would
read
a
little
,
 
and
then
would
sleep
a
good
deal
.
<EOS>
Old
Mrs.
Kennedy
slept
also
,
and
Lady
Laura
looked
as
though
she
would
like
to
sleep
if
it
were
not
that
her
husband
's
eye
was
upon
her
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
she
administered
tea
,
Mr.
Kennedy
not
liking
the
practice
of
having
it
handed
round
by
a
servant
when
none
were
there
but
members
of
the
family
circle
,
and
she
read
novels
.
<EOS>
Phineas
got
hold
of
a
stiff
bit
of
reading
for
himself
,
and
tried
to
utilise
his
time
.
<EOS>
He
took
Alison
in
hand
,
and
worked
his
way
gallantly
through
a
couple
of
volumes
.
<EOS>
But
even
he
,
more
than
once
or
twice
,
found
himself
on
the
very
verge
of
slumber
.
<EOS>
Then
he
would
wake
up
and
try
to
think
about
things
.
<EOS>
Why
was
he
,
Phineas
Finn
,
an
Irishman
from
Killaloe
,
living
in
that
great
house
of
Loughlinter
as
though
he
were
one
of
the
family
,
striving
to
kill
the
hours
,
and
feeling
that
he
was
in
some
way
subject
to
the
dominion
of
his
host
?
<EOS>
Would
it
not
be
better
for
him
to
get
up
and
go
away
?
<EOS>
In
his
heart
of
hearts
he
did
not
like
Mr.
Kennedy
,
though
he
believed
him
to
be
a
good
man
.
<EOS>
And
of
what
service
to
him
was
it
to
like
Lady
Laura
,
now
that
Lady
Laura
was
a
possession
in
the
hands
of
Mr.
Kennedy
?
<EOS>
Then
he
would
tell
himself
that
he
owed
his
position
in
the
world
entirely
to
Lady
Laura
,
and
that
he
was
ungrateful
to
feel
himself
ever
dull
in
her
society
.
<EOS>
And
,
moreover
,
there
was
something
to
be
done
in
the
world
beyond
making
love
and
being
merry
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
could
occupy
himself
with
a
blue
book
for
hours
together
without
wincing
.
<EOS>
So
Phineas
went
to
work
again
with
his
Alison
,
and
read
away
till
he
nodded
.
  
<EOS>
In
those
days
he
often
wandered
up
and
down
the
Linter
and
across
the
moor
to
the
Linn
,
and
so
down
to
the
lake
.
<EOS>
He
would
take
a
book
with
him
,
and
would
seat
himself
down
on
spots
which
he
loved
,
and
would
pretend
to
read
;
 
but
I
do
not
think
that
he
got
much
advantage
from
his
book
.
<EOS>
He
was
thinking
of
his
life
,
and
trying
to
calculate
whether
the
wonderful
success
which
he
had
achieved
would
ever
be
of
permanent
value
to
him
.
<EOS>
Would
he
be
nearer
to
earning
his
bread
when
he
should
be
member
for
Loughton
than
he
had
been
when
he
was
member
for
Loughshane
?
<EOS>
Or
was
there
before
him
any
slightest
probability
that
he
would
ever
earn
his
bread
?
<EOS>
And
then
he
thought
of
Violet
Effingham
,
and
was
angry
with
himself
for
remembering
at
that
moment
that
Violet
Effingham
was
the
mistress
of
a
large
fortune
.
  
<EOS>
Once
before
when
he
was
sitting
beside
the
Linter
he
had
made
up
his
mind
to
declare
his
passion
to
Lady
Laura
;
 
and
he
had
done
so
on
the
very
spot
.
<EOS>
Now
,
within
a
twelvemonth
of
that
time
,
he
made
up
his
mind
on
the
same
spot
to
declare
his
passion
to
Miss
Effingham
,
and
he
thought
his
best
mode
of
carrying
his
suit
would
be
to
secure
the
assistance
of
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
,
no
doubt
,
had
been
very
anxious
that
her
brother
should
marry
Violet
;
but
Lord
Chiltern
,
as
Phineas
knew
,
had
asked
for
Violet
's
hand
twice
in
vain
;
and
,
moreover
,
Chiltern
himself
had
declared
to
Phineas
that
he
would
never
ask
for
it
again
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
,
who
was
always
reasonable
,
would
surely
perceive
that
there
was
no
hope
of
success
for
her
brother
.
<EOS>
That
Chiltern
would
quarrel
with
him
,
 
would
quarrel
with
him
to
the
knife
,
 
he
did
not
doubt
;
but
he
felt
that
no
fear
of
such
a
quarrel
as
that
should
deter
him
.
<EOS>
He
loved
Violet
Effingham
,
and
he
must
indeed
be
pusillanimous
if
,
loving
her
as
he
did
,
he
was
deterred
from
expressing
his
love
from
any
fear
of
a
suitor
whom
she
did
not
favour
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
willingly
be
untrue
to
his
friendship
for
Lady
Laura
's
brother
.
<EOS>
Had
there
been
a
chance
for
Lord
Chiltern
he
would
have
abstained
from
putting
himself
forward
.
<EOS>
But
what
was
the
use
of
his
abstaining
,
when
by
doing
so
he
could
in
no
wise
benefit
his
friend
,
 
when
the
result
of
his
doing
so
would
be
that
some
interloper
would
come
in
and
carry
off
the
prize
?
<EOS>
He
would
explain
all
this
to
Lady
Laura
,
and
,
if
the
prize
would
be
kind
to
him
,
he
would
disregard
the
anger
of
Lord
Chiltern
,
even
though
it
might
be
anger
to
the
knife
.
  
<EOS>
As
he
was
thinking
of
all
this
Lady
Laura
stood
before
him
where
he
was
sitting
at
the
top
of
the
falls
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
he
remembered
well
all
the
circumstances
of
the
scene
when
he
had
been
there
with
her
at
his
last
visit
to
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
How
things
had
changed
since
then
!
<EOS>
Then
he
had
loved
Lady
Laura
with
all
his
heart
,
and
he
had
now
already
brought
himself
to
regard
her
as
a
discreet
matron
whom
to
love
would
be
almost
as
unreasonable
as
though
he
were
to
entertain
a
passion
for
the
Lord
Chancellor
.
<EOS>
The
reader
will
understand
how
thorough
had
been
the
cure
effected
by
Lady
Laura
's
marriage
and
the
interval
of
a
few
months
,
when
the
swain
was
already
prepared
to
make
this
lady
the
depositary
of
his
confidence
in
another
matter
of
love
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
often
here
,
I
suppose
?
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
looking
down
upon
him
as
he
sat
upon
the
rock
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;
 
yes
;
not
very
often
;
I
come
here
sometimes
because
the
view
down
upon
the
lake
is
so
fine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
prettiest
spot
about
the
place
.
<EOS>
I
hardly
ever
get
here
now
.
<EOS>
Indeed
this
is
only
the
second
time
that
I
have
been
up
since
we
have
been
at
home
,
and
then
I
came
to
bring
papa
here
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
little
wooden
seat
near
to
the
rock
upon
which
Phineas
had
been
lying
,
and
upon
this
Lady
Laura
sat
down
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
with
his
eyes
turned
upon
the
lake
,
was
considering
how
he
might
introduce
the
subject
of
his
love
for
Violet
Effingham
;
but
he
did
not
find
the
matter
very
easy
.
<EOS>
He
had
just
resolved
to
begin
by
saying
that
Violet
would
certainly
never
accept
Lord
Chiltern
,
when
Lady
Laura
spoke
a
word
or
two
which
stopped
him
altogether
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
well
I
remember
,
"
she
said
,
"
the
day
when
you
and
I
were
here
last
autumn
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
do
I.
You
told
me
then
that
you
were
going
to
marry
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
How
much
has
happened
since
then
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
Much
indeed
!
<EOS>
Enough
for
a
whole
lifetime
.
<EOS>
And
yet
how
slow
the
time
has
gone
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
it
has
been
slow
with
me
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
you
have
been
active
.
<EOS>
You
have
had
your
hands
full
of
work
.
<EOS>
I
am
beginning
to
think
that
it
is
a
great
curse
to
have
been
born
a
woman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
yet
I
have
heard
you
say
that
a
woman
may
do
as
much
as
a
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
was
before
I
had
learned
my
lesson
properly
.
<EOS>
I
know
better
than
that
now
.
<EOS>
Oh
dear
!
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
it
is
all
for
the
best
as
it
is
,
but
I
have
a
kind
of
wish
that
I
might
be
allowed
to
go
out
and
milk
the
cows
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
may
you
not
milk
the
cows
if
you
wish
it
,
Lady
Laura
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
no
means
;
 
not
only
not
milk
them
,
but
hardly
look
at
them
.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
I
must
not
talk
about
them
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
of
course
understood
that
she
was
complaining
of
her
husband
,
and
hardly
knew
how
to
reply
to
her
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
sharp
enough
to
perceive
already
that
Mr.
Kennedy
was
an
autocrat
in
his
own
house
,
and
he
knew
Lady
Laura
<EOS>
well
enough
to
be
sure
that
such
masterdom
would
be
very
irksome
to
her
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
not
imagined
that
she
would
complain
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
so
different
at
Saulsby
,
"
Lady
Laura
continued
.
<EOS>
"
Everything
there
seemed
to
be
my
own
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
everything
here
is
your
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
 
according
to
the
prayer
-
book
.
<EOS>
And
everything
in
truth
is
my
own
,
 
as
all
the
dainties
at
the
banquet
belonged
to
Sancho
the
Governor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
mean
,
"
said
he
,
 
<EOS>
and
then
he
hesitated
;
"
you
mean
that
Mr.
Kennedy
stands
over
you
,
guarding
you
for
your
own
welfare
,
as
the
doctor
stood
over
Sancho
and
guarded
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
pause
before
she
answered
,
 
a
long
pause
,
during
which
he
was
looking
away
over
the
lake
,
and
thinking
how
he
might
introduce
the
subject
of
his
love
.
<EOS>
But
long
as
was
the
pause
,
he
had
not
begun
when
Lady
Laura
was
again
speaking
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
truth
is
,
my
friend
,
"
she
said
,
"
that
I
have
made
a
mistake
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
mistake
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Phineas
,
a
mistake
.
<EOS>
I
have
blundered
as
fools
blunder
,
thinking
that
I
was
clever
enough
to
pick
my
footsteps
<EOS>
aright
without
asking
counsel
from
any
one
.
<EOS>
I
have
blundered
and
stumbled
and
fallen
,
and
now
I
am
so
bruised
that
I
am
not
able
to
stand
upon
my
feet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
word
that
struck
him
most
in
all
this
was
his
own
Christian
name
.
<EOS>
She
had
never
called
him
Phineas
before
.
<EOS>
He
was
aware
that
the
circle
of
his
acquaintance
had
fallen
into
a
way
of
miscalling
him
by
his
Christian
name
,
as
one
observes
to
be
done
now
and
again
in
reference
to
some
special
young
man
.
<EOS>
Most
of
the
men
whom
he
called
his
friends
called
him
Phineas
.
<EOS>
Even
the
Earl
had
done
so
more
than
once
on
occasions
in
which
the
greatness
of
his
position
had
dropped
for
a
moment
out
of
his
mind
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Low
had
called
him
Phineas
when
she
regarded
him
as
her
husband
's
most
cherished
pupil
;
and
Mrs.
Bunce
had
called
him
Mr.
Phineas
.
<EOS>
He
had
always
been
Phineas
to
everybody
at
Killaloe
.
<EOS>
But
still
he
was
quite
sure
that
Lady
Laura
had
never
so
called
him
before
.
<EOS>
Nor
would
she
have
done
so
now
in
her
husband
's
presence
.
<EOS>
He
was
sure
of
that
also
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
mean
that
you
are
unhappy
?
"
he
said
,
still
looking
away
from
her
towards
the
lake
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
do
mean
that
.
<EOS>
Though
I
do
not
know
why
I
should
come
and
tell
you
so
,
 
except
that
I
am
still
blundering
and
stumbling
,
and
have
fallen
into
a
way
of
hurting
myself
at
every
step
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
tell
no
one
who
is
more
anxious
for
your
happiness
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
a
very
pretty
speech
,
but
what
would
you
do
for
my
happiness
?
<EOS>
Indeed
,
what
is
it
possible
that
you
should
do
?
<EOS>
I
mean
it
as
no
rebuke
when
I
say
that
my
happiness
or
unhappiness
is
a
matter
as
to
which
you
will
soon
become
perfectly
indifferent
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
say
so
,
Lady
Laura
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Because
it
is
natural
that
it
should
be
so
.
<EOS>
You
and
Mr.
Kennedy
might
have
been
friends
.
<EOS>
Not
that
you
will
be
,
because
you
are
unlike
each
other
in
all
your
ways
.
<EOS>
But
it
might
have
been
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
are
not
you
and
I
to
be
friends
?
"
he
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
<EOS>
In
a
very
few
months
you
will
not
think
of
telling
me
what
are
your
desires
or
what
your
sorrows
;
 
and
as
for
me
,
it
will
be
out
of
the
question
that
I
should
tell
mine
to
you
.
<EOS>
How
can
you
be
my
friend
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
were
not
quite
sure
of
my
friendship
,
Lady
Laura
,
you
would
not
speak
to
me
as
you
are
speaking
now
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Still
he
did
not
look
at
her
,
but
lay
with
his
face
supported
on
his
hands
,
and
his
eyes
turned
away
upon
the
lake
.
<EOS>
But
she
,
where
she
was
sitting
,
could
see
him
,
and
was
aided
by
her
sight
in
making
comparisons
in
her
mind
between
the
two
men
who
had
been
her
lovers
,
 
between
him
whom
she
had
taken
and
<EOS>
him
whom
she
had
left
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
the
hard
,
dry
,
unsympathising
,
unchanging
virtues
of
her
husband
which
almost
revolted
her
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
a
fault
,
but
she
had
tried
him
at
every
point
and
had
been
able
to
strike
no
spark
of
fire
from
him
.
<EOS>
Even
by
disobeying
she
could
produce
no
heat
,
 
only
an
access
of
firmness
.
<EOS>
How
would
it
have
been
with
her
had
she
thrown
all
ideas
of
fortune
to
the
winds
,
and
linked
her
lot
to
that
of
the
young
Phoebus
who
was
lying
at
her
feet
?
<EOS>
If
she
had
ever
loved
any
one
she
had
loved
him
.
<EOS>
And
she
had
not
thrown
away
her
love
for
money
.
<EOS>
So
she
swore
to
herself
over
and
over
again
,
trying
to
console
herself
in
her
cold
unhappiness
.
<EOS>
She
had
married
a
rich
man
in
order
that
she
might
be
able
to
do
something
in
the
world
;
 
and
now
that
she
was
this
rich
man
's
wife
she
found
that
she
could
do
nothing
.
<EOS>
The
rich
man
thought
it
to
be
quite
enough
for
her
to
sit
at
home
and
look
after
his
welfare
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
young
Phoebus
,
 
<EOS>
her
Phoebus
as
he
had
been
once
<EOS>
,
 
was
thinking
altogether
of
some
one
else
.
  
<EOS>
"
Phineas
,
"
she
said
,
slowly
,
"
I
have
in
you
such
perfect
confidence
that
I
will
tell
you
the
truth
;
 
as
one
man
may
tell
it
to
another
.
<EOS>
I
wish
you
would
go
from
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
at
once
?
"
  
"
Not
to
-
day
,
or
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Stay
here
now
till
the
election
;
but
do
not
return
.
<EOS>
He
will
ask
you
to
come
,
and
press
you
hard
,
and
will
be
hurt
;
 
for
,
strange
to
say
,
with
all
his
coldness
,
he
really
likes
you
.
<EOS>
He
has
a
pleasure
in
seeing
you
here
.
<EOS>
But
he
must
not
have
that
pleasure
at
the
expense
of
trouble
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
is
it
a
trouble
to
you
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
<EOS>
Men
are
such
fools
;
 
so
awkward
,
so
unready
,
with
their
wits
ever
behind
the
occasion
by
a
dozen
seconds
or
so
!
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
words
were
uttered
,
he
knew
that
they
should
not
have
been
spoken
.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
am
a
fool
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
Why
else
?
Is
not
that
enough
for
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Laura
 
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
 
no
;
I
will
have
none
of
that
.
<EOS>
I
am
a
fool
,
but
not
such
a
fool
as
to
suppose
that
any
cure
is
to
be
found
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Only
say
what
I
can
do
for
you
,
though
it
be
with
my
entire
life
,
and
I
will
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
do
nothing
,
 
except
to
keep
away
from
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
earnest
in
telling
me
that
?
"
<EOS>
Now
at
last
he
had
turned
himself
round
and
was
looking
at
her
,
and
as
he
looked
he
saw
the
hat
of
a
man
appearing
up
the
path
,
and
immediately
afterwards
the
face
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
hat
and
face
of
the
laird
of
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
"
Here
is
Mr.
Kennedy
,
"
said
Phineas
,
in
a
tone
of
voice
<EOS>
not
devoid
of
dismay
and
trouble
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
perceive
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
dismay
or
trouble
in
the
tone
of
her
voice
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
countenance
of
Mr.
Kennedy
,
as
he
approached
closer
,
there
was
not
much
to
be
read
,
 
only
,
perhaps
,
some
slight
addition
of
gloom
,
or
rather
,
perhaps
,
of
that
frigid
propriety
of
moral
demeanour
for
which
he
had
always
been
conspicuous
,
which
had
grown
upon
him
at
his
marriage
,
and
which
had
been
greatly
increased
by
the
double
action
of
being
made
a
Cabinet
Minister
and
being
garrotted
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
that
your
headache
is
better
,
"
he
said
to
his
wife
,
who
had
risen
from
her
seat
to
meet
him
.
<EOS>
Phineas
also
had
risen
,
and
was
now
looking
somewhat
sheepish
where
he
stood
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
came
out
because
it
was
worse
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
It
irritated
me
so
that
I
could
not
stand
the
house
any
longer
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
send
to
Callender
for
Dr.
Macnuthrie
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Pray
do
nothing
of
the
kind
,
Robert
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
want
Dr.
Macnuthrie
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
there
is
illness
,
medical
advice
is
always
expedient
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
ill
.
<EOS>
A
headache
is
not
illness
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
had
thought
it
was
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
,
very
drily
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
I
would
rather
not
have
Dr.
Macnuthrie
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
it
can
not
do
you
any
good
to
climb
up
here
in
the
heat
of
the
sun
.
<EOS>
Had
you
been
here
long
,
Finn
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
the
morning
;
 
here
,
or
hereabouts
.
<EOS>
I
clambered
up
from
the
lake
and
had
a
book
in
my
pocket
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
happened
to
come
across
him
by
accident
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
asked
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
so
simple
in
the
question
that
its
very
simplicity
proved
that
there
was
no
suspicion
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
by
chance
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
But
every
one
at
Loughlinter
always
comes
up
here
.
<EOS>
If
any
one
ever
were
missing
whom
I
wanted
to
find
,
this
is
where
I
should
look
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
on
towards
Linter
forest
to
meet
Blane
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
Blane
was
the
gamekeeper
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
mind
the
trouble
,
Finn
,
I
wish
you
'd
take
Lady
Laura
down
to
the
house
.
<EOS>
Do
not
let
her
stay
out
in
the
heat
.
<EOS>
I
will
take
care
that
somebody
goes
over
to
Callender
for
Dr.
Macnuthrie
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Kennedy
went
on
,
and
Phineas
was
left
with
the
charge
of
taking
Lady
Laura
back
to
the
house
.
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Kennedy
's
hat
had
first
appeared
coming
up
the
walk
,
Phineas
had
been
ready
to
proclaim
himself
prepared
for
any
devotion
in
the
service
of
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
had
begun
to
reply
with
criminal
tenderness
to
the
indiscreet
avowal
which
Lady
Laura
had
made
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
he
felt
now
,
after
what
had
just
occurred
in
the
husband
's
presence
,
that
any
show
of
tenderness
,
 
of
criminal
tenderness
,
 
was
impossible
.
<EOS>
The
absence
of
all
suspicion
on
the
part
of
Mr.
Kennedy
had
made
Phineas
feel
that
he
was
bound
by
all
social
laws
to
refrain
from
such
tenderness
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
began
to
descend
the
path
before
him
without
a
word
;
 
and
went
on
,
and
on
,
as
though
she
would
have
reached
the
house
without
speaking
,
had
he
not
addressed
her
.
"
<EOS>
Does
your
head
still
pain
you
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
does
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
he
is
right
in
saying
that
you
should
not
be
out
in
the
heat
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
worth
while
to
think
about
that
.
<EOS>
He
sends
me
in
,
and
so
of

I
must

.
<EOS>
And
he

to

,
and
so
of
course
you
must
take
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Would
you
wish
that
I
should
let

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I

.
<EOS>
Only

will

sure
to
find

out
;
and
you
must

that
you
left

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you

that
I

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
I
think
you
are
.
<EOS>
I

I

,

papa

;

his

soul
her

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Kennedy
is
nothing

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
something
to
me
,

so

go

.
<EOS>

with

,

take
Scotch
physic
,
 
which
seems
to
increase
in

and

as
doses
in

decrease
.
<EOS>
And
he
will
stand

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
;
 
the
doctor

Callender
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
but
Mr.
Kennedy
will
.
<EOS>
If
he
advised

to
have
a
hole
in
my
glove
<EOS>
mended
,
he
would

before

.
<EOS>
He
never

,
and

.
<EOS>
That
I

will
do
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
You

out
from

,
and

as

.
<EOS>
We

part

.
<EOS>
Remember

up

.
<EOS>
And

it
is
in

to
do

else

.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
he
turned
away
towards
the
lake
,
and
let
Lady
Laura
go
across
the
wide
lawn
to
the
house
by
herself
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
failed
altogether
in
his
intention
of
telling
his
friend
of
his
love
for
Violet
,
and
had
come
to

that

for

.
<EOS>
After

passed
it
would

for

to
go
to
Lady
Laura
with
a

of
his
longing
for
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
If
he
were
even
to
speak
to

of
love
at
all
,
it
must
be
quite
of
another
love
than
that
.
<EOS>
But
he
never
would
speak
to
her
of
love
;
nor
,
 
as
he
felt
quite
sure
,
 
would
she
allow
him
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
But
what
astounded
him
most
as
he
thought
of
the
interview
which
had
just
passed
,
was
the
fact
that
the
Lady
Laura
whom
he
had
known
,
 
whom

had
thought

had

,
 
should
have

so

to
such
a
man
as
Mr.
Kennedy
,
a
man
whom
he
had
despised
as
being

,

,
and
without

!
<EOS>
For
the
day
or
two
that
he

Loughlinter
,
he

the
family
closely
,
and
became
aware
that
Lady
Laura
had

when

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
follow

almost

,
"
said
the
Earl
confidentially
to

,
when

.
<EOS>
"
I
do

,

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
took

from
Mr.
Kennedy
,
with
a

of
friendship
on
the
part
of
his
host
,
and
from
Lady
Laura
with
a
mere
touch
of

hand
.
<EOS>
He
tried
to
say
a
word
;
but
she
was
sullen
,
or
,
if
not
,
she
put
on
some
mood
like
to
sullenness
,
and
said
never
a
word
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
day
after
the
departure
of
Phineas
Finn
for
Loughton
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
still
had
a
headache
.
<EOS>
She
had
complained
of
a
headache
ever
since
she
had
been
at
Loughlinter
,
and
Dr.
Macnuthrie
had
been
over
more
than
once
.
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
what
it
is
that
ails
you
,
"
said
her
husband
,
standing
over
her
in
her
own
sitting
-
room
up
-
stairs
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
pretty
room
,
looking
away
to
the
mountains
,
with
just
a
glimpse
of
the
lake
to
be
caught
from
the
window
,
and
it
had
been
prepared
for
her
with
all
the
skill
and
taste
of
an
accomplished
upholsterer
.
<EOS>
She
had
selected
the
room
for
herself
soon
after
her
engagement
,
and
had
thanked
her
future
husband
with
her
sweetest
smile
for
giving
her
the
choice
.
<EOS>
She
had
thanked
him
and
told
him
that
she
always
meant
to
be
happy
,
 
so
happy
in
that
room
!
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
not
much
given
to
romance
,
but
he
thought
of
this
promise
as
he
stood
over
her
and
asked
after
her
health
.
<EOS>
As
far
as
he
could
see
she
had
never
been
even
comfortable
since
she
had
been
at
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
A
shadow
of
the
truth
came
across
his
mind
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
his
wife
was
bored
.
<EOS>
If
so
,
what
was
to
be
the
future
of
his
life
and
of
hers
?
<EOS>
He
went
up
to
London
every
year
,
and
to
Parliament
,
as
a
duty
;
and
then
,
during
some
period
of
the
recess
,
would
have
his
house
full
of
guests
,
 
as
another
duty
.
<EOS>
But
his
happiness
was
to
consist
in
such
hours
as
these
which
seemed
to
inflict
upon
his
wife
the
penalty
of
a
continual
headache
.
<EOS>
A
shadow
of
the
truth
came
upon
him
.
<EOS>
What
if
his
wife
did
not
like
living
quietly
at
home
as
the
mistress
of
her
husband
's
house
?
<EOS>
What
if
a
headache
was
always
to
be
the
result
of
a
simple
performance
of

?
  
<EOS>
More
than
a
shadow
of
truth
had
come
upon
Lady
Laura
herself
.
<EOS>
The
dark
cloud
created
by
the
entire
truth
was
upon
her
,
making
everything
black
and
wretched
around
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
asked

a
question

,
and
had
discovered
that
she
had
no

for
her

,
that

which

from

was

to

,
and
that
she

and

in

upon

.
<EOS>
She
perceived
that
her
father
had
already

of
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
that
,
lonely

as
he
would

at
Saulsby
by

,
it
was
his
intention
to
repudiate
the
idea
of
making
a
home
at
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
Yes
;
 
she
would
be

by
everyone
,
except
of
course
by
her

;
and
then---
<EOS>
Then
she
would
throw
herself
on
some
early
morning
into
the
lake
,
for
life
would
be
insupportable
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
what
it
is
that
ails

,
"
said

Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing

.
<EOS>

ca

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

.

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

Macnuthrie
 
<EOS>
"
  
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

my

"
  
"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Headache

comes

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
What

,

?
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then

?
<EOS>
You
can

to

every

,
 
making

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is

?
<EOS>
"
she

,

.
"
<EOS>
Set

,

do

go

,
I
'll
get
through

.
<EOS>
There
are
the
account

.
<EOS>
Give

.
<EOS>
I
do

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Laura
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of

;

.
<EOS>
What

last

!
<EOS>
Oh

,
oh

!
<EOS>
what

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will

Macnuthrie

,
"

Kennedy
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
do
no
such

,
"
she

,
springing

and

before

.
<EOS>
"
If

comes
I
will

.
<EOS>
I

word
that
I
will
not
speak
to
him
if

.
<EOS>
You
do
not
understand
,
"
she

;
"
you
do
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
that
I
ought
to
understand
?
"
<EOS>
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
a
woman
does
not
like

be

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
made
no
reply
at
once
,
but
stood
there
twisting

of
the
door
,
and
collecting

.
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
he
at

;
"
I
am
beginning
to

out
;
 
and
to
find

also
what
it
is
that
bothers
a
woman
,
as
you
call
it
.
<EOS>
I
can
see
now
what
it
is
that
makes
your
head
ache
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
the
stomach
.
<EOS>
You
are
quite
right
there
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
prospect
of
a
quiet
decent
life
,
to

would
be

the
performance
of
certain

.
<EOS>
Dr.
Macnuthrie
is
a
learned

,

I
doubt

he
can
do
anything
for
such
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
right
,
Robert
;
he
can

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
malady
you

cure
for

,
Laura
;
 
and
which
is
to
be

by

.
<EOS>
If
you
can
bring

to
try
 
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
I
can
not

to

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

that
I

not

by

.
<EOS>
That

<EOS>

<EOS>
,

.
"
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>
He

for

,
and

left

room
without
another

.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Slide
's
Grievance
 
<EOS>
Our
hero
was
elected
member
for
Loughton
without
any
trouble
to
him
or
,
as
far
as
he
could
see
,
to
any
one
else
.
<EOS>
He
made
one
speech
from
a
small
raised
booth
that
was
called
a
platform
,
and
that
was
all
that
he
was
called
upon
to
do
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grating
made
a
speech
in
proposing
him
,
and
Mr.
Shortribs
another
in
seconding
him
;
and
these
were
all
the
speeches
that
were
required
.
<EOS>
The
thing
seemed
to
be
so
very
easy
that
he
was
afterwards
almost
offended
when
he
was
told
that
the
bill
for
so
insignificant
a
piece
of
work
came
to
£
247
13s
.
<EOS>
9d
.
<EOS>
He
had
seen
no
occasion
for
spending
even
the
odd
forty
-
seven
pounds
.
<EOS>
But
then
he
was
member
for
Loughton
;
and
as
he
passed
the
evening
alone
at
the
inn
,
having
dined
in
company
with
Messrs.
Grating
,
Shortribs
,
and
sundry
other
influential
electors
,
he
began
to
reflect
that
,
after
all
,
it
was
not
so
very
great
a
thing
to
be
a
member
of
Parliament
.
<EOS>
It
almost
seemed
that
that
which
had
come
to
him
so
easily
could
not
be
of
much
value
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
following
day
he
went
to
the
castle
,
and
was
there
when
the
Earl
arrived
.
<EOS>
They
two
were
alone
together
,
and
the
Earl
was
very
kind
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
So
you
had
no
opponent
after
all
,
"
said
the
great
man
of
Loughton
,
with
a
slight
smile
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
the
ghost
of
another
candidate
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
think
there
would
be
.
<EOS>
They
have
tried
it
once
or
twice
and
have
always
failed
.
<EOS>
There
are
only
one
or
two
in
the
place
who
like
to
go
one
way
just
because
their
neighbours
go
the
other
.
<EOS>
But
,
in
truth
,
there
is
no
conservative
feeling
in
the
place
!
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
although
he
was
at
the
present
moment
the
member
for
Loughton
himself
,
could
not
but
enjoy
the
joke
of
this
.
<EOS>
Could
there
be
any
liberal
feeling
in
such
a
place
,
or
,
indeed
,
any
political
feeling
whatsoever
?
<EOS>
Would
not
Messrs.
Grating
and
Shortribs
have
done
just
the
same
<EOS>
had
it
happened
that
Lord
Brentford
had
been
a
Tory
peer
?
<EOS>
"
They
all
seemed
to
be
very
obliging
,
"
said
Phineas
,
in
answer
to
the
Earl
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
they
are
.
<EOS>
There
is
n't
a
house
in
the
town
,
you
know
,
let
for
longer
than
seven
years
,
and
most
of
them
merely
from
year
to
year
.
<EOS>
And
,
do
you
know
,
I
have
n't
a
farmer
on
the
property
with
a
lease
,
 
not
one
;
and
they
do
n't
want
leases
.
<EOS>
They
know
they
're
safe
.
<EOS>
But
I
do
like
the
people
round
me
to
be
of
the
same
way
of
thinking
as
myself
about
politics
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
On
the
second
day
after
dinner
,
 
the
last
evening
of
Finn
's
visit
to
Saulsby
,
 
the
Earl
fell
suddenly
into
a
confidential
conversation
about
his
daughter
and
his
son
,
and
about
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
So
sudden
,
indeed
,
and
so
confidential
was
the
conversation
,
that
Phineas
was
almost
silenced
for
awhile
.
<EOS>
A
word
or
two
had
been
said
about
Loughlinter
,
of
the
beauty
of
the
place
and
of
the
vastness
of
the
property
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
almost
afraid
,
"
said
Lord
Brentford
,
"
that
Laura
is
not
happy
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
she
is
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
so
hard
and
dry
,
and
what
I
call
exacting
.
<EOS>
That
is
just
the
word
for
it
.
<EOS>
Now
Laura
has
never
been
used
to
that
.
<EOS>
With
me
she
always
had
her
own
way
in
everything
,
and
I
always
found
her
fit
to
have
it
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
understand
why
her
husband
should
treat
her
differently
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
is
the
temper
of
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Temper
,
yes
;
but
what
a
bad
prospect
is
that
for
her
!
<EOS>
And
she
,
too
,
has
a
temper
,
and
so
he
will
find
if
he
tries
her
too
far
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
stand
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
I
told
Laura
so
fairly
.
<EOS>
It
is
one
of
those
houses
in
which
a
man
can
not
call
his
hours
his
own
.
<EOS>
I
told
Laura
that
I
could
not
undertake
to
remain
there
for
above
a
day
or
two
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
sad
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
indeed
;
it
is
sad
for
her
,
poor
girl
;
and
very
sad
for
me
too
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
one
else
<EOS>
but
Laura
,
 
literally
no
one
;
and
now
I
am
divided
from
her
!
<EOS>
It
seems
that
she
has
been
taken
as
much
away
from
me
as
though
her
husband
lived
in
China
.
<EOS>
I
have
lost
them
both
now
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
my
lord
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
I
have
.
<EOS>
As
to
Chiltern
,
I
can
perceive
that
he
becomes
more
and
more
indifferent
to
me
every
day
.
<EOS>
He
thinks
of
me
only
as
a
man
in
his
way
who
must
die
some
day
and
may
die
soon
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
wrong
him
,
Lord
Brentford
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
wrong
him
at
all
.
<EOS>
Why
has
he
answered
every
offer
I
have
made
him
with
so
much
insolence
as
to
make
it
impossible
for
me
to
put
myself
into
further
communion
with
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
thinks
that
you
have
wronged
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
because
I
have
been
unable
to
shut
my
eyes
to
his
mode
of
living
.
<EOS>
I
was
to
go
on
paying
his
debts
,
and
taking
no
other
notice
whatsoever
of
his
conduct
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
he
is
in
debt
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Because
his
sister
the
other
day
spent
every
shilling
of
her
fortune
in
paying
them
.
<EOS>
She
gave
him
£
40,000
!
<EOS>
Do
you
think
she
would
have
married
Kennedy
but
for
that
?
<EOS>
I
do
n't
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
prevent
her
.
<EOS>
I
had
said
that
I
would
not
cripple
my
remaining
years
of
life
by
raising
the
money
,
and
I
could
not
go
back
from
my
word
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
You
and
Chiltern
might
raise
the
money
between

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
do
no
good
now
.
<EOS>
She
has
married
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
the
money
is
nothing
to
her
or
to
him
.
<EOS>
Chiltern
might
have
put
things
right
by
marrying
Miss
Effingham
if
he

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
did
his
best
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
he
did
his
worst
.
<EOS>
He
asked
her
to
be
his
wife
as
a
man
asks
for
a

-
ticket
or
a

of

,
which
he
buys
with

price
;
and
because

would

into

he

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
I

has
some

connection
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
of

.
<EOS>
He
would

-

.
<EOS>
My

Miss
Effingham
is
sincere
in

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
that
she
will
never
change
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
well
;
I
do
n't

,

I
daresay
I
know

better

.
<EOS>
But
everything
goes
against
me
.
<EOS>
I
had
set
my
heart
upon
it
,
and
therefore
of
course
I
shall
be
disappointed
.
<EOS>
What
is
he
going
to
do
this

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
yachting
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
who
are
with

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
the
boat
belongs
to
Captain
Colepepper
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
greatest
blackguard
in
all
England
!
<EOS>
A
man
who
shoots
pigeons
and
rides
steeple
-
chases
!
<EOS>
And
the
worst
of
Chiltern
is
this
,
that
even
if
he
did
n't

man
,
and

,

just
the
same
because
he
thinks
it
a

.
<EOS>
"
This
was
so
true
that
Phineas
did
not
dare
to

,
and
therefore
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
I
had
some

,
"
continued

Earl
,
"
while
Laura
could
always

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
But
that
is
all

.
<EOS>
She
will
have
enough
to
do
to
watch
herself
!
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
had
felt
that
the
Earl
had
put

down
rather

when
he
had
said
that
Violet
would
never
accept
Lord
Chiltern
,
and

Brentford

again
of
Miss
Effingham
the
following

,
holding
in

a

which

had

.
<EOS>
"
They
are
to
be
at
Loughlinter
on

,
"

,
"
and
she

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lady
Baldock

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

;
Lady
Baldock
and
all
.
<EOS>
I
am
not

of
Lady
Baldock
,
but
I
will

for
a

for

Violet
.
<EOS>
She
is
more
like

.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
see
her
all

.
<EOS>
I

Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
will

better
when
the
house
is

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
there
,
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
no
;
I
think
not
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
had
enough
of
it
,
have
you
?
"
<EOS>
Phineas
made
no
reply
to
this
,
but
smiled
slightly
.
<EOS>
"
By
Jove
,
I
do
n't
wonder
at
it
,
"
said
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
would
have
given
all
he
had
in
the
world
to
be

in
the
same

house
with
Violet
Effingham
,
could
not

how
it
had
come

that

was

.
<EOS>
"
I

you
were

?
"
said

Earl
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
I
was
asked
.
<EOS>
Nothing
can
be
kinder
than
they

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Kennedy
told

that
you
were

as

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
explained
to
him

,
"
said

,
"
that
I
should
not
return
.
<EOS>
I
shall
go
over
to
Ireland
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
deal
of
hard
reading
to
do
,
and
I
can
get
through
it
there
without
interruption
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
went
up
from
Saulsby
to
London
on
that
day
,
and
found
himself
quite
alone
in
Mrs.
Bunce
's
lodgings
.
<EOS>
I
mean
not
only
that
he
was
alone
at
his
lodgings
,
but
he
was
alone
at
his
club
,
and
alone
in
the
streets
.
<EOS>
July
was
not
quite
over
,
and
yet
all
the
birds
of
passage
had
migrated
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
,
by
his
short
session
,
had
half
ruined
the
London
tradesmen
,
and
had
changed
the
summer
mode
of
life
of
all
those
who
account
themselves
to
be
anybody
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
as
he
sat
alone
in
his
room
,
felt
himself
to
be
nobody
.
<EOS>
He
had
told
the
Earl
that
he
was
going
to
Ireland
,
and
to
Ireland
he
must
go
;
 
because
he
had
nothing
else
to
do
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
asked
indeed
to
join
one
or
two
parties
in
their
autumn
plans
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
had
wanted
him
to
go
to
the
Pyrenees
,
and
Lord
Chiltern
had
suggested
that
he
should
join
the
yacht
;
 
but
neither
plan
suited
him
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
suited
him
to
be
at
Loughlinter
with
Violet
Effingham
,
but
Loughlinter
was
a
barred
house
to
him
.
<EOS>
His
old
friend
,
Lady
Laura
,
had
told
him
not
to
come
thither
,
explaining
,
with
sufficient
clearness
,
her
reasons
for
excluding
him
from
the
number
of
her
husband
's
guests
.
<EOS>
As
he
thought
of
it
the
past
scenes
of
his
life
became
very
marvellous
to
him
.
<EOS>
Twelve
months
since
he
would
have
given
all
the
world
for
a
word
of
love
from
Lady
Laura
,
and
had
barely
dared
to
hope
that
such
a
word
,
at
some
future
day
,
might
possibly
be
spoken
.
<EOS>
Now
such
a
word
had
in
truth
been
spoken
,
and
it
had
come
to
be
simply
a
trouble
to
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
owned
to
him
,
 
for
,
in
truth
,
such
had
been
the
meaning
of
her
warning
to
him
,
 
that
,
though
she
had
married
another
man
,
she
had
loved
and
did
love
him
.
<EOS>
But
in
thinking
of
this
he
took
no
pride
in
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
till
he
had
thought
of
it
long
that
he
began
to
ask
himself
whether
he
might
not
be
justified
in
gathering
from
what
happened
some
hope
that
Violet
also
might
learn
to
love
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
thought
so
little
of
himself
as
to
have
been
afraid
at
first
to
press
his
suit
with
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
Might
he
not
venture
to
think
more
of
himself
,
having
learned
how
far
he
had
succeeded
?
  
<EOS>
But
how
was
he
to
get
at
Violet
Effingham
?
<EOS>
From
the
moment
at
which
he
had
left
Saulsby
he
had
been
angry
with
himself
for
not
having
asked
Lord
Brentford
to
allow
him
to
remain
there
till
after
the
Baldock
party
should
have
gone
on
to
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
,
who
was
very
lonely
in
his
house
,
would
have
consented
at
once
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
indeed
,
was
driven
to
confess
to
himself
<EOS>
that
success
with
Violet
would
at
once
have
put
an
end
to
all
his
friendship
with
Lord
Brentford
;
 
as
also
to
all
his
friendship
with
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
He
would
,
in
such
case
,
be
bound
in

to
vacate
his

and
give
back
Loughton
to
his
offended

.
<EOS>
But
he
would
have
given
up
much
more
than
his
seat
for
Violet
Effingham
!
<EOS>
At
present
,
however
,
he
had
no
means
of
getting
at
her
to
ask
her
the
question
.
<EOS>
He
could
hardly
go
to
Loughlinter
in
opposition
to
the
wishes
of
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
A
little
adventure
happened
to
him
in
London
which
somewhat
relieved
the
dulness
of
the
days
of
the
first
week
in
August
.
<EOS>
He
remained
in
London
till
the
middle
of
August
,
half
resolving
to
rush
down
to
Saulsby
when
Violet
Effingham
should
be
there
,
 
endeavouring
to
find
some

for
such

proceeding
,
but
racking
his
brains
in
vain
,
 
<EOS>
and
then
there
came
about
his
little
adventure
.
<EOS>
The
adventure
was
commenced
by
the
receipt
of
the
following
letter
:
    
Banner
of
the
People
Office
,
3rd
August
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
MY
DEAR
FINN
,
  
<EOS>
I
must
say
I
think
you
have
treated
me
badly
,
and
without
that
sort
of
brotherly
fairness
which
we
on

public
press
expect
from
one

.
<EOS>
However
,
perhaps
we
can
come
to
an
understanding
,
and
if

,
things
may
yet
go
smoothly
.
<EOS>
Give
me
a
turn
<EOS>
and
I
am
not
at
all
adverse
to
give
you
one
.
<EOS>
Will
you
come
to
me
here
,
or

call

?
  
<EOS>
Yours
always
,
Q.
S.
  
Phineas
was
not
only

,
but
disgusted
also
,
at
the
receipt

this
letter
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
imagine
what
was
the
deed
by
which
he
had
offended
Mr.
Slide
.
<EOS>
He
thought
over
all
the
circumstances
of
his
short
connection
with
the
_
People
's
Banner
_
,
but
could
remember
nothing
which
might
have
created
offence
.
<EOS>
But
his
disgust
was
greater
than
his
surprise
.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
he
had
done
nothing
and
said
nothing
to
justify
Quintus
Slide
in
calling
him
"
dear
Finn
.
"
<EOS>
He
,
who
had
Lady
Laura
's
secret
in
his
keeping
;
he
who
hoped
to
be
the
possessor
of
Violet
Effingham
's
affections
,
 
he
to
be
called
"
dear
Finn
"
by
such

one
as
Quintus
Slide
!
<EOS>
He
soon
made
up
his
mind
that
he
would
not
answer

note
,
but
would
go
at
once
to
the
_
People
's
Banner
_
office
at
the
hour
at
which
Quintus
Slide
was
always
there
.
<EOS>
He
certainly
would
not
write
to
"
dear
Slide
;
"
and
,
until
he
had
heard
something

of
this
cause

,
he
would
not
make
an
enemy
for
ever
by
calling
the
man
"
dear
Sir
.
"
<EOS>
He
went
to
the
office
of
the
_
People
's
Banner
_
,
and

Mr.
Slide
ensconced
in

,
writing

article
for
the
next
day
's

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
're
very

,
"
said
Phineas
,
inserting
himself
with
some

on
to
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
so
particular
but
<EOS>
what
I
'm

see
you
.
<EOS>
You
shoot
,
do

you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shoot
!
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
It
could
not

that
Mr.
Slide
was

,
after
this

,
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Grouse
and

,

them

?
"

Slide
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
ah
;
I
understand
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
shoot
sometimes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

12th

for
grouse
in

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
The
12th
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
What

just

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
doing
a
letter
about

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

;

.
<EOS>
What

date

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas

.
  
<EOS>
"
Stirling
's

town
,

?
<EOS>
Callender
sounds
better

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
the
letter
which
was
to

young
grouse
was
dated
from

;
and
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
having
written

word
,
threw

,
came

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
Finn
,
"

,
"

you
've

about

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Treated
you
badly
about
Loughton
!
"
<EOS>
Phineas
,

,
was

Slide
's

.
<EOS>
Did

_

_
?
  
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"

,

,
 
"

!
<EOS>
Men

press
together
do
expect

're

be
stuck

,

not

.
<EOS>
Damn

,

;

ai

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Upon

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Did

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
 
h
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
?
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
You

this

.
<EOS>
If

Lord
What's
-

-

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
In

,

is

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Will

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Agree
!
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
It
's

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
Go

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But

's

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very

!
<EOS>
Now

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Good

.
<EOS>
"
  
Phineas
,
quite
satisfied
at
the
result
of
the
interview
as
regarded
himself
,
and
by
no
means
sorry
that
there
should
have
arisen
a
cause
of
separation
between
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
and
his
"
dear
Finn
,
"
shook
off
a
little
dust
from
his
foot
as
he
left
the
office
of
the
_
People
's
Banner
_
,
and
resolved
that
in
future
he
would
attempt
to
make
no
connection
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
As
he
returned
home
he
told
himself
that
a
member
of
Parliament
should
be
altogether
independent
of
the
press
.
<EOS>
On
the
second
morning
after
his
meeting
with
his
late
friend
,
he
saw
the
result
of
his
independence
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
startling
article
,
a
tremendous
article
,
showing
the
pressing
necessity
of
immediate
reform
,
and
proving
the
necessity
by
an
illustration
of
the
borough
-
mongering
rottenness
of
the
present
system
.
<EOS>
When
such
a
patron
as
Lord
Brentford
,
 
himself
a
Cabinet
Minister
with
a
sinecure
,
 
could
by
his
mere
word
put
into
the
House
such
a
stick
as
Phineas
Finn
,
 
a
man
who
had
struggled
to
stand
on
his
legs
before
the
Speaker
,
but
had
wanted
both
the
courage
and
the
capacity
,
nothing
further
could
surely
be
wanted
to
prove
that
the
Reform
Bill
of
1832
required
to
be
supplemented
by
some
more
energetic
measure
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
laughed
as
he
read
the
article
,
and
declared
to
himself
that
the
joke
was
a
good
joke
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
he
suffered
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
,
when
he
was
really
anxious
to
use
his
thong
earnestly
,
could
generally
raise
a
wale
.
   
<EOS>
Was
He
Honest
?
 
<EOS>
On
the
10th
of
August
,
Phineas
Finn
did
return
to
Loughton
.
<EOS>
He
went
down
by
the
mail
train
on
the
night
of
the
10th
,
having
telegraphed
to
the
inn
for
a
bed
,
and
was
up
eating
his
breakfast
in
that
hospitable
house
at
nine
o'clock
.
<EOS>
The
landlord
and
landlady
with
all
their
staff
were
at
a
loss
to
imagine
what
had
brought
down
their
member
again
so
quickly
to
his
borough
;
but
the
reader
,
who
will
remember
that
Lady
Baldock
with
her
daughter
and
Violet
Effingham
were
to
pass
the
11th
of
the
month
at
Saulsby
,
may
perhaps
be
able
to
make
a
guess
on
the
subject
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
had
been
thinking
of
making
this
sudden
visit
to
Loughton
ever
since
he
had
been
up
in
town
,
but
he
could
suggest
to
himself
no
reason
to
be
given
to
Lord
Brentford
for
his
sudden
reappearance
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
had
been
very
kind
to
him
,
but
he
had
said
nothing
which
could
justify
his
young
friend
in
running
in
and
out
of
Saulsby
Castle
at
pleasure
,
without
invitation
and
without
notice
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
so
well
aware
of
this
himself
that
often
as
he
had
half
resolved
during
the
last
ten
days
to
return
to
Saulsby
,
so
often
had
he
determined
that
he
could
not
do
so
.
<EOS>
He
could
think
of
no
excuse
.
<EOS>
Then
the
heavens
favoured
him
,
and
he
received
a
letter
from
Lord
Chiltern
,
in
which
there
was
a
message
for
Lord
Brentford
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
see
my
father
,
tell
him
that
I
am
ready
at
any
moment
to
do
what
is
necessary
for
raising
the
money
for
Laura
.
"
<EOS>
Taking
this
as
his
excuse
he
returned
to
Loughton
.
  
<EOS>
As
chance
arranged
it
,
he
met
the
Earl
standing
on
the
great
steps
before
his
own
castle
doors
.
<EOS>
"
What
,
Finn
;
is
this
you
?
<EOS>
I
thought
you
were
in
Ireland
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
,
my
lord
,
as
you
see
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
opened
his
budget
at
once
,
and
blushed
at
his
own
hypocrisy
as
he
went
on
with
his
story
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
he
said
,
felt
the
message
from
Chiltern
to
be
so
all
-
important
that
he
could
not
bring
himself
to
go
over
to
Ireland
without
delivering
it
.
<EOS>
He
urged
upon
the
Earl
that
he
might
learn
from
this
how
anxious
Lord
Chiltern
was
to
effect
a
reconciliation
.
<EOS>
When
it
occurred
to
him
,
he
said
,
that
there
might
be
a
hope
of
doing
anything
towards
such
an
object
,
he
could
not
go
to
Ireland
leaving
the
good
work
behind
him
.
<EOS>
In
love
and
war
all
things
are
fair
.
<EOS>
So
he
declared
to
himself
;
but
as
he
did
so
he
felt
that
his
story
was
so
weak
that
it
would
hardly
gain
for
him
an
admittance
into
the
Castle
.
<EOS>
In
this
he
was
completely
wrong
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
,
swallowing
the
bait
,
put
his
arm
through
that
of
the
intruder
,
and
,
walking
with
him
through
the
paths
of
the
shrubbery
,
at
length
confessed
that
he
would
be
glad
to
be
reconciled
to
his
son
if
it
were
possible
.
<EOS>
"
Let
him
come
here
,
and
she
shall
be
here
also
,
"
said
the
Earl
,
speaking
of
Violet
.
<EOS>
To
this
Phineas
could
say
nothing
out
loud
,
but
he
told
himself
that
all
should
be
fair
between
them
.
<EOS>
He
would
take
no
dishonest
advantage
of
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
He
would
give
Lord
Chiltern
the
whole
message
as
it
was
given
to
him
by
Lord
Brentford
.
<EOS>
But
should
it
so
turn
out
that
he
himself
got
an
opportunity
of
saying
to
Violet
all
that
he
had
come
to
say
,
and
should
it
also
turn
out
,
 
an
event
which
he
acknowledged
to
himself
to
be
most
unlikely
,
 
that
Violet
did
not
reject
him
,
then
how
could
he
write
his
letter
to
Lord
Chiltern
?
<EOS>
So
he
resolved
that
the
letter
should
be
written
before
he
saw
Violet
.
<EOS>
But
how
could
he
write
such
a
letter
and
instantly
afterwards
do
that
which
would
be
false
to
the
spirit
of
a
letter
so
written
?
<EOS>
Could
he
bid
Lord
Chiltern
come
home
to
woo
Violet
Effingham
,
and
instantly
go
forth
to
woo
her
for
himself
?
<EOS>
He
found
that
he
could
not
do
so
,
 
unless
he
told
the
whole
truth
to
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
In
no
other
way
could
he
carry
out
his
project
and
satisfy
his
own
idea
of
what
was
honest
.
  
<EOS>
The
Earl
bade
him
send
to
the
hotel
for
his
things
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Baldock
people
are
all
here
,
you
know
,
but
they
go
very
early
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
declared
that
he
also
must
return
to
London
very
early
on
the
morrow
;
 
but
in
the
meantime
he
would
go
to
the
inn
and
fetch
his
things
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
thanked
him
again
and
again
for
his
generous
kindness
;
and
Phineas
,
blushing
as
he
received
the
thanks
,
went
back
and
wrote
his
letter
to
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
It
was
an
elaborate
letter
,
written
,
as
regards
the
first
and
larger
portion
of
it
,
with
words
intended
to
bring
the
prodigal
son
back
to
the
father
's
home
.
<EOS>
And
everything
was
said
about
Miss
Effingham
that
could
or
should
have
been
said
.
<EOS>
Then
,
on
the
last
page
,
he
told
his
own
story
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
must
speak
of
myself
:
"
 
and
he
went
on
to
explain
to
his
friend
,
in
the
plainest
language
that
he
could
use
,
his
own
position
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
loved
her
,
"
he
said
,
"
for
six
months
,
and
I
am
here
with
the
express
intention
of
asking
her
to
take
me
.
<EOS>
The
chances
are
ten
to
one
that
she
refuses
me
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
deprecate
your
anger
,
 
if
you
choose
to
be
angry
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
endeavouring
to
treat
you
well
,
and
I
ask
you
to
do
the
same
by
me
.
<EOS>
I
must
convey
to
you
your
father
's
message
,
and
after
doing
so
I
can
not
address
myself
to
Miss
Effingham
without
telling
you
.
<EOS>
I
should
feel
myself
to
be
false
<EOS>
were
I
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
In
the
event
,
 
the
probable
,
nay
,
almost
certain
event
of
my
being
refused
,
 
I
shall
trust
you
to
keep
my
secret
.
<EOS>
Do
not
quarrel
with
me
if
you
can
help
it
;
 
but
if
you
must
I
will
be
ready
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
posted
the
letter
and
went
up
to
the
Castle
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
only
the
one
day
for
his
action
,
and
he
knew
that
Violet
was
watched
by
Lady
Baldock
as
by
a
dragon
.
<EOS>
He
was
told
that
the
Earl
was
out
with
the
young
ladies
,
and
was
shown
to
his
room
.
<EOS>
On
going
to
the
drawing
-
room
he
found
Lady
Baldock
,
with
whom
he
had
been
,
to
a
certain
degree
,
a
favourite
,
and
was
soon
deeply
engaged
in
a
conversation
as
to
the
practicability
of
shutting
up
all
the
breweries
and
distilleries
by
Act
of
Parliament
.
<EOS>
But
lunch
relieved
him
,
and
brought
the
young
ladies
in
at
two
.
<EOS>
Miss
Effingham
seemed
to
be
really
glad
to
see
him
,
and
even
Miss
Boreham
,
Lady
Baldock
's
daughter
,
was
very
gracious
to
him
.
<EOS>
For
the
Earl
had
been
speaking
well
of
his
young
member
,
and
Phineas
had
in
a
way
grown
into
the
good
graces
of
sober
and
discreet
people
.
<EOS>
After
lunch
they
were
to
ride
;
 
the
Earl
,
that
is
,
and
Violet
.
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
and
her
daughter
were
to
have
the
carriage
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
mount
you
,
Finn
,
if
you
would
like
it
,
"
said
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
he
'll
like
it
,
"
said
Violet
;
"
do
you
suppose
Mr.
Finn
will
object
to
ride
with
me
in
Saulsby
Woods
?
<EOS>
It
wo
n't
be
the
first
time
,
will
it
?
"
<EOS>
"
Violet
,
"
said
Lady
Baldock
,
"
you
have
the
most
singular
way
of
talking
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
have
,
"
said
Violet
;
<EOS>
"
but
I
do
n't
think
I
can
change
it
now
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
knows
me
too
well
to
mind
it
much
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
past
five
before
they
were
on
horseback
,
and
up
to
that
time
Phineas
had
not
found
himself
alone
with
Violet
Effingham
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
They
had
sat
together
after
lunch
in
the
dining
-
room
for
nearly
an
hour
,
and
had
sauntered
into
the
hall
and
knocked
about
the
billiard
balls
,
and
then
stood
together
at
the
open
doors
of
a
conservatory
.
<EOS>
But
Lady
Baldock
or
Miss
Boreham
had
always
been
there
.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
be
more
pleasant
than
Miss
Effingham
's
words
,
or
more
familiar
than
her
manner
to
Phineas
.
<EOS>
She
had
expressed
strong
delight
at
his
success
in
getting
a
seat
in
Parliament
,
and
had
talked
to
him
about
the
Kennedys
as
though
they
had
created
some
special
bond
of
union
between
her
and
Phineas
which
ought
to
make
them
intimate
.
<EOS>
But
,
for
all
that
,
she
could
not
be
got
to
separate
herself
from
Lady
Baldock
;
 
and
when
she
was
told
that
if
she
meant
to
ride
she
must
go
and
dress
herself
,
she
went
at
once
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
thought
that
he
might
have
a
chance
on
horseback
;
and
after
they
had
been
out
about
half
an
hour
,
chance
did
favour
him
.
<EOS>
For
awhile
he
rode
behind
with
the
carriage
,
calculating
that
by
his
so
doing
the
Earl
would
be
put
off
his
guard
,
and
would
be
disposed
after
awhile
to
change
places
with
him
.
<EOS>
And
so
it
fell
out
.
<EOS>
At
a
certain
fall
of
ground
in
the
park
,
where
the
road
turned
round
and
crossed
a
bridge
over
the
little
river
,
the
carriage
came
up
with
the
first
two
horses
,
and
Lady
Baldock
spoke
a
word
to
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
Then
Violet
pulled
up
,
allowing
the
vehicle
to
pass
the
bridge
first
,
and
in
this
way
she
and
Phineas
were
brought
together
,
 
and
in
this
way
they
rode
on
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
aware
that
he
must
greatly
increase
the
distance
between
them
and
the
others
of
their
party
before
he
could
dare
to
plead
his
suit
,
and
even
were
that
done
<EOS>
he
felt
that
he
would
not
know
how
to
plead
it
on
horseback
.
  
<EOS>
They
had
gone
on
some
half
mile
in
this
way
when
they
reached
a
spot
on
which
a
green
ride
led
away
from
the
main
road
through
the
trees
to
the
left
.
<EOS>
"
You
remember
this
place
,
do
you
not
?
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
Phineas
declared
that
he
remembered
it
well
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
go
round
by
the
woodman
's
cottage
.
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
mind
coming
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
said
that
he
would
not
mind
,
and
trotted
on
to
tell
them
in
the
carriage
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
is
she
going
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Lady
Baldock
;
and
then
,
when
Phineas
explained
,
she
begged
the
Earl
to
go
back
to
Violet
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
,
feeling
the
absurdity
of
this
,
declared
that
Violet
knew
her
way
very
well
herself
,
and
thus
Phineas
got
his
opportunity
.
  
<EOS>
They
rode
on
almost
without
speaking
for
nearly
a
mile
,
cantering
through
the
trees
,
and
then
they
took
another
turn
to
the
right
,
and
came
upon
the
cottage
.
<EOS>
They
rode
to
the
door
,
and
spoke
a
word
or
two
to
the
woman
there
,
and
then
passed
on
.
<EOS>
"
I
always
come
here
when
I
am
at
Saulsby
,
"
said
Violet
,
"
that
I
may
teach
myself
to
think
kindly
of
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
understand
it
all
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
used
to
be
so
nice
;
 
and
is
so
still
,
I
believe
,
only
that
he
has
taught
himself
to
be
so
rough
.
<EOS>
Will
he
ever
change
,
do
you
think
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
knew
that
in
this
emergency
it
was
his
especial
duty
to
be
honest
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
would
be
changed
altogether
if
we
could
bring
him
here
,
 
so
that
he
should
live
among
his
friends
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
he
would
?
<EOS>
We
must
put
our
heads
together
,
and
do
it
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
that
it
is
to
be
done
?
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
replied
that
he
thought
it
was
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
the
truth
at
once
,
Miss
Effingham
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
do
it
by
a
single
word
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
 
yes
;
"
she
said
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
do
not
mean
that
;
 
without
that
.
<EOS>
It
is
absurd
,
you
know
,
that
a
father
should
make
such
a
condition
as
that
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
said
that
he
thought
it
was
absurd
;
and
then
they
rode
on
again
,
cantering
through
the
wood
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
bold
to
speak
to
her
about
Lord
Chiltern
as
he
had
done
,
and
she
had
answered
just
as
he
would
have
wished
to
be
answered
.
<EOS>
But
how
could
he
press
his
suit
for
himself
while
she
was
cantering
by
his
side
?
  
<EOS>
Presently
they
came
to
rough
ground
over
which
they
were
forced
to
walk
,
and
he
was
close
by
her
side
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
,
"
she
said
,
"
I
wonder
whether
I
may
ask
a
question
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Any
question
,
"
he
replied
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
there
any
quarrel
between
you
and
Lady
Laura
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
None
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Or
between
you
and
him
?
"
  
"
No
;
 
none
.
<EOS>
We
are
greater
allies
than
ever
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
are
you
not
going
to
be
at
Loughlinter
?
<EOS>
She
has
written
to
me
expressly
saying
you
would
not
be
there
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
paused
a
moment
before
he
replied
.
<EOS>
"
It
did
not
suit
,
"
he
said
at
last
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
secret
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
it
is
a
secret
.
<EOS>
You
are
not
angry
with
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Angry
;
no
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
a
secret
of
my
own
,
or
I
should
not
keep
it
from
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
can
guess
it
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
will
not
try
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
even
think
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
cause
,
whatever
it
be
,
has
been
full
of
sorrow
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
would
have
given
my
left
hand
to
have
been
at
Loughlinter
this
autumn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
so
fond
of
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
been
staying
there
with
you
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
He
paused
,
and
for
a
moment
there
was
no
word
spoken
by
either
of
them
;
but
he
could
perceive
that
the
hand
in
which
she
held
her
whip
was
playing
with
her
horse
's
mane
with
a
nervous
movement
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
I
found
how
it
must
be
,
and
that
I
must
miss
you
,
I
rushed
down
here
that
I
might
see
you
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
And
now
I
am
here
<EOS>
I
do
not
dare
to
speak
to
you
of
myself
.
<EOS>
"
They
were
now
beyond
the
rocks
,
and
Violet
,
without
speaking
a
word
,
again
put
her
horse
into
a
trot
.
<EOS>
He
was
by
her
side
in
a
moment
,
but
he
could
not
see
her
face
.
"
<EOS>
Have
you
not
a
word
to
say
to
me
?
"
he
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
no
;
 
no
<EOS>
;
"
she
replied
,
"
not
a
word
when
you
speak
to
me
like
that
.
<EOS>
There
is
the
carriage
.
<EOS>
Come
;
 
we
will
join
them
.
"
<EOS>
Then
she
cantered
on
,
and
he
followed
her
till
they
reached
the
Earl
and
Lady
Baldock
and
Miss
Boreham
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
my
devotions
now
,
"
said
Miss
Effingham
,
"
and
am
ready
to
return
to
ordinary
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
could
not
find
another
moment
in
which
to
speak
to
her
.
<EOS>
Though
he
spent
the
evening
with
her
,
and
stood
over
her
as
she
sang
at
the
Earl
's
request
,
and
pressed
her
hand
as
she
went
to
bed
,
and
was
up
to
see
her
start
in
the
morning
,
he
could
not
draw
from
her
either
a
word
or
a
look
.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
upon
Reform
 
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
went
to
Ireland
immediately
after
his
return
from
Saulsby
,
having
said
nothing
further
to
Violet
Effingham
,
and
having
heard
nothing
further
from
her
than
what
is
recorded
in
the
last
chapter
.
<EOS>
He
felt
very
keenly
that
his
position
was
unsatisfactory
,
and
brooded
over
it
all
the
autumn
and
early
winter
;
but
he
could
form
no
plan
for
improving
it
.
<EOS>
A
dozen
times
he
thought
of
writing
to
Miss
Effingham
,
and
asking
for
an
explicit
answer
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
,
however
,
bring
himself
to
write
the
letter
,
thinking
that
written
expressions
of
love
are
always
weak
and
vapid
,
 
and
deterred
also
by
a
conviction
that
Violet
,
if
driven
to
reply
in
writing
,
would
undoubtedly
reply
by
a
refusal
.
<EOS>
Fifty
times
he
rode
again
in
his
imagination
his
ride
in
Saulsby
Wood
,
and
he
told
himself
as
often
that
the
syren
's
answer
to
him
,
 
her
<EOS>
no
,
no
,
no
,
 
had
been
,
of
all
possible
answers
,
the
most
indefinite
and
provoking
.
<EOS>
The
tone
of
her
voice
as
she
galloped
away
from
him
,
the
bearing
of

when
he
rejoined

,
her

to

when
he
saw

from
the
Castle
in
the
morning
,
all
forbade
him
to
believe
that
his

to

had
been

.
<EOS>
She
had
replied

with

,
simply

word
"
no
;
"
but

had
so

that
there

any

in

;
and

had
known

,

Effingham
as

.
  
<EOS>
But
the
doubt
made
his

in
Ireland
very
wearisome
to
him
.
<EOS>
And
there

other

which

,
though
he

not
left
even

this

without

of
success
which
seemed
to

very

.
<EOS>
And
,
first
,
I
will
say

word
of
his

.
<EOS>
He
heard
not
a

from
Lord
Chiltern
in

to

.
<EOS>
From
Lady
Laura
he
did

.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
wrote
to
him
exactly
as
though

had
never

away

Loughlinter
,
and

.
<EOS>
She

just

here

and

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
It

that

,
and
,

.
<EOS>
In

,

,
and
that

.
<EOS>
But

no

of
Violet
Effingham
;
and
though
Lady

did

.
<EOS>
There

Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
He
had
thought
that
Violet
might
probably
tell

what

at

;
 
but
if

,
Lady

happy

.
<EOS>
Our
hero
was

Mrs.
Flood
Jones

.
<EOS>
I

,

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

Mary

Jones
had

Killaloe
because

thought

he
had
ill
-

,
and

.
<EOS>
In
the

the
heat

he
had

,

which
some

had

as
to
his

about
poor
Mary
.
<EOS>
This

answered

.
<EOS>
Nothing

had

about
Miss
Jones
,
and
nothing

said

when

.
<EOS>
He
could
not
,

,
but

Mary
,
and

,

was

again

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

"

"

.
<EOS>
She

.
"
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
"

,
 
understanding

.
<EOS>
Then

had
demurely

further
on

,
and
not

.
<EOS>
They
were
at
Floodborough
,
living
<EOS>
,
he

not

,

,

<EOS>
But

?
<EOS>
Now

,
he
thought
that
he
did

dear
Mary

.
<EOS>
He

that
he
had

,
 
that

,

,

,

,

,

,

Mary
Flood

as

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

against

fulness

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
How

,
 
he
,
with

jobs
of

on

!
<EOS>
It
was
not

.
<EOS>
He
must
abandon

of
making

Mary
his

.
<EOS>
No
doubt
they
had

to

.
<EOS>
But
,
still
,

he

,
and

,

,
and

of

,
of

Violet
to
some

,
 
to

,

,

.
<EOS>
Miss

;
whereas
Mary
,

,

come

without

.
<EOS>
Dear
Mary
!
<EOS>
In
these

of

,
he
told

that
,

,

Mary

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

.
<EOS>
He
had
letters

from
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
which
made

impossible
for

to
think
in

of
giving
up

.
  
<EOS>
And
then
there
came
a
wonderful
piece
of

in

way
.
<EOS>
There
lived
,
or
had

,
in
the
town
of
Galway
a
very

lady
,
one
Miss
Marian
Persse
,
who
was
the
aunt
of
Mrs.
Finn
,

hero
.
<EOS>
With
this

Dr.
Finn
had
quarrelled

ever
since
his

,
because
the
lady
had
expressed
her

to

in
the
management
of

,
 
offering
to

in

to

.
<EOS>
This
the
doctor
had
resented
,
and
there
had
been

.
<EOS>
Miss
Persse
was
not
a
very
rich
old
lady
,
but
she
thought
a
good
deal
of
her
own
money
.
<EOS>
And
now
she
died
,
leaving
£
3,000
to
her
nephew
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
Another
sum
of
about

amount
she
bequeathed
to
a
Roman
Catholic

;
and
thus
was
her
worldly
wealth
divided
.
<EOS>
"
She
could
n't
have
done
better
with
it
,
"
said
the
old
doctor
;
"
and
as
far
as
we
are

,
the
windfall
is
the
more
pleasant
as
being
wholly

.
<EOS>
"
In
these
days
the
doctor
was
undoubtedly
gratified
by
his
son
's
success
in
life
,
and
never
said
much
about
the
law
.
<EOS>
Phineas
in
truth
did
do
some
work
during

,
reading
blue
-
books
,
reading
law

,
reading

,
 
but
shutting

up

as

,
so
that

that

day
not

.
  
<EOS>
On

;

<EOS>
"
It

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
What

ca
n't

.
<EOS>
As

present

,

;
and

later

,

.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
,

,

,

£

.
<EOS>
He
owed

£
500
;
and

he
would
,

,
invest
.
  
<EOS>
There
had
been
some

an

,
but

Mildmay
's
decision
had
at
last

against

.
<EOS>
Who
can
not

that
such

be
the
decision
of
any

to
whom

left
the
slightest

?
<EOS>
Why

any

court
the

,

to

,
and

?
<EOS>
In

the

as

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
Do

,
"

;
 
and

.
<EOS>
Afterwards
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Lord

had

,
and

.
<EOS>
The

till
February
,
somewhat
to
the

of
Phineas
Finn
,
who
had
become

of
blue
-

.
<EOS>
The
difference
between

so

,
that
it
was
hardly

that

not

.
<EOS>
He
did
become
weary
of

,
but
strove

to
hide

from
his
father
and

.
  
<EOS>
At
this
time
the
world
was
talking
much
about
Reform
,
though
Mr.
Mildmay
had
become
placidly
patient
.
<EOS>
The
feeling
was
growing
,
and
Mr.
Turnbull
,
with
his
friends
,
was
doing
all
he
could
to
make
it
grow
fast
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
certain
amount
of
excitement
on
the
subject
;
but
the
excitement
had
grown
downwards
,
from
the
leaders
to
the
people
,
 
from
the
self
-
instituted
leaders
of
popular
politics
down
,
by
means
of
the
press
,
to
the
ranks
of
working
men
,
instead
of
growing
upwards
,
from
the
dissatisfaction
of
the
masses
,
till
it
expressed
itself
by
this
mouthpiece
and
that
,
chosen
by
the
people
themselves
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
strong
throb
through
the
country
,
making
men
feel
that
safety
was
to
be
had
by
Reform
,
and
could
not
be
had
without
Reform
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
an
understanding
that
the
press
and
the
