were
too
strong
to
be
ignored
,
and
that
some
new
measure
of
Reform
must
be
conceded
to
them
.
<EOS>
The
sooner
the
concession
was
made
,
the
less
it
might
be
necessary
to
concede
.
<EOS>
And
all
men
of
all
parties
were
agreed
on
this
point
.
<EOS>
That
Reform
was
in
itself
odious
to
many
of
those
who
spoke
of
it
freely
,
who
offered
themselves
willingly
to
be
its
promoters
,
was
acknowledged
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
only
odious
to
Lord
de
Terrier
and
to
most
of
those
who
worked
with
him
,
but
was
equally
so
to
many
of
Mr.
Mildmay
's
most
constant
supporters
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
had
no
wish
for
Reform
.
<EOS>
Indeed
it
is
hard
to
suppose
that
such
a
Duke
can
wish
for
any
change
in
a
state
of
things
that
must
seem
to
him
to
be
so
salutary
.
<EOS>
Workmen
were
getting
full
wages
.
<EOS>
Farmers
were
paying
their
rent
.
<EOS>
Capitalists
by
the
dozen
were
creating
capitalists
by
the
hundreds
.
<EOS>
Nothing
was
wrong
in
the
country
,
but
the
over
-
dominant
spirit
of
speculative
commerce
;
 
and
there
was
nothing
in
Reform
to
check
that
.
<EOS>
Why
should
the
Duke
want
Reform
?
<EOS>
As
for
such
men
as
Lord
Brentford
,
Sir
Harry
Coldfoot
,
Lord
Plinlimmon
,
and
Mr.
Legge
Wilson
,
it
was
known
to
all
men
that
they
advocated
Reform
as
we
all
of
us
advocate
doctors
.
<EOS>
Some
amount
of
doctoring
is
necessary
for
us
.
<EOS>
We
may
hardly
hope
to
avoid
it
.
<EOS>
But
let
us
have
as
little
of
the
doctor
as
possible
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
,
and
the
cheap
press
,
and
the
rising
spirit
of
the
loudest
among
the
people
,
made
it
manifest
that
something
must
be
conceded
.
<EOS>
Let
us
be
generous
in
our
concession
.
<EOS>
That
was
now
the
doctrine
of
many
,
 
perhaps
of
most
of
the
leading
politicians
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
Let
us
be
generous
.
<EOS>
Let
us
at
any
rate
seem
to
be
generous
.
<EOS>
Let
us
give
with
an
open
hand
,
 
but
still
with
a
hand
which
,
though
open
,
shall
not
bestow
too
much
.
<EOS>
The
coach
must
be
allowed
to
run
down
the
hill
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
unless
the
coach
goes
on
running
no
journey
will
be
made
.
<EOS>
But
let
us
have
the
drag
on
both
the
hind
wheels
.
<EOS>
And
we
must
remember
that
coaches
running
down
hill
without
drags
are
apt
to
come
to
serious
misfortune
.
  
<EOS>
But
there
were
men
,
even
in
the
Cabinet
,
who
had
other
ideas
of
public
service
than
that
of
dragging
the
wheels
of
the
coach
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
was
in
earnest
.
<EOS>
Plantagenet
Palliser
was
in
earnest
.
<EOS>
That
exceedingly
intelligent
young
nobleman
Lord
Cantrip
was
in
earnest
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
threw
,
perhaps
,
as
much
of
earnestness
into
the
matter
as
was
compatible
with
his
age
and
his
full
appreciation
of
the
manner
in
which
the
present
cry
for
Reform
had
been
aroused
.
<EOS>
He
was
thoroughly
honest
,
thoroughly
patriotic
,
and
thoroughly
ambitious
that
he
should
be
written
of
hereafter
as
one
who
to
the
end
of
a
long
life
had
worked
sedulously
for
the
welfare
of
the
people
;
 
but
he
disbelieved
in
Mr.
Turnbull
,
and
in
the
bottom
of
his
heart
indulged
an
aristocratic
contempt
for
the
penny
press
.
<EOS>
And
there
was
no
man
in
England
more
in
earnest
,
more
truly
desirous
of
Reform
,
than
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
It
was
his
great
political
idea
that
political
advantages
should
be
extended
to
the
people
,
whether
the
people
clamoured
for
them
or
did
not
clamour
for
them
,
 
even
whether
they
desired
them
or
did
not
desire
them
.
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
ask
a
child
whether
he
would
like
to
learn
his
lesson
,
"
he
would
say
.
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
you
do
not
wait
till
he
cries
for
his
book
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
,
therefore
,
men
said
to
him
that
there
was
no
earnestness
in
the
cry
for
Reform
,
that
the
cry
was
a
false
cry
,
got
up
for
factious
purposes
by
interested
persons
,
he
would
reply
that
the
thing
to
be
done
should
not
be
done
in
obedience
to
any
cry
,
but
because
it
was
demanded
by
justice
,
and
was
a
debt
due
to
the
people
.
  
<EOS>
Our
hero
in
the
autumn
had
written
to
Mr.
Monk
on
the
politics
of
the
moment
,
and
the
following
had
been
Mr.
Monk
's
reply
:
    
Longroyston
,
October
12
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
MY
DEAR
FINN
,
  
<EOS>
I
am
staying
here
with
the
Duke
and
Duchess
of
St.
Bungay
.
<EOS>
The
house
is
very
full
,
and
Mr.
Mildmay
was
here
last
week
;
but
as
I
do
n't
shoot
,
and
ca
n't
play
billiards
,
and
have
no
taste
for
charades
,
I
am
becoming
tired
of
the
gaieties
,
and
shall
leave
them
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Of
course
you
know
that
we
are
not
to
have
the
autumn
session
.
<EOS>
I
think
that
Mr.
Mildmay
is
right
.
<EOS>
Could
we
have
been
sure
of
passing
our
measure
<EOS>
,
it
would
have
been
very
well
;
but
we
could
not
have
been
sure
,
and
failure
with
our
bill
in
a
session
convened
for
the
express
purpose
of
passing
it
would
have
injured
the
cause
greatly
.
<EOS>
We
could
hardly
have
gone
on
with
it
again
in
the
spring
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
we
must
have
resigned
.
<EOS>
And
though
I
may
truly
say
that
I
would
as
lief
have
a
good
measure
from
Lord
de
Terrier
as
from
Mr.
Mildmay
,
and
that
I
am
indifferent
to
my
own
present
personal
position
,
still
I
think
that
we
should
endeavour
to
keep
our
seats
as
long
as
we
honestly
believe
ourselves
to
be
more
capable
of
passing
a
good
measure
than
are
our
opponents
.
  
<EOS>
I
am
astonished
by
the
difference
of
opinion
which
exists
about
Reform
,
 
not
only
as
to
the
difference
in
the
extent
and
exact
tendency
of
the
measure
that
is
needed
,
 
but
that
there
should
be
such
a
divergence
of
ideas
as
to
the
grand
thing
to
be
done
and
the
grand
reason
for
doing
it
.
<EOS>
We
are
all
agreed
that
we
want
Reform
in
order
that
the
House
of
Commons
may
be
returned
by
a
larger
proportion
of
the
people
than
is
at
present
employed
upon
that
work
,
and
that
each
member
when
returned
should
represent
a
somewhat
more
equal
section
of
the
whole
constituencies
of
the
country
than
our
members
generally
do
at
present
.
<EOS>
All
men
confess
that
a
£
50
county
franchise
must
be
too
high
,
and
that
a
borough
with
less
than
two
hundred
registered
voters
must
be
wrong
.
<EOS>
But
it
seems
to
me
that
but
few
among
us
perceive
,
or
at
any
rate
acknowledge
,
the
real
reasons
for
changing
these
things
and
reforming
what
is
wrong
without
delay
.
<EOS>
One
great
authority
told
us
the
other
day
that
the
sole
object
of
legislation
on
this
subject
should
be
to
get
together
the
best
possible
658
members
of
Parliament
.
<EOS>
That
to
me
would
be
a
most
repulsive
idea
if
it
were
not
that
by
its
very
vagueness
it
becomes
inoperative
.
<EOS>
Who
shall
say
what
is
best
;
or
what
characteristic
constitutes
excellence
in
a
member
of
Parliament
?
<EOS>
If
the
gentleman
means
excellence
in
general
wisdom
,
or
in
statecraft
,
or
in
skill
in
talking
,
or
in
private
character
,
or
even
excellence
in
patriotism
,
then
I
say
that
he
is
utterly
wrong
,
and
has
never
touched
with
his
intellect
the
true
theory
of
representation
.
<EOS>
One
only
excellence
may
be
acknowledged
,
and
that
is
the
excellence
of
likeness
.
<EOS>
As
a
portrait
should
be
like
the
person
portrayed
,
so
should
a
representative
House
be
like
the
people
whom
it
represents
.
<EOS>
Nor
in
arranging
a
franchise
does
it
seem
to
me
that
we
have
a
right
to
regard
any
other
view
.
<EOS>
If
a
country
be
unfit
for
representative
government
,
 
<EOS>
and
it
may
be
that
there
are
still
peoples
unable
to
use
properly
that
greatest
of
all
blessings
,
 
<EOS>
the
question
as
to
what
state
policy
may
be
best
for
them
is
a
different
question
.
<EOS>
But
if
we
do
have
representation
,
let
the
representative
assembly
be
like
the
people
<EOS>
,
whatever
else
may
be
its
virtues
,
 
and
whatever
else
its
vices
.
  
<EOS>
Another
great
authority
has
told
us
that
our
House
of
Commons
should
be
the
mirror
of
the
people
.
<EOS>
I
say
,
not
its
mirror
,
but
its
miniature
.
<EOS>
And
let
the
artist
be
careful
to
put
in
every
line
of
the
expression
of
that
ever
-
moving
face
.
<EOS>
To
do
this
is
a
great
work
,
and
the
artist
must
know
his
trade
well
.
<EOS>
In
America
the
work
has
been
done
with
so
coarse
a
hand
that
nothing
is
shown
in
the
picture
but
the
broad
,
plain
,
unspeaking
outline
of
the
face
.
<EOS>
As
you
look
from
the
represented
to
the
representation
you
can
not
but
acknowledge
the
likeness
;
  
but
there
is
in
that
portrait
more
of
the
body
than
of
the
mind
.
<EOS>
The
true
portrait
should
represent
more
than
the
body
.
<EOS>
With
us
,
hitherto
,
there
have
been
snatches
of
the
countenance
of
the
nation
which
have
been
inimitable
,
 
a
turn
of
the
eye
here
and
a
curl
of
the
lip
there
,
which
have
seemed
to
denote
a
power
almost
divine
.
<EOS>
There
have
been
marvels
on
the
canvas
so
beautiful
that
one
approaches
the
work
of
remodelling
it
with
awe
.
<EOS>
But
not
only
is
the
picture
imperfect
,
 
a
thing
of
snatches
,
 
but
with
years
it
becomes
less
and
still
less
like
its
original
.
  
<EOS>
The
necessity
for
remodelling
it
is
imperative
,
and
we
shall
be
cowards
if
we
decline
the
work
.
<EOS>
But
let
us
be
specially
careful
to
retain
as
much
as
possible
of
those
lines
which
we
all
acknowledge
to
be
so
faithfully
representative
of
our
nation
.
<EOS>
To
give
to
a
bare
numerical
majority
of
the
people
that
power
which
the
numerical
majority
has
in
the
United
States
,
would
not
be
to
achieve
representation
.
<EOS>
The
nation
as
it
now
exists
would
not
be
known
by
such
a
portrait
;
 
but
neither
can
it
now
be
known
by
that
which
exists
.
<EOS>
It
seems
to
me
that
they
who
are
adverse
to
change
,
looking
back
with
an
unmeasured
respect
on
what
our
old
Parliaments
have
done
for
us
,
ignore
the
majestic
growth
of
the
English
people
,
and
forget
the
present
in
their
worship
of
the
past
.
<EOS>
They
think
that
we
must
be
what
we
were
,
 
at
any
rate
,
what
we
were
thirty
years
since
.
<EOS>
They
have
not
,
perhaps
,
gone
into
the
houses
of
artisans
,
or
,
if
there
,
they
have
not
looked
into
the
breasts
of
the
men
.
<EOS>
With
population
vice
has
increased
,
and
these
politicians
,
with
ears
but
no
eyes
,
hear
of
drunkenness
and
sin
and
ignorance
.
<EOS>
And
then
they
declare
to
themselves
that
this
wicked
,
half
-
barbarous
,
idle
people
should
be
controlled
and
not
represented
.
<EOS>
A
wicked
,
half
-
barbarous
,
idle
people
may
be
controlled
;
 
but
not
a
people
thoughtful
,
educated
,
and
industrious
.
<EOS>
We
must
look
to
it
that
we
do
not
endeavour
to
carry
our
control
beyond
the
wickedness
and
the
barbarity
,
and
that
we
be
ready
to
submit
to
control
from
thoughtfulness
and
industry
.
  
<EOS>
I
hope
we
shall
find
you
helping
at
the
good
work
early
in
the
spring
.
  
<EOS>
Yours
,
always
faithfully
,
  
JOSHUA
MONK
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
was
up
in
London
before
the
end
of
January
,
but
did
not
find
there
many
of
those
whom
he
wished
to
see
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
was
there
,
and
to
him
he
showed
Mr.
Monk
's
letter
,
thinking
that
it
must
be
convincing
even
to
Mr.
Low
.
<EOS>
This
he
did
in
Mrs.
Low
's
drawing
-
room
,
knowing
that
Mrs.
Low
would
also
condescend
to
discuss
politics
on
an
occasion
.
<EOS>
He
had
dined
with
them
,
and
they
had
been
glad
to
see
him
,
and
Mrs.
Low
had
been
less
severe
than
hitherto
against
the
great
sin
of
her
husband
's
late
pupil
.
<EOS>
She
had
condescended
to
congratulate
him
on
becoming
member
for
an
English
borough
instead
of
an
Irish
one
,
and
had
asked
him
questions
about
Saulsby
Castle
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
Mr.
Monk
's
letter
was
not
received
with
that
respectful
admiration
which
Phineas
thought
that
it
deserved
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
foolishly
,
had
read
it
out
loud
,
so
that
the
attack
came
upon
him
simultaneously
from
the
husband
and
from
the
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
just
the
usual
claptrap
,
"
said
Mr.
Low
,
"
only
put
into
language
somewhat
more
grandiloquent
than
usual
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Claptrap
!
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
what
I
call
downright
Radical
nonsense
,
"
said
Mrs.
Low
,
nodding
her
head
energetically
.
<EOS>
"
Portrait
indeed
!
<EOS>
Why
should
we
want
to
have
a
portrait
of
ignorance
and
ugliness
?
<EOS>
What
we
all
want
is
to
have
things
quiet
and
orderly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
'd
better
have
a
paternal
government
at
once
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Just
so
,
"
said
Mr.
Low
,
 
"
only
that
what
you
call
a
paternal
government
is
not
always
quiet
and
orderly
.
<EOS>
National
order
I
take
to
be
submission
to
the
law
.
<EOS>
I
should
not
think
it
quiet
and
orderly
if
I
were
sent
to
Cayenne
without
being
brought
before
a
jury
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
such
a
man
as
you
would
not
be
sent
to
Cayenne
,
"
said
Phineas
,
  
"
<EOS>
My
next
-
door
neighbour
might
be
,
 
which
would
be
almost
as
bad
.
<EOS>
Let
him
be
sent
to
Cayenne
if
he
deserves
it
,
but
let
a
jury
say
that
he
has
deserved
it
.
<EOS>
My
idea
of
government
is
this
,
 
that
we
want
to
be
governed
by
law
and
not
by
caprice
,
and
that
we
must
have
a
legislature
to
make
our
laws
.
<EOS>
If
I
thought
that
Parliament
as
at
present
established
made
the
laws
badly
,
I
would
desire
a
change
;
but
I
doubt
whether
we
shall
have
them
better
from
any
change
in
Parliament
which
Reform
will
give
us
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
not
,
"
said
Mrs.
Low
.
<EOS>
"
But
we
shall
have
a
lot
of
beggars
put
on
horseback
,
and
we
all
know
where
they
ride
to
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
became
aware
that
it
is
not
easy
to
convince
any
man
or
any
woman
on
a
point
of
politics
,
 
not
even
though
he
who
argues
may
have
an
eloquent
letter
from
a
philosophical
Cabinet
Minister
in
his
pocket
to
assist
him
.
   
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
Makes
<EOS>
Progress
 
February
was
far
advanced
and
the
new
Reform
Bill
had
already
been
brought
forward
,
before
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
came
up
to
town
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
of
course
seen
Mr.
Kennedy
and
had
heard
from
him
tidings
of
his
wife
.
<EOS>
She
was
at
Saulsby
with
Lady
Baldock
and
Miss
Boreham
and
Violet
Effingham
,
but
was
to
be
in
London
soon
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
,
as
it
appeared
,
did
not
quite
know
when
he
was
to
expect
his
wife
;
and
Phineas
thought
that
he
could
perceive
from
the
tone
of
the
husband
's
voice
that
something
was
amiss
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
however
ask
any
questions
excepting
such
as
referred
to
the
expected
arrival
.
<EOS>
Was
Miss
Effingham
to
come
to
London
with
Lady
Laura
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
believed
that
Miss
Effingham
would
be
up
before
Easter
,
but
he
did
not
know
whether
she
would
come
with
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
Women
,
"
he
said
,
"
are
so
fond
of
mystery
that
one
can
never
quite
know
what
they
intend
to
do
.
"
<EOS>
He
corrected
himself
at
once
however
,
perceiving
that
he
had
seemed
to
say
something
against
his
wife
,
and
explained
that
his
general
accusation
against
the
sex
was
not
intended
to
apply
to
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
This
,
however
,
he
did
so
awkwardly
as
to
strengthen
the
feeling
with
Phineas
that
something
assuredly
was
wrong
.
"
<EOS>
Miss
Effingham
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
,
"
never
seems
to
know
her
own
mind
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
she
is
like
other
beautiful
girls
who
are
petted
on
all
sides
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
for
her
beauty
,
I
do
n't
think
much
of
it
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
;
"
and
as
for
petting
,
I
do
not
understand
it
in
reference
to
grown
persons
.
<EOS>
Children
may
be
petted
,
and
dogs
,
 
though
that
too
is
bad
;
but
what
you
call
petting
for
grown
persons
is
I
think
frivolous
and
almost
indecent
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
could
not
help
thinking
of
Lord
Chiltern
's
opinion
that
it
would
have
been
wise
to
have
left
Mr.
Kennedy
in
the
hands
of
the
garrotters
.
  
<EOS>
The
debate
on
the
second
reading
of
the
bill
was
to
be
commenced
on
the
1st
of
March
,
and
two
days
before
that
Lady
Laura
arrived
in
Grosvenor
Place
.
<EOS>
Phineas
got
a
note
from
her
in
three
words
to
say
that
she
was
at
home
and
would
see
him
if
he
called
on
Sunday
afternoon
.
<EOS>
The
Sunday
to
which
she
alluded
was
the
last
day
of
February
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
now
more
certain
than
ever
that
something
was
wrong
.
<EOS>
Had
there
been
nothing
wrong
between
Lady
Laura
and
her
husband
<EOS>
,
she
would
not
have
rebelled
against
him
by
asking
visitors
to
the
house
on
a
Sunday
.
<EOS>
He
had
nothing
to
do
with
that
,
however
,
and
of
course
he
did
as
he
was
desired
.
<EOS>
He
called
on
the
Sunday
,
and
found
Mrs.
Bonteen
sitting
with
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
just
in
time
for
the
debate
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
when
the
first
greeting
was
over
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mean
to
say
that
you
intend
to
sit
it
out
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
"
Every
word
of
it
,
 
unless
I
lose
my
seat
.
<EOS>
What
else
is
there
to
be
done
at
present
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
the
place
they
give
us
is
so
unpleasant
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
are
worse
places
even
than
the
Ladies
'
Gallery
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
And
perhaps
it
is
as
well
to
make
oneself
used
to
inconveniences
of
all
kinds
.
<EOS>
You
will
speak
,
Mr.
Finn
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
intend
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
will
.
<EOS>
The
great
speeches
will
be
Mr.
Gresham
's
,
Mr.
Daubeny
's
,
and
Mr.
Monk
's
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Mr.
Palliser
intends
to
be
very
strong
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
man
can
not
be
strong
or
not
as
he
likes
it
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
I
believe
to
be
a
most
useful
man
,
but
he
never
can
become
an
orator
.
<EOS>
He
is
of
the
same
class
as
Mr.
Kennedy
,
 
only
of
course
higher
in
the
class
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
all
look
for
a
great
speech
from
Mr.
Kennedy
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
the
slightest
idea
whether
he
will
open
his
lips
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
Immediately
after
that
Mrs.
Bonteen
took
her
leave
.
<EOS>
"
I
hate
that
woman
like
poison
,
"
continued
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
always
playing
a
game
,
and
it
is
such
a
small
game
that
she
plays
!
<EOS>
And
she
contributes
so
little
to
society
.
<EOS>
She
is
not
witty
nor
well
-
informed
,
 
not
even
sufficiently
ignorant
or
ridiculous
to
be
a
laughing
-
stock
.
<EOS>
One
gets
nothing
from
her
,
and
yet
she
has
made
her
footing
good
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
she
was
a
friend
of
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
did
not
think
so
!
<EOS>
You
could
not
have
thought
so
!
<EOS>
How
can
you
bring
such
an
accusation
against
me
,
knowing
me
as
you
do
?
<EOS>
But
never
mind
Mrs.
Bonteen
now
.
<EOS>
On
what
day
shall
you
speak
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On
Tuesday
if
I
can
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
can
arrange
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
endeavour
to
do
so
,
as
far
as
any
arrangement
can
go
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
carry
the
second
reading
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Phineas
;
"
I
think
we
shall
;
but
by
the
votes
of
men
who
are
determined
so
to
pull
the
bill
to
pieces
in
committee
,
that
its
own
parents
will
not
know
it
.
<EOS>
I
doubt
whether
Mr.
Mildmay
will
have
the
temper
to
stand
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
tell
me
that
Mr.
Mildmay
will
abandon
the
custody
of
the
bill
to
Mr.
Gresham
after
his
first
speech
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
Mr.
Gresham
's
temper
is
more
enduring
than
Mr.
Mildmay
's
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;
 
we
shall
see
.
<EOS>
My
own
impression
is
that
nothing
would
save
the
country
so
effectually
at
the
present
moment
as
the
removal
of
Mr.
Turnbull
to
a
higher
and
a
better
sphere
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
us
say
the
House
of
Lords
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
God
forbid
!
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
sat
there
for
half
an
hour
and
then
got
up
to
go
,
having
spoken
no
word
on
any
other
subject
than
that
of
politics
.
<EOS>
He
longed
to
ask
after
Violet
.
<EOS>
He
longed
to
make
some
inquiry
respecting
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
And
,
to
tell
the
truth
,
he
felt
painfully
curious
to
hear
Lady
Laura
say
something
about
her
own
self
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
but
remember
what
had
been
said
between
them
up
over
the
waterfall
,
and
how
he
had
been
warned
not
to
return
to
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
And
then
again
,
did
Lady
Laura
know
anything
of
what
had
passed
between
him
and
Violet
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
is
your
brother
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
as
he
rose
from
his
chair
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oswald
is
in
London
.
<EOS>
He
was
here
not
an
hour
before
you
came
in
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
staying
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
At
Moroni
's
.
<EOS>
He
goes
down
on
Tuesday
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
He
is
to
see
his
father
to
-
morrow
morning
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
By
agreement
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
by
agreement
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
new
trouble
,
 
about
money
that
they
think
to
be
due
to
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
not
tell
you
all
now
.
<EOS>
There
have
been
some
words
between
Mr.
Kennedy
and
papa
.
<EOS>
But
I
wo
n't
talk
about
it
.
<EOS>
You
would
find
Oswald
at
Moroni
's
at
any
hour
before
eleven
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
he
say
anything
about
me
?
"
asked
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
mentioned
your
name
certainly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
ask
from
vanity
,
but
I
want
to
know
whether
he
is
angry
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Angry
with
you
!
<EOS>
Not
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
just
what
he
said
.
<EOS>
He
said
he
should
not
wish
to
live
even
with
you
,
but
that
he
would
sooner
try
it
with
you
than
with
any
man
he
ever
knew
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
He
had
got
a
letter
from
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
did
not
say
so
;
 
but
he
did
not
say
he
had
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
see
him
to
-
morrow
if
I
can
.
"
<EOS>
And
then
Phineas
prepared
to
go
.
  
<EOS>
"
One
word
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
hardly
looking
him
in
the
face
and
yet
making
an
effort
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
to
forget
what
I
said
to
you
at
Loughlinter
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
shall
be
as
though
it
were
forgotten
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
it
be
absolutely
forgotten
.
<EOS>
In
such
a
case
a
man
is
bound
to
do
all
that
a
woman
asks
him
,
and
no
man
has
a
truer
spirit
of
chivalry
than
yourself
.
<EOS>
That
is
all
.
<EOS>
Look
in
when
you
can
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
ask
you
to
dine
here
as
yet
,
because
we
are
so
frightfully
dull
.
<EOS>
Do
your
best
on
Tuesday
,
and
then
let
us
see
you
on
Wednesday
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
as
he
walked
across
the
park
towards
his
club
made
up
his
mind
that
he
would
forget
the
scene
by
the
waterfall
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
quite
known
what
it
had
meant
,
and
he
would
wipe
it
away
from
his
mind
altogether
.
<EOS>
He
acknowledged
to
himself
that
chivalry
did
demand
of
him
that
he
should
never
allow
himself
to
think
of
Lady
Laura
's
rash
words
to
him
.
<EOS>
That
she
was
not
happy
with
her
husband
<EOS>
was
very
clear
to
him
;
 
but
that
was
altogether
another
affair
.
<EOS>
She
might
be
unhappy
with
her
husband
without
indulging
any
guilty
love
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
thought
it
possible
that
she
could
be
happy
living
with
such
a
husband
as
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
All
that
,
however
,
was
now
past
remedy
,
and
she
must
simply
endure
the
mode
of
life
which
she
had
prepared
for
herself
.
<EOS>
There
were
other
men
and
women
in
London
tied
together
for
better
and
worse
,
in
reference
to
whose
union
their
friends
knew
that
there
would
be
no
better
;
 
that
it
must
be
all
worse
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
must
bear
it
,
as
it
was
borne
by
many
another
married
woman
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
Monday
morning
Phineas
called
at
Moroni
's
Hotel
at
ten
o'clock
,
but
in
spite
of
Lady
Laura
's
assurance
to
the
contrary
,
he
found
that
Lord
Chiltern
was
out
.
<EOS>
He
had
felt
some
palpitation
at
the
heart
as
he
made
his
inquiry
,
knowing
well
the
fiery
nature
of
the
man
he
expected
to
see
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
that
there
would
be
some
actual
personal
conflict
between
him
and
this
half
-
mad
lord
before
he
got
back
again
into
the
street
.
<EOS>
What
Lady
Laura
had
said
about
her
brother
did
not
in
the
estimation
of
Phineas
make
this
at
all
the
less
probable
.
<EOS>
The
half
-
mad
lord
was
so
singular
in
his
ways
that
it
might
well
be
that
he
should
speak
handsomely
of
a
rival
behind
his
back
and
yet
take
him
by
the
throat
as
soon
as
they
were
together
,
face
to
face
.
<EOS>
And
yet
,
as
Phineas
thought
,
it
was
necessary
that
he
should
see
the
half
-
mad
lord
.
<EOS>
He
had
written
a
letter
to
which
he
had
received
no
reply
,
and
he
considered
it
to
be
incumbent
on
him
to
ask
whether
it
had
been
received
and
whether
any
answer
to
it
was
intended
to
be
given
.
<EOS>
He
went
therefore
to
Lord
Chiltern
at
once
,
 
as
I
have
said
,
with
some
feeling
at
his
heart
that
there
might
be
violence
,
at
any
rate
of
words
,
before
he
should
find
himself
again
in
the
street
.
<EOS>
But
Lord
Chiltern
was
not
there
.
<EOS>
All
that
the
porter
knew
was
that
Lord
Chiltern
intended
to
leave
the
house
on
the
following
morning
.
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
wrote
a
note
and
left
it
with
the
porter
.
  
<EOS>
DEAR
CHILTERN
,
  
I
particularly
want
to
see
you
with
reference
to
a
letter
I
wrote
to
you
last
summer
.
<EOS>
I
must
be
in
the
House
to
-
day
from
four
till
the
debate
is
over
.
<EOS>
I
will
be
at
the
Reform
Club
from
two
till
half
-
past
three
,
and
will
come
if
you
will
send
for
me
,
or
I
will
meet
you
anywhere
at
any
hour
to
-
morrow
morning
.
  
<EOS>
Yours
,
always
,
P.
F.
  
No
message
came
to
him
at
the
Reform
Club
,
and
he
was
in
his
seat
in
the
House
by
four
o'clock
.
<EOS>
During
the
debate
a
note
was
brought
to
him
,
which
ran
as
follows
:
    
<EOS>
I
have
got
your
letter
this
moment
.
<EOS>
Of
course
we
must
meet
.
<EOS>
I
hunt
on
Tuesday
,
and
go
down
by
the
early
train
;
but
I
will
come
to
town
on
Wednesday
.
<EOS>
We
shall
require
to
be
private
,
and
I
will
therefore
be
at
your
rooms
at
one
o'clock
on
that
day
.
 
<EOS>
C.
  
Phineas
at
once
perceived
that
the
note
was
a
hostile
note
,
written
in
an
angry
spirit
,
 
written
to
one
whom
the
writer
did
not
at
the
moment
acknowledge
to
be
his
friend
.
<EOS>
This
was
certainly
the
case
,
whatever
Lord
Chiltern
may
have
said
to
his
sister
as
to
his
friendship
for
Phineas
.
<EOS>
Phineas
crushed
the
note
into
his
pocket
,
and
of
course
determined
that
he
would
be
in
his
rooms
at
the
hour
named
.
  
<EOS>
The
debate
was
opened
by
a
speech
from
Mr.
Mildmay
,
in
which
that
gentleman
at
great
length
and
with
much
perspicuity
explained
his
notion
of
that
measure
of
Parliamentary
Reform
which
he
thought
to
be
necessary
.
<EOS>
He
was
listened
to
with
the
greatest
attention
to
the
close
,
 
and
perhaps
,
at
the
end
of
his
speech
,
with
more
attention
than
usual
,
as
there
had
gone
abroad
a
rumour
that
the
Prime
Minister
intended
to
declare
that
this
would
be
the
last
effort
of
his
life
in
that
course
.
<EOS>
But
,
if
he
ever
intended
to
utter
such
a
pledge
,
his
heart
misgave
him
when
the
time
came
for
uttering
it
.
<EOS>
He
merely
said
that
as
the
management
of
the
bill
in
committee
would
be
an
affair
of
much
labour
,
and
probably
spread
over
many
nights
,
he
would
be
assisted
in
his
work
by
his
colleagues
,
and
especially
by
his
right
honourable
friend
the
Secretary
of
State
for
Foreign
Affairs
.
<EOS>
It
was
then
understood
that
Mr.
Gresham
would
take
the
lead
<EOS>
should
the
bill
go
into
committee
;
 
but
it
was
understood
also
that
no
resignation
of
leadership
had
been
made
by
Mr.
Mildmay
.
  
<EOS>
The
measure
now
proposed
to
the
House
was
very
much
the
same
as
that
which
had
been
brought
forward
in
the
last
session
.
<EOS>
The
existing
theory
of
British
representation
was
not
to
be
changed
,
but
the
actual
practice
was
to
be
brought
nearer
to
the
ideal
theory
.
<EOS>
The
ideas
of
manhood
suffrage
,
and
of
electoral
districts
,
were
to
be
as
for
ever
removed
from
the
bulwarks
of
the
British
Constitution
.
<EOS>
There
were
to
be
counties
with
agricultural
constituencies
,
purposely
arranged
to
be
purely
agricultural
,
whenever
the
nature
of
the
counties
would
admit
of
its
being
so
.
<EOS>
No
artificer
at
Reform
,
let
him
be
Conservative
or
Liberal
,
can
make
Middlesex
or
Lancashire
agricultural
;
but
Wiltshire
and
Suffolk
were
to
be
preserved
inviolable
to
the
plough
,
 
and
the
apples
of
Devonshire
were
still
to
have
their
sway
.
<EOS>
Every
town
in
the
three
kingdoms
with
a
certain
population
was
to
have
two
members
.
<EOS>
But
here
there
was
much
room
for
cavil
,
 
as
all
men
knew
would
be
the
case
.
<EOS>
Who
shall
say
what
is
a
town
,
or
where
shall
be
its
limits
?
<EOS>
Bits
of
counties
might
be
borrowed
,
so
as
to
lessen
the
Conservatism
of
the
county
without
endangering
the
Liberalism
of
the
borough
.
<EOS>
And
then
there
were
the
boroughs
with
one
member
,
 
and
then
the
groups
of
little
boroughs
.
<EOS>
In
the
discussion
of
any
such
arrangement
how
easy
is
the
picking
of
holes
;
how
impossible
the
fabrication
of
a
garment
that
shall
be
impervious
to
such
picking
!
<EOS>
Then
again
there
was
that
great
question
of
the
ballot
.
<EOS>
On
that
there
was
to
be
no
mistake
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
again
pledged
himself
to
disappear
from
the
Treasury
bench
should
any
motion
,
clause
,
or
resolution
be
carried
by
that
House
in
favour
of
the
ballot
.
<EOS>
He
spoke
for
three
hours
,
and
then
left
the
carcass
of
his
bill
to
be
fought
for
by
the
opposing
armies
.
  
<EOS>
No
reader
of
these
pages
will
desire
that
the
speeches
in
the
debate
should
be
even
indicated
.
<EOS>
It
soon
became
known
that
the
Conservatives
would
not
divide
the
House
against
the
second
reading
of
the
bill
.
<EOS>
They
declared
,
however
,
very
plainly
their
intention
of
so
altering
the
clauses
of
the
bill
in
committee
,
 
or
at
least
of
attempting
so
to
do
,
 
as
to
make
the
bill
their
bill
,
rather
than
the
bill
of
their
opponents
.
<EOS>
To
this
Mr.
Palliser
replied
that
as
long
as
nothing
vital
was
touched
,
the
Government
would
only
be
too
happy
to
oblige
their
friends
opposite
.
<EOS>
If
anything
vital
were
touched
,
the
Government
could
only
fall
back
upon
their
friends
on
that
side
.
<EOS>
And
in
this
way
men
were
very
civil
to
each
other
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Turnbull
,
who
opened
the
debate
on
the
Tuesday
,
thundered
out
an
assurance
to
gods
and
men
that
he
would
divide
the
House
on
the
second
reading
of
the
bill
itself
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
doubt
but
that
there
were
many
good
men
and
true
to
go
with
him
into
the
lobby
,
but
into
the
lobby
he
would
go
if
he
had
no
more
than
a
single
friend
to
support
him
.
<EOS>
And
he
warned
the
Sovereign
,
and
he
warned
the
House
,
and
he
warned
the
people
of
England
,
that
the
measure
of
Reform
now
proposed
by
a
so
-
called
liberal
Minister
was
a
measure
prepared
in
concert
with
the
ancient
enemies
of
the
people
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
loud
,
very
angry
,
and
quite
successful
in
hallooing
down
sundry
attempts
which
were
made
to
interrupt
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
find
,
"
he
said
,
"
that
there
are
many
members
here
who
do
not
know
me
yet
,
 
young
members
,
probably
,
who
are
green
from
the
waste
lands
and
road
-
sides
of
private
life
.
<EOS>
They
will
know
me
soon
,
and
then
,
may
be
,
there
will
be
less
of
this
foolish
noise
,
less
of
this
elongation
of
unnecessary
necks
.
<EOS>
Our
Rome
must
be
aroused
to
a
sense
of
its
danger
by
other
voices
than
these
.
"
<EOS>
He
was
called
to
order
,
but
it
was
ruled
that
he
had
not
been
out
of
order
,
 
and
he
was
very
triumphant
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
answered
him
,
and
it
was
declared
afterwards
that
Mr.
Monk
's
speech
was
one
of
the
finest
pieces
of
oratory
that
had
ever
been
uttered
in
that
House
.
<EOS>
He
made
one
remark
personal
to
Mr.
Turnbull
.
<EOS>
"
I
quite
agreed
with
the
right
honourable
gentleman
in
the
chair
,
"
he
said
,
"
when
he
declared
that
the
honourable
member
was
not
out
of
order
just
now
.
<EOS>
We
all
of
us
agree
with
him
always
on
such
points
.
<EOS>
The
rules
of
our
House
have
been
laid
down
with
the
utmost
latitude
,
so
that
the
course
of
our
debates
may
not
be
frivolously
or
too
easily
interrupted
.
<EOS>
But
a
member
may
be
so
in
order
as
to
incur
the
displeasure
of
the
House
,
and
to
merit
the
reproaches
of
his
countrymen
.
<EOS>
"
This
little
duel
gave
great
life
to
the
debate
;
but
it
was
said
that
those
two
great
Reformers
,
Mr.
Turnbull
and
Mr.
Monk
,
could
never
again
meet
as
friends
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
the
debate
on
Tuesday
,
Phineas
got
upon
his
legs
.
<EOS>
The
reader
,
I
trust
,
will
remember
that
hitherto
he
had
failed
altogether
as
a
speaker
.
<EOS>
On
one
occasion
he
had
lacked
even
the
spirit
to
use
and
deliver
an
oration
which
he
had
prepared
.
<EOS>
On
a
second
occasion
he
had
broken
down
,
 
woefully
,
and
past
all
redemption
,
as
said
those
who
were
not
his
friends
,
 
unfortunately
,
but
not
past
redemption
,
as
said
those
who
were
his
true
friends
.
<EOS>
After
that
once
again
he
had
arisen
and
said
a
few
words
which
had
called
for
no
remark
,
and
had
been
spoken
as
though
he
were
in
the
habit
of
addressing
the
House
daily
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
doubted
whether
there
were
half
-
a
-
dozen
men
now
present
who
recognised
the
fact
that
this
man
,
who
was
so
well
known
to
so
many
of
them
,
was
now
about
to
make
another
attempt
at
a
first
speech
.
<EOS>
Phineas
himself
diligently
attempted
to
forget
that
such
was
the
case
.
<EOS>
He
had
prepared
for
himself
a
few
headings
of
what
he
intended
to
say
,
and
on
one
or
two
points
had
arranged
his
words
.
<EOS>
His
hope
was
that
even
though
he
should
forget
the
words
,
he
might
still
be
able
to
cling
to
the
thread
of
his
discourse
.
<EOS>
When
he
found
himself
again
upon
his
legs
amidst
those
crowded
seats
,
for
a
few
moments
there
came
upon
him
that
old
sensation
of
awe
.
<EOS>
Again
things
grew
dim
before
his
eyes
,
and
again
he
hardly
knew
at
which
end
of
that
long
chamber
the
Speaker
was
sitting
.
<EOS>
But
there
arose
within
him
a
sudden
courage
,
as
soon
as
the
sound
of
his
own
voice
in
that
room
had
made
itself
intimate
to
his
ear
;
and
after
the
first
few
sentences
,
all
fear
,
all
awe
,
was
gone
from
him
.
<EOS>
When
he
read
his
speech
in
the
report
afterwards
,
he
found
that
he
had
strayed
very
wide
of
his
intended
course
,
but
he
had
strayed
without
tumbling
into
ditches
,
or
falling
into
sunken
pits
.
<EOS>
He
had
spoken
much
from
Mr.
Monk
's
letter
,
but
had
had
the
grace
to
acknowledge
whence
had
come
his
inspiration
.
<EOS>
He
hardly
knew
,
however
,
whether
he
had
failed
again
or
not
,
till
Barrington
Erle
came
up
to
him
as
they
were
leaving
the
House
,
with
his
old
easy
pressing
manner
.
"
<EOS>
So
you
have
got
into
form
at
last
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
always
thought
that
it
would
come
.
<EOS>
I
never
for
a
moment
believed
but
that
it
would
come
sooner
or
later
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
answered
not
a
word
;
but
he
went
home
and
lay
awake
all
night
triumphant
.
<EOS>
The
verdict
of
Barrington
Erle
sufficed
to
assure
him
that
he
had
succeeded
.
   
<EOS>
A
Rough
Encounter
 
Phineas
,
when
he
woke
,
had
two
matters
to
occupy
his
mind
,
 
his
success
of
the
previous
night
,
and
his
coming
interview
with
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
He
stayed
at
home
the
whole
morning
,
knowing
that
nothing
could
be
done
before
the
hour
Lord
Chiltern
had
named
for
his
visit
.
<EOS>
He
read
every
word
of
the
debate
,
studiously
postponing
the
perusal
of
his
own
speech
till
he
should
come
to
it
in
due
order
.
<EOS>
And
then
he
wrote
to
his
father
,
commencing
his
letter
as
though
his
writing
had
no
reference
to
the
affairs
of
the
previous
night
.
<EOS>
But
he
soon
found
himself
compelled
to
break
into
some
mention
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
send
you
a
_
Times
_
,
"
he
said
,
"
in
order
that
you
may
see
that
I
have
had
my
finger
in
the
pie
.
<EOS>
I
have
hitherto
abstained
from
putting
myself
forward
in
the
House
,
partly
through
a
base
fear
for
which
I
despise
myself
,
and
partly
through
a
feeling
of
prudence
that
a
man
of
my
age
should
not
be
in
a
hurry
to
gather
laurels
.
<EOS>
This
is
literally
true
.
<EOS>
There
has
been
the
fear
,
and
there
has
been
the
prudence
.
<EOS>
My
wonder
is
,
that
I
have
not
incurred
more
contempt
from
others
because
I
have
been
a
coward
.
<EOS>
People
have
been
so
kind
to
me
that
I
must
suppose
them
to
have
judged
me
more
leniently
than
I
have
judged
myself
.
"
<EOS>
Then
,
as
he
was
putting
up
the
paper
,
he
looked
again
at
his
own
speech
,
and
of
course
read
every
word
of
it
once
more
.
<EOS>
As
he
did
so
it
occurred
to
him
that
the
reporters
had
been
more
than
courteous
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
man
who
had
followed
him
had
been
,
he
thought
,
at
any
rate
as
long
-
winded
as
himself
;
but
to
this
orator
less
than
half
a
column
had
been
granted
.
<EOS>
To
him
had
been
granted
ten
lines
in
big
type
,
and
after
that
a
whole
column
and
a
half
.
<EOS>
Let
Lord
Chiltern
come
and
do
his
worst
!
  
<EOS>
When
it
wanted
but
twenty
minutes
to
one
,
and
he
was
beginning
to
think
in
what
way
he
had
better
answer
the
half
-
mad
lord
,
should
the
lord
in
his
wrath
be
very
mad
,
there
came
to
him
a
note
by
the
hand
of
some
messenger
.
<EOS>
He
knew
at
once
that
it
was
from
Lady
Laura
,
and
opened
it
in
hot
haste
<EOS>
It
was
as
follows
:
    
<EOS>
DEAR
MR
.
FINN
,
  
<EOS>
We
are
all
talking
about
your
speech
.
<EOS>
My
father
was
in
the
gallery
and
heard
it
,
 
and
said
that
he
had
to
thank
me
for
sending
you
to
Loughton
.
<EOS>
That
made
me
very
happy
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
declares
that
you
were
eloquent
,
but
too
short
.
<EOS>
That
coming
from
him
is
praise
indeed
.
<EOS>
I
have
seen
Barrington
,
who
takes
pride
to
himself
that
you
are
his
political
child
.
<EOS>
Violet
says
that
it
is
the
only
speech
she
ever
read
.
<EOS>
I
was
there
,
and
was
delighted
.
<EOS>
I
was
sure
that
it
was
in
you
to
do
it
.
  
<EOS>
Yours
,
L.
K.
  
I
suppose
we
shall
see
you
after
the
House
is
up
,
but
I
write
this
as
I
shall
barely
have
an
opportunity
of
speaking
to
you
then
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
in
Portman
Square
,
not
at
home
,
from
six
till
seven
.
  
<EOS>
The
moment
in
which
Phineas
refolded
this
note
and
put
it
into
his
breast
coat
-
pocket
was
,
I
think
,
the
happiest
of
his
life
.
<EOS>
Then
,
before
he
had
withdrawn
his
hand
from
his
breast
,
he
remembered
that
what
was
now
about
to
take
place
between
him
and
Lord
Chiltern
would
probably
be
the
means
of
separating
him
altogether
from
Lady
Laura
and
her
family
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
might
it
not
render
it
necessary
that
he
should
abandon
the
seat
in
Parliament
which
had
been
conferred
upon
him
by
the
personal
kindness
of
Lord
Brentford
?
<EOS>
Let
that
be
as
it
might
.
<EOS>
One
thing
was
clear
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
abandon
Violet
Effingham
till
he
should
be
desired
to
do
so
in
the
plainest
language
by
Violet
Effingham
herself
.
<EOS>
Looking
at
his
watch
he
saw
that
it
was
one
o'clock
,
and
at
that
moment
Lord
Chiltern
was
announced
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
went
forward
immediately
with
his
hand
out
to
meet
his
visitor
.
<EOS>
"
Chiltern
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
am
very
glad
to
see
you
.
"
<EOS>
But
Lord
Chiltern
did
not
take
his
hand
.
<EOS>
Passing
on
to
the
table
,
with
his
hat
still
on
his
head
,
and
with
a
dark
scowl
upon
his
brow
,
the
young
lord
stood
for
a
few
moments
perfectly
silent
.
<EOS>
Then
he
chucked
a
letter
across
the
table
to
the
spot
at
which
Phineas
was
standing
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
taking
up
the
letter
,
perceived
that
it
was
that
which
he
,
in
his
great
attempt
to
be
honest
,
had
written
from
the
inn
at
Loughton
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
my
own
letter
to
you
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
it
is
your
letter
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
received
it
oddly
enough
together
with
your
own
note
at
Moroni
's
,
 
on
Monday
morning
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
round
the
world
,
I
suppose
,
and
reached
me
only
then
.
<EOS>
You
must
withdraw
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Withdraw
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
withdraw
it
.
<EOS>
As
far
as
I
can
learn
,
without
asking
any
question
which
would
have
committed
myself
or
the
young
lady
,
you
have
not
acted
upon
it
.
<EOS>
You
have
not
yet
done
what
you
there
threaten
to
do
.
<EOS>
In
that
you
have
been
very
wise
,
and
there
can
be
no
difficulty
in
your
withdrawing
the
letter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
shall
not
withdraw
it
,
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
remember
 
<EOS>
what
 
I
once
 
told
you
,
 
about
myself
and
Miss
Effingham
?
<EOS>
"
This
question
he
asked
very
slowly
,
pausing
between
the
words
,
and
looking
full
into
the
face
of
his
rival
,
towards
whom
he
had
gradually
come
nearer
.
<EOS>
And
his
countenance
,
as
he
did
so
,
was
by
no
means
pleasant
.
<EOS>
The
redness
of
his
complexion
had
become
more
ruddy
than
usual
;
he
still
wore
his
hat
as
though
with
studied
insolence
;
his
right
hand
was
clenched
;
and
there
was
that
look
of
angry
purpose
in
his
eye
which
no
man
likes
to
see
in
the
eye
of
an
antagonist
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
afraid
of
no
violence
,
personal
to
himself
;
but
he
was
afraid
of
,
 
of
what
I
may
,
perhaps
,
best
call
"
a
row
.
"
<EOS>
To
be
tumbling
over
the
chairs
and
tables
with
his
late
friend
and
present
enemy
in
Mrs.
Bunce
's
room
would
be
most
unpleasant
to
him
.
<EOS>
If
there
were
to
be
blows
he
,
too
,
must
strike
;
 
and
he
was
very
averse
to
strike
Lady
Laura
's
brother
,
Lord
Brentford
's
son
,
Violet
Effingham
's
friend
.
<EOS>
If
need
be
,
however
,
he
would
strike
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
remember
what
you
mean
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
declared
that
you
would
quarrel
with
any
man
who
might
presume
to
address
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
Is
it
that
to
which
you
allude
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
that
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
remember
what
you
said
very
well
.
<EOS>
If
nothing
else
was
to
deter
me
from
asking
Miss
Effingham
to
be
my
wife
,
you
will
hardly
think
that
that
ought
to
have
any
weight
.
<EOS>
The
threat
had
no
weight
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
spoken
as
a
threat
,
sir
,
and
that
you
know
as
well
as
I
do
.
<EOS>
It
was
said
from
a
friend
to
a
friend
,
 
as
I
thought
then
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
not
the
less
true
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
what
you
can
think
of
faith
and
truth
and
honesty
of
purpose
when
you
took
advantage
of
my
absence
,
 
you
,
whom
I
had
told
a
thousand
times
that
I
loved
her
better
than
my
own
soul
!
<EOS>
You
stand
before
the
world
as
a
rising
man
,
and
I
stand
before
the
world
as
a
man
 
damned
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
chosen
by
my
father
to
sit
for
our
family
borough
,
while
I
am
an
outcast
from
his
house
.
<EOS>
You
have
Cabinet
Ministers
for
your
friends
,
while
I
have
hardly
a
decent
associate
left
to
me
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
say
of
myself
that
I
have
never
done
anything
unworthy
of
a
gentleman
,
while
this
thing
that
you
are
doing
is
unworthy
of
the
lowest
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
nothing
unworthy
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
I
wrote
to
you
instantly
when
I
had
resolved
,
 
though
it
was
painful
to
me
to
have
to
tell
such
a
secret
to
any
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
wrote
!
<EOS>
Yes
;
when
I
was
miles
distant
;
weeks
,
months
away
.
<EOS>
But
I
did
not
come
here
to
bullyrag
like
an
old
woman
.
<EOS>
I
got
your
letter
only
on
Monday
,
and
know
nothing
of
what
has
occurred
.
<EOS>
Is
Miss
Effingham
to
be
 
your
wife
?
"
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
had
now
come
quite
close
to
Phineas
,
and
Phineas
felt
that
that
clenched
fist
might
be
in
his
face
in
half
a
moment
.
<EOS>
Miss
Effingham
of
course
was
not
engaged
to
him
,
but
it
seemed
to
him
that
if
he
were
now
so
to
declare
,
such
declaration
would
appear
to
have
been
drawn
from
him
by
fear
.
<EOS>
"
I
ask
you
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
,
"
in
what
position
you
now
stand
towards
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
not
a
coward
you
will
tell
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whether
I
tell
you
or
not
,
you
know
that
I
am
not
a
coward
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
have
to
try
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
But
if
you
please
I
will
ask
you
for
an
answer
to
my
question
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
paused
for
a
moment
,
thinking
what
honesty
of
purpose
and
a
high
spirit
would
,
when
combined
together
,
demand
of
him
,
and
together
with
these
requirements
<EOS>
he
felt
that
he
was
bound
to
join
some
feeling
of
duty
towards
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
was
standing
there
,
fiery
red
,
with
his
hand
still
clenched
,
and
his
hat
still
on
,
waiting
for
his
answer
.
<EOS>
"
Let
me
have
your
question
again
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
and
I
will
answer
it
if
I
find
that
I
can
do
so
without
loss
of
self
-
respect
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ask
you
in
what
position
you
stand
towards
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
Mind
,
I
do
not
doubt
at
all
,
but
I
choose
to
have
a
reply
from
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
remember
,
of
course
,
that
I
can
only
answer
to
the
best
of
my
belief
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Answer
to
the
best
of
your
belief
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
she
regards
me
as
an
intimate
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Had
you
said
as
an
indifferent
acquaintance
,
you
would
,
I
think
,
have
been
nearer
the
mark
.
<EOS>
But
we
will
let
that
be
.
<EOS>
I
presume
I
may
understand
that
you
have
given
up
any
idea
of
changing
that
position
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
understand
nothing
of
the
kind
,
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
;
 
what
hope
have
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
another
thing
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
speak
of
that
;
 
at
any
rate
not
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
sir
,
 
"
and
now
Lord
Chiltern
advanced
another
step
and
raised
his
hand
as
though
he
were
about
to
put
it
with
some
form

violence
on
the
person
of
his
rival
.
  
<EOS>
"
Stop
,
Chiltern
,
"
said
Phineas
,
stepping
back
,
so
that
there
was
some
article
of
furniture
between
him
and
his
adversary
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
choose
that
there
should
be
a
riot
here
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
call
a
riot
,
sir
?
<EOS>
I
believe
that
after
all
you
are
a
poltroon
.
<EOS>
What
I
require
of
you
is
that
you
shall
meet
me
.
<EOS>
Will
you
do
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
mean
,
 
to
fight
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
 
to
fight
;
to
fight
;
to
fight
.
<EOS>
For
what
other
purpose
do
you
suppose
that
I
can
wish
to
meet
you
?
"
<EOS>
Phineas
felt
at
the
moment
that
the
fighting
of
a
duel
would
be
destructive
to
all
his
political
hopes
.
<EOS>
Few
Englishmen
fight
duels
in
these
days
.
<EOS>
They
who
do
so
are
always
reckoned
to
be
fools
.
<EOS>
And
a
duel
between
him
and
Lord
Brentford
's
son
must
,
as
he
thought
,
separate
him
from
Violet
,
from
Lady
Laura
,
from
Lord
Brentford
,
and
from
his
borough
.
<EOS>
But
yet
how
could
he
refuse
?
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
to
think
of
,
sir
,
when
such
an
offer
as
that
is
made
to
you
?
"
said
the
fiery
-
red
lord
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
to
think
whether
I
have
courage
enough
to
refuse
to
make
myself
an
ass
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
say
that
you
do
not
wish
to
have
a
riot
.
<EOS>
That
is
your
way
to
escape
what
you
call
 
a
riot
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
want
to
bully
me
,
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
sir
;
 
I
simply
want
this
,
that
you
should
leave
me
where
you
found
me
,
and
not
interfere
with
that
which
you
have
long
known
<EOS>
I
claim
as
my
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
is
not
your
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
can
only
fight
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
send
some
friend
to
me
,
and
I
will
name
some
one
,
whom
he
shall
meet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
will
do
that
if
I
have
your
promise
to
meet
me
.
<EOS>
We
can
be
in
Belgium
in
an
hour
or
two
,
and
back
again
in
a
few
more
hours
;
 
that
is
,
any
one
of
us
who
may
chance
to
be
alive
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
select
a
friend
,
and
will
tell
him
everything
,
and
will
then
do
as
he
bids
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
some
old
steady
-
going
buffer
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
,
perhaps
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
certainly
not
be
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
I
shall
probably
ask
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
to
manage
for
me
in
such
an
affair
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
will
see
him
at
once
,
then
,
so
that
Colepepper
may
arrange
with
him
this
afternoon
.
<EOS>
And
let
me
assure
you
,
Mr.
Finn
,
that
there
will
be
a
meeting
between
us
after
some
fashion
,
let
the
ideas
of
your
friend
Mr.
Fitzgibbon
be
what
they
may
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Lord
Chiltern
purposed
to
go
,
but
turned
again
as
he
was
going
.
"
<EOS>
And
remember
this
,
"
he
said
,
"
my
complaint
is
that
you
have
been
false
to
me
,
 
damnably
false
;
not
that
you
have
fallen
in
love
with
this
young
lady
or
with
that
.
"
<EOS>
Then
the
fiery
-
red
lord
opened
the
door
for
himself
and
took
his
departure
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
as
soon
as
he
was
alone
,
walked
down
to
the
House
,
at
which
there
was
an
early
sitting
.
<EOS>
As
he
went
there
was
one
great
question
which
he
had
to
settle
with
himself
,
 
<EOS>
Was
there
any
justice
in
the
charge
made
against
him
that
he
had
been
false
to
his
friend
?
<EOS>
When
he
had
thought
over
the
matter
at
Saulsby
,
after
rushing
down
there
that
he
might
throw
himself
at
Violet
's
feet
,
he
had
assured
himself
that
such
a
letter
as
that
which
he
resolved
to
write
to
Lord
Chiltern
,
would
be
even
chivalrous
in
its
absolute
honesty
.
<EOS>
He
would
tell
his
purpose
to
Lord
Chiltern
the
moment
that
his
purpose
was
formed
;
 
and
would
afterwards
speak
of
Lord
Chiltern
behind
his
back
as
one
dear
friend
should
speak
of
another
.
<EOS>
Had
Miss
Effingham
shown
the
slightest
intention
of
accepting
Lord
Chiltern
's
offer
,
he
would
have
acknowledged
to
himself
that
the
circumstances
of
his
position
made
it
impossible
that
he
should
,
with
honour
,
become
his
friend
's
rival
.
<EOS>
But
was
he
to
be
debarred
for
ever
from
getting
that
which
he
wanted
because
Lord
Chiltern
wanted
it
also
,
 
<EOS>
knowing
,
<EOS>
as
he
did
so
well
,
that
Lord
Chiltern
could
not
get
the
thing
which
he
wanted
?
<EOS>
All
this
had
been
quite
sufficient
for
him
at
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
But
now
the
charge
against
him
that
he
had
been
false
to
his
friend
rang
in
his
ears
and
made
him
unhappy
.
<EOS>
It
certainly
was
true
that
Lord
Chiltern
had
not
given
up
his
hopes
,
and
that
he
had
spoken
probably
more
openly
to
Phineas
respecting
them
than
he
had
done
to
any
other
human
being
.
<EOS>
If
it
was
true
that
he
had
been
false
,
then
he
must
comply
with
any
requisition
which
Lord
Chiltern
might
make
,
 
short
of
voluntarily
giving
up
the
lady
.
<EOS>
He
must
fight
if
he
were
asked
to
do
so
,
even
though
fighting
were
his
ruin
.
  
<EOS>
When
again
in
the
House
yesterday
's
scene
came
back
upon
him
,
and
more
than
one
man
came
to
him
congratulating
him
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
took
his
hand
and
spoke
a
word
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
old
Premier
nodded
to
him
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
greeted
him
;
and
Plantagenet
Palliser
openly
told
him
that
he
had
made
a
good
speech
.
<EOS>
How
sweet
would
all
this
have
been
had
there
not
been
ever
at
his
heart
the
remembrance
of
his
terrible
difficulty
,
 
the
consciousness
that
he
was
about
to
be
forced
into
an
absurdity
which
would
put
an
end
to
all
this
sweetness
!
<EOS>
Why
was
the
world
in
England
so
severe
against
duelling
?
<EOS>
After
all
,
as
he
regarded
the
matter
now
,
a
duel
might
be
the
best
way
,
nay
,
the
only
way
out
of
a
difficulty
.
<EOS>
If
he
might
only
be
allowed
to
go
out
with
Lord
Chiltern
the
whole
thing
might
be
arranged
.
<EOS>
If
he
were
not
shot
he
might
carry
on
his
suit
with
Miss
Effingham
unfettered
by
any
impediment
on
that
side
.
<EOS>
And
if
he
were
shot
,
what
matter
was
that
to
any
one
but
himself
?
<EOS>
Why
should
the
world
be
so
thin
-
skinned
,
 
so
foolishly
chary
of
human
life
?
  
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
did
not
come
to
the
House
,
and
Phineas
looked
for
him
at
both
the
clubs
which
he
frequented
,
 
leaving
a
note
at
each
as
he
did
not
find
him
.
<EOS>
He
also
left
a
note
for
him
at
his
lodgings
in
Duke
Street
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
see
you
this
evening
.
<EOS>
I
shall
dine
at
the
Reform
Club
,
 
<EOS>
pray
come
there
.
"
<EOS>
After
that
,
Phineas
went
up
to
Portman
Square
,
in
accordance
with
the
instructions
received
from
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
There
he
saw
Violet
Effingham
,
meeting
her
for
the
first
time
since
he
had
parted
from
her
on
the
great
steps
at
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
spoke
to
her
,
and
of
course
she
was
gracious
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
her
graciousness
was
only
a
smile
and
his
speech
was
only
a
word
.
<EOS>
There
were
many
in
the
room
,
but
not
enough
to
make
privacy
possible
,
 
as
it
becomes
possible
at
a
crowded
evening
meeting
.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
was
there
,
and
the
Bonteens
,
and
Barrington
Erle
,
and
Lady
Glencora
Palliser
,
and
Lord
Cantrip
with
his
young
wife
.
<EOS>
It
was
manifestly
a
meeting
of
Liberals
,
semi
-
social
and
semi
-
political
;
 
so
arranged
that
ladies
might
feel
that
some
interest
in
politics
was
allowed
to
them
,
and
perhaps
some
influence
also
.
<EOS>
Afterwards
Mr.
Palliser
himself
came
in
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
however
,
was
most
struck
by
finding
that
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
was
there
,
and
that
Mr.
Kennedy
was
not
.
<EOS>
In
regard
to
Mr.
Kennedy
,
he
was
quite
sure
that
had
such
a
meeting
taken
place
before
Lady
Laura
's
marriage
,
Mr.
Kennedy
would
have
been
present
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
speak
to
you
as
we
go
away
,
"
said
Phineas
,
whispering
a
word
into
Fitzgibbon
's
ear
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
leaving
notes
for
you
all
about
the
town
.
"
<EOS>
"
Not
a
duel
,
I
hope
,
"
said
Fitzgibbon
.
  
<EOS>
How
pleasant
it
was
,
 
that
meeting
;
or
would
have
been
had
<EOS>
there
not
been
that
nightmare
on
his
breast
!
<EOS>
They
all
talked
as
though
there
were
perfect
accord
between
them
and
perfect
confidence
.
<EOS>
There
were
there
great
men
,
 
Cabinet
Ministers
,
and
beautiful
women
,
 
the
wives
and
daughters
of
some
of
England
's
highest
nobles
.
<EOS>
And
Phineas
Finn
,
throwing
back
,
now
and
again
,
a
thought
to
Killaloe
,
found
himself
among
them
as
one
of
themselves
.
<EOS>
How
could
any
Mr.
Low
say
that
he
was
wrong
?
  
<EOS>
On
a
sofa
near
to
him
,
so
that
he
could
almost
touch
her
foot
with
his
,
was
sitting
Violet
Effingham
,
and
as
he
leaned
over
from
his
chair
discussing
some
point
in
Mr.
Mildmay
's
bill
with
that
most
inveterate
politician
,
Lady
Glencora
,
<EOS>
Violet
looked
into
his
face
and
smiled
.
<EOS>
Oh
heavens
!
<EOS>
If
Lord
Chiltern
and
he
might
only
toss
up
as
to
which
of
them
should
go
to
Patagonia
and
remain
there
for
the
next
ten
years
,
and
which
should
have
Violet
Effingham
for
a
wife
in
London
!
  
<EOS>
"
Come
along
,
Phineas
,
if
you
mean
to
come
,
"
said
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
of
course
bound
to
go
,
though
Lady
Glencora
was
still
talking
Radicalism
,
and
Violet
Effingham
was
still
smiling
ineffably
.
     
<EOS>
The
Duel
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
it
was
a
duel
;
 
bedad
I
did
,
"
said
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
,
standing
at
the
corner
of
Orchard
Street
and
Oxford
Street
,
when
Phineas
had
half
told
his
story
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
sure
of
it
from
the
tone
of
your
voice
,
my
boy
.
<EOS>
We
must
n't
let
it
come
off
,
that
's
all
;
 
not
if
we
can
help
it
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
was
allowed
to
proceed
and
finish
his
story
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
see
any
way
out
of
it
;
I
do
n't
,
indeed
,
"
said
Laurence
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
Phineas
had
come
to
think
that
the
duel
was
in
very
truth
the
best
way
out
of
the
difficulty
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
bad
way
out
,
but
then
it
was
a
way
;
 
and
he
could
not
see
any
other
.
"
<EOS>
As
for
ill
treating
him
,
that
's
nonsense
,
"
said
Laurence
.
<EOS>
"
What
are
the
girls
to
do
,
if
one
fellow
may
n't
come
on
as
soon
as
another
fellow
is
down
?
<EOS>
But
then
,
you
see
,
a
fellow
never
knows
when
he
's
down
himself
,
and
therefore
he
thinks
that
he
's
ill
used
.
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
what
now
.
<EOS>
I
should
n't
wonder
if
we
could
n't
do
it
on
the
sly
,
 
unless
one
of
you
is
stupid
enough
to
hit
the
other
in
an
awkward
place
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
certain
of
your
hand
now
,
the
right
shoulder
is
the
best
spot
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
felt
very
certain
that
he
would
not
hit
Lord
Chiltern
in
an
awkward
place
,
although
he
was
by
no
means
sure
of
his
hand
.
<EOS>
Let
come
what
might
,
he
would
not
aim
at
his
adversary
.
<EOS>
But
of
this
he
had
thought
it
proper
to
say
nothing
to
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
.
  
<EOS>
And
the
duel
did
come
off
on
the
sly
.
<EOS>
The
meeting
in
the
drawing
-
room
in
Portman
Square
,
of
which
mention
was
made
in
the
last
chapter
,
took
place
on
a
Wednesday
afternoon
.
<EOS>
On
the
Thursday
,
Friday
,
Monday
,
and
Tuesday
following
,
the
great
debate
on
Mr.
Mildmay
's
bill
was
continued
,
and
at
three
on
the
Tuesday
night
the
House
divided
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
majority
in
favour
of
the
Ministers
,
not
large
enough
to
permit
them
to
claim
a
triumph
for
their
party
,
or
even
an
ovation
for
themselves
;
but
still
sufficient
to
enable
them
to
send
their
bill
into
committee
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Daubeny
and
Mr.
Turnbull
had
again
joined
their
forces
together
in
opposition
to
the
ministerial
measure
.
<EOS>
On
the
Thursday
Phineas
had
shown
himself
in
the
House
,
but
during
the
remainder
of
this
interesting
period
he
was
absent
from
his
place
,
nor
was
he
seen
at
the
clubs
,
nor
did
any
man
know
of
his
whereabouts
.
<EOS>
I
think
that
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
was
the
first
to
miss
him
with
any
real
sense
of
his
absence
.
<EOS>
She
would
now
go
to
Portman
Square
on
the
afternoon
of
every
Sunday
,
 
at
which
time
her
husband
was
attending
the
second
service
of
his
church
,
 
<EOS>
and
there
she
would
receive
those
whom
she
called
her
father
's
guests
.
<EOS>
But
as
her
father
was
never
there
on
the
Sundays
,
and
as
these
gatherings
had
been
created
by
herself
,
the
reader
will
probably
think
that
she
was
obeying
her
husband
's
behests
in
regard
to
the
Sabbath
after
a
very
indifferent
fashion
.
<EOS>
The
reader
may
be
quite
sure
,
however
,
that
Mr.
Kennedy
knew
well
what
was
being
done
in
Portman
Square
.
<EOS>
Whatever
might
be
Lady
Laura
's
faults
,
she
did
not
commit
the
fault
of
disobeying
her
husband
in
secret
.
<EOS>
There
were
,
probably
,
a
few
words
on
the
subject
;
but
we
need
not
go
very
closely
into
that
matter
at
the
present
moment
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
Sunday
which
afforded
some
rest
in
the
middle
of
the
great
Reform
debate
Lady
Laura
asked
for
Mr.
Finn
,
and
no
one
could
answer
her
question
.
<EOS>
And
then
it
was
remembered
that
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
was
also
absent
.
<EOS>
Barrington
Erle
knew
nothing
of
Phineas
,
 
had
heard
nothing
;
but
was
able
to
say
that
Fitzgibbon
had
been
with
Mr.
Ratler
,
the
patronage
secretary
and
liberal
whip
,
early
on
Thursday
,
expressing
his
intention
of
absenting
himself
for
two
days
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Ratler
had
been
wroth
,
bidding
him
remain
at
his
duty
,
and
pointing
out
to
him
the
great
importance
of
the
moment
.
<EOS>
Then
Barrington
Erle
quoted
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
's
reply
.
<EOS>
"
My
boy
,
"
said
Laurence
to
poor
Ratler
,
"
the
path
of
duty
leads
but
to
the
grave
.
<EOS>
All
the
same
;
I
'll
be
in
at
the
death
,
Ratler
,
my
boy
,
as
sure
as
the
sun
's
in
heaven
.
<EOS>
"
Not
ten
minutes
after
the
telling
of
this
little
story
,
Fitzgibbon
entered
the
room
in
Portman
Square
,
and
Lady
Laura
at
once
asked
him
after
Phineas
.
"
<EOS>
Bedad
,
Lady
Laura
,
I
have
been
out
of
town
myself
for
two
days
,
and
I
know
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Finn
has
not
been
with
you
,
then
?
"
  
"
With
me
!
<EOS>
No
,
 
not
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
had
a
job
of
business
of
my
own
which
took
me
over
to
Paris
.
<EOS>
And
has
Phinny
fled
too
?
<EOS>
Poor
Ratler
!
<EOS>
I
should
n't
wonder
if
it
is
n't
an
asylum
<EOS>
he
's
in
before
the
session
is
over
.
"
  
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
certainly
possessed
the
rare
accomplishment
of
telling
a
lie
with
a
good
grace
.
<EOS>
Had
any
man
called
him
a
liar
he
would
have
considered
himself
to
be
not
only
insulted
,
but
injured
also
.
<EOS>
He
believed
himself
to
be
a
man
of
truth
.
<EOS>
There
were
,
however
,
in
his
estimation
certain
subjects
on
which
a
man
might
depart
as
wide
as
the
poles
are
asunder
from
truth
without
subjecting
himself
to
any
ignominy
for
falsehood
.
<EOS>
In
dealing
with
a
tradesman
as
to
his
debts
,
or
with
a
rival
as
to
a
lady
,
or
with
any
man
or
woman
in
defence
of
a
lady
's
character
,
or
in
any
such
matter
as
that
of
a
duel
,
Laurence
believed
that
a
gentleman
was
bound
to
lie
,
and
that
he
would
be
no
gentleman
if
he
hesitated
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
Not
the
slightest
prick
of
conscience
disturbed
him
when
he
told
Lady
Laura
that
he
had
been
in
Paris
,
and
that
he
knew
nothing
of
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
But
,
in
truth
,
during
the
last
day
or
two
he
had
been
in
Flanders
,
and
not
in
Paris
,
and
had
stood
as
second
with
his
friend
Phineas
on
the
sands
at
Blankenberg
,
a
little
fishing
-
town
some
twelve
miles
distant
from
Bruges
,
and
had
left
his
friend
since
that
at
an
hotel
at
Ostend
,
 
with
a
wound
just
under
the
shoulder
,
from
which
a
bullet
had
been
extracted
.
  
<EOS>
The
manner
of
the
meeting
had
been
in
this
wise
.
<EOS>
Captain
Colepepper
and
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
had
held
their
meeting
,
and
at
this
meeting
Laurence
had
taken
certain
standing
-
ground
on
behalf
of
his
friend
,
and
in
obedience
to
his
friend
's
positive
instruction
;
 
which
was
this
,
that
his
friend
could
not
abandon
his
right
of
addressing
the
young
lady
,
should
he
hereafter
ever
think
fit
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
Let
that
be
granted
,
and
Laurence
would
do
anything
.
<EOS>
But
then
that
could
not
be
granted
,
and
Laurence
could
only
shrug
his
shoulders
.
<EOS>
Nor
would
Laurence
admit
that
his
friend
had
been
false
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
question
lies
in
a
nutshell
,
"
said
Laurence
,
with
that
sweet
Connaught
brogue
which
always
came
to
him
when
he
desired
to
be
effective
;
 
"
here
it
is
.
<EOS>
One
gentleman
tells
another
that
he
's
sweet
upon
a
young
lady
,
but
that
the
young
lady
has
refused
him
,
and
always
will
refuse
him
,
for
ever
and
ever
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
truth
anyhow
.
<EOS>
Is
the
second
gentleman
bound
by
that
not
to
address
the
young
lady
?
<EOS>
I
say
he
is
not
bound
.
<EOS>
It
'd
be
a
d
 
d
hard
tratement
,
Captain
Colepepper
,
if
a
man
's
mouth
and
all
the
ardent

of
his
heart

to
be

!
<EOS>
By
Jases
,
I
do
n't
know
who
'd
like
to
be
the
friend
of
any
man
<EOS>
if
that
's
to

the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Captain
Colepepper
was
not

at
an
argument
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
they
'd
better
see

other
,
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
If

so
,

.
<EOS>
But
I
think
it
the
hardest
thing
in
the
world
;
 
I
do
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
Then
they
put
their

together
in
the
most
friendly
way
,
and
declared
that
the
affair

,
if

.
  
<EOS>
On
the
Thursday
night
Lord
Chiltern
and
Captain
Colepepper
went
over
by
Calais
and
Lille
to
Bruges
.
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
,
with
his
friend

O'Shaughnessy
,
crossed
by
the
direct

from
Dover
to
Ostend
.
<EOS>
Phineas
went
to
Ostend
by
Dover
and
Calais
,
but
he
took
the
day
route
on
Friday
.
<EOS>
It
had
all
been
arranged
among
them
,
so
that
there
might
be
no

as

job

.
<EOS>
Even
O'Shaughnessy
and
Laurence

had
left

.
<EOS>
They
met
on
the
sands
at
Blankenberg
about
nine

on

Saturday

,
having

that

in
different

from
Ostend

Bruges
,
and
had

.
<EOS>
But
one

had
been
exchanged
,

Phineas
had
been
wounded
in

.
<EOS>
He
had
proposed
to
exchange
another
shot
with
his
left

,
declaring
his
capability
of
shooting
quite

with

left

right
;
but
to

Fitzgibbon

.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
had
offered
to
shake

his
late
friend
in
a
true

of

,
if

his
late

would
say

.
<EOS>
In

.
<EOS>
Phineas

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
I

Chiltern

;
but
then
Lord
Chiltern
was

,

.
<EOS>
Of

's

,

.
<EOS>
Laurence

,
and

.
<EOS>
Not

,

that
a

.
  
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
made

by

's

,
and
was
able

.
"
<EOS>
Know

Finn
?
<EOS>
"

.
"
<EOS>
Not

!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Barrington
,

Dr.

<EOS>
No

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
---
,

,
"

,

.

"
<EOS>

;

"

<EOS>
,

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
But

"
<EOS>
In

Finn

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
He
did

,

.
<EOS>
He
had
,

said
,

down
in
Kent
,

had

,

.
<EOS>
When

and

,

,

.
<EOS>
One

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
This

Laurence

,
who
,

,

.
<EOS>
Phineas
stayed
and
voted
,
and
then
he
went

.
  
<EOS>
How
singular

if
this

,
and
no
one
be
a
bit
the
wiser
but

!
<EOS>
Again

wondered
at
his
own

.
<EOS>
He
had
told

that
a

Lord
Chiltern
must

and
Lord

's

,

Effingham
;

,

.
<EOS>
And
now

had
fought

,
and
was
back
in

,
 
and
the

seemed
to
have
been

.
<EOS>
He
had
not
as

Lady
Laura

,
but
he
had
no
doubt
<EOS>
but
they
both
were
as

.
<EOS>
The

might

,

,

Effingham
what

,
but

had
not

.
<EOS>
Whither
Lord
Chiltern
had
gone
,
or
what
Lord
Chiltern

,
he
had
not

;
but
he

that
he
should
soon

of

from
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
That
Lord
Chiltern
should
say

of
what

,
 
or
to
any

person
in

,
 
he
did
not

.
<EOS>
There
could
be
no
man

likely
to
be

in

than
Lord
Chiltern
,
 
or
more

be

by
an

.
<EOS>
Nor
did
he
doubt

discretion
of
his
friend
Fitzgibbon
;
 
if
only
his
friend
might
not
damage
the
secret
by

.
<EOS>
Of
the
silence
of
the
doctor
and

he
was
by

;
but

,

in

out
and

information
,
as
to
have

.
<EOS>
Were

Laura
to
hear

that
he
had
been

Belgium
,
and
had
fought
a

with
Lord
Chiltern
respecting
Violet
<EOS>
,
she

probably

;
but

,

.
  
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
,

,

;
 
had

,

,

,

Standish

,

.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
as

thought

,

not

Lord
Chiltern
's

,
but
there

.
<EOS>
Was
he
bound
,
in

,

?
<EOS>
He
made

that
he
was
not
so

unless
Lord

that

;
but
,

,

.
<EOS>
It
was
quite
true
that
the
seat
now
was
his
for
this
session
by
all

,
even

might

,
and
that

Brentford
could
not

mouth
upon
the
matter
in
a

more
loud
than
that

.
<EOS>
But
Phineas
,
feeling
that
he
had
consented
to
accept
the

of
a
corrupt
seat
from
Lord
Brentford
,
felt
also
that
he
was
bound
to
give

.
<EOS>
If
it
were
demanded
from
him
,
either
by
the
father
or
the
son
,
it
should
be
given
up
at
once
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
he
found
a
leading
article
in
the
_
People
's
Banner
_
devoted
solely
to
himself
.
"
<EOS>
During
the
late
debate
,
"
 
so
ran
a
passage
in
the
leading
article
,
 
"
Mr.
Finn
,
Lord
Brentford
's
Irish
nominee
for
his
pocket
-
borough
at
Loughton
,
did
at
last
manage
to
stand
on
his
legs
and
open
his
mouth
.
<EOS>
If
we
are
not
mistaken
,
this
is
Mr.
Finn
's
third
session
in
Parliament
,
and
hitherto
he
has
been
unable
to
articulate
three
sentences
,
though
he
has
on
more
than
one
occasion
made
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
For
what
special
merit
this
young
man
has
been
selected
for
aristocratic
patronage
we
do
not
know
,
 
but
that
there
must
be
some
merit
recognisable
by
aristocratic
eyes
,
we
surmise
.
<EOS>
Three
years
ago
he
was
a
raw
young
Irishman
,
living
in
London
as
Irishmen
only
know
how
to
live
,
earning
nothing
,
and
apparently
without
means
;
and
then
suddenly
he
bursts
out
as
a
member
of
Parliament
and
as
the
friend
of
Cabinet
Ministers
.
<EOS>
The
possession
of
one
good
gift
must
be
acceded
to
the
honourable
member
for
Loughton
,
 
he
is
a
handsome
young
man
,
and
looks
to
be
as
strong
as
a
coal
-
porter
.
<EOS>
Can

wound
in
your
heart
will
soon
be
cured
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
stood
silent
before
her
,
looking
away
from
her
,
thinking
over
it
all
.
<EOS>
He
certainly
had
believed
himself
to
be
violently
in
love
with
Lady
Laura
,
and
yet
when
he
had
just
now
entered
her
drawing
-
room
,
he
had
almost
forgotten
that
there
had
been
such
a
passage
in
his
life
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
believed
that
she
had
forgotten
it
,
 
even
though
she
had
counselled
him
not
to
come
to
Loughlinter
within
the
last
nine
months
!
<EOS>
He
had
been
a
boy
then
,
and
had
not
known
himself
;
 
but
now
he
was
a
man
,
and
was
proud
of
the
intensity
of
his
love
.
<EOS>
There
came
upon
him
some
passing
throb
of
pain
from
his
shoulder
,
reminding
him
of
the
duel
,
and
he
was
proud
also
of
that
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
willing
to
risk
everything
,
 
life
,
prospects
,
and
position
,
 
sooner
than
abandon
the
slight
hope
which
was
his
of
possessing
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
And
now
he
was
told
that
this
wound
in
his
heart
would
soon
be
cured
,
and
was
told
so
by
a
woman
to
whom
he
had
once
sung
a
song
of
another
passion
.
<EOS>
It
is
very
hard
to
answer
a
woman
in
such
circumstances
,
because
her
womanhood
gives
her
so
strong
a
ground
of
vantage
!
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
might
venture
to
throw
in
his
teeth
the
fickleness
of
his
heart
,
but
he
could
not
in
reply
tell
her
that
to
change
a
love
was
better
than
to
marry
without
love
,
 
that
to
be

of
such

change
showed
no
such
inferiority
of
nature
as
did
the
capacity
for
such
a
marriage
.
<EOS>
She
could
hit
him
with
her
argument
;
but
he
could
only
remember
his
,
and
think
how
violent
might
be
the
blow
he
could
inflict
,
 
if
it
were
not
that
she
were
a
woman
,
and
therefore
guarded
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
help
me
then
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
when
they
had
both

silent
for
a
while
.
  
<EOS>
"
Help
you
?
<EOS>
How
should
I
help
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wanted
no
other
help
than
this
,
 
that
I
might
have
had
an

of
meeting
Violet
here
,
and

getting
from

some

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Has
the
question
then
never
been
asked
already
?
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
To

made

.
<EOS>
There
was
no

why
he
should
show
his

to
an

.
<EOS>
"
Why

not

Lady
Baldock
's

?
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
You
know
Lady
Baldock
.
<EOS>
Go

your

.
<EOS>
See

.
<EOS>
As

,

the

,
open

in
which
gentlemen
are
wo
nt
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
make

to
none

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
have
you

"

Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
to
you
as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
sister
?
<EOS>
Psha
!
<EOS>
I
am
not
your
sister
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
Nor
,
were
I
so
<EOS>
,
should
I
fail
to
remember
that
I
have
a
dearer
brother
to
whom
my
faith
is
pledged
.
<EOS>
Look
here
.
<EOS>
Within
the
last
three
weeks
Oswald
has
sacrificed
everything
to
his
father
,
because
he
was
determined
that
Mr.
Kennedy
should
have
the

which
he

to
my

.
<EOS>
He
has
enabled
my
father
to
do
what
he
will
with
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
Papa
will
never
hurt
him
;
 
I
know
that
.
<EOS>
Hard
as
papa
is
with

,
he
will
never
hurt
Oswald
's
future
position
.
<EOS>
Papa
is
too
proud
to
do

.
<EOS>
Violet
has
heard
what
Oswald
has
done
;
and

,

,
I

that
she

.
<EOS>
That

her

.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
again
paused
a
moment
before
he
replied
.
<EOS>
"
Let
him
try
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
away
,
 
in
Brussels
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Send
to
him
,
and
bid
him
return
.
<EOS>
I
will
be
patient
,
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
Let
him
come
and
try
,
and
I
will
bide

.
<EOS>
I
confess
that
I
have
no
right
to
interfere
with
him
if
there
be
a
chance
for
him
.
<EOS>
If
there
is
no
chance
,
my
right
is
as
good
as
that
of
any
other
.
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
this
which
made
Lady
Laura
feel
that
she
could
not
maintain
her
hostility
against
this
man
on
behalf
of
her
brother
;
 
and
yet
she
could
not
force
herself
to
be
other
than
hostile
to
him
.
<EOS>
Her
heart
was
sore
,
and
it
was
he
that
had
made
it
sore
.
<EOS>
She
had
lectured
herself
,
schooling
herself
with
mental
sackcloth
and
ashes
,
rebuking
herself
with
heaviest
censures
from
day
to
day
,
because
she
had
found
herself
to
be
in
danger
of
regarding
this
man
with
a
perilous
love
;
and
she
had
been
constant
in
this
work
of
penance
till
she
had
been
able
to
assure
herself
that
the
sackcloth
and
ashes
had
done
their
work
,
and
that
the
danger
was
past
.
<EOS>
"
I
like
him
still
and
love
him
well
,
"
she
had
said
to
herself
with
something
almost
of
triumph
,
"
but
I
have
ceased
to
think
of
him
as
one
who
might
have
been
my
lover
.
"
<EOS>
And
yet
she
was
now
sick
and
sore
,
almost
beside
herself
with
the
agony
of
the
wound
,
because
this
man
whom
she
had
been
able
to
throw
aside
from
her
heart
had
also
been
able
so
to
throw
her
aside
.
<EOS>
And
she
felt
herself
constrained
to
rebuke
him
with
what
bitterest
words
she
might
use
.
<EOS>
She
had
felt
it
easy
to
do
this
at
first
,
on
her
brother
's
score
.
<EOS>
She
had
accused
him
of
treachery
to
his
friendship
,
 
both
as
to
Oswald
and
as
to
herself
.
<EOS>
On
that
she
could
say
cutting
words
without
subjecting
herself
to
suspicion
even
from
herself
.
<EOS>
But
now
this
power
was
taken
away
from
her
,
and
still
she
wished
to
wound
him
.
<EOS>
She
desired
to
taunt
him
with
his
old
fickleness
,
and
yet
to
subject
herself
to
no
imputation
.
"
<EOS>
Your
right
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
What
gives
you
any
right
in
the
matter
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Simply
the
right
of
a
fair
field
,
and
no

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
yet
you
come
to
me
for
favour
,
 
to

,
because
I
am
her
friend
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
win
her
yourself
,
and
think
I
may
help

!
<EOS>
I
do
not
believe
in
your
love
for
her
.
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
If
there

no
other

,
and
I
could
help
you
,
I
would
not
,
because
I
think
your
heart
is
a
sham
heart
.
<EOS>
She
is
pretty
,
and
has
money
 
"
  
"
Lady
Laura
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
pretty
,

has
money
,

is
the
fashion
.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But
,

Finn
,
I

;
 
and

do

.
<EOS>
His

is

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
understood
it
all
now
as

her

,
and

.
<EOS>
There
was
written
there
plainly
enough
<EOS>
that
spretæ
injuria
formæ
of
which
she
herself
was
conscious
,
but
only
conscious
.
<EOS>
Even
his

,
blind

,
were

,
 
and

knew
that

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of

must

brother
.
"
  
<EOS>
He

,
and

with

,
"
He
has
been

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have

?
"
  
"

;
 
I

.
"
  
"
And

?
<EOS>
How

?
<EOS>

"

,

"
and

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
<EOS>
As

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;

.
<EOS>
We

,

.
<EOS>
He

"
  
<EOS>
"
Suppose

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

Laura
,

.
"
<EOS>
Then

,

.
<EOS>
"
You
have

,
Lady
Laura
,

.
<EOS>
I

,

,
 
that
my

will
not

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
you
may
be

.
<EOS>
"
This
she
said

,
with

and

which
she
lately

.
<EOS>
Neither

knew
what
was
taking

between

;
but
she
was
,
in
truth
,
gradually
submitting

again
to
this
man
's

.
<EOS>
Though
she
rebuked
him
at
every

for
what

said
,
for
what
he
had
done
,
for
what
he

to
do
,

not

to

him
,
or

.
<EOS>
She
knew
it
all
now
,

that

passed

Violet
and
Phineas
in
the
rides
of
Saulsby
Park
.
<EOS>
But
she
suspected
something
even
of
that
,
feeling

that
the

Phineas
would
say
nothing

that
of
his
own

,
 
if

.
"
<EOS>
And
so
you

Oswald
have
quarrelled
,
and
there
has

a

.
<EOS>
That
is
why
you

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

I
was
away
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
wrong
of
you
,
 
how
very
wrong
!
<EOS>
Had
he
been
,
 
<EOS>
killed
,
how
could
you
have
looked
us
in
the
face
again
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
have
looked
you
in
the
face
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
that
is
over
now
.
<EOS>
And

friends
afterwards
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
we
did
not
part
as

.
<EOS>
Having

fight

him
,
 
most

,
 
I
could
not

him
that
I

Effingham
.
<EOS>
You

will

.
<EOS>
Let

come
and
try
.
"
<EOS>
She
had
nothing

,
 
no
other

to
use
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
soreness
at
her
heart
still
present
to
her
,
making
her

,
instigating
her
to
hurt
him
if
she
knew
how
to
do
so
,
in
spite
of
her
regard
for
him
.
<EOS>
But
she
felt
that
she
was
weak
and
powerless
.
<EOS>
She
had
shot
her
arrows
at
him
,
 
all
but
one
,
 
and
if
she
used
that
,
its
poisoned
point
would
wound
herself
far
more
surely
than
it
would
touch
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
duel
was
very
silly
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
speak
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
;
certainly
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
at
least
that
I
have
told
you
everything
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
why
you
should

glad
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
help
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
will
say
nothing
to
Violet
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Everything
that
I
can
say
in
Oswald
's
favour
.
<EOS>
I
will
say
nothing
of
the
duel
;
but
beyond
that
you
have
no
right
to
demand
my
secrecy
with
her
.
<EOS>
Yes
;
you
had
better
go
,
Mr.
Finn
,
for
I
am
hardly
well
.
<EOS>
And
remember
this
,
 
If
you
can
forget
this
little

about
Miss
Effingham
,
so
will
I
forget
it
also
;
and
so
will
Oswald
.
<EOS>
I
can
promise
for
him
.
"
<EOS>
Then
she
smiled
and
gave
him
her
hand
,
and
he
went
.
  
<EOS>
She
rose
from
her
chair
as
he
left
the
room
,
and
waited
till
she
heard
the
sound
of
the
great
door
closing
behind
him
before
she
again
sat
down
.
<EOS>
Then
,
when
he
was
gone
,
 
when
she
was
sure
that
he
was
no
longer
there
with
her
in
the
same

,
 
she
laid
her
head
down
upon
the
arm
of
the
sofa
,
and
burst
into
a

of

.
<EOS>
She
was
no
longer
angry
with
Phineas
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
further

in
her

for

.
<EOS>
She
did
not
now
desire
to
injure
him
,
though
she
had
done
so
as

as
he
was
with
her
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
 
she
resolved
instantly
,
almost

,
that
Lord
Brentford
must
know
nothing
of
all
this
,
lest
the
political

of
the
young
member
for
Loughton
should
be

.
<EOS>
To
have
rebuked

,
to
rebuke

again

again
,
would
be
only
fair
,
 
would
at
least
be
womanly
;
but
she
would
protect
him
from
all
material
injury
as
far
as
her
power
of
protection
might
avail
.
<EOS>
And
why
was
she
weeping
now
so

?
<EOS>
Of
course
she
asked
herself
,
as
she
rubbed
away
the
tears
with
her
hands
,
 
Why
should
she
weep
?
<EOS>
She
was
not
weak
enough
to
tell
herself
that
she
was
weeping
for
any
injury
that
had
been
done
to
Oswald
.
<EOS>
She
got

from
the
sofa
,
and
pushed
away

her

,

as

out

,
looking

.
"
<EOS>
Ass
!
<EOS>
"
she
exclaimed
.
"
<EOS>
Fool
!
<EOS>
Idiot
!
<EOS>
That

not

!
<EOS>
Why

?
<EOS>
After

better

.
<EOS>
Oh
,
 
is

you
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

and
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
 
it
is
I.
Is

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very

wrong
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

,
Laura
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
can

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
"
<EOS>
she

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Laura
,

,
 
not

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
 
both
.
<EOS>
I

,
but
I
could
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Laura
,
you
should

such

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

,
Robert
,
when

herself

her

.
<EOS>
It

so
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
do
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
make

woman
subject

as

.
<EOS>
You
may

.
<EOS>
With

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

,

,
 
if

.
<EOS>
I
will
not

on
a

which
I
have
not

.
<EOS>
"
Then

,

,

,
 
but

.
   
<EOS>
Madame
Max
Goesler
 
<EOS>
Day
after
day
,
and
clause
after
clause
,
the
bill
was
fought
in
committee
,
and
few
men
fought
with
more
constancy
on
the
side
of
the
Ministers
than
did
the
member
for
Loughton
.
<EOS>
Troubled
though
he
was
by
his
quarrel
with
Lord
Chiltern
,
by
his
love
for
Violet
Effingham
,
by
the
silence
of
his
friend
Lady
Laura
,
 
for
since
he
had
told
her
of
the
duel
she
had
become
silent
to
him
,
never
writing
to
him
,
and
hardly
speaking
to
him
when
she
met
him
in
society
,
 
<EOS>
nevertheless
Phineas
was
not
so
troubled
but
what
he
could
work
at
his
vocation
.
<EOS>
Now
,
when
he
would
find
himself
upon
his
legs
in
the
House
,
he
would
wonder
at
the
hesitation
which
had
lately
troubled
him
so
sorely
.
<EOS>
He
would
sit
sometimes
and
speculate
upon
that
dimness
of
eye
,
upon
that
tendency
of
things
to
go
round
,
upon
that
obtrusive
palpitation
of
heart
,
which
had
afflicted
him
so
seriously
for
so
long
a
time
.
<EOS>
The
House
now
was
no
more
to
him
than
any
other
chamber
,
and
the
members
no
more
than
other
men
.
<EOS>
He
guarded
himself
from
orations
,
speaking
always
very
shortly
,
 
because
he
believed
that
policy
and
good
judgment
required
that
he
should
be
short
.
<EOS>
But
words
were
very
easy
to
him
,
and
he
would
feel
as
though
he
could
talk
for
ever
.
<EOS>
And
there
quickly
came
to
him
a
reputation
for
practical
usefulness
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
with
strong
opinions
,
who
could
yet
be
submissive
.
<EOS>
And
no
man
seemed
to
know
how
his
reputation
had
come
.
<EOS>
He
had
made
one
good
speech
after
two
or
three
failures
.
<EOS>
All
who
knew
him
,
his
whole
party
,
had
been
aware
of
his
failure
;
and
his
one
good
speech
had
been
regarded
by
many
as
no
very
wonderful
effort
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
a
man
who
was
pleasant
to
other
men
,
 
not
combative
,
not
self
-
asserting
beyond
the
point
at
which
self
-
assertion
ceases
to
be
a
necessity
of
manliness
.
<EOS>
Nature
had
been
very
good
to
him
,
making
him
comely
inside
and
out
,
 
and
with
this
comeliness
he
had
crept
into
popularity
.
  
<EOS>
The
secret
of
the
duel
was
,
I
think
,
at
this
time
,
known
to
a
great
many
men
and
women
.
<EOS>
So
Phineas
perceived
;
but
it
was
not
,
he
thought
,
known
either
to
Lord
Brentford
or
to
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
And
in
this
he
was
right
.
<EOS>
No
rumour
of
it
had
yet
reached
the
ears
of
either
of
these
persons
;
 
and
rumour
,
though
she
flies
so
fast
and
so
far
,
is
often
slow
in
reaching
those
ears
which
would
be
most
interested
in
her

.
<EOS>
Some
dim
report
of
the
duel
reached
even
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
he
asked
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
Who
told
you
?
"
<EOS>
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Bonteen
told

that

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Bonteen
always

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

?
"
  
<EOS>
Lady

,
 
and
then

lied
.
<EOS>
"
Of

is

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
"
<EOS>
Then

Kennedy
believed
that

.
<EOS>
In

's
word

put
absolute

,
and

that

.
<EOS>
As

was
a

,

about
the

.
  
<EOS>
At

,

had

;
 
but

<EOS>

,
and

.
<EOS>
There

_

_

Lord
C

,
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
Here

,

,

,

,

,
 
and

!
<EOS>
There

,
 
so

article
 
of
what

Lord

;

,

186
 
,
&

&
c.
<EOS>
And

went

.
<EOS>
Any

may
fill

the

for

as

.
<EOS>
But
Phineas
had
so
far

that

had
almost

.
  
<EOS>
Certainly
I
think
that
the
duel
did
him
no

.
<EOS>
Otherwise
he
would
hardly
have
been

a

-

at
Lady
Glencora
Palliser
's
,

five

who

.
<EOS>
To

of

five

was

;
but
