sixteen
was
a
great
deal
,
 
was
indeed
so
much
that
Phineas
,
not
understanding
as
yet

,

.
<EOS>
There
was
no
man
among

eight

at

-
party
not

,
 
and
the
only

except
Phineas
not
attached
to
the
Government
<EOS>
was
Mr.
Palliser
's
great

,
John

,

.
<EOS>
There

four
Cabinet

,
 
the
Duke
,
Lord
Cantrip
,
Mr.
Gresham
,

owner

.
<EOS>
There

Barrington
Erle
and
young
Lord
Fawn
,
an
Under
-

State
.
<EOS>
But
the

and
grace
of
the
ladies
present
lent
more
of
character
to
the
party
than
even
the

of

men
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
Palliser
herself
was
a
host
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
woman
then
in
London
better
able
to
talk
to
a
dozen
people
on
a
dozen
subjects
;
and
then
,
moreover
,
she
was
still
in
the
flush
of
her

and
the
bloom
of

.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
was
there
;
 
by
what
means
divided
from
her
husband
Phineas
could
not
imagine
;
but
Lady
Glencora
was
good
at
such
divisions
.
<EOS>
Lady
Cantrip
had
been
allowed
to
come
with
her
lord
;
 
but
,
as
was
well
understood
,
Lord
Cantrip
was
not
so
manifestly
a
husband
as
was
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
There
are
men
who
can
not
guard
themselves
from
the
assertion
of
marital
rights
at
most
inappropriate
moments
.
<EOS>
Now
Lord
Cantrip
lived
with
his
wife
most
happily
;
yet
you
should
pass
hours
with
him
and
her
together
,
and
hardly
know
that
they
knew
each
other
.
<EOS>
One
of
the
Duke
's
daughters
was
there
,
 
but
not
the
Duchess
,
who
was
known
to
be
heavy
;
 
and
there
was
the
beauteous
Marchioness
of
Hartletop
.
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
was
in
the
room
also
,
 
giving
Phineas
a
blow
at
the
heart
as
he
saw
her
smile
.
<EOS>
Might
it
be
that
he
could
speak
a
word
to
her
on
this
occasion
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
had
also
brought
his
wife
;
 
and
then
there
was
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
<EOS>
Phineas
found
that
it
was
his
fortune
to
take
down
to
dinner
,
 
not
Violet
Effingham
,
but
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
<EOS>
And
,
when
he
was
placed
at
dinner
,
on
the
other
side
of
him
there
sat
Lady
Hartletop
,
who
addressed
the
few
words
which
she
spoke
exclusively
to
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
in
former
days
matters
difficult
of
arrangement
between
those
two
;
but
I
think
that
those
old
passages
had
now
been
forgotten
by
them
both
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
,
therefore
,
driven
to
depend
exclusively
on
Madame
Max
Goesler
for
conversation
,
and
he
found
that
he
was
not
called
upon
to
cast
his
seed
into
barren
ground
.
  
<EOS>
Up
to
that
moment
he
had
never
heard
of
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
,
in
introducing
them
,
had
pronounced
the
lady
's
name
so
clearly
that
he
had
caught
it
with
accuracy
,
but
he
could
not
surmise
whence
<EOS>
she
had
come
,
or
why
she
was
there
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
woman
probably
something
over
thirty
years
of
age
.
<EOS>
She
had
thick
black
hair
,
which
she
wore
in
curls
,
 
unlike
anybody
else
in
the
world
,
 
in
curls
which
hung
down
low
beneath
her
face
,
covering
,
and
perhaps
intended
to
cover
,
a
certain
thinness
in
her
cheeks
which
would
otherwise
have
taken
something
from
the
charm
of
her
countenance
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
were
large
,
of
a
dark
blue
colour
,
and
very
bright
,
 
and
she
used
them
in
a
manner
which
is
as
yet
hardly
common
with
Englishwomen
.
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
intend
that
you
should
know
that
she
employed
them
to
conquer
you
,
looking
as
a
knight
may
have
looked
in
olden
days
who
entered
a
chamber
with
his
sword
drawn
from
the
scabbard
and
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
Her
forehead
was
broad
and
somewhat
low
.
<EOS>
Her
nose
was
not
classically
beautiful
,
being
broader
at
the
nostrils
than
beauty
required
,
and
,
moreover
,
not
perfectly

in

.
<EOS>
Her
lips
were
thin
.
<EOS>
Her
teeth
,
which
she
endeavoured
to
show
as
little
as
possible
,
were
perfect
in
form
and
colour
.
<EOS>
They
who
criticised
her
severely
said
,
however
,
that
they
were
too
large
.
<EOS>
Her
chin
was
well
formed
,
and
divided
by
a
dimple
which
gave
to
her
face
a
softness
of
grace
which
would
otherwise
have
been
much
missed
.
<EOS>
But
perhaps
her
great
beauty
was
in
the
brilliant
clearness
of
her
dark
complexion
.
<EOS>
You
might
almost
fancy
that
you
could
see
into
it
so
as
to
read
the
different
lines
beneath
the
skin
.
<EOS>
She
was
somewhat
tall
,
though
by
no

tall
to
a
fault
,
and
was
so
thin
as
to
be
almost

in
her

.
<EOS>
She
always
wore
her
dress
close
up
to
her
neck
,
and
never
showed
the
bareness
of
her

.
<EOS>
Though
she
was
the
only

so

now

in

room
,
this

did
not
specially

,
because
in

her

was
so

as

make
inattention
to

.
<EOS>
The

who
did

would

that
Madame
Max
Goesler
's

unlike

of
other

,
but

,

,
and
<EOS>
unlike

in

for

of

.
<EOS>
In

she
was
abundant
,
and
yet

fabric
of
her

was
always

.
<EOS>
My

may
not

went
in

black

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

no

,
and
hardly
anything

.
<EOS>
And

,

of

,
were
fitted

;
and
round

neck

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

Max

;

could

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
To
Blankenberg
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
to
Blankenberg
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
asking
for
it
now
.
<EOS>
But
I
shall
look
for
it
some
day
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Glencora
rose
from
her
seat
,
and
Madame
Max
Goesler
went
out
with
the
others
.
   
<EOS>
Lord
Fawn
 
<EOS>
What
had
Madame
Max
Goesler
to
do
with
his
journey
to
Blankenberg
?
<EOS>
thought
<EOS>
Phineas
,
as
he
sat
for
a
while
in
silence
between
Mr.
Palliser
and
Mr.
Grey
;
and
why
should
she
,
who
was
a
perfect
stranger
to
him
,
have
dared
to
ask
him
such
a
question
?
<EOS>
But
as
the
conversation
round
the
table
,
after
the
ladies
had
gone
,
soon
drifted
into
politics
and
became
general
,
Phineas
,
for
a
while
,
forgot
Madame
Max
Goesler
and
the
Blankenberg
journey
,
and
listened
to
the
eager
words
of
Cabinet
Ministers
,
now
and
again
uttering
a
word
of
his
own
,
and
showing
that
he
,
too
,
was
as
eager
as
others
.
<EOS>
But
the
session
in
Mr.
Palliser
's
dining
-
room
was
not
long
,
and
Phineas
soon
found
himself
making
his
way
amidst
a
throng
of
coming
guests
into
the
rooms
above
.
<EOS>
His
object
was
to
meet
Violet
Effingham
,
but
,
failing
that
,
he
would
not
be
unwilling
to
say
a
few
more
words
to
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
  
<EOS>
He
first
encountered
Lady
Laura
,
to
whom
he
had
not
spoken
as
yet
,
and
,
finding
himself
standing
close
to
her
for
a
while
,
he
asked
her
after
his
late
neighbour
.
"
<EOS>
Do
tell
me
one
thing
,
Lady
Laura
;
 
who
is
Madame
Max
Goesler
,
and
why
have
I
never
met
her
before
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
will
be
two
things
,
Mr.
Finn
;
but
I
will
answer
both
questions
as
well
as
I
can
.
<EOS>
You
have
not
met
her
before
,
because
she
was
in
Germany
last
spring
and
summer
,
and
in
the
year
before
that
you
were
not
about
so
much
as
you
have
been
since
.
<EOS>
Still
you
must
have
seen
her
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
She
is
the
widow
of
an
Austrian
banker
,
and
has
lived
the
greater
part
of
her
life
at
Vienna
.
<EOS>
She
is
very
rich
,
and
has
a
small
house
in
Park
Lane
,
where
she
receives
people
so
exclusively
that
it
has
come
to
be
thought
an
honour
to
be
invited
by
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
<EOS>
Her
enemies
say
that
her
father
was
a
German
Jew
,
living
in
England
,
in
the
employment
of
the
Viennese
bankers
,
and
they
say
also
that
she
has
been
married
a
second

to
an
Austrian
Count
,
to
whom
she
allows
ever
so
much
a
year
to
stay
away
from
her
.
<EOS>
But
of
all
this
,
nobody
,
I
fancy
,
knows
anything
.
<EOS>
What
they
do
know
is
that
Madame
Max
Goesler
spends
seven
or
eight
thousand
a
year
,
and
that
she
will
give
no
man
an
opportunity
of
even

to

.
<EOS>
People
used

of
her
,
but

goes

now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
not
been
at
Portman
Square
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
no
<EOS>
;
but
then
Lady
Glencora
is
so
much

advanced
than
we
are
!
<EOS>
After
all
,
we
are
but
humdrum
people
,
as
the
world
goes
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
began
to
roam
about
the
rooms
,
striving
to
find
an
opportunity
of
engrossing
five

of
Miss
Effingham
's

.
<EOS>
During

Lady
Laura
was

the
history
of
Madame
Max
Goesler
<EOS>
his

had

,

on

,
 
so

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

Lord
Fawn
,

,

.
<EOS>
Lord
Fawn
had
been

to
Violet

the

,
and

was
beginning
to
think
that

should
like

Blankenberg
,
with

lordship
on

.
<EOS>
When
Lady
Laura

,

.
<EOS>
"
It

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

no

,
because

.
<EOS>
"
To

Phineas

,
but
went
and

.
<EOS>
Why
should
it
be
of
no
use
?
<EOS>
Would
Violet
Effingham
marry
any
man
merely

he

?
  
<EOS>
Some

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

,

,
"
she

.
"
<EOS>
Lord
Fawn
has
made

-

,

has

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have

,
"
said
Lord
Fawn
;
 
"
more

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
felt
that

ought
to
give

to

reach

,

.
<EOS>
Had

,

he

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
I

how

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
 
yes
;

,

.
<EOS>
Why

?
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

;

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
The

,

.

"
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!

.
<EOS>
Madame
Max

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

,
 
political

,

had

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
"
You

Max
Goesler
,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

;

.
<EOS>
No
one
<EOS>
,

,

;

.
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
Then

,

,

.

<EOS>

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
We

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
Half

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

to

Violet
for
an
answer
to
his
old

,
and
was

,
but
not

.
<EOS>
Lord
Fawn
,
he
thought
,
was
not
a

in

way
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
had
told

that

;
but
then
Lady
Laura
's
mind
on
that

was
,

thought
,
prejudiced
.
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
certainly
knew
what
were
his
wishes
,
and
knowing
them
,
smiled
on
him
and
was
gracious
to
him
.
<EOS>
Would
she
do
so
if
his
pretensions
were
thoroughly

to
her
?
  
<EOS>
"
I
saw
that
you
were

this

,
"
said
Madame
Max
Goesler
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
aware
of
any

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
call
it
great
success
to
be
able

make

where
you
will
through
such

as
there
is

.
<EOS>
You
seem

to

so

that
I
shall

to
find
my
servant
,
and
bid
him
get
my
carriage
.
<EOS>
Will
you
mind
?
<EOS>
"
Phineas
,
of
course
,
declared
that
he
would
be
delighted
.
"
<EOS>
He
is
a
German
,
and
not
in
livery
.
<EOS>
But
if
somebody
will
call
out
,
he
will
hear
.
<EOS>
He
is
very
sharp
,
and
much
more
attentive
than
your
English
footmen
.
<EOS>
An
Englishman
hardly
ever
makes
a
good
servant
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
a
compliment
to
us
Britons
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
certainly
not
.
<EOS>
If
a
man
is
a
servant
,
he
should
be
clever
enough
to
be
a
good
one
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
had
now
given
the
order
for
the
carriage
,
and
,
having

,
was
standing
with
Madame
Max
Goesler
in

.
<EOS>
"
After
all
,
we
are
surely

in
the
world
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
Lord
Fawn
,
who
was

to
Miss
Effingham
just
now
.
<EOS>
You
should
have
heard

trying

.
<EOS>
It
was
like

,
and
yet
they
say

is
a

man
and
can

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Could

be

that
Madame
Max
Goesler
's

were

that
she
had
heard

Lord
Fawn

said
of

?
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
a

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
For

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
But

,

?
<EOS>
And

is
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

;
and

that
somebody

,
 
unless

.
<EOS>
Thank

;
I

.
<EOS>
Mind

,
 
193
,
Park
Lane
.
<EOS>
I
dare
say
you
know

little

.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
put
Madame
Max
Goesler

,

.
   
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
Does
Not
Send
a
Card
to
Phineas
Finn
 
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
's
house
in
Berkeley
Square
was
very
stately
,
 
a
large
house
with
five
front
windows
in
a
row
,
and
a
big
door
,
and
a
huge
square
hall
,
and
a
fat
porter
in
a
round
-

chair
;
 
but
it
was
dingy
and
dull
,
and
could
not
have
been
painted
for
the
last
ten
years
,
or
furnished
for
the
last
twenty
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
Lady
Baldock
had
"
evenings
,
"
and
people
went
to
them
,
 
though
not
such
a
crowd
of
people
as
would
go
to
the
evenings
of
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
Now
Mr.
Phineas
Finn
had
not
been
asked
to
the
evenings
of
Lady
Baldock
for
the
present
season
,
and
the
reason
was
after
this
wise
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
Lady
Baldock
had
said
to
her
daughter
,
who
,
early
in
the
spring
,
was
preparing
the
cards
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
send
one
to
Mr.
Finn
,
certainly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
he
is
very
nice
,
"
said
Augusta
Boreham
,
whose
eyes
at
Saulsby
had
been
sharper
perhaps
than
her
mother
's
,
and
who
had
her
suspicions
.
  
<EOS>
But
Lady
Baldock
did
not
like

daughter
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
,
certainly
,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
,
mamma
 
"
  
"

!
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

,

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Count

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

.

.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
sat

at

,
and
Augusta
Boreham
sat
by
,

for
orders
.
<EOS>
She
felt
pretty
nearly
sure
that
new
orders
would
be
given
if

did
not
herself

.
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

<EOS>
"
I
will
make

.
<EOS>
I
do

a

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

"

<EOS>
Not

<EOS>
what

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
card
of
course
was
not
sent
,
and
Lady
Baldock
at
any
rate
put
so
much
faith
in
her
son
's
story
as
to
make
her
feel
it
to
be
her
duty
to
interrogate
her
niece
on

.
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
at
this
period
of
her
life
was
certainly
not
free
from
fear
of
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
In
the
numerous

which
took
place
between
them
,
the
aunt
seldom
gained
that
amount
of
victory
which
would
have
completely
satisfied
her
spirit
.
<EOS>
She
longed
to
be
dominant
over
her
niece
as
she
was
dominant
over
her
daughter
;
and
when
she
found
that
she
missed
such
supremacy
,
she
longed
to
tell
Violet
to
depart
from
out
her
borders
,
and
be
no
longer
niece
of
hers
.
<EOS>
But
had
she
ever
done
so
<EOS>
,
Violet
would
have
gone
at
the
instant
,
and
then
terrible
things
would
have
followed
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
satisfaction
in
turning
out
of
doors
a
nephew
or
niece
who
is
pecuniarily
dependent
,
but
when
the
youthful
relative
is
richly
endowed
,
the
satisfaction
is
much
diminished
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
duty
of
a
guardian
,
no
doubt
,
to
look
after
the
ward
;
but
if
this
can
not
be
done
,
the
ward
's
money
should
at
least
be
held
with
as
close
a
fist
as
possible
.
<EOS>
But
Lady
Baldock
,
though
she
knew
that
she
would
be
sorely
wounded
,
poked
about
on
her
old
body
with
the
sharp
lances
of
disobedience
,
and
struck
with
the
cruel
swords
of
satire
,
if
she
took
upon
herself
to
scold
or
even
to
question
Violet
,
nevertheless
would
not
abandon
the
pleasure
of
lecturing
and

.
<EOS>
"
It
is
my
duty
,
"
she
would
say
to

,
"
and
though
it
be
taken
in
a
bad
spirit
,
I
will
always
perform
my
duty
.
"
<EOS>
So
she
performed
her
duty
,
and
asked
Violet
Effingham
some
few
questions
respecting
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
<EOS>
,
"
she
said
,
"
do
you
remember

a
Mr.
Finn

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
Mr.
Finn
,
aunt
!
<EOS>
Why
,
he
is
a
particular

.
<EOS>
Of

do
,
and
he

.
<EOS>
I
have

there

.
<EOS>
Do

we

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
remember
that
he
was
there
,

;
but
I
did
not

he
was

special
 
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Most
especial
,
aunt
.
<EOS>
A
1
,
I
may
say
;
 
among
young
men
,
I
mean
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
was
certainly
the
most
indiscreet
of
old
women
in
such

matter
as
this
,
and
Violet
the
most

.
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
,

that
there

something

,
 
as
,

,
there
was
,
much

,

destroy

card
,
and
to
keep
the
young

the
young

,

.
<EOS>
But

as
being
A
1
.
<EOS>
Fond

of
Miss

,

,

must

,
on

aunt
.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

,
<EOS>

<EOS>
But

.
   
<EOS>
Promotion
 
Phineas
got
no
card
from
Lady
Baldock
,
but
one

he
received
a
note
from
Lord
Brentford
which
was

more
importance
to
him
than
any
card
could
have
been
.
<EOS>
At
this
time
,
bit
by
bit
,
the
Reform
Bill
of
the
day
had
nearly
made
its
way
through
the
committee
,
but
had
been
so

as
to
be
almost
impossible
of
recognition
by
its

.
<EOS>
And
there
was
still
a
clause
or

as
to
the

of
seats
,
<EOS>
respecting
which
it
was
known
that
there
would
be
a
combat
,
 
probably

,
 
carried
on
after
the
internecine
fashion
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
certain
clipping
of
counties
to
be
done
,
<EOS>
as
to
which
it
was
said
that
Mr.
Daubeny
had
declared
that
he
would
not
yield
till
he
was
made
to
do
so
by
the
brute

of

;
 
and
there
was
another

for
the

of
certain

members
from
little

,
and

on

at
which

were
much

,
respecting

Mr.
Turnbull
had
proclaimed
that

as

now
stood
was
a

clause
,
capable

doing
,
and

do
,
no

<EOS>
;
a

who
had
not

;
a

,

,
 
to

every

worse

of

,
as

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
had
been

,
 
had

much
of

,

.
<EOS>
The

did

,
 
but

Mr.

,

Turnbull
.
<EOS>

,
 
the

,

,

.

,

<EOS>
Lord

as

:
    
House
of

,
<EOS>
16th

,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
MY

MR
.
<EOS>
FINN
,
  
<EOS>
You

Lord
Bosanquet
's

Mottram
into

,
and
that

Under

,
and

Under
-

must

,

up
.
  
<EOS>
The
heart
of
Phineas
Finn
at
this
moment
was
almost
in

mouth
.
<EOS>
Not
only
to
be
selected
for
political
employment
,
but
to
be

once
for
an

so

!
<EOS>
Under
-
Secretaries
,
he
fancied
,
were
paid
two
thousand
a

.
<EOS>
What
would
Mr.
Low
say
now
?
<EOS>
But
his
great

soon
received
a
check
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
has
spoken

,
"

,
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
!
  
<EOS>
I

think

he

,
as

.
<EOS>
This

Irish

,

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

-
morrow

of

.
  
<EOS>
Yours
very
sincerely
,
  
BRENTFORD
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
was
himself
surprised
to
find
that
his
first
feeling
on
reading
this
letter
was
one
of
dissatisfaction
.
<EOS>
Here
were
his
golden
hopes
about
to
be
realised
,
 
hopes
as
to
the
realisation
of
which
he
had
been
quite
despondent
twelve
months
ago
,
 
and
yet
he
was
uncomfortable
because
he
was
to
be
postponed
to
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
.
<EOS>
Had
the
new
Under
-
Secretary
been
a
man
whom
he
had
not
known
,
whom
he
had
not
learned
to
look
down
upon
as
inferior
to
himself
<EOS>
,
he
would
not
have
minded
it
,
 
would
have
been
full
of
joy
at
the
promotion
proposed
for
himself
.
<EOS>
But
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
was
such
a
poor
creature
,
that
the
idea
of
filling
a
place
from
which
Laurence
had
risen
was
distasteful
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
It
seems
to
be
all
a
matter
of
favour
and
convenience
,
"
he
said
to
himself
,
"
without
any
reference
to
the
service
.
"
<EOS>
His
triumph
would
have
been
so
complete
<EOS>
had
Mr.
Mildmay
allowed
him
to
go
into
the
higher
place
at
one
leap
.
<EOS>
Other
men
who
had
made
themselves
useful
had
done
so
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
hour
after
receiving
Lord
Brentford
's
letter
,
the
idea
of
becoming
a
Lord
of
the
Treasury
was
almost
displeasing
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
an
idea
that
junior
lordships
of
the
Treasury
were
generally
bestowed
on
young
members
whom
it
was
convenient
to
secure
,
but
who
were
not
good
at
doing
anything
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
moment
in
which
he
thought
that
he
would
refuse
to
be
made
a
junior
lord
.
  
<EOS>
But
during
the
night
cooler
reflections
told
him
that
he
had
been
very
wrong
.
<EOS>
He
had
taken
up
politics
with
the
express
desire
of
getting
his
foot
upon
a
rung
of
the
ladder
of
promotion
,
and
now
,
in
his
third
session
,
he
was
about
to
be
successful
.
<EOS>
Even
as
a
junior
lord
he
would
have
a
thousand
a
year
;
and
how
long
might
he
have
sat
in
chambers
,
and
have
wandered
about
Lincoln
's
Inn
,
and
have
loitered
in
the
courts
striving
to
look
as
though
he
had
business
,
before
he
would
have
earned
a
thousand
a
year
!
<EOS>
Even
as
a
junior
lord
he
could
make
himself
useful
,
and
when
once
he
should
be
known
to
be
a
good
working
man
,
promotion
would
come
to
him
.
<EOS>
No
ladder
can
be
mounted
without
labour
;
but
this
ladder
was
now
open
above
his
head
,
and
he
already
had
his
foot
upon
it
.
  
<EOS>
At
half
-
past
eleven
he
was
with
Lord
Brentford
,
who
received
him
with
the
blandest
smile
and
a
pressure
of
the
hand
which
was
quite
cordial
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Finn
,
"
he
said
,
"
this
gives
me
the
most
sincere
pleasure
,
 
the
greatest
pleasure
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
Our
connection
together
at
Loughton
of
course
makes
it
doubly
agreeable
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
be
too
grateful
to
you
,
Lord
Brentford
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
;
no
,
no
.
<EOS>
It
is
all
your
own

.

<EOS>
Phineas
was

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.

,

.

.

.

we

;

?
"
<EOS>

,

.

Could

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
He
had

Monk
,

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
He

not

.
<EOS>
Now
,

,
  
now

had

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
He
had

.
<EOS>
Individual

Government
,
and

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Phineas
and
His
Friends
 
<EOS>
Our
hero
's
friends
were
,

,

hero
's

.
<EOS>
He
never

,

that

.
<EOS>
But

friends
were
loud

,
 
or

.
  
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

.
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

!
<EOS>
I

,
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

?
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

,

.

"

ai

.
"
<EOS>
"
Gentleman
be
d
 
d
,
"

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.

_

_

,

.
<EOS>

,

of

own
,
and
are
as

.
<EOS>
"

as

.
<EOS>
"

;

,

?

---

"
  
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Bunce

.
<EOS>
Quintus

was

.
<EOS>
Turnbull

.
<EOS>
For

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
And

that

,

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>

,

that
the
ignorant
but

of

should
 
"
d
 
n
it
all
"
?
  
<EOS>
On

Low

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.

,

<EOS>
But

,

,

,

,

.

"

.

"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
,
"

<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

bears
being
petted
and
spoilt
without
being
either
awkward
or
conceited
.
"
<EOS>
"
On
the
whole
,
he
is
rather
nice
,
"
said
Violet
;
"
only
he
has
not
got
a
shilling
in
the
world
,
and
has
to
make
himself
before
he
will
be
anybody
.
"
<EOS>
"
He
must
marry
money
,
of
course
,
"
said
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
are
contented
?
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
rising
from
her
chair
and
coming
opposite
to
him
as
soon
as
they
were
alone
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
am
contented
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
,
 
when
I
first
heard
of
it
.
<EOS>
Why
did
they
promote
that
empty
-
headed
countryman
of
yours
to
a
place
for
which
he
was
quite
unfit
?
<EOS>
I
was
not
contented
.
<EOS>
But
then
I
am
more
ambitious
for
you
than
you
are
for
yourself
.
"
<EOS>
He
sat
without
answering
her
for
awhile
,
and
she
stood
waiting
for
his
reply
.
"
<EOS>
Have
you
nothing
to
say
to
me
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
what
to
say
.
<EOS>
When
I
think
of
it
all
,
I
am
lost
in
amazement
.
<EOS>
You
tell
me
that
you
are
not
contented
;
 
that
you
are
ambitious
for
me
.
<EOS>
Why
is
it
that
you
should
feel
any
interest
in
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
reasonable
that
we
should
be
interested
for
our
friends
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
when
you
and
I
last
parted
here
in
this
room
you
were
hardly
my
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
I
not
?
<EOS>
You
wrong
me
there
;
 
very
deeply
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
what
was
my
ambition
,
and
you
resented
it
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
said
that
I
could
not
help
you
,
and
<EOS>
I
think
I
said
also
that
I
thought
you
would
fail
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
that
I
showed
much
resentment
.
<EOS>
You
see
,
I
told
her
that
you
were
here
,
that
she
might
come
and
meet
you
.
<EOS>
You
know
that
I
wished
my
brother
should
succeed
.
<EOS>
I
wished
it
before
I
ever
knew
you
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
expect
that
I
should
change
my
wishes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
if
he
can
not
succeed
,
"
pleaded
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
is
to
say
that
?
<EOS>
Has
a
woman
never
been
won
by
devotion
and
perseverance
?
<EOS>
Besides
,
how
can
I
wish
to
see
you
go
on
with
a
suit
which
must
sever
you
from
my
father
,
and
injure
your
political

;
 
perhaps
fatally

?
<EOS>
It
seems
to
me
now
that
my
father
is
almost
the

man
in
London
who
has
not
heard
of
this
duel
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
he
will
hear
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
half
made
up
my
mind
to
tell
him
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
do
that
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
There
can
be
no
reason
for
it
.
<EOS>
But
I
did
not
ask
you
to
come
here
to
-
day
to
talk
to
you
about
Oswald
or
Violet
.
<EOS>
I
have
given
you
my
advice
about
that
,
and
I
can
do
no
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lady
Laura
,
I
can
not
take
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
out
of
my
power
to
take
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
.
<EOS>
The
matter
shall
be
what
you
members
of
Parliament
call
an
open
question
between
us
.
<EOS>
When
papa
asked
you
to
accept
this
place
at
the
Treasury
,
did
it
ever
occur
to
you
to
refuse

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
did
;
 
for
half
an
hour
or
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hoped
you
would
,
 
and
yet
I
knew
that
I
was
wrong
.
<EOS>
I
thought
that
you
should
count
yourself
to
be
worth
more
than
that
,
and
that
you
should
,
as
it
were
,
assert
yourself
.
<EOS>
But
then
it
is
so
difficult
to
draw
the
line
between
proper
self
-
assertion
and
proper
self
-
denial
;
 
to
know
how
high
to
go
up
the
table
,
and
how
low
to
go
down
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
doubt
that
you
have
been
right
<EOS>
,
 
only
make
them
understand
that
you
are
not
as
other
junior

;
 
that
you
have
been
willing
to
be

lord
,
or
anything
else
for

;
but
that
the

is
something
higher
than
that
of
fetching
and
carrying
in
Parliament
for
Mr.
Mildmay
and
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
in
time
to
get
beyond
fetching
and
carrying
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
will
;
and
knowing
that
,
I
am
glad
that
you
are
in
office
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
there
will
be
no
difficulty
about
Loughton
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
laughed
.
<EOS>
"
I
hear
,
"
said
he
,
"
that
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
,
of
the
_
People
's
Banner
_
,
has
already
gone
down
to
canvass
the
electors
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
!
<EOS>
To
canvass
the
electors
of
Loughton
!
"
<EOS>
and
Lady
Laura
drew
herself
up
and
spoke
of
this
unseemly
intrusion
on
her
father
's
borough
,
as
though
the
vulgar
man
who
had
been
named
had
forced
his
way
into
the
very
drawing
-
room
in
Portman
Square
.
<EOS>
At
that
moment
Mr.
Kennedy
came
in
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
what
Mr.
Finn
tells
me
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
He
has
heard
that
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
has
gone
down
to
Loughton
to
stand
against
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
not
?
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
!
"
<EOS>
ejaculated
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
will
no
doubt
lose
his
time
and
his
money
;
 
but
he
will
gain
the
prestige
of
having
stood
for
a
borough
,
which
will
be
something
for
him
on
the
staff
of
the
_
People
's
Banner
_
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
will
get
that
horrid
man
Vellum
to
propose
him
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
likely
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
"
And
the
less
any
of
us
say
about
it
the
better
.
<EOS>
Finn
,
my
dear
fellow
,
I
congratulate
you
heartily
.
<EOS>
Nothing
for
a
long
time
has
given
me
greater
pleasure
than
hearing
of
your
appointment
.
<EOS>
It
is
equally
honourable
to
yourself
and
to
Mr.
Mildmay
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
great
step
to
have
gained
so
early
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
as
he
thanked
his
friend
,
could
not
help
asking
himself
what
his
friend
had
done
to
be
made
a
Cabinet
Minister
.
<EOS>
Little
as
he
,
Phineas
,
himself
had
done
in
the
House
in
his
two
sessions
and
a
half
,
Mr.
Kennedy
had
hardly
done
more
in
his
fifteen
or
twenty
.
<EOS>
But
then
Mr.
Kennedy
was
possessed
of
almost
miraculous
wealth
,
and
owned
half
a
county
,
whereas
he
,
Phineas
,
owned
almost
nothing
at
all
.
<EOS>
Of
course
no
Prime
Minister
would
offer
a
junior
lordship
at
the
Treasury
to
a
man
with
£
30,000
a
year
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
this
Phineas
took
his
leave
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
will
do
well
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
to
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
he
will
do
well
,
"
replied
Lady
Laura
,
almost
scornfully
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
not
quite
such
a
black
swan
with
me
as
he
is
with
you
;
but
still
I
think
he
will
succeed
,
if
he
takes
care
of
himself
.
<EOS>
It
is
astonishing
how
that
absurd
story
of
his
duel
with
Chiltern
has
got
about
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
impossible
to
prevent
people
talking
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
there
was
some
quarrel
,
though
neither
of
them
will
tell
you
.
<EOS>
They
say
it
was
about
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
I
should
hardly
think
that
Finn
could
have
any
hopes
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
he
not
have
hopes
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Because
he
has
neither
position
,
nor
money
,
nor
birth
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
gentleman
.
"
said
Lady
Laura
;
"
and
I
think
he
has
position
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
see
why
he
should
not
ask
any
girl
to
marry
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
understanding
you
,
Laura
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
had
quite
other
hopes
about
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
have
;
but
that
has
nothing
to
do
with
it
.
<EOS>
You
spoke
of
Mr.
Finn
as
though
he
would
be
guilty
of
some
crime
<EOS>
were
he
to
ask
Violet
Effingham
to
be
his
wife
.
<EOS>
In
that
I
disagree
with
you
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
is
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
You
will
make
me
sick
of
the
name
of
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
that
I
offend
you
by
my
gratitude
to
a
man
who
saved
your
life
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
shook
his
head
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
the
argument
used
against
him
was
false
,
but
he
did
not
know
how
to
show
that
he
knew
that
it
was
false
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
had
better
not
mention
his
name
any
more
,
"
continued
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
quite
agree
with
you
that
it
is
nonsense
,
Robert
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
I
mean
to
say
is
,
that
if
you
go
on
as
you
do
,
you
will
turn
his
head
and
spoil
him
.
<EOS>
Do
you
think
I
do
not
know
what
is
going
on
among
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
what
is
going
on
among
us
,
 
as
you
call
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
taking
this
young
man
up
and
putting
him
on
a
pedestal
and
worshipping
him
,
just
because
he
is
well
-
looking
,
and
rather
clever
and
decently
behaved
.
<EOS>
It
's
always
the
way
with
women
who
have
nothing
to
do
,
and
who
can
not
be
made
to
understand
that
they
should
have
duties
.
<EOS>
They
can
not
live
without
some
kind
of
idolatry
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
I
neglected
my
duty
to
you
,
Robert
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
 
you
know
you
have
;
 
in
going
to
those
receptions
at
your
father
's
house
on
Sundays
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
has
that
to
do
with
Mr.
Finn
?
"
  
"
Psha
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
begin
to
think
I
had
better
tell
Mr.
Finn
not
to
come
here
any
more
,
since
his
presence
is
disagreeable
to
you
.
<EOS>
All
the
world
knows
how
great
is
the
service
he
did
you
,
and
it
will
seem
to
be
very
ridiculous
.
<EOS>
People
will
say
all
manner
of
things
;
but
anything
will
be
better
than
that
you
should
go
on
as
you
have
done
,
 
accusing
your
wife
of
idolatry
towards
 
a
young
man
,
because
 
he
is
 
well
-
looking
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
said
anything
of
the
kind
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
did
,
Robert
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
speak
more
of
you
than
of
a
lot
of
others
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
accused
me
personally
,
saying
that
because
of
my
idolatry
I
had
neglected
my
duty
;
but
really
you
made
such
a
jumble
of
it
all
,
with
papa
's
visitors
,
and
Sunday
afternoons
,
that
I
can
not
follow
what
was
in
your
mind
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Kennedy
stood
for
awhile
,
collecting
his
thoughts
,
so
that
he
might
unravel
the
jumble
,
if
that
were
possible
to
him
;
but
finding
that
it
was
not
possible
,
he
left
the
room
,
and
closed
the
door
behind
him
.
  
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Laura
was
left
alone
to
consider
the
nature
of
the
accusation
which
her
husband
had
brought
against
her
;
or
the
nature
rather
of
the
accusation
which
she
had
chosen
to
assert
that
her
husband
had
implied
.
<EOS>
For
in
her
heart
she
knew
that
he
had
made
no
such
accusation
,
and
had
intended
to
make
none
such
.
<EOS>
The
idolatry
of
which
he
had
spoken
was
the
idolatry
which
a
woman
might
show
to
her
cat
,
her
dog
,
her
picture
,
her
china
,
her
furniture
,
her
carriage
and
horses
,
or
her
pet
maid
-
servant
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
idolatry
of
which
Mr.
Kennedy
had
spoken
;
 
but
was
there
no
other
worship
in
her
heart
,
worse
,
more
pernicious
than
that
,
in
reference
to
this
young
man
?
  
<EOS>
She
had
schooled
herself
about
him
very
severely
,
and
had
come
to
various
resolutions
.
<EOS>
She
had
found
out
and
confessed
to
herself
that
she
did
not
,
and
could
not
,
love
her
husband
.
<EOS>
She
had
found
out
and
confessed
to
herself
that
she
did
love
,
and
could
not
help
loving
,
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
Then
she
had
resolved
to
banish
him
from
her
presence
,
and
had
gone
the
length
of
telling
him
so
.
<EOS>
After
that
she
had
perceived
that
she
had
been
wrong
,
and
had
determined
to
meet
him
as
she
met
other
men
,
 
and
to
conquer
her
love
.
<EOS>
Then
,
when
this
could
not
be
done
,
when
something
almost
like
idolatry
grew
upon
her
,
she
determined
that
it
should
be
the
idolatry
of
friendship
,
that
she
would
not
sin
even
in
thought
,
that
there
should
be
nothing
in
her
heart
of
which
she
need
be
ashamed
;
 
but
that
the
one
great
object
and
purport
of
her
life
should
be
the
promotion
of
this
friend
's
welfare
.
<EOS>
She
had
just
begun
to
love
after
this
fashion
,
had
taught
herself
to
believe
that
she
might
combine
something
of
the
pleasure
of
idolatry
towards
her
friend
with
a
full
complement
of
duty
towards
her
husband
,
when
Phineas
came
to
her
with
his
tale
of
love
for
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
The
lesson
which
she
got
then
was
a
very
rough
one
,
 
so
hard
that
at
first
she
could
not
bear
it
.
<EOS>
Her
anger
at
his
love
for
her
brother
's
wished
-
for
bride
was
lost
in
her
dismay
that
Phineas
should
love
any
one
after
having
once
loved
her
.
<EOS>
But
by
sheer
force
of
mind
she
had
conquered
that
dismay
,
that
feeling
of
desolation
at
her
heart
,
and
had
almost
taught
herself
to
hope
that
Phineas
might
succeed
with
Violet
.
<EOS>
He
wished
it
,
 
and
why
should
he
not
have
what
he
wished
,
 
he
,
whom
she
so
fondly
idolised
?
<EOS>
It
was
not
his
fault
that
he
and
she
were
not
man
and
wife
.
<EOS>
She
had
chosen
to
arrange
it
otherwise
,
and
was
she
not
bound
to
assist
him
now
in
the
present
object
of
his
reasonable
wishes
?
<EOS>
She
had
got
over
in
her
heart
that
difficulty
about
her
brother
,
but
she
could
not
quite
conquer
the
other
difficulty
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
bring
herself
to
plead
his
cause
with
Violet
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
brought
herself
as
yet
to
do
it
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
she
was
accused
of
idolatry
for
Phineas
by
her
husband
,
 
<EOS>
she
with
"
a
lot
of
others
,
"
in
which
lot
Violet
was
of
course
included
.
<EOS>
Would
it
not
be
better
that
they
two
should
be
brought
together
?
<EOS>
Would
not
her
friend
's
husband
still
be
her
friend
?
<EOS>
Would
she
not
then
forget
to
love
him
?
<EOS>
Would
she
not
then
be
safer
than
she
was
now
?
  
<EOS>
As
she
sat
alone
struggling
with
her
difficulties
,
she
had
not
as
yet
forgotten
to
love
him
,
 
nor
was
she
as
yet
safe
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Effingham
's
Four
Lovers
 
One
morning
early
in
June
Lady
Laura
called
at
Lady
Baldock
's
house
and
asked
for
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
The
servant
was
showing
her
into
the
large
drawing
-
room
,
when
she
again
asked
specially
for
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
Miss
Effingham
is
there
,
"
said
the
man
,
opening
the
door
.
<EOS>
Miss
Effingham
was
not
there
.
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
was
sitting
all
alone
,
and
Lady
Laura
perceived
that
she
had
been
caught
in
the
net
which
she
specially
wished
to
avoid
.
<EOS>
Now
Lady
Baldock
had
not
actually
or
openly
quarrelled
with
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
or
with
Lord
Brentford
,
but
she
had
conceived
a
strong
idea
that
her
niece
Violet
was
countenanced
in
all
improprieties
by
the
Standish
family
generally
,
and
that
therefore
the
Standish
family
was
to
be
regarded
as
a
family
of
enemies
.
<EOS>
There
was
doubtless
in
her
mind
considerable
confusion
on
the
subject
,
for
she
did
not
know
whether
Lord
Chiltern
or
Mr.
Finn
was
the
suitor
whom
she
most
feared
,
 
and
she
was
aware
,
after
a
sort
of
muddled
fashion
,
that
the
claims
of
these
two
wicked
young
men
were
antagonistic
to
each
other
.
<EOS>
But
they
were
both
regarded
by
her
as
emanations
from
the
same
source
of
iniquity
,
and
,
therefore
,
without
going
deeply
into
the
machinations
of
Lady
Laura
,
 
without
resolving
whether
Lady
Laura
was
injuring
her
by
pressing
her
brother
as
a
suitor
upon
Miss
Effingham
,
or
by
pressing
a
rival
of
her
brother
,
 
still
she
became
aware
that
it
was
her
duty
to
turn
a
cold
shoulder
on
those
two
houses
in
Portman
Square
and
Grosvenor
Place
.
<EOS>
But
her
difficulties
in
doing
this
were
very
great
,
and
it
may
be
said
that
Lady
Baldock
was
placed
in
an
unjust
and
cruel
position
.
<EOS>
Before
the
end
of
May
she
had
proposed
to
leave
London
,
and
to
take
her
daughter
and
Violet
down
to
Baddingham
,
 
or
to
Brighton
,
if
they
preferred
it
,
or
to
Switzerland
.
<EOS>
"
Brighton
in
June
!
"
<EOS>
Violet
had
exclaimed
.
"
<EOS>
Would
not
a
month
among
the
glaciers
be
delightful
!
"
<EOS>
Miss
Boreham
had
said
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
let
me
keep
you
in
town
,
aunt
,
"
Violet
replied
;
"
but
I
do
not
think
I
shall
go
till
other
people
go
.
<EOS>
I
can
have
a
room
at
Laura
Kennedy
's
house
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Baldock
,
whose
position
was
hard
and
cruel
,
resolved
that
she
would
stay
in
town
.
<EOS>
Here
she
had
in
her
hands
a
ward
over
whom
she
had
no
positive
power
,
and
yet
in
respect
to
whom
her
duty
was
imperative
!
<EOS>
Her
duty
was
imperative
,
and
Lady
Baldock
was
not
the
woman
to
neglect
her
duty
;
 
and
yet
she
knew
that
the
doing
of
her
duty
would
all
be
in

.
<EOS>
Violet
would
marry
a
shoe
-
black
out
of
the
streets
if
she
were
so
minded
.
<EOS>
It
was
of
no
use
that
the
poor
lady
had
provided
herself
with
two
strings
,
two
most
excellent
strings
,
to
her
bow
,
 
two
strings
either
one
of
which
should
have
contented
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
There
was
Lord
Fawn
,
a
young
peer
,
not
very
rich

,
 
but
still
with
means
sufficient
for
a
wife
,
a
rising
man
,
and
in
every

respectable
,
although

.
<EOS>
And

Mr.
Appledom
,
one

the
richest
commoners
in
England
,
a
fine
Conservative
too
,
with
a
seat
in
the
House
,
and
everything
appropriate
.
<EOS>
He
was
fifty
,
but
looked
hardly
more
than
thirty
-
five
,
and
was
,
 
so
at
least
Lady
Baldock
frequently
asserted
,
 
violently
in
love
with
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
Why
had
not
the
law
,
or
the

,
or

Lord

,
or
some
power
levied
for
the

proprieties
,
made
Violet
absolutely
subject
to
her
guardian
till
she
should
be

to
a
husband
?
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
think
she
is
at
home
,
"
said
Lady
Baldock
,
in

Lady
Laura
's

.
<EOS>
"
At
least
,
I
hardly
know
.
<EOS>
She
seldom
tells
me
what
she
means
to
do
,
 
and
sometimes
she
will
walk
out
quite
alone
!
"
<EOS>
A
most
imprudent
old
woman
was
Lady
Baldock
,
always
opening
her
hand
to
her
adversaries
,
unable
to
control
herself
in
the
scolding
of
people
,
either
before

or

backs
,
even
at

in
which
such

was
most

.
<EOS>
"
However
,
we
will
see
,
"
she

.
<EOS>
Then
the
bell
was
rung
,
and
in
a

minutes
Violet
was
in
the
room
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
more
they
were
up
-
stairs
together
in
Violet
's
own
room
,
in
spite
of
the
openly
-

of
Lady
Baldock
.
<EOS>
"
I
almost
wish
she
had
never
been

,
"

Baldock
to

.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
mamma
,
do

.
"
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
do
wish
that
I
had
never
seen
her
.
"
<EOS>
"
Indeed
she
has
been
a
grievous

to

,

,
"

Boreham
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Brighton
!
<EOS>
What
nonsense
!
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course

's
nonsense
.
<EOS>
Fancy

Brighton
!
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
If

Augusta
talking
in

a

!
<EOS>
And
I

.
<EOS>
I

three

with
me
at

,

,
 
<EOS>
so

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
I
wo

go
.
<EOS>
I
know

;

I
ca

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

;
 
<EOS>
you
,
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why

"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

Max

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

Not

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

<EOS>
"

Nothing

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whom

?
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
A

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
She

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Old

,

<EOS>
I

,

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Just

,
 
that

Finn
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

!
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Only

;

,

"
  
"
No

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

ca

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

?

"

"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
His

that
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
throw
it
in
his
teeth
then
that

does
not

more

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
have
you
come
to
tell
me
to

Mr.
Phineas
Finn
?
<EOS>
That
is
what
I
want
to

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Phineas
Finn
,
as

I
am

,
has
not
a

in
the

,
 
except

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Phineas
Finn
I

be

son

a

in
Ireland
,
 
with

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Phineas
Finn

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Phineas
Finn
is
,
 
or

,
 
in

another

;
and
Mr.
Phineas
Finn
is
not

at
this

what
he
is
able

his

to

.
<EOS>
None

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Has

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,
I
never

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

"

"
I

;
 
about

.
<EOS>
Foolish

!
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Only

<EOS>
Gustavus

.
<EOS>
Why

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

No

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
There

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
Psha

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
Mousetrap
 
Phineas
had
certainly
no
desire
to
make
love
by
an
ambassador
,
 
at
second
-
hand
.
<EOS>
He
had
given
no
commission
to
Lady
Laura
,
and
was
,
as
the
reader
is
aware
,
quite
ignorant
of
what
was
being
done
and
said
on
his
behalf
.
<EOS>
He
had
asked
no
more
from
Lady
Laura
than
an

of
speaking
for

,
and
that
he
had
asked
almost
with
a
conviction
<EOS>
that
by
so
asking
he
would
turn
his
friend
into
an
enemy
.
<EOS>
He
had
read
but
little
of
the
workings
of
Lady
Laura
's
heart
towards
himself
,
and
had
no
idea
of
the
assistance
she
was
anxious
to
give

.
<EOS>
She
had
never
told

that
she
was
willing
to
sacrifice
her
brother
on
his
behalf
,
and
,
of
course
,
had
not
told

that
she
was
willing

to
sacrifice
herself
.
<EOS>
Nor
,
when
she
wrote
to

one
June

and

that
Violet
would
be
found
in
Portman
Square
,
alone
,
that

,
 
naming

,
and

Miss
Effingham
would

to

,
but
that

such

she
would
be
certainly
alone
,
 
<EOS>
did

even
then

how
much

was

do

.
<EOS>
The
short

was
signed
"
L.
,
"
and

.
<EOS>
"
Ask
for

,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
I
shall

,
and

.
<EOS>
I

,

,
 
you

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Burn

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
destroyed
the
note
,
tearing

into
atoms
,
the
moment
that
he
had
read

and
re

read

.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
would
go
to
Portman
Square
at
the
hour
named
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
would
take
his
chance
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
buoyed
up
by
much
of
hope
;
 
but
even
though
there
were
no
hope
,
he
would
take
his
chance
.
  
<EOS>
When
Lord
Brentford
had
first

,
he
had
also

new

.
<EOS>
This
Phineas
had
found

;
 
and

had
done

.
<EOS>
The
letter
had
been
difficult
enough
to
write
,
 
but
he
had
written

.
<EOS>
After
having
made
the

,
he
had
found
himself
bound
to
keep

.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Lord
Chiltern
,
"

,
"
I
will

.
<EOS>
I
now

your

,

.
<EOS>
"

's

.
"
<EOS>
Pray

home
,
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
Touching
V.
E.
,
I
feel
that
I
am
bound
to

that
I
still

try
my

,
but
that

have
no

my

will

.
<EOS>
Since
the
day
on

sands
,
I
have

but

.
<EOS>
I

;

.
 
<EOS>
Yours

,
  
"
PHINEAS
FINN
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
he
had
to
try
his
fortune
,
 
that

of
which
he
had
told
Lord
Chiltern
that
he
had
no

that

would

.
<EOS>
He
went

from
his

the
Treasury
to

,
resolving
that

would

no

as
to

,
simply

and

were

down

the
House
,
and

Earl
's

Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Effingham
,
"

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
she

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
am
alone
,
 
a
poor
unprotected
female
.
<EOS>
But
I
fear
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
have
strong
reason
for
believing
that
Lord
Brentford
is
somewhere
about
.
<EOS>
And
Pomfret
the
butler
,
who
has

,

host

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
With
such
allies
you
can

nothing

,
"
he

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
even
without
them
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
We
unprotected
females
in
these
days
are
so
self

that
our
natural
protectors
fall
off
from
us
,
finding
themselves
to
be
no

wanted
.
<EOS>
Now
with
you
,
 
what
can
I
fear
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
 
as
I
hope
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
There
used

,
and
that
not
so

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
Do

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
All

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
In

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;
 
in

.
<EOS>
Is

?
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

?
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
was

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Am

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Effingham
,

.
<EOS>
You

,
 
I

<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

Finn
.
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Effingham
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very

;
 
as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
,
I

;

in

.
<EOS>
Whatever
may
be
my
fate
,
the
question
must

asked
,
and
an

given
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
hoped
that
you
should

me
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
For
what

?
"
  
"
For

,

;
 
but

.
"
  
"

,
 
instantly
.
<EOS>
I
give

my
word

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Can

never

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
No
;
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

because
 
?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
's
Bill
 
<EOS>
It

Finn

.
<EOS>
There

,

of

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
absolutely

,

Vellum
for

.
<EOS>
Mr.

being

,

of

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Slide
was

,
and

's

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
He
received
three

,
and

.
<EOS>
This
in

could
hardly
have

which
Mr.
Slide
or
his

must

;
 
but

,

_

_
;

,

Slide
was

some

.
<EOS>
Most

_

's

_
were

Slide
by

.
<EOS>
The

had
been
very
severe
upon
our
hero
;
and
though
the

had
been
so

and

at
Loughton
as
to

,
 
so

that
in
point
of

he
had
not

above

at

,
 
<EOS>
nevertheless

did

a

.
<EOS>
Why
Phineas
should
have
read
it
who
can

?
<EOS>
But
who

?
  
<EOS>
In

as

printed
Mr.
Slide
declared
that

had
no

being

for

.
<EOS>
He

how

,
what

;
 
how

.
<EOS>
Of

's

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
There

!
<EOS>
Any

,

,

's

_

_
.
 
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Phineas
Finn
,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
Quintus
Slide
,

,

could

<EOS>

Loughton

,

,

,

,

;

,

.

<EOS>

"

.

"

.

"

.
<EOS>
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
Whatever
Mr.
Kennedy
and
Lady
Laura
might
think
about
Loughton
and
the

of
small

,

was
found
by

Government
,
to
their

,
that
Mr.
Turnbull
's
clause
was
a
reality
.
<EOS>
After
two
months
of
hard
work
,
all
questions
of
franchise
had
been
settled
,
rating
and
renting
,
new

,
fancy

and
those
which
no
one
fancied
,
franchises
for
boroughs
and

for

,
franchises
single
,
dual
,
three
-

,
and
four
-
sided
,
 
by
various

to
which
the
Committee
of
the
whole
House
had
agreed
after
some
score
of
divisions
,
 
the
matter
of
the
franchise
had
been
settled
.
<EOS>
No
doubt
there
was
the
House
of
Lords
,
and
there
might
yet
be
shipwreck
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
generally
believed
that
the
Lords
would
hardly
look
at
the
bill
,
 
that
they
would
not
even
venture
on
an
amendment
.
<EOS>
The
Lords
would
only
be
too
happy
to
let
the
matter
be
settled
by
the
Commons
themselves
.
<EOS>
But
then
,
after
the
franchise
,
came
redistribution
.
<EOS>
How
sick
of
the
subject
were
all
members
of
the
Government
,
no
one
could
tell
who
did
not
see
their
weary
faces
.
<EOS>
The
whole
House
was
sick
,
having
been
whipped
into
various
lobbies
,
night
after
night
,
during
the
heat
of
the
summer
,
for
weeks
past
.
<EOS>
Redistribution
!
<EOS>
Why
should
there
be
any
redistribution
?
<EOS>
They
had
got
,
or
would
get
,
a
beautiful
franchise
.
<EOS>
Could
they
not
see
what
that
would
do
for
them
?
<EOS>
Why
redistribute
anything
?
<EOS>
But
,
alas
,
it
was
too
late
to
go
back
to
<EOS>
so
blessed
an
idea
as
that
!
<EOS>
Redistribution
they
must
have
.
<EOS>
But
there
should
be
as
little
redistribution
as
possible
.
<EOS>
Men
were
sick
of
it
all
,
and
would
not
be
exigeant
.
<EOS>
Something
should
be
done
for
overgrown
counties
;
 
something
for
new
towns
which
had
prospered
in
brick
and
mortar
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
easy
to
crush
up
a
peccant
borough
or
two
,
 
a
borough
that
had
been
discovered
in
its
sin
.
<EOS>
And
a
few
boroughs
now
blessed
with
two
members
might
consent
to
be
blessed
only
with
one
.
<EOS>
Fifteen
small
clauses
might
settle
the
redistribution
,
in
spite
of
Mr.
Turnbull
,
 
if
only
Mr.
Daubeny
would
be
good
-
natured
.
  
<EOS>
Neither
the
weather
,
which
was
very
hot
,
nor
the
tedium
of
the
session
,
which
had
been
very
great
,
nor
the
anxiety
of
Ministers
,
which
was
very
pressing
,
had
any
effect
in
impairing
the
energy
of
Mr.
Turnbull
.
<EOS>
He
was
as
instant
,
as
oratorical
,
as
hostile
,
as
indignant
about
redistribution
as
he
had
been
about
the
franchise
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
sure
then
,
and
he
was
sure
now
,
that
Ministers
desired
to
burke
the
question
,
to
deceive
the
people
,
to
produce
a
bill
that
should
be
no
bill
.
<EOS>
He
brought
out
his
clause
,
 
and
made
Loughton
his
instance
.
"
<EOS>
Would
the
honourable
gentleman
who
sat
lowest
on
the
Treasury
bench
,
 
who
at
this
moment
was
in
sweet
confidential

with
the
right
honourable
gentleman
now
President
of
the
Board
of
Trade
,
who
had
once
been
a

of
the
people
,
 
would
the
young
Lord
of
the
Treasury
get
up
in

and
tell

that
no
peer
of
Parliament
had
at
present
a
voice
in

a
member
to
their
House
of
Commons
,
 
that
no
peer
would
have

if
this
bill
,
as

Government
,
were
passed
in
its
present
useless
,

,

,
and
most
dishonest
form
?
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
replied
to
this
,
and
who
told
Mr.
Turnbull
that
he
himself
could
not
answer
for
any
peers
,
 
but
that
he
thought
it
probable
that
most
peers
would
,
by
their
opinions
,
somewhat
influence
the
opinions
of
some
electors
,
 
was
thought
to
have
got
out
of
his
difficulty
very
well
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
the
clause
of
Mr.
Turnbull
to
be
dealt
with
,
 
a
clause
directly
disfranchising
seven
single
-
winged
boroughs
,
of
which
Loughton
was
of
course
one
,
 
a
clause
to
which
the
Government
must
either
submit
or
object
.
<EOS>
Submission
would
be
certain
defeat
in
one
way
,
and
objection
would
be
as
certain
defeat
in
another
,
 
if
the
gentlemen
on
the
other
side
were
not
disposed
to
assist
the
ministers
.
<EOS>
It
was
said
that
the
Cabinet
was
divided
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
and
Mr.
Monk
were
for
letting
the
seven
boroughs
go
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Mildmay
could
not
bring
himself
to
obey
Mr.
Turnbull
,
and
Mr.
Palliser
supported
him
.
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Mildmay
was

that
Mr.
Daubeny
would
certainly

Mr.
Turnbull
respecting

,

reported

that

Mr.

must

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Daubeny
made
a
beautiful
speech
about
the
seven
boroughs
;
 
the
seven
sins
,
and
seven
stars
,
and
seven
churches
,
and
seven

.
<EOS>
He
would
make
no
party
question
of
this
.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
who
usually
acted
with
him
would
vote
as
their
own
sense
of
right
or
wrong
directed
them
;
 
from
which
expression
of
a
special
sanction
it
was
considered
that
these
gentlemen
were
not
accustomed
to
exercise
the
privilege
now

to

.
<EOS>
But
in
regarding
the
question
as
one
of

,
and
in

at
what
he

be
both
the

and

,
he
,
Mr.
Daubeny
,
 
he
,
himself
,

of
that

,
 
must
support
the

of
the

gentleman
.
<EOS>
Almost
all

to
whom

of
using

for
that

,

,
 
as

had

,
 
and
Mr.
Turnbull

.
<EOS>
It
was
then
3
a.m.
,

Gresham
,

,
said

to
state

.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
though
he
had
made
his

in

to

Turnbull
with
good
-

,
had
recorded

seven

with

.
<EOS>
Much
as

disliked
Mr.
Turnbull
,

Mr.

was

in

.
<EOS>
He

Monk
on

,
as

Mr.

's

to

,
and

Mildmay
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Monk
was
angry
with

,
telling

that
his
conscience
was
of
that
restless
,
uneasy
sort
which
is
neither
useful
nor

.
<EOS>
"
We
all
know
,
"
said

,
"
and
none
better

,
that

,
 
any

should

.
<EOS>
There

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

any

?
<EOS>
Would

?
<EOS>
Believe

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
had
no

,
but

was
not

.
<EOS>
And

the
less

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
in

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low

very

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low

,
and

.
<EOS>
He
never

;

,

,

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
too

,

"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.

"
  
<EOS>
"

.

"

The

.
<EOS>

'

.

;

<EOS>
And

passed

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Turnbull
carried
his
clause
,
and
Loughton
was
doomed
.
<EOS>
Loughton
and
the
other
six
deadly
sins
were
anathematized
,
exorcised
,
and
finally
got
rid
of
out
of
the
world
by
the
voices
of
the
gentlemen
who
had
been
proclaiming
the
beauty
of
such
pleasant
vices
all
their
lives
,
and
who
in
their
hearts
hated
all
changes
that
tended
towards
popular
representation
.
<EOS>
But
not
the
less
was
Mr.
Mildmay
beaten
;
and
,
in
accordance
with
the
promise
made
by
his
first
lieutenant
immediately
after
the
vote
was
taken
,
the
Prime
Minister
came
forward
on

next

and
made

.
<EOS>
He
had
already
put
his
resignation
into
the
hands
of
Her
Majesty
,
and
Her
Majesty
had
graciously

.
<EOS>
He
was
very
old
,
and
felt
that
the
time
had
come
in
which
it
behoved
him
to
retire
into
that
leisure
which
he
thought
he
had
,
perhaps
,

.
<EOS>
He
had
hoped
to
carry
this
bill
as
the
last

of
his
political

;
but
he
was
too
old
,
too

,
as

,
in

,
to
bend
further
than
he
had

,
and
he
must

in

.
<EOS>
Her

had
sent

Mr.
Gresham
,
and
Mr.

had
already
seen
Her

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
and
his
other
colleagues
,
though

from

had

,
and
of

below

on

,
were

,
and
would
,
for
the

's

,
 
and

,
 
endeavour
to

bill
through
.
<EOS>
There
would
then
,
of
course
,
be
a

,
and
the
future
Government
would
,
no
doubt
,
depend

.
<EOS>
From
all

was

that
Mr.

to

to

,
whatever

,
and
that

State
for

must

.
<EOS>
Phineas
understood
,
also
,
that
he
had
lost
his
seat
at
Loughton
.
<EOS>
For
the
borough
of
Loughton
there
would
never
again

an
election
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
had

Mr.
Mildmay
,
I

bill
up

,
"
Lord
Brentford
said

;
"
but
of
course

was
not

to

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
session
was
protracted
for
two
months
after
that
,
 
beyond
the
time
at
which
grouse
should
have
been
shot
,
 
and
by
the
23rd
of
August
became
the
law
of
the
land
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
get
over

,
"
said

Ratler
to

Finn
,
seated
one

hot

on

behind

Ministers
,
 
"
<EOS>
never
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't

such

session
for
work
was
ever
known
before
.
<EOS>
Think
what
it
is
to

to
keep
men
together
in

,

the

at
81
°
,
and
the
river
stinking
like
,
 
like
the
very
mischief
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Ratler
,
however
,
did
not
die
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
last
day
of
the
session
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
resigned
.
<EOS>
Rumours
reached
the
ears
of
Phineas
as
to
the
cause
of
this
,
but
no
certain
cause
was
told
him
.
<EOS>
It
was

Lord
Cantrip
had
insisted
upon

,
Laurence
having
by

been
called
upon
for
some

during
an

.
<EOS>
There
was
,
however
,
a
mystery
about

;
 
but

as
the

to

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
shall

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
none
of

,
"
said

Gresham
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
shall

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
election
will
not

,
and

must

.
<EOS>
Both

Monk
and

seem

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
so
the
bill
was
carried
,
and
the
session
was
ended
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
Duke
"
 
By
the
middle
of
September
there
was
assembled
a
large
party
at
Matching
Priory
,
a
country
mansion
belonging
to
Mr.
Plantagenet
Palliser
.
<EOS>
The
men
had
certainly
been
chosen
in
reference
to
their
political
feelings
and
position
,
 
for
there
was
not
a
guest
in
the
house
who
had
voted
for
Mr.
Turnbull
's
clause
,
or
the
wife
or
daughter
,
or
sister
of
any
one
who
had
so
voted
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
in
these
days
politics
ran
so
high
that
among
politicians
all
social
gatherings
were
brought
together
with
some
reference
to
the
state
of
parties
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
invited
,
and
when
he
arrived
at
Matching
he
found
that
half
the
Cabinet
was
there
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
was
not
there
,
nor
was
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
was
there
,
and
the
Duke
,
 
with
the
Duchess
,
and
Mr.
Gresham
,
and
Lord
Thrift
;
Mrs.
Max
Goesler
was
there
also
,
and
Mrs.
Bonteen
,
 
Mr.
Bonteen
being
detained
somewhere
out
of
the
way
;
and
Violet
Effingham
was
expected
in
two
days
,
and
Lord
Chiltern
at
the
end
of
the
week
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
took
an
opportunity
of
imparting
this
latter
information
to
Phineas
very
soon
after
his
arrival
;
and
Phineas
,
as
he
watched
her
eye
and
her
mouth
while
she
spoke
,
was
quite
sure
that
Lady
Glencora
knew
the
story
of
the
duel
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
delighted
to
see
him
again
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
That
is
all
right
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
There
were
also
there
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Grey
,
who
were
great
friends
of
the
Pallisers
,
 
and
on
the
very
day
on
which
Phineas
reached
Matching
,
at
half
an
hour
before
the
time
for
dressing
,
the
Duke
of
Omnium
arrived
.
<EOS>
Now
,
Mr.
Palliser
was
the
Duke
's
nephew
and
heir
,
 
and
the
Duke
of
Omnium
was
a
very
great
person
indeed
.
<EOS>
I
hardly
know
why
it
should
have
been
so
,
but
the
Duke
of
Omnium
was
certainly
a
greater
man
in
public
estimation
than
the
other
duke
then
present
,
 
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
was
a
useful
man
,
and
had
been
so
all
his
life
,
sitting
in
Cabinets
and
serving
his
country
,
constant
as
any
peer
in
the
House
of
Lords
,
always
ready
to
take
on
his
own
shoulders
any
troublesome
work
required
of
him
,
than
whom
Mr.
Mildmay
,
and
Mr.
Mildmay
's
predecessor
at
the
head
of
the
liberal
party
,
had
had
no
more
devoted
adherent
.
<EOS>
But
the
Duke
of
Omnium
had
never
yet
done
a
day
's
work
on
behalf
of
his
country
.
<EOS>
They
both
wore
the
Garter
,
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
having
earned
it
by
service
,
the
Duke
of
Omnium
having
been
decorated
with
the
blue
ribbon
,
 
because
he
was
Duke
of
Omnium
.
<EOS>
The
one
was
a
moral
,
good
man
,
a
good
husband
,
a
good
father
,
and
a
good
friend
.
<EOS>
The
other
,
 
did
not
bear
quite
so
high
a
reputation
.
<EOS>
But
men
and
women
thought
but
little
of
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
,
while
the
other
duke
was
regarded
with
an
almost
reverential
awe
.
<EOS>
I
think
the
secret
lay
in
the
simple
fact
that
the
Duke
of
Omnium
had
not
been
common
in
the
eyes
of
the
people
.
<EOS>
He
had
contrived
to
envelope
himself
in
something
of
the
ancient
mystery
of
wealth
and
rank
.
<EOS>
Within
three
minutes
of
the
Duke
's
arrival
Mrs.
Bonteen
,
with
an
air
of
great
importance
,
whispered
a
word
to
Phineas
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
come
.
<EOS>
He
arrived
exactly
at
seven
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
has
come
?
"
<EOS>
Phineas
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
Duke
of
Omnium
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
almost
reprimanding
him
by
her
tone
of
voice
for
his
indifference
.
<EOS>
"
There
has
been
a
great
doubt
whether
or
no
he
would
show
himself
at
last
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
told
me
that
he
never
will
pledge
himself
.
<EOS>
I
am
so
glad
he
has
come
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
I
ever
saw
him
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
have
seen
him
,
 
a
magnificent
-
looking
man
!
<EOS>
I
think
it
is
so
very
nice
of
Lady
Glencora
getting
him
to
meet
us
.
<EOS>
It
is
very
rarely
that
he
will
join
in
a
great
party
,
but
they
say
Lady
Glencora
can
do
anything
with
him
since
the
heir
was
born
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
have
heard
all
about
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Phineas
;
"
I
have
heard
nothing
of
the
heir
,
but
I
know
that
there
are
three
or
four
babies
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
was
no
heir
,
you
know
,
for
a
year
and
a
half
,
and
they
were
all
au
désespoir
;
and
the
Duke
was
very
nearly
quarrelling
with
his
nephew
;
and
Mr.
Palliser
 
;
you
know
it
had
very
nearly
come
to
a
separation
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
anything
at
all
about
it
,
"
said
Phineas
,
who
was
not
very
fond
of
the
lady
who
was
giving
him
the
information
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
,
I
can
assure
you
;
but
since
the
boy
was
born
Lady
Glencora
can
do
anything
with
the
Duke
.
<EOS>
She
made
him
go
to
Ascot
last
spring
,
and
he
presented
her
with
the
favourite
for
one
of
the
races
on
the
very
morning
the
horse
ran
.
<EOS>
They
say
he
gave
three
thousand
pounds
for
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
did
Lady
Glencora
win
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
the
horse
lost
;
and
Mr.
Palliser
has
never
known
what
to
do
with
him
since
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
very
pretty
of
the
Duke
;
 
was
it
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
though
he
had
intended
to
show
to
Mrs.
Bonteen
<EOS>
how
little
he
thought
about
the
Duke
of
Omnium
,
 
how
small
was
his
respect
for
a
great
peer
who
took
no
part
in
politics
,
 
could
not
protect
himself
from
a
certain
feeling
of
anxiety
as
to
the
aspect
and
gait
and
words
of
the
man
of
whom
people
thought
so
much
,
of
whom
he
had
heard
so
often
,
and
of
whom
he
had
seen
so
little
.
<EOS>
He
told
himself
that
the
Duke
of
Omnium
should
be
no
more
to
him
than
any
other
man
,
but
yet
the
Duke
of
Omnium
was
more
to
him
than
other
men
.
<EOS>
When
he
came
down
into
the
drawing
-
room
he
was
angry
with
himself
,
and
stood
apart
;
 
and
was
then
angry
with
himself
again
because
he
stood
apart
.
<EOS>
Why
should
he
make
a
difference
in
his
own
bearing
because
there
was
such
a
man
in
the
company
?
<EOS>
And
yet
he
could
not
avoid
it
.
<EOS>
When
he
entered
the
room
the
Duke
was
standing
in
a
large
bow
-
window
,
and
two
or
three
ladies
and
two
or
three
men
were
standing
round
him
.
<EOS>
Phineas
would
not
go
near
the
group
,
telling
himself
that
he
would
not
approach
a
man
<EOS>
so
grand
as
was
the
Duke
of
Omnium
.
<EOS>
He
saw
Madame
Max
Goesler
among
the
party
,
and
after
a
while
he
saw
her
retreat
.
<EOS>
As
she
retreated
,
Phineas
knew
that
some
words
from
Madame
Max
Goesler
had
not
been
received
with
the
graciousness
which
she
had
expected
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
prettiest
smile
in
the
world
on
the
lady
's
face
,
and
she
took
a
corner
on
a
sofa
with
an
air
of
perfect
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
But
yet
Phineas
knew
that
she
had
received
a
wound
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
called
twice
on
you
in
London
,
"
said
Phineas
,
coming
up
close
to
her
,
"
but
was
not
fortunate
enough
to
find
you
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
but
you
came
so
late
in
the
season
as
to
make
it
impossible
that
there
should
be
any
arrangements
for
our
meeting
.
<EOS>
What
can
any
woman
do
when
a
gentleman
calls
on
her
in
August
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
came
in
July
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
you
did
;
on
the
31st
.
<EOS>
I
keep
the
most
accurate
record
of
all
such
things
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
But
let
us
hope
that
we
may
have
better
luck
next
year
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
we
can
only
enjoy
the
good
things
that
are
going
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Socially
,
or
politically
,
Madame
Goesler
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
socially
.
<EOS>
How
can
I
mean
anything
else
when
the
Duke
of
Omnium
is
here
?
<EOS>
I
feel
so
much
taller
at
being
in
the
same
house
with
him
.
<EOS>
Do
not
you
?
<EOS>
But
you
are
a
spoilt
child
of
fortune
,
and
perhaps
you
have
met
him
before
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
once
saw
the
back
of
a
hat
in
the
park
,
and
somebody
told
me
that
the
Duke
's
head
was
inside
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
have
never
seen
him
but
that
once
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Never
but
that
once
,
 
till
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
do
not
you
feel
elated
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
do
.
<EOS>
For
what
do
you
take
me
,
Madame
Goesler
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
 
immensely
.
<EOS>
I
believe
him
to
be
a
fool
,
and
I
never
heard
of
his
doing
a
kind
act
to
anybody
in
my
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
when
he
gave
the
racehorse
to
Lady
Glencora
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whether
that
was
true
.
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
hear
of
such
an
absurdity
?
<EOS>
As
I
was
saying
,
I
do
n't
think
he
ever
did
anything
for
anybody
;
 
but
then
,
you
know
,
to
be
Duke
of
Omnium
!
<EOS>
It
is
n't
necessary
,
 
is
it
,
 
that
a
Duke
of
Omnium
should
do
anything
except
be
Duke
of
Omnium
?
"
  
<EOS>
At
this
moment
Lady
Glencora
came
up
to
Phineas
,
and
took
him
across
to
the
Duke
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
had
expressed
a
desire
to
be
introduced
to
him
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
half
-
pleased
and
half
-
disgusted
,
had
no
alternative
,
and
followed
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
shook
hands
with
him
,
and
made
a
little
bow
,
and
said
something
about
the
garrotters
,
which
Phineas
,
in
his
confusion
,
did
not
quite
understand
.
<EOS>
He
tried
to
reply
as
he
would
have
replied
to
anybody
else
,
but
the
weight
of
the
Duke
's
majesty
was
too
much
for
him
,
and
he
bungled
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
made
another
little
bow
,
and
in
a
moment
was
speaking
a
word
of
condescension
to
some
other
favoured
individual
.
<EOS>
Phineas
retreated
altogether
disgusted
,
 
hating
the
Duke
,
but
hating
himself
worse
;
but
he
would
not
retreat
in
the
direction
of
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
<EOS>
It
might
suit
that
lady
to
take
an
instant
little
revenge
for
her
discomfiture
,
but
it
did
not
suit
him
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
The
question
with
him
would
be
,
whether
in
some
future
part
of
his
career
it
might
not
be
his
duty
to
assist
in
putting
down
Dukes
of
Omnium
.
  
<EOS>
At
dinner
Phineas
sat
between
Mrs.
Bonteen
and
the
Duchess
of
St.
Bungay
,
and
did
not
find
himself
very
happy
.
<EOS>
At
the
other
end
of
the
table
the
Duke
,
 
the
great
Duke
,
was
seated
at
Lady
Glencora
's
right
hand
,
and
on
his
other
side
Fortune
had
placed
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
<EOS>
The
greatest
interest
which
Phineas
had
during
the
dinner
was
in
watching
the
operations
,
 
the
triumphantly
successful
operations
of
that
lady
.
<EOS>
Before
dinner
she
had
been
wounded
by
the
Duke
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
had
not
condescended
to
accord
the
honour
of
his
little
bow
of
graciousness
to
some
little
flattering
morsel
of
wit
which
the
lady
had
uttered
on
his
behoof
.
<EOS>
She
had
said
a
sharp
word
or
two
in
her
momentary
anger
to
Phineas
;
but
when
Fortune
was
so
good
to
her
in
that
matter
of
her
place
at
dinner
,
she
was
not
fool
enough
to
throw
away
her
chance
.
<EOS>
Throughout
the
soup
and
fish
she
was
very
quiet
.
<EOS>
She
said
a
word
or
two
after
her
first
glass
of
champagne
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
refused
two
dishes
,
one
after
another
,
and
then
she
glided
into
conversation
.
<EOS>
By
the
time
that
he
had
his
roast
mutton
before
him
she
was
in
full
play
,
and
as
she
eat
her
peach
,
the
Duke
was
bending
over
her
with
his
most
gracious
smile
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
you
think
the
session
was
very
long
,
Mr.
Finn
?
"
said
the
Duchess
to
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
long
indeed
,
Duchess
,
"
said
Phineas
,
with
his
attention
still
fixed
on
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
Duke
found
it
very
troublesome
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
daresay
he
did
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
That
duke
and
that
duchess
were
no
more
than
any
other
man
and
any
other
man
's
wife
.
<EOS>
The
session
had
not
been
longer
to
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
than
to
all
the
public
servants
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
the
greatest
possible
respect
for
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
,
but
he
could
not
take
much
interest
in
the
wailings
of
the
Duchess
on
her
husband
's
behalf
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
things
do
seem
to
be
so
very
uncomfortable
now
,
"
said
the
Duchess
,
 
thinking
partly
of
the
resignation
of
Mr.
Mildmay
,
and
partly
of
the
fact
that
her
own
old
peculiar
maid
who
had
lived
with
her
for
thirty
years
had
retired
into
private
life
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
so
very
bad
,
Duchess
,
I
hope
,
"
said
Phineas
,
observing
that
at
this
moment
Madame
Max
Goesler
's
eyes
were
brilliant
with
triumph
.
<EOS>
Then
there
came
upon
him
a
sudden
ambition
,
 
that
he
would
like
to
"
cut
out
"
the
Duke
of
Omnium
in
the
estimation
of
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
<EOS>
The
brightness
of
Madame
Max
Goesler
's
eyes
had
not
been
thrown
away
upon
our
hero
.
  
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
came
at
the
appointed
time
,
and
,
to
the
surprise
of
Phineas
,
was
brought
to
Matching
by
Lord
Brentford
.
<EOS>
Phineas
at
first
thought
that
it
was

that
the
Earl
and
his
son
should
meet
and
make

at
Mr.
Palliser
's

.
<EOS>
But
Lord
Brentford
stayed
only
one

,
and
Phineas
on
the
next
morning
heard
the
whole
history
of
his
coming
and
going
from
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
almost
been
on
my

to
him
to
stay
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
I
did
go
on
my
knees
,
 
actually
on
my
knees
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
did
he
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
He
put
his
arm
round
me
and
kissed
me
,
and
,
 
and
,
 
I
can
not
tell
you
all
that
he
said
.
<EOS>
But
it
ended
in
this
,
 
that
if
Chiltern
can
be
made
to
go
to
Saulsby
,
fatted
calves
without
stint
will
be
killed
.
<EOS>
I
shall
do
all
I
can
to
make

go
;
and
so

you
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
Of
course
that
silly
affair
in
foreign
parts
is
not
to
make
any
difference
between
you
two
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
smiled
,
and
said
he
would
do
his
best
,
and
looked
up
into
her
face
,
and
was
just
able
to
talk
to
her
as
though
things
were
going
comfortably
with
him
.
<EOS>
But
his
heart
was
very
cold
.
<EOS>
As
Violet
had
spoken
to
him
about
Lord
Chiltern
there
had
come
upon
him
,
for
the
first

,
 
for
the
first

since
he
had
known
that
Lord
Chiltern
had

refused
,
 
an
idea
,
a

,
whether
even

Violet
might
not

Lord
Chiltern
's

.
<EOS>
His
heart
was
very

,
but
he
struggled
on
,
 
declaring
that
it
was
incumbent
on
them
both
to
bring
together

father
and
son
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so

say

,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
I
really
do
believe
that
you
can
do
more
towards
it
than
any
one
else
.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
would
think
nothing
of
my
advice
,
 
would
hardly

to

on
such

.
<EOS>
But
he
respects
you
as
well

likes
you
,
and
not
the

because

what

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
How
was
it
that
Violet
should
know
aught
of
the
respect
or
liking
<EOS>
felt
by
this
rejected

for
that
other

,
 
who
had
also

?
<EOS>
And
how
was

that
she
was
thus

,
as

?
<EOS>
Phineas
felt
his
position
to
be
so
strange
as
to
be
almost

.
<EOS>
He
had
told
Violet
,
when
she
had
refused

,
very

,
that
he
should
come
again
to
her
,
and
ask

more

the
great

which

.
<EOS>
But
he
could
not
ask
again
now
.
<EOS>
In
the
first

,
there
was
that
in
her

which
made
him
sure
that
were

to

,

in

;
and
then
he
felt
that
she
was
placing
a

in
him
,
against

he
would
commit
a
sin

to
use
her
present

with

for

of
making
love
.
<EOS>
They
two
were
to
put
their
shoulders
together
to
help
Lord
Chiltern
,
and
while
doing
so
he
could
not
continue
a
suit
which
would
be
felt
by
both

to
be
hostile
to
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
There
might
be

for
a
chance

,
and
if
so
the
chance

should
be
spoken
;
but
he
could
not
make
a

,
such

had

Square
.
<EOS>
Violet
also
probably
understood
that
she
had
not
now
been
caught
in
a
mousetrap
.
  
<EOS>
The
Duke
was
to
spend
four
days
at
Matching
,
and
on
the
third
day
,
 
the
day
before
Lord
Chiltern
was
expected
,
 
he
was
to
be
seen
riding
with
Madame
Max
Goesler
by

.
<EOS>
Madame
Max
Goesler
was
known
as
a
perfect
horsewoman
,
 
one
indeed
who
was
rather
fond
of
going
a
little
fast
on

,
and
who
rode
well
to
hounds
.
<EOS>
But
the
Duke
seldom
moved
out
of
a
walk
,
and
on
this

Madame
Max
was
as
steady
in

and
almost

as
the
mounted

in
_
Don
Juan
_
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
said
by
some
there
,
especially

Mrs.
Bonteen
,
that
the
conversation
between
them
was
not
slow
.
<EOS>
And
on
the
next
morning
the
Duke
and
Madame
Max
Goesler
were
together
again
before

,
standing
on
a

at
the
back

the

,
looking

who

on

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
never
play
?
"
said
the
Duke
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
;
 
one
does
everything
a
little
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
you
would
play
well
.
<EOS>
Why
do
you
not
play
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
I
shall
not
play
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
see
you
with
your
mallet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
your
Grace
can
not
be
gratified
.
<EOS>
I
have
played
croquet
till
I
am
tired
of
it
,
and
have
come
to
think
it
is
only

boys
and

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And

,

Goesler
?
"
  
"
Never

,
Duke
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
 
I
am

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
<EOS>

Max

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Madame

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
Then

something

Madame
Max

blushed

,

<EOS>
Mrs.
Bonteen
had

,

and

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
The

so

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Two

,

,
"

,
who

<EOS>
"
Our

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
You
see

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
talked
enough
to

in
all

,
"
said
Mrs.
Bonteen
,
who
was
now

.
   
<EOS>
The
Duellists
Meet
 
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
arrived
,
and
Phineas
was
a
little
nervous
as
to
their
meeting
.
<EOS>
He
came
back
from
shooting
on
the
day
in
question
,
and
was
told
by
the
servant
that
Lord
Chiltern
was
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
Phineas
went
into
the
billiard
-
room
in
his
knickerbockers
,
thinking
probably
that
he
might
be
there
,
and
then
into
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
at
last
into
the
library
,
 
but
Lord
Chiltern
was
not
to
be
found
.
<EOS>
At
last
he
came
across
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
seen
him
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
he
was
with
me
half
an
hour
since
,
walking
round
the
gardens
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
is
he
?
<EOS>
Come
;
 
tell
me
something
about
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
knew
him
to
be
more
pleasant
.
<EOS>
He
would
give
no
promise
about
Saulsby
,
but
he
did
not
say
that
he
would
not
go
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Does
he
know
that
I
am
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
I
told
him
so
.
<EOS>
I
told
him
how
much
pleasure
I
should
have
in
seeing
you
two
together
,
 
as
friends
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
did
he
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
laughed
,
and
said
you
were
the
best
fellow
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
You
see
I
am
obliged
to
be
explicit
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
why
did
he
laugh
?
"
<EOS>
Phineas
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
did
not
tell
me
,
but
I
suppose
it
was
because
he
was
thinking
of
a
little
trip
he
once
took
to
Belgium
,
and
he
perceived
that
I
knew
all
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
who
told
you
.
<EOS>
But
never
mind
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
mean
to
ask
any
questions
.
<EOS>
As
I
do
not
like
that
our
first
meeting
should
be
before
all
the
people
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
I
will
go
to
him
in
his
own
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
,
do
;
 
that
will
be
so
nice
of
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
sent
his
card
up
by
a
servant
,
and
in
a
few
minutes
was
standing
with
his
hand
on
the
lock
of
Lord
Chiltern
's
door
.
<EOS>
The
last
time
he
had
seen
this
man
,
they
had
met
with
pistols
in
their
hands
to
shoot
at
each
other
,
and
Lord
Chiltern
had
in
truth
done
his
very
best
to
shoot
his
opponent
.
<EOS>
The
cause
of
quarrel
was
the
same
between
them
as
ever
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
not
given
up
Violet
,
and
had
no
intention
of
giving
her
up
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
received
no
intimation
whatever
from
his
rival
that
there
was
to
be
a
truce
between
them
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
indeed
written
in
friendship
to
Lord
Chiltern
,
but
he
had
received
no
answer
;
 
and
nothing
of
certainty
was
to
be
gathered
from
the
report
which
Violet
had
just
made
.
<EOS>
It
might
well
be
that
Lord
Chiltern
would
turn
upon
him
now
in
his
wrath
,
and
that
there
would
be
some
scene
which
in
a
strange
house
would
be
obviously
objectionable
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
he
had
resolved
that
even
that
would
be
better
than
a
chance
encounter
among
strangers
in
a
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
So
the
door
was
opened
and
the
two
men
met
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
old
fellow
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
Then
all
doubt
was
over
,
and
in
a
moment
Phineas
was
shaking
his
former
,
 
and
present
friend
,
warmly
by
the
hand
.
<EOS>
"
So
we
've
come
to
be
<EOS>
an
Under
-
Secretary
have
we
?
 
<EOS>
and
all
that
kind
of
thing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
had
to
get
into
harness
,
 
when
the
harness
offered
itself
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
so
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
deuce
of
a
bore
,
is

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
always

,

<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
That

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

,

No
;

.

"
How

?
<EOS>

;

.

.
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

had
in
one

,

.
<EOS>
It

and

Chiltern
were
again

.
<EOS>
It

this
half

,

,

.
<EOS>
Lord

to

hero
's

,

was

our

was

.
<EOS>
Phineas
understood

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,
 
and

.
<EOS>
If

Effingham

Lord
Chiltern
<EOS>
,
what
had

,

,

?
  
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
Phineas

that

Glencora
,

.
<EOS>

Max

.
<EOS>
He

Madame
Max
Goesler
;
but
that

was

.
<EOS>
He

Effingham
.
<EOS>
And
yet
,

well

,

.
<EOS>
He
knew
beforehand
,
with
absolute

,
the
manner

she
would

.
<EOS>
She
would

kind
,

,

,

,
nay
,

;
and
yet
her

mean
nothing
,

to

Chiltern
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
as

thought
,
a

with
Violet
Effingham
that
she
could
treat
her

as

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.

,
"

,
"
your

<EOS>
are
tell
-

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,
 
very

;

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

!
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
arranged
that
Phineas
and
Lord
Chiltern
were

together
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
to
remain
at
his
office
all
October
,
and
in
November
the
general
election
was
to
take
place
.
<EOS>
What
he
had
hitherto
heard
about
a
future
seat
<EOS>
was
most
vague
,
but
he
was
to
meet
Ratler
and
Barrington

in
London
,
and

had
been

that
Barrington
Erle
,
who
was
now

,
was
to
make
some
inquiry
as

that

of
which
Loughton
at
this

formed

.
<EOS>
But
as
Loughton
was
the
smallest
of

,
and
as

the
four
had
for

had

.

.

.

,

,

,

,

.

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
