to
have
been
successful
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
very
pleasant
to
us
,
Phineas
.
<EOS>
Mamma
has
been
so
much
rejoiced
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
sorry
not
to
see
her
.
<EOS>
She
is
at
Floodborough
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
;
 
she
is
at
home
.
<EOS>
She
does
not
like
coming
out
at
night
in
winter
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
staying
here
you
know
for
two
days
,
but
I
go
home
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
ride
over
and
call
on
your
mother
.
<EOS>
"
Then
there
was
a
pause
in
the
conversation
for
a
moment
.
"
<EOS>
Does
it
not
seem
odd
,
Mary
,
that
we
should
see
so
little
of
each
other
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
so
much
away
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
that
is
the
reason
.
<EOS>
But
still
it
seems
almost
unnatural
.
<EOS>
I
often
wonder
when
the
time
will
come
that
I
shall
be
quietly
at
home
again
.
<EOS>
I
have
to
be
back
in
my
office
in
London
this
day
week
,
and
yet
I
have
not
had
a
single
hour
to
myself
since
I
have
been
at
Killaloe
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
certainly
ride
over
and
see
your
mother
.
<EOS>
You
will
be
at
home
on
Wednesday
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
 
I
shall
be
at
home
.
"
  
<EOS>
Upon
that
he
got
up
and
went
away
,
but
again
in
the
evening
he
found
himself
near
her
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
there
is
no
position
more
perilous
to
a
man
's
honesty
than
that
in
which
Phineas
now
found
himself
;
 
that
,
namely
,
of
knowing
himself
to
be
quite
loved
by
a
girl
whom
he
almost
loves
himself
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
loved
Violet
Effingham
;
and
they
who
talk
best
of
love
protest
that
no
man
or
woman
can
be
in
love
with
two
persons
at
once
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
not
in
love
with
Mary
Flood
Jones
;
but
he
would
have
liked
to
take
her
in
his
arms
and
kiss
her
;
 
he
would
have
liked
to
gratify
her
by
swearing
that
she
was
dearer
to
him
than
all
the
world
;
he
would
have
liked
to
have
an
episode
,
 
and
did
,
at
the
moment
,
think
that
it
might
be
possible
to
have
one
life
in
London
and
another
life
altogether
different
at
Killaloe
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dear
Mary
,
"
he
said
as
he
pressed
her
hand
that
night
,
"
things
will
get
themselves
settled
at
last
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
He
was
behaving
very
ill
to
her
,
but
he
did
not
mean
to
behave
ill
.
  
<EOS>
He
rode
over
to
Floodborough
,
and
saw
Mrs.
Flood
Jones
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Flood
Jones
,
however
,
received
him
very
coldly
;
and
Mary
did
not
appear
.
<EOS>
Mary
had
communicated
to
her
mother
her
resolutions
as
to
her
future
life
.
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
,
mamma
,
I
love
him
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
help
it
.
<EOS>
If
he
ever
chooses
to
come
for
me
,
here
I
am
.
<EOS>
If
he
does
not
,
I
will
bear
it
as
well
as
I
can
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
very
mean
of
me
,
but
it
's
true
.
"
   
<EOS>
Troubles
at
Loughlinter
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
dull
house
at
Loughlinter
during
the
greater
part
of
this
autumn
.
<EOS>
A
few
men
went
down
for
the
grouse
shooting
late
in
the
season
;
but
they
stayed
but
a
short
time
,
and
when
they
went
Lady
Laura
was
left
alone
with
her
husband
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
had
explained
to
his
wife
,
more
than
once
,
that
though
he
understood
the
duties
of
hospitality
and
enjoyed
the
performance
of
them
,
he
had
not
married
with
the
intention
of
living
in
a
whirlwind
.
<EOS>
He
was
disposed
to
think
that
the
whirlwind
had
hitherto
been
too
predominant
,
and
had
said
so
very
plainly
with
a
good
deal
of
marital
authority
.
<EOS>
This
autumn
and
winter
were
to
be
devoted
to
the
cultivation
of
proper
relations
between
him
and
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
Does
that
mean
Darby
and
Joan
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
his
wife
had
asked
him
,
when
the
proposition
was
made
to
her
.
"
<EOS>
It
means
mutual
regard
and
esteem
,
"
replied
Mr.
Kennedy
in
his
most
solemn
tone
,
"
and
I
trust
that
such
mutual
regard
and
esteem
between
us
may
yet
be
possible
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
Lady
Laura
showed
him
a
letter
from
her
brother
,
received
some
weeks
after
this
conversation
,
in
which
Lord
Chiltern
expressed
his
intention
of
coming
to
Loughlinter
for
Christmas
,
he
returned
the
note
to
his
wife
without
a
word
.
<EOS>
He
suspected
that
she
had
made
the
arrangement
without
asking
him
,
and
was
angry
;
but
he
would
not
tell
her
that
her
brother
would
not
be
welcome
at
his
house
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
my
doing
,
"
she
said
,
when
she
saw
the
frown
on
his
brow
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
said
nothing
about
anybody
's
doing
,
"
he
replied
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
write
to
Oswald
and
bid
him
not
come
,
if
you
wish
it
.
<EOS>
Of
course
you
can
understand
why
he
is
coming
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
to
see
me
,
I
am
sure
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
me
,
"
replied
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
coming
because
my
friend
Violet
Effingham
will
be
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Effingham
!
<EOS>
Why
was
I
not
told
of
this
?
<EOS>
I
knew
nothing
of
Miss
Effingham
's
coming
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Robert
,
it
was
settled
in
your
own
presence
last
July
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
deny
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Laura
rose
up
,
very
haughty
in
her
gait
and
with
something
of
fire
in
her
eye
,
and
silently
left
the
room
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
,
when
he
found
himself
alone
,
was
very
unhappy
.
<EOS>
Looking
back
in
his
mind
to
the
summer
weeks
in
London
,
he
remembered
that
his
wife
had
told
Violet
that
she
was
to
spend
her
Christmas
at
Loughlinter
,
that
he
himself
had
given
a
muttered
assent
and
that
Violet
,
 
as
far
as
he
could
remember
,
 
had
made
no
reply
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
one
of
those
things
which
are
so
often
mentioned
,
but
not
settled
.
<EOS>
He
felt
that
he
had
been
strictly
right
in
denying
that
it
had
been
"
settled
"
in
his
presence
;
 
but
yet
he
felt
that
he
had
been
wrong
in
contradicting
his
wife
so
peremptorily
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
just
man
,
and
he
would
apologise
for
his
fault
;
but
he
was
an
austere
man
,
and
would
take
back
the
value
of
his
apology
in
additional
austerity
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
see
his
wife
for
some
hours
after
the
conversation
which
has
been
narrated
,
but
when
he
did
meet
her
his
mind
was
still
full
of
the
subject
.
<EOS>
"
Laura
"
,
he
said
,
"
I
am
sorry
that
I
contradicted
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
used
to
it
,
Robert
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
you
are
not
used
to
it
.
"
<EOS>
She
smiled
and
bowed
her
head
.
<EOS>
"
You
wrong
me
by
saying
that
you
are
used
to
it
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
paused
a
moment
,
but
she
said
not
a
word
,
 
only
smiled
and
bowed
her
head
again
.
<EOS>
"
I
remember
,
"
he
continued
,
"
that
something
was
said
in
my
presence
to
Miss
Effingham
about
her
coming
here
at
Christmas
.
<EOS>
It
was
so
slight
,
however
,
that
it
had
passed
out
of
my
memory
till
recalled
by
an
effort
.
<EOS>
I
beg
your
pardon
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
is
unnecessary
,
Robert
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
do
you
wish
that
I
should
put
her
off
,
 
or
put
Oswald
off
,
 
or
both
?
<EOS>
My
brother
never
yet
has
seen
me
in
your
house
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
whose
fault
has
that
been
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
nothing
about
anybody
's
fault
,
Robert
.
<EOS>
I
merely
mentioned
a
fact
.
<EOS>
Will
you
let
me
know
whether
I
shall
bid
him
stay
away
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
welcome
to
come
,
 
only
I
do
not
like
assignations
for
love
-
making
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Assignations
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Clandestine
meetings
.
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
would
not
wish
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lady
Baldock
!
<EOS>
Do
you
think
that
Violet
would
exercise
any
secrecy
in
the
matter
,
 
or
that
she
will
not
tell
Lady
Baldock
that
Oswald
will
be
here
,
 
as
soon
as
she
knows
it
herself
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
has
nothing
to
do
with
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
Robert
,
it
must
have
much
to
do
with
it
.
<EOS>
And
why
should
not
these
two
young
people
meet
?
<EOS>
The
acknowledged
wish
of
all
the
family
is
that
they
should
marry
each
other
.
<EOS>
And
in
this
matter
,
at
any
rate
,
my
brother
has
behaved
extremely
well
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
said
nothing
further
at
the
time
,
and
it
became
an
understanding
that
Violet
Effingham
was
to
be
a
month
at
Loughlinter
,
staying
from
the
20th
of
December
to
the
20th
of
January
,
and
that
Lord
Chiltern
was
to
come
there
for
Christmas
,
 
which
with
him
would
probably
mean
three
days
.
  
<EOS>
Before
Christmas
came
,
however
,
there
were
various
other
sources
of
uneasiness
at
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
,
as
a
matter
of
course
,
great
anxiety
as
to
the
elections
.
<EOS>
With
Lady
Laura
this
anxiety
had
been
very
strong
,
and
even
Mr.
Kennedy
had
been
warmed
with
some
amount
of
fire
as
the
announcements
reached
him
of
the
successes
and
of
the
failures
.
<EOS>
The
English
returns
came
first
,
 
and
then
the
Scotch
,
which
were
quite
as
interesting
to
Mr.
Kennedy
as
the
English
.
<EOS>
His
own
seat
was
quite
safe
,
 
was
not
contested
;
but
some
neighbouring
seats
were
sources
of
great
solicitude
.
<EOS>
Then
,
when
this
was
over
,
there
were
the
tidings
from
Ireland
to
be
received
;
and
respecting
one
special
borough
in
Ireland
,
Lady
Laura
evinced
more
solicitude
than
her
husband
approved
.
<EOS>
There
was
much
danger
for
the
domestic
bliss
of
the
house
of
Loughlinter
,
when
things
came
to
such
a
pass
,
and
such
words
were
spoken
,
as
the
election
at
Loughshane
produced
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
in
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
opening
a
telegram
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
is
in
?
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
,
with
that
frown
on
his
brow
to
which
his
wife
was
now
well
accustomed
.
<EOS>
Though
he
asked
the
question
,
he
knew
very
well
who
was
the
hero
to
whom
the
telegram
referred
.
  
<EOS>
"
Our
friend
Phineas
Finn
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
speaking
still
with
an
excited
voice
,
 
with
a
voice
that
was
intended
to
display
excitement
.
<EOS>
If
there
was
to
be
a
battle
on
this
matter
,
there
should
be
a
battle
.
<EOS>
She
would
display
all
her
anxiety
for
her
young
friend
,
and
fling
it
in
her
husband
's
face
if
he
chose
to
take
it
as
an
injury
.
<EOS>
What
,
 
should
she
endure
reproach
from
her
husband
because
she
regarded
the
interests
of
the
man
who
had
saved
his
life
,
of
the
man
respecting
whom
she
had
suffered
so
many
heart
-
struggles
,
and
as
to
whom
she
had
at
last
come
to
the
conclusion
that
he
should
ever
be
regarded
as
a
second
brother
,
loved
equally
with
the
elder
brother
?
<EOS>
She
had
done
her
duty
by
her
husband
,
 
so
at
least
she
had
assured
herself
;
 
and
should
he
dare
to
reproach
her
on
this
subject
,
she
would
be
ready
for
the
battle
.
<EOS>
And
now
the
battle
came
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
of
this
,
"
she
said
,
with
all
the
eagerness
she
could
throw
into
her
voice
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
indeed
,
 
and
so
ought
you
to
be
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
husband
's
brow
grew
blacker
and
blacker
,
but
still
he
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
He
had
long
been
too
proud
to
be
jealous
,
and
was
now
too
proud
to
express
his
jealousy
,
 
if
only
he
could
keep
the
expression
back
.
<EOS>
But
his
wife
would
not
leave
the
subject
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
thankful
for
this
,
"
she
said
,
pressing
the
telegram
between
her
hands
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
so
afraid
he
would
fail
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
over
-
do
your
anxiety
on
such
a
subject
,
"
at
last
he
said
,
speaking
very
slowly
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
,
Robert
?
<EOS>
How
can
I
be
over
-
anxious
?
<EOS>
If
it
concerned
any
other
dear
friend
that
I
have
in
the
world
,
it
would
not
be
an
affair
of
life
and
death
.
<EOS>
To
him
it
is
almost
so
.
<EOS>
I
would
have
walked
from
here
to
London
to
get
him
his
election
.
"
<EOS>
And
as
she
spoke
she
held
up
the
clenched
fist
of
her
left
hand
,
and
shook
it
,
while
she
still
held
the
telegram
in
her
right
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
Laura
,
I
must
tell
you
that
it
is
improper
that
you
should
speak
of
any
man
in
those
terms
;
 
of
any
man
that
is
a
stranger
to
your
blood
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
stranger
to
my
blood
!
<EOS>
What
has
that
to
do
with
it
?
<EOS>
This
man
is
my
friend
,
is
your
friend
;
 
saved
your
life
,
has
been
my
brother
's
best
friend
,
is
loved
by
my
father
,
 
and
is
loved
by
me
,
very
dearly
.
<EOS>
Tell
me
what
you
mean
by
improper
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
have
you
love
any
man
,
 
very
dearly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Robert
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
that
I
will
have
no
such
expressions
from
you
.
<EOS>
They
are
unseemly
,
and
are
used
only
to
provoke
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Am
I
to
understand
that
I
am
insulted
by
an
accusation
?
<EOS>
If
so
,
let
me
beg
at
once
that
I
may
be
allowed
to
go
to
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
I
would
rather
accept
your
apology
and
retractation
there
than
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
go
to
Saulsby
,
and
there
has
been
no
accusation
,
and
there
will
be
no
apology
.
<EOS>
If
you
please
there
will
be
no
more
mention
of
Mr.
Finn
's
name
between
us
,
for
the
present
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
take
my
advice
you
will
cease
to
think
of
him
extravagantly
;
 
and
I
must
desire
you
to
hold
no
further
direct
communication
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
held
no
communication
with
him
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
advancing
a
step
towards
him
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Kennedy
simply
pointed
to
the
telegram
in
her
hand
,
and
left
the
room
.
<EOS>
Now
in
respect
to
this
telegram
there
had
been
an
unfortunate
mistake
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
prepared
to
say
that
there
was
any
reason
why
Phineas
himself
should
not
have
sent
the
news
of
his
success
to
Lady
Laura
;
but
he
had
not
done
so
.
<EOS>
The
piece
of
paper
which
she
still
held
crushed
in
her
hand
was
in
itself
very
innocent
.
"
<EOS>
Hurrah
for
the
Loughshanes
.
<EOS>
Finny
has
done
the
trick
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Such
were
the
words
written
on
the
slip
,
and
they
had
been
sent
to
Lady
Laura
by
her
young
cousin
,
the
clerk
in
the
office
who
acted
as
private
secretary
to
the
Under
-
Secretary
of
State
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
resolved
that
her
husband
should
never
see
those
innocent
but
rather
undignified
words
.
<EOS>
The
occasion
had
become
one
of
importance
,
and
such
words
were
unworthy
of
it
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
she
would
not
condescend
to
defend
herself
by
bringing
forward
a
telegram
as
evidence
in
her
favour
.
<EOS>
So
she
burned
the
morsel
of
paper
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
and
Mr.
Kennedy
did
not
meet
again
till
late
that
evening
.
<EOS>
She
was
ill
,
she
said
,
and
would
not
come
down
to
dinner
.
<EOS>
After
dinner
she
wrote
him
a
note
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dear
Robert
,
I
think
you
must
regret
what
you
said
to
me
.
<EOS>
If
so
,
pray
let
me
have
a
line
from
you
to
that
effect
.
<EOS>
Yours
affectionately
,
L.
"
When
the
servant
handed
it
to
him
,
and
<EOS>
he
had
read
it
,
he
smiled
and
thanked
the
girl
who
had
brought
it
,
and
said
he
would
see
her
mistress
just
now
.
<EOS>
Anything
would
be
better
than
that
the
servants
should
know
that
there
was
a
quarrel
.
<EOS>
But
every
servant
in
the
house
had
known
all
about
it
for
the
last
three
hours
.
<EOS>
When
the
door
was
closed
and
he
was
alone
,
he
sat
fingering
the
note
,
thinking
deeply
how
he
should
answer
it
,
or
whether
he
would
answer
it
at
all
.
<EOS>
No
;
he
would
not
answer
it
;
 
not
in
writing
.
<EOS>
He
would
give
his
wife
no
written
record
of
his
humiliation
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
acted
wrongly
.
<EOS>
He
had
said
nothing
more
than
now
,
upon
mature
consideration
,
he
thought
that
the
circumstances
demanded
.
<EOS>
But
yet
he
felt
that
he
must
in
some
sort
withdraw
the
accusation
which
he
had
made
.
<EOS>
If
he
did
not
withdraw
it
,
there
was
no
knowing
what
his
wife
might
do
.
<EOS>
About
ten
in
the
evening
he
went
up
to
her
and
made
his
little
speech
.
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
I
have
come
to
answer
your
note
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
would
have
written
to
me
a
line
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
instead
,
Laura
.
<EOS>
Now
,
if
you
will
listen
to
me
for
one
moment
,
I
think
everything
will
be
made
smooth
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
will
listen
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
knowing
very
well
that
her
husband
's
moment
would
be
rather
tedious
,
and
resolving
that
she
also
would
have
her
moment
afterwards
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
will
acknowledge
that
if
there
be
a
difference
of
opinion
between
you
and
me
as
to
any
question
of
social
intercourse
,
it
will
be
better
that
you
should
consent
to
adopt
my
opinion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
the
law
on
your
side
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
speaking
of
the
law
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;
 
go
on
,
Robert
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
interrupt
you
if
I
can
help
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
speaking
of
the
law
.
<EOS>
I
am
speaking
simply
of
convenience
,
and
of
that
which
you
must
feel
to
be
right
.
<EOS>
If
I
wish
that
your
intercourse
with
any
person
should
be
of
such
or
such
a
nature
it
must
be
best
that
you
should
comply
with
my
wishes
.
"
<EOS>
He
paused
for
her
assent
,
but
she
neither
assented
nor
dissented
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
far
as
I
can
understand
the
position
of
a
man
and
wife
in
this
country
,
there
is
no
other
way
in
which
life
can
be
made
harmonious
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Life
will
not
run
in
harmonies
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
expect
that
ours
shall
be
made
to
do
so
,
Laura
.
<EOS>
I
need
hardly
say
to
you
that
I
intend
to
accuse
you
of
no
impropriety
of
feeling
in
reference
to
this
young
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Robert
;
you
need
hardly
say
that
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
to
speak
my
own
mind
,
I
think
that
you
need
hardly
have
alluded
to
it
.
<EOS>
I
might
go
further
,
and
say
that
such
an
allusion
is
in
itself
an
insult
,
 
an
insult
now
repeated
after
hours
of
deliberation
,
 
an
insult
which
I
will
not
endure
to
have
repeated
again
.
<EOS>
If
you
say
another
word
in
any
way
suggesting
the
possibility
of
improper
relations
between
me
and
Mr.
Finn
,
either
as
to
deeds
or
thoughts
,
as
God
is
above
me
,
I
will
write
to
both
my
father
and
my
brother
,
and
desire
them
to
take
me
from
your
house
.
<EOS>
If
you
wish
me
to
remain
here
,
you
had
better
be
careful
!
"
<EOS>
As
she
was
making
this
speech
,
her
temper
seemed
to
rise
,
and
to
become
hot
,
and
then
hotter
,
till
it
glowed
with
a
red
heat
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
cool
till
the
word
insult
,
used
by
herself
,
had
conveyed
back
to
her
a
strong
impression
of
her
own
wrong
,
 
or
<EOS>
perhaps
I
should
rather
say
a
strong
feeling
of
the
necessity
of
becoming
indignant
.
<EOS>
She
was
standing
as
she
spoke
,
and
the
fire
flashed
from
her
eyes
,
and
he
quailed
before
her
.
<EOS>
The
threat
which
she
had
held
out
to
him
was
very
dreadful
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
terribly
in
fear
of
the
world
's
good
opinion
,
who
lacked
the
courage
to
go
through
a
great
and
harassing
trial
in
order
that
something
better
might
come
afterwards
.
<EOS>
His
married
life
had
been
unhappy
.
<EOS>
His
wife
had
not
submitted
either
to
his
will
or
to
his
ways
.
<EOS>
He
had
that
great
desire
to
enjoy
his
full
rights
,
so
strong
in
the
minds
of
weak
,
ambitious
men
,
and
he
had
told
himself
that
a
wife
's
obedience
was
one
of
those
rights
which
he
could
not
abandon
without
injury
to
his
self
-
esteem
.
<EOS>
He
had
thought
about
the
matter
,
slowly
,
as
was
his
wo
nt
,
and
had
resolved
that
he
would
assert
himself
.
<EOS>
He
had
asserted
himself
,
and
his
wife
told
him
to
his
face
that
she
would
go
away
and
leave
him
.
<EOS>
He
could
detain
her
legally
,
but
he
could
not
do
even
that
without
the
fact
of
such
forcible
detention
being
known
to
all
the
world
.
<EOS>
How
was
he
to
answer
her
now
at
this
moment
,
so
that
she
might
not
write
to
her
father
,
and
so
that
his
self
-
assertion
might
still
be
maintained
?
  
<EOS>
"
Passion
,
Laura
,
can
never
be
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Would
you
have
a
woman
submit
to
insult
without
passion
?
<EOS>
I
at
any
rate
am
not
such
a
woman
.
<EOS>
"
Then
there
was
a
pause
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
nothing
else
to
say
to
me
,
you
had
better
leave
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
far
from
well
,
and
my
head
is
throbbing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
came
up
and
took
her
hand
,
but
she
snatched
it
away
from
him
.
<EOS>
"
Laura
,
"
he
said
,
"
do
not
let
us
quarrel
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
shall
quarrel
if
such
insinuations
are
repeated
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
made
no
insinuation
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
repeat
them
.
<EOS>
That
is
all
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
cowed
and
left
her
,
having
first
attempted
to
get
out
of
the
difficulty
of
his
position
by
making
much
of
her
alleged
illness
,
and
by
offering
to
send
for
Dr.
Macnuthrie
.
<EOS>
She
positively
refused
to
see
Dr.
Macnuthrie
,
and
at
last
succeeded
in
inducing
him
to
quit
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
This
had
occurred
about
the
end
of
November
,
and
on
the
20th
of
December
Violet
Effingham
reached
Loughlinter
.
<EOS>
Life
in
Mr.
Kennedy
's
house
had
gone
quietly
during
the
intervening
three
weeks
,
but
not
very
pleasantly
.
<EOS>
The
name
of
Phineas
Finn
had
not
been
mentioned
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
had
triumphed
;
but
she
had
no
desire
to
acerbate
her
husband
by
any
unpalatable
allusion
to
her
victory
.
<EOS>
And
he
was
quite
willing
to
let
the
subject
die
away
,
if
only
it
would
die
.
<EOS>
On
some
other
matters
he
continued
to
assert
himself
,
taking
his
wife
to
church
twice
every
Sunday
,
using
longer
family
prayers
than
she
approved
,
reading
an
additional
sermon
himself
every
Sunday
evening
,
calling
upon
her
for
weekly
attention
to
elaborate
household
accounts
,
asking
for
her
personal
assistance
in
much
local
visiting
,
initiating
her
into
his
favourite
methods
of
family
life
in
the
country
,
till
sometimes
she
almost
longed
to
talk
again
about
Phineas
Finn
,
so
that
there
might
be
a
rupture
,
and
she
might
escape
.
<EOS>
But
her
husband
asserted
himself
within
bounds
,
and
she
submitted
,
longing
for
the
coming
of
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
write
to
her
father
and
beg
to
be
taken
away
,
because
her
husband
would
read
a
sermon
to
her
on
Sunday
evening
.
  
<EOS>
To
Violet
,
very
shortly
after
her
arrival
,
she
told
her
whole
story
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
terrible
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
makes
me
feel
that
I
never
will
be
married
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
yet
what
can
a
woman
become
if
she
remain
single
?
<EOS>
The
curse
is
to
be
a
woman
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
always
felt
so
proud
of
the
privileges
of
my
sex
,
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
have
found
them
,
"
said
the
other
;
"
never
.
<EOS>
I
have
tried
to
make
the
best
of
its
weaknesses
,
and
this
is
what
I
have
come
to
!
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
ought
to
have
loved
some
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
did
you
never
love
any
man
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
never
did
,
 
not
as
people
mean
when
they
speak
of
love
.
<EOS>
I
have
felt
that
I
would
consent
to
be
cut
in
little
pieces
for
my
brother
,
 
because
of
my
regard
for
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
that
is
nothing
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
have
felt
something
of
the
same
thing
for
another
,
 
a
longing
for
his
welfare
,
a
delight
to
hear
him
praised
,
a
charm
in
his
presence
,
 
so
strong
a
feeling
for
his
interest
<EOS>
,
that
were
he
to
go
to
wrack
and
ruin
,
<EOS>
I
too
,
should
,
after
a
fashion
,
be
wracked
and
ruined
.
<EOS>
But
it
has
not
been
love
either
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
I
know
whom
you
mean
?
<EOS>
May
I
name
him
?
<EOS>
It
is
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
is
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Did
he
ever
ask
you
,
 
to
love
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
feared
he
would
do
so
,
and
therefore
accepted
Mr.
Kennedy
's
offer
almost
at
the
first
word
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
quite
understand
your
reasoning
,
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
understand
it
.
<EOS>
I
could
have
refused
him
nothing
in
my
power
to
give
him
,
but
I
did
not
wish
to
be
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
he
never
asked
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
paused
a
moment
,
thinking
what
reply
she
should
make
;
 
and
then
she
told
a
fib
.
"
<EOS>
No
;
he
never
asked
me
.
"
<EOS>
But
Violet
did
not
believe
the
fib
.
<EOS>
Violet
was
quite
sure
that
Phineas
had
asked
Lady
Laura
Standish
to
be
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
As
far
as
I
can
see
,
"
said
Violet
,
"
Madame
Max
Goesler
is
his
present
passion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
believe
it
in
the
least
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
firing
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
does
not
much
matter
,
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
matter
very
much
.
<EOS>
You
know
,
you
,
 
you
;
you
know
whom
he
loves
.
<EOS>
And
I
do
believe
that
sooner
or
later
you
will
be
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
.
"
  
"
Yes
,
you
will
.
<EOS>
Had
you
not
loved
him
you
would
never
have
condescended
to
accuse
him
about
that
woman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
accused
him
.
<EOS>
Why
should
he
not
marry
Madame
Max
Goesler
?
<EOS>
It
would
be
just
the
thing
for
him
.
<EOS>
She
is
very
rich
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
.
<EOS>
You
will
be
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Laura
,
you
are
the
most
capricious
of
women
.
<EOS>
You
have
two
dear
friends
,
and
you
insist
that
I
shall
marry
them
both
.
<EOS>
Which
shall
I
take
first
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oswald
will
be
here
in
a
day
or
two
,
and
you
can
take
him
if
you
like
it
.
<EOS>
No
doubt
he
will
ask
you
.
<EOS>
But
I
do
not
think
you
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
do
not
think
I
shall
.
<EOS>
I
shall
knock
under
to
Mr.
Mill
,
and
go
in
for
women
's
rights
,
and
look
forward
to
stand
for
some
female
borough
.
<EOS>
Matrimony
never
seemed
to
me
to
be
very
charming
,
and
upon
my
word
it
does
not
become
more
alluring
by
what
I
find
at
Loughlinter
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
thus
that
Violet
and
Lady
Laura
discussed
these
matters
together
,
but
Violet
had
never
showed
to
her
friend
the
cards
in
her
hand
,
as
Lady
Laura
had
shown
those
which
she
held
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
had
in
fact
told
almost
everything
that
there
was
to
tell
,
 
had
spoken
either
plainly
with
true
words
,
or
equally
plainly
with
words
that
were
not
true
.
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
had
almost
come
to
love
Phineas
Finn
;
 
<EOS>
but
she
never
told
her
friend
that
it
was
so
.
<EOS>
At
one
time
she
had
almost
made
up
her
mind
to
give
herself
and
all
her
wealth
to
this
adventurer
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
better
man
,
she
thought
,
than
Lord
Chiltern
;
and
she
had
come
to
persuade
herself
that
it
was
almost
imperative
on
her
to
take
the
one
or
the
other
.
<EOS>
Though
she
could
talk
about
remaining
unmarried
,
she
knew
that
that
was
practically
impossible
.
<EOS>
All
those
around
her
,
 
those
of
the
Baldock
as
well
as
those
of
the
Brentford
faction
,
 
would
make
such
a
life
impossible
to
her
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
in
such
a
case
what
could
she
do
?
<EOS>
It
was
all
very
well
to
talk
of
disregarding
the
world
and
of
setting
up
a
house
for
herself
;
 
but
she
was
quite
aware
that
that
project
could
not
be
used
further
than
for
the
purpose
of
scaring
her
amiable
aunt
.
<EOS>
And
if
not
that
,
 
then
could
she
content
herself
to
look
forward
to
a
joint
life
with
Lady
Baldock
and
Augusta
Boreham
?
<EOS>
She
might
,
of
course
,
oblige
her
aunt
by
taking
Lord
Fawn
,
or
oblige
her
aunt
equally
by
taking
Mr.
Appledom
;
but
she
was
strongly
of
opinion
that
either
Lord
Chiltern
or
Phineas
would
be
preferable
to
these
.
<EOS>
Thinking
over
it
always
she
had
come
to
feel
that
it
must
be
either
Lord
Chiltern
or
Phineas
;
but
she
had
never
whispered
her
thought
to
man
or
woman
.
<EOS>
On
her
journey
to
Loughlinter
,
where
she
then
knew
that
she
was
to
meet
Lord
Chiltern
,
she
endeavoured
to
persuade
herself
that
it
should
be
Phineas
.
<EOS>
But
Lady
Laura
had
marred
it
all
by
that
ill
-
told
fib
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
a
moment
before
in
which
Violet
had
felt
that
Phineas
had
sacrificed
something
of
that
truth
of
love
for
which
she
gave
him
credit
to
the
glances
of
Madame
Goesler
's
eyes
;
but
she
had
rebuked
herself
for
the
idea
,
accusing
herself
not
only
of
a
little
jealousy
,
but
of
foolish
vanity
.
<EOS>
Was
he
,
whom
she
had
rejected
,
not
to
speak
to
another
woman
?
<EOS>
Then
came
the
blow
from
Lady
Laura
,
and
Violet
knew
that
it
was
a
blow
.
<EOS>
This
gallant
lover
,
this
young
Crichton
,
this
unassuming
but
ardent
lover
,
had
simply
taken
up
with
her
as
soon
as
he
had
failed
with
her
friend
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
had
been
most
enthusiastic
in
her
expressions
of
friendship
.
<EOS>
Such
platonic
regards
might
be
all
very
well
.
<EOS>
It
was
for
Mr.
Kennedy
to
look
to
that
.
<EOS>
But
,
for
herself
,
she
felt
that
such
expressions
were
hardly
compatible
with
her
ideas
of
having
her
lover
all
to
herself
.
<EOS>
And
then
she
again
remembered
Madame
Goesler
's
bright
blue
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
came
on
Christmas
eve
,
and
was
received
with
open
arms
by
his
sister
,
and
with
that
painful
,
irritating
affection
which
such
a
girl
as
Violet
can
show
to
such
a
man
as
Lord
Chiltern
,
when
she
will
not
give
him
that
other
affection
for
which
his
heart
is
panting
.
<EOS>
The
two
men
were
civil
to
each
other
,
 
but
very
cold
.
<EOS>
They
called
each
other
Kennedy
and
Chiltern
,
but
even
that
was
not
done
without
an
effort
.
<EOS>
On
the
Christmas
morning
Mr.
Kennedy
asked
his
brother
-
in
-
law
to
go
to
church
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
kind
of
thing
I
never
do
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
gave
a
little
start
,
and
looked
a
look
of
horror
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
showed
that
she
was
unhappy
.
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
turned
away
her
face
,
and
smiled
.
  
<EOS>
As
they
walked
across
the
park
Violet
took
Lord
Chiltern
's
part
.
"
<EOS>
He
only
means
that
he
does
not
go
to
church
on
Christmas
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
he
means
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
need
not
speak
of
it
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
to
church
with
him
on
Sundays
myself
,
"
said
Violet
,
perhaps
not
reflecting
that
the
practices
of
early
years
had
little
to
do
with
the
young
man
's
life
at
present
.
  
<EOS>
Christmas
day
and
the
next
day
passed
without
any
sign
from
Lord
Chiltern
,
and
on
the
day
after
that
he
was
to
go
away
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
not
to
leave
till
one
or
two
in
the
afternoon
.
<EOS>
Not
a
word
had
been
said
between
the
two
women
,
since
he
had
been
in
the
house
,
on
the
subject
of
which
both
of
them
were
thinking
.
<EOS>
Very
much
had
been
said
of
the
expediency
of
his
going
to
Saulsby
,
but
on
this
matter
he
had
declined
to
make
any
promise
.
<EOS>
Sitting
in
Lady
Laura
's
room
,
in
the
presence
of
both
of
them
,
he
had
refused
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
bad
to
drive
,
"
he
said
,
turning
to
Violet
,
"
and
you
had
better
not
try
to
drive
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
not
you
be
driven
as
well
as
another
?
"
<EOS>
she
answered
,
laughing
.
   
<EOS>
The
First
Blow
 
Lord
Chiltern
,
though
he
had
passed
two
entire
days
in
the
house
with
Violet
without
renewing
his
suit
,
had
come
to
Loughlinter
for
the
express
purpose
of
doing
so
,
and
had
his
plans
perfectly
fixed
in
his
own
mind
.
<EOS>
After
breakfast
on
that
last
morning
he
was
up
-
stairs
with
his
sister
in
her
own
room
,
and
immediately
made
his
request
to
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Laura
,
"
he
said
,
"
go
down
like
a
good
girl
,
and
make
Violet
come
up
here
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
stood
a
moment
looking
at
him
and
smiled
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
mind
,
"
he
continued
,
"
you
are
not
to
come
back
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
must
have
Violet
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
suppose
Violet
will
not
come
?
<EOS>
Young
ladies
do
not
generally
wait
upon
young
men
on
such
occasions
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
but
I
rank
her
so
high
among
young
women
,
that
I
think
she
will
have
common
sense
enough
to
teach
her
that
,
after
what
has
passed
between
us
,
I
have
a
right
to
ask
for
an
interview
,
and
that
it
may
be
more
conveniently
had
here
than
in
the
wilderness
of
the
house
below
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Whatever
may
have
been
the
arguments
used
by
her
friend
,
Violet
did
come
.
<EOS>
She
reached
the
door
all
alone
,
and
opened
it
bravely
.
<EOS>
She
had
promised
herself
,
as
she
came
along
the
passages
,
that
she
would
not
pause
with
her
hand
on
the
lock
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
She
had
first
gone
to
her
own
room
,
and
as
she
left
it
<EOS>
she
had
looked
into
the
glass
with
a
hurried
glance
,
and
had
then
rested
for
a
moment
,
 
thinking
that
something
should
be
done
,
that
her
hair
might
be
smoothed
,
or
a
ribbon
set
straight
,
or
the
chain
arranged
under
her
brooch
.
<EOS>
A
girl
would
wish
to
look
well
before
her
lover
,
even
when
she
means
to
refuse
him
.
<EOS>
But
her
pause
was
but
for
an
instant
,
and
then
she
went
on
,
having
touched
nothing
.
<EOS>
She
shook
her
head
and
pressed
her
hands
together
,
and
went
on
quick
and
opened
the
door
,
 
almost
with
a
little
start
.
<EOS>
"
Violet
,
this
is
very
good
of
you
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
,
standing
with
his
back
to
the
fire
,
and
not
moving
from
the
spot
.
  
<EOS>
"
Laura
has
told
me
that
you
thought
I
would
do
as
much
as
this
for
you
,
and
therefore
I
have
done
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thanks
,
dearest
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
old
story
,
Violet
,
and
I
am
so
bad
at
words
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
have
been
bad
at
words
too
,
as
I
have
not
been
able
to
make
you
understand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
have
understood
.
<EOS>
You
are
always
clear
-
spoken
,
and
I
,
though
I
can
not
talk
,
am
not
muddle
-
pated
.
<EOS>
I
have
understood
.
<EOS>
But
while
you
are
single
there
must
be
yet
hope
;
 
unless
,
indeed
,
you
will
tell
me
that
you
have
already
given
yourself
to
another
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
done
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
how
can
I
not
hope
?
<EOS>
Violet
,
I
would
if
I
could
tell
you
all
my
feelings
plainly
.
<EOS>
Once
,
twice
,
thrice
,
I
have
said
to
myself
that
I
would
think
of
you
no
more
.
<EOS>
I
have
tried
to
persuade
myself
that
I
am
better
single
than
married
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
not
the
only
woman
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
me
you
are
,
 
absolutely
,
as
though
there
were
none
other
on
the
face
of
God
's
earth
.
<EOS>
I
live
much
alone
;
but
you
are
always
with
me
.
<EOS>
Should
you
marry
any
other
man
,
it
will
be
the
same
with
me
still
.
<EOS>
If
you
refuse
me
now
I
shall
go
away
,
 
and
live
wildly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oswald
,
what
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
that
I
will
go
to
some
distant
part
of
the
world
,
where
I
may
be
killed
or
live
a
life
of
adventure
.
<EOS>
But
I
shall
do
so
simply
in
despair
.
<EOS>
It
will
not
be
that
I
do
not
know
how
much
better
and
greater
should
be
the
life
at
home
of
a
man
in
my
position
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
do
not
talk
of
going
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
stay
.
<EOS>
You
will
acknowledge
,
Violet
,
that
I
have
never
lied
to
you
.
<EOS>
I
am
thinking
of
you
day
and
night
.
<EOS>
The
more
indifferent
you
show
yourself
to
me
,
the
more
I
love
you
.
<EOS>
Violet
,
try
to
love
me
.
"
<EOS>
He
came
up
to
her
,
and
took
her
by
both
her
hands
,
and
tears
were
in
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
Say
you
will
try
to
love
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
that
,
"
said
Violet
,
looking
away
,
but
still
leaving
her
hands
with
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
what
,
dear
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
you
call
,
 
trying
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
that
you
do
not
wish
to
try
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oswald
,
you
are
so
violent
,
so
headstrong
.
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
of
you
,
 
as
is
everybody
.
<EOS>
Why
have
you
not
written
to
your
father
,
as
we
have
asked
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
write
to
him
instantly
,
now
,
before
I
leave
the
room
,
and
you
shall
dictate
the
letter
to
him
.
<EOS>
By
heavens
,
you
shall
!
"
<EOS>
He
had
dropped
her
hands
when
she
called
him
violent
;
but
now
he
took
them
again
,
and
still
she
permitted
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
postponed
it
only
till
I
had
spoken
to
you
once
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Lord
Chiltern
,
I
will
not
dictate
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
will
you
love
me
?
"
<EOS>
She
paused
and
looked
down
,
having
even
now
not
withdrawn
her
hands
from
him
.
<EOS>
But
I
do
not
think
he
knew
how
much
he
had
gained
.
<EOS>
"
You
used
to
love
me
,
 
a
little
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
 
indeed
,
I
did
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
now
?
<EOS>
Is
it
all
changed
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
she
said
,
retreating
from
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
is
it
,
then
?
<EOS>
Violet
,
speak
to
me
honestly
.
<EOS>
Will
you
be
my
wife
?
<EOS>
"
She
did
not
answer
him
,
and
he
stood
for
a
moment
looking
at
her
.
<EOS>
Then
he
rushed
at
her
,
and
,
seizing
her
in
his
arms
,
kissed
her
all
over
,
 
her
forehead
,
her
lips
,
her
cheeks
,
then
both
her
hands
,
and
then
her
lips
again
.
"
<EOS>
By
G
 
,
she
is
my
own
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
<EOS>
Then
he
went
back
to
the
rug
before
the
fire
,
and
stood
there
with
his
back
turned
to
her
.
<EOS>
Violet
,
when
she
found
herself
thus
deserted
,
retreated
to
a
sofa
,
and
sat
herself
down
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
negative
to
produce
now
in
answer
to
the
violent
assertion
which
he
had
pronounced
as
to
his
own
success
.
<EOS>
It
was
true
.
<EOS>
She
had
doubted
,
and
doubted
,
 
and
still
doubted
.
<EOS>
But
now
she
must
doubt
no
longer
.
<EOS>
Of
one
thing
she
was
quite
sure
.
<EOS>
She
could
love
him
.
<EOS>
As
things
had
now
gone
,
she
would
make
him
quite
happy
with
assurances
on
that
subject
.
<EOS>
As
to
that
other
question
,
 
that
fearful
question
,
whether
or
not
she
could
trust
him
,
 
on
that
matter
she
had
better
at
present
say
nothing
,
and
think
as
little
,
perhaps
,
as
might
be
.
<EOS>
She
had
taken
the
jump
,
and
therefore
why
should
she
not
be
gracious
to
him
?
<EOS>
But
how
was
she
to
be
gracious
to
a
lover
who
stood
there
with
his
back
turned
to
her
?
  
<EOS>
After
the
interval
of
a
minute
or
two
he
remembered
himself
,
and
turned
round
.
<EOS>
Seeing
her
seated
,
he
approached
her
,
and
went
down
on
both
knees
close
at
her
feet
.
<EOS>
Then
he
took
her
hands
again
,
for
the
third
time
,
and
looked
up
into
her
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oswald
,
you
on
your
knees
!
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
bend
to
a
princess
,
"
he
said
,
"
to
ask
for
half
her
throne
;
but
I
will
kneel
here
all
day
,
if
you
will
let
me
,
in
thanks
for
the
gift
of
your
love
.
<EOS>
I
never
kneeled
to
beg
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
man
who
can
not
make
speeches
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
could
talk
now
by
the
hour
,
with
you
for
a
listener
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
I
must
talk
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
will
you
say
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
while
you
are
kneeling
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
natural
that
you
should
kneel
.
<EOS>
You
are
like
Samson
with
his
locks
shorn
,
or
Hercules
with
a
distaff
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
better
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
as
he
got
up
and
put
his
arm
round
her
waist
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
earnest
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
earnest
.
<EOS>
I
hardly
thought
that
that
would
be
doubted
.
<EOS>
Do
you
not
believe
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
believe
you
.
<EOS>
And
you
will
be
good
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
 
I
do
not
know
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Try
,
and
I
will
love
you
so
dearly
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
I
do
love
you
dearly
.
<EOS>
I
do
.
<EOS>
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Say
it
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
say
it
fifty
times
,
 
till
your
ears
are
weary
with
it
"
;
 
and
she
did
say
it
to
him
,
after
her
own
fashion
,
fifty
times
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
great
change
,
"
he
said
,
getting
up
after
a
while
and
walking
about
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
a
change
for
the
better
;
 
is
it
not
,
Oswald
?
"
  
"
So
much
for
the
better
that
I
hardly
know
myself
in
my
new
joy
.
<EOS>
But
,
Violet
,
we
'll
have
no
delay
,
 
will
we
?
<EOS>
No
shilly
-
shallying
.
<EOS>
What
is
the
use
of
waiting
now
that
it
's
settled
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
None
in
the
least
,
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
Let
us
say
,
 
this
day
twelvemonth
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
laughing
at
me
,
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Remember
,
sir
,
that
the
first
thing
you
have
to
do
is
to
write
to
your
father
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
instantly
went
to
the
writing
-
table
and
took
up
paper
and
pen
.
<EOS>
"
Come
along
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
to
dictate
it
.
"
<EOS>
But
this
she
refused
to
do
,
telling
him
that
he
must
write
his
letter
to
his
father
out
of
his
own
head
,
and
out
of
his
own
heart
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
write
it
,
"
he
said
,
throwing
down
the
pen
.
<EOS>
"
My
blood
is
in
such
a
tumult
that
I
can
not
steady
my
hand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
not
be
so
tumultuous
,
Oswald
,
or
I
shall
have
to
live
in
a
whirlwind
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
shall
shake
down
.
<EOS>
I
shall
become
as
steady
as
an
old
stager
.
<EOS>
I
'll
go
as
quiet
in
harness
by
-
and
-
by
as
though
I
had
been
broken
to
it
a
four
-
year
-
old
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
Laura
could
not
write
this
letter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
should
write
it
yourself
,
Oswald
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
bid
me
I
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bid
you
indeed
!
<EOS>
As
if
it
was
for
me
to
bid
you
.
<EOS>
Do
you
not
know
that
in
these
new
troubles
you
are
undertaking
you
will
have
to
bid
me
in
everything
,
and
that
I
shall
be
bound
to
do
your
bidding
?
<EOS>
Does
it
not
seem
to
be
dreadful
?
<EOS>
My
wonder
is
that
any
girl
can
ever
accept
any
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
have
accepted
me
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
indeed
.
"
  
"
And
you
repent
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
indeed
,
and
I
will
try
to
do
your
biddings
;
 
but
you
must
not
be
rough
to
me
,
and
outrageous
,
and
fierce
,
 
will
you
,
Oswald
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
at
any
rate
be
like
Kennedy
is
with
poor
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
that
is
not
your
nature
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
do
my
best
,
dearest
.
<EOS>
And
you
may
at
any
rate
be
sure
of
this
,
that
I
will
love
you
always
.
<EOS>
So
much
good
of
myself
,
if
it
be
good
,
I
can
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
good
,
"
she
answered
;
"
the
best
of
all
good
words
.
<EOS>
And
now
I
must
go
.
<EOS>
And
as
you
are
leaving
Loughlinter
I
will
say
good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
When
am
I
to
have
the
honour
and
felicity
of
beholding
your
lordship
again
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Say
a
nice
word
to
me
before
I
am
off
,
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
,
 
love
,
 
you
,
 
better
,
 
than
all
the
world
beside
;
and
I
mean
,
 
to
be
your
wife
,
 
some
day
.
<EOS>
Are
not
those
twenty
nice
words
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
would
not
prolong
his
stay
at
Loughlinter
,
though
he
was
asked
to
do
so
both
by
Violet
and
his
sister
,
and
though
,
as
he
confessed
himself
,
he
had
no
special
business
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
no
use
mincing
the
matter
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
Kennedy
,
and
I
do
n't
like
being
in
his
house
,
"
he
said
to
Violet
.
<EOS>
And
then
he
promised
that
there
should
be
a
party
got
up
at
Saulsby
before
the
winter
was
over
.
<EOS>
His
plan
was
to
stop
that
night
at
Carlisle
,
and
write
to
his
father
from
thence
.
"
<EOS>
Your
blood
,
perhaps
,
wo
n't
be
so
tumultuous
at
Carlisle
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
He
shook
his
head
and
went
on
with
his
plans
.
<EOS>
He
would
then
go
on
to
London
and
down
to
Willingford
,
and
there
wait
for
his
father
's
answer
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
reason
why
I
should
lose
more
of
the
hunting
than
necessary
.
"
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
lose
a
day
for
me
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
heard
from
his
father
,
he
would
do
his
father
's
bidding
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
go
to
Saulsby
,
"
said
Violet
;
"
you
can
hunt
at
Saulsby
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
to
Jericho
if
he
asks
me
,
only
you
will
have
to
go
with
me
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
thought
we
were
to
go
to
,
 
Belgium
,
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
that
is
settled
at
last
,
"
said
Violet
to
Laura
that
night
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
do
not
regret
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
On
the
contrary
,
I
am
as
happy
as
the
moments
are
long
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
fine
girl
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
happy
because
I
love
him
.
<EOS>
I
have
always
loved
him
.
<EOS>
You
have
known
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
no
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
,
after
my
fashion
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
tumultuous
,
as
he
calls
himself
.
<EOS>
Since
he
began
to
make
eyes
at
me
when
he
was
nineteen
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
Fancy
Oswald
making
eyes
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
he
did
,
and
mouths
too
.
<EOS>
But
from
the
beginning
,
when
I
was
a
child
,
I
have
known
that
he
was
dangerous
,
and
I
have
thought
that
he
would
pass
on
and
forget
me
after
a
while
.
<EOS>
And
I
could
have
lived
without
him
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
there
have
been
moments
when
I
thought
I
could
learn
to
love
some
one
else
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
Phineas
,
for
instance
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
will
mention
no
names
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Appledom
,
perhaps
,
more
likely
.
<EOS>
He
has
been
my
most
constant
lover
,
and
then
he
would
be
so
safe
!
<EOS>
Your
brother
,
Laura
,
is
dangerous
.
<EOS>
He
is
like
the
bad
ice
in
the
parks
where
they
stick
up
the
poles
.
<EOS>
He
has
had
a
pole
stuck
upon
him
ever
since
he
was
a
boy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
give
a
dog
a
bad
name
and
hang
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Remember
that
I
do
not
love
him
a
bit
the
less
on
that
account
;
 
perhaps
the
better
.
<EOS>
A
sense
of
danger
does
not
make
me
unhappy
,
though
the
threatened
evil
may
be
fatal
.
<EOS>
I
have
entered
myself
for
my
forlorn
hope
,
and
I
mean
to
stick
to
it
.
<EOS>
Now
I
must
go
and
write
to
his
worship
.
<EOS>
Only
think
,
 
I
never
wrote
a
love
-
letter
yet
!
"
  
<EOS>
Nothing
more
shall
be
said
about
Miss
Effingham
's
first
love
-
letter
,
which
was
,
no
doubt
,
creditable
to
her
head
and
heart
;
but
there
were
two
other
letters
sent
by
the
same
post
from
Loughlinter
which
shall
be
submitted
to
the
reader
,
as
they
will
assist
the
telling
of
the
story
.
<EOS>
One
was
from
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
to
her
friend
Phineas
Finn
,
and
the
other
from
Violet
to
her
aunt
,
Lady
Baldock
.
<EOS>
No
letter
was
written
to
Lord
Brentford
,
as
it
was
thought
desirable
that
he
should
receive
the
first
intimation
of
what
had
been
done
from
his
son
.
  
<EOS>
Respecting
the
letter
to
Phineas
,
which
shall
be
first
given
,
Lady
Laura
thought
it
right
to
say
a
word
to
her
husband
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
of
course
told
of
the
engagement
,
and
had
replied
that
he
could
have
wished
that
the
arrangement
could
have
been
made
elsewhere
than
at
his
house
,
knowing
as
he
did
that
Lady
Baldock
would
not
approve
of

.
<EOS>
To
this
Lady
Laura
had
made
no
reply
,
and
Mr.
Kennedy
had
condescended
to
congratulate
the
bride
-
elect
.
<EOS>
When
Lady
Laura
's
letter
to
Phineas
was
completed
she
took
care
to
put
it
into
the
letter
-
box
in
the

of
her

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
written
to
Mr.
Finn
,
"
she

,
"
to

of
this

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
was

necessary
that
he
should
be
told
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
was
due
to
him
,
 
from
certain
circumstances
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whether
there
was
any
truth
in
what
everybody
was
saying
about
their
fighting
a
duel
?
"
asked
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
His
wife
made
no
answer
,
and
then
he
continued
 
<EOS>
"
You
told

of
your
own
knowledge
that

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
of

own

,
Robert
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
of
your
own
knowledge
.
<EOS>
"
Then
Mr.
Kennedy
walked
away
,
and
was
certain
that
his
wife
had
deceived
him
about
the
duel
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
a
duel
,
and
she
had
known

;
and
yet
she
had
told
him
that
the
report
was
a

.
<EOS>
He
never
forgot
anything
.
<EOS>
He
remembered
at
this

the
words
of
the
falsehood
,
and
the
look
of
her

as

.
<EOS>
He
had
believed
her
implicitly
,
but
he
would
never
believe
her
again
.
<EOS>
He
was
one
of
those

who
,

experience
of
the

,

their

,
imagine
that
lips

have

never

.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
's

to

was
as

:
  
Loughlinter
,
December
28th
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
MY
DEAR
FRIEND
,
  
Violet
Effingham
is
here
,
and
Oswald
has
just

.
<EOS>
It

may
see

.
<EOS>
But
,

rate
,
I

best

that
she
has
accepted
him
,
 
at
last
.
<EOS>
If
there
be
any

in
this
to

,
be

that
I
will

.
<EOS>
You
will
not

to

that
I
regret

which
was
the

of
my
heart
before
I

.
<EOS>
Lately
,

,
I
have

.
<EOS>
You
will

what

,

I

need

;
 
except

,
that

among

that

may

that
may

to

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Your
most
sincere
friend
  
LAURA
KENNEDY
.
  
<EOS>
Even

should
read

,

.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
read

.
<EOS>
He
simply

as

its

,
and
inquired

,

,
that

'

.
  
<EOS>
And

's

to

:
    
MY
DEAR
AUNT
,
  
<EOS>
The
thing
has
come
at
last
,
and
all

will

soon

;
 
for
I

.
<EOS>
At

,

.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern

just

,

have

.
<EOS>
I

hardly

;

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

Lord

-

.
<EOS>
Tell

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
Your

,
  
VIOLET
EFFINGHAM
.
  
<EOS>
Loughlinter
,
Friday
.
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

would
 
joke
,

,
"

Lady
Baldock
.
   
<EOS>
Showing
How
Phineas
Bore
the
Blow
 
<EOS>
When
Phineas
received
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
's
letter
,
he
was
sitting
in
his
gorgeous
apartment
in
the
Colonial
Office
.
<EOS>
It
was
gorgeous
in
comparison
with
the
very
dingy
room
at
Mr.
Low
's
to
which
he
had
been
accustomed
in
his
early
days
,
 
and
somewhat
gorgeous
also
as
compared
with
the
lodgings
he
had
so
long
inhabited
in
Mr.
Bunce
's
house
.
<EOS>
The
room
was
large
and
square
,
and
looked
out
from
three
windows
on
to
St.
James
's
Park
.
<EOS>
There
were
in
it
two
very
comfortable
arm
-
chairs
and
a
comfortable
sofa
.
<EOS>
And
the
office
table
at
which
he
sat
was
of
old
mahogany
,
shining
brightly
,
and
seemed
to
be
fitted
up
with
every
possible
appliance
for
official
comfort
.
<EOS>
This
stood
near
one
of
the
windows
,
so
that
he
could
sit
and
look
down
upon
the
park
.
<EOS>
And
there
was
a
large
round
table
covered
with
books
and
newspapers
.
<EOS>
And
the
walls
of
the
room
were
bright
with
maps
of
all
the
colonies
.
<EOS>
And
there
was
one
very
interesting
map
,
 
but
not
very
bright
,
 
showing
the
American
colonies
,
as
they
used
to
be
.
<EOS>
And
there
was
a
little
inner
closet
in
which
he
could
brush
his
hair
and
wash
his
hands
;
and
in
the
room
adjoining
there
sat
,
 
or
ought
to
have
sat
,
for
he
was
often
absent
,
vexing
the
mind
of
Phineas
,
 
the
Earl
's
nephew
,
his
private
secretary
.
<EOS>
And
it
was
all
very
gorgeous
.
<EOS>
Often
as
he
looked
round
upon
it
,
thinking
of
his
old
bedroom
at
Killaloe
,
of
his
little
garrets
at
Trinity
,
of
the
dingy
chambers
in
Lincoln
's
Inn
,
he
would
tell
himself
that
it
was
very
gorgeous
.
<EOS>
He
would
wonder
that
anything
so
grand
had
fallen
to
his
lot
.
  
<EOS>
The
letter
from
Scotland
was
brought
to
him
in
the
afternoon
,
having
reached
London
by
some
day
-
mail
from
Glasgow
.
<EOS>
He
was
sitting
at
his

with
a
heap

papers
before
him
referring
to
a
contemplated
railway
from
Halifax
,
in
Nova
Scotia
,
to
the
foot
of
the
Rocky
Mountains
.
<EOS>
It
had
become
his
business
to
get
up
the
subject
,
and
then
discuss
with
his
principal
,
Lord
Cantrip
,
the

of
advising
the
Government
to
lend
a
company
five
million
of
money
,
in
order
that
this
railway
might
be
made
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
big
subject
,
and
the
contemplation
of
it
gratified
him
.
<EOS>
It
required
that
he
should
look
forward
to
great
events
,
and
exercise
the
wisdom
of
a
statesman
.
<EOS>
What
was
the
chance
of
these
colonies
being
swallowed
up
by
those
other
regions
,
 
once
colonies
,
 
of
which
the
map
that

?
<EOS>
And
if

,
would
the
five
million
ever

?
<EOS>
And
if
not

up
,
were
the

worth
so
great
an
adventure
of
national

?
<EOS>
Could
they
repay
it
?
<EOS>
Would
they
do
so
?
<EOS>
Should
they
be
made
to
do

?
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
,
who
was
now
a
Q.C.
and
in

,
would
not

greater
subjects
than
this
before

,
even
if
he
should

to
be

General
.
<EOS>
Lord
Cantrip
had
specially
asked
him
to
get
up
this
matter
,
 
and
he
was
getting
it
up
sedulously
.
<EOS>
Once
in
nine
years
the
harbour
of
Halifax
was
blocked
up
by
ice
.
<EOS>
He
had
just
jotted
down
the
fact
,
which
was
material
,
when
Lady
Laura
's
letter
was
brought

.
<EOS>
He
read
it
,
and
putting
it
down
by
his
side
very
gently
,
went
back
to
his
maps
as
though
the
thing
would
not
so
trouble
his
mind
as
to
disturb

work
.
<EOS>
He
absolutely
wrote
,
automatically
,
certain
words
of
a
note
about
the
harbour
,
after
he
had
received
the
information
.
<EOS>
A
horse
will
gallop
for
some
scores
of
yards
,
after
his
back
has
been
broken
,
before
he
knows
of
his
great

;
 
and
so
it
was
with
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
His
back
was
broken
,
but
,
nevertheless
,
he
galloped
,
for
a
yard
or
two
.
"
<EOS>
Closed
in
1860
-
61
for
thirteen
days
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
began
to
be
aware
that
his
back
was
broken
,
and
that
the
writing
of
any
more
notes
about
the
ice
in
Halifax
harbour
was
for
the
present
out
of

.
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
best
to
let
you

that
she
has
accepted
him
.
<EOS>
"
These
were
the
words
which
he
read
the
oftenest
.
<EOS>
Then
it
was
all
over
!
<EOS>
The
game
was
played
out
,
and
all
his
victories
were
as
nothing
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
sat
for
an
hour
in
his
gorgeous
room
thinking
of
it
,
and
various
were
the
answers
which
he
gave
during
the
time
to
various
messages
;
 
but
he
would
see
nobody
.
<EOS>
As
for
the
colonies
,
he
did
not
care
if
they
revolted
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
parted
with
every
colony
belonging
to
Great
Britain
to
have
gotten
the
hand
of
Violet
Effingham
for

.
<EOS>
Now
,
 
now
at
this
moment
,
he
told
himself
with
oaths
that
he
had
never
loved
any
one
but
Violet
Effingham
.
  
<EOS>
There
had
been
so
much
to
make
such
a
marriage
desirable
!
<EOS>
I
should
wrong
my
hero
<EOS>
deeply
were
I
to
say
that
the
weight
of
his
sorrow
was
occasioned
by
the
fact
that
he
had
lost
an
heiress
.
<EOS>
He
would
never
have
thought
of
looking
for
Violet
Effingham
<EOS>
had
he
not
first
learned
to
love
her
.
<EOS>
But
as
the
idea
opened
itself
out
to
him
,
everything
had
seemed
to
be
so
suitable
.
<EOS>
Had
Miss
Effingham
become
his
wife
,
the
mouths
of
the
Lows
and
of
the
Bunces
would
have
been
stopped
altogether
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
would
have
come
to
his
house
as
his
familiar
guest
,
and
he
would
have
been
connected
with
half
a
score
of
peers
.
<EOS>
A
seat
in
Parliament
would
be
simply
his
proper
place
,
and
even
Under
-
Secretaryships
of
State
might
soon
come
to
be
below
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
playing
a
great
game
,
but
hitherto
he
had
played
it
with
so
much
success
,
 
with
such
wonderful
luck
!
<EOS>
that
it
had
seemed
to
him
that
all
things
were
within
his
reach
.
<EOS>
Nothing
more
had
been
wanting
to
him
than
Violet
's
hand
for
his
own
comfort
,
and
Violet
's
fortune
to
support
his
position
;
and
these
,
too
,
had
almost
seemed
to
be
within
his
grasp
.
<EOS>
His
goddess
had
indeed
refused
him
,
 
but
not
with
disdain
.
<EOS>
Even
Lady
Laura
had
talked
of
his
marriage
as
not
improbable
.
<EOS>
All
the
world
,
almost
,
had
heard
of
the
duel
;
and
all
the
world
had
smiled
,
and
seemed
to
think
that
in
the
real
fight
Phineas
Finn
would
be
the
victor
,
 
that
the
lucky
pistol
was
in
his
hands
.
<EOS>
It
had
never
occurred
to
any
one
to
suppose
,
 
as
far
as
he
could
see
,
 
that
he
was
presuming
at
all
,
or
pushing
himself
out
of
his
own
sphere
,
in
asking
Violet
Effingham
to
be
his
wife
.
<EOS>
No
;
 
he
would
trust
his
luck
,
would
persevere
,
and
would
succeed
.
<EOS>
Such
had
been
his
resolution
on
that
very
morning
,
 
and
now
there
had
come
this
letter
to
dash
him
to
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
moments
in
which
he
declared
to
himself
that
he
would
not
believe
the
letter
,
 
not
that
there
was
any
moment
in
which
there
was
in
his
mind
the
slightest
spark
of
real
hope
.
<EOS>
But
he
would
tell
himself
that
he
would
still
persevere
.
<EOS>
Violet
might
have
been
driven
to
accept
that
violent
man
by
violent
influence
,
 
or
it
might
be
that
she
had
not
in
truth
accepted
him
,
that
Chiltern
had
simply
so
asserted
.
<EOS>
Or
,
even
if
it
were
so
,
did
women
never
change
their
minds
?
<EOS>
The
manly
thing
would
be
to
persevere
to
the
end
.
<EOS>
Had
he
not
before
been
successful
,
when
success
seemed
to
be
as
far
from
him
?
<EOS>
But
he
could
buoy
himself
up
with
no
real
hope
.
<EOS>
Even
when
these
ideas
were
present
to
his
mind
,
he
knew
,
 
he
knew
well
,
 
at
those
very
moments
,
that
his
back
was
broken
.
  
<EOS>
Some
one
had
come
in
and
lighted
the
candles
and
drawn
down
the
blinds
while
he
was
sitting
there
,
and
now
,
as
he
looked
at
his
watch
,
he
found
that
it
was
past
five
o'clock
.
<EOS>
He
was
engaged
to
dine
with
Madame
Max
Goesler
at
eight
,
and
in
his
agony
he
half
-
resolved
that
he
would
send
an
excuse
.
<EOS>
Madame
Max
would
be
full
of
wrath
,
as
she
was
very
particular
about
her
little
dinner
-
parties
;
 
but
,
what
did
he
care
now
about
the
wrath
of
Madame
Max
Goesler
?
<EOS>
And
yet
only
this
morning
he
had
been
congratulating
himself
,
among
his
other
successes
,
upon
her
favour
,
and
had
laughed
inwardly
at
his
own
falseness
,
 
his
falseness
to
Violet
Effingham
,
 
as
he
did
so
.
<EOS>
He
had
said
something
to
himself
jocosely
about
lovers
'
perjuries
,
the
remembrance
of
which
was
now
very
bitter
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
took
up
a
sheet
of
note
-
paper
and
scrawled
an
excuse
to
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
News
from
the
country
,
he
said
,
made
it
impossible
that
he
should
go
out
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
send
the
note
.
<EOS>
At
about
half
-
past
five
he
opened
the
door
of
his
private
secretary
's
room
and
found
the
young
man
fast
asleep
,
with
a
cigar
in
his
mouth
.
"
<EOS>
Halloa
,
Charles
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
All
right
!
"
<EOS>
Charles
Standish
was
a
first
cousin
of
Lady
Laura
's
,
and
,
having
been
in
the
office
before
Phineas
had
joined
it
,
and
being
a
great
favourite
with
his
cousin
,
had
of
course
become
the
Under
-
Secretary
's
private
secretary
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
all
here
,
"
said
Charles
Standish
,
getting
up
and
shaking
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
.
<EOS>
Just
tie
up
those
papers
,
 
exactly
as
they
are
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
here
early
to
-
morrow
,
but
I
sha
n't
want
you
before
twelve
.
<EOS>
Good
night
,
Charles
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ta
,
ta
,
"
said
his
private
secretary
,
who
was
very
fond
of
his
master
,
but
not
very
respectful
,
 
unless
upon
express
occasions
.
  
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
went
out
and
walked
across
the
park
;
but
as
he
went
he
became
quite
aware
that
his
back
was
broken
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
the
less
broken
because
he
sang
to
himself
little
songs
to
prove
to
himself
that
it
was
whole
and
sound
.
<EOS>
It
was
broken
,
and
it
seemed
to
him
now
that
he
never
could
become
an
Atlas
again
,
to
bear
the
weight
of
the
world
upon
his
shoulders
.
<EOS>
What
did
anything
signify
?
<EOS>
All
that
he
had
done
had
been
part
of
a
game
which
he
had
been
playing
throughout
,
and
now
he
had
been
beaten
in
his
game
.
<EOS>
He
absolutely
ignored
his
old
passion
for
Lady
Laura
as
though
it
had
never
been
,
and
regarded
himself
as
a
model
of
constancy
,
 
as
a
man
who
had
loved
,
not
wisely
perhaps
,
but
much
too
well
,
 
and
who
must
now
therefore
suffer
a
living
death
.
<EOS>
He
hated
Parliament
.
<EOS>
He
hated
the
Colonial
Office
.
<EOS>
He
hated
his
friend
Mr.
Monk
;
and
he
especially
hated
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
<EOS>
As
to
Lord
Chiltern
,
 
he
believed
that
Lord
Chiltern
had
obtained
his
object
by
violence
.
<EOS>
He
would
see
to
that
!
<EOS>
Yes
;
 
let
the
consequences
be
what
they
might
,
he
would
see
to
that
!
  
<EOS>
He
went
up
by
the
Duke
of
York
's
column
,
and
as
he
passed
the
Athenæum
he
saw
his
chief
,
Lord
Cantrip
,
standing
under
the
portico
talking
to
a
bishop
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
gone
on
unnoticed
,
had
it
been
possible
;
but
Lord
Cantrip
came
down
to
him
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
put
your
name
down
here
,
"
said
his
lordship
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
use
?
"
said
Phineas
,
who
was
profoundly
indifferent
at
this
moment
to
all
the
clubs
in
London
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
ca
n't
do
any
harm
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
You
'll
come
up
in
time
.
<EOS>
And
if
you
should
get
into
the
ministry
,
they
'll
let
you
in
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ministry
!
"
ejaculated
Phineas
.
<EOS>
But
Lord
Cantrip
took
the
tone
of
voice
as
simply
suggestive
of
humility
,
and
suspected
nothing
of
that
profound
indifference
to
all
ministers
and
ministerial
honours
which
Phineas
had
intended
to
express
.
<EOS>
"
By
-
the
-
bye
,
"
said
Lord
Cantrip
,
putting
his
arm
through
that
of
the
Under
-
Secretary
,
"
I
wanted
to
speak
to
you
about
the
guarantees
.
<EOS>
We
shall
be
in
the
devil
's
own
mess
,
you
know
 
<EOS>
"
And
so
the
Secretary
of
State
went
on
about
the
Rocky
Mountain
Railroad
,
and
Phineas
strove
hard
to
bear
his
burden
with
his
broken
back
.
<EOS>
He
was
obliged
to
say
something
about
the
guarantees
,
and
the
railway
,
and
the
frozen
harbour
,
 
and
something
especially
about
the
difficulties
which
would
be
found
,
not
in
the
measures
themselves
,
but
in
the
natural
pugnacity
of
the
Opposition
.
<EOS>
In
the
fabrication
of
garments
for
the
national
wear
,
the
great
thing
is
to
produce
garments
that
shall
,
as
far
as
possible
,
defy
hole
-
picking
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
,
and
sometimes
is
,
the
case
,
that
garments
so
fabricated
will
be
good
also
for
wear
.
<EOS>
Lord
Cantrip
,
at
the
present
moment
,
was
very
anxious
and
very
ingenious
in
the
stopping
of
holes
;
and
he
thought
that
perhaps
his
Under
-
Secretary
was
too
much
prone
to
the
indulgence
of
large
philanthropical
views
without
sufficient
thought
of
the
hole
-
pickers
.
<EOS>
But
on
this
occasion
,
by
the
time
that
he
reached
Brooks
's
,
he
had
been
enabled
to
convince
his
Under
-
Secretary
,
and
though
he
had
always
thought
well
of
his
Under
-
Secretary
,
he
thought
better
of
him
now
than
ever
he
had
done
.
<EOS>
Phineas
during
the
whole
time
had
been
meditating
what
he
could
do
to
Lord
Chiltern
when
they
two
should
meet
.
<EOS>
Could
he
take
him
by
the
throat
and
smite
him
?
<EOS>
"
I
happen
to
know
that
Broderick
is
working
as
hard
at
the
matter
as
we
are
,
"
said
Lord
Cantrip
,
stopping
opposite
to
the
club
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
moved
for
papers
,
you
know
,
at
the
end
of
last
session
.
"
<EOS>
Now
Mr.
Broderick
was
a
gentleman
in
the
House
looking
for
promotion
in
a
Conservative
Government
,
and
of
course
would
oppose
any
measure
that
could
be
brought
forward
by
the
Cantrip
-
Finn
Colonial
Administration
.
<EOS>
Then
Lord
Cantrip
slipped
into
the
club
,
and
Phineas
went
on
alone
.
  
<EOS>
A
spark
of
his
old
ambition
with
reference
to
Brooks
's
was
the
first
thing
to
make
him
forget
his
misery
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
He
had
asked
Lord
Brentford
to
put
his
name
down
,
and
was
not
sure
whether
it
had
been
done
.
<EOS>
The
threat
of
Mr.
Broderick
's
opposition
had
been
of
no
use
towards
the
strengthening
of
his
broken
back
,
but
the
sight
of
Lord
Cantrip
hurrying
in
at
the
coveted
door
did
do
something
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
man
ca
n't
cut
his
throat
or
blow
his
brains
out
,
"
he
said
to
himself
;
"
after
all
,
he
must
go
on
and
do
his
work
.
<EOS>
For
hearts
will
break
,
yet
brokenly
live
on
.
<EOS>
"
Thereupon
he
went
home
,
and
after
sitting
for
an
hour
over
his
own
fire
,
and
looking
wistfully
at
a
little
treasure
which
he
had
,
 
a
treasure
obtained
by
some
slight
fraud
at
Saulsby
,
and
which
he
now
chucked
into
the
fire
,
and
then
instantly
again
pulled
out
of
it
,
soiled
but
unscorched
,
 
<EOS>
he
dressed
himself
for
dinner
,
and
went
out
to
Madame
Max
Goesler
's
.
<EOS>
Upon
the
whole
,
he
was
glad
that
he
had
not
sent
the
note
of
excuse
.
<EOS>
A
man
must
live
,
even
though
his
heart
be
broken
,
and
living
he
must
dine
.
  
<EOS>
Madame
Max
Goesler
was
fond
of
giving
little
dinners
at
this
period
of
the
year
,
before
London
was
crowded
,
and
when
her
guests
might
probably
not
be
called
away
by
subsequent
social
arrangements
.
<EOS>
Her
number
seldom
exceeded
six
or
eight
,
and
she
always
spoke
of
these
entertainments
as
being
of
the
humblest
kind
.
<EOS>
She
sent
out
no
big
cards
.
<EOS>
She
preferred
to
catch
her
people
as
though
by
chance
,
when
that
was
possible
.
"
<EOS>
Dear
Mr.
Jones
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Smith
is
coming
to
tell
me
about
some
sherry
on
Tuesday
.
<EOS>
Will
you
come
and
tell
me
too
?
<EOS>
I
daresay
you
know
as
much
about
it
.
"
<EOS>
And
then
there
was
a
studious
absence
of
parade
.
<EOS>
The
dishes
were
not
very
numerous
.
<EOS>
The
bill
of
fare
was
simply
written
out
once
,
for
the
mistress
,
and
so
circulated
round
the
table
.
<EOS>
Not
a
word
about
the
things
to
be
eaten
or
the
things
to
be
drunk
was
ever
spoken
at
the
table
,
 
or
at
least
no
such
word
was
ever
spoken
by
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
they
who
knew
anything
about
dinners
were
aware
that
Madame
Goesler
gave
very
good
dinners
indeed
.
<EOS>
Phineas
Finn
was
beginning
to
flatter
himself
that
he
knew
something
about
dinners
,
and
had
been
heard
to
assert
that
the
soups
at
the
cottage
in
Park
Lane
were
not
to
be
beaten
in
London
.
<EOS>
But
he
cared
for
no
soup
to
-
day
,
as
he
slowly
made
his
way
up
Madame
Goesler
's
staircase
.
  
<EOS>
There
had
been
one
difficulty
in
the
way
of
Madame
Goesler
's
dinner
-
parties
which
had
required
some
patience
and
great
ingenuity
in
its
management
.
<EOS>
She
must
either
have
ladies
,
or
she
must
not
have
them
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
great
allurement
in
the
latter
alternative
;
but
she
knew
well
that
if
she
gave
way
to
it
,
all
prospect
of
general
society
would
for
her
be
closed
,
 
and
for
ever
.
<EOS>
This
had
been
in
the
early
days
of
her
widowhood
in
Park
Lane
.
<EOS>
She
cared
but
little
for
women
's
society
;
but
she
knew
well
that
the
society
of
gentlemen
without
women
would
not
be
that
which
she
desired
.
<EOS>
She
knew
also
that
she
might
as
effectually
crush
herself
and
all
her
aspirations
by
bringing
to
her
house
indifferent
women
,
 
women
lacking
something
either
in
character
,
or
in
position
,
or
in
talent
,
 
as
by
having
none
at
all
.
<EOS>
Thus
there
had
been
a
great
difficulty
,
and
sometimes
she
had
thought
that
the
thing
could
not
be
done
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
These
English
are
so
stiff
,
so
hard
,
so
heavy
!
"
<EOS>
And
yet
she
would
not
have
cared
to
succeed
elsewhere
than
among
the
English
.
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
however
,
the
thing
was
done
.
<EOS>
Her
prudence
equalled
her
wit
,
and
even
suspicious
people
had
come
to
acknowledge
that
they
could
not
put
their
fingers
on
anything
wrong
.
<EOS>
When
Lady
Glencora
Palliser
had
once
dined
at
the
cottage
in
Park
Lane
,
Madame
Max
Goesler
had
told
herself
that
henceforth
she
did
not
care
what
the
suspicious
people
said
.
<EOS>
Since
that
the
Duke
of
Omnium
had
almost
promised
that
he
would
come
.
<EOS>
If
she
could
only
entertain
the
Duke
of
Omnium
she
would
have
done
everything
.
  
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
Duke
of
Omnium
there
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
At
this
time
the
Duke
of
Omnium
was
,
of
course
,
not
in
London
.
<EOS>
But
Lord
Fawn
was
there
;
and
our
old
friend
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
,
who
had
 
resigned
his
place
at
the
Colonial
Office
;
and
there
were
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
They
,
with
our
hero
,
made
up
the
party
.
<EOS>
No
one
doubted
for
a
moment
to
what
source
Mr.
Bonteen
owed
his
dinner
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bonteen
was
good
-
looking
,
could
talk
,
was
sufficiently
proper
,
and
all
that
kind
of
thing
,
 
and
did
as
well
as
any
other
woman
at
this
time
of
year
to
keep
Madame
Max
Goesler
in
countenance
.
<EOS>
There
was
never
any
sitting
after
dinner
at
the
cottage
;
or
,
I
should
rather
say
,
there
was
never
any
sitting
after
Madame
Goesler
went
;
so
that
the
two
ladies
could
not
weary
each
other
by
being
alone
together
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bonteen
understood
quite
well
that
she
was
not
required
there
to
talk
to
her
hostess
,
and
was
as
willing
as
any
woman
to
make
herself
agreeable
to
the
gentlemen
she
might
meet
at
Madame
Goesler
's
table
.
<EOS>
And
thus
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Bonteen
not
unfrequently
dined
in
Park
Lane
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
we
have
only
to
wait
for
that
horrible
man
,
Mr.
Fitzgibbon
,
"
said
Madame
Max
Goesler
,
as
she
welcomed
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
always
late
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
blow
for
me
!
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
 
you
are
always
in
good
time
.
<EOS>
But
there
is
a
limit
beyond
which
good
time
ends
,
and
being
shamefully
late
at
once
begins
.
<EOS>
But
here
he
is
.
"
<EOS>
And
then
,
as
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
entered
the
room
,
Madame
Goesler
rang
the
bell
for
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
found
himself
placed
between
his
hostess
and
Mr.
Bonteen
,
and
Lord
Fawn
was
on
the
other
side
of
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
They
were
hardly
seated
at
the
table
before
some
one
stated
it
as
a
fact
that
Lord
Brentford
and
his
son
were
reconciled
.
<EOS>
Now
Phineas
knew
,
or
thought
that
he
knew
,
that
this
could
not
as
yet
be
the
case
;
and
indeed
such
was
not
the
case
,
though
the
father
had
already
received
the
son
's
letter
.
<EOS>
But
Phineas
did
not
choose
to
say
anything
at
present
about
Lord
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
odd
it
is
,
"
said
Madame
Goesler
;
"
how
often
you
English
fathers
quarrel
with
your
sons
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
often
we
English
sons
quarrel
with
our
fathers
rather
,
"
said
Lord
Fawn
,
who
was
known
for
the
respect
he
had
always
paid
to
the
fifth
commandment
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
all
comes
from
entail
and
primogeniture
,
and
old
-
fashioned
English
prejudices
of
that
kind
,
"
said
Madame
Goesler
.
"
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
is
a
friend
of
yours
,
Mr.
Finn
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
are
both
friends
of
mine
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
yes
;
but
you
,
 
you
,
 
you
and
Lord
Chiltern
once
did
something
odd
together
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
little
mystery
,
was
there
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
little
of
a
mystery
now
,
"
said
Fitzgibbon
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
about
a
lady
;
 
was
it
not
?
"
said
Mrs.
Bonteen
,
affecting
to
whisper
to
her
neighbour
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
at
liberty
to
say
anything
on
the
subject
,
"
said
Fitzgibbon
;
"
but
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
Phineas
will
tell
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
this
about
Lord
Brentford
,
"
said
Mr.
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
"
I
happen
to
know
that
Chiltern
was
down
at
Loughlinter
three
days
ago
,
and
that
he
passed
through
London
yesterday
on
his
way
to
the
place
where
he
hunts
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
is
at
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
gone
to
Saulsby
if
it
were
true
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
all
depends
upon
whether
Miss
Effingham
will
accept
him
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bonteen
,
looking
over
at
Phineas
as
she
spoke
.
  
<EOS>
As
there
were
two
of
Violet
Effingham
's
suitors
at
table
,
the
subject
was
becoming
disagreeably
personal
;
and
the
more
so
,
as
every
one
of
the
party
knew
or
surmised
something
of
the
facts
of
the
case
.
<EOS>
The
cause
of
the
duel
at
Blankenberg
had
become
almost
as
public
as
the
duel
,
and
Lord
Fawn
's
courtship
had
not
been
altogether
hidden
from
the
public
eye
.
<EOS>
He
on
the
present
occasion
might
probably
be
able
to
carry
himself
better
than
Phineas
,
even
presuming
him
to
be
equally
eager
in
his
love
,
 
for
he
knew
nothing
of
the
fatal
truth
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
unable
to
hear
Mrs.
Bonteen
's
statement
with
indifference
,
and
showed
his
concern
in
the
matter
by
his
reply
.
<EOS>
"
Any
lady
will
be
much
to
be
pitied
,
"
he
said
,
"
who
does
that
.
<EOS>
Chiltern
is
the
last
man
in
the
world
to
whom
I
would
wish
to
trust
the
happiness
of
a
woman
for
whom
I
cared
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Chiltern
is
a
very
good
fellow
,
"
said
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Just
a
little
wild
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
never
had
a
shilling
in
his
pocket
in
his
life
,
"
said
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
regard
him
as
simply
a
madman
,
"
said
Lord
Fawn
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
so
wish
I
knew
him
,
"
said
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
fond
of
madmen
,
and
men
who
have
n't
shillings
,
and
who
are
a
little
wild
,
Could
you
not
bring
him
here
,
Mr.
Finn
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
did
not
know
what
to
say
,
or
how
to
open
his
mouth
without
showing
his
deep
concern
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
happy
to
ask
him
if
you
wish
it
,
"
he
replied
,
as
though
the
question
had
been
put
to
him
in
earnest
;
"
but
I
do
not
see
so
much
of
Lord
Chiltern
as
I
used
to
do
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
believe
that
Violet
Effingham
will
accept
him
?
"
asked
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
He
paused
a
moment
before
he
spoke
,
and
then
made
his
answer
in
a
deep
solemn
voice
,
 
with
a
seriousness
which
he
was
unable
to
repress
.
<EOS>
"
She
has
accepted
him
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
that
you
know
it
?
"
said
Madame
Goesler
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
I
mean
that
I
know
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Had
anybody
told
him
beforehand
that
he
would
openly
make
this
declaration
at
Madame
Goesler
's
table
,
he
would
have
said
that
of
all
things
it
was
the
most
impossible
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
declared
that
nothing
would
have
induced
him
to
speak
of
Violet
Effingham
in
his
existing
frame
of
mind
,
and
that
he
would
have
had
his
tongue
cut
out
before
he
spoke
of
her
as
the
promised
bride
of
his
rival
.
<EOS>
And
now
he
had
declared
the
whole
truth
of
his
own
wretchedness
and
discomfiture
.
<EOS>
He
was
well
aware
that
all
of
them
there
knew
why
he
had
fought
the
duel
at
Blankenberg
;
 
<EOS>
all
,
that
is
,
except
perhaps
Lord
Fawn
.
<EOS>
And
he
felt
as
he
made
the
statement
as
to
Lord
Chiltern
that
he
blushed
up
to
his
forehead
,
and
that
his
voice
was
strange
,
and
that
he
was
telling
the
tale
of
his
own
disgrace
.
<EOS>
But
when
the
direct
question
had
been
asked
him
he
had
been
unable
to
refrain
from
answering
it
directly
.
<EOS>
He
had
thought
of
turning
it
off
with
some
jest
or
affectation
of
drollery
,
but
had
failed
.
<EOS>
At
the
moment
he
had
been
unable
not
to
speak
the
truth
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
a
word
of
it
,
"
said
Lord
Fawn
,
 
who
also
forgot
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
believe
it
,
if
Mr.
Finn
says
so
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bonteen
,
who
rather
liked
the
confusion
she
had
caused
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
who
could
have
told
you
,
Finn
?
"
asked
Mr.
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
"
His
sister
,
Lady
Laura
,
told
me
so
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
it
must
be
true
,
"
said
Madame
Goesler
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
quite
impossible
,
"
said
Lord
Fawn
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
may
say
that
I
know
that
it
is
impossible
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
so
,
it
would
be
a
most
shameful
arrangement
.
<EOS>
Every
shilling
she
has
in
the
world
would
be
swallowed
up
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
Lord
Fawn
in
making
his
proposals
had
been
magnanimous
in
his
offers
as
to
settlements
and
pecuniary
provisions
generally
.
  
<EOS>
For
some
minutes
after
that
Phineas
did
not
speak
another
word
,
and
the
conversation
generally
was
not
so
brisk
and
bright
as
it
was
expected
to
be
at
Madame
Goesler
's
.
<EOS>
Madame
Max
Goesler
herself
thoroughly
understood
our
hero
's
position
,
and
felt
for
him
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
encouraged
no
questionings
about
Violet
Effingham
<EOS>
had
she
thought
that
they
would
have
led
to
such
a
result
,
and
now
she
exerted
herself
to
turn
the
minds
of
her
guests
to
other
subjects
.
<EOS>
At
last
she
succeeded
;
and
after
a
while
,
too
,
Phineas
himself
was
able
to
talk
.
<EOS>
He
drank
two
or
three
glasses
of
wine
,
and
dashed
away
into
politics
,
taking
the
earliest
opportunity
in
his
power
of
contradicting
Lord
Fawn
very
plainly
on
one
or
two
matters
.
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
was
of
course
of
opinion
that
the
ministry
could
not
stay
in
long
.
<EOS>
Since
he
had
left
the
Government
the
ministers
had
made
wonderful
mistakes
,
and
he
spoke
of
them
quite
as
an
enemy
might
speak
.
"
<EOS>
And
yet
,
Fitz
,
"
said
Mr.
Bonteen
,
"
you
used
to
be
so
staunch
a
supporter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
the
error
of
my
way
,
I
can
assure
you
,
"
said
Laurence
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
always
observe
,
"
said
Madame
Max
Goesler
,
"
that
when
any
of
you
gentlemen
resign
,
 
which
you
usually
do
on
some
very
trivial
matter
,
 
the
resigning
gentleman
becomes
of
all
foes
the
bitterest
.
<EOS>
Somebody
goes
on
very
well
with
his
friends
,
agreeing
most
cordially
about
everything
,
till
he
finds
that
his
public
virtue
can
not
swallow
some
little
detail
,
and
then
he
resigns
.
<EOS>
Or
some
one
,
perhaps
,
on
the
other
side
has
attacked
him
,
and
in
the
mêlée
he
is
hurt
,
and
so
he
resigns
.
<EOS>
But
when
he
has
resigned
,
and
made
his
parting
speech
full
of
love
and
gratitude
,
I
know
well
after
that
where
to
look
for
the
bitterest
hostility
to
his
late
friends
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
am
beginning
to
understand
the
way
in
which
politics
are
done
in
England
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
All
this
was
rather
severe
upon
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
;
but
he
was
a
man
of
the
world
,
and
bore
it
better
than
Phineas
had
borne
his
defeat
.
  
<EOS>
The
dinner
,
taken
altogether
,
was
not
a
success
,
and
so
Madame
Goesler
understood
.
<EOS>
Lord
Fawn
,
after
he
had
been
contradicted
by
Phineas
,
hardly
opened
his
mouth
.
<EOS>
Phineas
himself
talked
rather
too
much
and
rather
too
loudly
;
and
Mrs.
Bonteen
,
who
was
well
enough
inclined
to
flatter
Lord
Fawn
,
contradicted
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
made
a
mistake
,
"
said
Madame
Goesler
afterwards
,
"
in
having
four
members
of
Parliament
who
all
of
them
were
or
had
been
in
office
.
<EOS>
I
never
will
have
two
men
in
office
together
again
.
<EOS>
"
This
she
said
to
Mrs.
Bonteen
.
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Madame
Max
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bonteen
,
"
your
resolution
ought
to
be
that
you
will
never
again
have
two
claimants
for
the
same
young
lady
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
the
drawing
-
room
up
-
stairs
Madame
Goesler
managed
to
be
alone
for
three
minutes
with
Phineas
Finn
.
"
<EOS>
And
it
is
as
you
say
,
my
friend
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
.
<EOS>
Her
voice
was
plaintive
and
soft
,
and
there
was
a
look
of
real
sympathy
in
her
eyes
.
<EOS>
Phineas
almost
felt
that
if
they
two
had
been
quite
alone
he
could
have
told
her
everything
,
and
have
wept
at
her
feet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
he
said
,
"
it
is
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
doubted
it
when
you
had
declared
it
.
<EOS>
May
I
venture
to
say
that
I
wish
it
had
been
otherwise
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
too
late
now
,
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
A
man
of
course
is
a
fool
to
show
that
he
has
any
feelings
in
such
a
matter
.
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
I
heard
it
just
before
I
came
here
,
and
had
made
up
my
mind
to
send
you
an
excuse
.
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
say
that
,
Mr.
Finn
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
made
such
an
ass
of
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
my
estimation
you
have
done
yourself
honour
.
<EOS>
But
if
I
may
venture
to
give
you
counsel
,
do
not
speak
of
this
affair
again
as
though
you
had
been
personally
concerned
in
it
.
<EOS>
In
the
world
now
-
a
-
days
the
only
thing
disgraceful
is
to
admit
a
failure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
have
failed
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
need
not
admit
it
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
I
know
I
ought
not
to
say
as
much
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
,
rather
,
am
deeply
indebted
to
you
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
now
,
Madame
Goesler
,
as
I
do
not
wish
to
leave
the
house
with
Lord
Fawn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
come
and
see
me
soon
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
promised
that
he
would
come
soon
;
and
felt
as
he
made
the
promise
that
he
would
have
an
opportunity
of
talking
over
his
love
with
his
new
friend
at
any
rate
without
fresh
shame
as
to
his
failure
.
  
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
went
away
with
Phineas
,
and
Mr.
Bonteen
,
having
sent
his
wife
away
by
herself
,
walked
off
towards
the
clubs
with
Lord
Fawn
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
anxious
to
have
a
few
words
with
Lord
Fawn
.
<EOS>
Lord
Fawn
had
evidently
been
annoyed
by
Phineas
,
and
Mr.
Bonteen
did
not
at
all
love
the
young
Under
-
Secretary
.
<EOS>
"
That
fellow
has
become
the
most
consummate
puppy
I
ever
met
,
"
said
he
,
as
he
linked
himself
on
to
the
lord
,
"
Monk
,
and
one
or
two
others
among
them
,
have
contrived
to
spoil
him
altogether
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
a
word
of
what
he
said
about
Lord
Chiltern
,
"
said
Lord
Fawn
.
  
<EOS>
"
About
his
marriage
with
Miss
Effingham
?
"
  
"
It
would
be
such
an
abominable
shame
to
sacrifice
the
girl
,
"
said
Lord
Fawn
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Only
think
of
it
.
<EOS>
Everything
is
gone
.
<EOS>
The
man
is
a
drunkard
,
and
I
do
n't
believe
he
is
any
more
reconciled
to
his
father
than
you
are
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
must
have
had
some
object
in
saying
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Perhaps
an
invention
of
Finn
's
altogether
,
"
said
Mr.
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
"
Those
Irish
fellows
are
just
the
men
for
that
kind
of
thing
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
man
,
you
know
,
so
violent
that
nobody
can
hold
him
,
"
said
Lord
Fawn
,
thinking
of
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
so
absurdly
conceited
,
"
said
Mr.
Bonteen
,
thinking
of
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
man
who
has
never
done
anything
,
with
all
his
advantages
in
the
world
,
 
and
never
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
wo
n't
hold
his
place
long
,
"
said
Mr.
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
"
Whom
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
I
was
talking
of
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
I
believe
Finn
to
be
a
very

,

undoubtedly

.
<EOS>
They
say

likes

.
<EOS>
He
'll
do
very

.
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't

about
