.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Bonteen
felt
himself
to
be
snubbed
,
and
soon
afterwards
left
Lord
Fawn
alone
.
   
<EOS>
Consolation
 
<EOS>
On
the
day
following
Madame
Goesler
's
dinner
party
,
Phineas
,
though
he
was
early
at
his
office
,
was
not
able
to
do
much
work
,
still
feeling
that
as
regarded
the
realities
of
the
world
,
his
back
was
broken
.
<EOS>
He
might
no
doubt
go
on
learning
,
and
,
after
a
time
,
might
be
able
to
exert
himself
in
a
perhaps
useful
,
but
altogether
uninteresting
kind
of
way
,
doing
his
work
simply
because
it
was
there
to
be
done
,
 
as
the
carter
or
the
tailor
does
his
;
 
and
from
the
same
cause
,
knowing
that
a
man
must
have
bread
to
live
.
<EOS>
But
as
for
ambition
,
and
the
idea
of
doing
good
,
and
the
love
of
work
for
work
's
sake
,
 
as
for
the
elastic
springs
of
delicious
and
beneficent
labour
,
 
all
that
was
over
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
worked
from
day
till
night
,
and
from
night
till
day
,
and
from
month
till
month
throughout
the
year
to
have
secured
for
Violet
Effingham
the
assurance
that
her
husband
's
position
was
worthy
of
her
own
.
<EOS>
But
now
he
had
no
motive
for
such
work
as
this
.
<EOS>
As
long
as
he
took
the
public
pay
,
he
would
earn
it
;
and
that
was
all
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
next
day
things
were
a
little
better
with
him
.
<EOS>
He
received
a
note
in
the
morning
from
Lord
Cantrip
saying
that
they
two
were
to
see
the
Prime
Minister
that
evening
,
in
order
that
the
whole
question
of
the
railway
to
the
Rocky
Mountains
might
be
understood
,
and
Phineas
was
driven
to
his
work
.
<EOS>
Before
the
time
of
the
meeting
came
he
had
once
more
lost
his
own
identity
in
great
ideas
of
colonial
welfare
,
and
had
planned
and
peopled
a
mighty
region
on
the
Red
River
,
which
should
have
no
sympathy
with
American
democracy
.
<EOS>
When
he
waited
upon
Mr.
Gresham
in
the
afternoon
he
said
nothing
about
the
mighty
region
;
indeed
,
he
left
it
to
Lord
Cantrip
to
explain
most
of
the
proposed
arrangements
,
 
speaking
only
a
word
or
two
here
<EOS>
and
there
as
occasion
required
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
aware
that
he
had
so
far
recovered
as
to
be
able
to
save
himself
from
losing
ground
during
the
interview
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
about
the
first
Irishman
we
've
had
that
has
been
worth
his
salt
,
"
said
Mr.
Gresham
to
his
colleague
afterwards
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
other
Irishman
was
a
terrible
fellow
,
"
said
Lord
Cantrip
,
shaking
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
fourth
day
after
his
sorrow
had
befallen
him
,
Phineas
went
again
to
the
cottage
in
Park
Lane
.
<EOS>
And
in
order
that
he
might
not
be
balked
in
his
search
for
sympathy
he
wrote
a
line
to
Madame
Goesler
to
ask
if
she
would
be
at
home
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
be
at
home
from
five
to
six
,
 
and
alone
.
 
<EOS>
M.
M.
G.
"
<EOS>
That
was
the
answer
from
Marie
Max
Goesler
,
and
Phineas
was
of
course
at
the
cottage
a
few
minutes
after
five
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
,
I
think
,
surprising
that
a
man
when
he
wants
sympathy
in
such
a
calamity
as
that
which
had
now
befallen
Phineas
Finn
,
should
seek
it
from
a
woman
.
<EOS>
Women
sympathise
most
effectually
with
men
,
as
men
do
with
women
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
,
perhaps
,
a
little
odd
that
a
man
when
he
wants
consolation
because
his
heart
has
been
broken
,
always
likes
to
receive
it
from
a
pretty
woman
.
<EOS>
One
would
be
disposed
to
think
that
at
such
a
moment
he
would
be
profoundly
indifferent
to
such
a
matter
,
that
no
delight
could
come
to
him
from
female
beauty
,
and
that
all
he
would
want
would
be
the
softness
of
a
simply
sympathetic
soul
.
<EOS>
But
he
generally
wants
a
soft
hand
as
well
,
and
an
eye
that
can
be
bright
behind
the
mutual
tear
,
and
lips
that
shall
be
young
and
fresh
as
they
express
their
concern
for
his
sorrow
.
<EOS>
All
these
things
were
added
to
Phineas
when
he
went
to
Madame
Goesler
in
his
grief
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
glad
to
see
you
,
"
said
Madame
Max
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
-
natured
to
let
me
come
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
but
<EOS>
it
is
so
good
of
you
to
trust
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
was
sure
you
would
come
after
what
took
place
the
other
night
.
<EOS>
I
saw
that
you
were
pained
,
and
I
was
so
sorry
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
made
such
a
fool
of
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
at
all
.
<EOS>
And
I
thought
that
you
were
right
to
tell
them
when
the
question
had
been
asked
.
<EOS>
If
the
thing
was
not
to
be
kept
a
secret
,
it
was
better
to
speak
it
out
.
<EOS>
You
will
get
over
it
quicker
in
that
way
than
in
any
other
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
seen
the
young
lord
,
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
there
is
nothing
amiss
about
him
.
<EOS>
As
to
what
Lord
Fawn
said
,
the
half
of
it
is
simply

,
and
the

is

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
this
country
it
is
so
much

lord
,
"
said
Madame
Goesler
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
thought
a
moment
of
that
matter
before
he
replied
.
<EOS>
All
the
Standish
family
had
been
very
good
to
him
,
and
Violet
Effingham
had
been
very
good
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
the
fault
of
any
of
them
that
he
was
now
wretched
and
back
-
broken
.
<EOS>
He
had
meditated
much
on
this
,
and
had
resolved
that
he
would
not
even
think
evil
of
them
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
in
my
heart
believe
that
that
has
had
anything
to
do

,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
has
,
my
friend
,
 
always
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
your
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
not
mine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;
 
I
do
not
know
this
Violet
that
is
not
yours
.
<EOS>
I
have
met
her
,
and
did
not
specially
admire
her
.
<EOS>
But
then
the
tastes
of
men
and
women
about
beauty
are
never
the
same
.
<EOS>
But
I
know
she
is
one
that
always
lives
with
lords
and
countesses
.
<EOS>
A
girl
who
always
lived
with
countesses
feels
it
to
be
hard
to
settle
down
as
a
plain
Mistress
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
had
plenty
of
choice
among
all
sorts
of
men
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
the
title
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
have
accepted
Chiltern
unless
she
had
 
.
<EOS>
But
what
is
the
use
of
talking
of
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
had
known
each
other
long
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
 
as
children
.
<EOS>
And
the
Earl
desired
it
of
all
things
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
;
 
then
he
arranged

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not

.
<EOS>
Nobody
could

anything
for
Chiltern
,
 
nor
,

far

that

,

Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
They
arranged
it
themselves
,
I
fancy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
had
asked
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
twice
.
<EOS>
And
she
had
refused
him
more
than
twice
.
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
for
which
to
blame

;
but
yet
I
had
thought
,
 
I
had
thought
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
She
is
a
jilt
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
I
will
not
let
you
say
that
of
her
.
<EOS>
She
is
no
jilt
.
<EOS>
But
I
think
she
has
been
strangely
ignorant
of
her
own
mind
.
<EOS>
What
is
the
use
of
talking
of
it
,
Madame
Goesler
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
None
;
 
<EOS>
only
sometimes
it
is
better
to
speak
a
word
,
than
to
keep
one
's
sorrow
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
it
is
;
 
and
there
is
not
one
in
the

to
whom
I
can
speak
such
a
word
,
except
yourself
.
<EOS>
Is
not
that
odd
?
<EOS>
I
have
sisters
,
but
they
have
never
heard
of
Miss
Effingham
,
and
would
be
quite
indifferent
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
they
have
some
other

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
;
 
well
.
<EOS>
That
does
not
matter
,
And
my
best
friend
here
in
London
is
Lord
Chiltern
's
own

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
knew
of
your
attachment
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

.
"
  
"
And

of
Miss
Effingham
's

.
<EOS>
Was

it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
always
desired
the

.
<EOS>
And
yet
I
think
she
would
have
been
satisfied
had
it

.
<EOS>
But

her
heart
must
be

.
<EOS>
I

to

Blankenberg

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
for
the
best
,

.
<EOS>
Everybody
says
you
behaved
so
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
but
go
,
as
things
were
then
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
if
you
had
 
shot
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

an

.
<EOS>
She

after

.
<EOS>
Indeed

should
have
shot

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
;
 
you
English

.
<EOS>
But

best
not

a
man
.
<EOS>
And
,
Mr.
Finn
,
there
are
other

prettier
than
Miss
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
No
;
 
of

will

now
.
<EOS>
Just

,
and

,
she

,

to
be
of
all

most

.
<EOS>
But
you
have
the
ball
at
your
feet
.
<EOS>
I
know
no
one
so
young
who
has
got
the
ball
at
his
feet
so
well
.
<EOS>
I
call
it
nothing
to
have
the
ball
at
your
feet
if
you
are
born
with
it
there
.
<EOS>
It
is
so
easy
to
be
a
lord
if
your
father
is
one
before
you
,
 
and
so
easy
to
marry
a
pretty
girl
if
you
can
make
her
a

.
<EOS>
But
to
make

lord
,
or
to
be
as
good
as
a
lord
,
when
nothing
has
been
born
to
you
,
 
that
I
call
very
much
.
<EOS>
And
there
are
women
,
and
pretty
women
too
,
Mr.
Finn
,
who
have
spirit
enough
to
understand
this
,
and
to
think
that
the
man
,

all
,
is
more
important
than
the
lord
.
"
<EOS>
Then
she
sang

old
well
-

of
the
Scotch
song
with

,
and
with
a

and

hitherto

.

"
A

mak

,

,

,

a
'
that
;
But

's

his
might
,
Guid
faith
<EOS>
he
mauna

'

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,
 
"
A

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"
There

in
Scotland
more
lovely
by
far
,
Who
would
gladly
be
bride
to
the
young
Lochinvar
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
young
Lochinvar
got
his
bride
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Take
the
spirit
of
the
lines
,
Mr.
Finn
,
which
is
true
;
and
not
the
tale
as
it
is

,

is

.
<EOS>
I
often

that
Jock
of

,

,
probably
lived
to

.
<EOS>
We

Chiltern
may

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

all

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
You

at

,
and
no

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
And

look

,

I

Mrs.
Bonteen

.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
.
"
<EOS>
She

him
her

,
which
was
very

,
and
left

for

his
,
and
he

.
  
<EOS>
Madame
Goesler
,
when
she
was
alone
,
threw
herself
on
to
her
chair
and
began
to
think
of
things
.
<EOS>
In
these
days
she
would
often
ask
herself
what
in
truth
was
the
object
of
her
ambition
,
and
the
aim
of
her
life
.
<EOS>
Now
at
this
moment
she
had
in
her

a
note
from
the
Duke
of
Omnium
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
had
allowed
himself
to
say
something
about
a
photograph
,
which
had
justified
her
in
writing

him
,
 
or
which
she

taken
for
such

.
<EOS>
And
the
Duke
had

.
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"

,
 
but

?
<EOS>
What
was

definite

,
 
or

any
?
<EOS>
In
what
way

?
<EOS>
She
could
not

was

yet
.
<EOS>
The

with

were

.
  
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
Omnium
should

,
 
if

.
<EOS>
And

,
 
that

.
<EOS>
Heavens

!
<EOS>
What

!
<EOS>
Then

.
<EOS>
Should

.
   
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
at
Saulsby
 
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
did
exactly
as
he
said
he
would
do
.
<EOS>
He
wrote
to
his
father
as
he
passed
through
Carlisle
,
and
at

on
to
his

at
Willingford
.
<EOS>
But
his
letter
was
very
stiff
and
ungainly
,
and
it
may
be
doubted

Miss
Effingham
was

.
<EOS>
He
began

letter
,
"
My
Lord
,
"
and
did
not

improve

style
as

.
<EOS>
The
reader
may
as
well
see
the
whole

;
    
Railway
Hotel
,
Carlisle
,
December
27
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
MY
LORD
,
  
<EOS>
I
am
now
on
my
way
from
Loughlinter
to
London
,
and
write
this
letter
to
you
in
compliance
with

.
<EOS>
I
have

Violet
to

,
and
she
has

,
and
they
think
that
you

.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
,

,

,

Edwards

.
<EOS>
Laura
thinks

at
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
For

,

,

that

.
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>
I
am
,
my
lord
,
yours
affect
.
<EOS>
,
  
CHILTERN
.
  
<EOS>
P.S.
 
<EOS>
My

will

"
The
Bull
,
Willingford
.
"
  
<EOS>
That

word
,
in

he
half
-

himself
to
be

in

relations
to
his
father
,
caused

a

.
<EOS>
But
he
could
find
no
term
for

,
without
a

,

that

of

towards
his
father
which
really

.
<EOS>
He
would

"

with

,
"

,
"

"

,
"

"

,
"
exactly

the

's

,

.
<EOS>
He
was

in

of

,
and
was
firmly

in
his

that

.
<EOS>
If

,

,
but
he

not

a

things
done

.
<EOS>
If
his
father

choose

to
them
,
his
father
must

.
  
<EOS>
The
Earl
was

son
's

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

.

Here

,

.

as

;
    
Saulsby
,

186
 
.
  
<EOS>
MY

CHILTERN
,
  
I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
Your

BRENTFORD
.
  
<EOS>
Richards

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

to
 
to
 
to
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
Her

was

"
that

,
"

.
<EOS>
But

only

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

"

"
had

before

in

,
and
had

.
"
<EOS>

,

"

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
"
But

,

?
"

.
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
would
not
argue

any

,
but
stalked
out

the
room
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
met
them
at
Saulsby
,
having
had
something
of
a
battle
with
her
husband
before
she
left
her
home
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
When
she
told
him
of
her
desire
to

this

between
her
father
and

,
he

by
pointing
out
that
her
first

was
at
Loughlinter
,
and
before
the

ended
had
come
to
express

opinion
that
that
duty
was

.
<EOS>
She
in
the

had
declared
that
she

go
to
Saulsby
,
or
that
she
would
explain
to
her
father
that

was

her

to
do

.
"
<EOS>
And
I
also

,
"

Kennedy
.
<EOS>
In

,
Lady
Laura

she

.
<EOS>
When

,

wife

.
<EOS>
She
had
almost

to

her
husband
;
and
he
had

to

what

.
<EOS>
The
wife
was
subject
to
her

by

both
of
God
and
man
;
and
Mr.
Kennedy
was
one
who
thought
much
of
such
laws
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
Lady
Laura
carried
her
point
and
went
to
Saulsby
,
leaving
her
husband
to
go
up
to
London
and
begin
the
session
by
himself
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
and
Violet
were
both
at
Saulsby
before
Lord
Chiltern
arrived
,
and
many
were
the
consultations
which
were
held
between
them
as
to
the
best
mode
in
which
things
might
be
arranged
.
<EOS>
Violet
was
of
opinion
that
there
had
better
be
no
arrangement
,
that
Lord
Chiltern
should
be
allowed
to
come
in
and
take
his
father
's
hand
,
and
sit
down
to
dinner
,
 
and
that
so
things
should
fall
into
their
places
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
was
rather
in
favour
of
some
scene
.
<EOS>
But
the
interview
had
taken
place
before
either
of
them
were
able
to
say
a
word
.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
,
on
his
arrival
,
had
gone
immediately
to
his
father
,
taking
the
Earl
very
much
by
surprise
,
and
had
come
off
best
in
the
encounter
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
"
said
he
,
walking
up
to
his
father
with
his
hand
out
,
"
I
am
very
glad
to
come
back
to
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
"
He
had
written
to
his
sister
to
say
that
he
would
be
at
Saulsby
on
that
day
,
but
had
named
no
hour
.
<EOS>
He
now
appeared
between
ten
and
eleven
in
the
morning
,
and
his
father
had
as
yet
made
no
preparation
for
him
,
 
had
arranged
no
appropriate
words
.
<EOS>
He
had
walked
in
at
the
front
door
,
and
had
asked
for
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
was
in
his
own
morning
-
room
,
 
a
gloomy
room
,
full
of
dark
books
and
darker
furniture
,
and
thither
Lord
Chiltern
had
at
once
gone
.
<EOS>
The
two
women
still
were
sitting
together
over
the
fire
in
the
breakfast
-
room
,
and
knew
nothing
of
his
arrival
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oswald
!
"
said
his
father
,
"
I
hardly
expected
you
so
early
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
early
.
<EOS>
I
came
across
country
,
and
slept
at
Birmingham
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
Violet
is
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
she
is
here
,
 
and
Laura
.
<EOS>
They
will
be
very
glad
to
see
you
.
<EOS>
So
am
I.
"
<EOS>
And
the
father
took
the
son
's
hand
for
the
second
time
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
,
looking
his
father
full
in
the
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
very
much
pleased
by
this
engagement
,
"
continued
the
Earl
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
I
must
be
,
then
?
"
said
the
son
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
at
it
,
you
know
,
off
and
on
,
ever
so
many
years
;
and
have
sometimes
thought
I
was
quite
a
fool
not
to
get
it
out
of
my
head
.
<EOS>
But
I
could
n't
get
it
out
of
my
head
.
<EOS>
And
now
she
talks
as
though
it
were
she
who
had
been
in
love
with
me
all
the
time
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
she
was
,
"
said
the
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
it
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
She
may
be
a
little
so
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
mean
that
she
always
shall
be
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
sha
n't
be
the
worst
husband
in
the
world
,
I
hope
;
and
I
am
quite
sure
I
sha
n't
be
the
best
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
and
see
her
now
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
shall
find
her
somewhere
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
I
thought
it
best
to
see
you
first
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stop
half
a
moment
,
Oswald
,
"
said
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
And
then
Lord
Brentford
did
make
something
of
a
shambling
speech
,
in
which
he
expressed
a
hope
that
they
two
might
for
the
future
live
together
on
friendly
terms
,
forgetting
the
past
.
<EOS>
He
ought
to
have
been
prepared
for
the
occasion
,
and
the
speech
was
poor
and
shambling
.
<EOS>
But
I
think
that
it
was
more
useful
than
it
might
have
been
,
had
it
been
uttered
roundly
and
with
that
paternal
and
almost
majestic
effect
which
he
would
have
achieved
had
he
been
thoroughly
prepared
.
<EOS>
But
the
roundness
and
the
majesty
would
have
gone
against
the
grain
with
his
son
,
and
there
would
have
been
a
danger
of
some
outbreak
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
Lord
Chiltern
smiled
,
and
muttered
some
word
about
things
being
"
all
right
,
"
and
then
made
his
way
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
great
deal
better
than
I
had
hoped
,
"
he
said
to
himself
;
"
and
it
has
all
come
from
my
going
in
without
being
announced
.
"
<EOS>
But
there
was
still
a
fear
upon
him
that
his
father
even
yet
might
prepare
a
speech
,
and
speak
it
,
to
the
great
peril
of
their
mutual
comfort
.
  
<EOS>
His
meeting
with
Violet
was
of
course
pleasant
enough
.
<EOS>
Now
that
she
had
succumbed
,
and
had
told
herself
and
had
told
him
that
she
loved
him
,
she
did
not
scruple
to
be
as
generous
as
a
maiden
should
be
who
has
acknowledged
herself
to
be
conquered
,
and
has
rendered
herself
to
the
conqueror
.
<EOS>
She
would
walk
with
him
and
ride
with
him
,
and
take
a
lively
interest
in
the
performances
of
all
his
horses
,
and
listen
to
hunting
stories
as
long
as
he
chose
to
tell
them
.
<EOS>
In
all
this
,
she
was
so
good
and
so
loving
that
Lady
Laura
was
more
than
once
tempted
to
throw
in
her
teeth
her
old
,
often
-
repeated
assertions
,
that
she
was
not
prone
to
be
in
love
,
 
that
it
was
not
her
nature
to
feel
any
ardent
affection
for
a
man
,
and
that
,
therefore
,
she
would
probably
remain
unmarried
.
<EOS>
"
You
begrudge
me
my
little
bits
of
pleasure
,
"
Violet
said
,
in
answer
to
one
such
attack
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
;
 
<EOS>
but
it
is
so
odd
to
see
you
,
of
all
women
,
become
so
love
-
lorn
,
<EOS>
"
"
I
am
not
love
-
lorn
,
"
said
Violet
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
like
the
freedom
of
telling
him
everything
and
of
hearing
everything
from
him
,
and
of
having
him
for
my
own
best
friend
.
<EOS>
He
might
go
away
for
twelve
months
,
and
I
should
not
be
unhappy
,
believing
,
as
I
do
,
that
he
would
be
true
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
All
of
which
set
Lady
Laura
thinking
whether
her
friend
had
not
been
wiser
than
she
had
been
.
<EOS>
She
had
never
known
anything
of
that
sort
of
friendship
with
her
husband
which
already
seemed
to
be
quite
established
between
these
two
.
  
<EOS>
In
her
misery
one
day
Lady
Laura
told
the
whole
story
of
her
own
unhappiness
to
her
brother
,
saying
nothing
of
Phineas
Finn
,
 
thinking
nothing
of
him
as
she
told
her
story
,
but
speaking
more
strongly
perhaps
than
she
should
have
done
,
of
the
terrible
dreariness
of
her
life
at
Loughlinter
,
and
of
her
inability
to
induce
her
husband
to
alter
it
for
her
sake
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
that
he
,
 
ill
-
treats
you
?
"
said
the
brother
,
with
a
scowl
on
his
face
which
seemed
to
indicate
that
he
would
like
no
task
better
than
that
of
resenting
such
ill
-
treatment
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
does
not
beat
me
,
if
you
mean
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
he
cruel
to
you
?
<EOS>
Does
he
use
harsh
language
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
never
said
a
word
in
his
life
either
to
me
or
,
as
I
believe
,
to
any
other
human
being
,
that
he
would
think
himself
bound
to
regret
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
simply
chooses
to
have
his
own
way
,
and
his
way
can
not
be
my
way
.
<EOS>
He
is
hard
,
and
dry
,
and
just
,
and
dispassionate
,
and
he
wishes
me
to
be
the
same
.
<EOS>
That
is
all
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
fairly
,
Laura
,
as
far
as
I
am
concerned
,
I
never
could
speak
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
is
antipathetic
to
me
.
<EOS>
But
then
I
am
not
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
;
 
and
I
suppose
I
must
bear
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
spoken
to
my
father
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
"
Or
to
Violet
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
does
she
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
can
she
say
?
<EOS>
She
has
nothing
to
say
.
<EOS>
Nor
have
you
.
<EOS>
Nor
,
if
I
am
driven
to
leave
him
,
can
I
make
the
world
understand
why
I
do
so
.
<EOS>
To
be
simply
miserable
,
as
I
am
,
is
nothing
to
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
could
never
understand
why
you
married
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
be
cruel
to
me
,
Oswald
.
"
  
"
Cruel
!
<EOS>
I
will
stick
by
you
in
any
way
that
you
wish
.
<EOS>
If
you
think
well
of
it
,
I
will
go
off
to
Loughlinter
to
-
morrow
,
and
tell
him
that
you
will
never
return
to
him
.
<EOS>
And
if
you
are
not
safe
from
him
here
at
Saulsby
,
you
shall
go
abroad
with
us
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
Violet
would
not
object
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
be
cruel
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
in
truth
neither
of
Lady
Laura
's
councillors
was
able
to
give
her
advice
that
could
serve
her
.
<EOS>
She
felt
that
she
could
not
leave
her
husband
without
other
cause
than
now
existed
,
although
she
felt
,
also
,
that
to
go
back
to
him
was
to
go
back
to
utter
wretchedness
.
<EOS>
And
when
she
saw
Violet
and
her
brother
together
there
came
to
her
dreams
of
what
might
have
been
her
own
happiness
<EOS>
had
she
kept
herself
free
from
those
terrible
bonds
in
which
she
was
now
held
a
prisoner
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
get
out
of
her
heart
the
remembrance
of
that
young
man
who
would
have
been
her
lover
,
if
she
would
have
let
him
,
 
of
whose
love
for
herself
she
had
been
aware
before
she
had
handed
herself
over
as
a
bale
of
goods
to
her
unloved
,
unloving
husband
.
<EOS>
She
had
married
Mr.
Kennedy
because
she
was
afraid
that
otherwise
she
might
find
herself
forced
to
own
that
she
loved
that
other
man
who
was
then
a
nobody
;
 
almost
nobody
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
Mr.
Kennedy
's
money
that
had
bought
her
.
<EOS>
This
woman
in
regard
to
money
had
shown
herself
to
be
as
generous
as
the
sun
.
<EOS>
But
in
marrying
Mr.
Kennedy
she
had
maintained
herself
in
her
high
position
,
among
the
first
of
her
own
people
,
 
among
the
first
socially
and
among
the
first
politically
.
<EOS>
But
had
she
married
Phineas
,
 
had
she
become
Lady
Laura
Finn
<EOS>
,
 
there
would
have
been
a
great
descent
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
have
entertained
the
leading
men
of
her
party
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
have
been
on
a
level
with
the
wives
and
daughters
of
Cabinet
Ministers
.
<EOS>
She
might
,
indeed
,
have
remained
unmarried
!
<EOS>
But
she
knew
that
had
she
done
so
,
 
had
she
so
resolved
,
 
that
which
she
called
her
fancy
would
have
been
too
strong
for
her
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
have
remained
unmarried
.
<EOS>
At
that
time
it
was
her
fate
to
be
either
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
or
Lady
Laura
Finn
.
<EOS>
And
she
had
chosen
to
be
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
To
neither
Violet
Effingham
nor
to
her
brother
<EOS>
could
she
tell
one
half
of
the
sorrow
which
afflicted
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
go
back
to
Loughlinter
,
"
she
said
to
her
brother
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
not
,
unless
you
wish
it
,
"
he
answered
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
wish
it
.
<EOS>
But
I
shall
do
it
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
is
in
London
now
,
and
has
been
there
since
Parliament
met
,
but
he
will
be
in
Scotland
again
in
March
,
and
I
will
go
and
meet
him
there
.
<EOS>
I
told
him
that
I
would
do
so
when
I
left
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
go
up
to
London
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
so
.
<EOS>
I
must
do
as
he
tells
me
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
What
I
mean
is
,
I
will
try
it
for
another
year
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
it
does
not
succeed
,
come
to
us
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
say
what
I
will
do
.
<EOS>
I
would
die
if
I
knew
how
.
<EOS>
Never
be
a
tyrant
,
Oswald
;
or
at
any
rate
,
not
a
cold
tyrant
.
<EOS>
And
remember
this
,
there
is
no
tyranny
to
a
woman
like
telling
her
of
her
duty
.
<EOS>
Talk
of
beating
a
woman
!
<EOS>
Beating
might
often
be
a
mercy
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
remained
ten
days
at
Saulsby
,
and
at
last
did
not
get
away
without
a
few
unpleasant
words
with
his
father
,
 
or
without
a
few
words
that
were
almost
unpleasant
with
his
mistress
.
<EOS>
On
his
first
arrival
he
had
told
his
sister
that
he
should
go
on
a
certain
day
,
and
some
intimation
to
this
effect
had
probably
been
conveyed
to
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
But
when
his
son

-

seven

,

that

was

.
<EOS>
There

,

no

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
very

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
Laura

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
What

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

You

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
But

;

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
But

Chiltern
.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern

<EOS>

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
What

<EOS>

"

"

;
 
plans

.

I

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
<EOS>
Lord

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Am

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
All

Earl
very

,

to

.
<EOS>
When

again
as

the

,

Chiltern

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
He

of

,

again

to

of

,

of

.
<EOS>
Then

than

,

Lord
Chiltern
simply

.
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
and
I
've

.
<EOS>
Good
-

.
<EOS>
"

,

Lord
Brentford

,

.
  
<EOS>
After

Chiltern

,

;
and

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Such

,
"
he

,

.
"
<EOS>
Nay
;

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
 
whether

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
"
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
But

present

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
What
the
People
in
Marylebone
Thought
 
Phineas
Finn
,
when
the
session
began
,
was
still
hard
at
work
upon
his
Canada
bill
,
and
in
his
work
found
some
relief
for
his
broken
back
.
<EOS>
He
went
into
the
matter
with
all

,
and
before
the

came

,
knew
much

about
the
seven

of
some

of
square

at

back
of
Canada
,
than
he
did
of
the
people
of
London
or

County
Clare
.
<EOS>
And
he
found
some

also
in
the
good
-
nature
of
Madame
Goesler
,
whose
drawing
-
room
was
always
open
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
could
talk
freely
now
to
Madame
Goesler
about
Violet
,
and
had
even
ventured
to
tell
her
that
once
,
in
old
days
,
he
had
thought
of
loving
Lady
Laura
Standish
.
<EOS>
He
spoke
of
those
days
as
being
very
old
;
and
then
he
perhaps
said
some
word
to
her
about
dear
little
Mary
Flood
Jones
.
<EOS>
I
think
that
there
was
not
much
in
his
career
of
which
he
did
not
say
something
to
Madame
Goesler
,
and
that
he
received
from
her
a
good

in
the
direction

his

.
<EOS>
"
A
man
should
work
,
"
she
said
,
 
"
and
you
do
work
.
<EOS>
A
woman
can
only
look
on
,
and
admire
and
long
.
<EOS>
What
is
there
that
I
can
do
?
<EOS>
I
can
learn

care

these
Canadians
,
just

.
<EOS>
If

was
the
beavers
that
you

of
,
I
should
have
to
care
for
the
beavers
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
of
course
told
her
that
such
sympathy
from
her
was
all
and
all
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
the
reader
must
not

this

that
he
was
untrue
in
his

to
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
His
back
was
altogether
broken
by

fall
,
and
he
was
quite

that
such
was
the

.
<EOS>
Not
as

,
at

,

.
  
<EOS>
Early

he
heard

Lady
Laura
was
up

,
and
of

was
bound

.
<EOS>
The

him
by
Mr.
Kennedy
himself
,
who

that
he

been

.
<EOS>
In
these

,
but

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
Mr.
Kennedy
was
a
man

.
<EOS>
With
Phineas
<EOS>
he
now

House
,
and
when

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
had
no

see

the
man

had

;
but

;
and

,

to

.
<EOS>
No

;

.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
is
in

,
"

;
"

before

.
<EOS>
"
Phineas

promised
that

.
  
<EOS>
In
these
days
Phineas
was
beginning
to
be

that

,
 
though

.
<EOS>
There

Fitzgibbon
,

,

,

,
to

,

.
<EOS>
"
You

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
But

party
,
bedad
,

's
rotten
to

core
,
and
wo
n't
stand
another

.
<EOS>
Mind
,

's
I
who
tell

so
.
"
<EOS>
And
the
poor
idle
Irishman
,
in

,
spoke

truth
as
well
as
he

.
<EOS>
But
the
Ratlers
and
the
Bonteens
were
Finn
's
bitter

,
and
did
not

to
let
him
know
that
such
was
the
case
.
<EOS>
Barrington
Erle
had
scruples
on
the
subject
,
and
in
a
certain

way
still
spoke
well
of
the
young
man
,
whom
he
had
himself
first
introduced
into
political

only
four
years
since
;
 
but
there
was
no

or

in
Barrington
Erle
's

,
and
Phineas
knew
that
his
first
staunch
friend
could
no
longer

as

.
<EOS>
But
there
was
a
set
of
men
,
quite
as
influential
,
 
<EOS>
so
Phineas
thought
,
 
as
the
busy
politicians
of
the
club
,
who
were
very
friendly
to
him
.
<EOS>
These
were
men
,
generally
of
high

,
of
steady

,
 
hard
workers
,
 
who
thought
quite
as
much
of
what
a
man

in

as
what
he
said

the
House
.
<EOS>
Lords
Cantrip
,
Thrift
,
and
Fawn
were
of
this
class
,
 
and
they
were
all
very
courteous
to
Phineas
.
<EOS>
Envious
men
began
to
say
of
him
that
he
cared
little
now
for
any
one
of
the
party
who
had
not
a
handle
to
his
name
,
and
that
he
preferred
to
live
with
lords
and
lordlings
.
<EOS>
This
was
hard
upon
him
,
as
the
great
political
ambition
of
his
life
was
to
call
Mr.
Monk
his
friend
;
and
he
would
sooner
have
acted
with
Mr.
Monk
than
with
any
other
man
in
the
Cabinet
.
<EOS>
But
though
Mr.
Monk
had
not
deserted

,
there

come
to
be
little
of
late
in

between
the
two
.
<EOS>
His
life
was
becoming
that
of
a

official
rather
than
that
of

;
 
<EOS>
whereas
,
though
Mr.
Monk
was
in
office
,
his
public
life
was
purely
political
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
had
great
ideas
of
his
own
which
he
intended
to
hold
,
whether
by
holding
them
he
might
remain
in
office
or
be
forced
out
of
office
;
and
he
was
indifferent
as
to
the
direction
which
things
in
this
respect
might
take
with
him
.
<EOS>
But
Phineas
,
who
had
achieved
his
declared
object
in
getting
into
place
,
felt
that
he
was
almost
constrained
to
adopt
the
views
of
others
,
let
them
be
what
they
might
.
<EOS>
Men
spoke
to
him
,
as
though
his
parliamentary
career
were
wholly
at
the
disposal
of
the
Government
,
 
as
though
he
were
like
a
proxy
in
Mr.
Gresham
's
pocket
,
 
with
this
difference
,
<EOS>
that
when
directed
to
get
up
and
speak
on
a
subject
he
was
bound
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
This
annoyed
him
,
and
he
complained
to
Mr.
Monk
;
but
Mr.
Monk
only
shrugged
his
shoulders
and
told
him
that
he
must
make
his
choice
.
<EOS>
He
soon
discovered
Mr.
Monk
's
meaning
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
choose
to
make
Parliament
a
profession
,
 
as
you
have
chosen
,
 
you
can
have
no
right
even
to
think
of
independence
.
<EOS>
If
the
country
finds
you
out
when
you
are
in
Parliament
,
and
then
invites
you
to
office
,
of
course
the
thing
is
different
.
<EOS>
But
the
latter
is
a
slow
career
,
and
probably
would
not
have
suited
you
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That
was
the
meaning
of
what
Mr.
Monk
said
to
him
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
these
official
and
parliamentary
honours
were
greater
when
seen
at
a
distance
than
he
found
them
to
be
now
that
he
possessed
them
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Low
worked
ten
hours
a
day
,
and
could
rarely
call
a
day
his
own
;
but
,
after
all
,
with
all
this
work
,
Mr.
Low
was
less
of
a
slave
,
and
more
independent
,
than
was
he
,
Phineas
Finn
,
Under
-
Secretary
of
State
,
the
friend
of
Cabinet
Ministers
,
and
Member
of
Parliament
since
his
twenty
-
fifth
year
!
<EOS>
He
began
to
dislike
the
House
,
and
to
think
it
a
bore
to
sit
on
the
Treasury
bench
;
 
he
,
who
a
few
years
since
had
regarded
Parliament
as
the
British
heaven
on
earth
,
and
who
,
since
he
had
been
in
Parliament
,
had
looked
at
that
bench
with
longing
envious
eyes
.
<EOS>
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
,
who
seemed
to
have
as
much
to
eat
and
drink
as
ever
,
and
a
bed
also
to
lie
on
,
could
come
and
go
in
the
House
as
he
pleased
,
since
his
 
resignation
.
  
<EOS>
And
there
was
a
new
trouble
coming
.
<EOS>
The
Reform
Bill
for
England
had
passed
;
but
now
there
was
to
be
another
Reform
Bill
for
Ireland
.
<EOS>
Let
them
pass
what
bill
they
might
,
this
would
not
render
necessary
a
new
Irish
election
till
the
entire
House
should
be
dissolved
.
<EOS>
But
he
feared
that
he
would
be
called
upon
to
vote
for
the
abolition
of
his
own
borough
,
 
and
for
other
points
almost
equally
distasteful
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
would
not
be
consulted
,
 
but
would
be
called
upon
to
vote
,
and
perhaps
to
speak
;
and
was
certain
that
if
he
did
so
,
there
would
be
war
between
him
and
his
constituents
.
<EOS>
Lord
Tulla
had
already
communicated
to
him
his
ideas
that
,
for
certain
excellent
reasons
,
Loughshane
ought
to
be
spared
.
<EOS>
But
this
evil
was
,
he
hoped
,
a
distant
one
.
<EOS>
It
was
generally
thought
that
,
as
the
English
Reform
Bill
had
been
passed
last
year
,
and
as
the
Irish
bill
,
if
carried
,
could
not
be
immediately
operative
,
the
doing
of
the
thing
might
probably
be
postponed
to
the
next
session
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
first
saw
Lady
Laura
he
was
struck
by
the
great
change
in
her
look
and
manner
.
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
him
to
be
old
and
worn
,
and
he
judged
her
to
be
wretched
,
 
as
she
was
.
<EOS>
She
had
written
to
him
to
say
that
she
would
be
at
her
father
's
house
on
such
and
such
a
morning
,
and
he
had
gone
to
her
there
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
of
no
use
your
coming
to
Grosvenor
Place
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
see
nobody
there
,
and
the
house
is
like
a
prison
.
"
<EOS>
Later
in
the
interview
she
told
him
not
to
come
and
dine
there
,
even
though
Mr.
Kennedy
should
ask
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
not
?
"
he
demanded
.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
everything
would
be
stiff
,
and
cold
,
and
uncomfortable
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
do
not
wish
to
make
your
way
into
a
lady
's
house
if
she
asks
you
not
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
sort
of
smile
on
her
face
as
she
said
this
,
but
he
could
perceive
that
it
was
a
very
bitter
smile
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
easily
excuse
yourself
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
can
excuse
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
do
so
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
particularly
anxious
to
dine
with
Mr.
Kennedy
,
you
can
easily
do
so
at
your
club
.
<EOS>
"
In
the
tone
of
her
voice
,
and
the
words
she
used
,
she
hardly
attempted
to
conceal
her
dislike
of
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
now
tell
me
about
Miss
Effingham
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
for
me
to
tell
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
there
is
;
 
much
to
tell
.
<EOS>
You
need
not
spare
me
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
pretend
to
deny
to
you
that
I
have
been
hit
hard
,
 
so
hard
,
that
I
have
been
nearly
knocked
down
;
but
it
will
not
hurt
me
now
to
hear
of
it
all
.
<EOS>
Did
she
always
love
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
say
.
<EOS>
I
think
she
did
after
her
own
fashion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
sometimes
think
women
would
be
less
cruel
,
"
he
said
,
"
if
they
knew
how
great
is
the
anguish
they
can
cause
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Has
she
been
cruel
to
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
to
complain
of
.
<EOS>
But
if
she
loved
Chiltern
,
why
did
she
not
tell
him
so
at
once
?
<EOS>
And
why
 
"
  
"
This
is
complaining
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
complain
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
even
think
of
it
,
if
I
could
help
it
.
<EOS>
Are
they
to
be
married
soon
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
July
;
 
so
they
now
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
where
will
they
live
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
no
one
can
tell
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
that
they
agree
as
yet
as
to
that
.
<EOS>
But
if
she
has
a
strong
wish
Oswald
will
yield
to
it
.
<EOS>
He
was
always
generous
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
even
have
had
a
wish
,
 
except
to
have
her
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
pause
for
a
moment
,
and
then
Lady
Laura
answered
him
with
a
touch
of
scorn
in
her
voice
,
 
and
with
some
scorn
,
too
,
in
her
eye
:
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
all
very
well
,
Mr.
Finn
;
but
the
season
will
not
be
over
before
there
is
some
one
else
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
you
wrong
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
tell
me
that
you
are
already
at
Madame
Goesler
's
feet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Madame
Goesler
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
matters
who
it
is
as
long
as
she
is
young
and
pretty
,
and
has
the
interest
attached
to
her
of
something
more
than
ordinary
position
?
<EOS>
When
men
tell
me
of
the
cruelty
of
women
,
I
think
that
no
woman
can
be
really
cruel
because
no
man
is
capable
of
suffering
.
<EOS>
A
woman
,
if
she
is
thrown
aside
,
does
suffer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
to
tell
me
,
then
,
that
I
am
indifferent
to
Miss
Effingham
?
<EOS>
"
When
he
thus
spoke
,
I
wonder
whether
he
had
forgotten
that
he
had
ever
declared
to
this
very
woman
to
whom
he
was
speaking
,
a
passion
for
herself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Psha
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
suits
you
,
Lady
Laura
,
to
be
harsh
to
me
,
but
you
are
not
speaking
your
thoughts
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
she
lost
all
control
of
herself
,
and
poured
out
to
him
the
real
truth
that
was
in
her
.
"
<EOS>
And
whose
thoughts
did
you
speak
when
you
and
I
were
on
the
braes
of
Loughlinter
?
<EOS>
Am
I
wrong
in
saying
that
change
is
easy
to
you
,
or
have
I
grown
to
be
so
old
that
you
can
talk
to
me
as
though
those
far
-
away
follies
ought
to
be
forgotten
?
<EOS>
Was
it
so
long
ago
?
<EOS>
Talk
of
love
!
<EOS>
I
tell
you
,
sir
,
that
your
heart
is
one
in
which
love
can
have
no
durable
hold
.
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
!
<EOS>
There
may
be
a
dozen
Violets
after
her
,
and
you
will
be
none
the
worse
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
she
walked
away
from
him
to
the
window
,
and
he
stood
still
,
dumb
,
on
the
spot
that
he
had
occupied
.
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
go
now
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
forget
what
has
passed
between
us
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
you
are
a
gentleman
,
and
that
you
will
forget
it
.
<EOS>
"
The
strong
idea
of
his
mind
when
he
heard
all
this
was
the
injustice
of
her
attack
,
 
of
the
attack
as
coming
from
her
,
who
had
all
but
openly
acknowledged
that
she
had
married
a
man
whom
she
had
not
loved
because
it
suited
her
to
escape
from
a
man
whom
she
did
love
.
<EOS>
She
was
reproaching
him
now
for
his
fickleness
in
having
ventured
to
set
his
heart
upon
another
woman
,
when
she
herself
had
been
so
much
worse
than
fickle
,
 
so
profoundly
false
!
<EOS>
And
yet
he
could
not
defend
himself
by
accusing
her
.
<EOS>
What
would
she
have
had
of
him
?
<EOS>
What
would
she
have
proposed
to
him
,
had
he
questioned
her
as
to
his
future
,
when
they
were
together
on
the
braes
of
Loughlinter
?
<EOS>
Would
she
not
have
bid
him
to
find
some
one
else
whom
he
could
love
?
<EOS>
Would
she
then
have
suggested
to
him
the
propriety
of
nursing
his
love
for
herself
,
 
for
her
who
was
about
to
become
another
man
's
wife
,
 
for
her
after
she
should
have
become
another
man
's
wife
?
<EOS>
And
yet
because
he
had
not
done
so
,
and
because
she
had
made
herself
wretched
by
marrying
a
man
whom
she
did
not
love
,
she
reproached
him
!
  
<EOS>
He
could
not
tell
her
of
all
this
,
so
he
fell
back
for
his
defence
on
words
which
had
passed
between
them
since
the
day
when
they
had
met
on
the
braes
.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
,
"
he
said
,
"
it
is
only
a
month
or
two
since
you
spoke
to
me
as
though
you
wished
that
Violet
Effingham
might
be
my
wife
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
wished
it
.
<EOS>
I
never
said
that
I
wished
it
.
<EOS>
There
are
moments
in
which
we
try
to
give
a
child
any
brick
on
the
chimney
top
for
which
it
may
whimper
.
"
<EOS>
Then
there
was
another
silence
which
she
was
the
first
to
break
.
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
go
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
I
have
committed
myself
,
and
of
course
I
would
rather
be
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
would
you
wish
that
I
should
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
What
you
do
can
be
nothing
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Must
we
be
strangers
,
you
and
I
,
because
there
was
a
time
in
which
we
were
almost
more
than
friends
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
spoken
nothing
about
myself
,
sir
,
 
only
as
I
have
been
drawn
to
do
so
by
your
pretence
of
being
love
-
sick
.
<EOS>
You
can
do
nothing
for
me
,
 
nothing
,
 
nothing
.
<EOS>
What
is
it
possible
that
you
should
do
for
me
?
<EOS>
You
are
not
my
father
,
or
my
brother
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
to
be
supposed
that
she
wanted
him
to
fall
at
her
feet
.
<EOS>
It
is
to
be
supposed
that
had
he
done
so
her
reproaches
would
have
been
hot
and
heavy
on
him
;
but
yet
it
almost
seemed
to
him
as
though
he
had
no
other
alternative
.
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
her
father
or
her
brother
;
 
nor
could
he
be
her
husband
.
<EOS>
And
at
this
very
moment
,
as
she
knew
,
his
heart
was
sore
with
love
for
another
woman
.
<EOS>
And
yet
he
hardly
knew
how
not
to
throw
himself
at
her
feet
,
and
swear
,
that
he
would
return
now
and
for
ever
to
his
old
passion
,
hopeless
,
sinful
,
degraded
as
it
would
be
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
it
were
possible
for
me
to
do
something
,
"
he
said
,
drawing
near
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
to
be
done
,
"
she
said
,
clasping
her
hands
together
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
me
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
have
before
me
no
escape
,
no
hope
,
<EOS>
no
prospect
of
relief
,
no
place
of
consolation
.
<EOS>
You
have
everything
before
you
.
<EOS>
You
complain
of
a
wound
!
<EOS>
You
have
at
least
shown
that
such
wounds
with
you
are

.
<EOS>
You
can
not
but

that

I

,
I
must
be
impatient
.
<EOS>
You
had
better
leave
me
now
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
are
we
to
be
no

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
As
far
as
friendship
can
go
without
intercourse
,
I
shall
always

your
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
he

,
and
as

,
<EOS>
so

on
that
which
had

that

,

.
<EOS>
There

<EOS>

,

as

?
<EOS>
He

Violet
,

.
<EOS>
There

before

.
<EOS>
But

were

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

before

"
no

,

.

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Phineas

<EOS>
The
Top
Brick
of
the
Chimney
 
Madame
Max
Goesler
was
a
lady
who
knew
that
in

the

which
fell
to
her

,

,

,
very

was

,
 
and

too
about

,
 
than
was

.
<EOS>
And
this
was
not
the

so
much
on

any

she

,
as

was
ambitious
of
doing
the
very

with
those

which
she

.
<EOS>
Her
own
birth
had
not
been
high
,
and
that
of
her
husband
,
we
may
perhaps

,
had

.
<EOS>
He
had
been
old
when
she
had

,
and
she
had
had
little

of
making

till

.
<EOS>
Then
she
found
herself
possessed
of

,

;
of

,
 
as

;
and
of

something

,

,
she

.
<EOS>
She
was
a
woman
who
did
not
flatter

,
who
did
not

in
herself
,
who
could
even

herself
to
wonder
that
men

women
in
high
position
should

to
notice
such

as

.
<EOS>
With
all

,
there

;
and
with

had

there

which
would
sometimes

upon

.
<EOS>
When
she
found
a
woman
really
kind

her
,
she
would
be
very
kind
in

.
<EOS>
And
though
she
prized
wealth
,
and
knew
that
her
money
was
her
only
rock
of
strength
,
she
could
be
lavish
with

,
as
though
it
were

.
  
<EOS>
But
she
was
highly
ambitious
,
and
she
played
her
game
with
great

and
great
caution
.
<EOS>
Her
doors
were
not
open
to
all

;
 
were
shut

some
who
find
but

doors

against

;
 
were

to
those

most

to
see
within

.
<EOS>
She
knew
how
to
allure
by
denying
,
and
to
make
the

rich
by

.
<EOS>
We
are
told
by
the
Latin

that
he
who

quickly

twice
;
but
I
say
that
she
who
gives

seldom

more

half
.
<EOS>
When
in
the
early

the
Duke

first

at
Madame
Max
Goesler
's

,

was

.
<EOS>
The
Duke
felt

cross

,
 
on

.
<EOS>
He

cross
.
<EOS>
She
had

that
she
was
always

between

.
<EOS>
He

,

!
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
Any

,

.
<EOS>
No
;
 
he

.
<EOS>

,

!
 
<EOS>
so

,

,

MY

DUKE
,
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
Yours

,
  
MARIE
M.
G.
  
<EOS>
The
note
-

was
very

note

,

,

,

,
<EOS>

O.

,

.

.

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

as

<EOS>
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Duke
certainly
was
an

,

;

.
<EOS>
He
moved

,

,

,

.

But

.
<EOS>
He
was

;

,

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
He

Max
Goesler
's

.
<EOS>
When

,

as

;

,

on

,
 
just

.
  
<EOS>
After

Grace
's

.
<EOS>
That

of

,
with

,
is
the
most

of

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

,

?
"
<EOS>
"
Oh

,
 
very

,

;

.
<EOS>
These

which
on

.
<EOS>
It

to

without

some

which
would

to

,

.
<EOS>
At

was

,

the

had

.
<EOS>
Words
were
spoken
that
were
very
absurd
.
<EOS>
Madame
Goesler
protested
that
the
Duke
's

was

than

;

next

,
 
I

afraid
he
said

.
<EOS>
Then

,
and
was

that

he

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
when

talk
of
going
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
dine
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
just
the
reason
you
should
dine
with
me
.
<EOS>
You
shall
meet
nobody
you
do
not

meet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
so
much

you
in
this

,
 
I
would

.
<EOS>
I
do

out
occasionally
,
but

,

I
can
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
can
not
escape
my
little
not
formal
party
,
 
without
giving
offence
.
<EOS>
"
She
looked
into
his
face
as
she
spoke
,
and
he
knew
that
she
meant

.
<EOS>
And
he

into
hers
,
and
thought
that
her

were

any

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Name
your
own

,
Duke
.
<EOS>
Will
a

suit

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
must
come
 
"
  
"
You
must
come
.
<EOS>
"
As
she
spoke
her
eyes
sparkled
more
and
more
,
and
her
colour
went
and
came
,
and
she
shook
her

till

emitted
through

the
same

of
a

that
her
note

.
<EOS>
Then

out

of

,
and
the
Duke
saw
that

was
perfect
.
<EOS>
And
she

as
she

.
<EOS>
Her
hand
was
very
fair
,
and
her

were
bright
with
rich

.
<EOS>
To
men
such
as
the
Duke
,
a
hand
,
to
be
quite
fair
,
should
be
bright
with
rich
gems
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
come
,
"
she
said
,
 
not

but

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
come
,
"
he

,
and
a
certain
Sunday
was
fixed
.
  
<EOS>
The

of
the
guests
was
a

,
till

Goesler

Duke

bring

Lady
Glencora
Palliser
,

.
<EOS>
This

.
<EOS>
As

,
Lady
Glencora
was
to
the

all
that

woman
could

.
<EOS>
She
was
everything
that
was
proper
as

her

,
and
not

as

his
.
<EOS>
She
did
not

,
and

.
<EOS>
Although

's

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
;
she

,
"

,
"
she

.
<EOS>
If

,

.
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
Madame

's

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
And

<EOS>
It

"

,

<EOS>
Yes

"
My

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Rara
Avis
in

"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

but
most
probably
you
know
nothing
even
of
the
modes
of
thought
of
the
man
who
lives
next
door
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
are
general
laws
current
in
the
world
as
to
morality
.
"
<EOS>
Thou
shalt
not
steal
,
"
for
instance
.
<EOS>
That
has
necessarily
been
current
as
a
law
through
all
nations
.
<EOS>
But
the
first
man
you
meet
in
the
street
will
have
ideas
about
theft
so
different
from
yours
,
that
,
if
you
knew
them
as
you
know
your
own
,
you
would
say
that
this
law
and
yours
were
not
even
founded
on
the
same
principle
.
<EOS>
It
is
compatible
with
this
man
's
honesty
to
cheat
you
in
a
matter
of
horseflesh
,
with
that
man
's
in
a

of
railway

,
with
that

man
's
as
to
a
woman
's

;
with
a
fourth
's
anything
may
be
done
for
a
seat
in
Parliament
,
while
the
fifth
man
,
who
stands
high
among
us
,
and
who

every
Sunday
to
write
that
law
on

,
spends

daily
toil
in
a
system
of
fraud
,
and
is
regarded
as
a
pattern
of
the
national
commerce
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
and
Phineas
were
dining
together
at
Mr.
Monk
's
house
,
and
the
elder

of
the
two

this

speech
had
recurred
to
certain

had

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
was
becoming
somewhat

of

in
the
Cabinet
,
though

had
not

;
and
he
had
begun
to
pine
for
the
lost

of
a
seat
below

gangway
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
discussing
political
honesty
with
Phineas
,
and
hence
had
come
the
sermon
of
which
I
have
ventured
to
reproduce
the

.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
was
fond
of
such

and
fond
of
holding
them
with
Mr.
Monk
,
 
in
this
matter
fluttering
like
a
moth
<EOS>
round
a
candle
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
perceive
that
as
he
had
made

to

of
the
public

,
he

abandon

;
and
unless

so
he
could
be

as

,

useful
to
the
public

he
served
.
<EOS>
Could
a
man
be
honest
in
Parliament
,
and
yet
abandon
all
idea
of
independence
?
<EOS>
When
he
put
such

to
Mr.
Monk
he
did
not

.
<EOS>
And
indeed
the

was
never

.
<EOS>
But
the

which
he
received
was
ever

a

to

.
<EOS>
It
was
always

this

:
"
You
have

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
"
<EOS>
And

Mr.
Monk
would

such

as
that

just

!
<EOS>
Perhaps

is
no

more

a

's

than

of

of

.
<EOS>
Whether

because

?
  
<EOS>
"
But

,
you
will

?
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

in
a

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
This
trip
to
Ireland
had
been
proposed
in

of
certain

respecting
tenant
-
right
which
Mr.
Monk
was
beginning

,
and
as
to
which

were
becoming

.
<EOS>
It
had
been
all
very
well
to
put
down
Fenianism
,
and
Ribandmen
,
and
Repeal
,
 
and
everything
that
had

put
down
in

in

way

for
the
last

-

.
<EOS>
England
and
Ireland
had
been
apparently
joined
together
by
laws
of
nature
so
fixed
,
that
even
politicians
liberal
as
was
Mr.
Monk
,
 
liberal

was
Mr.
Turnbull
,
 
could
not
trust

to
think
that
disunion
could
be
for
the

of
the
Irish
.
<EOS>
They
had
taught
themselves
that
it
certainly
could
not
be

for

English
.
<EOS>
But
if

was
incumbent
on
England
to
force
upon
Ireland
the
maintenance
of
the
Union
for
her
own

,
and
for
England
's

,
because
England
could
not
afford
independence
established
so
close
against
her
own
ribs
,
 
it
was
at
any
rate
necessary
to
England
's
character
that
the
bride
thus
bound
in
a
compulsory
wedlock
should
be
endowed
with
all
the
best

that
a
wife
can
enjoy
.
<EOS>
Let
her
at
least
not

a

.
<EOS>
Let
it
be
bone
of
my
bone
and
flesh

my
flesh
,
if

to

.
<EOS>
Between

and

a
warm

now

,

good

at

.
<EOS>
But
let

that

at

.
<EOS>
What
about
this
Protestant
Church
;
and
what
about
this
tenant
<EOS>
-
right
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
had
been
asking

for
some
time
past
.
<EOS>
In
regard
to
the
Church
,
he
had
long
made
up
his
mind
that
the
Establishment
in
Ireland
was
a
crying
sin
.
<EOS>
A
man
had
married
a
woman
whom
he
knew
to
be
of
a

different
from
his
own
,
and
then

that
his

should
say

he

.
<EOS>
But
,
as
Mr.
Monk
well

,
the

the
Protestant
Endowments
in
Ireland
was
so
difficult
that
it
would

almost
more

to

.
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
those
matters
which
almost

to
require
the

of
some
higher
power
,
 
the

of
some

chance

,
 
to

away

;
as

comes
,
and

;
as

,

;
as

,
and

.
<EOS>
But

-

,

,

,
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
thought
that

that

.
<EOS>

,

;

!
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

?

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
,

.

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

;

.
<EOS>
There

;
 
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
and

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
But
,
"

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
Look

,
 
Maynooth

.
<EOS>
It

that

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

-

to

.
<EOS>
Why

up
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk

before

.
<EOS>
"
If
I

-

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Moreover
,

,

.
<EOS>
For

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
We

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said

Monk
,
"
we
will
go
and
see
.
<EOS>
"
And
thus
,
in
the
month
of
May
,

was

between

that
,
as

,

should

to

,
they
two
should

.
<EOS>
Phineas
felt
rather
proud
as
he
wrote
to
his
father
and

to
bring
home
with
him
a
Cabinet
Minister
as

.
<EOS>
At
this
time
the
reputation
of
Phineas
at
Killaloe
,
as
well
in
the

of
the
Killaloeians
generally
as

,
stood
very
high

.
<EOS>
How
could
a
father
think
that
a
son
had
done
badly
when
before
he
was
thirty
years
of
age
he
was
earning
£
2,000
a

?
<EOS>
And
how
could
a
father
not
think
well
of
a
son
who
had
absolutely
paid
back
certain
moneys
into
the
paternal

?
<EOS>
The
moneys
so
repaid
had
not
been
much
;
but
the

of
any
such
money
at
Killaloe
had
been
regarded
as
little
short
of

.
<EOS>
The
news
of
Mr.
Monk
's
coming
flew
about
the
town
,
about
the
county
,
about
the
diocese
,
and
all
people
began
to
say
all
good
things
about
the
old
doctor
's
only
son
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Finn
had
long
since
been
quite
sure
that
a
real
black

had
been
sent
forth
out

her

.
<EOS>
And
the
sisters
Finn
,
for
some

,
had
felt

they
stood
quite

than
formerly
because

.
<EOS>
They
were
asked
about
in
the
county
,
and
two
of

had
been
staying
only
last
Easter
with
the
Molonys
,
 
the
Molonys
of
Poldoodie
!
<EOS>
How
should
a
father
and
a
mother
and
sisters
not
be
grateful
to
such
a
son
,
to
such
a
brother
,
to
such
a
veritable
black
swan
out
of
the
nest
!
<EOS>
And
as
for
dear
little
Mary
Flood
Jones
,
her
eyes
became
suffused
with
tears
as
in
her
solitude
<EOS>
she
thought
how
much
out
of
her
reach
this
swan
was
flying
.
<EOS>
And
yet
she
took
joy
in
his
swanhood
,
and
swore
that
she
would
love
him
still
;
 
that
she
would
love
him
always
.
<EOS>
Might
he
bring
home
with
him
to
Killaloe
,
Mr.
Monk
,
the
Cabinet
Minister
!
<EOS>
Of
course
he
might
.
<EOS>
When
Mrs.
Finn
first
heard
of
this
august
arrival
,
she
felt
as
though
she
would
like
to
expend
herself
in
entertaining
,
though
but
an
hour
,
the
whole
cabinet
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
during
the
spring
,
had
,
of
course
,
met
Mr.
Kennedy
frequently
in
and
about
the
House
,
and
had
become
aware
that
Lady
Laura
's
husband
,
from
time
to
time
,
made
little
overtures
of
civility
to
him
,
 
taking
him
now
and
again
by
the
button
-
hole
,
walking
home
with
him
as
far
as
their
joint
paths
allowed
,
and
asking
him
once
or
twice
to
come
and
dine
in
Grosvenor
Place
.
<EOS>
These
little
advances
towards
a
repetition
of
the
old
friendship
Phineas
would
have
avoided
altogether
,
had
it
been
possible
.
<EOS>
The
invitation
to
Mr.
Kennedy
's
house
he
did
refuse
,
feeling
himself
positively
bound
to
do
so
by
Lady
Laura
's
command
,
let
the
consequences
be
what
they
might
.
<EOS>
When
he
did
refuse
,
Mr.
Kennedy
would
assume
a
look
of
displeasure
and
leave
him
,
and
Phineas
would
hope
that
the
work
was
done
.
<EOS>
Then
there
would
come
another
encounter
,
and
the
invitation
would
be
repeated
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
about
the
middle
of
May
,
there
came
another
note
.
<EOS>
"
Dear
Finn
,
will
you
dine
with
us
on
Wednesday
,
the
28th
?
<EOS>
I
give
you
a
long
notice
,
because
you
seem
to
have
so
many
appointments
.
<EOS>
Yours
always
,
Robert
Kennedy
.
"
<EOS>
He
had
no
alternative
.
<EOS>
He
must
refuse
,
even
though
double
the
notice
had
been
given
.
<EOS>
He
could
only
think
that
Mr.
Kennedy
was
a
very
obtuse
man
and
one
who
would
not
take
a
hint
,
and
hope
that
he
might
succeed
at
last
.
<EOS>
So
he
wrote
an
answer
,
not
intended
to
be
conciliatory
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Kennedy
,
I
am
sorry
to
say
that
I
am
engaged
on
the
28th
.
<EOS>
Yours
always
,
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
At
this
period
he
did
his
best
to
keep
out
of
Mr.
Kennedy
's
way
,
and
would
be
very
cunning
in
his
manoeuvres
that
they
should
not
be
alone
together
.
<EOS>
It
was
difficult
,
as
they
sat
on
the
same
bench
in
the
House
,
and
consequently
saw
each
other
almost
every
day
of
their
lives
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
he
thought
that
with
a
little
cunning
he
might
prevail
,
especially
as
he
was
not
unwilling
to
give
so
much
of
offence
as
might
assist
his
own
object
.
<EOS>
But
when
Mr.
Kennedy
called
upon
him
at
his
office
the
day
after
he
had
written
the
above
note
,
he
had
no
means
of
escape
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
you
can
not
come
to
us
on
the
28th
,
"
Mr.
Kennedy
said
,
as
soon
as
he
was
seated
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
was
taken
so
much
by
surprise
that
all
his
cunning
failed
him
.
"
<EOS>
Well
,
yes
,
"
said
he
;
"
I
was
very
sorry
;
 
very
sorry
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
seems
to
me
,
Finn
,
that
you
have
had
some
reason
for
avoiding
me
of
late
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
that
I
have
done
anything
to
offend
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nothing
on
earth
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
wrong
,
then
,
in
supposing
that
anything
beyond
mere
chance
has
prevented
you
from
coming
to
my
house
?
"
<EOS>
Phineas
felt
that
he
was
in
a
terrible
difficulty
,
and
he
felt
also
that
he
was
being
rather
ill
-
used
in
being
thus
cross
-
examined
as
to
his
reasons
for
not
going
to
a
gentleman
's
dinner
.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
a
man
ought
to
be
allowed
to
choose
where
he
would
go
and
where
he
would
not
go
,
and
that
questions
such
as
these
were
very
uncommon
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
was
sitting
opposite
to
him
,
looking
more
grave
and
more
sour
than
usual
;
 
and
now
his
own
countenance
also
became
a
little
solemn
.
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
that
he
should
use
Lady
Laura
's
name
,
and
yet
he
must
,
in
some
way
,
let
his
persecuting
friend
know
that
no
further
invitation
would
be
of
any
use
;
 
that
there
was
something
beyond
mere
chance
in
his
not
going
to
Grosvenor
Place
.
<EOS>
But
how
was
he
to
do
this
?
<EOS>
The
difficulty
was
so
great
that
he
could
not
see
his
way
out
of
it
.
<EOS>
So
he
sat
silent
with
a
solemn
face
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
then
asked
him
another
question
,
which
made
the
difficulty
ten
times
greater
.
"
<EOS>
Has
my
wife
asked
you
not
to
come
to
our
house
?
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
necessary
now
that
he
should
make
a
rush
and
get
out
of
his
trouble
in
some
way
.
<EOS>
"
To
tell
you
the
truth
,
Kennedy
,
I
do
n't
think
she
wants
to
see
me
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
does
not
answer
my
question
.
<EOS>
Has
she
asked
you
not
to
come
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
said
that
which
left
on
my
mind
an
impression
that
she
would
sooner
that
I
did
not
come
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
did
she
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
answer
such
a
question
as
that
,
Kennedy
?
<EOS>
Is
it
fair
to
ask
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
fair
,
 
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
quite
unfair
,
and
I
must
decline
to
answer
it
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
imagine
what
you
expect
to
gain
by
cross
-
questioning
me
in
this
way
.
<EOS>
Of
course
no
man
likes
to
go
to
a
house
if
he
does
not
believe
that
everybody
there
will
make
him
welcome
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
and
Lady
Laura
used
to
be
great
friends
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
we
are
not
enemies
now
.
<EOS>
But
things
will
occur
that
cause
friendships
to
grow
cool
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
quarrelled
with
her
father
?
"
  
"
With
Lord
Brentford
?
 
no
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Or
with
her
brother
,
 
since
the
duel
I
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Upon
my
word
and
honour
I
can
not
stand
this
,
and
I
will
not
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
as
yet
quarrelled
with
anybody
;
but
I
must
quarrel
with
you
,
if
you
go
on
in
this
way
.
<EOS>
It
is
quite
unusual
that
a
man
should
be
put
through
his
facings
after
such
a
fashion
,
and
I
must
beg
that
there
may
be
an
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
must
ask
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
say
what
you
like
to
your
own
wife
of
course
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
hinder
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Upon
that
Mr.
Kennedy
formally
shook
hands
with
him
,
in
token
that
there
was
no
positive
breach
between
them
,
 
as
two
nations
may
still
maintain
their
alliance
,
though
they
have
made
up
their
minds
to
hate
each
other
,
and
thwart
each
other
at
every
turn
,
 
and
took
his
leave
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
as
he
sat
at
his
window
,
looking
out
into
the
park
,
and
thinking
of
what
had
passed
,
could
not
but
reflect
that
,
disagreeable
as
Mr.
Kennedy
had
been
to
him
,
he
would
probably
make
himself
much
more
disagreeable
to
his
wife
.
<EOS>
And
,
for
himself
,
he
thought
that
he
had
got
out
of
the
scrape
very
well
by
the
exhibition
of
a
little
mock
anger
.
   
<EOS>
The
Earl
's
Wrath
 
<EOS>
The
reader
may
remember
that
a
rumour
had
been
conveyed
to
Phineas
,
 
a
rumour
indeed
which
reached
him
from
a
source
which
he
regarded
as
very
untrustworthy
,
 
that
Violet
Effingham
had
quarrelled
with
her
lover
.
<EOS>
He
would
probably
have
paid
no
attention
to
the
rumour
,
beyond
that
which
necessarily
attached
itself
to
any
tidings
as
to
a
matter
so
full
of
interest
to
him
,
had
it
not
been
repeated
to
him
in
another
quarter
.
<EOS>
"
A
bird
has
told
me
that
your
Violet
Effingham
has
broken
with
her
lover
,
"
Madame
Goesler
said
to
him
one
day
.
"
<EOS>
What
bird
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
that
I
can
not
tell
you
.
<EOS>
But
this
I
will
confess
to
you
,
that
these
birds
which
tell
us
news
are
seldom
very
credible
,
 
and
are
often
not
very
creditable
,
You
must
take
a
bird
's
word
for
what
it
may
be
worth
.
<EOS>
It
is
said
that
they
have
quarrelled
.
<EOS>
I
daresay
,
if
the
truth
were
known
,
they
are
billing
and
cooing
in
each
other
's
arms
at
this
moment
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
did
not
like
to
be
told
of
their
billing
and
cooing
,
 
did
not
like
to
be
told
even
of
their
quarrelling
.
<EOS>
Though
they
were
to
quarrel
,
it
would
do
him
no
good
.
<EOS>
He
would
rather
that
nobody
should
mention
their
names
to
him
;
 
so
that
his
back
,
which
had
been
so
utterly
broken
,
might
in
process
of
time
get
itself
cured
.
<EOS>
From
what
he
knew
of
Violet
he
thought
it
very
improbable
that
,
even
were
she
to
quarrel
with
one
lover
,
she
would
at
once
throw
herself
into
the
arms
of
another
.
<EOS>
And
he
did
feel
,
too
,
that
there
would
be
some
meanness
in
taking
her
,
were
she
willing
to
be
so
taken
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
these
rumours
,
coming
to
him
in
this
way
from
different
sources
,
almost
made
it
incumbent
on
him
to
find
out
the
truth
.
<EOS>
He
began
to
think
that
his
broken
back
was
not
cured
;
 
that
perhaps
,
after
all
,
it
was
not
in
the
way
of
being
cured
,
And
was
it
not
possible
that
there
might
be
explanations
?
<EOS>
Then
he
went
to
work
and
built
castles
in
the
air
,
so
constructed
as
to
admit
of
the
possibility
of
Violet
Effingham
becoming
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
This
had
been
in
April
,
and
at
that
time
all
that
he
knew
of
Violet
was
,
that
she
was
not
yet
in
London
.
<EOS>
And
he
thought
that
he
knew
the
same
as
to
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
had
told
him
that
Chiltern
was
not
in
town
,
nor
expected
in
town
as
yet
;
and
in
saying
so
had
seemed
to
express
displeasure
against
his
son
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
met
Lady
Baldock
at
some
house
which
he
frequented
,
and
had
been
quite
surprised
to
find
himself
graciously
received
by
the
old
woman
.
<EOS>
She
had
said
not
a
word
of
Violet
,
but
had
spoken
of
Lord
Chiltern
,
 
mentioning
his
name
in
bitter
wrath
.
"
<EOS>
But
he
is
a
friend
of
mine
,
"
said
Phineas
,
smiling
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
friend
indeed
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
I
know
what
sort
of
a
friend
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
believe
that
you
are
his
friend
.
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
he
is
not
worthy
of
having
any
friend
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
did
not
quite
understand
from
this
that
Lady
Baldock
was
signifying
to
him
that
,
badly
as
she
had
thought
of
him
as
a
suitor
for
her
niece
,
she
would
have
preferred
him
,
 
especially
now
when
people
were
beginning
to
speak
well
of
him
,
 
to
that
terrible
young
man
,
who
,
from
his
youth
upwards
,
had
been
to
her
a
cause
of
fear
and
trembling
.
<EOS>
Of
course
it
was
desirable
that
Violet
should
marry
an
elder
son
,
and
a
peer
's
heir
.
<EOS>
All
that
kind
of
thing
,
in
Lady
Baldock
's
eyes
,
was
most
desirable
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
anything
was
better
than
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
If
Violet
would
not
take
Mr.
Appledom
or
Lord
Fawn
,
in
heaven
's
name
let
her
take
this
young
man
,
who
was
kind
,
worthy
,
and
steady
,
who
was
civilised
in
his
manners
,
and
would
no
doubt
be
amenable
in
regard
to
settlements
.
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
had
so
far
fallen
in
the
world
that
she
would
have
consented
to
make
a
bargain
with
her
niece
,
 
almost
any
bargain
,
so
long
as
Lord
Chiltern
was
excluded
.
<EOS>
Phineas
did
not
quite
understand
all
this
;
but
when
Lady
Baldock
asked
him
to
come
to
Berkeley
Square
,
he
perceived
that
help
was
being
proffered
to
him
where
he
certainly
had
not
looked
for
help
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
frequently
with
Lord
Brentford
,
who
talked
to
him
constantly
on
matters
connected
with
his
parliamentary
life
.
<EOS>
After
having
been
the
intimate
friend
of
the
daughter
and
of
the
son
,
it
now
seemed
to
be
his
lot
to
be
the
intimate
friend
of
the
father
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
had
constantly
discussed
with
him
his
arrangements
with
his
son
,
and
had
lately
expressed
himself
as
only
half
satisfied
with
such
reconciliation
as
had
taken
place
.
<EOS>
And
Phineas
could
perceive
that
from
day
to
day
the
Earl
was
less
and
less
satisfied
.
<EOS>
He
would
complain
bitterly
of
his
son
,
 
complain
of
his
silence
,
complain
of
his
not
coming
to
London
,
complain
of
his
conduct
to
Violet
,
complain
of
his
idle
indifference
to
anything
like
proper
occupation
;
but
he
had
never
as
yet
said
a
word
to
show
that
there
had
been
any
quarrel
between
Violet
and
her
lover
,
and
Phineas
had
felt
that
he
could
not
ask
the
question
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
,
"
said
the
Earl
to
him
one
morning
,
as
soon
as
he
entered
the
room
,
"
I
have
just
heard
a
story
which
has
almost
seemed
to
me
to
be
incredible
.
<EOS>
"
The
nobleman
's
manner
was
very
stern
,
and
the
fact
that
he
called
his
young
friend
"
Mr.
Finn
"
,
showed
at
once
that
something
was
wrong
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
you
have
heard
,
my
lord
?
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
you
and
Chiltern
went
over
,
 
last
year
to
,
 
Belgium
,
and
fought
,
 
a
duel
there
!
"
  
<EOS>
Now
it
must
have
been
the
case
that
,
in
the
set
among
which
they
all
lived
,
 
Lord
Brentford
and
his
son
and
daughter
and
Phineas
Finn
,
 
the
old
lord
was
the
only
man
who
had
not
heard
of
the
duel
before
this
.
<EOS>
It
had
even
penetrated
to
the
dull
ears
of
Mr.
Kennedy
,
reminding
him
,
as
it
did
so
,
that
his
wife
had
,
 
told
him
a
lie
!
<EOS>
But
it
was
the
fact
that
no
rumour
of
the
duel
had
reached
the
Earl
till
this
morning
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
true
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
been
so
much
shocked
in
my
life
;
 
never
.
<EOS>
I
had
no
idea
that
you
had
any
thought
of
aspiring
to
the
hand
of
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
lord
's
voice
as
he
said
this
was
very
stern
.
  
<EOS>
"
As
I
aspired
in
vain
,
and
as
Chiltern
has
been
successful
,
that
need
not
now
be
made
a
reproach
against
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
what
to
think
of
it
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
I
am
so
much
surprised
that
I
hardly
know
what
to
say
.
<EOS>
I
must
declare
my
opinion
at
once
,
that
you
behaved
,
 
very
badly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
how
much
you
know
,
my
lord
,
and
how
much
you
do
not
know
;
and
the
circumstances
of
the
little
affair
do
not
permit
me
to
be
explicit
about
them
;
but
,
as
you
have
expressed
your
opinion
<EOS>
so
openly
you
must
allow
me
to
express
mine
,
and
to
say
that
,
as
far
as
I
can
judge
of
my
own
actions
,
I
did
not
behave
badly
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
intend
to
defend
duelling
,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
<EOS>
If
you
mean
to
tell
me
that
a
duel
is
of
itself
sinful
,
I
have
nothing
to
say
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
it
is
.
<EOS>
My
defence
of
myself
merely
goes
to
the
manner
in
which
this
duel
was
fought
,
and
the
fact
that
I
fought
it
with
your
son
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
conceive
how
you
can
have
come
to
my
house
as
my
guest
,
and
stood
upon
my
interest
for
my
borough
,
when
you
at
the
time
were
doing
your
very
best
to
interpose
yourself
between
Chiltern
and
the
lady
whom
you
so
well
knew
I
wished
to
become
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
was
aware
that
the
Earl
must
have
been
very
much
moved
indeed
when
he
thus
permitted
himself
to
speak
of
"
his
"
borough
.
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
now
,
however
,
though
the
Earl
paused
;
 
and
then
the
angry
lord
went
on
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
say
that
there
was
something
,
 
something
almost
approaching
to
duplicity
in
such
conduct
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
were
to
defend
myself
by
evidence
,
Lord
Brentford
,
I
should
have
to
go
back
to
exact
dates
,
 
and
dates
not
of
facts
which
I
could
verify
,
but
dates
as
to
my
feelings
which
could
not
be
verified
,
 
and
that
would
be
useless
.
<EOS>
I
can
only
say
that
I
believe
I
know
what
the
honour
and
truth
of
a
gentleman
demand
,
 
even
to
the
verge
of
self
-
sacrifice
,
and
that
I
have
done
nothing
that
ought
to
place
my
character
as
a
gentleman
in
jeopardy
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
ask
your
son
,
I
think
he
will
tell
you
the
same
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
asked
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
he
who
told
me
of
the
duel
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
did
he
tell
you
,
my
lord
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Just
now
;
this
morning
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Thus
Phineas
learned
that
Lord
Chiltern
was
at
this
moment
in
the
house
,
 
or
at
least
in
London
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
did
he
complain
of
my
conduct
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
complain
of
it
,
sir
.
<EOS>
I
complain
of
it
very
bitterly
.
<EOS>
I
placed
the
greatest
confidence
in
you
,
especially
in
regard
to
my
son
's
affairs
,
and
you
deceived
me
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Earl
was
very
angry
,
and
was
more
angry
from
the
fact
that
this
young
man
who
had
offended
him
,
to
whom
he
had
given
such
vital
assistance
when
assistance
was
needed
,
had
used
that
assistance
to
its
utmost
before
his
sin
was
found
out
.
<EOS>
Had
Phineas
still
been
sitting
for
Loughton
,
so
that
the
Earl
could
have
said
to
him
,
"
You
are
now
bound
to
retreat
from
this
borough
because
you
have
offended
me
,
your
patron
,
"
I
think
that
he
would
have
forgiven
the
offender
and
allowed
him
to
remain
in
his
seat
.
<EOS>
There
would
have
been
a
scene
,
and
the
Earl
would
have
been
pacified
.
<EOS>
But
now
the
offender
was
beyond
his
reach
altogether
,
having
used
the
borough
as
a
most
convenient
stepping
-
stone
over
his
difficulties
,
and
having
so
used
it
just
at
the
time
when
he
was
committing
this
sin
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
good
fortune
about
Phineas
which
added
greatly
to
the
lord
's
wrath
.
<EOS>
And
then
,
to
tell
the
truth
,
he
had
not
that
rich
consolation
for
which
Phineas
gave
him
credit
.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
had
told
him
that
morning
that
the
engagement
between
him
and
Violet
was
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
so
preached
to
her
,
my
lord
,
about
my
duties
,
"
the
son
had
said
to
his
father
,
"
that
she
finds
herself
obliged
to
give
me
your
sermons
at
second
hand
,
till
I
can
bear
them
no
longer
.
"
<EOS>
But
of
this
Phineas
knew
nothing
as
yet
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
,
however
,
was
so
imprudent
in
his
anger
that
before
this
interview
was
over
he
had
told
the
whole
story
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
 
<EOS>
you
deceived
me
,
"
he
continued
;
"
and
I
can
never
trust
you
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
it
for
me
,
my
lord
,
to
tell
you
of
that
which
would
have
increased
your
anger
against
your
own
son
?
<EOS>
When
he
wanted
me
to
fight
was
I
to
come
,
like
a
sneak
at
school
,
and
tell
you
the
story
?
<EOS>
I
know
what
you
would
have
thought
of
me
had
I
done
so
.
<EOS>
And
when
it
was
over
was
I
to
come
and
tell
you
then
?
<EOS>
Think
what
you
yourself
would
have
done
when
you
were
young
,
and
you
may
be
quite
sure
that
I
did
the
same
.
<EOS>
What
have
I
gained
?
<EOS>
He
has
got
all
that
he
wanted
;
and
you
have
also
got
all
that
you
wanted
;
 
and
I
have
helped
you
both
.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
,
I
can
put
my
hand
on
my
heart
and
say
that
I
have
been
honest
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
got
nothing
that
I
wanted
,
"
said
the
Earl
in
his
despair
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lord
Chiltern
and
Miss
Effingham
will
be
man
and
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
they
will
not
.
<EOS>
He
has
quarrelled
with
her
.
<EOS>
He
is
so
obstinate
that
she
will
not
bear
with
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
it
was
all
true
,
even
though
the
rumours
had
reached
him
through
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
and
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
my
lord
,
that
has
not
been
my
fault
,
"
he
said
,
after
a
moment
's
hesitation
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
was
walking
up
and
down
the
room
,
angry
with
himself
at
his
own
mistake
in
having
told
the
story
,
and
not
knowing
what
further
to
say
to
his
visitor
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
in
the
habit
of
talking
so
freely
to
Phineas
about
his
son
that
he
could
hardly
resist
the
temptation
of
doing
so
still
;
and
yet
it
was
impossible
that
he
could
swallow
his
anger
and
continue
in
the
same
strain
.
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
"
said
Phineas
,
after
a
while
,
"
I
can
assure
you
that
I
grieve
that
you
should
be
grieved
.
<EOS>
I
have
received
so
much
undeserved
favour
from
your
family
,
that
I
owe
you
a
debt
which
I
can
never
pay
.
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
that
you
should
be
angry
with
me
now
;
but
I
hope
that
a
time
may
come
when
you
will
think
less
severely
of
my
conduct
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
about
to
leave
the
room
when
the
Earl
stopped
him
.
"
<EOS>
Will
you
give
me
your
word
,
"
said
the
Earl
,
"
that
you
will
think
no
more
of
Miss
Effingham
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
stood
silent
,
considering
how
he
might
answer
this
proposal
,
resolving
that
nothing
should
bring
him
to
such
a
pledge
as
that
suggested
while
there
was
yet
a
ledge
for
hope
to
stand
on
.
"
<EOS>
Say
that
,
Mr.
Finn
,
and
I
will
forgive
everything
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
acknowledge
that
I
have
done
anything
to
be
forgiven
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Say
that
,
"
repeated
the
Earl
,
"
and
everything
shall
be
forgotten
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
need
be
no
cause
for
alarm
,
my
lord
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
sure
that
Miss
Effingham
will
not
think
of
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
give
me
your
word
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
lord
;
 
certainly
not
.
<EOS>
You
have
no
right
to
ask
it
,
and
the
pursuit
is
open
to
me
as
to
any
other
man
who
may
choose
to
follow
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
hardly
a
vestige
of
a
hope
of
success
.
<EOS>
It
is
barely
possible
that
I
should
succeed
.
<EOS>
But
if
it
be
true
that
Miss
Effingham
be
disengaged
,
I
shall
endeavour
to
find
an
opportunity
of
urging
my
suit
.
<EOS>
I
would
give
up
everything
that
I
have
,
my
seat
in
Parliament
,
all
the
ambition
of
my
life
,
for
the
barest
chance
of
success
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
accepted
your
son
,
I
desisted
,
 
of
course
.
<EOS>
I
have
now
heard
,
from
more
sources
than
one
,
that
she
or
he
or
both
of
them
have
changed
their
minds
.
<EOS>
If
this
be
so
,
I
am
free
to
try
again
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Earl
stood
opposite
to
him
,
scowling
at
him
,
but
said
nothing
.
"
<EOS>
Good
morning
,
my
lord
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
morning
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
it
must
be
good
-
bye
,
for
some
long
days
to
come
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
morning
,
sir
,
"
And
the
Earl
as
he
spoke
rang
the
bell
.
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
took
up
his
hat
and
departed
.
  
<EOS>
As
he
walked
away
his
mind
filled
itself
gradually
with
various
ideas
,
all
springing
from
the
words
which
Lord
Brentford
had
spoken
.
<EOS>
What
account
had
Lord
Chiltern
given
to
his
father
of
the
duel
?
<EOS>
Our
hero
was
a
man
very
sensitive
as
to
the
good
opinion
of
others
,
and
in
spite
of
his
bold
assertion
of
his
own
knowledge
of
what
became
a
gentleman
,
was
beyond
measure
solicitous
that
others
should
acknowledge
his
claim
at
any
rate
to
that
title
.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
he
had
been
generous
to
Lord
Chiltern
;
and
as
he
went
back
in
his
memory
over
almost
every
word
that
had
been
spoken
in
the
interview
that
had
just
passed
,
he
fancied
that
he
was
able
to
collect
evidence
that
his
antagonist
at
Blankenberg
had
not
spoken
ill
of
him
.
<EOS>
As
to
the
charge
of
deceit
which
the
Earl
had
made
against
him
,
he
told
himself
that
the
Earl
had
made
it
in
anger
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
even
think
hardly
of
the
Earl
who
had
been
so
good
<EOS>
a
friend
to
him
,
<EOS>
but
he
believed
in
his
heart
that
the
Earl
had
made
the
accusation
out
of
his
wrath
and
not
out
of
his
judgment
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
can
not
think
that
I
have
been
false
to
him
,
"
Phineas
said
to
himself
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
very
sad
to
him
that
he
should
have
to
quarrel
with
all
the
family
of
the
Standishes
,
as
he
could
not
but
feel
that
it
was
they
who
had
put
him
on
his
feet
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
as
though
he
were
never
to
see
Lady
Laura
again
except
when
they
chanced
to
meet
in
company
,
 
on
which
occasions
he
simply
bowed
to
her
.
<EOS>
Now

Earl
had
almost

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
Madame
Goesler
's
Politics
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
remembered
that
when
Lady
Glencora
Palliser
was
shown
into
Madame
Goesler
's
room
,
Madame
Goesler
had
just
explained
somewhat
forcibly
to
the
Duke
of
Omnium
her

for
refusing
the
loan
of
his
Grace
's
villa
at
Como
.
<EOS>
She
had
told
the
Duke
in
so
many
words
that
she
did
not
mean

give
the
world
an

of
maligning

,
and
it
would
then
have
been

Duke
to

other

might
have
been

for
taking
Madame
Goesler
to
Como
,
had
he
not
been
interrupted
.
<EOS>
That
he
was
very
anxious
to
take
her
<EOS>
was
certain
.
<EOS>
The
green
brougham
had
already
been
often
enough
at
the
door
in
Park
Lane
to
make
his
Grace
feel
that
Madame
Goesler
's
company
was
very

,
 
was
,
perhaps
,
of

his

,
the
one
thing
the
most
desirable
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
had
spoken
to
her

of
children
crying
for
the
top
brick
of
the
chimney
.
<EOS>
Now
it
had
come
to
this
,
that
in
the

the
Duke
of
Omnium
Marie
Max
Goesler
was
the
top

of
the

.
<EOS>
She
had
more
wit
for
him
than

,
 
more

.
<EOS>
She

a

to

more

other

.
<EOS>
He
was
sick
of
fair

,
and

,
and
free

.
<EOS>
Madame
Goesler
's
eyes
sparkled
as
other

did
not

,
and
there
was
something
of
the

of

,
 
as

was
the

of

world
which
he
had
not
yet
known
.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
The

Duke
had
of

had
been
somewhat

,
 
perhaps

,
 
though
,

.
<EOS>
In

,

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
Lady

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

But

<EOS>
So

<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
Madame

,

,

,

,

and

.
<EOS>
When

with
something

hour

,

,
or
trying
to
resolve
<EOS>
,
what
should
be
her
conduct
.
<EOS>
She
did
few

without
much

,
and
though
she
walked
very

,

.
<EOS>
She
often
told
herself
that
such

as

had

much

.
<EOS>
And
yet
she
was
ever
discontented
with

,
telling

that
all

done
was
nothing
,

.
<EOS>
What
was

all
,
to

,
to

lords

,
if

her
,

!
<EOS>
Life

her
was
dull
,

.
<EOS>
And
what
if

caught

man
,

,

to

,

,

<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
Were

?
  
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

?
<EOS>
Money

already

;

.
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
But

Omnium
!
<EOS>
After

,

;

.
<EOS>
There

,

;

,

ill

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
As

she

that
probably

.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
had
treated

,
and

.
<EOS>
As

of
Omnium
she
would

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
<EOS>
In

,
one

would
of
course

.
<EOS>
She
and
Lady
Glencora
would
understand

;
 
and
no

,
respect

.
  
<EOS>
I
have
said
that
she
would
sit
there
resolving
,
or
trying
to
resolve
.
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
in
the
world
so
difficult
as
that
task
of
making
up
one
's
mind
.
<EOS>
Who
is
there
that
has
not
longed
that
the
power
and

of
selection
among
alternatives
should
be
taken
away
from
him
in
some
important

of
his
life
,
and
that
his
conduct
should
be
arranged
for

,
either
this
way
or
that
,
by
some

,

some

,
 
or

,

better

chance
could
be

?
<EOS>
But
no
one
dares
to
cast
the
die
,
and
to
go
honestly
by
the

.
<EOS>
There
must
be
the
actual

of
obeying
the
die
,
before
even

can
be
of

.
<EOS>
As

,

Madame
Goesler
had

for
an

,
till
her

were

,
she
had

.
<EOS>
It
must
be
as
her

should

when

.
<EOS>
There

not

could
go
for
counsel
,
and
when
she
asked

for
counsel
,
the
