.
  
<EOS>
Two
days
afterwards
the
Duke
called
again
.
<EOS>
He
would
come
generally
on
a
Thursday
,
 
early
,
so
that
he
might
be
there
before
other
visitors
;
and
he
had
already
quite
learned
that
when
he
was
there
other
visitors
would
probably
be
refused
admittance
.
<EOS>
How
Lady
Glencora
had
made
her
way
in
,
telling
the
servant
that
her
uncle
was
there
,
he
had
not
understood
.
<EOS>
That
visit
had
been
made
on
the
Thursday
,
but
now
he
came
on
the
Saturday
,
 
having
,
I
regret
to
say
,
sent
down
some
early
fruit
from
his
own
hot
-
houses
,
 
or
from
Covent
Garden
,
 
with
a
little
note
on
the
previous
day
.
<EOS>
The
grapes
might
have
been
pretty
well
,
but
the
note
was
injudicious
.
<EOS>
There
were
three
lines
about
the
grapes
,
as
to
which
there
was
some
special
history
,
the
vine
having
been
brought
from
the
garden
of
some
villa
in
which
some
ill
-
used
queen
had
lived
and
died
;
and
then
there
was
a
postscript
in
one
line
to
say
that
the
Duke
would
call
on
the
following
morning
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
that
he
had
meant
to
add
this
when
he
began
his
note
;
but
then
children
,
who
want
the
top
brick
,
want
it
so
badly
,
and
cry
for
it
so
perversely
!
  
<EOS>
Of
course
Madame
Goesler
was
at
home
.
<EOS>
But
even
then
she
had
not
made
up
her
mind
.
<EOS>
She
had
made
up
her
mind
only
to
this
,
 
that
he
should
be
made
to
speak
plainly
,
and
that
she
would
take
time
for
her
reply
.
<EOS>
Not
even
with
such
a
gem
as
the
Duke
's
coronet
before
her
eyes
,
would
she
jump
at
it
.
<EOS>
Where
there
was
so
much
doubt
,
there
need
at
least
be
no
impatience
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
ran
away
the
other
day
,
Duke
,
because
you
could
not
resist
the
charm
of
that
little
boy
,
"
she
said
,
laughing
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
dear
little
boy
,
 
<EOS>
but
it
was
not
that
,
"
he
answered
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
what
was
it
?
<EOS>
Your
niece
carried
you
off
in
a
whirl
-
wind
.
<EOS>
She
was
come
and
gone
,
taking
you
with
her
,
in
half
a
minute
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
had
disturbed
me
when
I
was
thinking
of
something
,
"
said
the
Duke
.
  
<EOS>
"
Things
should
n't
be
thought
of
,
 
not
so
deeply
as
that
.
"
<EOS>
Madame
Goesler
was
playing
with
a
bunch
of
his
grapes
now
,
eating
one
or
two
from
a
small
china
plate
which
had
stood
upon
the
table
,
and
he
thought
that
he
had
never
seen
a
woman
so
graceful
and
yet
so
natural
.
"
<EOS>
Will
you
not
eat
your
own
grapes
with
me
?
<EOS>
They
are
delicious
;
 
flavoured
with
the
poor
queen
's
sorrows
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
shook
his
head
,
knowing
that
it
did
not
suit
his
gastric
juices
to
have
to
deal
with
fruit
eaten
at
odd
times
.
"
<EOS>
Never
think
,
Duke
.
<EOS>
I
am
convinced
that
it
does
no
good
.
<EOS>
It
simply
means
doubting
,
and
doubt
always
leads
to
error
.
<EOS>
The
safest
way
in
the
world
is
to
do
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
so
,
"
said
the
Duke
.
  
<EOS>
"
Much
the
safest
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
have
not
sufficient
command
over
yourself
to
enable
you
to
sit
in
repose
,
always
quiet
,
never
committing
yourself
to
the
chance
of
any
danger
,
 
then
take
a
leap
in
the
dark
;
or
rather
many
leaps
.
<EOS>
A
stumbling
horse
regains
his
footing
by
persevering
in
his
onward
course
.
<EOS>
As
for
moving
cautiously
,
that
I
detest
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
yet
one
must
think
;
 
for
instance
,
whether
one
will
succeed
or
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Take
that
for
granted
always
.
<EOS>
Remember
,
I
do
not
recommend
motion
at
all
.
<EOS>
Repose
is
my
idea
of
life
;
 
repose
and
grapes
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Duke
sat
for
a
while
silent
,
taking
his
repose
as
far
as
the
outer
man
was
concerned
,
looking
at
his
top
brick
of
the
chimney
,
as
from
time
to
time
she
ate
one
of
his
grapes
.
<EOS>
Probably
she
did
not
eat
above
half
-
a
-
dozen
of
them
altogether
,
but
he
thought
that
the
grapes
must
have
been
made
for
the
woman
,
she
was
so
pretty
in
the
eating
of
them
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
necessary
that
he
should
speak
at
last
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have
you
been
thinking
of
coming
to
Como
?
<EOS>
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
that
I
never
think
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
want
an
answer
to
my
proposition
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
I
had
answered
your
Grace
on
that
question
.
<EOS>
"
Then
she
put
down
the
grapes
,
and
moved
herself
on
her
chair
,
so
that
she
sat
with
her
face
turned
away
from
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
a
request
to
a
lady
may
be
made
twice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
.
<EOS>
And
I
am
grateful
,
knowing
how
far
it
is
from
your
intention
to
do
me
any
harm
.
<EOS>
And
I
am
somewhat
ashamed
of
my
warmth
on
the
other
day
.
<EOS>
But
still
there
can
be
but
one
answer
.
<EOS>
There
are
delights
which
a
woman
must
deny
herself
,
let
them
be
ever
so
delightful
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
had
thought
,
 
"
the
Duke
began
,
and
then
he
stopped
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
Grace
was
saying
that
you
thought
,
 
"
  
"
Marie
,
a
man
at
my
age
does
not
like
to
be
denied
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
man
likes
to
be
denied
anything
by
a
woman
at
any
age
?
<EOS>
A
woman
who
denies
anything
is
called
cruel
at
once
,
 
even
though
it
be
her
very
soul
.
<EOS>
"
She
had
turned
round
upon
him
now
,
and
was
leaning
forward
towards
him
from
her
chair
,
so
that
he
could
touch
her
if
he
put
out
his
hand
.
  
<EOS>
He
put
out
his
hand
and
touched
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Marie
,
"
he
said
,
"
will
you
deny
me
if
I
ask
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
my
lord
;
how
shall
I
say
?
<EOS>
There
is
many
a
trifle
I
would
deny
you
.
<EOS>
There
is
many
a
great
gift
I
would
give
you
willingly
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
the
greatest
gift
of
all
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
lord
,
if
you
have
anything
to
say
,
you
must
say
it
plainly
.
<EOS>
There
never
was
a
woman
worse
than
I
am
at
the
reading
of
riddles
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Could
you
endure
to
live
in
the
quietude
of
an
Italian
lake
with
an
old
man
?
"
Now
he
touched
her
again
,
and
had
taken
her
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
lord
;
 
nor
with
a
young
one
,
 
for
all
my
days
.
<EOS>
But
I
do
not
know
that
age
would
guide
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
the
Duke
rose
and
made
his
proposition
in
form
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Marie
,
you
know
that
I
love
you
.
<EOS>
Why
it
is
that
I
at
my
age
should
feel
so
sore
a
love
,
I
can
not
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
So
sore
a
love
!
"
  
"
So
sore
,
if
it
be
not
gratified
.
<EOS>
Marie
,
I
ask
you
to
be
my
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Duke
of
Omnium
,
this
from
you
!
"
  
"
Yes
,
from
me
.
<EOS>
My
coronet
is
at
your
feet
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
allow
me
to
raise
it
,
I
will
place
it
on
your
brow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
she
went
away
from
him
,
and
seated
herself
at
a
distance
.
<EOS>
After
a
moment
or
two
he
followed
her
,
and
stood
with
his
arm
upon
her
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
give
me
an
answer
,
Marie
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
have
thought
of
this
,
my
lord
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nay
;
I
have
thought
of
it
much
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
your
friends
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
I
may
venture
to
please
myself
in
this
,
 
as
in
everything
.
<EOS>
Will
you
not

me
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly
not
on
the
spur
of
the
moment
,
my
lord
.
<EOS>
Think
how
high
is
the
position
you
offer
me
,
and
how
immense
is
the
change
you
propose
to
me
.
<EOS>
Allow
me
two
days
,
and
I
will
answer

by

.
<EOS>
I
am
so
fluttered
now
that
I
must
leave
you
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
came
to
her
,
took
her
hand
,
kissed
her
brow
,
and
opened
the
door
for
her
.
   
<EOS>
Another
Duel
 
<EOS>
It
happened
that
there
were
at
this
time
certain
matters
of
business
to
be
settled
between
the
Duke
of
Omnium
and
his
nephew
Mr.
Palliser
,
respecting
which
the
latter
called
upon
his
uncle
on
the
morning
after
the
Duke
had
committed
himself
by
his
offer
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
had
come
by
appointment
made
with
Mr.
Fothergill
,
the
Duke
's
man
of
business
,
and
had
expected
to
meet
Mr.
Fothergill
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Fothergill
,
however
,
was
not
with
the
Duke
,
and
the
uncle
told
the
nephew
that
the
business
had
been
postponed
.
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Palliser
asked
some
question
as
to
the
reason
of
such
postponement
,
not
meaning
much
by
his
question
,
 
and
the
Duke
,
after
a
moment
's
hesitation
,
answered
him
,
meaning
very
much
by
his
answer
.
"
<EOS>
The
truth
is
,
Plantagenet
,
that
it
is
possible
that
I
may
marry
,
and
if
so
this
arrangement
would
not
suit
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
to
be
married
?
"
asked
the
astonished
nephew
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
exactly
that
,
 
but
it
is
possible
that
I
may
do
so
.
<EOS>
Since
I
proposed
this
matter
to
Fothergill
,
I
have
been
thinking
over
it
,
and
I
have
changed
my
mind
.
<EOS>
It
will
make
but
<EOS>
little
difference
to
you
;
and
after
all
you
are
a
far
richer
man
than
I
am
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
thinking
of
money
,
Duke
,
"
said
Plantagenet
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
what
then
were
you
thinking
?
"
  
"
Simply
of
what
you
told
me
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
in
the
least
mean
to
interfere
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
Plantagenet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
could
not
hear
such
a
statement
from
you
without
some
surprise
.
<EOS>
Whatever
you
do
<EOS>
I
hope
will
tend
to
make
you
happy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
much
passed
between
the
uncle
and
the
nephew
,
and
what
the
uncle
told
to
the
nephew
,
the
nephew
of
course
told
to
his
wife
.
"
<EOS>
He
was
with
her
again
,
yesterday
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
"
for
more
than
an
hour
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
been
half
the
morning
dressing
himself
before
he
went
to
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
not
engaged
to
her
,
or
he
would
have
told
me
,
"
said
Plantagenet
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
would
,
but
there
is
no
knowing
.
<EOS>
At
the
present
moment
I
have
only
one
doubt
,
 
whether
to
act
upon
him
or
upon
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
see
that
you
can
do
good
by
going
to
either
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
we
will
see
.
<EOS>
If
she
be
the
woman
I
take
her
to
be
,
I
think
I
could
do
something
with
her
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
supposed
her
to
be
a
bad
woman
,
 
never
.
<EOS>
I
will
think
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Glencora
left
her
husband
,
and
did
not
consult
him
afterwards
as
to
the
course
she
would
pursue
.
<EOS>
He
had
his
budget
to
manage
,
and
his
speeches
to
make
.
<EOS>
The
little
affair
of
the
Duke
and
Madame
Goesler
<EOS>
,
she
thought
it
best
to
take
into
her
own
hands
without
any
assistance
from
him
.
<EOS>
"
What
a
fool
I
was
,
"
she
said
to
herself
,
"
to
have
her
down
there
when
the
Duke
was
at
Matching
!
"
  
<EOS>
Madame
Goesler
,
when
she
was
left
alone
,
felt
that
now
indeed
she
must
make
up
her
mind
.
<EOS>
She
had
asked
for
two
days
.
<EOS>
The
intervening
day
was
a
Sunday
,
and
on
the
Monday
she
must
send
her
answer
.
<EOS>
She
might
doubt
at
any
rate
for
this
one
night
,
 
the
Saturday
night
,
 
and
sit
playing
,
as
it
were
,
with
the
coronet
of
a
duchess
in
her
lap
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
born
the
daughter
of
a
small
country
attorney
,
and
now
a
duke
had
asked
her
to
be
his
wife
,
 
and
a
duke
who
was
acknowledged
to
stand
above
other
dukes
!
<EOS>
Nothing
at
any
rate
could
rob
her
of
that
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
Whatever
resolution
she
might
form
at
last
,
she
had
by
her
own
resources
reached
a
point
of
success
in
remembering
which
there
would
always
be
a
keen
gratification
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
much
to
be
Duchess
of
Omnium
;
but
it
would
be
something
also
to
have
refused
to
be
a
Duchess
of
Omnium
.
<EOS>
During
that
evening
,
that
night
,
and
the
next
morning
,
she
remained
playing
with
the
coronet
in
her
lap
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
go
to
church
.
<EOS>
What
good
could
any
sermon
do
her
while
that
bauble
was
dangling
before
her
eyes
?
<EOS>
After
church
-
time
,
about
two
o'clock
,
Phineas
Finn
came
to
her
.
<EOS>
Just
at
this
period
Phineas
would
come
to
her
often
;
 
sometimes
full
of
a
new
decision
to
forget
Violet
Effingham
altogether
,
at
others
minded
to
continue
his
siege
<EOS>
let
the
hope
of
success
be
ever
so
small
.
<EOS>
He
had
now
heard
that
Violet
and
Lord
Chiltern
had
in
truth
quarrelled
,
and
was
of
course
anxious
to
be
advised
to
continue
the
siege
.
<EOS>
When
he
first
came
in
and
spoke
a
word
or
two
,
in
which
there
was
no
reference
to
Violet
Effingham
,
there
came
upon
Madame
Goesler
a
strong
wish
to
decide
at
once
that
she
would
play
no
longer
with
the
coronet
,
that
the
gem
was
not
worth
the
cost
she
would
be
called
upon
to
pay
for
it
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
the
world
better
for
her
than
the
coronet
,
 
if
only
it
might
be
had
.
<EOS>
But
within
ten
minutes
he
had
told
her
the
whole
tale
about
Lord
Chiltern
,
and
how
he
had
seen
Violet
at
Lady
Baldock
's
,
 
and
how
there
might
yet
be
hope
for
him
.
<EOS>
What
would
she
advise
him
to
do
?
"
<EOS>
Go
home
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
write
a
sonnet
to
her
eyebrow
.
<EOS>
See
if
that
will
have
any
effect
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
well
!
<EOS>
It
is
natural
that
you
should
laugh
at
me
;
but
somehow
,
I
did
not
expect
it
from
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
be
angry
with
me
.
<EOS>
What
I
mean
is
that
such
little
things
seem
to
influence
this
Violet
of
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
they
?
<EOS>
I
have
not
found
that
they
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
she
had
loved
Lord
Chiltern
she
would
not
have
quarrelled
with
him
for
a
few
words
.
<EOS>
If
she
had
loved
you
,
she
would
not
have
accepted
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
If
she
loves
neither
of
you
,
she
should
say
so
.
<EOS>
I
am
losing
my
respect
for
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
say
that
,
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
I
respect
her
as
strongly
as
I
love
her
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Madame
Goesler
almost
made
up
her
mind
that
she
would
have
the
coronet
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
substance
about
the
coronet
that
would
not
elude
her
grasp
.
  
<EOS>
Late
that
afternoon
,
while
she
was
still
hesitating
,
there
came
another
caller
to
the
cottage
in
Park
Lane
.
<EOS>
She
was
still
hesitating
,
feeling
that
she
had
as
yet
another
night
before
her
.
<EOS>
Should
she
be
Duchess
of
Omnium
or
not
?
<EOS>
All
that
she
wished
to
be
,
she
could
not
be
;
 
but
to
be
<EOS>
Duchess
of
Omnium
was
within
her
reach
.
<EOS>
Then
she
began
to
ask
herself
various
questions
.
<EOS>
Would
the
Queen
refuse
to
accept
her
in
her
new
rank
?
<EOS>
Refuse
!
<EOS>
How
could
any
Queen
refuse
to
accept
her
?
<EOS>
She
had
not
done
aught
amiss
in
life
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
slur
on
her
name
;
no
stain
on
her
character
.
<EOS>
What
though
her
father
had
been
a
small
attorney
,
and
her
first
husband
a
Jew
banker
!
<EOS>
She
had
broken
no
law
of
God
or
man
,
had
been
accused
of
breaking
no
law
,
which
breaking
or
which
accusation
need
stand
in
the
way
of
her
being
as
good
a
duchess
as
any
other
woman
!
<EOS>
She
was
sitting
thinking
of
this
,
almost
angry
with
herself
at
the
awe
with
which
the
proposed
rank
inspired
her
,
when
Lady
Glencora
was
announced
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Madame
Goesler
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
"
I
am
very
glad
to
find
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
more
than
equally
so
,
to
be
found
,
"
said
Madame
Goesler
,
smiling
with
all
her
grace
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
uncle
has
been
with
you
since
I
saw
you
last
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
;
 
more
than
once
if
I
remember
right
.
<EOS>
He
was
here
yesterday
at
any
rate
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
comes
often
to
you
then
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
so
often
as
I
would
wish
,
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
is
one
of
my
dearest
friends
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
a
quick
friendship
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;
 
a
quick
friendship
,
"
said
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
Then
there
was
a
pause
for
some
moments
which
Madame
Goesler
was
determined
that
she
would
not
break
.
<EOS>
It
was
clear
to
her
now
on
what
ground
Lady
Glencora
had
come
to
her
,
and
she
was
fully
minded
that
if
she
could
bear
the
full
light
of
the
god
himself
in
all
his
glory
,
she
would
not
allow
herself
to
be
scorched
by
any
reflected
heat
coming
from
the
god
's
niece
.
<EOS>
She
thought
she
could
endure
anything
that
Lady
Glencora
might
say
;
but
she
would
wait
and
hear
what
might
be
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
Madame
Goesler
,
that
I
had
better
hurry
on
to
my
subject
at
once
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
almost
hesitating
as
she
spoke
,
and
feeling
that
the
colour
was
rushing
up
to
her
cheeks
and
covering
her
brow
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
what
I
have
to
say
will
be
disagreeable
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
shall
offend
you
.
<EOS>
And
yet
I
do
not
mean
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
offended
at
nothing
,
Lady
Glencora
,
unless
I
think
that
you
mean
to
offend
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
protest
that
I
do
not
.
<EOS>
You
have
seen
my
little
boy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
The
sweetest
child
!
<EOS>
God
never
gave
me
anything
half
so
precious
as
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
the
Duke
's
heir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
understand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For
myself
,
by
my
honour
as
a
woman
,
I
care
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
am
rich
and
have
all
that
the
world
can
give
me
.
<EOS>
For
my
husband
,
in
this
matter
,
I
care
nothing
.
<EOS>
His
career
he
will
make
for
himself
,
and
it
will
depend
on
no
title
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
all
this
to
me
,
Lady
Glencora
?
<EOS>
What
have
I
to
do
with
your
husband
's
titles
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Much
;
 
if
it
be
true
that
there
is
an
idea
of
marriage
between
you
and
the
Duke
of
Omnium
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Psha
!
"
said
Madame
Goesler
,
with
all
the
scorn
of
which
she
was
mistress
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
untrue
,
then
?
"
asked
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
it
is
not
untrue
.
<EOS>
There
is
an
idea
of
such
a
marriage
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
are
engaged
to
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
I
am
not
engaged
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Has
he
asked
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lady
Glencora
,
I
really
must
say
that
such
a
cross
-
questioning
from
one
lady
to
another
is
very
unusual
.
<EOS>
I
have
promised
not
to
be
offended
,
unless
I
thought
that
you
wished
to
offend
me
.
<EOS>
But
do
not
drive
me
too
far
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Madame
Goesler
,
if
you
will
tell
me
that
I
am
mistaken
,
I
will
beg
your
pardon
,
and
offer
to
you
the
most
sincere
friendship
which
one
woman
can
give
another
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lady
Glencora
,
I
can
tell
you
nothing
of
the
kind
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
it
is
to
be
so
!
<EOS>
And
have
you
thought
what
you
would
gain
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
thought
much
of
what
I
should
gain
:
 
and
something
also
of
what
I
should
lose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
money
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
indeed
;
plenty
,
 
for
wants
so
moderate
as
mine
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
position
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
yes
;
a
sort
of
position
.
<EOS>
Not
such
as
yours
,
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
That
,
if
it
be
not
born
to
a
woman
,
can
only
come
to
her
from
a
husband
.
<EOS>
She
can
not
win
it
for
herself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
free
as
air
,
going
where
you
like
,
and
doing
what
you
like
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Too
free
,
sometimes
,
"
said
Madame
Goesler
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
will
you
gain
by
changing
all
this
simply
for
a
title
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
for
such
a
title
,
Lady
Glencora
!
<EOS>
It
may
be
little
to
you
to
be
Duchess
of
Omnium
,
but
think
what
it
must
be
to
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
for
this
you
will
not
hesitate
to
rob
him
of
all
his
friends
,
to
embitter
his
future
life
,
to
degrade
him
among
his
peers
,
 
"
  
"
Degrade
him
!
<EOS>
Who
dares
say
that
I
shall
degrade
him
?
<EOS>
He
will
exalt
me
,
but
I
shall
no
whit
degrade
him
.
<EOS>
You
forget
yourself
,
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ask
any
one
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
that
I
despise
you
.
<EOS>
If
I
did
,
would
I
offer
you
my
hand
in
friendship
?
<EOS>
But
an
old
man
,
over
seventy
,
carrying
the
weight
and
burden
of
such
rank
as
his
,
will
degrade
himself
in
the
eyes
of
his
fellows
,
if
he
marries
a
young
woman
without
rank
,
let
her
be
ever
so
clever
,
ever
so
beautiful
.
<EOS>
A
Duke
of
Omnium
may
not
do
as
he
pleases
,
as
may
another
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
well
,
Lady
Glencora
,
for
other
dukes
,
and
for
the
daughters
and
heirs
and
cousins
of
other
dukes
,
that
his
Grace
should
try
that
question
.
<EOS>
I
will
,
if
you
wish
it
,
argue
this
matter
with
you
on
many
points
,
but
I
will
not
allow
you
to
say
that
I
should
degrade
any
man
whom
I
might
marry
.
<EOS>
My
name
is
as
unstained
as
your
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
meant
nothing
of
that
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
For
him
;
 
I
certainly
would
not
willingly
injure
him
.
<EOS>
Who
wishes
to
injure
a
friend
?
<EOS>
And
,
in
truth
,
I
have
so
little
to
gain
,
that
the
temptation
to
do
him
an
injury
,
if
I
thought
it
one
,
is
not
strong
.
<EOS>
For
your
little
boy
,
Lady
Glencora
,
I
think
your
fears
are
premature
.
<EOS>
"
As
she
said
this
,
there
came
a
smile
over
her
face
,
which
threatened
to
break
from
control
and
almost
become
laughter
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
if
you
will
allow
me
to
say
so
,
my
mind
will
not
be
turned
against
this
marriage
half
so
strongly
by
any
arguments
you
can
use
as
by
those
which
I
can
adduce
myself
.
<EOS>
You
have
nearly
driven
me
into
it
by
telling
me
I
should
degrade
his
house
.
<EOS>
It
is
almost
incumbent
on
me
to
prove
that
you
are
wrong
.
<EOS>
But
you
had
better
leave
me
to
settle
the
matter
in
my
own
bosom
.
<EOS>
You
had
indeed
.
"
  
<EOS>
After
a
while
Lady
Glencora
did
leave
her
,
 
to
settle
the
matter
within
her
own
bosom
,
 
having
no
other
alternative
.
   
<EOS>
The
Letter
That
Was
Sent
to
Brighton
 
Monday
morning
came
and
Madame
Goesler
had
as
yet
written
no
answer
to
the
Duke
of
Omnium
.
<EOS>
Had
not
Lady
Glencora
gone
to
Park
Lane
on
the
Sunday
afternoon
<EOS>
,
I
think
the
letter
would
have
been
written
on
that
day
;
but
,
whatever
may
have
been
the
effect
of
Lady
Glencora
's
visit
,
it
so
far
disturbed
Madame
Goesler
as
to
keep
her
from
her
writing
-
table
.
<EOS>
There
was
yet
another
night
for
thought
,
and
then
the
letter
should
be
written
on
the
Monday
morning
.
  
<EOS>
When
Lady
Glencora
left
Madame
Goesler
<EOS>
she
went
at
once
to
the
Duke
's
house
.
<EOS>
It
was
her
custom
to
see
her
husband
's
uncle
on
a
Sunday
,
and
she
would
most
frequently
find
him
just
at
this
hour
,
 
before
he
went
up
-
stairs
to
dress
for
dinner
.
<EOS>
She
usually
took
her
boy
with
her
,
but
on
this
occasion
she
went
alone
.
<EOS>
She
had
tried
what
she
could
do
with
Madame
Goesler
,
and
she
found
that
she
had
failed
.
<EOS>
She
must
now
make
her
attempt
upon
the
Duke
.
<EOS>
But
the
Duke
,
perhaps
anticipating
some
attack
of
the
kind
,
had
fled
.
<EOS>
"
Where
is
his
Grace
,
Barker
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
to
the
porter
.
<EOS>
"
We
do
not
know
,
your
ladyship
.
<EOS>
His
Grace
went
away
yesterday
evening
with
nobody
but
Lapoule
.
<EOS>
"
Lapoule
was
the
Duke
's
French
valet
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
could
only
return
home
and
consider
in
her
own
mind
what
batteries
might
yet
be
brought
to
bear
upon
the
Duke
,
towards
stopping
the
marriage
,
even
after
the
engagement
should
have
been
made
,
 
if
it
were
to
be
made
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
felt
that
such
batteries
might
still
be
brought
up
as
would
not
improbably
have
an
effect
on
a
proud
,
weak
old
man
.
<EOS>
If
all
other
resources
failed
,
royalty
in
some
of
its
branches
might
be
induced
to
make
a
request
,
and
every
august
relation
in
the
peerage
should
interfere
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
no
doubt
might
persevere
and
marry
whom
he
pleased
,
 
if
he
were
strong
enough
.
<EOS>
But
it
requires
much
personal
strength
,
 
that
standing
alone
against
the
well
-
armed
batteries
of
all
one
's
friends
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
had
once
tried
such
a
battle
on
her
own
behalf
,
and
had
failed
.
<EOS>
She
had
wished
to
be
imprudent
when
she
was
young
;
but
her
friends
had
been
too
strong
for
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
reduced
,
and
kept
in
order
,
and
made
to
run
in
a
groove
,
 
and
was
now
,
when
she
sat
looking
at
her
little
boy
with
his
bold
face
,
almost
inclined
to
think
that
the
world
was
right
,
and
that
grooves
were
best
.
<EOS>
But
if
she
had
been
controlled
when
she
was
young
,
so
ought
the
Duke
to
be
controlled
now
that
he
was
old
.
<EOS>
It
is
all
very
well
for
a
man
or
woman
to
boast
that
he
,
 
or
she
,
 
may
do
what
he
likes
with
his
own
,
 
or
with
her
own
.
<EOS>
But
there
are
circumstances
in
which
such
self
-
action
is
ruinous
to
so
many
that
coercion
from
the
outside
becomes
absolutely
needed
.
<EOS>
Nobody
had
felt
the
injustice
of
such
coercion
when
applied
to
herself
more
sharply
than
had
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
lived
to
acknowledge
that
such
coercion
might
be
proper
,
and
was
now
prepared
to
use
it
in
any
shape
in
which
it
might
be
made
available
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
very
well
for
Madame
Goesler
to
laugh
and
exclaim
,
"
Psha
!
"
<EOS>
when
Lady
Glencora
declared
her
real
trouble
.
<EOS>
But
should
it
ever
come
to
pass
that
a
black
-
browed
baby
with
a
yellow
skin
should
be
shown
to
the
world
as
Lord
Silverbridge
,
Lady
Glencora
knew
that
her
peace
of
mind
would
be
gone
for
ever
.
<EOS>
She
had
begun
the
world
desiring
one
thing
,
and
had
missed
it
.
<EOS>
She
had
suffered
much
,
and
had
then
reconciled
herself
to
other
hopes
.
<EOS>
If
those
other
hopes
were
also
to
be
cut
away
from
her
,
the
world
would
not
be
worth
a
pinch
of
snuff
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
had
fled
,
and
she
could
do
nothing
to
-
day
;
but
to
-
morrow
she
would
begin
with
her
batteries
.
<EOS>
And
she
herself
had
done
the
mischief
!
<EOS>
She
had
invited
this
woman
down
to
Matching
!
<EOS>
Heaven
and
earth
!
 
<EOS>
that
such
a
man
as
the
Duke
should
be
such
a
fool
!
 
<EOS>
The
widow
of
a
Jew
banker
!
<EOS>
He
,
the
Duke
of
Omnium
,
 
and
thus
to
cut
away
from
himself
,
for
the
rest
of
his
life
,
all
honour
,
all
peace
of
mind
,
all
the
grace
of
a
noble
end
to
a
career
which
,
if
not
very
noble
in
itself
,
had
received
the
praise
of
nobility
!
<EOS>
And
to
do
this
for
a
thin
,
black
-
browed
,
yellow
-
visaged
woman
with
ringlets
and
devil
's

,
and
a
beard
on
her
upper

,
 
a
Jewess
,
 
a

of
whose
habits
of
life
and

of
thought
they
all
were
absolutely

;
who
drank
,
possibly
;
who
might
have
been
a
forger
,
for
what
any
one
knew
;
an
adventuress
who
had
found
her
way
into
society
by
her
art
and
perseverance
,
 
and
who
did
not
even
pretend
to
have
a
relation
in
the
world
!
<EOS>
That
such
a
one
should
have
influence
enough
to
intrude
herself
into
the
house
of
Omnium
,
and
blot
the
scutcheon
,
and
,
  
what
was
worst
of
all
,
 
perhaps
be
the
mother
of
future
dukes
!
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
,
in
her
anger
,
was
very
unjust
to
Madame
Goesler
,
thinking
all
evil
of
her
,
accusing
her
in
her
mind
of
every
crime
,
denying
her
all
charm
,
all
beauty
.
<EOS>
Had
the
Duke
forgotten
himself
and
his
position
for
the

of
some
fair
girl
with
a
pink
complexion
and
grey

,
and
smooth
hair
,
and
a
father
,
Lady
Glencora
thought
that
she
would
have
forgiven
it
better
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
that
Madame
Goesler
would
win
her
way
to
the
coronet
;
but
when
she
came
to
put
it
on
,
she
should
find
that
there
were
sharp
thorns
inside
the
lining
of
it
.
<EOS>
Not
a
woman
worth
the
knowing
in
all
London
should
speak
to
her
;
 
nor
a
man
either
of
those
men
with
whom
a
Duchess
of
Omnium
would
wish
to
hold
converse
.
<EOS>
She
should
find
her
husband
rated
as
a
doting
fool
,
and
herself
rated
as
a
scheming
female

.
<EOS>
And
it
should
go
hard
with
Lady
Glencora
,
if
the
Duke
were
not
separated
from
his
new
Duchess
before
the
end
of
the
first

!
<EOS>
In
her
anger
Lady
Glencora
was
very
unjust
.
  
<EOS>
The
Duke
,
when
he
left
his
house
without
telling
his

whither
he
was
going
,
did
send
his
address
to
,
 
the
top
brick
of
the
chimney
.
<EOS>
His
note
,
which
was
delivered
at
Madame
Goesler
's

,
was
as
follows
:
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
to
have
your
answer
on
Monday
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
at
Brighton
.
<EOS>
Send
it
by
a

to
the
Bedford

there
.
<EOS>
I
need
not
tell
you
with
what
expectation
,
with
what
hope
,
with
what
fear
I
shall
await
it
.
 
<EOS>
O.
"
Poor
old
man
!
<EOS>
He
had
run
through
all
the
pleasures
of
life
too
quickly
,
and
had
not
much
left
with
which
to
amuse
himself
.
<EOS>
At
length
he
had
set
his
eyes
on
a
top
brick
,
and
being
tired
of
everything
else
,
wanted
it
very
sorely
.
<EOS>
Poor
old
man
!
<EOS>
How
should
it
do
him
any
good
,
even
if
he
got
it
?
<EOS>
Madame
Goesler
,
when
she
received
the
note
,
sat
with
it
in
her
hand
,
thinking
of
his
great
want
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
would
be
tired
of
his
new
plaything
after
a
month
,
"
she
said
to
herself
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
given
herself
to
the
next
morning
,
and
she
would
not
make
up
her
mind
that
night
.
<EOS>
She
would
sleep
once
more
with
the
coronet
of
a
duchess
within
her
reach
.
<EOS>
She
did
do
so
;
and
woke
in
the
morning
with
her
mind
absolutely
in
doubt
.
<EOS>
When
she
walked
down
to
breakfast
,
all
doubt
was
at
an
end
.
<EOS>
The
time
had
come
when
it
was
necessary
that
she
should
resolve
,
and
while
her
maid
was
brushing
her
hair
for
her
she
did
make
her
resolution
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
thing
it
is
to
be
a
great
lady
,
"
said
the
maid
,
who
may
probably
have
reflected
that
the
Duke
of
Omnium
did
not
come
here
so
often
for
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
that
,
Lotta
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
women
I
know
,
madame
,
talk
so
much
of
their
countesses
,
and
ladyships
,
and
duchesses
.
<EOS>
I
would
never
rest
till
I
had
a
title
in
this
country
,
if
I
were
a
lady
,
 
and
rich
and
beautiful
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
can
the
countesses
,
and
the
ladyships
,
and
the
duchesses
do
as
they
please
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
madame
;
 
I
know
not
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
know
.
<EOS>
That
will
do
,
Lotta
.
<EOS>
Now
leave
me
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Madame
Goesler
had
made
up
her
mind
;
but
I
do
not
know
whether
that
doubt
as
to
having
her
own
way
had
much
to
do
with
it
.
<EOS>
As
the
wife
of
an
old
man
she
would
probably
have
had
much
of
her
own
way
.
<EOS>
Immediately
after
breakfast
she
wrote
her
answer
to
the
Duke
,
which
was
as
follows
:
    
Park
Lane
,
Monday
.
  
<EOS>
MY
DEAR
DUKE
OF
OMNIUM
,
  
<EOS>
I
find
so
great
a
difficulty
in
expressing
myself
to
your
Grace
in
a
written
letter
,
that
since
you
left
me
I
have
never
ceased
to
wish
that
I
had
been
less
nervous
,
less
doubting
,
and
less
foolish
when
you
were
present
with
me
here
in
my
room
.
<EOS>
I
might
then
have
said
in
one
word
what
will
take
so
many
awkward
words
to
explain
.
  
<EOS>
Great
as
is
the
honour
you
propose
to
confer
on
me
,
rich
as
is
the
gift
you
offer
me
,
I
can
not
accept
it
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
be
your
Grace
's
wife
.
<EOS>
I
may
almost
say
that
I
knew
it
was
so
when
you
parted
from
me
;
but
the
surprise
of
the
situation
took
away
from
me
a
part
of
my
judgment
,
and
made
me
unable
to
answer
you
as
I
should
have
done
.
<EOS>
My
lord
,
the
truth
is
,
that
I
am
not
fit
to
be
the
wife
of
the
Duke
of
Omnium
.
<EOS>
I
should
injure
you
;
and
though
I
should
raise
myself
in
name
,
I
should
injure
myself
in
character
.
<EOS>
But
you
must
not
think
,
because
I
say
this
,
that
there
is
any
reason
why
I
should
not
be
an
honest
man
's
wife
.
<EOS>
There
is
none
.
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
on
my
conscience
which
I
could
not
tell
you
,
 
or
to
another
man
;
nothing
that
I
need
fear
to
tell
to
all
the
world
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
my
lord
,
there
is
nothing
to
tell
<EOS>
but
this
,
 
that
I
am
not
fitted
by
birth
and
position
to
be
the
wife
of
the
Duke
of
Omnium
.
<EOS>
You
would
have
to
blush
for
me
,
and
that
no
man
shall
ever
have
to
do
on
my
account
.
  
<EOS>
I
will
own
that
I
have
been
ambitious
,
too
ambitious
,
and
have
been
pleased
to
think
that
one
so
exalted
as
you
are
,
one
whose
high
position
is
so
rife
in
the
eyes
of
all
men
,
should
have
taken
pleasure
in
my
company
.
<EOS>
I
will
confess
to
a
foolish
woman
's
silly
vanity
in
having
wished
to
be
known
to
be
the
friend
of
the
Duke
of
Omnium
.
<EOS>
I
am
like
the
other
moths
that
flutter
near
the
light
and
have
their
wings
burned
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
wiser
than
they
in
this
,
that
having
been
scorched
,
I
know
that
I
must
keep
my
distance
.
<EOS>
You
will
easily
believe
that
a
woman
,
such
as
I
am
,
does
not
refuse
to
ride
in
a
carriage
with
your
Grace
's
arms
on
the
panels
without
a
regret
.
<EOS>
I
am
no
philosopher
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
pretend
to
despise
the
rich
things
of
the
world
,
or
the
high
things
.
<EOS>
According
to
my
way
of
thinking
a
woman
ought
to
wish
to
be
Duchess
of
Omnium
;
 
but
she
ought
to
wish
also
to
be
able
to
carry
her
coronet
with
a
proper
grace
.
<EOS>
As
Madame
Goesler
I
can
live
,
even
among
my
superiors
,
at
my
ease
.
<EOS>
As
your
Grace
's
wife
,
I
should
be
easy
no
longer
;
  
nor
would
your
Grace
.
  
<EOS>
You
will
think
perhaps
that
what
I
write
is
heartless
,
that
I
speak
altogether
of
your
rank
,
and
not
at
all
of
the
affection
you
have
shown
me
,
or
of
that
which
I
might
possibly
bear
towards
you
.
<EOS>
I
think
that
when
the
first
flush
of
passion
is
over
in
early
youth
men
and
women
should
strive
to
regulate
their
love
,
as
they
do
their
other
desires
,
by
their
reason
.
<EOS>
I
could
love
your
Grace
,
fondly
,
as
your
wife
,
if
I
thought
it
well
for
your
Grace
or
for
myself
that
we
should
be
man
and
wife
.
<EOS>
As
I
think
it
would
be
ill
for
both
of
us
,
I
will
restrain
that
feeling
,
and
remember
your
Grace
ever
with
the
purest
feeling
of
true
friendship
.
  
<EOS>
Before
I
close
this
letter
,
I
must
utter
a
word
of
gratitude
.
<EOS>
In
the
kind
of
life
which
I
have
led
as
a
widow
,
a
life
which
has
been
very
isolated
as
regards
true
fellowship
,
it
has
been
my
greatest
effort
to
obtain
the
good
opinion
of
those
among
whom
I
have
attempted
to
make
my
way
.
<EOS>
I
may
,
perhaps
,
own
to
you
now
that
I
have
had
many
difficulties
.
<EOS>
A
woman
who
is
alone
in
the
world
is
ever
regarded
with
suspicion
.
<EOS>
In
this
country
a
woman
with
a
foreign
name
,
with
means
derived
from
foreign
sources
,
with
a
foreign
history
,
is
specially
suspected
.
<EOS>
I
have
striven
to
live
that
down
,
and
I
have
succeeded
.
<EOS>
But
in
my
wildest
dreams
I
never
dreamed
of
such
success
as
this
,
 
that
the
Duke
of
Omnium
should
think
me
the
worthiest
of
the
worthy
.
<EOS>
You
may
be
sure
that
I
am
not
ungrateful
,
 
that
I
never
will
be
ungrateful
.
<EOS>
And
I
trust
it
will
not
derogate
from
your
opinion
of
my
worth
,
that
I
have
known
what
was
due
to
your
Grace
's
highness
.
  
<EOS>
I
have
the
honour
to
be
,
My
Lord
Duke
,
Your
most
obliged
and
faithful
servant
,
  
MARIE
MAX
GOESLER
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
many
unmarried
women
in
England
are
there
would
do
the
same
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
to
herself
,
as
she
folded
the
paper
,
and
put
it
into
an
envelope
,
and
sealed
the
cover
.
<EOS>
The
moment
that
the
letter
was
completed
she
sent
it
off
,
as
she
was
directed
to
send
it
,
so
that
there
might
be
no
possibility
of
repentance
and
subsequent
hesitation
.
<EOS>
She
had
at
last
made
up
her
mind
,
and
she
would
stand
by
the
making
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
there
would
come
moments
in
which
she
would
deeply
regret
the
opportunity
that
she
had
lost
,
 
the
chance
of
greatness
that
she
had
flung
away
from
her
.
<EOS>
But
so
would
she
have
often
regretted
it
,
also
,
had
she
accepted
the
greatness
.
<EOS>
Her
position
was
one
in
which
there
must
be
regret
,
let
her
decision
have
been
what
it
might
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
decided
,
and
the
thing
was
done
.
<EOS>
She
would
still
be
free
,
 
Marie
Max
Goesler
,
 
unless
in
abandoning
her
freedom
she
would
obtain
something
that
she
might
in
truth
prefer
to
it
.
<EOS>
When
the
letter
was
gone
she
sat
disconsolate
,
at
the
window
of
an
up
-
stairs
room
in
which
she
had
written
,
thinking
much
of
the
coronet
,
much
of
the
name
,
much
of
the
rank
,
much
of
that
position
in
society
which
she
had
flattered
herself
she
might
have
won
for
herself
as
Duchess
of
Omnium
by
her
beauty
,
her
grace
,
and
her
wit
.
<EOS>
It
had
not
been
simply
her
ambition
to
be
a
duchess
,
without
further
aim
or
object
.
<EOS>
She
had
fancied
that
she
might
have
been
such
a
duchess
as
there
is
never
another
,
so
that
her
fame
might
have
been
great
throughout
Europe
,
as
a
woman
charming
at
all
points
.
<EOS>
And
she
would
have
had
friends
,
then
,
 
real
friends
,
and
would
not
have
lived
alone
as
it
was
now
her
fate
to
do
.
<EOS>
And
she
would
have
loved
her
ducal
husband
,
old
though
he
was
,
and
stiff
with
pomp
and
ceremony
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
loved
him
,
and
done
her
best
to
add
something
of
brightness
to
his
life
.
<EOS>
It
was
indeed
true
that
there
was
one
whom
she
loved
better
;
but
of
what
avail
was
it
to
love
a
man
who
,
when
he
came
to
her
,
would
speak
to
her
of
nothing
but
of
the
charms
which
he
found
in
another
woman
!
  
<EOS>
She
had
been
sitting
thus
at
her
window
,
with
a
book
in
her
hand
,
at
which
she
never
looked
,
gazing
over
the
park
which
was
now
beautiful
with
its
May
verdure
,
when
on
a
sudden
a
thought
struck
her
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
Palliser
had
come
to
her
,
trying
to
enlist
her
sympathy
for
the
little
heir
,
behaving
,
indeed
,
not
very
well
,
as
Madame
Goesler
had
thought
,
but
still
with
an
earnest
purpose
which
was
in
itself
good
.
<EOS>
She
would
write
to
Lady
Glencora
and
put
her
out
of
her
misery
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
there
was
some
feeling
of
triumph
in
her
mind
as
she
returned
to
the
desk
from
which
her
epistle
had
been
sent
to
the
Duke
;
 
not
of
that
triumph
which
would
have
found
its
gratification
in
boasting
of
the
offer
that
had
been
made
to
her
,
but
arising
from
a
feeling
that
she
could
now
show
the
proud
mother
of
the
bold
-
faced
boy
that
though
she
would
not
pledge
herself
to
any
woman
as
to
what
she
might
do
or
not
do
,
she
was
nevertheless
capable
of
resisting
such
a
temptation
as
would
have
been
irresistible
to
many
.
<EOS>
Of
the
Duke
's
offer
to
her
she
would
have
spoken
to
no
human
being
,
had
not
this
woman
shown
that
the
Duke
's
purpose
was
known
at
least
to
her
,
and
now
,
in
her
letter
,
she
would
write
no
plain
word
of
that
offer
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
state
,
in
words
intelligible
to
any
one
who
might
read
,
that
the
Duke
had
offered
her
his
hand
and
his
coronet
.
<EOS>
But
she
would
write
so
that
Lady
Glencora
should
understand
her
.
<EOS>
And
she
would
be
careful
that
there
should
be
no
word
in
the
letter
to
make
Lady
Glencora
think
that
she
supposed
herself
to
be
unfit
for
the
rank
offered
to
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
very
humble
in
what
she
had
written
to
the
Duke
,
but
she
would
not
be
at
all
humble
in
what
she
was
about
to
write
to
the
mother
of
the
bold
-
faced
boy
.
<EOS>
And
this
was
the
letter
when
it
was
written
:
    
MY
DEAR
LADY
GLENCORA
,
  
<EOS>
I
venture
to
send
you
a
line
to
put
you
out
of
your
misery
;
 
for
you
<EOS>
were
very
miserable
when
you
were
so
good
as
to
come
here
yesterday
.
<EOS>
Your
dear
little
boy
is
safe
from
me
;
 
and
,
what
is
more
to
the
purpose
,
so
are
you
and
your
husband
,
 
and
your
uncle
,
whom
,
in
truth
,
I
love
.
<EOS>
You
asked
me
a
downright
question
which
I
did
not
then
choose
to
answer
by
a
downright
answer
.
<EOS>
The
downright
answer
was
not
at
that
time
due
to
you
.
<EOS>
It
has
since
been
given
,
and
as
I
like
you
too
well
to
wish
you
to
be
in
torment
<EOS>
,
I
send
you
a
line
to
say
that
I
shall
never
be
in
the
way
of
you
or
your
boy
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
,
dear
Lady
Glencora
,
one
word
more
.
<EOS>
Should
it
ever
again
appear
to
you
to
be
necessary
to
use
your
zeal
for
the
protection
of
your
husband
or
your
child
,
do
not
endeavour
to
dissuade
a
woman
by
trying
to
make
her
think
that
she
,
by
her
alliance
,
would
bring
degradation
into
any
house
,
or
to
any
man
.
<EOS>
If
there
could
have
been
an
argument
powerful
with
me
,
to
make
me
do
that
which
you
wished
to
prevent
,
it
was
the
argument
which
you
used
.
<EOS>
But
my
own
comfort
,
and
the
happiness
of
another
person
whom
I
value
almost
as
much
as
myself
,
were
too
important
to
be
sacrificed
even
to
a
woman
's

.
<EOS>
I
take
mine
by
writing
to
you
and
telling
you
that
I
am
better
and
more
rational
and
wiser
than
you
took
me
to
be
.
  
<EOS>
If
,
after
this
,
you
choose
to
be
on
good
terms
with
me
,
I
shall
be
happy
to
be
your
friend
.
<EOS>
I
shall
want
no
further
revenge
.
<EOS>
You
owe
me
some
little
apology
;
but
whether
you
make
it
or
not
,
I
will
be
contented
,
and
will
never
do
more
than
ask
whether
your
darling
's
prospects
are
still
safe
.
<EOS>
There
are
more
women
than
one
in
the
world
,
you
know
,
and
you
must
not
consider
yourself
to
be
out
of
the
wood
because
you
have
escaped
from
a
single
danger
.
<EOS>
If
there
arise
another
,
come
to
me
,
and
we
will
consult
together
.
  
<EOS>
Dear
Lady
Glencora
,
yours
always
sincerely
,
  
MARIE
M.
G.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
thing
or
two
besides
which
she
longed
to
say
,
laughing
as
she
thought
of
them
.
<EOS>
But
she
refrained
,
and
her
letter
,
when
finished
,
was
as
it
is
given
above
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
day
following
,
Lady
Glencora
was
again
in
Park
Lane
.
<EOS>
When
she
first
read
Madame
Goesler
's
letter
,
she
felt
herself
to
be
annoyed
and
angry
,
but
her
anger
was
with
herself
rather
than
with
her
correspondent
.
<EOS>
Ever
since
her
last
interview
with
the
woman
whom
she
had
feared
,
she
had
been
conscious
of
having
been
indiscreet
.
<EOS>
All
her
feelings
had
been
too
violent
,
and
it
might
well
have
been
that
she
should
have
driven
this
woman
to
do
the
very
thing
that
she
was
so
anxious
to
avoid
.
<EOS>
"
You
owe
me
some
little
apology
,
"
Madame
Goesler
had
said
.
<EOS>
It
was
true
,
 
and
she
would
apologise
.
<EOS>
Undue
pride
was
not
a
part
of
Lady
Glencora
's
character
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
there
was
not
enough
of
pride
in
her
composition
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
quite
ready
to
hate
this
woman
,
and
to
fight
her
on
every
point
as
long
as
the
danger
existed
;
but
she
was
equally
willing
to
take
the
woman
to
her
heart
now
that
the
danger
was
over
.
<EOS>
Apologise
!
<EOS>
Of
course
she
would
apologise
.
<EOS>
And
she
would
make
a
friend
of
the
woman
if
the
woman
wished
it
.
<EOS>
But
she
would
not
have
the
woman
and
the
Duke
at
Matching
together
again
,
lest
,
after
all
,
there
might
be
a
mistake
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
show
Madame
Goesler
's
letter
to
her
husband
,
or
tell
him
anything
of
the
relief
she
had
received
.
<EOS>
He
had
cared
but
little
for
the
danger
,
thinking
more
of
his
budget
than
of
the
danger
;
and
would
be
sufficiently
at
his
ease
if
he
heard
no
more
rumours
of
his
uncle
's
marriage
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
went
to
Park
Lane
early
on
the
Tuesday
morning
,
but
she
did
not
take
her
boy
with
her
.
<EOS>
She
understood
that
Madame
Goesler
might
perhaps
indulge
in
a
little
gentle

at
the
child
's
expense
,
and
the
mother
felt
that
this
might
be
borne
the
more
easily
if
the
child
were
not
present
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
to
thank
you
for
your
letter
,
Madame
Goesler
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
before

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
come
ye
in
peace
here
,

,
or
to

?
"
said
Madame
Goesler
,
standing
up
from
her

and
laughing
,
as
she
sang
the
lines
.
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
not
to
dance
at
your
bridal
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alas
!
<EOS>
no
.
<EOS>
You
have
forbidden
the
banns
too
effectually
for
that
,
and
I
sit
here

the
willow

.
<EOS>
Why
should
n't
I
be
allowed
to
get
married
as
well
as
another
woman
,
I
wonder
?
<EOS>
I
think
you
have
been
very
hard

me

.
<EOS>
But
sit
down
,
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
At

come
in
peace
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly

peace
,
and

,
 
and

and

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

too

,
Lady
Glencora
;
 
for

's

,
if

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
have

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
made
as
soon
as
your
carriage
stopped
at
my

with

.
<EOS>
Of
course
I

.
<EOS>
I
can

to

,
 
even

dear

Plantagenet

.
<EOS>
Fancy

Plantagenet
!
<EOS>
I
am
far

well

history
,
I
can

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
said
a
word
for
which
I
am
sorry
,
and

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Never
mind
the
word
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
it
was
a
true

.
<EOS>
I
do

,

will
allow

woman
to
say

,
 
and
no

.
<EOS>
I
should
have
degraded
him
,
 
and
disgraced
him
.
"
<EOS>
Madame
Goesler
now
had
dropped
the
bantering

she

,
and
was

.
<EOS>
"
I
,

,
have

.
<EOS>
I
have
no

to

,
no
story

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
want
nothing
,
dear
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
You
have
all
that
society
can

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know

that
.
<EOS>
I
have
much

to
me
by

,
but
there

many

that
I
want
;
 
a
bright

boy
,

,

go

.
<EOS>
Why

not

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
came

,

,
one

.
<EOS>
I
had
half
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
bring
him

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
.
<EOS>
He

other

who
was
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
did

that
the

aunt
,
was
a
possible
 
?
<EOS>
But

not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
told

nothing
of

fears
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Some
day
,
when
I
am
a
very

,
and

his

is

,

,

.
<EOS>
Then

will

what
a
madman
his

,
to

as

.
"
  
<EOS>
They
parted
the
best

<EOS>
Mr.
Low
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,
than
marry
any
other
woman
as
long
as
there
was
a
chance
that
Violet
might
be
won
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
very
desirable
that
he
should
know
whether
Violet
might
be
won
or
not
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
July
,
and
everybody
would
be
gone
in
another
month
.
<EOS>
Before
August
would
be
over
<EOS>
he
was
to
start
for
Ireland
with
Mr.
Monk
,
and
he
knew
that
words
would
be
spoken
in
Ireland
which
might
make
it
indispensable
for
him
to
be
,
at
any
rate
,
able
to
throw
up
his
office
.
<EOS>
In
these
days
he
became
more
anxious
than
he
used
to
be
about
Miss
Effingham
's
fortune
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
never
spoken
as
yet
to
Lord
Brentford
since
the
day
on
which
the
Earl
had
quarrelled
with
him
,
nor
had
he
ever
been
at
the
house
in
Portman
Square
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
he
met
occasionally
,
and
had
always
spoken
to
her
.
<EOS>
She
was
gracious
to
him
,
but
there
had
been
no
renewal
of
their
intimacy
.
<EOS>
Rumours
had
reached
him
that
things
were
going
badly
with
her
and
her
husband
;
but
when
men
repeated
such
rumours
in
his
presence
,
he
said
little
or
nothing
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
for
him
,
at
any
rate
,
to
speak
of
Lady
Laura
's
unhappiness
.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
he
had
seen
once
or
twice
during
the
last
month
,
and
they
had
met
cordially
as
friends
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
could
ask
no
question
from
Lord
Chiltern
as
to
Violet
;
but
he
did
learn
that
his
friend
had
again
patched
up
some

with
his
father
.
"
<EOS>
He
has
quarrelled
with
me
,
you
know
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sorry
,
but
what
could
I
do
?
<EOS>
As
things
went
,
I
was
obliged
to
tell
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
suppose
for
a
moment
that
I
am
blaming
you
.
<EOS>
It
is
,
no
doubt
,
much
better
that
he
should
know
it
all
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
it
can
not
make
much
difference
to
you
,
I
should
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
One
does
n't
like
to
quarrel
with
those
who
have
been
kind
to
one
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
is
n't
your
doing
.
<EOS>
He
'll
come
right
again
after

.
<EOS>
When
I

,
you

be

do

to
bring
him
round
.
<EOS>
But
what
's
the
reason
you
never
see
Laura
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
reason
that
everything
goes
awry
?
"
said
Phineas
,
bitterly
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
mentioned
your
name
to
Kennedy
the
other
day
,
he
looked
as
black

thunder
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
not
odd
that
any
one
should
quarrel
with
him
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
stand
him
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
,
I
sometimes
think
that
Laura
will
have
to
give

up
.
<EOS>
Then
there
will
be
another
mess
in

family
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
was

well
as

Lord
Chiltern
;
but
there
was
no
word
about
Violet
,
and
Phineas
did
not
know
how
to
get
a
word
from
any

.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
could
have
told
him
everything
,
but
he
could
not
go
to
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
He
did
go
to
Lady
Baldock
's
house
as
often
as
he
thought
he
could
with
propriety
,
and
occasionally
he
saw
Violet
.
<EOS>
But
he
could
do
no
more
than
see
her
,
and
the
days
and
weeks
were
passing
by
,
and
the
time
was
coming
in
which
he
would
have
to
go
away
,
and
be
with
her
no

.
<EOS>
The
end
of
the
season
,
which
was
always
to
other
men
,
 
to
other
working
men
such
as
our
hero
,
 
a
period
of
pleasurable
anticipation
,

him
was
a
time
of
sadness
,
in
which
he
felt
that
he
was
not
exactly
like
to
,
or
even

to
,
the
men
with

in
London
.
<EOS>
In

old

,
in
which
he
was
allowed
to
go

Loughlinter
or

,
when
all

going
to
their
Loughlinters
and

,

;
but
there

something

in
his
yearly

to
Ireland
.
<EOS>
He
loved
his
father
and
mother

as
do

;
but
there
was
a
falling
off
in
the

of
his
life
which
made
him
feel
that
he
had
been

some
sort

his
own

in

.
<EOS>
He
would
have
liked
to
have
shot

at
Loughlinter
,
or

at
Saulsby
,
or
to
have
hunted
down
at
Willingford
,
 
or
better
still
,
to

Violet
Effingham
wherever

Effingham
might

.
<EOS>
But
all
this
was
closed
to

now
;
and
there

to

Killaloe
,
or
to
return

his
work
in
Downing
Street
,
from
August
to
February
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
,
indeed
,

going

for

;
but
even

did
not

which

.
  
<EOS>
The
session
went
on
very
quietly
.
<EOS>
The
question
of
the
Irish
Reform
Bill
was
postponed
till
the
next
year
,
which
was
a
great
thing
gained
.
<EOS>
He
carried

about

,

sundry

,
through
the
House
in

which
redounded

to

.
<EOS>
There
was
just
enough
of
opposition
to
give
a
zest
to
the
work
,
and
to
make
the

conspicuous
among
the

of
the
year
.
<EOS>
As
his
chief
was
in
the
other
house
,
the
work
fell
altogether
into
his
hands
,
so
that
he
came
to
be
conspicuous
among
Under
-
Secretaries
.
<EOS>
It
was
only
when

said

to
any

about

,
 
about
Irish
Tenant
-
right
,

,
which
was

,
that

.
<EOS>
But

no
room
for

this
year
in
reference
to
Irish
Tenant
-
right
,
and
therefore
any
deep

of
that
discomfort
might

.
<EOS>
If
he
did
by
chance
open

on

to
Mr.
Monk
,
even
Mr.
Monk
discouraged

.
  
<EOS>
In
the
early

of
July
,
when
the
weather
was
very
hot
,
and
people
were
beginning
to
complain
of
the

,
and
members
were

after

,
and
the

of

work
were
being
counted
up
<EOS>
,
there
came
to

news
,

that
was
soon
known
throughout
the
fashionable

,
 
that
the
Duke
of
Omnium
was

at
a

villa

on

above

.
<EOS>
It

to

such

garden

as

never

before
.
<EOS>
And
it
would
be
the
more
remarkable
because
the
Duke

never

.
<EOS>
The
villa
was
called
The
Horns
,
and
had
,

,

Duke
to
Lady
Glencora
on

;

Duke
's

,
and

Horns
,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,
was

.
<EOS>
Scores

were
about

through

three

of

.
<EOS>
The

did
not

,
 
why

.
<EOS>
But
Lady
Glencora
knew
,
and
Madame

shrewdly

,
the

.
<EOS>
When

's

Grace
,
he

,

.
<EOS>
After
a

's

,
he

that
he
would

.
<EOS>
The
top

was

;
but

.
<EOS>
Then
,

,
he

,
 
or

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

;
but

would
stand
his

and
bear

.
<EOS>
Therefore
he
gave

at

.
  
<EOS>
Who
was
to
be
invited
?
<EOS>
Before

first

in
July
was
over
,
many
a
bosom

London
was

on

.
<EOS>
The
Duke
,
in

,

.
<EOS>
Her

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
was

,
 
the

.
<EOS>
On

Duke
's
own

was

Madame

.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
understood

all
.
<EOS>
When
Madame
Goesler
got
her
card
,
she
thought
that

.
<EOS>
And
she
thought
also
that
the
Duke
was
behaving
in

.
  
<EOS>
There
was
,
no

,
much

about
the

,
and

ill
-
will
was
created
.
<EOS>
And
they
who
considered

to

,

,

,

Duke

Lady
Glencora
,

.
<EOS>
It
was
soon

Lady
Glencora
was
the

the
favours
,
and
I
fancy
that
her

was

her

before

.
<EOS>
The

was
to

on
Wednesday
,
the
27th
of

,
and
before

,
men

women
had

the

that

were

;
and

Lady
Glencora
putting

and
that

.
"
<EOS>
No
,
that
is
too

,
"

,

Grey
,

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
She
sha

,
even

Plantagenet

to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bonteen
did
not

;

Finn
had

,

.
<EOS>
He

"
an

,
"

.
<EOS>
But

Bonteen
never
had

,

.
<EOS>
Phineas
,

,
got
his
card
,
and
,

,

the

.
  
<EOS>
The
grounds
were
opened
at
four
.
<EOS>
There
was
to

an
early
dinner
out
in
tents
at
five
;
and
after

men
and
women
were
to
walk

,
or

,
or

love
 
or
hay
,
as

.
<EOS>
The
haycocks
,
however
,
were
ready
prepared
,
while
it

expected
that
they
should
bring
the
love

.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
knowing
that
he
should
meet
Violet
Effingham
,
took
a
great
deal
with
him
ready
made
.
  
<EOS>
For
an
hour
and
a
half
Lady
Glencora
kept

in

through

the

passed
to
the
grounds
,
and
to

that
the
Duke
was
on

;
 
to
every

one
.
<EOS>
To
Madame
Goesler
<EOS>
she
said
no
such
word
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
glad
to
see
you
,
my
dear
,
"
she

,
as

pressed

's

:
"

I

not
killed
by
this
work
,
I
'll

by
-
and
-
by
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Madame
Goesler
passed
on
,
and
soon
found
herself
amidst
a
throng
of

.
<EOS>
After

she
saw
the
Duke

in
an
arm
-

,
close
to
the
river
-
bank
,
and

,

.
<EOS>
"
The
thanks
are
due
to
you
for

,
"
said
the
Duke
,
rising
to

.
<EOS>
There
were
a
dozen
people
standing
round
,
and
so
the
thing
was
done
without
difficulty
.
<EOS>
At
that

came
a
notice
that
their

were
on
the
ground
,
and
the
Duke
,
of

,
went
off

.
<EOS>
There
was
not
a
word

between

Duke

.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
did
not
come
till
late
,
 
till
seven
,
when
the

was
over
.
<EOS>
I
think
he
was
right
in
this
,
as
the
banqueting
in
tents
loses
in
comfort
almost
more
than
it
gains
in
romance
.
<EOS>
A
small
picnic
may
be
very
well
,
and
the
distance
previously
travelled
may
give
to
a
dinner
on
the
ground
the
seeming
excuse
of
necessity
.
<EOS>
Frail
human
nature
must
be
supported
,
 
and
human
nature
,
having
gone
so
far
in
pursuit
of
the
beautiful
,
is
entitled
to
what
best
support
the
unaccustomed
circumstances
will
allow
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
out
with
the
cold
pies
,
out
with
the
salads
,
and
the
chickens
,
and
the
champagne
.
<EOS>
Since
no
better
may
be
,
let
us
recruit
human
nature
sitting
upon
this
moss
,
and
forget
our
discomforts
in
the
glory
of
the
verdure
around
us
.
<EOS>
And
dear
Mary
,
seeing
that
the
cushion
from
the
waggonet
is
small
,
and
not
wishing
to
accept
the
too
generous
offer
that
she
should
take
it
all
for
her
own
use
,
will
admit
a
contact
somewhat
closer
than
the
ordinary
chairs
of
a
dining
-
room
render
necessary
.
<EOS>
That
in
its
way
is
very
well
;
 
but
I
hold
that
a
banquet
on
narrow
tables
in
a
tent
is
displeasing
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
strolled
into
the
grounds
when
the
tent
was
nearly
empty
,
and
when
Lady
Glencora
,
almost
sinking
beneath
her
exertions
,
was
taking
rest
in
an
inner
room
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
at
this
time
was
dining
with
their
royal
highnesses
,
and
three
or
four
others
,
specially
selected
,
very
comfortably
within
doors
.
<EOS>
Out
of
doors
the
world
had
begun
to
dance
,
 
and
the
world
was
beginning
to
say
that
it
would
be
much
nicer
to
go
and
dance
upon
the
boards
inside
as
soon
as
possible
.
<EOS>
For
,
though
of
all
parties
a
garden
party
is
the
nicest
,
everybody
is
always
anxious
to
get
out
of
the
garden
as
quick
as
may
be
.
<EOS>
A
few
ardent
lovers
of
suburban
picturesque
effect
were
sitting
beneath
the
haycocks
,
and
four
forlorn
damsels
were
vainly
endeavouring
to
excite
the
sympathy
of
manly
youth
by
playing
croquet
in
a
corner
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
sure
,
however
,
that
the
lovers
beneath
the
haycocks
and
the
players
at
croquet
were
not
actors
hired
by
Lady
Glencora
for
the
occasion
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
had
not
been
long
on
the
lawn
before
he
saw
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
She
was
standing
with
another
lady
,
and
Barrington
Erle
was
with
them
.
"
<EOS>
So
you
have
been
successful
?
"
said
Barrington
,
greeting
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Successful
in
what
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
In
what
?
<EOS>
In
getting
a
ticket
.
<EOS>
I
have
had
to
promise
three
tide
-
waiterships
,
and
to
give
deep
hints
about
a
bishopric
expected
to
be
vacant
,
before
I
got
in
.
<EOS>
But
what
matters
?
<EOS>
Success
pays
for
everything
.
<EOS>
My
only
trouble
now
is
how
I
'm
to
get
back
to
London
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
shook
hands
with
Phineas
,
and
then
as
he
was
passing
on
,
followed
him
for
a
step
and
whispered
a
word
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
,
"
she
said
,
"
if
you
are
not
going
yet
,
come
back
to
me
presently
.
<EOS>
I
have
something
to
say
to
you
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
be
far
from
the
river
,
and
shall
stay
here
for
about
an
hour
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
said
that
he
would
,
and
then
went
on
,
not
knowing
exactly
where
he
was
going
.
<EOS>
He
had
one
desire
,
 
to
find
Violet
Effingham
,
but
when
he
should
find
her
he
could
not
carry
her
off
,
and
sit
with
her
beneath
a
haycock
.
   
<EOS>
The
Horns
 
<EOS>
While
looking
for
Violet
Effingham
,
Phineas
encountered
Madame
Goesler
,
among
a
crowd
of
people
who
were
watching
the
adventurous
embarkation
of
certain
daring
spirits
in
a
pleasure
-
boat
.
<EOS>
There
were
watermen
there
in
the
Duke
's
livery
,
ready
to
take
such
spirits
down
to
Richmond
or
up
to
Teddington
lock
,
and
many
daring
spirits
did
take
such
trips
,
 
to
the
great
peril
of
muslins
,
ribbons
,
and
starch
,
to
the
peril
also
of
ornamental
summer
white
garments
,
so
that
when
the
thing
was
over
,
the
boats
were
voted
to
have
been
a
bore
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
to
venture
?
"
said
Phineas
to
the
lady
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
it
of
all
things
if
I
were
not
afraid
for
my
clothes
.
<EOS>
Will
you
come
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
never
good
upon
the
water
.
<EOS>
I
should
be
sea
-
sick
to
a
certainty
.
<EOS>
They
are
going
down
beneath
the
bridge
too
,
and
we
should
be
splashed
by
the
steamers
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
my
courage
is
high
enough
.
"
<EOS>
Thus
Phineas
excused
himself
,
being
still
intent
on
prosecuting
his
search
for
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
neither
will
I
,
"
said
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
"
One
dash
from
a
peccant
oar
would
destroy
the
whole
symmetry
of
my
dress
.
<EOS>
Look
.
<EOS>
That
green
young
lady
has
already
been
sprinkled
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
the
blue
young
gentleman
has
been
sprinkled
also
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
and
they
will
be
happy
in
a
joint
baptism
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
they
strolled
along
the
river
path
together
,
and
were
soon
alone
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
leaving
town
soon
,
Madame
Goesler
?
"
  
"
Almost
immediately
.
"
  
"
And
where
do
you
go
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
 
to
Vienna
.
<EOS>
I
am
there
for
a
couple
of
months
every
year
,
minding
my
business
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
you
would
know
me
,
if
you
saw
me
;
 
sometimes
sitting
on
a
stool
in
a
counting
-
house
,
sometimes
going
about
among
old
houses
,
settling
what
must
be
done
to
save
them
from
tumbling
down
.
<EOS>
I
dress
so
differently
at
such
times
,
and
talk
so
differently
,
and
look
so
much
older
,
that
I
almost
fancy
myself
to
be
another
person
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
a
great
trouble
to
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
 
I
rather
like
it
.
<EOS>
It
makes
me
feel
that
I
do
something
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
go
alone
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Quite
alone
.
<EOS>
I
take
a
German
maid
with
me
,
and
never
speak
a
word
to
any
one
else
on
the
journey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
must
be
very
bad
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
it
is
the
worst
of
it
.
<EOS>
But
then
I
am
so
much
accustomed
to
be
alone
.
<EOS>
You
see
me
in
society
,
and
in
society
only
,
and
therefore
naturally
look
upon
me
as
one
of
a
gregarious
herd
;
but
I
am
in
truth
an
animal
that
feeds
alone
and
lives
alone
.
<EOS>
Take
the
hours
of
the
year
all
through
,
and
I
am
a
solitary
during
four
-
fifths
of
them
.
<EOS>
And
what
do
you
intend
to
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
go
to
Ireland
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Home
to
your
own
people
.
<EOS>
How
nice
!
<EOS>
I
have
no
people
to
go
to
.
<EOS>
I
have
one
sister
,
who
lives
with
her
husband
at
Riga
.
<EOS>
She
is
my
only
relation
,
and
I
never
see
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
have
thousands
of
friends
in
England
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
 
as
you
see
them
,
"
 
and
she
turned
and
spread
out

hands
towards
the
crowded
lawn
,
which
was
behind

.
<EOS>
"
What
are
such
friends
worth
?
<EOS>
What
would
they
do
for

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
that
the
Duke
would
do
much
,
"
said
Phineas
laughing
.
  
<EOS>
Madame
Goesler
laughed
also
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Duke
is
not
so
bad
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
The
Duke
would
do
as
much
as
any
one
else
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
have
the
Duke
abused
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
He
may
be
your
particular
friend
,
for
what
I
know
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
;
 
no
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
particular
friend
.
<EOS>
And
were
I
to
wish
to
choose
one
,
I
should
think
the
Duke
a
little
above
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
;
 
and
too
stiff
,
and

old
,
and

,
and
too
cold
,
and
too

-
believe
,
and

.
"
  
"
Mr.
Finn
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
Duke
is
all
buckram
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
do
you
come
to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
see
you
,
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that

,
Mr.
Finn
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
it
is
true
in
its
way
.
<EOS>
One
goes
about
to
meet
those
whom
one
likes
,
not

the

's

.
<EOS>
I
hope
I
am
not
wrong
because
I
go
to
houses
at
which
I
like
neither
the
host
nor
the
hostess
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
as

said
this
was
thinking
of
Lady
Baldock
,

late
he
had
been
exceedingly
civil
,
 
but

certainly

not

Lady
Baldock
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
have
been
too
hard
upon
the
Duke
of
Omnium
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
him
well
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Personally
?
<EOS>
certainly
not
.
<EOS>
Do
you
?
<EOS>
Does
anybody
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
is
a
gracious
gentleman
,
"
said
Madame
Goesler
,
"
and
though
I
can
not
boast
of
knowing
him
well
,
I
do
not
like
to
hear

called
buckram
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
he
is
buckram
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
very
easy
for
a
man
in
his
position
to
live
so
as
to
please
all
people
.
<EOS>
He
has
to
maintain
the
prestige
of
the
highest

in

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Look
at
his
nephew
,
who
will
be
the
next
Duke
,
and
who
works
as

any
man
in

.
<EOS>
Will
he
not
maintain
it
better
?
<EOS>
What
good
did
the
present
man
ever
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
believe
only
in
motion
,
Mr.
Finn
;
 
and
not
at
all
in

.
<EOS>
An
express
train
at
full
speed
is
grander
to
you
than
a
mountain
with

of
snow
.
<EOS>
I
own
that

me
there

something

in
the

of
a
man
too
high
to
do
anything
,
 
if

with

.
<EOS>
I
think
that
there
should
be
breasts

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stars
which
they
have
never

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
;
 
well
;
we
will
not

.
<EOS>
Go
and
earn
your
star
,
and
I
will
say
that
it
becomes
you
better
than
any
glitter

the
Duke

Omnium
.
<EOS>
"
This
she
said
with
an

which
he

.
<EOS>
"
I
too
may

able

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Though
,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
;
 
that

.
<EOS>
For

,
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
I
strive
sometimes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
am
sure

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
.
<EOS>
I
hate

.
<EOS>
You

Duke

fair

;
you
as

,
who
will

an
hour
in

,
but
may
possibly
go
down
a

with

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
I
may
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
the
Duke
,
as
the
mountain
,
which
is
fixed
in
its
stateliness
,
short
of
the
power
of
some

,
which
shall
be
grander

.
<EOS>
Here

are
at
the
house

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

,

Goesler
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
in

again

,

.
<EOS>
You

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
then
this
love
trouble
of

will
be
over
,
 
one

or

;

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
who
can
say
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Faint
heart
never
won
fair
lady
.
<EOS>
But
your
heart
is
never
faint
.
<EOS>
Farewell
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
he
left
her
.
<EOS>
Up

this

he
had
not
seen
Violet
,
and
yet
he
knew
that
she
was
to
be

.
<EOS>
She
had
herself

that

was
to

Laura
,
whom
he
had
already

.
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
had
not
been
invited
,
and
had
expressed
great
animosity
against
the
Duke
in
consequence
.
<EOS>
She
had
gone
so
far
as
to
say
that
the
Duke
was
a
man
at
whose
house
a
young
lady
such
as
her
niece
ought
not
to
be
seen
.
<EOS>
But
Violet
had
laughed
at
this
,
and
declared
her
intention
of
accepting
the
invitation
.
<EOS>
"
Go
,
"
she
had
said
;
"
of
course
I
shall
go
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
broken
my
heart
if
I
could
not
have
got
there
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
therefore
was
sure
that
she
must
be
in
the
place
.
<EOS>
He
had
kept
his
eyes
ever
on
the
alert
,
and
yet
he
had
not
found
her
.
<EOS>
And
now
he
must
keep
his
appointment
with
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
So
he
went
down
to
the
path
by
the
river
,
and
there
he
found
her
seated
close
by
the
water
's
edge
.
<EOS>
Her
cousin
Barrington
Erle
was
still
with
her
,
but
as
soon
as
Phineas
joined
them
,
Erle
went
away
.
<EOS>
"
I
had
told
him
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
,
"
that
I
wished
to
speak
to
you
,
and
he
stayed
with
me
till
you
came
.
<EOS>
There
are
worse
men
than
Barrington
a
great
deal
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
of
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
and
he
still
friends
,
Mr.
Finn
?
"
  
"
I
hope
so
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
see
so
much
of
him
as
I
did
when
I
had
less
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
says
that
you
have
got
into
altogether
a
different
set
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
.
<EOS>
I
have
gone
as
circumstances
have
directed
me
,
but
I
have
certainly
not
intended
to
throw
over
so
old
and
good
a
friend
as
Barrington
Erle
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
 
he
does
not
blame
you
.
<EOS>
He
tells
me
that
you
have
found
your
way
among
what
he
calls
the
working
men
of
the
party
,
and
he
thinks
you
will
do
very
well
,
 
if
you
can
only
be
patient
enough
.
<EOS>
We
all
expected
a
different
line
from
you
,
you
know
,
 
more
of
words
and
less
of
deeds
,
if
I
may
say
so
;
 
more
of
liberal
oratory
and
less
of
government
action
;
but
I
do
not
doubt
that
you
are
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
that
I
have
been
wrong
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
becoming
heartily
sick
of
officialities
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
comes
from
the
fickleness
about
which
papa
is
so
fond
of
quoting
his
Latin
.
<EOS>
The
ox
desires
the
saddle
.
<EOS>
The
charger
wants
to
plough
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
which
am
I
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
career
may
combine
the
dignity
of
the
one
with
the
utility
of
the
other
.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
you
must
not
think
of
changing
now
.
<EOS>
Have
you
seen
Mr.
Kennedy
lately
?
"
<EOS>
She
asked
the
question
abruptly
,
showing
that
she
was
anxious
to
get
to
the
matter
respecting
which
she
had
summoned
him
to
her
side
,
and
that
all
that
she
had
said
hitherto
had
been
uttered
as
it
were
in
preparation
of
that
subject
.
  
<EOS>
"
Seen
him
?
<EOS>
yes
;
I
see
him
daily
.
<EOS>
But
we
hardly
do
more
than
speak
,
"
  
"
Why
not
?
"
<EOS>
Phineas
stood
for
a
moment
in
silence
,
hesitating
.
<EOS>
"
Why
is
it
that
he
and
you
do
not
speak
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
answer
that
question
,
Lady
Laura
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
you
know
any
reason
?
<EOS>
Sit
down
,
or
,
if
you
please
,
I
will
get
up
and
walk
with
you
.
<EOS>
He
tells
me
that
you
have
chosen
to
quarrel
with
him
,
and
that
I
have
made
you
do
so
.
<EOS>
He
says
that
you
have
confessed
to
him
that
I
have
asked
you
to
quarrel
with
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
can
hardly
have
said
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
has
said
it
,
 
in
so
many
words
.
<EOS>
Do
you
think
that
I
would
tell
you
such
a
story
falsely
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
he
here
now
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
he
is
not
here
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
come
.
<EOS>
I
came
alone
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Is
not
Miss
Effingham
with
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
she
is
to
come
with
my
father
later
.
<EOS>
She
is
here
no
doubt
,
now
.
<EOS>
But
answer
my
question
,
Mr.
Finn
;
 
unless
you
find
that
you
can
not
answer
it
.
<EOS>
What
was
it
that
you
did
say
to
my
husband
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
to
justify
what
he
has
told
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
to
say
that
he
has
spoken
falsely
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
to
use
no
harsh
word
,
 
<EOS>
but
I
think
that
Mr.
Kennedy
when
troubled
in
his
spirit
looks
at
things
gloomily
,
and
puts
meaning
upon
words
which
they
should
not
bear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
has
troubled
his
spirit
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
know
that
better
than
I
can
do
,
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
I
will
tell
you
all
that
I
can
tell
you
.
<EOS>
He
invited
me
to
his
house
<EOS>
and
I
would
not
go
,
because
you
had
forbidden
me
.
<EOS>
Then
he
asked
me
some
questions
about
you
.
<EOS>
Did
I
refuse
because
of
you
,
 
or
of
anything
that
you
had
said
?
<EOS>
If
I
remember
right
,
I
told
him
that
I
did
fancy
that
you
would
not
be
glad
to
see
me
,
 
and
that
therefore
I
would
rather
stay
away
.
<EOS>
What
was
I
to
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
have
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
with
him
would
have
been
worse
than
what
I
did
say
.
<EOS>
Remember
that
he
asked
me
the
question
point
-
blank
,
and
that
no
reply
would
have
been
equal
to
an
affirmation
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
confessed
that
his
suggestion
was
true
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
could
not
then
have
twitted
me
with
your
words
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
have
erred
,
Lady
Laura
,
and
brought
any
sorrow
on
you
,
I
am
indeed
grieved
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
all
sorrow
.
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
but
sorrow
.
<EOS>
I
have
made
up
my
mind
to
leave
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Lady
Laura
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
bad
,
 
but
not
so
bad
,
I
think
,
as
the
life
I
am
now
leading
.
<EOS>
He
has
accused
me
 
,
of
what
do
you
think
?
<EOS>
He
says
that
you
are
my
lover
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
did
not
say
that
,
 
in
those
words
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
said
it
in
words
which
made
me
feel
that
I
must
part
from
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
did
you
answer
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
answer
him
at
all
.
<EOS>
If
he
had
come
to
me
like
a
man
,
 
not
accusing
me
,
but
asking
me
,
 
I
would
have
told
him
everything
.
<EOS>
And
what
was
there
to
tell
?
<EOS>
I
should
have
broken
my
faith
to
you
,
in
speaking
of
that
scene
at
Loughlinter
,
but
women
always
tell
such
stories
to
their
husbands
when
their
husbands
are
good
to
them
,
and
true
,
and
just
.
<EOS>
And
it
is
well
that
they
should
be
told
.
<EOS>
But
to
Mr.
Kennedy
I
can
tell
nothing
.
<EOS>
He
does
not
believe
my
word
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
believe
you
,
Lady
Laura
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
Because
I
did
not
blurt
out
to
him
all
that
story
about
your
foolish
duel
,
 
because
I
thought
it
best
to
keep
my
brother
's
secret
,
as
long
as
there
was
a
secret
to
be
kept
,
he
told
me
that
I
had
,
 
lied
to
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
with
that
word
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
 
with
that
very
word
.
<EOS>
He
is
not
particular
about
his
words
,
when
he
thinks
it
necessary
to
express
himself
strongly
.
<EOS>
And
he
has
told
me
since
that
because
of
that
he
could
never
believe
me
again
.
<EOS>
How
is
it
possible
that
a
woman
should
live
with
such
a
man
?
"
<EOS>
But
why
did
she
come
to
him
with
this
story
,
 
to
him
whom
she
had
been
accused
of
entertaining
as
a
lover
;
 
to
him
who
of
all
her
friends
was
the
last
whom
she
should
have
chosen
as
the
recipient
for
such
a
tale
?
<EOS>
Phineas
as
he
thought
how
he
might
best
answer
her
,
with
what
words
he
might
try
to
comfort
her
,
could
not
but
ask

this
question
.
<EOS>
"
The
moment
that
the
word
was
out
of
his
mouth
,
"
she
went
on
to
say
,
"
I
resolved
that
I
would
tell
you
.
<EOS>
The
accusation
is
against
you
as
it
is
against
me
,
and
is
equally
false
to
both
.
<EOS>
I
have
written
to
him
,
and
there
is
my
letter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
will
see
him
again
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
I
will
go
to
my
father
's
house
.
<EOS>
I
have
already
arranged
it
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
has
my
letter
by
this
time
,
and
I
go
from
hence
home
with
my
father
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
wish
that
I
should
read
the
letter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
 
certainly
.
<EOS>
I
wish
that
you
should
read
it
.
<EOS>
Should
I
ever
meet
him
again
,
I
shall
tell
him
that
you
saw
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
They
were
now
standing
close
upon
the
river
's
bank
,
at
a
corner
of
the
grounds
,
and
,
though
the
voices
of
people
sounded
near
to
them
,
they
were
alone
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
no
alternative
but
to
read
the
letter
,
which
was
as
follows
:
    
<EOS>
After
what
you
have
said
to
me
it
is
impossible
that
I
should
return
to
your
house
.
<EOS>
I
shall
meet
my
father
at
the
Duke
of
Omnium
's
,
and
have
already
asked
him
to
give
me
an
asylum
.
<EOS>
It
is
my
wish
to
remain
wherever
he
may
be
,
either
in
town
or
in
the
country
.
<EOS>
Should
I
change
my
purpose
in
this
,
and
change
my
residence
<EOS>
,
I
will
not
fail
to
let
you
know
where
I
go
and
what
I
propose
to
do
.
<EOS>
You
I
think
must
have
forgotten
that
I
was
your
wife
;
but
I
will
never
forget
it
.
  
<EOS>
You
have
accused
me
of
having
a
lover
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
have
expected
that
I
should
continue
to
live
with
you
after
such
an
accusation
.
<EOS>
For
myself
I
can
not
understand
how
any
man
can
have
brought
himself
to
bring
such
a
charge
against
his
wife
.
<EOS>
Even
had
it
been
true
the
accusation
should
not
have
been
made
by
your
mouth
to
my
ears
.
  
<EOS>
That
it
is
untrue
<EOS>
I
believe
you
must
be
as
well
aware
as
I
am
myself
.
<EOS>
How
intimate
I
was
with
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
,
and
what
were
the
limits
of
my
intimacy
with
him
you
knew
before
I
married
you
.
<EOS>
After
our
marriage
I
encouraged
his
friendship
till
I
found
that
there
was
something
in
it
that
displeased
you
,
 
and
,
after
learning
that
,
I
discouraged
it
.
<EOS>
You
have
said
that
he
is
my
lover
,
but
you
have
probably
not
defined
for
yourself
that
word
very
clearly
.
<EOS>
You
have
felt
yourself
slighted
because
his
name
has
been
mentioned
with
praise
;
 
and
your
jealousy
has
been
wounded
because
you
have
thought
that
I
have
regarded
him
as
in
some
way
superior
to
yourself
.
<EOS>
You
have
never
really
thought
that
he
was
my
lover
,
 
that
he
spoke
words
to
me
which
others
might
not
hear
,
that
he
claimed
from
me
aught
that
a
wife
may
not
give
,
that
he
received
aught
which
a
friend
should
not
receive
.
<EOS>
The
accusation
has
been
a
coward
's
accusation
.
  
<EOS>
I
shall
be
at
my
father
's
to
-
night
,
and
to
-
morrow
I
will
get
you
to
let
my
servant
bring
to
me
such
things
as
are
my
own
,
 
my
clothes
,
namely
,
and
desk
,
and
a
few
books
.
<EOS>
She
will
know
what
I
want
.
<EOS>
I
trust
you
may
be
happier
without
a
wife
,
than
ever
you
have
been
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
felt
almost
daily
since
we
were
married
that
you
were
a
man
who
would
have
been
happier
without
a
wife
than
with
one
.
  
<EOS>
Yours
affectionately
,
  
LAURA
KENNEDY
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
at
any
rate
true
,
"
she
said
,
when
Phineas
had
read
the
letter
.
  
<EOS>
"
True
!
<EOS>
Doubtless
it
is
true
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
except
that
I
do
not
suppose
he
was
ever
really
angry
with
me
,
or
jealous
,
or
anything
of
the
sort
,
 
because
I
got
on
well
.
<EOS>
It
seems
absurd
even
to
think
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
too
absurd
for
some
men
.
<EOS>
I
remember
your
telling
me
that
he
was
weak
,
and
poor
,
and
unworthy
.
<EOS>
I
remember
your
saying
so
when
I
first
thought
that
he
might
become
my
husband
.
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
believed
you
when
you
told
me
so
.
<EOS>
I
should
not
have
made
such
a
shipwreck
of
myself
as
I
have
done
.
<EOS>
That
is
all
I
had
to
say
to
you
.
<EOS>
After
what
has
passed
between
us
I
did
not
choose
that
you
should
hear
how
I
was
separated
from
my
husband
from
any
lips
but
my
own
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
now
and
find
papa
.
<EOS>
Do
not
come
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
prefer
being
alone
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
was
left
standing
by
himself
,
looking
down
upon
the
river
as
it
glided
by
.
<EOS>
How
would
it
have
been
with
both
of
them
if
Lady
Laura
had
accepted
him
three
years
ago
,
when
she
consented
to
join
her
lot
with
that
of
Mr.
Kennedy
,
and
had
rejected
him
?
<EOS>
As
he
stood
he
heard
the
sound
of
music
from
the
house
,
and
remembered
that
he
had
come
there
with
the
one
sole
object
of
seeing
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
He
had
known
that
he
would
meet
Lady
Laura
,
and
it
had
been
in
his
mind
to
break
through
that
law
of
silence
which
she
had
imposed
upon
him
,
and
once
more
to
ask
her
to
assist
him
,
 
to
implore
her
for
the
sake
of
their
old
friendship
to
tell
him
whether
there
might
yet
be
for
him
any
chance
of
success
.
<EOS>
But
in
the
interview
which
had
just
taken
place
it
had
been
impossible
for
him
to
speak
a
word
of
himself
or
of
Violet
.
<EOS>
To
her
,
in
her
great
desolation
,
he
could
address
himself
on
no
other
subject
than
that
of
her
own
misery
.
<EOS>
But
not
the
less
when
she
was
talking
to
him
of
her
own
sorrow
,
of
her
regret
that
she
had
not
listened
to
him
when
in
years
past
he
had
spoken
slightingly
of
Mr.
Kennedy
,
was
he
thinking
of
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Kennedy
had
certainly
mistaken
the
signs
of
things
when
he
had
accused
his
wife
by
saying
that
Phineas
was
her
lover
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
soon
got
over
that
early
feeling
;
and
as
far
as
he
himself
was
concerned
had
never
regretted
Lady
Laura
's
marriage
.
  
<EOS>
He
remained
down
by
the
water
for
a
few
minutes
,
giving
Lady
Laura
time
to
escape
,
and
then
he
wandered
across
the
grounds
towards
the
house
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
about
nine
o'clock
,
and
though
there
were
still
many
walking
about
the
grounds
,
the
crowd
of
people
were
in
the
rooms
.
<EOS>
The
musicians
were
ranged
out
on
a
verandah
,
so
that
their
music
might
have
been
available
for
dancing
within
or
without
;
but
the
dancers
had
found
the
boards
pleasanter
than
the
lawn
,
and
the
Duke
's
garden
party
was
becoming
a
mere
ball
,
with
privilege
for
the
dancers
to
stroll
about
the
lawn
between
the
dances
.
<EOS>
And
in
this
respect
the
fun
was
better
than
at
a
ball
,
 
<EOS>
that
let
the
engagements
made
for
partners
be
what
they
might
,
they
could
always
be
broken
with
ease
.
<EOS>
No
lady
felt
herself
bound
to
dance
with
a
cavalier
who
was
displeasing
to
her
;
and
some
gentlemen
were
left
sadly
in
the
lurch
.
<EOS>
Phineas
felt
himself
to
be
very
much
in
the
lurch
,
even
after
he
had
discovered
Violet
Effingham
standing
up
to
dance
with
Lord
Fawn
.
  
<EOS>
He
bided
his
time
patiently
,
and
at
last
he
found
his
opportunity
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Would
she
dance
with
him
?
"
<EOS>
She
declared
that
she
intended
to
dance
no
more
,
and
that
she
had
promised
to
be
ready
to
return
home
with
Lord
Brentford
before
ten
o'clock
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
pledged
myself
not
to
be
after
ten
,
"
she
said
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
Then
she
put
her
hand
upon
his
arm
,
and
they
stepped
out
upon
the
terrace
together
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have
you
heard
anything
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
asked
him
,
almost
in
a
whisper
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
what
you
mean
.
<EOS>
I
have
heard
it
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
dreadful
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
fear
it
is
the
best
thing
she
can
do
.
<EOS>
She
has
never
been
happy
with
him
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
to
be
accused
after
that
fashion
,
 
by
her
husband
!
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
One
can
hardly
believe
it
in
these
days
.
<EOS>
And
of
all
women
she
is
the
last
to
deserve
such

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
very
last
,
"
said
Phineas
,
feeling
that
the
subject
was
one
upon
which
it
was
not
easy
for
him
to
speak
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
conceive
to
whom
he
can
have
alluded
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
began
to
understand
that
Violet
had
not
heard
the
whole
story
;
but
the
difficulty
of
speaking
was
still
very
great
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
the
result
of
ungovernable
temper
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
a
man
does
not
usually
strive
to
dishonour
himself
because
he
is
in
a
rage
.
<EOS>
And
this
man
is
incapable
of
rage
.
<EOS>
He
must
be
cursed
with
one
of
those
dark
gloomy
minds
in
which
love
always
leads
to
jealousy
.
<EOS>
She
will
never
return
to
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
One
can
not
say
.
<EOS>
In
many
respects
it
would
be
better
that
she
should
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
will
never
return
to
him
,
"
repeated
Violet
,
 
"
never
.
<EOS>
Would
you
advise
her
to
do
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
say
?
<EOS>
If
one
were
called
upon
for
advice
,
one
would
think
so
much
before
one
spoke
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
,
 
not
for
a
minute
.
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
to
be
accused
of
that
!
<EOS>
How
are
a
man
and
woman
to
live
together
after
there
have

such

?
<EOS>
Poor
Laura
!
<EOS>
What
a
terrible
end
to
all
her
high

!
<EOS>
Do
you
not
grieve
for
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
They
were
now
at
some
distance
from
the
house
,
and
Phineas
could
not
but
feel
that
chance
had
been
very
good
to
him
in
giving
him
his
opportunity
.
<EOS>
She
was
leaning
on
his
arm
,
and
they
were
alone
,
and
she
was
speaking
to
him
with
all
the
familiarity
of
old

.
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whether
I
may
change
the

,
"
said
he
,
"
and
ask
you
a
word
about
yourself
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
word
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
sharply
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
 
"
  
"
What
have
you
heard
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Simply
this
,
 
that
you
are
not
now
as
you
were
six
months
ago
.
<EOS>
Your
marriage
was
then
fixed
for
June
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
unfixed
since
then
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
it
has
been
unfixed
.
<EOS>
I
know
it
.
<EOS>
Miss
Effingham
,
you
will
not
be
angry
with
me
if
I
say
that
when
I
heard
it
was
so
,
something
of
a
hope
,
 
no
,
I
must

,
 
something
that
longed
to

into
hope
returned
to
my

,
and
from
that

to
this
has

on
which
I
have
cared
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lord
Chiltern
is
your

,
Mr.
Finn
?
"
  
"
He
is
so
,
and
I
do
not

that
I
have

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
says
that
no

has
ever

.
<EOS>
He
will

that
in
all

.
<EOS>
And
I
,

,

.
<EOS>
As
his
friend
,
let

one

,
 
one

I

,

.
<EOS>
You

a

,
and

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
will
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
will
not
,
because
you
are
a
gentleman
.
<EOS>
I
told
Lord
Chiltern
in
the
autumn
of
last
year
that
I
loved
him
.
<EOS>
And
I
did
love
him
.
<EOS>
I
shall
never
have
the
same
confession
to
make
to
another
man
.
<EOS>
That
he
and
I
are
not
now
,
 
on
those

,
 
which
once

,
can

no

in

.
<EOS>
A
woman
can
not
transfer
her
heart
.
<EOS>
There
have
been
things
which
have
made
me
feel
,
 
that
I
was
perhaps
