,
 
in
saying
that
I
would
be
,
 
his
wife
.
<EOS>
But
I
said
so
,
and
can
not
now
give
myself
to
another
.
<EOS>
Here
is
Lord
Brentford
,
and
we
will
join
him
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
Lord
Brentford
with
Lady
Laura
on
his
arm
,
very
gloomy
,
 
resolving
on
what
way
he
might
be
avenged
on
the
man
who
had
insulted
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
He
took
but
little
notice
of
Phineas
as
he
resumed
his
charge
of
Miss
Effingham
;
but
the
two
ladies
wished
him
good
night
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
Lady
Laura
,
"
said
Phineas
,
standing
with
his
hat
in
his
hand
,
 
"
good
night
,
Miss
Effingham
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
was
alone
,
 
quite
alone
.
<EOS>
Would
it
not
be
well
for
him
to
go
down
to
the
bottom
of
the
garden
,
and
fling
himself
into
the
quiet
river
,
so
that
there
might
be
an
end
of
him
?
<EOS>
Or
would
it
not
be
better
still
that
he
should
create
for
himself
some
quiet
river
of
life
,
away
from
London
,
away
from
politics
,
away
from
lords
,
and
titled
ladies
,
and
fashionable
squares
,
and
<EOS>
the
parties
given
by
dukes
,
and
the
disappointments
incident
to
a
small
man
in
attempting
to
make
for
himself
a
career
among
big
men
?
<EOS>
There
had
frequently
been
in
the
mind
of
this
young
man
an
idea
that
there
was
something
almost
false
in
his
own
position
,
 
that
his
life
was
a
pretence
,
and
that
he
would
ultimately
be
subject
to
that
ruin
which
always
comes
,
sooner
or
later
,
on
things
which
are
false
;
and
now
as
he
wandered
alone
about
Lady
Glencora
's
gardens
,
this
feeling
was
very
strong
within
his
bosom
,
and
robbed
him
altogether
of
the
honour
and
glory
of
having
been
one
of
the
Duke
of
Omnium
's
guests
.
   
<EOS>
The
Cabinet
Minister
at
Killaloe
 
<EOS>
Phineas
did
not
throw
himself
into
the
river
from
the
Duke
's
garden
;
and
was
ready
,
in
spite
of
Violet
Effingham
,
to
start
for
Ireland
with
Mr.
Monk
at
the
end
of
the
first
week
in
August
.
<EOS>
The
close
of
that
season
in
London
certainly
was
not
a
happy
period
of
his
life
.
<EOS>
Violet
had
spoken
to
him
after
such
a
fashion
that
he
could
not
bring
himself
not
to
believe
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
given
him
no
hint
whether
it
was
likely
or
unlikely
that
she
and
Lord
Chiltern
would
be
reconciled
;
but
she
had
convinced
him
that
he
could
not
be
allowed
to
take
Lord
Chiltern
's
place
.
<EOS>
"
A
woman
can
not
transfer
her
heart
,
"
she
had
said
.
<EOS>
Phineas
was
well
aware
that
many
women
do
transfer
their
hearts
;
but
he
had
gone
to
this
woman
too
soon
after
the
wrench
which
her
love
had
received
;
he
had
been
too
sudden
with
his
proposal
for
a
transfer
;
and
the
punishment
for
such
ill
judgment
must
be
that
success
would
now
be
impossible
to
him
.
<EOS>
And
yet
how
could
he
have
waited
,
feeling
that
Miss
Effingham
,
if
she
were
at
all
like
other
girls
whom
he
had
known
,
might
have
promised
herself
to
some
other
lover
before
she
would
return
within
his
reach
in
the
succeeding
spring
?
<EOS>
But
she
was
not
like
some
other
girls
.
<EOS>
Ah
;
 
he
knew
that
now
,
and
repented
him
of
his
haste
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
was
ready
for
Mr.
Monk
on
the
7th
of
August
,
and
they
started
together
.
<EOS>
Something
less
than
twenty
hours
took
them
from
London
to
Killaloe
,
and
during
four
or
five
of
those
twenty
hours
Mr.
Monk
was
unfitted
for
any
conversation
by
the
uncomfortable
feelings
incidental
to
the
passage
from
Holyhead
to
Kingstown
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
there
was
a
great
deal
of
conversation
between
them
during
the
journey
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
had
almost
made
up
his
mind
to
leave
the
Cabinet
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
sad
to
me
to
have
to
confess
it
,
"
he
said
,
"
but
the
truth
is
that
my
old
rival
,
Turnbull
,
is
right
.
<EOS>
A
man
who
begins
his
political
life
as
I
began
mine
,
is
not
the
man
of
whom
a
Minister
should
be
formed
.
<EOS>
I
am
inclined
to
think
that
Ministers
of
Government
require
almost
as
much
education
in
their
trade
as
shoemakers
or
tallow
-
chandlers
.
<EOS>
I
doubt
whether
you
can
make
a
good
public
servant
of
a
man
simply
because
he
has
got
the
ear
of
the
House
of
Commons
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
mean
to
say
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
that
we
are
altogether
wrong
from
beginning
to
end
,
in
our
way
of
arranging
these
things
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
say
that
at
all
.
<EOS>
Look
at
the
men
who
have
been
leading
statesmen
since
our
present
mode
of
government
was
formed
,
 
from
the
days
in
which
it
was
forming
itself
,
say
from
Walpole
down
,
and
you
will
find
that
all
who
have
been
of
real
use
had
early
training
as
public
servants
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Are
we
never
to
get
out
of
the
old
groove
?
"
  
"
Not
if
the
groove
is
good
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
,
"
Those
who
have
been
efficient
as

sucked
in
their
efficacy
with
their
mother
's

.
<EOS>
Lord
Brock
did
so
,
and
Lord
de
Terrier
,
and
Mr.
Mildmay
.
<EOS>
They
seated

in
office

the
moment

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
was
in
office
before

eight
-
and
-
twenty
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
was

he

three
-

-
twenty
.
<EOS>
You
,

,

done

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
regret

every

my

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
cause
for

,
but
it

.
<EOS>
If

any
man
unfitted

previous

for

,
it
is
he
who
has

,
or
who
has

to

,
a
popular

,
 
an

,
if

,

.
<EOS>
As

I

,
office
is
offered
to
such
men
with
one

only
,
 
that
of
clipping

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
of
obtaining
their

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
same
thing
.
<EOS>
Help
from
Turnbull
would
mean
the
withdrawal
of
all
power
of
opposition
from
him
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
give
other
help
for
any

,
as
the
very

of
his
accepting
power
and
patronage
would
take

his
popular

.
<EOS>
The
masses
outside
require
to
have
their
minister
as
the
Queen
has
hers
;
but
the
same
man
can
not
be

.
<EOS>
If
the
people
's

chooses
to

,

,
something

in

.
<EOS>
But
there

,

.
<EOS>
Of

has
this

,
that

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
did
not

.
<EOS>
To

will

state
so
much

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
I
did
not

,
though
I
am
so
poor
<EOS>
a
man
that
the
shilling

more

.
<EOS>
I

,

,
but
guided

this
,
that
I

.
<EOS>
They

,
 
Mr.
Mildmay

,
 
that

.
<EOS>
I
have
not

,
and

not

,
 
unless

be

the
good

the
country
that
my

.
<EOS>
If

,
I
ought
to

my

without

for

.
<EOS>
I
have
made

,
my
friend
.
<EOS>
Such

can

;
but
,

,
I
must
do

best
in
my
power
to

.
"
  
<EOS>
There

in

this
to

himself
of

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
truth
is
,
"
he

,
"
that
a
man

be

,
and
that

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
I
think
you
are
wrong
.
<EOS>
If
you

.
<EOS>
If

Bar

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can

ought

.
<EOS>
You
are

,

your

.
<EOS>
With

.
<EOS>
If

this

,

.
<EOS>
Could

begin

,
I
would
willingly

as
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
day
in
Killaloe
,
that
on
which
Mr.
Monk
arrived
with
Phineas
at
the
doctor
's
house
.
<EOS>
In
London
,
perhaps
,
a
bishop
inspires
more
awe
than
a
Cabinet
Minister
.
<EOS>
In
Killaloe
,
where
a
bishop
might
be
seen
walking
about
every
day
,
the
mitred
dignitary
of
the
Church
,
though
much
loved
,
was
thought
of
,
I
fear
,
but
lightly
;
whereas
a
Cabinet
Minister
coming
to
stay
in
the
house
of
a
townsman
was
a
thing
to
be
wondered
at
,
to
be
talked
about
,
to
be
afraid
of
,
to
be
a
fruitful
source
of
conversation
for
a
year
to
come
.
<EOS>
There
were
many
in
Killaloe
,
especially
among
the
elder
ladies
,
who
had
shaken
their
heads
and
expressed
the
saddest

when
young
Phineas
Finn
had
first
become
a
Parliament

.
<EOS>
And
though
by
degrees
they
had
been
half

round
,
having
been
driven
to
acknowledge
that
he
had
been
wonderfully
successful
as
a
Parliament
man
,
still
they
had
continued
to
shake
their
heads
among
themselves
,
and
to
fear
something
in
the
future
,
 
until
he
appeared
at
his
old
home
leading
a
Cabinet
Minister
by
the
hand
.
<EOS>
There
was
such
assurance
in
this
that
even
old
Mrs.
Callaghan
,
at
the
brewery
,
gave
way
,
and
began
to
say
all
manner
of
good
things
,
and
to
praise
the
doctor
's
luck
in
that
he
had
a
son
gifted
with
parts
so
excellent
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
great
desire
to
see
the
Cabinet
Minister
in
the
flesh
,
to
be
with
him
when
he
ate
and

,
to
watch
the
gait
and

of
the
man
,
and
to

water
from
this
fountain
of
state
lore
which
had
been
so

brought
among
them
by
their
young

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Finn
was
aware
that
it
behoved
her
to
be
chary
of
her
invitations
,
but
the
lady
from
the
brewery
had
said

good
things
of
Mrs.
Finn
's
black

,
that
she
carried
her
point
,
and
was
invited
to
meet
the
Cabinet
Minister
at

on

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Flood
Jones
and
her
daughter
were
invited
also
to
be
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
When
Phineas
had
been
last
at
Killaloe
,
Mrs.
Flood
Jones
,
as
the
reader
may
remember
,
had
remained
with
her
daughter
at
Floodborough
,
 
feeling

to
be
her
duty
to
keep
her
daughter
away

the

an

.
<EOS>
But

seemed
that
her
purpose
was
changed
now
,
or
that
she
no

the
danger
,
 
for
both
Mary
and
her
mother
were
now
again
living
in
Killaloe
,
and
Mary
was
at
the
doctor
's
house
as
much
as
ever
.
  
<EOS>
A
day
or

before

the
god

to

,
Barbara
Finn
and
her
friend
had
thus

Shannon

.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
,
my
dear
,
that
he
is

,
"
said

Finn
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
am
sure
,
my

,
"
said
Mary
,
"
that
I
do
not

he
is
or

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
what
I
say
.
<EOS>
Why
should
I
care
?
<EOS>
Five
years
ago
I
had
a
foolish

,
and
now
I

.
<EOS>
Think

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
you

.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

this

;
 
that
I

.
<EOS>
Mamma
and
I
quite

.
<EOS>
She
used

,
but
she
has

.
<EOS>
It
always

;
 
<EOS>
the

a
man
<EOS>
because
,
 
because
 
!
<EOS>
You
know
one
ca
n't

it
,
it
is
so

.
<EOS>
But
that
is
all

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

do

,
Mary
?
<EOS>
Do

less

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
remember

all

,

I

.
<EOS>
As

,

,
 
because

,
and

.
<EOS>
But

-

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Barbara
Finn
walked
on

before
she

.
<EOS>
"
Mary
,
"
she

,
"
I
do
n't

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
;
 
then
all
that
I
shall
ask

you
is
,
that
we
may
not
talk
about
him
any

.
<EOS>
Mamma
believes
it
,
and
that
is
enough

me
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
they
did
talk
about
Phineas
during
the
whole
of
that
day
,
and
very
often
talked
about
him
afterwards
,
as
long

Mary
remained
at
Killaloe
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
large
dinner
party
at
the
doctor
's
on
the
day
after
Mr.
Monk
's
arrival
.
<EOS>
The
bishop
was
not
there
,
though
he
was
on
terms
sufficiently
friendly
with
the
doctor
's
family
to
have
been

on
so
grand

;
but
he
was
not
there
,
because
Mrs.
Finn
was
determined
that
she
would
be
taken
out
to
dinner
by
a
Cabinet
Minister
in
the
face
of
all
her
friends
.
<EOS>
She
was
aware
that
had
the
bishop
been
there
,
she
must
have
taken
the
bishop
's
arm
.
<EOS>
And
though
there
would
have
been
glory
in
that
,
the
other

was
more
to
her
taste
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
time
in
her
life
that
she
had
ever
seen
a
Cabinet
Minister
,
and
I
think
that
she
was
a
little
disappointed
at
finding
him
so
like
other
middle
-
aged
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
She
had
hoped
that
Mr.
Monk
would
have
assumed
something
of
the
dignity
of
his
position
;
but
he
assumed
nothing
.
<EOS>
Now
the
bishop
,
though
he
was
a
very
mild
man
,
did
assume
something
by
the
very
facts
of
his
apron
and
knee
-
breeches
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
,
sir
,
it
is
very
good
of
you
to
come
and
put
up
with
our
humble
way
of
living
,
"
said
Mrs.
Finn
to
her
guest
,
as
they
sat
down
at
table
.
<EOS>
And
yet
she
had
resolved
that
she
would
not
make
any
speech
of
the
kind
,
 
that
she
would
condescend
to
no
apology
,
 
that
she
would
bear
herself
as
though
a
Cabinet
Minister
dined
with
her
at
least
once
a
year
.
<EOS>
But
when
the
moment
came
,
she
broke
down
,
and
made
this
apology
with
almost
abject
meekness
,
and
then
hated
herself
because
she
had
done
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
madam
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
,
"
I
live
myself
so
much
like
a
hermit
that
your
house
is
a
palace
of
luxury
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
he
felt
that
he
had
made
a
foolish
speech
,
and
he
also
hated
himself
.
<EOS>
He
found
it
very
difficult
to
talk
to
his
hostess
upon
any
subject
,
until
by
chance
he
mentioned
his
young
friend
Phineas
.
<EOS>
Then
her
tongue
was
unloosed
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
son
,
madam
,
"
he
said
,
"
is
going
with
me
to
Limerick
and
back
to
Dublin
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
shame
,
I
know
,
taking
him
so
soon
away
from
home
,
but
I
should
not
know
how
to
get
on
without
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Monk
,
it
is
such
a
blessing
for
him
,
and
such
an
honour
for
us
,
that
you
should
be
so
good
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
Then
the
mother
spoke
out
all
her
past
fears
and
all
her
present
hopes
,
and
acknowledged
the
great
glory
which
it
was
to
her
to
have
a
son
sitting
in
Parliament
,
holding
an
office
with
a
stately
name
and
a
great
salary
,
and
blessed
with
the
friendship
of
such
a
man
as
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
After
that
Mr.
Monk
got
on
better
with
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
any
young
man
,
"
said
he
,
"
in
whose
career
I
have
taken
so
strong
an
interest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
always
good
,
"
said
Mrs.
Finn
,
with
a
tear
forcing
itself
into
the
corner
of
each
eye
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
his
mother
,
and
of
course
I
ought
not
to
say
so
,
 
not
in
this
way
;
but
it
is
true
,
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
then
the
poor
lady
was
obliged
to
raise
her

and
wipe
away

drops
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
on
this
occasion
had
taken
out
to
dinner
the
mother
of
his
devoted
Mary
,
Mrs.
Flood
Jones
.
<EOS>
"
What
a

it
must

to

Mrs.
Finn
to
see
you
come
back
in
this

,
"
said

Flood
Jones
.
  
<EOS>
"
With
all
my
bones
unbroken
?
"
said

,
laughing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
with
all
your
bones
unbroken
.
<EOS>
You
know
,
Phineas
,

,

,
 
since

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
Everybody

;

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

have

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

,

,

Flood
Jones
.
<EOS>
There

in

still
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
far

I

,

.
<EOS>
All

,
that

,

,

.
<EOS>
Rumours

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Rumours
always
lie
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Sometimes
they
do
,
of
course
;
and
I

not

.
<EOS>
But
that
is
what
we
all

.
<EOS>
Mary
was
saying
,
only

other

,
that
if
you
were
once
married
,
we
should
all

quite

about

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
It

County
Clare

on
as
you

done
,
and
therefore

are
bound
to
think

.
"
<EOS>
Thus
Mrs.
Flood
Jones
signified
to
Phineas
Finn
that

forgiven

,

;

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

think

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Every

should

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
When

ladies

,

was
impossible
but
that

discuss

Monk
.
<EOS>
There
was
Mrs.
Callaghan
from
the
brewery
there
,
and
old
Lady
Blood
,
of
Bloodstone
,
 
who
on
ordinary

would
hardly

that
she
was
on
dining
-
out
terms
with
any

in
Killaloe
except

,
but
who
had
found

a
Cabinet

,
 
and

Mrs.
Stackpoole
from
Sixmiletown
,
a

-

of

Finns
,
who
hated
Lady
Blood
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,

,
"

Blood
.
  
<EOS>
"
I

he
is

,
"

Mrs.
Flood
Jones
.
  
<EOS>
"
So

,
my

,

,
"

Callaghan
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"

Blood
.
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

?
"

Stackpoole
.
<EOS>
"
Men
and
women

London
walk
upon

,
just

Ennis
.
"
<EOS>
Now
Lady
Blood
herself
had
been
born

Ennis
,
whereas
Mrs.
Stackpoole
had
come
from
Limerick
,
which
is
a

,
and

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
My

Stackpoole
,
I

.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Blood
had
once

in
London
while
Sir
Patrick
had
been

,
whereas
Mrs.
Stackpoole
had
never

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,
"

;
"

expect
.
<EOS>
I

Monk
ought

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,
Cabinet

,
"
said

Blood
.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

Finn
.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Now

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

.
<EOS>
"
All

,

come

;
and
as

,

in

.
<EOS>
"
Now

Mrs.
Stackpoole

,
as

.
<EOS>
After

,
as

that
all

good
-

,

.
   
<EOS>
Victrix
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
's
holiday
programme
allowed
him
a
week
at
Killaloe
,
and
from
thence
he
was
to
go
to
Limerick
,
and
from
Limerick
to
Dublin
,
in
order
that
,
at
both
places
,
he
might
be
entertained
at
a
public
dinner
and
make
a
speech
about
tenant
-
right
.
<EOS>
Foreseeing
that
Phineas
might
commit
himself
if
he
attended
these
meetings
,
Mr.
Monk
had
counselled
him
to
remain
at
Killaloe
.
<EOS>
But
Phineas
had
refused
to
subject
himself
to
such
cautious
abstinence
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
had
come
to
Ireland
as
his
friend
,
and
he
would
see
him
through
his
travels
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
,
probably
,
be
asked
to
speak
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
and
if
I
am
asked
,
I
need
not
say
more
than
a
few
words
.
<EOS>
And
what
if
I
did
speak
out
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
might
find
it
disadvantageous
to
you
in
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
take
my
chance
of
that
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
going
to
tie
myself
down
for
ever
and
ever
for
the
sake
of
being
Under
-
Secretary
to
the
Colonies
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
said
very
much
to
him
on
the
subject
,
 
was
constantly
saying
very
much
to
him
about
it
;
but
in
spite
of
all
that
Mr.
Monk
said
,
Phineas
did
make
the
journey
to
Limerick
and
Dublin
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
,
since
his
arrival
at
Killaloe
,
been
a
moment
alone
with
Mary
Flood
Jones
till
the
evening
before
he
started
with
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
She
had
kept
out
of
his
way
successfully
,
though
she
had
constantly
been
with
him
in
company
,
and
was
beginning
to
plume
herself
on
the
strength
and
valour
of
her
conduct
.
<EOS>
But
her
self
-
praise
had
in
it
nothing
of
joy
,
and
her
glory
was
very
sad
.
<EOS>
Of
course
she
would
care
for
him
no
more
,
 
more
especially
as
it
was
so
very
evident
that
he
cared
not
at
all
for
her
.
<EOS>
But
the
very
fact
of
her
keeping
out
of
his
way
,
made
her
acknowledge
to
herself
that
her
position
was
very
miserable
.
<EOS>
She
had
declared
to
her
mother
that
she
might
certainly
go
to
Killaloe
with
safety
,
 
that
it
would
be
better
for
her
to
put
herself
in
the
way
of
meeting
him
as
an
old
friend
,
 
that
the
idea
of
the
necessity
of
shutting
herself
up
because
of
his
approach
,
was
the
one
thing
that
gave
her
real
pain
.
<EOS>
Therefore
her
mother
had
brought
her
to
Killaloe
and
she
had
met
him
;
but
her
fancied
security
had
deserted
her
,
and
she
found
herself
to
be
miserable
,
hoping
for
something
she
did
not
know
what
,
still
dreaming
of
possibilities
,
feeling
during
every
moment
of
his
presence
with
her
that
some
special
conduct
was
necessary
on
her
part
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
make
further
confession
to
her
mother
and
ask
to
be
carried
back
to
Floodborough
;
but
she
knew
that
she
was
very
wretched
at
Killaloe
.
  
<EOS>
As
for
Phineas
,
he
had
felt
that
his
old
friend
was
very
cold
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
in
that
humour
with
reference
to
Violet
Effingham
which
seemed
especially
to
require
consolation
.
<EOS>
He
knew
now
that
all
hope
was
over
there
.
<EOS>
Violet
Effingham
could
never
be
his
wife
.
<EOS>
Even
were
she
not
to
marry
Lord
Chiltern
for
the
next
five
years
,
she
would
not
,
during
those
five
years
,
marry
any
other
man
.
<EOS>
Such
was
our
hero
's
conviction
;
and
,
suffering
under
this
conviction
,
he
was
in
want
of
the
comfort
of
feminine
sympathy
.
<EOS>
Had
Mary
known
all
this
,
and
had
it
suited
her
to
play
such
a
part
<EOS>
,
I
think
she
might
have
had
Phineas
at
her
feet
before
he
had
been
a
week
at
home
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
kept
aloof
from
him
and
had
heard
nothing
of
his
sorrows
.
<EOS>
As
a
natural
consequence
of
this
,
Phineas
was
more
in
love
with
her
than
ever
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
evening
before
he
started
with
Mr.
Monk
for
Limerick
,
he
managed
to
be
alone
with
her
for
a
few
minutes
.
<EOS>
Barbara
may
probably
have
assisted
in
bringing
about
this
arrangement
,
and
had
,
perhaps
,
been
guilty
of
some
treachery
,
 
sisters
in
such
circumstances
will
sometimes
be
very
treacherous
to
their
friends
.
<EOS>
I
feel
sure
,
however
,
that
Mary
herself
was
quite
innocent
of
any
guile
in
the
matter
.
"
<EOS>
Mary
,
"
Phineas
said
to
her
suddenly
,
"
it
seems
to
me
that
you
have
avoided
me
purposely
ever
since
I
have
been
at
home
.
"
<EOS>
She
smiled
and
blushed
,
and
stammered
and
said
nothing
.
"
<EOS>
Has
there
been
any
reason
for
it
,
Mary
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
reason
at
all
that
I
know
of
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
used
to
be
such
great
friends
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
was
before
you
were
a
great
man
,
Phineas
.
<EOS>
It
must
necessarily
be
different
now
.
<EOS>
You
know
so
many
people
now
,
and
people
of
such
a
different
sort
,
that
of
course
I
fall
a
little
into
the
background
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
you
talk
in
that
way
,
Mary
,
I
know
that
you
are
laughing
at
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
indeed
I
am
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
there
is
no
one
in
the
whole
world
,
"
he
said
,
after
a
pause
,
"
whose
friendship
is
more
to
me
than
yours
is
.
<EOS>
I
think
of
it
so
often
,
Mary
.
<EOS>
Say
that
when
we
come
back
it
shall
be
between
us
as
it
used
to
be
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
put
out
his
hand
for
hers
,
and
she
could
not
help
giving
it
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
there
will
be
people
,
"
he
said
,
"
who
talk
nonsense
,
and
one
can
not
help
it
;
but
I
will
not
put
up
with
it
from
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
mean
to
talk
nonsense
,
Phineas
!
"
<EOS>
Then
there
came
some
one
across
them
,
and
the
conversation
was
ended
;
but
the
sound
of
his
voice
remained
on
her
ears
,
and
she
could
not
help
but
remember
that
he
had
declared
that
her
friendship
was
dearer
to
him
than
the
friendship
of
any
one
else
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
went
with
Mr.
Monk
first
to
Limerick
and
then
to
Dublin
,
and
found
himself
at
both
places
to
be
regarded
as
a
hero
only
second
to
the
great
hero
.
<EOS>
At
both
places
the
one
subject
of
debate
was
tenant
-
right
;
 
could
anything
be
done
to
make
it
profitable
for
men
with
capital
to
put
their
capital
into
Irish
land
?
<EOS>
The
fertility
of
the
soil
was
questioned
by
no
one
,
 
nor
the
sufficiency
of
external
circumstances
,
such
as
railroads
and
the
like
;
 
nor
the
abundance
of
labour
;
 
nor
even
security
for
the
wealth
to
be
produced
.
<EOS>
The
only
difficulty
was
in
this
,
that
the
men
who
were
to
produce
the
wealth
had
no
guarantee
that
it
would
be
theirs
when
it
was
created
.
<EOS>
In
England
and
elsewhere
such
guarantees
were
in
existence
.
<EOS>
Might
it
not
be
possible
to
introduce
them
into
Ireland
?
<EOS>
That
was
the
question
which
Mr.
Monk
had
in
hand
;
and
in
various
speeches
which
he
made
both
before
and
after
the
dinners
given
to
him
,
he
pledged
himself
to
keep
it
well
in
hand
when
Parliament
should
meet
.
<EOS>
Of
course
Phineas
spoke
also
.
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
that
he
should
be
silent
when
his
friend
and
leader
was
pouring
out
his
eloquence
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
spoke
,
and
of
course
he
pledged
himself
.
<EOS>
Something
like
the
old
pleasures
of
the
debating
society
returned
to
him
,
as
standing
upon
a
platform
before
a
listening
multitude
,
he
gave
full
vent
to
his
words
.
<EOS>
In
the
House
of
Commons
,
of
late
he
had
been
so
cabined
,
cribbed
,
and
confined
by
office
as
to
have
enjoyed
nothing
of
this
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
from
the
commencement
of
his
career
,
he
had
fallen
so
thoroughly
into
the
decorum
of
Government
ways
,
as
to
have
missed
altogether
the
delights
of
that
wild
irresponsible
oratory
of
which
Mr.
Monk
had
spoken
to
him
so
often
.
<EOS>
He
had
envied
men
below
the
gangway
,
who
,
though
supporting
the
Government
on
main
questions
,
could
get
up
on
their
legs
whenever
the
House
was
full
enough
to
make
it
worth
their
while
,
and
say
almost
whatever
they
pleased
.
<EOS>
There
was
that
Mr.
Robson
,
who
literally
did
say
just
what
came
uppermost
;
and
the
thing
that
came
uppermost
was
often
ill
-
natured
,
often
unbecoming
the
gravity
of
the
House
,
was
always
startling
;
but
men
listened
to
him
and
liked
him
to
speak
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Robson
had
 
married
a
woman
with
money
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
why
,
 
why
,
had
not
Violet
Effingham
been
kinder
to
him
?
<EOS>
He
might
even
yet
,
perhaps
,
marry
a
woman
with
money
.
<EOS>
But
he
could
not
bring
himself
to
do
so
unless
he
loved
her
.
  
<EOS>
The
upshot
of
the
Dublin
meeting
was
that
he
also
positively
pledged
himself
to
support
during
the
next
session
of
Parliament
a
bill
advocating
tenant
-
right
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
you
went
so
far
as
that
,
"
Mr.
Monk
said
to
him
almost
as
soon
as
the
meeting
was
over
.
<EOS>
They
were
standing
on
the
pier
at
Kingstown
,
and
Mr.
Monk
was
preparing
to
return
to
England
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
not
I
as
far
as
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
had
thought
about
it
,
and
I
do
not
think
that
you
have
.
<EOS>
I
am
prepared
to
resign
my
office
to
-
morrow
;
and
directly
that
I
can
see
Mr.
Gresham
and
explain
to
him
what
I
have
done
,
I
shall
offer
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
wo
n't
accept
your
resignation
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
must
accept
it
,
unless
he
is
prepared
to
instruct
the
Irish
Secretary
to
bring
in
such

bill
as
I
can
support
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
exactly
in
the
same
boat
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
ought
not
to
be
in
the
same
boat
;
 
nor
need
you
.
<EOS>
My
advice
to
you
is
to
say
nothing
about
it
till
you
get
back
to
London
,
and
then
speak
to
Lord
Cantrip
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
that
you
will
not
say
anything
on
the
subject
in
the
House
,
but
that
in
the
event
of
there
being
a
division
you
hope
to
be
allowed
to
vote
as
on
an
open
question
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
I
shall
get
Gresham
's
assent
,
and
if
so
we
shall
be
all
right
.
<EOS>
If
I
do
not
,
and
if
they
choose
to
make
it
a
point
with
you
,
you
must
resign
also
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
shall
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
not
think
they
will
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
too
useful
,
and
they
will
wish
to
avoid
the
weakness
which
comes
to
a
ministry
from
changing
its
team
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
my
dear
fellow
;
and
remember
this
,
 
my
last
word
of
advice
to
you
is
to
stick
by
the
ship
.
<EOS>
I
am
quite
sure
it
is
a
career
which
will
suit
you
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
begin
it
soon
enough
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
was
rather
melancholy
as
he
returned
alone
to
Killaloe
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
very
well
to
bid
him
stick
to
the
ship
,
and
he
knew
as
well
as
any
one
could
tell
him
how
material
the
ship
was
to
him
;
but
there
are
circumstances
in
which
a
man
can
not
stick
to
his
ship
,
 
can
not
stick
,
at
least
,
to
this
special
Government
ship
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
whither
Mr.
Monk
went
,
in
this
session
,
he
must
follow
.
<EOS>
He
had
considerable
hope
that
when
Mr.
Monk
explained
his
purpose
to
the
Prime
Minister
,
the
Prime
Minister
would
feel
himself
obliged
to
give
way
.
<EOS>
In
that
case
Phineas
would
not
only
be
able
to
keep
his
office
,
but
would
have
such
an
opportunity
of
making
a
speech
in
Parliament
as
circumstances
had
never
yet
given
to
him
.
<EOS>
When
he
was
again
at
home
he
said
nothing
to
his
father
or
to
the
Killaloeians
as
to
the
danger
of
his
position
.
<EOS>
Of
what
use
would
it
be
to
make
his
mother
and
sisters
miserable
,
or
to
incur
the
useless
counsels
of
the
doctor
?
<EOS>
They
seemed
to
think
his
speech
at
Dublin
very
fine
,
and
were
never
tired
of
talking
of
what
Mr.
Monk
and
Phineas
were
going
to
do
;
but
the
idea
had
not
come
home
to
them
that
if
Mr.
Monk
or
Phineas
chose
to
do
anything
on
their
own
account
,
they
must
give
up
the
places
which
they
held
under
the
Crown
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
September
when
Phineas
found
himself
back
at
Killaloe
,
and
he
was
due
to
be
at
his
office
in
London
in
November
.
<EOS>
The
excitement
of
Mr.
Monk
's
company
was
now
over
,
and
he
had
nothing
to
do
but
to
receive
pouches
full
of
official
papers
from
the
Colonial
Office
,
and
study
all
the
statistics
which
came
within
his
reach
in
reference
to
the
proposed
new
law
for
tenant
-
right
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
Mary
was
still
living
with
her
mother
at
Killaloe
,
and
still
kept
herself
somewhat
aloof
from
the
man
she
loved
.
<EOS>
How
could
it
be
possible
for
him
not
to
give
way
in
such
circumstances
as
those
?
  
<EOS>
One
day
he
found
himself
talking
to
her
about
himself
,
and
speaking
to
her
of
his
own
position
with
more
frankness
than
he
ever
used
with
his
own
family
.
<EOS>
He
had
begun
by
reminding
her
of
that
conversation
which
they
had
had
before
he
went
away
with
Mr.
Monk
,
and
by
reminding
her
also
that
she
had
promised
to
return
to
her
old
friendly
ways
with
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
Phineas
;
there
was
no
promise
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
are
we
not
to
be
friends
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
only
say
that
I
made
no
particular
promise
.
<EOS>
Of
course
we
are
friends
.
<EOS>
We
have
always
been
friends
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
say
if
you
heard
that
I
had
resigned
my
office
and
given
up
my
seat
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
<EOS>
Of
course
she
expressed
her
surprise
,
almost
her
horror
,
at
such
an
idea
,
and
then
he
told
her
everything
.
<EOS>
It
took
long
in
the
telling
,
because
it
was
necessary
that
he
should
explain
to
her
the
working
of
the
system
which
made
it
impossible
for
him
,
as
a
member
of
the
Government
,
to
entertain
an
opinion
of
his
own
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
do
you
mean
that
you
would
lose
your
salary
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
I
should
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Would
not
that
be
very
dreadful
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
laughed
as
he
acknowledged
that
it
would
be
dreadful
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
dreadful
,
Mary
,
to
have
nothing
to
eat
and
drink
.
<EOS>
But
what
is
a
man
to
do
?
<EOS>
Would
you
recommend
me
to
say
that
black
is
white
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
you
will
never
do
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
Mary
,
it
is
very
nice
to
be
called
by
a
big
name
and
to
have
a
salary
,
and
it
is
very
comfortable
to
be
envied
by
one
's
friends
and
enemies
;
 
but
there
are
drawbacks
.
<EOS>
There
is
this
especial
drawback
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
paused
for
a
moment
before
he
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
especial
drawback
,
Phineas
?
"
  
"
A
man
can
not
do
what
he
pleases
with
himself
.
<EOS>
How
can
a
man
marry
,
so
circumstanced
as
I
am
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
hesitated
for
a
moment
,
and
then
she
answered
him
,
 
"
A
man
may
be
very
happy
without
marrying
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
also
paused
for
many
moments
before
he
spoke
again
,
and
she
then
made
a
faint
attempt
to
escape
from
him
.
<EOS>
But
before
she
succeeded
he
had
asked
her
a
question
which
arrested
her
.
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whether
you
would
listen
to
me
if
I
were
to
tell
you
a
history
?
<EOS>
"
Of
course
she
listened
,
and
the
history
he
told
her
was
the
tale
of
his
love
for
Violet
Effingham
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
she
has
money
of
her
own
?
"
<EOS>
Mary
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
she
is
rich
.
<EOS>
She
has
a
large
fortune
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
Mr.
Finn
,
you
must
seek
some
one
else
who
is
equally
blessed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mary
,
that
is
untrue
,
 
that
is
ill
-
natured
.
<EOS>
You
do
not
mean
that
.
<EOS>
Say
that
you
do
not
mean
it
.
<EOS>
You
have
not
believed
that
I
loved
Miss
Effingham
because
she
was
rich
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
have
told
me
that
you
could
love
no
one
who
is
not
rich
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
nothing
of
the
kind
.
<EOS>
Love
is
involuntary
.
<EOS>
It
does
not
often
run
in
a
yoke
with
prudence
.
<EOS>
I
have
told
you
my
history
as
far
as
it
is
concerned
with
Violet
Effingham
.
<EOS>
I
did
love
her
very
dearly
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Did
love
her
,
Mr.
Finn
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;
 
did
love
her
.
<EOS>
Is
there
any
inconstancy
in
ceasing
to
love
when
one
is
not
loved
?
<EOS>
Is
there
inconstancy
in
changing
one
's
love
,
and
in
loving
again
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
,
"
said
Mary
,
to
whom
the
occasion
was
becoming
so
embarrassing
that
she
no
longer
was
able
to
reply
with
words
that
had
a
meaning
in
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
there
be
,
dear
,
I
am
inconstant
.
"
<EOS>
He
paused
,
but
of
course
she
had
not
a
syllable
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
changed
my
love
.
<EOS>
But
I
could
not
speak
of
a
new
passion
till
I
had
told
the
story
of
that
which
has
passed
away
.
<EOS>
You
have
heard
it
all
now
,
Mary
.
<EOS>
Can
you
try
to
love
me
,
after
that
?
<EOS>
"
It
had
come
at
last
,
 
the
thing
for
which
she
had
been
ever
wishing
.
<EOS>
It
had
come
in
spite
of
her
imprudence
,
and
in
spite
of
her
prudence
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
heard
him
to
the
end
she
was
not
a
whit
angry
with
him
,
 
<EOS>
she
was
not
in
the
least
aggrieved
,
 
because
he
had
been
lost
to
her
in
his
love
for
this
Miss
Effingham
,
while
she
had
been
so
nearly
lost
by
her
love
for
him
.
<EOS>
For
women
such
episodes
in
the
lives
of
their
lovers
have
an
excitement
which
is
almost
pleasurable
,
whereas
each
man
is
anxious
to
hear
his
lady
swear
that
until
he
appeared
upon
the
scene
her
heart
had
been
fancy
free
.
<EOS>
Mary
,
upon
the
whole
,
had
liked
the
story
,
 
had
thought
that
it
had
been
finely
told
,
and
was
well
pleased
with
the
final
catastrophe
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
she
was
not
prepared
with
her
reply
.
"
<EOS>
Have
you
no
answer
to
give
me
,
Mary
?
<EOS>
"
he
said
,
looking
up
into
her
eyes
.
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
that
he
did
not
doubt
what
would
be
her
answer
,
 
as
it
would
be
good
that
all
lovers
should
do
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
vouchsafe
me
some
word
,
Mary
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When
she
essayed
to
speak
she
found
that
she
was
dumb
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
get
her
voice
to
give
her
the
assistance
of
a
single
word
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
cry
,
but
there
was
a
motion
as
of
sobbing
in
her
throat
which
impeded
all
utterance
.
<EOS>
She
was
as
happy
as
earth
,
 
as
heaven
could
make
her
;
but
she
did
not
know
how
to
tell
him
that
she
was
happy
.
<EOS>
And
yet
she
longed
to
tell
it
,
that
he
might
know
how
thankful
she
was
to
him
for
his
goodness
.
<EOS>
He
still
sat
looking
at
her
,
and
now
by
degrees
he
had
got
her
hand
in
his
.
"
<EOS>
Mary
,
"
he
said
,
"
will
you
be
my
wife
,
 
my
own
wife
?
"
  
<EOS>
When
half
an
hour
had
passed
,
they
were
still
together
,
and
now
she
had
found
the
use
of
her
tongue
.
<EOS>
"
Do
whatever
you
like
best
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
care
which
you
do
.
<EOS>
If
you
came
to
me
to
-
morrow
and
told
me
you
had
no
income
,
it
would
make
no
difference
.
<EOS>
Though
to
love
you
and
to
have
your
love
is
all
the
world
to
me
,
 
though
it
makes
all
the
difference
between
misery
and
happiness
,
 
I
would
sooner
give
up
that
than
be
a
clog
on
you
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
took
her
in
his
arms
and
kissed
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Phineas
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
"
I
do
love
you
so
entirely
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
own
one
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
your
own
one
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
had
known
it
always
!
<EOS>
Never
mind
.
<EOS>
Now
you
are
my
own
,
 
are
you
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
yes
,
dearest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
what
a
thing
it
is
to
be
victorious
at
last
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
on
earth
are
you
two
doing
here
these
two
hours
together
?
<EOS>
"
said
Barbara
,
bursting
into
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
are
we
doing
?
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
what
are
you
doing
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nothing
in
particular
,
"
said
Mary
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
at
all
in
particular
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Only
this
,
 
that
we
have
engaged
ourselves
to
marry
each
other
.
<EOS>
It
is
quite
a
trifle
,
 
is
it
not
,
Mary
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Barbara
!
"
said
the
joyful
girl
,
springing
forward
into
her
friend
's
arms
;
"
I
do
believe
I
am
the
happiest
creature
on
the
face
of
this
earth
!
"
   
<EOS>
Job
's
Comforters
 
<EOS>
Before
Phineas
had
returned
to
London
his
engagement
with
Mary
Flood
Jones
was
known
to
all
his
family
,
was
known
to
Mrs.
Flood
Jones
,
and
was
indeed
known
generally
to
all
Killaloe
.
<EOS>
That
other
secret
of
his
,
which
had
reference
to
the
probability
of
his
being
obliged
to
throw
up
his
office
,
was
known
only
to
Mary
herself
.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
he
had
done
all
that
honour
required
of
him
in
telling
her
of
his
position
before
he
had
proposed
;
 
so
that
she
might
on
that
ground
refuse
him
if
she
were
so
minded
.
<EOS>
And
yet
he
had
known
very
well
that
such
prudence
on
her
part
was
not
to
be
expected
.
<EOS>
If
she
loved
him
,
of
course
she
would
say
so
when
she
was
asked
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
known
that
she
loved
him
.
<EOS>
"
There
may
be
delay
,
Mary
,
"
he
said
to
her
as
he
was
going
;
"
nay
,
there
must
be
delay
,
if
I
am
obliged
to
resign
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
care
a
straw
for
delay
if
you
will
be
true
to
me
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
doubt
my
truth
,
dearest
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
I
will
swear
by
it
as
the
one
thing
that
is
truest
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
,
dearest
.
<EOS>
And
if
this
should
come
to
pass
I
must
go
to
work
and
put
my
shoulder
to
the
wheel
,
and
earn
an
income
for
you
by
my
old
profession
before
I
can
make
you
my
wife
.
<EOS>
With
such
a
motive
before
me
<EOS>
I
know
that
I
shall
earn
an
income
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
thus
they
parted
.
<EOS>
Mary
,
though
of
course
she
would
have
preferred
that
her
future
husband
should
remain
in
his
high
office
,
that
he
should
be
a
member
of
Parliament
and
an
Under
-
Secretary
of
State
,
admitted
no
doubt
into
her
mind
to
disturb
her
happiness
;
and
Phineas
,
though
he
had
many
misgivings
as
to
the
prudence
of
what
he
had
done
,
was
not
the
less
strong
in
his
resolution
of
constancy
and
endurance
.
<EOS>
He
would
throw
up
his
position
,
resign
his
seat
,
and
go
to
work
at
the
Bar
instantly
,
if
he
found
that
his
independence
as
a
man
required
him
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
And
,
above
all
,
let
come
what
might
,
he
would
be
true
to
Mary
Flood
Jones
.
  
<EOS>
December
was
half
over
before
he
saw
Lord
Cantrip
.
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
 
yes
;
"
said
Lord
Cantrip
,
when
the
Under
-
Secretary
began
to
tell
his
story
;
"
I
saw
what
you
were
about
.
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
been
at
your
elbow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
knew
the
country
as
I
know
it
,
you
would
be
as
eager
about
it
as
I
am
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
can
only
say
that
I
am
very
glad
that
I
do
not
know
the
country
as
you
know
it
.
<EOS>
You
see
,
Finn
,
it
's
my
idea
<EOS>
that
if
a
man
wants
to
make
himself
useful
he
should
stick
to
some
special
kind
of
work
.
<EOS>
With
you
it
's
a
thousand
pities
that
you
should
not
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
think
,
then
,
I
ought
to
resign
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
say
anything
about
that
.
<EOS>
As
you
wish
it
,
of
course
I
'll
speak
to
Gresham
.
<EOS>
Monk
,
I
believe
,
has
resigned
already
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
written
to
me
,
and
told
me
so
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
always
felt
afraid
of
him
for
your
sake
,
Finn
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
is
a
clever
man
,
and
as

man
as
any
in
the
House
,
but
I
always
thought
that
he
was
a

.
<EOS>
However
,
we
will
see
.
<EOS>
I
will
speak
to
Gresham
after
Christmas
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
hurry
about
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
When
Parliament
met
the
first
great
subject
of
interest
was
the
desertion
of
Mr.
Monk
from
the
Ministry
.
<EOS>
He
at
once
took
his
place
below
the
gangway
,
sitting
as
it
happened
exactly
in
front
of
Mr.
Turnbull
,
and
there
he
made
his
explanation
.
<EOS>
Some
one
opposite
asked
a
question
whether
a
certain
right
honourable
gentleman
had
not
left
the
Cabinet
.
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Gresham
replied
that
to
his
infinite
regret
his
right
honourable
friend
,
who
lately
presided
at
the
Board
of
Trade
,
had
resigned
;
and
he
went
on
to
explain
that
this
resignation
had
,
according
to
his
ideas
,
been
quite
unnecessary
.
<EOS>
His
right
honourable
friend
entertained
certain
ideas
about
Irish
tenant
-
right
,
as
to
which
he
himself
and
his
right
honourable
friend
the
Secretary
for
Ireland
could
not
exactly
pledge
themselves
to
be
in
unison
with
him
;
but
he
had
thought
that
the
motion
might
have
rested
at
any
rate
over
this
session
.
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Monk
explained
,
making
his
first
great
speech
on
Irish
tenant
-
right
.
<EOS>
He
found
himself
obliged
to
advocate
some
immediate
measure
for
giving
security
to
the
Irish
farmer
;
and
as
he
could
not
do
so
as
a
member
of
the
Cabinet
,
he
was
forced
to
resign
the
honour
of
that
position
.
<EOS>
He
said
something
also
as
to
the
great
doubt
which
had
ever
weighed
on
his
own
mind
as
to
the
inexpediency
of
a
man
at
his
time
of
life
submitting
himself
for
the
first
time
to
the
trammels
of
office
.
<EOS>
This
called
up
Mr.
Turnbull
,
who
took
the
opportunity
of
saying
that
he
now
agreed
cordially
with
his
old
friend
for
the
first
time
since
that
old
friend
had
listened
to
the
blandishments
of
the
ministerial
seducer
,
and
that
he
welcomed
his
old
friend
back
to
those
independent
benches
with
great
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
the
debate
was
very
exciting
.
<EOS>
Nothing
was
said
which
made
it
then
necessary
for
Phineas
to
get
upon
his
legs
or
to
declare
himself
;
but
he
perceived
that
the
time
would
rapidly
come
in
which
he
must
do
so
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
,
though
he
strove
to
speak
with
gentle
words
,
was
evidently
very
angry
with
the
late
President
of
the
Board
of
Trade
;
and
,
moreover
,
it
was
quite
clear
that
a
bill
would
be
introduced
by
Mr.
Monk
himself
,
which
Mr.
Gresham
was
determined
to
oppose
.
<EOS>
If
all
this
came
to
pass
and
there
should
be
a
close
division
,
Phineas
felt
that
his
fate
would
be
sealed
.
<EOS>
When
he
again
spoke
to
Lord
Cantrip
on
the
subject
,
the
Secretary
of
State
shrugged
his
shoulders
and
shook
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
only
advise
you
,
"
said
Lord
Cantrip
,
"
to
forget
all
that
took
place
in
Ireland
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
do
so
,
nobody
else
will
remember
it
.
"
<EOS>
"
As
if
it
were
possible
to
forget
such
things
,
"
he
said
in
the
letter

he

Mary
that

.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
shall
go
now
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
not
for
your
sake
,
I
should
not
in
the
least
regret
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
been
with
Madame
Goesler
frequently
in
the
winter
,
and
had
discussed
with
her
so
often
the
question
of
his
official
position
that
she
had
declared
that
she
was
coming
at
last
to
understand
the
mysteries
of
an
English
Cabinet
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
are
quite
right
,
my
friend
,
"
she
said
,
 
"
quite
right
.
<EOS>
What
 
you
are
to
be
in
Parliament
and
say
that
this
black
thing
is
white
,
or
that
this
white
thing
is
black
,
because
you
like
to
take
your
salary
!
<EOS>
That
can
not
be
honest
!
"
<EOS>
Then
,
when
he
came
to
talk
to
her
of
money
,
 
that
he
must
give
up
Parliament
itself
,
if
he
gave
up
his
place
,
 
she
offered
to
lend
him
money
.
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
not
treat
me
as
a
friend
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
When
he
pointed
out
to
her
that
there
would
never
come
a
time
in
which
he
could
pay
such
money
back
,
she
stamped
her
foot
and
told
him
that
he
had
better
leave
her
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
high
principle
,
"
she
said
,
"
but
not
principle
sufficiently
high
to
understand
that
this
thing
could
be
done
between
you
and
me
without
disgrace
to
either
of
us
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
assured
her
with
tears
in
his
eyes
that
such
an
arrangement
was
impossible
without
disgrace
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
whispered
to
this
new
friend
no
word
of
the
engagement
with
his
dear
Irish
Mary
.
<EOS>
His
Irish
life
,
he
would
tell
himself
,
was
a
thing
quite
apart
and
separate
from
his
life
in
England
.
<EOS>
He
said
not
a
word
about
Mary
Flood
Jones
to
any
of
those
with
whom
he
lived
in
London
.
<EOS>
Why
should
he
,
feeling
as
he
did
that
it
would
so
soon
be
necessary
that
he
should
disappear
from
among
them
?
<EOS>
About
Miss
Effingham
he
had
said
much
to
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
She
had
asked
him
whether
he
had
abandoned
all
hope
.
<EOS>
"
That
affair
,
then
,
is
over
?
"
she
had
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
it
is
all
over
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
she
will
marry
the
red
-
headed
,
violent
lord
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Heaven
knows
.
<EOS>
I
think
she
will
.
<EOS>
But
she
is
exactly
the
girl
to
remain
unmarried
if
she
takes
it
into
her
head
that
the
man
she
likes
is
in
any
way
unfitted
for
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Does
she
love
this
lord
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
;
 
there
is
no
doubt
of
that
.
"
<EOS>
And
Phineas
,
as
he
made
this
acknowledgment
,
seemed
to
do
so
without
much
inward
agony
of
soul
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
been
last
in
London
he
could
not
speak
of
Violet
and
Lord
Chiltern
together
without
showing
that
his
misery
was
almost
too
much
for
him
.
  
<EOS>
At
this
time
he
received
some
counsel
from
two
friends
.
<EOS>
One
was
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
,
and
the
other
was
Barrington
Erle
.
<EOS>
Laurence
had
always
been
true
to
him
after
a
fashion
,
and
had
never
resented
his
intrusion
at
the
Colonial
Office
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
,
me
boy
,
"
he
said
,
"
if
all
this
is
thrue
,
you
're
about
up
a
tree
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
true
that
I
shall
support
Monk
's
motion
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
me
boy
,
you
're
up
a
tree
as
far
as
office
goes
.
<EOS>
A
place
like
that
niver
suited
me
,
because
,
you
see
,
that
poker
of
a
young
lord
expected
so
much
of
a
man
;
but
you
do
n't
mind
that
kind
of
thing
,
and
I
thought
you
were
as
snug
as
snug
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Troubles
will
come
,
you
see
,
Laurence
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Bedad
,
yes
.
<EOS>
It
's
all
throubles
,
I
think
,
sometimes
.
<EOS>
But
you
've
a
way
out
of
all
your
throubles
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
What
way
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Pop
the
question
to

Max
.
<EOS>
The

's

thrue
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Anyways
,
thry

,

,

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
"
Phineas

<EOS>

"

Erle

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

;

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
what

,

?
<EOS>
He
ca
n't
smother
his
convictions
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Convictions
!
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
on

that
I
'm
so
much

of
in
a

member

Parliament
as
convictions
.
<EOS>
There
are
ever
so
many
rocks
against
which
men

broken
.
<EOS>
One
man
ca
n't
keep

.
<EOS>
Another
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
A

ca
n't

unless

has

half

.
<EOS>
A
fourth
is
always
thinking

,
and
wanting

.
<EOS>
A
fifth
is
idle
,
and
wo
n't
be

when

's

.
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
A

lies

that

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

n't

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
ca

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

d

.
<EOS>
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Men

.
<EOS>
It
's

that

he

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
could
only
thank

friend
for
his

,
which

at
least

,
and
was
good
of
its
kind
,
and
tell

that
he
would
think

.
<EOS>
He
did
think
of
it
very
much
.
<EOS>
He
almost
thought
that
,
were
it
to
do
again
,
he
would
allow
Mr.
Monk
to
go
upon
his

alone
,
and
keep

from
the

of
anything
that
so
good
a
judge
as
Erle
could
call
stump
balderdash
.
<EOS>
As
he
sat
in
his
arm
-

Colonial
Office
,
with

-

,
and

,
 
feeling

to
be
one
of
those
who
in
truth

and

this
great

,
feeling
also
that
if
he
relinquished

post
now
he
could
never

,
 
he
did
wish
that
he
had
been
a

less
in
love
with
independence
,
a
little

in
his
boastings
that
no
official

should
ever

.
<EOS>
But
all
this
was
too
late
now
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
his
skin
was
not
thick
enough
to
bear
the
arrows
of
those
archers
who
would
bend

bows
against
him
if
he
should
now

Monk
's

.
<EOS>
His
own
party
might

willing

;
but
there

others
who
would
read

,
and
would
appear
in
the
House
with
the
odious
tell
-

newspapers
in

.
  
<EOS>
Then
he
received
a
letter
from
his
father
.
<EOS>
Some
good
-
natured
person
had
enlightened
the
doctor
as
to
the
danger
in

his
son
was
placing

.
<EOS>
Dr.
Finn
,
who
in

own

was
a
very

-

,
had

,
as

's

.
<EOS>
He
had
thought
that
Phineas
was
carrying

as

with
proper

and

.
<EOS>
He
had
cared
nothing
himself
for

-

,
and
had

Monk
that
he

not

that

.
<EOS>
But

that
Mr.
Monk
was
a

,

he
thought
that
Phineas
was

.
<EOS>
Then

came
some
one
who
undeceived

,

.
<EOS>

do
n't

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
Yet

.
<EOS>
My

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
"
<EOS>
Mary
also

.
<EOS>
Mrs.

had

,

Mary
had

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

,

?
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
Resign

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Fiddlestick
!
"

Finn
.
<EOS>
"
How
is

to

,

,

?
<EOS>
I

n't

did

all

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
Mrs.
Finn

;

Mary
could
only

,

how
very

that

.
<EOS>
But
what

!
<EOS>
Phineas

.
<EOS>
Of

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,

,

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
can

?
<EOS>
Of

do
not

,
 
but
it
was

Mr.

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
Phineas

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

man
if

were

English

,
"
said
Madame
Goesler
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is

poor
fellow
to

?
"
said
Phineas
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
A
poor
fellow
need
not

poor
fellow
unless
he
likes
,
"
said
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
Immediately
after
this
Phineas
left
her
,
and
as
he
went
along
the
street
he
began
to
question
himself
whether
the
prospects
of
his
own
darling
Mary
were
at
all
endangered
by
his
visits
to
Park
Lane
;
and
to
reflect
what
sort
of
a
blackguard
he
would
be
,
 
a
blackguard
of
how
deep
a
dye
,
 
were
he
to
desert
Mary
and
marry
Madame
Max
Goesler
.
<EOS>
Then
he
also
asked
himself
as
to
the
nature
and
quality
of
his
own
political
honesty
if
he
were
to
abandon
Mary
in
order
that
he
might
maintain
his
parliamentary
independence
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
if
it
should
ever
come
to
pass
that
his
biography
should
be
written
,
his
biographer
would
say
very
much
more
about
the
manner
in
which
he
kept
his
seat
in
Parliament
than
of
the
manner
in
which
he
kept
his
engagement
with
Miss
Mary
Flood
Jones
.
<EOS>
Half
a
dozen
people
who
knew
him
and
her
might
think
ill
of
him
for
his
conduct
to
Mary
,
but
the
world
would
not
condemn
him
!
<EOS>
And
when
he
thundered
forth
his
liberal
eloquence
from
below
the
gangway
as
an
independent
member
,
having
the
fortune
of
his
charming
wife
to
back

,
giving
excellent
dinners
at
the
same
time
in
Park
Lane
,
would
not
the
world
praise
him
very
loudly
?
  
<EOS>
When
he
got
to
his
office
he
found
a
note
from
Lord
Brentford
inviting
him
to
dine
in
Portman
Square
.
   
<EOS>
The
Joint
Attack
 
<EOS>
The
note
from
Lord
Brentford
surprised
our
hero
not
a
little
.
<EOS>
He
had
had
no
communication
with
the
Earl
since
the
day
on
which
he
had
been
so
savagely
scolded
about
the
duel
,
when
the
Earl
had
plainly
told
him
that
his
conduct
had
been
as
bad
as
it
could
be
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
not
on
that
account
become
at
all
ashamed
of
his
conduct
in
reference
to
the
duel
,
but
he
had
conceived
that
any
reconciliation
between
him
and
the
Earl
had
been
out
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
Now
there
had
come
a
civilly
-
worded
invitation
,
asking
him
to
dine
with
the
offended
nobleman
.
<EOS>
The
note
had
been
written
by
Lady
Laura
,
but
it
had
purported
to
come
from
Lord
Brentford
himself
.
<EOS>
He
sent
back
word
to
say
that
he
should
be
happy
to
have
the
honour
of
dining
with
Lord
Brentford
.
  
<EOS>
Parliament
at
this
time
had
been
sitting
nearly
a
month
,
and
it
was
already
March
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
heard
nothing
of
Lady
Laura
,
and
did
not
even
know
that
she
was
in
London
till
he
saw
her
handwriting
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
know
that
she
had
not
gone
back
to
her
husband
,
and
that
she
had
remained
with
her
father
all
the
winter
at
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
He
had
also
heard
that
Lord
Chiltern
had
been
at
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
All
the
world
had
been
talking
of
the
separation
of
Mr.
Kennedy
from
his
wife
,
one
half
of
the
world
declaring
that
his
wife
,
if
not
absolutely
false
to
him
,
had
neglected
all
her
duties
;
and
the
other
half
asserting
that
Mr.
Kennedy
's
treatment
of
his
wife
had
been
so
bad
that
no
woman
could
possibly
have
lived
with
him
.
<EOS>
There
had
even
been
a
rumour
that
Lady
Laura
had
gone
off
with
a
lover
from
the
Duke
of
Omnium
's
garden
party
,
and
some
indiscreet
tongue
had
hinted
that
a
certain
unmarried
Under
-
Secretary
of
State
was
missing
at
the
same
time
.
<EOS>
But
Lord
Chiltern
upon
this
had
shown
his
teeth
with
so
strong
a
propensity
to
do
some
real
biting
,
that
no
one
had
ventured
to
repeat
that
rumour
.
<EOS>
Its
untruth
was
soon
established
by
the
fact
that
Lady
Laura
Kennedy
was
living
with
her
father
at
Saulsby
.
<EOS>
Of
Mr.
Kennedy
,
Phineas
had
as
yet
seen
nothing
since
he
had
been
up
in
town
.
<EOS>
That
gentleman
,
though
a
member
of
the
Cabinet
,
had
not
been
in
London
at
the
opening
of
the
session
,
nor
had
he
attended
the
Cabinet
meetings
during
the
recess
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
stated
in
the
newspapers
that
he
was
ill
,
and
stated
in
private
that
he
could
not
bear
to
show
himself
since
his
wife
had
left
him
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
however
,
he
came
to
London
,
and
Phineas
saw
him
in
the
House
.
<EOS>
Then
,
when
the
first
meeting
of
the
Cabinet
was
summoned
after
his
return
,
it
became
known
that
he
also
had
resigned
his
office
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
said
about
his
resignation
in
the
House
.
<EOS>
He
had
resigned
on
the
score
of
ill
-
health
,
and
that
very
worthy
peer
,
Lord
Mount
Thistle
,
formerly
Sir
Marmaduke
Morecombe
,
came
back
to
the
Duchy
of
Lancaster
in
his
place
.
<EOS>
A
Prime
Minister
sometimes
finds
great
relief
in
the
possession
of
a
serviceable
stick
who
can
be
made
to
go
in
and
out
as
occasion
may
require
;
only
it
generally
happens
that
the
stick
will
expect
some
reward
when
he
is
made
to
go
out
.
<EOS>
Lord
Mount
Thistle
immediately
saw
his
way
to
a
viscount
's
coronet
,
when
he
was
once
more
summoned
to
the
august
councils
of
the
Ministers
.
  
<EOS>
A
few
days
after
this
had
been
arranged
,
in
the
interval
between
Lord
Brentford
's
invitation
and
Lord
Brentford
's
dinner
,
Phineas
encountered
Mr.
Kennedy
so
closely
in
one
of
the
passages
of
the
House
that
it
was
impossible
that
they
should
not
speak
to
each
other
,
unless
they
were
to
avoid
each
other
as
people
do
who
have
palpably
quarrelled
.
<EOS>
Phineas
saw
that
Mr.
Kennedy
was
hesitating
,
and
therefore
took
the
bull
by
the
horns
.
<EOS>
He
greeted
his
former
friend
in
a
friendly
fashion
,
shaking
him
by
the
hand
,
and
then
prepared
to
pass
on
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Kennedy
,
though
he
had
hesitated
at
first
,
now
detained
his
brother
member
.
<EOS>
"
Finn
,
"
he
said
,
"
if
you
are
not
engaged
I
should
like
to
speak
to
you
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
was
not
engaged
,
and
allowed
himself
to
be
led
out
arm
-
in
-
arm
by
the
late
Chancellor
of
the
Duchy
into
Westminster
Hall
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
know
what
a
terrible
thing
has
happened
to
me
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
I
have
heard
of
it
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Everybody
has
heard
of
it
.
<EOS>
That
is
one
of
the
terrible
cruelties
of
such
a
blow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
those
things
are
very
bad
of
course
.
<EOS>
I
was
very
much
grieved
,
 
because
you
have
both
been
intimate
friends
of
mine
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
 
yes
;
we
were
.
<EOS>
Do
you
ever
see
her
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
since
last
July
,
 
at
the
Duke
's
party
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
yes
;
the
morning
of
that
day
was
the
last
on
which
I
spoke
to
her
.
<EOS>
It
was
then
she
left
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
to
dine
with
Lord
Brentford
to
-
morrow
,
and
I
dare
say
she
will
be
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
she
is
in
town
.
<EOS>
I
saw
her
yesterday
in
her
father
's
carriage
.
<EOS>
I
think
that
she
had
no
cause
to
leave
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
can
not
say
anything
about
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
she
had
no
cause
to
leave
me
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
as
he
heard
this
could
not
but
remember
all
that
Lady
Laura
had
told
himself
,
and
thought
that
no
woman
had
ever
had
a
better

for
leaving
her
husband
.
<EOS>
"
There
were
things
I
did
not

,
and
I
said

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
that
is
generally
the

,
"
replied

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
surely
a
wife
should
listen
to
a
word
of
caution
from
her
husband
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
fancy
they
never
like
it
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
are
we
all
of
us
to
have
all
that
we
like
?
<EOS>
I
have
not
found
it
so
.
<EOS>
Or
would
it
be
good
for
us
if
we
had
?
<EOS>
"
Then
he
paused
;
but
as
Phineas
had
no
further
remark
to
make
,
he
continued
speaking
after
they
had
walked
about
a
third
of
the
length
of
the
hall
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
of
my
own
comfort
I
am
thinking
now
so
much
as
of
her
name
and
her
future
conduct
.
<EOS>
Of
course
it
will
in
every
sense
be
best
for
her
that
she
should
come
back
to
her
husband
's
roof
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
;
yes
;
 
perhaps
it
would
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Has
she
not
accepted
that
lot
for
better
or
for
worse
?
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
,
solemnly
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
incompatibility
of
temper
,
you
know
,
is
always
,
 
always
supposed
 
.
<EOS>
You
understand
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
my
intention
that
she
should
come
back
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
wish
to
make
any
legal
demand
;
 
at
any
rate
,
not
as
yet
.
<EOS>
Will
you
consent
to
be
the
bearer
of
a
message
from
me
both
to
herself
and
to
the
Earl
?
"
  
<EOS>
Now
it
seemed
to
Phineas
that
of
all
the
messengers
whom
Mr.
Kennedy
could
have
chosen
<EOS>
he
was
the
most
unsuited
to
be
a
Mercury
in
this
cause
,
 
not
perceiving
that
he
had
been
so
selected
with
some
craft
,
in
order
that
Lady
Laura
might
understand
that
the
accusation
against
her
was
,
at
any
rate
,
withdrawn
,
which
had
named
Phineas
as
her
lover
.
<EOS>
He
paused
again
before
he
answered
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
should
be
most
willing
to
be
of
service
,
if
it
were
possible
.
<EOS>
But
I
do
not
see
how
I
can
speak
to
the
Earl
about
it
.
<EOS>
Though
I
am
going
to
dine
with
him
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
why
he
has
asked
me
;
 
for
he
and
I
are
on
very
bad
terms
.
<EOS>
He
heard
that
stupid
story
about
the
duel
,
and
has
not
spoken
to
me
since
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
heard
that
,
too
,
"
said
Mr.
Kennedy
,
frowning
blackly
as
he
remembered
his
wife
's
duplicity
.
  
<EOS>
"
Everybody
heard
of
it
.
<EOS>
But
it
has
made
such
a
difference
between
him
and
me
,
that
I
do
n't
think
I
can
meddle
.
<EOS>
Send
for
Lord
Chiltern
,
and
speak

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Speak
to
Chiltern
!
<EOS>
Never
!
<EOS>
He
would
probably
strike
me
on
the
head
with
his
club
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Call
on
the
Earl
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
and
he
would
not
see
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Write
to
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
and
he
sent
back
my
letter
unopened
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Write
to
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
;
 
and
she
answered
me
,
saying
only
thus
;
"
Indeed
,
indeed
,
it
can
not
be
so
.
<EOS>
"
But
it
must
be
so
.
<EOS>
The
laws
of
God
require
it
,
and
the
laws
of
man
permit
it
.
<EOS>
I
want
some
one
to
point

that
to
them
more

than
I
could
do
if
I
were

to
write

.
<EOS>
To
the
Earl
,
of
course
,
I
can
not
write
again
.
<EOS>
"
The
conference
ended
by
a
promise
from
Phineas
that
he
would
,
if
possible
,
say
a
word
to
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
was
shown
into
Lord
Brentford
's

-
room
he
found
not
only
Lady
Laura
there
,
but
her
brother
.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
was
not
in
the
room
.
<EOS>
Barrington
Erle
was
there
,
and
so
also
were
Lord
and
Lady
Cantrip
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
not
your
father
going
to
be
here
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
said
to
Lady
Laura
,
after

.
  
<EOS>
"
We
live
in
that
hope
,
"
said

,
"
and
do
not

all

why

should

.
<EOS>
What
has

of
him
,
Oswald
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
came
in
with

half

,
and
I
suppose
he
does
not
dress
as

as
I
do
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
;
upon
which
Phineas
immediately
understood
that
the
father
and
the
son
were
reconciled
,
and
he
rushed
to
the
conclusion
that
Violet
and
her
lover
would
also
soon
be
reconciled
,
if
such
were
not
already
the
case
.
<EOS>
He
felt
some
remnant
of
a
soreness
that
it
should
be
so
,
as
a
man
feels
where
his
headache
has
been
when
the
real
ache
itself
has
left
him
.
<EOS>
Then
the
host
came
in
and
made
his

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Chiltern
kept
me
standing
about
,
"
he
said
,
"
till
the
east
wind
had
chilled
me
through
and
through
.
<EOS>
The
only
charm
I
recognise
in
youth
is
that
it
is
impervious
to
the
east
wind
.
"
<EOS>
Phineas
felt
quite
sure
now
that
Violet
and
her
lover
were
reconciled
,
and
he
had
a
distinct

of
the
place
where
the
ache
had
been
.
<EOS>
Dear
Violet
!
<EOS>
But
,
after
all
,
Violet
lacked
that
sweet
,
clinging
,
feminine
softness
which
made
Mary
Flood
Jones
so
pre
-
eminently
the
most
charming
of
her
sex
.
<EOS>
The
Earl
,
when
he
had
repeated
his
general
apology
,
especially
to
Lady
Cantrip
,
who
was
the
only
lady
present
except
his
daughter
,
came
up
to
our
hero
and
shook
him

by

.
<EOS>
He
took
him
up
to
one

and
then

in
a

mock

.
  
<EOS>
"
Stick
to
the
colonies
,
young
man
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
never
meddle
with
foreign

;
 
especially

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Never
again
,

;
 
never

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

between

Horse
Guards
and

War

.
<EOS>
I
have

a

deal
about

I

,

I

.
<EOS>
But

duel
is
a
foolish
thing
,
 
a

.
<EOS>
Come
;
 
here
is

.
"
<EOS>
And
the
Earl
walked
off

Lady
Cantrip
,
and
Lord
Cantrip
walked
off

Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
Barrington
Erle
followed
,
and
Phineas
had
an
opportunity
of
saying
a
word
to
his
friend
,
Lord
Chiltern
,
as
they
went
down

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
right
between
you
and

father
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;
 
after
a
fashion
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
knowing
how
long
it
will
last
.
<EOS>
He
wants
me
to
do
three
things
,
and
I
wo
n't
do
any
one

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
are

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
go
into
Parliament
,
to
be
an
owner
of
sheep
and

,
and
to
hunt
in
his
own
county
.
<EOS>
I
should
never
attend
the
first
,
I
should
ruin
myself
with

,
and
I
should
never
get
a

in
the
third
.
<EOS>
"
But
there
was
not
a
word
said
about
his
marriage
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
only
seven
who
sat
down
to

,
and
the
six
were
all
people
with
whom
Phineas
was
or
had

on
most
intimate
terms
.
<EOS>
Lord
Cantrip
was
his
official
chief
,
and
,
since
that
connection
had
existed
between
them
,
Lady
Cantrip
had
been
very
gracious
to
him
.
<EOS>
She
quite
understood
the
comfort
which
it
was
to
her
husband
to
have
under
him
,
as
his
representative
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
a
man
whom
he
could
thoroughly
trust
and
like
,
and
therefore
she
had
used
her
woman
's
arts
to
bind
Phineas
to
her
lord
in
more
than
mere
official
bondage
.
<EOS>
She
had
tried
her
skill
also
upon
Laurence
Fitzgibbon
,
 
but
altogether
in
vain
.
<EOS>
He
had
eaten
her
dinners
and
accepted
her
courtesies
,
and
had
given
for
them
no
return
whatever
.
<EOS>
But
Phineas
had
possessed
a
more
grateful
mind
,
and
had
done
all
that
had
been
required
of
him
;
 
had
done
all
that
had
been
required
of
him
till
there
had
come
that
terrible
absurdity
in
Ireland
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
very
well
what
sort
of
things
would
happen
when
they
brought
such
a
man
as
Mr.
Monk
into
the
Cabinet
,
"
Lady
Cantrip
had
said
to
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
But
though
the
party
was
very
small
,
and
though
the
guests
were
all
his
intimate
friends
,
Phineas
suspected
nothing
special
till
an
attack
was
made
upon
him
as
soon
as
the
servants
had
left
the
room
.
<EOS>
This
was
done
in
the
presence
of
the
two
ladies
,
and
,
no
doubt
,
had
been
preconcerted
.
<EOS>
There
was
Lord
Cantrip
there
,
who
had
already
said
much
to
him
,
and
Barrington
Erle
who
had
said
more
even
than
Lord
Cantrip
.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
,
himself
a
member
of
the
Cabinet
,
opened
the
attack
by
asking
whether
it
was
actually
true
that
Mr.
Monk
meant
to
go
on
with
his
motion
.
<EOS>
Barrington
Erle
asserted
that
Mr.
Monk
positively
would
do
so
.
"
<EOS>
And
Gresham
will

?
"
asked

Earl
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
he
will
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
he
will
,
"
said

Cantrip
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
I

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
the
last

be

a
thing
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
knew
pretty
well
what
was
coming
on

.
  
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
began
again
by
asking
how

.
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

on

cards
that

.
"
<EOS>
"

?
"

.
<EOS>
"

,
"
said
Barrington
.
<EOS>
And
then
the
attack
was
made
.
  
<EOS>
Our
hero
had
a
bad
half
hour
of
it
,
though
many
words
were
said
which
must
have
gratified
him
much
.
<EOS>
They
all
wanted
to
keep
him
,
 
so
Lord
Cantrip
declared
,
"
except

whom

,

who

,
"
said

,
thinking
that
certain

of

with

Bonteen
and

as

as
any

to

.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
declared
that
he
could
not

,
 
that

should
find

lost

if
such

as

allowed

to

led

by

ignis
-

of
light
as
this
.
<EOS>
Lord
Cantrip
laid
down
the
unwritten
traditional
law
of
Government
officials
very
plainly
.
<EOS>
A
man
in
office
,
 
in
an
office
which
really
imposed
upon
him
as
much
work
as
he
could
possibly
do
with
credit
to
himself
or
his
cause
,
 
was
dispensed
from
the

of
a

with
reference
to
other

.
<EOS>
It
was
for
Sir
Walter
Morrison
to
have
a
conscience
about
Irish
tenant
-
right
,
as
no
doubt
he
had
,
 
just
as
Phineas
Finn
had
a
conscience
about
Canada
,
and
Jamaica
,
and
the
Cape
.
<EOS>
Barrington
Erle
was
very
strong
about
parties
in
general
,
and
painted
the
comforts
of
official
position
in
glowing

.
<EOS>
But
I
think
that
the
two
ladies
were
more
efficacious
than
even
their
male
relatives
in
the
arguments
which
they
used
.
<EOS>
"
We
have

so

,
"
said

Cantrip
,
looking

with

,

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
knows
,
"
said

,
"
that

into

I
have

,
and

.
"
<EOS>
"
We

over

,
as

,

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't

that

will

,
"
said

Laura
,
"
but
I
do
not

anything
of

kind
that
would
so

me
unhappy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
What
was
he
to
say
in

to
applications
so
flattering
and
so
pressing
?
<EOS>
He
would
have
said
nothing
,
had
that
been

,
but
he
felt
himself

to
reply
.
<EOS>
He
replied
very
weakly
,
 
of

,
not
justifying

,
but
declaring
that
as
he
had
gone
so
far
he
must

.
<EOS>
He
must
vote
for
the
measure
now
.
<EOS>
Both

and
Barrington

proved
,
or

,
that

wrong
in

.
<EOS>
Of

he
would
not

on

,
and
his

for
his
party
would
probably

.
<EOS>
One

two
newspapers
might
perhaps

;
but
what

cared
for

as

?
<EOS>
His

would
hang
by

,
and
in

would

ample

.
<EOS>
Phineas
could
only
say
that
he
would
think

;
 
and
this
he
said
in
so
irresolute

of

that
all

believed
that

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
"
<EOS>

when

,
"

Laura
to

.
<EOS>
But

Lady
Laura
had
been
in

,
 
was

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

ca

,
"

.
<EOS>
But

had
never

.
  
<EOS>
Phineas

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

;
 
"
<EOS>
never
,

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
 
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
His

!
"
  
<EOS>
When

,

to

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>

.

"

<EOS>
The
Temptress
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
's
bill
was
read

Easter
,
and
Phineas
Finn
still

.
<EOS>
He
had
spoken

Prime

once

,
and
had

at
that

's

;
 
for
Mr.
Gresham
had
the

of
being
unconciliatory
in
his

,
and
very
prone
to
resent
anything
like
desertion
from
that

which
was
due

as

leader
of

.
<EOS>
"
You
had

stay
where

and
take

that
may

,
till
you
have
quite

,
"
said

Gresham
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
fear
I
have
made

,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
can
be
done
till
after
Easter
,
"
replied

great
man
,
"
and
there
is
no
knowing
how
things
may

.
<EOS>
I

to

.
<EOS>
If

's

.
<EOS>
See
Monk
and

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.

possibly

that

,
when

injury
<EOS>
he

.
  
<EOS>
At
this
time
Phineas
received
the
following
letter
from
his
darling
Mary
:
    
Floodborough
,
Thursday
.
  
<EOS>
DEAREST
PHINEAS
,
  
<EOS>
We
have
just
got
home
from
Killaloe
,
and
mean
to
remain
here
all
through
the
summer
.
<EOS>
After
leaving
your
sisters
this
house
seems
so
desolate
;
but
I
shall
have
the
more
time
to
think
of
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
reading
Tennyson
,
as
you
told
me
,
and
I
fancy
that
I
could
in
truth
be
a
Mariana
here
,
if
it
were
not
that
I
am
so
quite
certain
that
you
will
come
;
 
and
that
makes
all
the
difference
in
the
world
in
a
moated
grange
.
<EOS>
Last
night
I
sat
at
the
window
and
tried
to
realise
what
I
should
feel
if
you
were
to
tell
me
that
you
did
not
want
me
;
and
I
got
myself
into
such
an
ecstatic
state
of
mock
melancholy
that
I
cried
for
half
an
hour
.
<EOS>
But
when
one
has
such
a
real
living
joy
at
the
back
of
one
's
romantic
melancholy
,
tears
are
very
pleasant
;
  
they
water
and
do
not
burn
.
  
<EOS>
I
must
tell
you
about
them
all
at
Killaloe
.
<EOS>
They
certainly
are
very
unhappy
at
the
idea
of
your
resigning
.
<EOS>
Your
father
says
very
little
,
but
I
made
him
own
that
to
act
as
you
are
acting
for
the
sake
of
principle
is
very
grand
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
leave
him
till
he
had
said
so
,
and
he
did
say
it
.
<EOS>
Dear
Mrs.
Finn
does
not
understand
it
as
well
,
but
she
will
do
so
.
<EOS>
She
complains
mostly
for
my
sake
,
and
when
I
tell
her
that
I
will
wait
twenty
years
if
it
is
necessary
,
she
tells
me
I
do
not
know
what
waiting
means
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
,
 
and
will
be
happy
,
and
will
never
really
think
myself
a
Mariana
.
<EOS>
Dear
,
dear
,
<EOS>
dear
Phineas
,
indeed
I
wo
n't
.
<EOS>
The
girls
are
half
sad
and
half
proud
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
wholly
proud
,
and
know
that
you
are
doing
just
what
you
ought
to
do
.
<EOS>
I
shall
think
more
of
you
as
a
man
who
might
have
been
a
Prime
Minister
than
if
you
were
really
sitting

like
Lord
Cantrip
.
<EOS>
As
for
mamma
,
I
can
not
make
her
quite
understand
it
.
<EOS>
She
merely
says
that
no
young
man
who
is
going
to
be
married
ought
to
resign
anything
.
<EOS>
Dear
mamma
;
 
sometimes
she
does
say
such
odd
things
.
  
<EOS>
You
told
me
to
tell
you
everything
,
and
so
I
have
.
<EOS>
I
talk
to
some
of
the
people
here
,
and
tell
them
what
they
might
do
if
they
had
tenant
-
right
.
<EOS>
One
old
fellow
,
Mike
Dufferty
,
 
I
do
n't
know
whether
you
remember
him
,
 
<EOS>
asked
if
he
would
have
to
pay
the
rent
all
the
same
.
<EOS>
When
I
said
certainly
he
would
,
then
he
shook
his
head
.
<EOS>
But
as
you
said
once
,
when
we
want
to
do
good
to
people
one
has
no
right
to
expect
that
they
should
understand

.
<EOS>
It
is
like
baptizing
little
infants
.
  
<EOS>
I
got
both
your
notes
;
 
<EOS>
seven
words
in
one
,
Mr.
Under
-
Secretary
,
and
nine
in
the
other
!
<EOS>
But
the
one
little
word
at
the
end
was
worth
a
whole
sheet
full
of
common
words
.
<EOS>
How
nice
it
is
to
write
letters
without
paying
postage
,
and
to
send
them
about
the
world
with
a
grand
name
in
the
corner
.
<EOS>
When
Barney
brings
me
one
he
always
looks
as
if
he
did
n't
know
whether
it
was
a
love
letter
or
an
order
to
go
to
Botany
Bay
.
<EOS>
If
he
saw
the
inside
of
them
,
how
short
they
are
,
I
do
n't
think
he
'd
think
much
of
you
as
a
lover
nor
yet
as
an
Under
-
Secretary
.
  
<EOS>
But
I
think
ever
so
much
of
you
as
both
;
 
I
do
,
indeed
;
and
I
am
not
scolding
you
a
bit
.
<EOS>
As
long
as
I
can
have
two
or
three
dear
,
sweet
,
loving
words
,
I
shall
be
as
happy
as
a
queen
.
<EOS>
Ah
,
if
you
knew
it
all
!
<EOS>
But
you
never
can
know
it
all
.
<EOS>
A
man
has
so
many
other
things
to
learn
that
he
can
not
understand
it
.
  
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
dear
,
dear
,
dearest
man
.
<EOS>
Whatever
you
do
I
shall
be
quite
sure
you
have
done
the
best
.
  
<EOS>
Ever
your
own
,
with
all
the
love
of
her
heart
,
  
<EOS>
MARY
F.
JONES
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
very
nice
.
<EOS>
Such
a
man
as
was
Phineas
Finn
always
takes
a
delight
which
he
can
not
express
even
to

in
the
receipt
of
such

letter
as
this
.
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
so
flattering
as
the
warm

of
the
confidence
of
a
woman
's
love
,
and
Phineas
thought
that
no
woman
ever
expressed
this
more
completely
than
did
his
Mary
.
<EOS>
Dear
,
dearest
Mary
.
<EOS>
As
for
giving
her
up
,
as
for
treachery
to
one
so
trusting
,
so
sweet
,
so
well

,
that
was
out
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
But
nevertheless
the
truth
came
home
to
him
more
clearly
day

,
that
he
of
all
men
was
the
last
who
ought
to
have
given
himself
up
to
such
a
passion
.
<EOS>
For
her

he
ought
to
have
abstained
.
<EOS>
So
he
told
himself
now
.
<EOS>
For
her
sake
he
ought
to
have
kept
aloof
from
her
;
 
and
for
his
own
sake
he
ought
to
have
kept
aloof
from
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
That
very
day
,
with
Mary
's
letter
in
his
pocket
,
he
went
to
the
livery

and
explained
that
he
would
not

his
horse
any

.
<EOS>
There
was
no

about
the
horse
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Howard
Macleod
of
the
Treasury
would
take
him
from
that
very
hour
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
as
he

away
,
uttered
a

upon
Mr.
Howard
Macleod
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Howard
Macleod
was
just
beginning
the
glory
of
his
life
in
London
,
and
he
,
Phineas
Finn
,
was
bringing
his
to
an

.
  
<EOS>
With
Mary
's
letter
in
his
pocket
he
went
up

Portman

.
<EOS>
He
had
again
got
into
the
habit
of
seeing
Lady
Laura
frequently
,
and
was
often
with
her
brother
,
who
now
again
lived
at
his
father
's
house
.
<EOS>
A

had
reached
Lord
Brentford
,
through
his

,
in
which
a

made
by
Mr.
Kennedy
for

his
wife
.
<EOS>
She
was
quite
determined
that
she
would
never

back
to

;
and
there

come
to
her
a

whether

expedient
that
she
should
live
abroad
so
as

be
out

the
way
of

from
her

.
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
was
in
great

,
and
Lord
Chiltern
had
once

that
perhaps

had
better
"
see
"

Kennedy
.
<EOS>
The

of

,
as

,
had
up
to
the
present
day
been

;
and
,

,
Phineas
had
been
used
as

between
Mr.
Kennedy
and

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
will
end
,
"
she

,
"
in
my
going
to
Dresden
,
and
settling

there
.
<EOS>
Papa
will
come
to
me
when
Parliament

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
very

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dull
!
<EOS>
What
does

when

as

?
<EOS>
When

is
in

,

very

;
but
when

comes
,

is
nothing
.
<EOS>
It

almost
like

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
hard
that
you
should
be
driven

.
<EOS>
"
She

,

.
<EOS>
Was

not

he

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
I

,
 
that

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
It

;

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

Laura
,

!
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How

we

!
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

!
<EOS>
With

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
Even

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Simply

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"

"

;

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

"
  
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
"

;

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Your

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>
He
,

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
 
that

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
Phineas

,

's

,
 
her

,
 
was
there

.
<EOS>
It

his

Laura

,

.
<EOS>
He

undying

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Go

Goesler
,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Madame
Goesler

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Psha
!
<EOS>
You
do

.
<EOS>
You

not

.
<EOS>
And

's

?
<EOS>
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
Again

,

.
<EOS>
"
What
was
it
<EOS>
you

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
regretted

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why

?
<EOS>
And

!
<EOS>
A

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Try
her
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Such

but

;
 
we

!
"
<EOS>
Still

nothing
of
the
letter

.
<EOS>
"
It

everything
that

go

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
A

,

.
<EOS>
Make

,

.
<EOS>
Office

,

.
<EOS>
Let

that

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Still

not
tell

of
the

.
<EOS>
He
felt
that
she
moved
him
,
 
that

acknowledge
to
himself
<EOS>
how
great
would
be
the

of
such

as

.
<EOS>
He
was
quite
as

to

that
work
at
the
Bar
,
either
in
London
or

Dublin
,
would
have
no
charms
for
him
now
.
<EOS>
The

of
such
a
life
was
very
dreary
to

.
<EOS>
Even
with
the
comfort
of
Mary
's
love
such

life
would
be
very
dreary
to
him
.
<EOS>
And
then
he
knew
,
 
he
thought
that
he
knew
,
 
that
were
he
to
offer
himself
to
Madame
Goesler
he
would
not
in

.
<EOS>
She
had
told
him
that
if
poverty
was
a

to
him
he
need
be
no
longer
poor
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
had
understood
this
.
<EOS>
Her
money
was
at
his
service
if
he
should
choose
to
stoop
and

.
<EOS>
And
it
was
not
only
money
that

give

.
<EOS>
He
had
acknowledged
to

more

that
Madame
Goesler
was
very
lovely
,
that
she
was
clever
,
attractive
in
every
way
,
and
as
far

he
could

,
blessed
with
a
sweet

.
<EOS>
She
had
a
position
,
too
,
in
the
world
that
would
help
him
rather
than
mar

.
<EOS>
What
might
he
not
do
with
an
independent
seat
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
and
as
joint
owner
of
the
little
house
in
Park
Lane
?
<EOS>
Of
all
