which
the
world
could
offer
to
a
man
the
pleasantest
would
then
be
within
his
reach
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
appear
to
me
as
a
tempter
,
"
he
said
at
last
to
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
unkind
of
you
to
say
that
,
and
ungrateful
.
<EOS>
I
would
do
anything
on
earth
in
my
power
to
help
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nevertheless
you
are
a
tempter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
how
it
ought
to
have
been
,
"
she
said
,
in
a
low
voice
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
very
well
how
it
ought
to
have
been
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
kept
myself
free
till
that
time
when
we
met
on
the
braes
of
Loughlinter
,
and
then
all
would
have
been
well
with
us
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
how
that
might
have
been
,
"
said
Phineas
,
hoarsely
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
know
!
<EOS>
But
I
know
.
<EOS>
Of
course
you
have
stabbed
me
with
a
thousand
daggers
when
you
have
told
me
from
time
to
time
of
your
love
for
Violet
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
very
cruel
,
 
needlessly
cruel
.
<EOS>
Men
are
so
cruel
!
<EOS>
But
for
all
that
I
have
known
that
I
could
have
kept
you
,
 
had
it
not
been
too
late
when
you
spoke
to
me
.
<EOS>
Will
you
not
own
as
much
as
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
would
have
been
everything
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
should
never
have
thought
of
Violet
then
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
the
only
kind
word
you
have
said
to
me
from
that
day
to
this
.
<EOS>
I
try
to
comfort
myself
in
thinking
that
it
would
have
been
so
.
<EOS>
But
all
that
is
past
and
gone
,
and
done
.
<EOS>
I
have
had
my
romance
and
you
have
had
yours
.
<EOS>
As
you
are
a
man
,
it
is
natural
that
you
should
have
been
disturbed
by
a
double
image
;
 
it
is
not
so
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
yet
you
can
advise
me
to
offer
marriage
to
a
woman
,
 
a
woman
whom
I
am
to
seek
merely
because
she
is
rich
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
I
do
so
advise
you
.
<EOS>
You
have
had
your
romance
and
must
now
put
up
with
reality
.
<EOS>
Why
should
I
so
advise
you
but
for
the
interest
that
I
have
in
you
?
<EOS>
Your
prosperity
will
do
me
no
good
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
even
be
here
to
see
it
.
<EOS>
I
shall
hear
of
it
only
as
so
many
a
woman
banished
out
of
England
hears
a
distant
misunderstood
report
of
what
is
going
on
in
the
country
she
has
left
.
<EOS>
But
I
still
have
regard
enough
,
 
I
will
be
bold
,
and
,
knowing
that
you
will
not
take
it
amiss
<EOS>
,
will
say
love
enough
for
you
,
 
to
feel
a
desire
that
you
should
not
be
shipwrecked
.
<EOS>
Since
we
first
took
you
in
hand
between
us
,
Barrington
and
I
,
I
have
never
swerved
in
my
anxiety
on
your
behalf
.
<EOS>
When
I
resolved
that
it
would
be
better
for
us
both
that
we
should
be
only
friends
,
I
did
not
swerve
.
<EOS>
When
you
would
talk
to
me
so
cruelly
of
your
love
for
Violet
,
I
did
not
swerve
.
<EOS>
When
I
warned
you
from
Loughlinter
because
I
thought
there
was
danger
,
I
did
not
swerve
.
<EOS>
When
I
bade
you
not
to
come
to
me
in
London
because
of
my
husband
,
I
did
not
swerve
.
<EOS>
When
my
father
was
hard
upon
you
,
I
did
not
swerve
then
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
leave
him
till
he
was
softened
.
<EOS>
When
you
tried
to
rob
Oswald
of
his
love
,
and
I
thought
you
would
succeed
,
 
<EOS>
for
I
did
think
so
,
 
I
did
not
swerve
.
<EOS>
I
have
ever
been
true
to
you
.
<EOS>
And
now
that
I
must
hide
myself
and
go
away
,
and
be
seen
no
more
,
I
am
true
still
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Laura
,
 
dearest
Laura
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
no
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
speaking
with
no
touch
of
anger
,
but
all
in
sorrow
;
 
<EOS>
"
it
must
not
be
like
that
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
room
for
that
.
<EOS>
Nor
do
you
mean
it
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
so
ill
of
you
.
<EOS>
But
there
may
not
be
even
words
of
affection
between
us
 
<EOS>
only
such
as
I
may
speak
to
make
you
know
that
I
am
your
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
my
friend
,
"
he
said
,
stretching
out
his
hand
to
her
as
he
turned
away
his
face
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
my
friend
,
indeed
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
do
as
I
would
have
you
do
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
put
his
hand
into
his
pocket
,
and
had
the
letter
between
his
fingers
with
the
purport
of
showing
it
to
her
.
<EOS>
But
at
the
moment
the
thought
occurred
to
him
that
were
he
to
do
so
,
then
,
indeed
,
he
would
be
bound
for
ever
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
was
bound
for
ever
,
 
bound
for
ever
to
his
own
Mary
;
but
he
desired
to
have
the
privilege
of
thinking
over
such
bondage
once
more
before
he
proclaimed
it
even
to
his
dearest
friend
.
<EOS>
He
had
told
her
that
she
tempted
him
,
and
she
stood
before
him
now
as
a
temptress
.
<EOS>
But
lest
it
might
be
possible
that
she
should
not
tempt
in
vain
,
 
that
letter
in
his
pocket
must
never
be
shown
to
her
.
<EOS>
In
that
case
Lady
Laura
must
never
hear
from
his
lips
the
name
of
Mary
Flood
Jones
.
  
<EOS>
He
left
her
without
any
assured
purpose
;
 
without
,
that
is
,
the
assurance
to
her
of
any
fixed
purpose
.
<EOS>
There
yet
wanted
a
week
to
the
day
on
which
Mr.
Monk
's
bill
was
to
be
read
,
 
or
not
to
be
read
,
 
the
second
time
;
and
he
had
still
that
interval
before
he
need
decide
.
<EOS>
He
went
to
his
club
,
and
before
he
dined
he
strove
to
write
a
line
to
Mary
;
 
but
when
he
had
the
paper
before
him
he
found
that
it
was
impossible
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
Though
he
did
not
even
suspect
himself
of
an
intention
to
be
false
,
the
idea
that
was
in
his
mind
made
the
effort
too
much
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
put
the
paper
away
from
him
and
went
down
and
eat
his
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
Saturday
,
and
there
was
no
House
in
the
evening
.
<EOS>
He
had
remained
in
Portman
Square
with
Lady
Laura
till
near
seven
o'clock
,
and
was
engaged
to
go
out
in
the
evening
to
a
gathering
at
Mrs.
Gresham
's
house
.
<EOS>
Everybody
in
London
would
be
there
,
and
Phineas
was
resolved
that
as
long
as
he
remained
in
London
he
would
be
seen
at
places
where
everybody
was
seen
.
<EOS>
He
would
certainly
be
at
Mrs.
Gresham
's
gathering
;
but
there
was
an
hour
or
two
before
he
need
go
home
to
dress
,
and
as
he
had
nothing
to
do
,
he
went
down
to
the
smoking
-
room
of
his
club
.
<EOS>
The
seats
were
crowded
,
but
there
was
one
vacant
;
and
before
he
had
looked
about
him
to
scrutinise
his
neighbourhood
,
he
found
that
he
had
placed
himself
with
Bonteen
on
his
right
hand
and
Ratler
on
his
left
.
<EOS>
There
were
no
two
men
in
all
London
whom
he
more
thoroughly
disliked
;
but
it
was
too
late
for
him
to
avoid
them
now
.
  
<EOS>
They
instantly
attacked
him
,
first
on
one
side
and
then
on
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
So
I
am
told
you
are
going
to
leave
us
,
"
said
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
can
have
been
ill
-
natured
enough
to
whisper
such
a
thing
?
<EOS>
"
replied
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
whispers
are
very
loud
,
I
can
tell
you
,
"
said
Ratler
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
know
already
pretty
nearly
how
every
man
in
the
House
will
vote
,
and
I
have
not
got
your
name
down
on
the
right
side
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Change
it
for
heaven
's
sake
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
if
you
'll
tell
me
seriously
that
I
may
,
"
said
Ratler
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
opinion
is
,
"
said
Bonteen
,
"
that
a
man
should
be
known
either
as
a
friend
or
foe
.
<EOS>
I
respect
a
declared
foe
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Know
me
as
a
declared
foe
then
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
and
respect
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
very
well
,
"
said
Ratler
,
"
but
it
means
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
've
always
had
a
sort
of
fear
about
you
,
Finn
,
that
you
would
go
over
the
traces
some
day
.
<EOS>
Of
course
it
's
a
very
grand
thing
to
be
independent
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
finest
thing
in
the
world
,
"
said
Bonteen
;
"
only
so
d
 
d
useless
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
a
man
should
n't
be
independent
and
stick
to
the
ship
at
the
same
time
.
<EOS>
You
forget
the
trouble
you
cause
,
and
how
you
upset
all
calculations
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
had
n't
thought
of
the
calculations
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
,
Finn
,
"
said
Bonteen
,
"
you
are
made
of
clay
too
fine
for
office
.
<EOS>
I
've
always
found
it
has
been
so
with
men
from
your
country
.
<EOS>
You
are
the
grandest
horses
in
the
world
to
look
at
out
on
a
prairie
,
but
you
do
n't
like
the
slavery
of
harness
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
the
sound
of
a
whip
over
our
shoulders
sets
us
kicking
;
 
does
it
not
,
Ratler
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
show
the
list
to
Gresham
to
-
morrow
,
"
said
Ratler
,
"
and
of
course
he
can
do
as
he
pleases
;
but
I
do
n't
understand
this
kind
of
thing
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
you
be
in
a
hurry
,
"
said
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
bet
you
a
sovereign
Finn
votes
with
us
yet
.
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
like
being
a
little
coy
to
set
off
a
girl
's
charms
.
<EOS>
I
'll
bet
you
a
sovereign
,
Ratler
,
that
Finn
goes
out
into
the
lobby
with
you
and
me
against
Monk
's
bill
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
not
being
able
to
stand
any
more
of
this
most
unpleasant
raillery
,
got
up
and
went
away
.
<EOS>
The
club
was
distasteful
to
him
,
and
he
walked
off
and
sauntered
for
a
while
about
the
park
.
<EOS>
He
went
down
by
the
Duke
of
York
's
column
as
though
he
were
going
to
his
office
,
which
of
course
was
closed
at
this
hour
,
but
turned
round
when
he
got
beyond
the
new
public
buildings
,
 
buildings
which
he
was
never
destined
to
use
in
their
completed
state
,
 
and
entered
the
gates
of
the
enclosure
,
and
wandered
on
over
the
bridge
across
the
water
.
<EOS>
As
he
went
his
mind
was
full
of
thought
.
<EOS>
Could
it
be
good
for
him
to
give
up
everything
for
a
fair
face
?
<EOS>
He
swore
to
himself
that
of
all
women
whom
he
had
ever
seen
Mary
was
the
sweetest
and
the
dearest
and
the
best
.
<EOS>
If
it
could
be
well
to
lose
the
world
for
a
woman
,
it
would
be
well
to
lose
it
for
her
.
<EOS>
Violet
,
with
all
her
skill
,
and
all
her
strength
,
and
all
her
grace
,
could
never
have
written
such
a
letter
as
that
which
he
still
held
in
his
pocket
.
<EOS>
The
best
charm
of
a
woman
is
that
she
should
be
soft
,
and
trusting
,
and
generous
;
and
who
ever
had
been
more
soft
,
more
trusting
,
and
more
generous
than
his
Mary
?
<EOS>
Of
course
he
would
be
true
to
her
,
though
he
did
lose
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
But
to
yield
such
a
triumph
to
the
Ratlers
and
Bonteens
whom
he
left
behind
him
,
 
to
let
them
have
their
will
over
him
,
 
to
know
that
they
would
rejoice
scurrilously
behind
his
back
over
his
downfall
!
<EOS>
The
feeling
was
terrible
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
last
words
which
Bonteen
had
spoken
made
it
impossible
to
him
now
not
to
support
his
old
friend
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
only
what
Bonteen
had
said
,
but
that
the
words
of
Mr.
Bonteen
so
plainly
indicated
what
would
be
the
words
of
all
the
other
Bonteens
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
was
weak
in
this
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
had
he
been
strong
,
he
would
have
allowed
himself
to
be
guided
,
 
if
not
by
the
firm
decision
of
his
own
spirit
,
 
by
the
counsels
of
such
men
as
Mr.
Gresham
and
Lord
Cantrip
,
and
not
by
the
sarcasms
of
the
Bonteens
and
Ratlers
of
official
life
.
<EOS>
But
men
who
sojourn
amidst
savagery
fear
the
mosquito
more
than
they
do
the
lion
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
bear
to
think
that
he
should
yield
his
blood
to
such
a
one
as
Bonteen
.
  
<EOS>
And
he
must
yield
his
blood
,
unless
he
could
vote
for
Mr.
Monk
's
motion
,
and
hold
his
ground
afterwards
among
them
all
in
the
House
of
Commons
.
<EOS>
He
would
at
any
rate
see
the
session
out
,
and
try
a
fall
with
Mr.
Bonteen
when
they
should
be
sitting
on
different
benches
,
 
if
ever
fortune
should
give
him
an
opportunity
.
<EOS>
And
in
the
meantime
,
what
should
he
do
about
Madame
Goesler
?
<EOS>
What
a
fate
was
his
to
have
the
handsomest
woman
in
London
with
thousands
and
thousands
a
year
at
his
disposal
!
<EOS>
For
,
 
so
he
now
swore
to
himself
,
 
Madame
Goesler
was
the
handsomest
woman
in
London
,
as
Mary
Flood
Jones
was
the
sweetest
girl
in
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
arrived
at
any
decision
so
fixed
as
to
make
him
comfortable
when
he
went
home
and
dressed
for
Mrs.
Gresham
's
party
.
<EOS>
And
yet
he
knew
,
 
he
thought
that
he
knew
that
he
would
be
true
to
Mary
Flood
Jones
.
   
<EOS>
The
Prime
Minister
's
House
 
<EOS>
The
rooms
and
passages
and
staircases
at
Mrs.
Gresham
's
house
were
very
crowded
when
Phineas
arrived
there
.
<EOS>
Men
of
all
shades
of
politics
were
there
,
and
the
wives
and
daughters
of
such
men
;
and
there
was
a
streak
of
royalty
in
one
of
the
saloons
,
and
a
whole
rainbow
of
foreign
ministers
with
their
stars
,
and
two
blue
ribbons
were
to
be
seen
together
on
the
first
landing
-
place
,
with
a
stout
lady
between
them
carrying
diamonds
enough
to
load
a
pannier
.
<EOS>
Everybody
was
there
.
<EOS>
Phineas
found
that
even
Lord
Chiltern
was
come
,
as
he
stumbled
across
his
friend
on
the
first
foot
-
ground
that
he
gained
in
his
ascent
towards
the
rooms
.
"
<EOS>
Halloa
,
 
you
here
?
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
by
George
!
"
said
the
other
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
am
going
to
escape
as
soon
as
possible
.
<EOS>
I
've
been
trying
to
make
my
way
up
for
the
last
hour
,
but
could
never
get
round
that
huge
promontory
there
.
<EOS>
Laura
was
more
persevering
.
"
<EOS>
"
Is
Kennedy
here
?
"
<EOS>
Phineas
whispered
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
,
"
said
Chiltern
,
"
but
<EOS>
she
was
determined
to
run
the
chance
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
little
higher
up
,
 
for
Phineas
was
blessed
with
more
patience
than
Lord
Chiltern
possessed
,
 
he
came
upon
Mr.
Monk
.
"
<EOS>
So
you
are
still
admitted
privately
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
<EOS>
yes
,
 
and
we
have
just
been
having
a
most
friendly
conversation
about
you
.
<EOS>
What
a
man
he
is
!
<EOS>
He
knows
everything
.
<EOS>
He
is
so
accurate
;
so
just
in
the
abstract
,
 
and
in
the
abstract
so
generous
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
been
very
generous
to
me
in
detail
as
well
as
in
abstract
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
yes
;
I
am
not
thinking
of
individuals
exactly
.
<EOS>
His
want
of
generosity
is
to
large
masses
,
 
to
a
party
,
to
classes
,
to
a
people
;
whereas
his
generosity
is
for
mankind
at
large
.
<EOS>
He
assumes
the
god
,
affects
to
nod
,
and
seems
to
shake
the
spheres
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
nothing
against
him
.
<EOS>
He
has
asked
me
here
to
-
night
,
and
has
talked
to
me
most
familiarly
about
Ireland
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
your
chance
of
a
second
reading
?
"
asked
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
it
?
 
<EOS>
you
hear
more
of
those
things
than
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Everybody
says
it
will
be
a
close
division
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
expected
it
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
I
,
till
I
heard
what
Daubeny
said
at
the
first
reading
.
<EOS>
They
will
all
vote
for
the
bill
en
masse
,
 
hating
it
in
their
hearts
all
the
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
us
hope
they
are
not
so
bad
as
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
way
with
them
always
.
<EOS>
They
do
all
our
work
for
us
,
 
sailing
either
on
one
tack
or
the
other
.
<EOS>
That
is
their
use
in
creation
,
that
when
we
split
among
ourselves
,
as
we
always
do
,
they
come
in
and
finish
our
job
for
us
.
<EOS>
It
must
be
unpleasant
for
them
to
be
always
doing
that
which
they
always
say
should
never
be
done
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wherever
the
gift
horse
may
come
from
,
I
shall
not
look
it
in
the
mouth
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
only
one
man
in
the
House
whom
I
hope
I
may
not
see
in
the
lobby
with
me
,
and
that
is
yourself
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
question
is
decided
now
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
is
it
decided
?
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
could
not
tell
his
friend
that
a
question
of
so
great
magnitude
to
him
had
been
decided
by
the
last
sting
which
he
had
received
from
an
insect
so
contemptible
as
Mr.
Bonteen
,
but
he
expressed
the
feeling
as
well
as
he
knew
how
to
express
it
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
shall
be
with
you
.
<EOS>
I
know
what
you
are
going
to
say
,
and
I
know
how
good
you
are
.
<EOS>
But
I
could
not
stand
it
.
<EOS>
Men
are
beginning
already
to
say
things
which
almost
make
me
get
up
and
kick
them
.
<EOS>
If
I
can
help
it
,
I
will
give
occasion
to
no
man
to
hint
anything
to
me
which
can
make
me
be
so
wretched
as
I
have
been
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
Pray
do
not
say
anything
more
.
<EOS>
My
idea
is
that
I
shall
resign
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
hope
that
we
may
fight
the
battle
side
by
side
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
,
giving
him
his
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
will
fight
the
battle
side
by
side
,
"
replied
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
After
that
he
pushed
his
way
still
higher
up
the
stairs
,
having
no
special
purpose
in
view
,
not
dreaming
of
any
such
success
as
that
of
reaching
his
host
or
hostess
,
 
merely
feeling
that
it
should
be
a
point
of
honour
with
him
to
make
a
tour
through
the
rooms
before
he
descended
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
The
thing
,
he
thought
,
was
to
be
done
with
courage
and
patience
,
and
this
might
,
probably
,
be
the
last
time
in
his
life
that
he
would
find
himself
in
the
house
of
a
Prime
Minister
.
<EOS>
Just
at
the
turn
of
the
balustrade
at
the
top
of
the
stairs
,
he
found
Mr.
Gresham
in
the
very
spot
on
which
Mr.
Monk
had
been
talking
with
him
.
"
<EOS>
Very
glad
to
see
you
,
"
said
Mr.
Gresham
.
<EOS>
"
You
,
I
find
,
are
a
persevering
man
,
with
a
genius
for
getting
upwards
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Like
the
sparks
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
quite
so
quickly
,
"
said
Mr.
Gresham
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
with
the
same
assurance
of
speedy
loss
of
my
little
light
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
did
not
suit
Mr.
Gresham
to
understand
this
,
so
he
changed
the
subject
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have
you
seen
the
news
from
America
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
have
seen
it
,
but
do
not
believe
it
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
you
have
such
faith
in
a
combination
of
British
colonies
,
properly
backed
in
Downing
Street
,
as
to
think
them
strong
against
a
world
in
arms
.
<EOS>
In
your
place
I
should
hold
to
the
same
doctrine
,
 
hold
to
it
stoutly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
do
now
,
I
hope
,
Mr.
Gresham
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
 
yes
,
 
I
am
not
down
-
hearted
.
<EOS>
But
I
confess
to
a
feeling
that
the
world
would
go
on
even
though
we
had
nothing
to
say
to
a
single
province
in
North
America
.
<EOS>
But
that
is
for
your
private
ear
.
<EOS>
You
are
not
to
whisper
that
in
Downing
Street
.
<EOS>
"
Then
there
came
up
somebody
else
,
and
Phineas
went
on
upon
his
slow
course
.
<EOS>
He
had
longed
for
an
opportunity
to
tell
Mr.
Gresham
that
he
could
go
to
Downing
Street
no
more
,
but
such
opportunity
had
not
reached
him
.
  
<EOS>
For
a
long
time
he
found
himself
stuck
close
by
the
side
of
Miss
Fitzgibbon
,
 
Miss
Aspasia
Fitzgibbon
,
 
who
had
once
relieved
him
from
terrible
pecuniary
anxiety
by
paying
for
him
a
sum
of
money
which
was
due
by
him
on
her
brother
's
account
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
very
nice
thing
to
be
here
,
but
one
does
get
tired
of
it
,
"
said
Miss
Fitzgibbon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
tired
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
is
a
part
of
your
duty
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
You
are
on
your
promotion
and
are
bound
to
be
here
.
<EOS>
When
I
asked
Laurence
to
come
,
he
said
there
was
nothing
to
be
got
till
the
cards
were
shuffled
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
'll
be
shuffled
very
soon
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Whatever
colour
comes
up
,
you
'll
hold
trumps
,
I
know
,
"
said
the
lady
.
<EOS>
"
Some
hands
always
hold
trumps
.
<EOS>
"
He
could
not
explain
to
Miss
Fitzgibbon
that
it
would
never
again
be
his
fate
to
hold
a
single
trump
in
his
hand
;
so
he
made
another
fight
,
and
got
on
a
few
steps
farther
.
  
<EOS>
He
said
a
word
as
he
went
to
half
a
dozen
friends
,
 
as
friends
went
with
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
detained
for
five
minutes
by
Lady
Baldock
,
who
was
very
gracious
and
very
disagreeable
.
<EOS>
She
told
him
that
Violet
was
in
the
room
,
but
where
she
did
not
know
.
"
<EOS>
She
is
somewhere
with
Lady
Laura
,
I
believe
;
and
really
,
Mr.
Finn
,
I
do
not
like
it
.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
had
heard
that
Phineas
had
quarrelled
with
Lord
Brentford
,
but
had
not
heard
of
the
reconciliation
.
"
<EOS>
Really
,
I
do
not
like
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
told
that
Mr.
Kennedy
is
in
the
house
,
and
nobody
knows
what
may
happen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Kennedy
is
not
likely
to
say
anything
.
"
  
"
One
can
not
tell
.
<EOS>
And
when
I
hear
that
a
woman
is
separated
from
her
husband
,
I
always
think
that
she
must
have
been
imprudent
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
uncharitable
,
but
I
think
it
is
most
safe
so
to
consider
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
far
as
I
have
heard
the
circumstances
,
Lady
Laura
was
quite
right
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
so
.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
will
always
take
the
lady
's
part
,
 
of
course
.
<EOS>
But
I
should
be
very
sorry
to
have
a
daughter
separated
from
her
husband
,
 
very
sorry
.
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
had
nothing
now
to
gain
from
Lady
Baldock
's
favour
,
left
her
abruptly
,
and
went
on
again
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
great
desire
to
see
Lady
Laura
and
Violet
together
,
though
he
could
hardly
tell
himself
why
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
seen
Miss
Effingham
since
his
return
from
Ireland
,
and
he
thought
that
if
he
met
her
alone
he
could
hardly
have
talked
to
her
with
comfort
;
but
he
knew
that
if
he
met
her
with
Lady
Laura
,
she
would
greet
him
as
a
friend
,
and
speak
to
him
as
though
there
were
no
cause
for
embarrassment
between
them
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
so
far
disappointed
,
that
he
suddenly
encountered
Violet
alone
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
leaning
on
the
arm
of
Lord
Baldock
,
and
Phineas
saw
her
cousin
leave
her
.
<EOS>
But
he
would
not
be
such
a
coward
as
to
avoid
her
,
especially
as
he
knew
that
she
had
seen
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mr.
Finn
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
"
do
you
see
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
See
what
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Look
;
There
is
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
We
had
heard
that
it
was
possible
,
and
Laura
made
me
promise
that
I
would
not
leave
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
turned
his
head
,
and
saw
Mr.
Kennedy
standing
with
his
back
bolt
upright
against
a
door
-
post
,
with
his
brow
as
black
as
thunder
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
just
opposite
to
him
,
where
he
can
see
her
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
Pray
take
me
to
her
.
<EOS>
He
will
think
nothing
of
you
,
because
I
know
that
you
are
still
friends
with
both
of
them
.
<EOS>
I
came
away
because
Lord
Baldock
wanted
to
introduce
me
to
Lady
Mouser
.
<EOS>
You
know
he
is
going
to
marry
Miss
Mouser
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
,
not
caring
much
about
Lord
Baldock
and
Miss
Mouser
,
took
Violet
's
hand
upon
his
arm
,
and
very
slowly
made
his
way
across
the
room
to
the
spot
indicated
.
<EOS>
There
they
found
Lady
Laura
alone
,
sitting
under
the
upas
-
tree
influence
of
her
husband
's
gaze
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
concourse
of
people
between
them
,
and
Mr.
Kennedy
did
not
seem
inclined
to
make
any
attempt
to
lessen
the
distance
.
<EOS>
But
Lady
Laura
had
found
it
impossible
to
move
while
she
was
under
her
husband
's
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Finn
,
"
she
said
,
"
could
you
find
Oswald
?
<EOS>
I
know
he
is
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
gone
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
speaking
to
him
downstairs
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
seen
my
father
?
<EOS>
He
said
he
would
come
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
seen
him
,
but
I
will
search
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
it
will
do
no
good
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
stay
.
<EOS>
His
carriage
is
there
,
I
know
,
 
waiting
for
me
.
"
<EOS>
Phineas
immediately
started
off
to
have
the
carriage
called
,
and
promised
to
return
with
as
much
celerity
as
he
could
use
.
<EOS>
As
he
went
,
making
his
way
much
quicker
through
the
crowd
than
he
had
done
when
he
had
no
such
object
for
haste
,
he
purposely
avoided
the
door
by
which
Mr.
Kennedy
had
stood
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
his
nearest
way
,
but
his
present
service
,
he
thought
,
required
that
he
should
keep
aloof
from
the
man
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Kennedy
passed
through
the
door
and
intercepted

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
she
going
?
<EOS>
"
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
.
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
I
dare
say
she
may
before
long
.
<EOS>
I
shall
look
for
Lord
Brentford
's
carriage
by
-
and
-
by
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
her
she
need
not
go
because
of
me
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
return
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
annoy
her
here
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
much
better
that
a
woman
in
such

should
not
have
come
to
such

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
would
not
wish

to
shut
herself
up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would

to
come
back

the

she

,
and
,

there

any
law

,
she

.
<EOS>
You
tell

that
I
say
so
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Kennedy
fought
his
way
down
the
stairs
,
and
Phineas
Finn
followed
in
his
wake
.
  
<EOS>
About
half
an
hour
afterwards
Phineas
returned
to
the
two
ladies
with
tidings
that
the
carriage
would
be
at
hand
as
soon
as
they
could
be
below
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Did
he
see
you
?
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
he
followed
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
did
he
speak
to
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
he
spoke
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
did
he
say
?
"
<EOS>
And
then
,
in
the
presence
of
Violet
,
Phineas
gave
the
message
.
<EOS>
He
thought
it
better
that
it
should
be
given
;
and
were
he
to
decline
to
deliver

now
,
it
would
never

.
"
<EOS>
Whether
there
be
law
in
the
land
to
protect
me
or

there

,
I
will
never

with

,
"

Laura
.
<EOS>
"
Is
a
woman
like
a
head

,
that
she
can
be
fastened
in
her
crib
by
force
?
<EOS>
I
will
never
live
with
him
though
all

judges
of
the
land
should
decide
that
I
must
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Phineas
thought
much
of
all
this
as
he
went
to
his
solitary
lodgings
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
was
not
the
world
much
better
with
him
than
it
was
with
either
of
those
two
wretched
married
beings
?
<EOS>
And
why
?
<EOS>
He
had
not
,
at
any
rate
as
yet
,
sacrificed
for
money
or
social
gains
any
of
the
instincts
of
his
nature
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
fickle
,
foolish
,
vain
,
uncertain
,
and
perhaps
covetous
;
 
but
as
yet
he
had
not
been
false
.
<EOS>
Then
he
took
out
Mary
's
last
letter
and
read
it
again
.
   
<EOS>
Comparing
Notes
 
<EOS>
It
would
,
perhaps
,
be
difficult
to
decide
,
 
between
Lord
Chiltern
and
Miss
Effingham
,
 
which
had
been
most
wrong
,
or
which
had
been
nearest
to
the
right
,
in
the
circumstances
which
had
led
to
their
separation
.
<EOS>
The
old
lord
,
wishing
to
induce
his
son
to
undertake
work
of
some
sort
,
and
feeling
that
his
own
efforts
in
this

were
worse
than

,
had
closeted
himself
with
his
intended
daughter
-

-
law
,
and
had
obtained
from
her
a

that
she
would
use
her
influence
with
her

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
I
think
it
right
that
he
should
do
something
,
"
Violet
had
said
.
<EOS>
"
And
he
will
if
you
bid
him
,
"
replied
the
Earl
.
<EOS>
Violet
expressed
a
great
doubt
as
to
this
willingness
of
obedience
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
she
promised
to
do
her
best
,
and
she
did
her
best
.
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
,
when
she
spoke
to
him
,
knit
his

with
an
apparent

of
anger
which
his
countenance
frequently
expressed
without
any

of

on
his
part
.
<EOS>
He
was
annoyed
,
but
was
not
savagely
disposed
to
Violet
.
<EOS>
As
he
looked
at
her
,
however
,
he
seemed
to
be
very
savagely
disposed
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
you
would

?
"
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
Oswald
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
What
is
it
that
you
mean
?
<EOS>
Ought
I
to
be
a

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
that
by
preference
,
I
should
say
;
but
that
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
When
her
lover
had
frowned
at
her
,
Violet
had
resolved
,
 
had
strongly
determined
,
with
inward

of
her
own

,
 
that

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

nonsense
,
Violet
.
<EOS>
You
know
that
I
can
not
be
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
go

Parliament
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
neither
can
,
nor
would
I
if
I
could
.
<EOS>
I
dislike
the
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
might
farm
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
afford
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
might
,
 
might
do
anything
.
<EOS>
You
ought
to
do
something
.
<EOS>
You
know
that
you
ought
.
<EOS>
You
know
that
your
father
is
right
in
what
he
says
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
is
easily

,
Violet
;
but
it

,
I

,

take
my

than

's
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

;

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

not

if

?
"
<EOS>
he

.
  
<EOS>
Then
Violet
looked
into
his

and
saw
that
the
frown
was
blacker
than
ever
.
<EOS>
The

was
deeper

more
like

than

;
and

;
and

was
red
as

.
<EOS>
If

with

when

no

,

when

man

wife
?
<EOS>
At

rate
,
she

not

,
 
not

.
"
<EOS>
No
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
If

,
I

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
How

respect
one
whose
whole

will
be
,
 
will
be
 
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will

what
?
"
<EOS>
he

with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oswald
,
you
are
very
rough
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
say
that
my
life
will
be
?
"
  
<EOS>
Then
she
again
resolved
that
she
would
not

.
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
discreditable
,
"
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
shall
not
discredit

,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
bring
disgrace
on
one
I
have
loved
so
well
.
<EOS>
Violet
,
after
what
you
have
said
,
we
had

.
<EOS>
"
She
was
still
proud
,
still

,
and
they
did

.
<EOS>
Though
it
nearly
broke
her
heart
to
see
him
leave
her
,
she
bid
him
go
.
<EOS>
She
hated
herself
afterwards
for
her
severity
to
him
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
she
would
not
submit
to
recall
the
words
which
she
had
spoken
.
<EOS>
She
had
thought
him
to
be
wrong
,
and
,
so
thinking
,
had
conceived
it
to
be
her
duty
and
her
privilege
to
tell
him
what
she
thought
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
no
wish
to
lose
him
;
 
no
wish
not
to
be
his
wife
<EOS>
even
,
though
he
should
be
as
idle
as
the
wind
.
<EOS>
She
was
so
constituted
that
she
had
never
allowed
him
or
any
other
man
to
be
master
of
her
heart
,
 
till
she
had
with
a
full
purpose
<EOS>
given
her
heart
away
.
<EOS>
The
day
before
she
had
resolved
to
give
it
to
one
man
,
she
might
,
I
think
,
have
resolved
to
give
it
to
another
.
<EOS>
Love
had
not
conquered
her
,
but
had
been
taken
into
her
service
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
she
could
not
now
rid
herself
of
her
servant
,
when
she
found
that
his
services
would
stand
her
no
longer
in

stead
.
<EOS>
She
parted
from
Lord
Chiltern
with
an
assent
,
with
an
assured
brow
,
and
with
much
dignity
in
her
gait
;
but
as
soon
as
she
was
alone
she
was
a
prey
to
remorse
.
<EOS>
She
had
declared
to
the
man
who
was
to
have
been
her
husband
that
his
life
was
discreditable
,
 
and
,
of
course
,
no
man
would
bear
such
language
.
<EOS>
Had
Lord
Chiltern
borne
it
,
he
would
not
have
been
worthy
of
her
love
.
  
<EOS>
She
herself
told
Lady
Laura
and
Lord
Brentford
what
had
occurred
,
 
and
had
told
Lady
Baldock
also
.
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
had
,
of
course
,
triumphed
,
 
and
Violet
sought
her
revenge
by
swearing
that
she
would
regret
for
ever
the
loss
of
so
inestimable
a
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
Then
why
have
you
given
him
up
,
my
dear
?
"
demanded
Lady
Baldock
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Because
I
found
that
he
was
too
good
for
me
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
doubtful
whether
Lady
Baldock
was
not
justified
,
when
she
declared
that
her
niece
was
to
her
a
care
so
harassing
that
no
aunt
known
in
history
had
ever
been
so
troubled
before
.
  
<EOS>
Lord
Brentford
had
fussed
and
fumed
,
and
had
certainly
made
things
worse
.
<EOS>
He
had
quarrelled
with
his
son
,
and
then
made
it
up
,
and
then
quarrelled
again
,
 
swearing
that
the
fault
must
all
be
attributed
to
Chiltern
's
stubbornness
and
Chiltern
's
temper
.
<EOS>
Latterly
,
however
,
by
Lady
Laura
's
intervention
,
Lord
Brentford
and
his
son
had
again
been
reconciled
,
and
the
Earl
endeavoured
manfully
to
keep
his
tongue
from
disagreeable
words
,
and
his
face
from
evil
looks
,
when
his
son
was
present
.
<EOS>
"
They
will
make
it
up
,
"
Lady
Laura
had
said
,
"
if
you
and
I
do
not
attempt
to
make

up
for
them
.
<EOS>
If
we
do
,
they
will
never
come
together
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Earl
was
convinced
,
and
did
his
best
.
<EOS>
But
the
task
was
very
difficult
to
him
.
<EOS>
How
was
he
to
keep
his
tongue
off
his
son
while
his
son
was
daily
saying
things
of
which
any
father
,
 
any
such
father
as
Lord
Brentford
,
 
could
not
but
disapprove
?
<EOS>
Lord
Chiltern
professed
to
disbelieve
even
in
the
wisdom
of
the
House
of
Lords
,
and
on
one

asserted
that
it
must
be
a
great
comfort
to
any
Prime
Minister
to
have
three

old
women
in
the
Cabinet
.
<EOS>
The
father
,
when
he
heard
this
,
tried
to
rebuke
his
son
tenderly
,
strove
even
to
be
jocose
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
one
wish
of
his
heart
that
Violet
Effingham
should
be
his
daughter
-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
But
even
with
this
wish
he
found
it
very
hard
to
keep
his
tongue
off
Lord
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
When
Lady
Laura
discussed
the
matter
with
Violet
,
Violet
would
always
declare
that
there
was
no
hope
.
<EOS>
"
The
truth
is
,
"
she
said
on
the

that

on

both

to
Mrs.
Gresham
's
,
"
that
though
we
like
each
other
,
 
love
each
other
,
if
you
choose
to
say
so
,
 
we
are
not
fit
to
be
man
and
wife
.
"
  
"
And
why
not
fit
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
too
much
alike
.
<EOS>
Each
is
too
violent
,
too
headstrong
,
and
too
masterful
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
,
as
the
woman
,
ought
to
give
way
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
we
do
not
always
do
just
what
we
ought
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
how
difficult
it
is
for
me
to
advise
,
seeing
to
what
a
pass
I
have
brought
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
say
that
,
dear
;
 
or
rather

,
for
we
have
,
both

,
brought

to
what

call

pass
,
 
to
such

pass
that
we
are
like
to
be
able
to
live

and
discuss

for

rest

.
<EOS>
The
difference
is
,
I
take

,
that
you
have
not
to
accuse
yourself
,
and
that
I
have
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
say
that
I
have
not
to
accuse
myself
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
that
I
have
done
much
wrong
to
Mr.
Kennedy
since
I
married
him
;
but
in
marrying
him
I
did
him
a
grievous
wrong
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
he
has
avenged
himself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
will
not
talk
of
vengeance
.
<EOS>
I
believe
he
is
wretched
,
and
I
know
that
I
am
;
 
and
that
has
come
of
the
wrong
that
I
have
done
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
make
no
man
wretched
,
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
that
your
mind
is
made
up
against
Oswald
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
that
,
and
I
mean
much
more
.
<EOS>
I
say
that
I
will
make
no
man
wretched
.
<EOS>
Your
brother
is
not
the
only
man
who
is
so
weak
as
to
be
willing
to
run
the
hazard
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
Lord
Fawn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
there
is
Lord
Fawn
,
certainly
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
should
not
do
him
much
harm
;
but
then
I
should
do
him
no
good
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
poor
Phineas
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
there
is
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
I
will
tell
you
something
,
Laura
.
<EOS>
The
only
man
I
ever
saw
in
the
world
whom
I
have
thought
for
a
moment
that
it
was
possible
that
I
should
like
,
 
like
enough
to
love
as
my
husband
,
 
except
your
brother
,
was
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
now
?
"
  
"
Oh
;
 
now
;
of
course
that
is
over
,
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
over
?
"
  
"
Quite
over
.
<EOS>
Is
he
not
going
to
marry
Madame
Goesler
?
<EOS>
I
suppose
all
that
is
fixed
by
this
time
.
<EOS>
I
hope
she
will
be
good
to
him
,
and
gracious
,
and
let
him
have
his
own
way
,
and
give
him
his
tea
comfortably
when
he
comes
up
tired
from
the
House
;
for
I
confess
that
my
heart
is
a
little
tender
towards
Phineas
still
.
<EOS>
I
should
not
like
to
think
that
he
had
fallen
into
the
hands
of
a
female
Philistine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
he
will
marry
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
hardly
tell
you
;
 
but
I
do
not
think
he
will
.
<EOS>
And
you
loved
him
once
,
 
eh
,
Violet
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
quite
that
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
difficult
with
me
to
love
.
<EOS>
The
difficulty
with
most
girls
,
I
fancy
,
is
not
to
love
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
,
when
I
came
to
measure
him
in
my
mind
,
was
not
small
,
but
he
was
never
quite
tall
enough
.
<EOS>
One
feels
oneself
to
be
a
sort
of
recruiting
sergeant
,
going
about
with
a
standard
of
inches
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Finn
was
just
half
an
inch
too
short
.
<EOS>
He
lacks
something
in
individuality
.
<EOS>
He
is
a
little
too
much
a
friend
to
everybody
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
tell
you
a
secret
,
Violet
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
dear
;
though
I
fancy
it
is
one
I
know
already
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
the
only
man
whom
I
ever
loved
,
"
said
Lady
Laura
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
was
too
late
when
you
learned
to
love
him
,
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
too
late
,
when
I
was
so
sure
of
it
as
to
wish
that
I
had
never
seen
Mr.
Kennedy
.
<EOS>
I
felt
it
coming
on
me
,
and
I
argued
with
myself
that
such
a
marriage
would
be
bad
for
us
both
.
<EOS>
At
that
moment
there
was
trouble
in
the
family
,
and
I
had
not
a
shilling
of
my
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
had
paid
it
for
Oswald
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
At
any
rate
,
I
had
nothing
;
 
and
he
had
nothing
.
<EOS>
How
could
I
have
dared
to
think
even
of
such
a
marriage
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
he
think
of
it
,
Laura
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
he
did
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
he
did
.
<EOS>
Did
you
not
tell
me
before
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
;
 
yes
.
<EOS>
He
thought
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
had
come
to
some
foolish
,
half
-
sentimental
resolution
as
to
friendship
,
believing
that
he
and
I
could
be
knit
together
by
some

of

that
should
be
void
of

to
my
husband
;
and
in
furtherance
of
this
he
was
asked
to
Loughlinter
when
I
went
there
,
just
after
I
had
accepted
Robert
.
<EOS>
He
came
down
,
and
I
measured
him
too
,
as
you
have
done
.
<EOS>
I
measured
him
,
and
I
found
that
he
wanted
nothing
to
come
up
to
the
height
required
by
my
standard
.
<EOS>
I
think
I
knew
him
better
than
you
did
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
possibly
;
 
but
why
measure
him
at
all
,
when
such
measurement
was
useless
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Can
one
help
such
things
?
<EOS>
He
came
to
me
one
day
as
I
was
sitting
up
by
the
Linter
.
<EOS>
You
remember
the
place
,
where
it
makes
its
first
leap
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
remember
it
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
do
I.
Robert
had
shown
it
me
as
the
fairest
spot
in
all
Scotland
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
there
this
lover
of

sang
his

to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
what
he
told
me
then
;
but
I
know
that
I
told

that
I
was
engaged
;
and
I
felt
when
I
told

so
that
my
engagement
was
a
sorrow
to
me
.
<EOS>
And
it
has
been
a
sorrow
from
that

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
the
hero
,
Phineas
,
 
<EOS>
he
is
still

to

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
to

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
You
would
have
hated
me
,
had
he

my
husband
?
<EOS>
And
you
will

Madame
Goesler
when
she
becomes
his
wife
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
I
am
no
dog
in
the
manger
.
<EOS>
I
have
even
gone
so
far
as
almost
to
wish
,
at
certain
moments
,
that
you
should
accept
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
he
has
wished
it
so
heartily
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
One
can
hardly
forgive
a
man
for
such
speedy
changes
,
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Was
I
not
to
forgive
him
;
 
I
,
who
had
turned
myself
away
from
him
with
a
fixed
purpose
the
moment
that
I
found
that
he
had
made
a
mark
upon
my
heart
?
<EOS>
I
could
not
wipe
off
the
mark
,
and
yet
I
married
.
<EOS>
Was
he
not
to
try
to
wipe
off
his
mark
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
seems
that
he
wiped
it
off
very
quickly
;
 
and
since
that
he
has
wiped
off
another
mark
.
<EOS>
One
does
n't
know
how
many
marks
he
has
wiped
off
.
<EOS>
They
are
like
the
inn
-
keeper
's
score
which
he
makes
in
chalk
.
<EOS>
A
damp
cloth
brings
them
all
away
,
and
leaves
nothing
behind
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
have
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
should
be
a
little
notch
on
the
stick
,
 
to
remember
by
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
that
I
complain
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
complain
,
as
I
was
not
notched
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
silly
,
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
In
not
having
allowed
myself
to
be
notched
by
this
great
champion
?
"
  
"
A
man
like
Mr.
Finn
has
his
life
to
deal
with
,
 
to
make
the
most
of
it
,
and
to
divide
it
between
work
,
pleasure
,
duty
,
ambition
,
and
the
rest
of
it
as
best
he
may
.
<EOS>
If
he
have
any
softness
of
heart
,
it
will
be
necessary
to
him
that
love
should
bear
a
part
in
all
these
interests
.
<EOS>
But
a
man
will
be
a
fool
who
will
allow
love
to
be
the
master
of
them
all
.
<EOS>
He
will
be
one
whose
mind
is
so
ill
-
balanced
as
to
allow
him
to
be
the
victim
of
a
single
wish
.
<EOS>
Even
in
a
woman
passion
such
as
that
is
evidence
of
weakness
,
and
not
of
strength
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
seems
,
then
,
Laura
,
that
you
are
weak
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
if
I
am
,
does
that
condemn
him
?
<EOS>
He
is
a
man
,
if
I
judge
him
rightly
,
who
will
be
constant
as
the
sun
,
when
constancy
can
be
of
service
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
mean
that
the
future
Mrs.
Finn
will
be
secure
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
what
I
mean
;
 
and
that
you
or
I
,
had
either
of
us
chosen
to
take
his
name
,
might
have
been
quite
secure
.
<EOS>
We
have
thought
it
right
to
refuse
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
many
more
,
I
wonder
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
unjust
,
and
unkind
,
Violet
.
<EOS>
So
unjust
and
unkind
that
it
is
clear
to
me
he
has
just
gratified
your
vanity
,
and
has
never
touched
your
heart
.
<EOS>
What
would
you
have
had
him
do
,
when
I
told
him
that
I
was
engaged
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
that
Mr.
Kennedy
would
not
have
gone
to
Blankenberg
with
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Violet
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
seems
to
be
the
proper
thing
to
do
.
<EOS>
But
even
that
does
not
adjust
things
finally
;
 
does
it
?
"
<EOS>
Then
some
one
came
upon
them
,
and
the
conversation
was
brought
to
an
end
.
   
<EOS>
Madame
Goesler
's
Generosity
 
<EOS>
When
Phineas
Finn
left
Mr.
Gresham
's
house
he
had
quite
resolved
what
he
would
do
.
<EOS>
On
the
next
morning
he
would
tell
Lord
Cantrip
that
his
resignation
was
a
necessity
,
and
that
he
would
take
that
nobleman
's
advice
as
to
resigning
at
once
,
or
waiting
till
the
day
on
which
Mr.
Monk
's
Irish
Bill
would
be
read
for
the
second
time
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Finn
,
I
can
only
say
that
I
deeply
regret
it
,
"
said
Lord
Cantrip
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
do
I.
I
regret
to
leave
office
,
which
I
like
,
 
and
which
indeed
I
want
.
<EOS>
I
regret
specially
to
leave
this
office
,
as
it
has
been
a
thorough
pleasure
to
me
;
and
I
regret
,
above
all
,
to
leave
you
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
convinced
that
Monk
is
right
,
and
I
find
it
impossible
not
to
support
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
that
Mr.
Monk
was
at
Bath
,
"
said
Lord
Cantrip
.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
could
only
smile
,
and
shrug
his
shoulders
,
and
say
that
even
though
Mr.
Monk
were
at
Bath
it
would
not
probably
make
much
difference
.
<EOS>
When
he
tendered
his
letter
of
resignation
,
Lord
Cantrip
begged
him
to
withdraw
it
for
a
day
or
two
.
<EOS>
He
would
,
he
said
,
speak
to
Mr.
Gresham
.
<EOS>
The
debate
on
the
second
reading
of
Mr.
Monk
's
bill
would
not
take
place
till
that
day
week
,
and
the
resignation
would
be
in
time
if
it
was
tendered
before
Phineas
either
spoke
or
voted
against
the
Government
.
<EOS>
So
Phineas
went
back
to
his
room
,
and
endeavoured
to
make
himself
useful
in
some
work
appertaining
to
his
favourite
Colonies
.
  
<EOS>
That
conversation
had
taken
place
on
a
Friday
,
and
on
the
following
Sunday
,
early
in
the
day
,
he
left
his
rooms
after
a
late
breakfast
,
 
a
prolonged
breakfast
,
during
which
he
had
been
studying
tenant
-
right
statistics
,
preparing
his
own
speech
,
and
endeavouring
to
look
forward
into
the
future
which
that
speech
was
to
do
so
much
to
influence
,
 
and
turned
his
face
towards
Park
Lane
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
a
certain
understanding
between
him
and
Madame
Goesler
that
he
was
to
call
in
Park
Lane
on
this
Sunday
morning
,
and
then
declare
to
her
what
was
his
final
resolve
as
to
the
office
which
he
held
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
simply
to
bid
her
adieu
,
"
he
said
to
himself
,
"
for
I
shall
hardly
see
her
again
.
"
<EOS>
And
yet
,
as
he
took
off
his
morning
easy
coat
,
and
dressed
himself
for
the
streets
,
and
stood
for
a
moment
before
his
looking
-
glass
,
and
saw
that
his
gloves
were
fresh
and
that
his
boots
were
properly
polished
,
I
think
there
was
a
care
about
his
person
which
he
would
have
hardly
taken
<EOS>
had
he
been
quite
assured
that
he
simply
intended
to
say
good
-
bye
to
the
lady
whom
he
was
about
to
visit
.
<EOS>
But
if
there
were
any
such
conscious
feeling
,
he
administered
to
himself
an
antidote
before
he
left
the
house
.
<EOS>
On
returning
to
the
sitting
-
room
he
went
to
a
little
desk
from
which
he
took
out
the
letter
from
Mary
which
the
reader
has
seen
,
and
carefully
perused
every
word
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
is
the
best
of
them
all
,
"
he
said
to
himself
,
as
he
refolded
the
letter
and

back

.
<EOS>
I
am
not

that
it

a

any

;
as
,

.
<EOS>
The

.
  
<EOS>
The

,
and
he

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Madame
Goesler
was

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Yes

<EOS>
Madame

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

credit
me
when
I
tell
you
this
?
<EOS>
What
do
you
fear
,
that
you
should
run
away
?
<EOS>
You
have
no
wife
;
 
no
children
.
<EOS>
What
is
the
coming
misfortune
that
you
dread
?
"
<EOS>
She
paused
a
moment
as
though
for
an
answer
,
and
he
felt
that
now
had
come
the
time
in
which
it
would
be
well
that
he
should
tell
her
of
his
engagement
with
his
own
Mary
.
<EOS>
She
had
received
him
very
playfully
;
but
now
within
the
last
few
minutes
there
had
come
upon
her
a
seriousness
of
gesture
,
and
almost
a
solemnity
of
tone
,
which
made
him
conscious
that
he
should
in
no
way
trifle
with
her
.
<EOS>
She
was
so
earnest
in
her
friendship
that
he
owed
it
to
her
to
tell
her
everything
.
<EOS>
But
before
he
could
think
of
the
words
in
which
his
tale
should
be
told
,
she
had
gone
on
with
her
quick
questions
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is
it
solely
about
money
that
you
fear
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
simply
that
I
have
no
income
on
which
to
live
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
I
not
offered
you
money
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
Madame
Goesler
,
you
who
offer
it
would
yourself
despise
me
if
I
took
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
I
do
deny
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
she
said
this
,
 
not
loudly
but
with
much
emphasis
,
 
she
came
and
stood
before
him
where
he
was
sitting
.
<EOS>
And
as
he
looked
at
her
he
could
perceive
that
there
was
a
strength
about
her
of
which
he
had
not
been
aware
.
<EOS>
She
was
stronger
,
larger
,
more
robust
physically
than
he
had
hitherto
conceived
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
deny
it
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
Money
is
neither
god
nor
devil
,
that
it
should
make
one
noble
and
another
vile
.
<EOS>
It
is
an
accident
,
and
,
if
honestly
possessed
,
may
pass
from
you
to
me
,
or
from
me
to
you
,
without
a
stain
.
<EOS>
You
may
take
my
dinner
from
me
if
I
give
it
you
,
<EOS>
my
flowers
,
my
friendship
,
my
,
 
my
,
 
my
everything
,
but
my
money
!
<EOS>
Explain
to
me
the
cause
of
the
phenomenon
.
<EOS>
If
I
give
to
you
a
thousand
pounds
,
now
this
moment
,
and
you
take
it
,
you
are
base
;
 
but
if
I
leave
it
you
in
my
will
,
 
and
die
,
 
<EOS>
you
take
it
,
and
are
not
base
.
<EOS>
Explain
to
me
the
cause
of
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
said
it
quite
all
,
"
said
Phineas
hoarsely
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
left
unsaid
?
<EOS>
If
I
have
left
anything
unsaid
,
do
you
say
the
rest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
because
you
are
a
woman
,
and
young
,
and
beautiful
,
that
no
man
may
take
wealth
from
your
hands
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
is
that
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
that
partly
,
"
  
"
If
I
were
a
man
you
might
take
it
,
though
I
were
young
and
beautiful
as
the
morning
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
presents
of
money
are
always
bad
.
<EOS>
They
stain
and
load
the
spirit
,
and
break
the
heart
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
specially
when
given
by
a
woman
's
hand
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
seems
so
to
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
not
argue
of
it
.
<EOS>
Do
not
let
us
talk
of
it
any
more
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
can
I
argue
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
argue
,
but
I
can
be
generous
,
 
very
generous
.
<EOS>
I
can
deny
myself
for
my
friend
,
 
can
even
lower
myself
in
my
own
esteem
for
my
friend
.
<EOS>
I
can
do
more
than
a
man
can
do
for
a
friend
.
<EOS>
You
will
not
take
money
from
my
hand
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Madame
Goesler
;
 
I
can
not
do
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Take
the
hand
then
first
.
<EOS>
When
it
and
all
that
it
holds
are
your
own
,
you
can
help
yourself
as
you
list
.
"
<EOS>
So
saying
,
she
stood
before
him
with
her
right
hand
stretched
out
towards
him
.
  
<EOS>
What
man
will
say
that
he
would
not
have
been
tempted
?
<EOS>
Or
what
woman
will
declare
that
such
temptation
should
have
had
no
force
?
<EOS>
The
very
air
of
the
room
in
which
she
dwelt
was
sweet
in
his
nostrils
,
and
there
hovered
around
her
an
halo
of
grace
and
beauty
which
greeted
all
his
senses
.
<EOS>
She
invited
him
to
join
his
lot
to
hers
,
in
order
that
she
might
give
to
him
all
that
was
needed
to
make
his
life
rich
and
glorious
.
<EOS>
How
would
the
Ratlers
and
the
Bonteens
envy
him
when
they
heard
of
the
prize
which
had
become
his
!
<EOS>
The
Cantrips
and
the
Greshams
would
feel
that
he
was
a
friend
doubly
valuable
,
if
he
could
be
won
back
;
and
Mr.
Monk
would
greet
him
as
a
fitting
ally
,
 
an
ally
strong
with
the
strength
which
he
had
before
wanted
.
<EOS>
With
whom
would
he
not
be
equal
?
<EOS>
Whom
need
he
fear
?
<EOS>
Who
would
not
praise
him
?
<EOS>
The
story
of
his
poor
Mary
would
be
known
only
in
a
small
village
,
out
beyond
the
Channel
.
<EOS>
The
temptation
certainly
was
very
strong
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
had
not
a
moment
in
which
to
doubt
.
<EOS>
She
was
standing
there
with
her
face
turned
from
him
,
but
with
her
hand
still
stretched
towards
him
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
took
it
.
<EOS>
What
man
so
placed
could
do
other
than
take
a
woman
's
hand
?
  
<EOS>
"
My
friend
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
be
called
friend
by
you
no
more
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
call
me
Marie
,
your
own
Marie
,
or
you
must
never
call
me
by
any
name
again
.
<EOS>
Which
shall
it
be
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
He
paused
a
moment
,
holding
her
hand
,
and
she
let
it
lie
there
for
an
instant
while
she
listened
.
<EOS>
But
still
she
did
not
look
at
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Speak
to
me
!
<EOS>
Tell
me
!
<EOS>
Which
shall
it
be
?
"
<EOS>
Still
he
paused
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Speak
to
me
.
<EOS>
Tell
me
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
can
not
be
as
you
have
hinted
to
me
,
"
he
said
at
last
.
<EOS>
His
words
did
not
come
louder
than
a
low
whisper
;
but
they
were
plainly
heard
,
and
instantly
the
hand
was
withdrawn
.
  
<EOS>
"
Can
not
be
!
"
<EOS>
she
exclaimed
.
"
<EOS>
Then
I
have
betrayed
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
;
I
say
yes
!
<EOS>
If
you
will
allow
me
I
will
leave
you
.
<EOS>
You
will
,
I
know
,
excuse
me
if
I
am
abrupt
to
you
.
"
<EOS>
Then
she
strode
out
of
the
room
,
and
was
no
more
seen
of
the
eyes
of
Phineas
Finn
.
  
<EOS>
He
never
afterwards
knew
how
he
escaped
out
of
that
room
and
found
his
way
into
Park
Lane
.
<EOS>
In
after
days
he
had
some
memory
that
he
remained
there
,
he
knew
not
how
long
,
standing
on
the
very
spot
on
which
she
had
left
him
;
and
that
at
last
there
grew
upon
him
almost
a
fear
of
moving
,
a
dread
lest
he
should
be
heard
,
an
inordinate
desire
to
escape
without
the
sound
of
a
footfall
,
without
the
clicking
of
a
lock
.
<EOS>
Everything
in
that
house
had
been
offered
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
refused
it
all
,
and
then
felt
that
of
all
human
beings
under
the
sun
none
had
so
little
right
to
be
standing
there
as
he
.
<EOS>
His
very
presence
in
that
drawing
-
room
was
an
insult
to
the
woman
whom
he
had
driven
from
it
.
  
<EOS>
But
at
length
he
was
in
the
street
,
and
had
found
his
way
across
Piccadilly
into
the
Green
Park
.
<EOS>
Then
,
as
soon
as
he
could
find
a
spot
apart
from
the
Sunday
world
,
he
threw
himself
upon
the
turf
;
and
tried
to
fix
his
thoughts
upon
the
thing
that
he
had
done
.
<EOS>
His
first
feeling
,
I
think
,
was
one
of
pure
and
unmixed
disappointment
;
 
of
disappointment
so
bitter
,
that
even
the
vision
of
his
own
Mary
did
not
tend
to
comfort
him
.
<EOS>
How
great
might
have
been
his
success
,
and
how
terrible
was
his
failure
!
<EOS>
Had
he
taken
the
woman
's
hand
and
her
money
,
had
he
clenched
his
grasp
on
the
great
prize
offered
to
him
,
his
misery
would
have
been
ten
times
worse
the
first
moment
that
he
would
have
been
away
from
her
.
<EOS>
Then
,
indeed
,
 
it
being
so
that
he
was
a
man
with
a
heart
within
his
breast
<EOS>
,
 
there
would
have
been
no
comfort
for
him
,
in
his
outlooks
on
any
side
.
<EOS>
But
even
now
,
when
he
had
done
right
,
 
knowing
well
that
he
had
done
right
,
 
he
found
that
comfort
did
not
come
readily
within
his
reach
.
   
<EOS>
Amantium
Iræ
 
<EOS>
Miss
Effingham
's
life
at
this
time
was
not
the
happiest
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
Her
lines
,
as
she
once
said
to
her
friend
Lady
Laura
,
were
not
laid
for
her
in
pleasant
places
.
<EOS>
Her
residence
was
still
with
her
aunt
,
and
she
had
come
to
find
that
it
was
almost
impossible
any
longer
to
endure
Lady
Baldock
,
and
quite
impossible
to
escape
from
Lady
Baldock
.
<EOS>
In
former
days
she
had
had
a
dream
that
she
might
escape
,
and
live
alone
if
she
chose
to
be
alone
;
that
she
might
be
independent
in
her
life
,
as
a
man
is
independent
,
if
she
chose
to
live
after
that
fashion
;
that
she
might
take
her
own
fortune
in
her
own
hand
,
as
the
law
certainly
allowed
her
to
do
,
and
act
with
it
as
she
might
please
.
<EOS>
But
latterly
she
had
learned
to
understand
that
all
this
was
not
possible
for
her
.
<EOS>
Though
one
law
allowed
it
,
another
law
disallowed
it
,
and
the
latter
law
was
at
least
as
powerful
as
the
former
.
<EOS>
And
then
her
present
misery
was
enhanced
by
the
fact
that
she
was
now
banished
from
the
second
home
which
she
had
formerly
possessed
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
<EOS>
she
had
always
been
able
to
escape
from
Lady
Baldock
to
the
house
of
her
friend
,
but
now
such
escape
was
out
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
Lady
Laura
and
Lord
Chiltern
lived
in
the
same
house
,
and
Violet
could
not
live
with
them
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
understood
all
this
,
and
tortured
her
niece
accordingly
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
premeditated
torture
.
<EOS>
The
aunt
did
not
mean
to
make
her
niece
's
life
a
burden
to
her
,
and
,
so
intending
,
systematically
work
upon
a
principle
to
that
effect
.
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
,
no
doubt
,
desired
to
do
her
duty
conscientiously
.
<EOS>
But
the
result
was
torture
to
poor
Violet
,
and
a
strong
conviction
on
the
mind
of
each
of
the
two
ladies
that
the
other
was
the
most
unreasonable
being
in
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
The
aunt
,
in
these
days
,
had
taken
it
into
her
head
to
talk
of
poor
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
This
arose
partly
from
a
belief
that
the
quarrel
was
final
,
and
that
,
therefore
,
there
would
be
no
danger
in
aggravating
Violet
by
this
expression
of
pity
,
 
partly
from
a
feeling
that
it
would
be
better
that
her
niece
should
marry
Lord
Chiltern
than
that
she
should
not
marry
at
all
,
 
and
partly
,
perhaps
,
from
the
general
principle
that
,
as
she
thought
it
right
to
scold
her
niece
on
all
occasions
,
this
might
be
best
done
by
taking
an
opposite
view
of
all
questions
to
that
taken
by
the
niece
to
be
scolded
.
<EOS>
Violet
was
supposed
to
regard
Lord
Chiltern
as
having
sinned
against
her
,
and
therefore
Lady
Baldock
talked
of
"
poor
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
the
other
lovers
,
she
had
begun
to
perceive
that
their
conditions
were
hopeless
.
<EOS>
Her
daughter
Augusta
had
explained
to
her
that
there
was
no
chance
remaining
either
for
Phineas
,
or
for
Lord
Fawn
,
or
for
Mr.
Appledom
.
<EOS>
"
I
believe
she
will
be
an
old
maid
,
on
purpose
to
bring
me
to
my
grave
,
"
said
Lady
Baldock
.
<EOS>
When
,
therefore
,
Lady
Baldock
was
told
one
day
that
Lord
Chiltern
was
in
the
house
,
and
was
asking
to
see
Miss
Effingham
<EOS>
,
she
did
not
at
once
faint
away
,
and
declare
that
they
would
all
be
murdered
,
 
as
she
would
have
done
some
months
since
.
<EOS>
She
was
perplexed
by
a
double
duty
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
possible
that
Violet
should
relent
and
be
reconciled
,
then
it
would
be
her
duty
to
save
Violet
from
the
claws
of
the
wild
beast
.
<EOS>
But
if
there
was
no
such
chance
,
then
it
would
be
her
duty
to
poor
Lord
Chiltern
to
see
that
he
was
not
treated
with
contumely
and
ill
-
humour
.
  
<EOS>
"
Does
she
know
that
he
is
here
?
"
<EOS>
Lady
Baldock
asked
her
daughter
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
,
mamma
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
oh
dear
!
<EOS>
I
suppose
she
ought
to
see
him
.
<EOS>
She
has
given
him
so
much
encouragement
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
she
will
do
as
she
pleases
,
mamma
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Augusta
,
how
can
you
talk
in
that
way
?
<EOS>
Am
I
to
have
no
control
in
my
own
house
?
<EOS>
"
It
was
,
however
,
soon
apparent
to
her
that
in
this
matter
she
was
to
have
no
control
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lord
Chiltern
is
down
-
stairs
,
"
said
Violet
,
coming
into
the
room
abruptly
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
Augusta
tells
me
.
<EOS>
Sit
down
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
sit
down
,
aunt
,
 
not
just
now
.
<EOS>
I
have
sent
down
to
say
that
I
would
be
with
him
in
a
minute
.
<EOS>
He
is
the
most
impatient
soul
alive
,
and
I
must
not
keep
him
waiting
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
mean
to
see
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
I
shall
see
him
,
"
said
Violet
,
as
she
left
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
that
any
woman
should
ever
take
upon
herself
the
charge
of
a
niece
!
"
said
Lady
Baldock
to
her
daughter
in
a
despondent
tone
,
as
she
held
up
her
hands
in
dismay
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
Violet
had
gone
down
-
stairs
with
a
quick
step
,
and
had
then
boldly
entered
the
room
in
which
her
lover
was
waiting
to
receive
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
to
thank
you
for
coming
to
me
,
Violet
,
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
There
was
still
in
his
face
something
of
savagery
,
 
an
expression
partly
of
anger
and
partly
of
resolution
to
tame
the
thing
with
which
he
was
angry
.
<EOS>
Violet
did
not
regard
the
anger
half
so
keenly
as
she
did
that
resolution
of
taming
.
<EOS>
An
angry
lord
,
she
thought
,
she
could
endure
,
but
she
could
not
bear
the
idea
of
being
tamed
by
any
one
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
not
come
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
came
when
I
was
told
that
you
were
here
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
that
there
need
be
a
quarrel
between
us
,
because
we
have
changed
our
minds
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Such
changes
make
quarrels
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
shall
not
do
so
with
me
,
unless
you
choose
that
it
shall
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
Why
should
we
be
enemies
,
 
we
who
have
known
each
other
since
we
were
children
?
<EOS>
My
dearest
friends
are
your
father
and
your
sister
.
<EOS>
Why
should
we
be
enemies
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
to
ask
you
whether
you
think
that
I
have
ill
-
used
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ill
-
used
me
!
<EOS>
Certainly
not
.
<EOS>
Has
any
one
told
you
that
I
have
accused
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
one
has
told
me
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
do
you
ask
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
would
not
have
you
think
so
,
 
if
I
could
help
it
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
intend
to
be
rough
with
you
.
<EOS>
When
you
told
me
that
my
life
was
disreputable
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
Oh
,
Oswald
,
do
not
let
us
go
back
to
that
.
<EOS>
What
good
will
it
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
said
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
that
that
was
your
word
,
 
the
harshest
word
that
you
could
use
in
all
the
language
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
mean
to
be
harsh
.
<EOS>
If
I
used
it
,
I
will
beg
your
pardon
.
<EOS>
Only
let
there
be
an
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
As
we
think
so
differently
about
life
in
general
,
it
was
better
that
we
should
not
be
married
.
<EOS>
But
that
is
settled
,
and
why
should
we
go
back
to
words
that
were
spoken
in
haste
,
and
which
are
simply
disagreeable
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
to
know
whether
it
is
settled
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Certainly
.
<EOS>
You
settled
it
yourself
,
Oswald
.
<EOS>
I
told
you
what
I
thought
myself
bound
to
tell
you
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
used
language
which
I
should
not
have
used
.
<EOS>
Then
you
told
me
that
I
could
not
be
your
wife
;
 
and
I
thought
you
were
right
,
quite
right
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
wrong
,
quite
wrong
,
"
he
said
impetuously
.
"
<EOS>
So
wrong
,
that
I
can
never
forgive
myself
,
if
you
do
not
relent
.
<EOS>
I
was
such
a
fool
,
that
I
can
not
forgive
myself
my
folly
.
<EOS>
I
had
known
before
that
I
could
not
live
without
you
;
and
when
you
were
mine
,
I
threw
you
away
for
an
angry
word
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
an
angry
word
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Say
it
again
,
and
let
me
have
another
chance
to
answer
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
said
that
idleness
was
not
,
 
respectable
,
or
something
like
that
,
taken
out
of
a
copy
-
book
probably
.
<EOS>
But
you
are
a
man
who
do
not
like
rebukes
,
even
out
of
copy
-
books
.
<EOS>
A
man
so
thin
-
skinned
as
you
are
must
choose
for
himself
a
wife
with
a
softer
tongue
than
mine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
choose
none
other
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
<EOS>
But
still
he
was
savage
in
his
tone
and
in
his
gestures
.
<EOS>
"
I
made
my
choice
long
since
,
as
you
know
well
enough
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
change
easily
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
change
in
this
.
<EOS>
Violet
,
say
that
you
will
be
my
wife
once
more
,
and
I
will
swear
to
work
for
you
like
a
coal
-
heaver
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
wish
is
that
my
husband
,
 
should
I
ever
have
one
,
 
should
work
,
not
exactly
as
a
coal
-
heaver
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Violet
,
"
he
said
,
 
and
<EOS>
now
the
look
of
savagery
departed
from
him
,
and
there
came
a
smile
over
his
face
,
which
,
however
,
had
in
it
more
of
sadness
than
of
hope
or
joy
,
 
"
treat
me
fairly
,
 
or
rather
,
treat
me
generously
if
you
can
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
whether
you
ever
loved
me
much
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
much
,
 
years
ago
,
when
you
were
a
boy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
not
since
?
<EOS>
If
it
be
so
,
I
had
better
go
.
<EOS>
Love
on
one
side
only
is
a
poor
affair
at
best
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
very
poor
affair
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
better
to
bear
anything
than
to
try
and
make
out
life
with
that
.
<EOS>
Some
of
you
women
never
want
to
love
any
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
was
what
I
was
saying
of
myself
to
Laura
but
the
other
day
.
<EOS>
With
some
women
it
is
so
easy
.
<EOS>
With
others
it
is
so
difficult
,
that
perhaps
it
never
comes
to
them
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
with
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
with
me
 
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
better
in
these
matters
to
confine
oneself
to
generalities
.
<EOS>
If
you
please
,
I
will
not
describe
myself
personally
.
<EOS>
Were
I
to
do
so
,
doubtless
I
should
do
it
falsely
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
love
no
one
else
,
Violet
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
my
affair
,
my
lord
.
"
  
"
By
heavens
,
and
it
is
mine
too
.
<EOS>
Tell
me
that
you
do
,
and
I
will
go
away
and
leave
you
at
once
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
ask
his
name
,
and
I
will
trouble
you
no
more
.
<EOS>
If
it
is
not
so
,
and
if
it
is
possible
that
you
should
forgive
me
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
Forgive
you
!
<EOS>
When
have
I
been
angry
with
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Answer
me
my
question
,
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
answer
you
your
question
,
 
not
that
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
question
will
you
answer
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Any
that
may
concern
yourself
and
myself
.
<EOS>
None
that
may
concern
other
people
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
told
me
once
that
you
loved
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
moment
I
told
you
that
I
did
so
,
 
years
ago
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
now
?
"
  
"
That
is
another
matter
.
"
  
"
Violet
,
do
you
love
me
now
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
a
point
-
blank
question
at
any
rate
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
will
answer
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
answer
it
,
 
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Oswald
,
what
a
fool
you
are
!
<EOS>
Love
you
!
<EOS>
of
course
I
love
you
.
<EOS>
If
you
can
understand
anything
,
you
ought
to
know
that
I
have
never
loved
any
one
else
;
 
that
after
what
has
passed
between
us
,
I
never
shall
love
any
one
else
.
<EOS>
I
do
love
you
.
<EOS>
There
.
<EOS>
Whether
you
throw
me
away
from
you
,
as
you
did
the
other
day
,
 
with
great
scorn
,
mind
you
,
 
or
come
to
me
with
sweet
,
beautiful
promises
,
as
you
do
now
,
I
shall
love
you
all
the
same
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
be
your
wife
,
if
you
will
not
have
me
;
can
I
?
<EOS>
When
you
run
away
in
your
tantrums
because
I
quote
something
out
of
the
copy
-
book
,
I
ca
n't
run
after
you
.
<EOS>
It
would
not
be
pretty
.
<EOS>
But
as
for
loving
you
,
if
you
doubt
that
,
I
tell
you
,
you
are
a
 
fool
.
<EOS>
"
As
she
spoke
the
last
words
she
pouted
out
her
lips
at
him
,
and
when
he
looked
into
her
face
he
saw
that
her
eyes
were
full
of
tears
.
<EOS>
He
was
standing
now
with
his
arm
round
her
waist
,
so
that
it
was
not
easy
for
him
to
look
into
her
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
fool
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
you
are
;
but
I
do
n't
love
you
the
less
on
that
account
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
doubt
it
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
;
 
do
not
;
and
,
for
me
,
I
will
not
say
another
word
,
whether
you
choose
to
heave
coals
or
not
.
<EOS>
You
shall
do
as
you
please
.
<EOS>
I
meant
to
be
very
wise
;
 
I
did
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
grandest
girl
that
ever
was
made
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
want
to
be
grand
at
all
,
and
I
never
will
be
wise
any
more
.
<EOS>
Only
do
not
frown
at
me
and
look
savage
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
she
put
up
her
hand
to
smooth
his
brow
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
half
afraid
of
you
still
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
There
.
<EOS>
That
will
do
.
<EOS>
Now
let
me
go
,
that
I
may
tell
my
aunt
.
<EOS>
During
the
last
two
months
she
has
been
full
of
pity
for
poor
Lord
Chiltern
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
poor
Lord
Chiltern
with
a
vengeance
!
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
now
that
we
have
made
it
up
,
she
will
be
horrified
again
at
all
your
wickednesses
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
a
turtle
dove
lately
;
 
now
you
will
be
an
ogre
again
.
<EOS>
But
,
Oswald
,
you
must
not
be
an
ogre
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
soon
as
she
could
get
quit
of
her
lover
,
she
did
tell
her
tale
to
Lady
Baldock
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
accepted
him
again
!
"
<EOS>
said
her
aunt
,
holding
up
her
hands
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
 
I
have
accepted
him
again
,
"
replied
Violet
.
"
<EOS>
Then
the
responsibility
must
be
on
your
own
shoulders
,
"
said
her
aunt
;
<EOS>
"
I
wash
my
hands
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
That
evening
,
when
she
discussed
the
matter
with
her
daughter
,
Lady
Baldock
spoke
of
Violet
and
Lord
Chiltern
,
as
though
their
intended
marriage
were
the
one
thing
in
the
world
which
she
most
deplored
.
   
<EOS>
The
Beginning
of
the
End
 
<EOS>
The
day
of
the
debate
had
come
,
and
Phineas
Finn
was
still
sitting
in
his
room
at
the
Colonial
Office
.
<EOS>
But
his
resignation
had
been
sent
in
and
accepted
,
and
he
was
simply
awaiting
the
coming
of
his
successor
.
<EOS>
About
noon
his
successor
came
,
and
he
had
the
gratification
of
resigning
his
arm
-
chair
to
Mr.
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
It
is
generally
understood
that
gentlemen
leaving
offices
give
up
either
seals
or
a
portfolio
.
<EOS>
Phineas
had
been
put
in
possession
of
no
seal
and
no
portfolio
;
but
there
was
in
the
room
which
he
had
occupied
a
special
arm
-
chair
,
and
this
with
much
regret
he
surrendered
to
the
use
and
comfort
of
Mr.
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
glance
of
triumph
in
his
enemy
's
eyes
,
and
an
exultation
in
the
tone
of
his
enemy
's
voice
,
which
were
very
bitter
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
So
you
are
really
going
?
"
said
Mr.
Bonteen
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
;
I
dare
say
it
is
all
very
proper
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
quite
understand
the
thing
myself
,
but
I
have
no
doubt
you
are
right
.
"
<EOS>
"
It
is
n't
easy
to
understand
;
is
it
?
"
said
Phineas
,
trying
to
laugh
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Bonteen
did
not
feel
the
intended
satire
,
and
poor
Phineas
found
it
useless
to
attempt
to
punish
the
man
he
hated
.
<EOS>
He
left
him
as
quickly
as
he
could
,
and
went
to
say
a
few
words
of
farewell
to
his
late
chief
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
Finn
,
"
said
Lord
Cantrip
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
great
trouble
to
me
that
we
should
have
to
part
in
this
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
to
me
also
,
my
lord
.
<EOS>
I
wish
it
could
have
been
avoided
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
not
have
gone
to
Ireland
with
so
dangerous
a
man
as
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
too
late
to
think
of
that
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
milk
is
spilt
;
is
it
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
these
terrible
rendings
asunder
never
last
very
long
,
"
said
Lord
Cantrip
,
"
unless
a
man
changes
his
opinions
altogether
.
<EOS>
How
many
quarrels
and
how
many
reconciliations
we
have
lived
to
see
!
<EOS>
I
remember
when
Gresham
went
out
of
office
,
because
he
could
not
sit
in
the
same
room
with
Mr.
Mildmay
,
and
yet
they
became
the
fastest
of
political
friends
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
time
when
Plinlimmon
and
the
Duke
could
not
stable
their
horses
together
at
all
;
and
do
n't
you
remember
when
Palliser
was
obliged
to
give
up
his
hopes
of
office
because
he
had
some
bee
in
his
bonnet
?
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
however
,
that
the
bee
in
Mr.
Palliser
's
bonnet
to
which
Lord
Cantrip
was
alluding
made
its
buzzing
audible
on
some
subject
that
was
not
exactly
political
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
have
you
back
again
before
long
,
I
do
n't
doubt
.
<EOS>
Men
who
can
really
do
their
work
are
too
rare
to
be
left
long
in
the
comfort
of
the
benches
below
the
gangway
.
<EOS>
"
This
was
very
kindly
said
,
and
Phineas
was
flattered
and
comforted
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
,
however
,
make
Lord
Cantrip
understand
the
whole
truth
.
<EOS>
For
him
the
dream
of
a
life
of
politics
was
over
for
ever
.
<EOS>
He
had
tried
it
,
and
had
succeeded
beyond
his
utmost
hopes
;
but
,
in
spite
of
his
success
,
the
ground
had
crumbled
to
pieces
beneath
his
feet
,
and
he
knew
that
he
could
never
recover
the
niche
in
the
world
's
gallery
which
he
was
now
leaving
.
  
<EOS>
That
same
afternoon
he
met
Mr.
Gresham
in
one
of
the
passages
leading
to
the
House
,
and
the
Prime
Minister
put
his
arm
through
that
of
our
hero
as
they
walked
together
into
the
lobby
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
that
we
are
losing
you
,
"
said
Mr.
Gresham
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
sure
that
I
am
sorry
to
be
so
lost
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
These
things
will
occur
in
political
life
,
"
said
the
leader
;
"
but
I
think
that
they
seldom
leave
rancour
behind
them
when
the
purpose
is
declared
,
and
when
the
subject
of
disagreement
is
marked
and
understood
.
<EOS>
The
defalcation
which
creates
angry
feeling
is
that
which
has
to
be
endured
without
previous
warning
,
 
when
a
man
votes
against
his
party
,
 
or
a
set
of
men
,
from
private
pique
or
from
some
cause
which
is
never
clear
.
"
<EOS>
Phineas
,
when
he
heard
this
,
knew
well
how
terribly
this
very
man
had
been
harassed
,
and
driven
nearly
wild
,
by
defalcation
,
exactly
of
that
nature
which
he
was
attempting
to
describe
.
"
<EOS>
No
doubt
you
and
Mr.
Monk
think
you
are
right
,
"
continued
Mr.
Gresham
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
have
given
strong
evidence
that
we
think
so
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
We
give
up
our
places
,
and
we
are
,
both
of
us
,
very
poor
men
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
are
wrong
,
you
know
,
not
so
much
in
your
views
on
the
question
itself
 
which
,
to
tell
the
truth
,
I
hardly
understand
as
yet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
will
endeavour
to
explain
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
will
do
so
very
clearly
,
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
But
I
think
that
Mr.
Monk
was
wrong
in
desiring
,
as
a
member
of
a
Government
,
to
force
a
measure
which
,
whether
good
or
bad
,
the
Government
as
a
body
does
not
desire
to
initiate
,
 
at
any
rate
,
just
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
therefore
he
resigned
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
.
<EOS>
But
it
seems
to
me
that
he
failed
to
comprehend
the
only
way
in
which
a
great
party
can
act
together
,
if
it
is
to
do
any
service
in
this
country
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
for
a
moment
think
that
I
am
blaming
him
or
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
nobody
in
this
matter
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
assure
you
,
Mr.
Finn
,
that
we
have
not
regarded
you
in
that
light
,
and
I
hope
that
the
time
may
come
when
we
may
be
sitting
together
again
on
the
same
bench
.
"
  
<EOS>
Neither
on
the
Treasury
bench
nor
on
any
other
in
that
House
was
he
to
sit
again
after
this
fashion
!
<EOS>
That
was
the
trouble
which
was
crushing
his
spirit
at
this
moment
,
and
not
the
loss
of
his
office
!
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
could
not
venture
to
think
of
remaining
in
London
as
a
member
of
Parliament
with
no
other
income
than
that
which
his
father
could
allow
him
,
even
if
he
could
again
secure
a
seat
in
Parliament
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
first
been
returned
for
Loughshane
he
had
assured
his
friends
that
his
duty
as
a
member
of
the
House
of
Commons
would
not
be
a
bar
to
his
practice
in
the
Courts
.
<EOS>
He
had
now
been
five
years
a
member
,
and
had
never
once
made
an
attempt
at
doing
any
part
of
a
barrister
's
work
.
<EOS>
He
had
gone
altogether
into
a
different
line
of
life
,
and
had
been
most
successful
;
 
so
successful
that
men
told
him
,
and
women
more
frequently
than
men
,
that
his
career
had
been
a
miracle
of
success
.
<EOS>
But
there
had
been
,
as
he
had
well
known
from
the
first
,
this
drawback
in
the
new
profession
which
he
had
chosen
,
that
nothing
in
it
could
be
permanent
.
<EOS>
They
who
succeed
in
it
,
may
probably
succeed
again
;
but
then
the
success
is
intermittent
,
and
there
may
be
years
of
hard
work
in
opposition
,
to
which
,
unfortunately
,
no
pay
is
assigned
.
<EOS>
It
is
almost
imperative
,
as
he
now
found
,
that
they
who
devote
themselves
to
such
a
profession
should
be
men
of
fortune
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
commenced
his
work
,
 
at
the
period
of
his
first
return
for
Loughshane
,
 
he
had
had
no
thought
of
mending
his
deficiency
in
this
respect
by
a
rich
marriage
.
<EOS>
Nor
had
it
ever
occurred
to
him
that
he
would
seek
a
marriage
for
that
purpose
.
<EOS>
Such
an
idea
would
have
been
thoroughly
distasteful
to
him
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
no
stain
of
premeditated
mercenary
arrangement
upon
him
at
any
time
.
<EOS>
But
circumstances
had
so
fallen
out
with
him
,
that
as
he
won
his
spurs
in
Parliament
,
as
he
became
known
,
and
was
placed
first
in
one
office
and
then
in
another
,
prospects
of
love
and
money
together
were
opened
to
him
,
and
he
ventured
on
,
leaving
Mr.
Low
and
the
law
behind
him
,
 
because
these
prospects
were
so
alluring
.
<EOS>
Then
had
come
Mr.
Monk
and
Mary
Flood
Jones
,
 
and
everything
around
him
had
collapsed
.
  
<EOS>
Everything
around
him
had
collapsed
,
 
with
,
however
,
a
terrible
temptation
to
him
to
inflate
his
sails
again
,
at
the
cost
of
his
truth
and
his
honour
.
<EOS>
The
temptation
would
have
affected
him
not
at
all
,
had
Madame
Goesler
been
ugly
,
stupid
,
or
personally
disagreeable
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
,
he
thought
,
the
most
beautiful
woman
he
had
ever
seen
,
the
most
witty
,
and
in
many
respects
the
most
charming
.
<EOS>
She
had
offered
to
give
him
everything
that
she
had
,
so
to
place
him
in
the
world
that
opposition
would
be
more
pleasant
to
him
than
office
,
to
supply
every
want
,
and
had
done
so
in
a
manner
that
had
gratified
all
his
vanity
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
refused
it
all
,
because
he
was
bound
to
the
girl
at
Floodborough
.
<EOS>
My
readers
will
probably
say
that
he
was
not
a
true
man
unless
he
could
do
this
without
a
regret
.
<EOS>
When
Phineas
thought
of
it
all
,
there
were
many
regrets
.
  
<EOS>
But
there
was
at
the
same
time
a
resolve
on
his
part
,
that
if
any
man
had
ever
loved
the
girl
he
promised
to
love
,
he
would
love
Mary
Flood
Jones
.
<EOS>
A
thousand
times
he
had
told
himself
that
she
had
not
the
spirit
of
Lady
Laura
,
or
the
bright
wit
of
Violet
Effingham
,
or
the
beauty
of
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
But
Mary
had
charms
of
her
own
that
were
more
valuable
than
them
all
.
<EOS>
Was
there
one
among
the
three
who
had
trusted
him
as
she
trusted
him
,
 
or
loved
him
with
the
same
satisfied
devotion
?
<EOS>
There
were
regrets
,
regrets
that
were
heavy
on
his
heart
;
 
for
London
,
and
Parliament
,
and
the
clubs
,
and
Downing
Street
,
had
become
dear
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
liked
to
think
of
himself
as
he
rode
in
the
park
,
and
was
greeted
by
all
those
whose
greeting
was
the
most
worth
having
.
<EOS>
There
were
regrets
,
 
sad
regrets
.
<EOS>
But
the
girl
whom
he
loved
better
than
the
parks
and
the
clubs
,
 
better
even
than
Westminster
and
Downing
Street
,
should
never
know
that
they
had
existed
.
  
<EOS>
These
thoughts
were
running
through
his
mind
even
while
he
was
listening
to
Mr.
Monk
,
as
he
propounded
his
theory
of
doing
justice
to
Ireland
.
<EOS>
This
might
probably
be
the
last
great
debate
in
which
Phineas
would
be
able
to
take
a
part
,
and
he
was
determined
that
he
would
do
his
best
in
it
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
intend
to
speak
on
this
day
,
if
,
as
was
generally
supposed
,
the
House
would
be
adjourned
before
a
division
could
be
obtained
.
<EOS>
But
he
would
remain
on
the
alert
and
see
how
the
thing
went
.
<EOS>
He
had
come
to
understand
the
forms
of
the
place
,
and
was
as
well
-
trained
a
young
member
of
Parliament
as
any
there
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
quick
at
learning
a
lesson
that
is
not
easily
learned
,
and
knew
how
things
were
going
,
and
what
were
the
proper
moments
for
this
question
or
that
form
of
motion
.
<EOS>
He
could
anticipate
a
count
-
out
,
understood
the
tone
of
men
's
minds
,
and
could
read
the
gestures
of
the
House
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
little
likely
that
the
debate
should
be
over
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
;
and
as
the
present
time
was
the
evening
of
Tuesday
,
he
resolved
at
once
that
he
would
speak
as
early
as
he
could
on
the
following
Thursday
.
<EOS>
What
a
pity
it
was
,
that
with
one
who
had
learned
so
much
,
all
his
learning
should
be
in
vain
!
  
<EOS>
At
about
two
o'clock
,
he
himself
succeeded
in
moving
the
adjournment
of
the
debate
.
<EOS>
This
he
did
from
a
seat
below
the
gangway
,
to
which
he
had
removed
himself
from
the
Treasury
bench
.
<EOS>
Then
the
House
was
up
,
and
he
walked
home
with
Mr.
Monk
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Monk
,
since
he
had
been
told
positively
by
Phineas
that
he
had
resolved
upon
resigning
his
office
,
had
said
nothing
more
of
his
sorrow
at
his
friend
's
resolve
,
but
had
used
him
as
one
political
friend
uses
another
,
telling
him
all
his
thoughts
and
all
his
hopes
as
to
this
new
measure
of
his
,
and
taking
counsel
with
him
as
to
the
way
in
which
the
fight
should
be
fought
.
<EOS>
Together
they
had
counted
over
the
list
of
members
,
marking
these
men
as
supporters
,
those
as
opponents
,
and
another
set
,
now
more
important
than
either
,
as
being
doubtful
.
<EOS>
From
day
to
day
those
who
had
been
written
down
as
doubtful
were
struck
off
that
third
list
,
and
put
in
either
the
one
or
the
other
of
those
who
were
either
supporters
or
opponents
.
<EOS>
And
their
different
modes
of
argument
were
settled
between
these
two
allied
orators
,
<EOS>
how
one
should
take
this
line
and
the
other
that
.
<EOS>
To
Mr.
Monk
this
was
very
pleasant
.
<EOS>
He
was
quite
assured
now
that
opposition
was
more
congenial
to
his
spirit
,
and
more
fitting
for
him
than
office
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
doubt
to
him
as
to
his
future
sitting
in
Parliament
,
let
the
result
of
this
contest
be
what
it
might
.
<EOS>
The
work
which
he
was
now
doing
,
was
the
work
for
which
he
had
been
training
himself
all
his
life
.
<EOS>
While
he
had
been
forced
to
attend
Cabinet
Councils
from
week
to
week
,
he
had
been
depressed
.
<EOS>
Now
he
was
exultant
.
<EOS>
Phineas
seeing
and
understanding
all
this
,
said
<EOS>
but
little
to
his
friend
of
his
own
prospects
.
<EOS>
As
long
as
this
pleasant
battle
was
raging
,
he
could
fight
in
it
shoulder
to
shoulder
with
the
man
he
loved
.
<EOS>
After
that
there
would
be
a
blank
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
see
how
we
are
to
fail
to
have
a
majority
after
Daubeny
's
speech
to
-
night
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
,
as
they
walked
together
down
Parliament
Street
through
the
bright
moonlight
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
expressly
said
that
he
only
spoke
for
himself
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
we
know
what
that
means
.
<EOS>
He
is
bidding
for
office
,
and
of
course
those
who
want
office
with
him
will
vote
as
he
votes
.
<EOS>
We
have
already
counted
those
who
would
go
into
office
,
but
they
will
not
carry
the
whole
party
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
carry
enough
of
them
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
are
forty
or
fifty
men
on
his
side
of
the
House
,
and
as
many
perhaps
on
ours
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
,
"
who
have
no
idea
of
any
kind
on
any
bill
,
and
who
simply
follow
the
bell
,
whether
into
this
lobby
or
that
.
<EOS>
Argument
never
touches
them
.
<EOS>
They
do
not
even
look
to
the
result
of
a
division
on
their
own
interests
,
as
the
making
of
any
calculation
would
be
laborious
to
them
.
<EOS>
Their
party
leader
is
to
them
a
Pope
whom
they
do
not
dream
of
doubting
.
<EOS>
I
never
can
quite
make
up
my
mind
whether
it
is
good
or
bad
that
there
should
be
such
men
in
Parliament
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Men
who
think
much
want
to
speak
often
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Exactly
so
,
 
and
of
speaking
members
,
God
knows
that
we
have
enough
.
<EOS>
And
I
suppose
that
these
purblind
sheep
do
have
some
occult
weight
that
is
salutary
.
<EOS>
They
enable
a
leader
to
be
a
