,
and
even
in
that
way
they
are
useful
.
<EOS>
We
shall
get
a
division
on
Thursday
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
understand
that
Gresham
has
consented
to
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
Ratler
told
me
.
<EOS>
Palliser
is
to
speak
,
and
Barrington
Erle
.
<EOS>
And
they
say
that
Robson
is
going
to
make
an
onslaught
specially
on
me
.
<EOS>
We
shall
get
it
over
by
one
o'clock
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
if
we
beat
them
?
"
asked

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
depend
on
the
numbers
.
<EOS>
Everybody
who
has
spoken
to
me
about
it
,
seems
to
think
that
they
will
dissolve
if
there
be
a
respectable

against

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
he
will
dissolve
,
"
said
Phineas
,
speaking

Mr.
Gresham
;
"
what
else
can

do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
very
anxious
to
carry
his
Irish
Reform
Bill
first
,
if
he
can
do
so
.
<EOS>
Good
-
night
,
Phineas
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
be
down
to
-
morrow
as
there
is
nothing
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
Come
to
me
on
Thursday
,
and
we
will
go
to
the
House
together
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
On
the
Wednesday
Phineas
was
engaged
to
dine
with
Mr.
Low
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
dinner
party
in
Bedford
Square
,
and
Phineas
met
half
-
a
-
dozen
barristers
and
their
wives
,
 
men
to
whom
he
had
looked
up
as
successful
pundits
in
the
law
some
five
or
six
years
ago
,
but
who
since
that
time
had
almost
learned
to
look
up
to
him
.
<EOS>
And
now
they
treated
him
with
that
courteousness
of
manner
which
success
in
life
always
begets
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
judge
there
who
was
very
civil
to
him
;
and
the
judge
's
wife
whom
he
had
taken
down
to
dinner
was
very
gracious
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
judge
had
got
his
prize
in
life
,
and
was
therefore
personally
indifferent
to
the
fate
of
ministers
;
but
the
judge
's
wife
had
a
brother
who
wanted
a
County
Court
from
Lord
De
Terrier
,
and
it
was
known
that
Phineas
was
giving
valuable
assistance
towards
the
attainment
of
this
object
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
think
that
you
and
Mr.
Monk
are
so
right
,
"
said
the
judge
's
wife
.
<EOS>
Phineas
,
who
understood
how
it
came
to
pass
that
the
judge
's
wife
should
so
cordially
approve
his
conduct
,
could
not
help
thinking
how
grand
a
thing
it
would
be
for
him
to
have
a
County
Court
for
himself
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
guests
were
gone
he
was
left
alone
with
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Low
,
and
remained
awhile
with
them
,
there
having
been
an
understanding
that
they
should
have
a
last

together
over
the

of
our
hero
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
really
mean
that
you
will
not
stand
again
?
"
asked
Mrs.
Low
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
mean
it
.
<EOS>
I
may
say
that
I
can
not
do
so
.
<EOS>
My
father
is
hardly
so
well
able
to

as
he
was
when
I
began
this
game
,
and
I
certainly
shall
not
ask
him
for

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
thousand
pities
,
"
said

Low
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
really
had
begun
to

,
"
said

Low
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
one

I
have
made

.
<EOS>
For
the
last
three
years
I
have
lived
upon
what
I
have

,
and
I
am
not
in
debt
.
<EOS>
But
now
I
must
begin
the
world
again
.
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
I
shall
find
the
drudgery
very
hard
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
hard
no

,
"
said
the
barrister
,
who
had
gone
through
it
all
,
and
was
now

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
suppose
you
have
not

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
can
say
?
<EOS>
I
dare
say
I
have
.
<EOS>
But
I
did
not
mean
the
drudgery
of
learning
,
so
much
as
the
drudgery
of
looking
after
work
;
 
of
expecting
briefs
which
perhaps
will
never

.
<EOS>
I
am
thirty
years
old
now
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
indeed
?
"
said
Mrs.
Low
,
 
who
knew
his
age
to
a

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
the
time
passes
.
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
I
hope
you
'll
get
on
,
Mr.
Finn
.
<EOS>
I
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
he
will
,
if
he
puts
his
shoulder
to
it
,
"
said
Mr.
Low
.
  
<EOS>
Neither
the
lawyer
nor
his
wife
repeated
any
of
those
sententious
admonitions
,
which
had
almost
become
rebukes
,
and
which
had
been
so
common
in

.
<EOS>
The
fall
with
which
they
had
threatened
Phineas
Finn
had
come
upon
him
,
and
they
were
too
generous
to
remind
him
of
their
wisdom
and
sagacity
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
when
he
got

to

,
Mrs.
Low
,
who
probably
might
not
see

again
for

,
was
quite

in
her

to

,
and
looked
as

as

.
<EOS>
"
We

,
"
she

,
"
when

are
Master
of

Rolls

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
him
before
then
thundering
at
us
poor
Tories
in
the
House
,
"
said
Mr.
Low
.
<EOS>
"
He
will
be
back
again
sooner
or
later
.
"
<EOS>
And
so
they
parted
.
   
<EOS>
P.
P.
C.
 
<EOS>
On
the
Thursday
morning
before
Phineas
went
to
Mr.
Monk
,
a
gentleman
called
upon
him
at
his
lodgings
.
<EOS>
Phineas
requested
the
servant
to
bring
up
the
gentleman
's
name
,
but
tempted
perhaps
by
a
shilling
the
girl
brought
up
the
gentleman
instead
.
<EOS>
It
was
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
from
the
office
of
the
"
Banner
of
the
People
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Finn
,
"
said
Quintus
,
with
his
hand
extended
,
"
I
have
come
to
offer
you
the
calumet
of
peace
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Phineas
certainly
desired
no
such
calumet
.
<EOS>
But
to
refuse
a
man
's
hand
is
to
declare
active
war
after
a
fashion
which
men
do
not
like
to
adopt
except
on
deliberation
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
cared
a
straw
for
the
abuse
which
Mr.
Slide
had
poured
upon
him
,
and
now
he
gave
his
hand
to
the
man
of
letters
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
sit
down
,
nor
did
he
offer
a
seat
to
Mr.
Slide
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
as
a
man
of
sense
who
knows
the
world
,
you
will
accept
the
calumet
of
peace
,
"
continued
Mr.
Slide
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
why
I
should
be
asked
particularly
to
accept
war
or
peace
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mr.
Finn
,
 
I
do
n't
often
quote
the
Bible
;
but
those
who
are
not
for
us
must
be
against
us
.
<EOS>
You
will
agree
to
that
.
<EOS>
Now
that
you
've
freed
yourself
from
the
iniquities
of
that
sink
of
abomination
in
Downing
Street
,
I
look
upon
you
as
a
man
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
you
are
very
kind
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
a
man
and
also
a
brother
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
know
that
I
've
got
the
_
Banner
_
into
my
own
'
ands
now
.
<EOS>
"
Phineas
was
obliged
to
explain
that
he
had
not
hitherto
been
made
acquainted
with
this
great
literary
and
political
secret
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
dear
,
yes
,
altogether
so
.
<EOS>
We
've
got
rid
of
old
Rusty
as
I
used
to
call
him
.
<EOS>
He
would
n't
go
the
pace
,
and
so
we
stripped
him
.
<EOS>
He
's
doing
the
_
West
of
England
Art
Journal
_
now
,
and
he
'
angs
out
down
at
Bristol
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
he
'll
succeed
,
Mr.
Slide
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
'll
earn
his
wages
.
<EOS>
He
's
a
man
who
will
always
earn
his
wages
,
but
nothing
more
.
<EOS>
Well
,
now
,
Mr.
Finn
,
I
will
just
offer
you
one
word
of
apology
for
our
little
severities
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
nothing
of
the
kind
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
I
shall
.
<EOS>
Dooty
is
dooty
.
<EOS>
There
was
some
things
printed
which
were
a
little
rough
,
but
if
one
is
n't
a
little
rough
there
ai
n't
no
flavour
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
wrote
'em
.
<EOS>
You
know
my
"
and
,
I
dare
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
only
remember
that
there
was
some
throwing
of
mud
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Just
so
.
<EOS>
But
mud
do
n't
break
any
bones
;
does
it
?
<EOS>
When
you
turned
against
us
I
had
to
be
down
on
you
,
and
I
was
down
upon
you
;
 
<EOS>
that
's
just
about
all
of
it
.
<EOS>
Now
you
're
coming
among
us
again
,
and
so
I
come
to
you
with
a
calumet
of
peace
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
not
coming
among
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
you
are
,
Finn
,
and
bringing
Monk
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
now
becoming
very
disagreeable
,
and
Phineas
was
beginning
to
perceive
that
it
would
soon
be
his
turn
to
say
something
rough
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
I
'll
tell
you
what
my
proposition
is
.
<EOS>
If
you
'll
do
us
two
leaders
a
week
through
the
session
,
you
shall
have
a
cheque
for
£
16
on
the
last
day
of
every
month
.
<EOS>
If
that
's
not
honester
money
than
what
you
got
in
Downing
Street
,
my
name
is
not
Quintus
Slide
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Slide
,
"
said
Phineas
,
 
<EOS>
and
then
he
paused
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
we
are
to
come
to
business
,
drop
the
Mister
.
<EOS>
It
makes
things
go
so
much
easier
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
not
to
come
to
business
,
and
I
do
not
want
things
to
go
easy
.
<EOS>
I
believe
you
said
some
things
of
me
in
your
newspaper
that
were
very
scurrilous
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
of
that
?
<EOS>
If
you
mind
that
sort
of
thing
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
did
not
regard
it
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
You
are
quite
welcome
to
continue
it
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
doubt
<EOS>
but
you
will
continue
it
.
<EOS>
But
you
are
not
welcome
to
come
here
afterwards
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
to
turn
me
out
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Just
that
.
<EOS>
You
printed
a
heap
of
lies
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
Lies
,
Mr.
Finn
!
<EOS>
Did
you
say
lies
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
said
lies
;
 
lies
;
 
lies
!
"
<EOS>
And
Phineas
walked
over
at
him
as
though
he
were
going
to
pitch
him
instantly
out
of
the
window
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
go
and
write
as
many
more
as
you
like
.
<EOS>
It
is
your
trade
,
and
you
must
do
it
or
starve
.
<EOS>
But
do
not
come
to
me
again
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
opened
the
door
and
stood
with
it
in
his
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
sir
.
<EOS>
I
shall
know
how
to
punish
this
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Exactly
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
please
you
'll
go
and
do
your
punishment
at
the
office
of
the
_
Banner
_
,
 
unless
you
like

here
.
<EOS>
You
want
to
kick
me
and
spit

,
but
you
will
prefer
to
do

in
print
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
said
Quintus
Slide
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
prefer
to
do
it
in
print
,
 
though
I
must
own
that
the
temptation
to
adopt
the
manual
violence
of
a
ruffian
is
great
,
very
great
,
very
great
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
But
he
resisted
the
temptation
and
walked
down
the
stairs
,
concocting
his
article
as
he
went
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Quintus
Slide
did
not
so
much
impede
the
business
of
his
day
but
what
Phineas
was
with
Mr.
Monk
by
two
,
and
in
his
place
in
the
House
when
prayers
were
read
at
four
.
<EOS>
As
he
sat
in
his
place
,
conscious
of
the
work
that
was
before
him
,
listening
to
the
presentation
of
petitions
,
and
to
the
formal
reading
of
certain
notices
of
motions
,
which
with
the
asking
of
sundry
questions
occupied
over
half
an
hour
,
he
looked
back
and
remembered
accurately
his
own
feelings
on
a
certain
night
on
which
he
had
intended
to
get
up
and
address
the
House
.
<EOS>
The
ordeal
before
him
had
then
been
so
terrible
,
that
it
had
almost
obliterated
for
the
moment
his
senses
of
hearing
and
of
sight
.
<EOS>
He
had
hardly
been
able
to
perceive
what
had
been
going
on
around
him
,
and
had
vainly
endeavoured
to
occupy
himself
in
recalling
to
his
memory
the
words
which
he
wished
to
pronounce
.
<EOS>
When
the
time
for
pronouncing
them
had
come
,
he
had
found
himself
unable
to
stand
upon
his
legs
.
<EOS>
He
smiled
as
he
recalled
all
this
in
his
memory
,
waiting
impatiently
for
the
moment
in
which
he
might
rise
.
<EOS>
His
audience
was
assured
to
him
now
,
and
he
did
not
fear
it
.
<EOS>
His
opportunity
for
utterance
was
his
own
,
and
even
the
Speaker
could
not
deprive
him
of
it
.
<EOS>
During
these
minutes
he
thought
not
at
all
of
the
words
that
he
was
to
say
.
<EOS>
He
had
prepared
his
matter
but
had
prepared
no
words
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
words
would
come
readily
enough
to
him
,
and
that
he
had
learned
the
task
of
turning
his
thoughts
quickly
into
language
while
standing
with
a
crowd
of
listeners
around
him
,
 
as
a
practised
writer
does
when
seated
in
his
chair
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
violent
beating
at
his
heart
now
,
no
dimness
of
the
eyes
,
no
feeling
that
the
ground
was
turning
round
under
his
feet
.
<EOS>
If
only
those
weary
vain
questions
would
get
themselves
all
asked
,
so
that
he
might
rise
and
begin
the
work
of
the
night
.
<EOS>
Then
there
came
the
last
thought
as
the
House
was
hushed
for
his
rising
.
<EOS>
What
was
the
good
of
it
all
,
when
he
would
never
have
an
opportunity
of
speaking
there
again
?
  
<EOS>
But
not
on
that
account
would
he
be
slack
in
his
endeavour
now
.
<EOS>
He
would
be
listened
to
once
at
least
,
not
as
a
subaltern
of
the
Government
but
as
the
owner
of
a
voice
prominent
in
opposition
to
the
Government
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
taught
by
Mr.
Monk
that
that
was
the
one
place
in
the
House
in
which
a
man
with
a
power
of
speaking
could
really
enjoy
pleasure
without
alloy
.
<EOS>
He
would
make
the
trial
,
 
once
,
if
never
again
.
<EOS>
Things
had
so
gone
with
him
that
the
rostrum
was
his
own
,
and
a
House
crammed
to
overflowing
was
there
to
listen
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
given
up
his
place
in
order
that
he
might
be
able
to
speak
his
mind
,
and
had
become
aware
that
many
intended
to
listen
to
him
while
he
spoke
.
<EOS>
He
had
observed
that
the
rows
of
strangers
were
thick
in
the
galleries
,
that
peers
were
standing
in
the
passages
,
and
that
over
the
reporter
's
head
,
the
ribbons
of
many
ladies
were
to
be
seen
through
the
bars
of
their
cage
.
<EOS>
Yes
;
 
for
this
once
he
would
have
an
audience
.
  
<EOS>
He
spoke
for
about
an
hour
,
and
while
he
was
speaking
he
knew
nothing
about
himself
,
whether
he
was
doing
it
well
or
ill
.
<EOS>
Something
of
himself
he
did
say
soon
after
he
had
commenced
,
 
not
quite
beginning
with
it
,
as
though
his
mind
had
been
laden
with
the
matter
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
he
said
,
found
himself
compelled
to
renounce
his
happy
allegiance
to
the
First
Lord
of
the
Treasury
,
and
to
quit
the
pleasant
company
in
which
,
humble
as
had
been
his
place
,
he
had
been
allowed
to
sit
and
act
,
by
his
unfortunate
conviction
in
this
great
subject
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
told
,
he
said
,
that
it
was
a
misfortune
in
itself
for
one
so
young
as
he
to
have
convictions
.
<EOS>
But
his
Irish
birth
and
Irish
connection
had
brought
this
misfortune
of
his
country
so
closely
home
to
him
that
he
had
found
the
task
of
extricating
himself
from
it
to
be
impossible
.
<EOS>
Of
what
further
he
said
,
speaking
on
that
terribly
unintelligible
subject
,
a
tenant
-
right
proposed
for
Irish
farmers
,
no
English
reader
will
desire
to
know
much
.
<EOS>
Irish
subjects
in
the
House
of
Commons
are
interesting
or
are
dull
,
are
debated
before
a
crowded
audience
composed
of
all
who
are
leaders
in
the
great
world
of
London
,
or
before
empty
benches
,
in
accordance
with
the
importance
of
the
moment
and
the
character
of
the
debate
.
<EOS>
For
us
now
it
is
enough
to
know
that
to
our
hero
was
accorded
that
attention
which
orators
love
,
 
which
will
almost
make
an
orator
if
it
can
be
assured
.
<EOS>
A
full
House
with
a
promise
of
big
type
on
the
next
morning
would
wake
to
eloquence
the
propounder
of
a
Canadian

,
or
the
mover
of
an
Indian

.
  
<EOS>
Phineas
did
not
stir
out
of
the
House
till
the
division
was
over
,
having
agreed
with
Mr.
Monk
that
they
two
would
remain
through
it
all
and
hear
everything
that
was
to

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
had
already
spoken
,
and
to
Mr.
Palliser
was
confided
the
task
of
winding
up
the

for
the
Government
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Robson
spoke
also
,
greatly
enlivening
the
tedium
of
the

,
and
to
Mr.
Monk
was

.
<EOS>
At
two
o'clock
the
division
came
,
and
the
Ministry
were

by
a

of

-
three
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
"
said

,

,
"
the

that

are
not

bit
nearer
tenant
-
right
than

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
we
are

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
one

,
yes
.
<EOS>
Such
a

and
such

majority
will
make

.
<EOS>
But
no
;
 
think
is
too
high

;
as

rule
men
do
n't
think
.
<EOS>
But
it
will
make
them
believe
that
there
is
something
in

.
<EOS>
Many
who
before
regarded

on
the
subject
as

,
will
now
fancy
that
it
is
only

,
or
perhaps

.
<EOS>
And
so

time

will
come
to

as

,

;
 
and
so

last
<EOS>
it
will

which
the
country

as

.
<EOS>
That
is
the
way
in
which
public
opinion
is

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
no
loss

,
"
said

,
"
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
first

,
"
said

Monk
,
 
"
taken

,

,

.
<EOS>
But
it
is
a
great
thing
to
take
any
step
that
leads
us
onwards
.
"
  
<EOS>
Two
days
after
this
Mr.
Gresham
declared
his
intention
of
dissolving
the
House
because
of
the
adverse
division
which
had
been
produced
by
Mr.
Monk
's

,
but
expressed

to
be

to
carry
an
Irish
Reform
Bill
through

before
he
did

.
<EOS>
He
explained
how
expedient
this
would
be
,
but
declared
at
the
same
time
that
if
any
strong

were
made
,
he

abandon

.
<EOS>
His
intention
simply
was
to
pass
with
regard
to
Ireland
a
measure
which
must
be
passed
soon
,
and
which
ought
to
be
passed
before
a
new
election
took
place
.
<EOS>
The
bill
was
ready
,
and
should
be
read
for
the
first
time
on
the
next
night
,
if
the
House
were
willing
.
<EOS>
The
House
was
willing
,
though
there
were
very
many
recalcitrant
Irish
members
.
<EOS>
The
Irish
members
made
loud
opposition
,
and
then
twitted
Mr.
Gresham
with
his
promise
that
he
would
not
go
on
with
his
bill
,
if
opposition
were
made
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
he
did
go
on
,
and
the
measure
was
hurried
through
the
two
Houses
in
a
week
.
<EOS>
Our
hero
who
still
sat
for
Loughshane
,
but
who
was
never
to
sit
for
Loughshane
again
,
gave
what

he
could
to
the
Government
,
and
voted
for
the
measure
which
deprived
Loughshane
for
ever
of
its
parliamentary
honours
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
very
dirty
conduct
<EOS>
I
think
it
was
,
"
said
Lord
Tulla
,
when
he
discussed
the
subject
with
his
agent
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
After
being
put
in
for
the
borough
twice
,
almost
free
of
expense
,
it
was
very
dirty
.
<EOS>
"
It
never
occurred
to
Lord
Tulla
that
a
member
of
Parliament
might
feel
himself
obliged
to
vote
on
such
a
subject
in
accordance
with
his
judgment
.
  
<EOS>
This
Irish
Reform
Bill
was
scrambled
through
the
two
Houses
,
and
then
the
session
was
over
.
<EOS>
The
session
was
over
,
and
they
who
knew
anything
of
the
private
concerns
of
Mr.
Phineas
Finn
were
aware
that
he
was
about
to
return
to
Ireland
,
and
did
not
intend
to
reappear
on
the
scene
which
had
known

so
well
for

last

.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
tell
you
how
sad
it
makes

,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
it
makes
me
sad
too
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
I
try
to
shake
off
the
melancholy
,
and
tell
myself
from
day
to
day
that
it
is
unmanly
.
<EOS>
But
it
gets
the
better
of
me
just
at
present
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
feel
quite
certain
that
you
will
come
back

again
,
"
said
Mr.
Monk
.
  
<EOS>
"
Everybody
tells
me
so
;
and
yet
I
feel
quite
certain
that
I
shall
never
come
back
<EOS>
,
 
never
come
back
with
a
seat
in
Parliament
.
<EOS>
As
my
old

,
Low
,
has
told
me
scores

,
I
began
at
the
wrong
end
.
<EOS>
Here
I
am
,
thirty
years
of
age
,
and
I
have
not
a
shilling
in
the
world
,
and
I
do
not

how
to
earn

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Only

me
you
would
still

receiving
ever
so
much
a

,
and
all

,
"
said

Monk
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
how

it
have

?
<EOS>
The
first
moment
that
Daubeny
got
the
upper
hand
I
should
have
fallen
lower
than
I
have

now
.
<EOS>
If
not
this
year
,
it
would
have
been
the

.
<EOS>
My
only
comfort
is
in
this
,
 
that
I
have
done
the
thing
myself
,
and
have
not
been
turned
out
.
"
<EOS>
To
the
very
last
,
however
,
Mr.
Monk
continued
to

opinion
that
Phineas
would
come
back
,
declaring
that
he
had
known
no
instance
of

who
had
made
himself
useful
in
Parliament
,
and
then
had
been
allowed
to
leave
it
in
early

.
  
<EOS>
Among

of

he
was
bound

,
the

the
family
of
Lord
Brentford
were
,

,

.
<EOS>
He
had
already

and

,
and

.
<EOS>
And

was

that

.
<EOS>
To

,

much

able

,
and
a

.
<EOS>
But
,
as

,
he
came
upon

two

together
,
and
then

that
he
had
hardly

before

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

Finn
,

.
<EOS>
I
read

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
did
n't

,

,
"
said

,

that
was
common

when

.
  
<EOS>
"
Laura
went
down

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

not

,
because
I

.
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
conceive
how
dutiful
I
am
during

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
is
it
to
be
in
a
month
,
Chiltern
?
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
says
so
.
<EOS>
She
arranges
everything
,
 
in
concert
with
my
father
.
<EOS>
When
I
threw
up
the
sponge
,
I
simply
asked
for
a
long
day
.
<EOS>
"
A
long
day
,
my
lord
,
"
I
said
.
<EOS>
But
my
father
and
Violet
between
them
refused
me
any
mercy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
believe
him
,
"
said
Violet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
word
.
<EOS>
If
I
did
he
would
want
to
see
me
on
the
coast
of
Flanders
again
,
I
do
n't
doubt
.
<EOS>
I
have
come
to
congratulate
you
both
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
said
Violet
,
taking
his
hand
with
hearty
kindness
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
have
been
quite
happy
without
one
nice
word
from
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
try
and
make
the
best
of
it
,
"
said
Chiltern
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
I
say
,
you
'll
come
over
and
ride
Bonebreaker
again
.
<EOS>
He
's
down
there
at
the
Bull
,
and
I
've
taken
a
little
box
close
by
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
stand
the
governor
's
county
for
hunting
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
will
your
wife
go
down
to
Willingford
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
she
will
,
and
ride
to
hounds
a
great
deal
closer
than
I
can
ever
do
.
<EOS>
Mind
you
come
,
and
if
there
's
anything
in
the
stable
fit
to
carry
you
,
you
shall
have
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
had
to
explain
that
he
had
come
to
bid
them
farewell
,
and
that
it
was
not
at
all
probable
that
he
should
ever
be
able
to
see
Willingford
again
in
the
hunting
season
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
suppose
that
I
shall
make
either
of
you
quite
understand
it
,
but
I
have
got
to
begin
again
.
<EOS>
The
chances
are
that
I
shall
never
see
another
foxhound
all
my
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
in
Ireland
!
"
exclaimed
Lord
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
unless
I
should
have
to
examine
one
as
a
witness
.
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
before
me
but
downright
hard
work
;
and
a
great
deal
of
that
must
be
done
before
I
can
hope
to
earn
a
shilling
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
so
clever
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
will
come
quickly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
mean
to
be
impatient
about
it
,
nor
yet
unhappy
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Only
hunting
wo
n't
be
much
in
my
line
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
will
you
leave
London
altogether
?
<EOS>
"
Violet
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Altogether
.
<EOS>
I
shall
stick
to
one
club
,
 
Brooks
's
;
but
I
shall
take
my
name
off
all
the
others
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
deuce
of
a
nuisance
!
"
said
Lord
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
you
will
be
very
happy
,
"
said
Violet
;
"
and
you
'll
be
a
Lord
Chancellor
in
no
time
.
<EOS>
But
you
wo
n't
go
quite
yet
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Next
Sunday
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
return
.
<EOS>
You
must
be
here
for
our
wedding
;
 
indeed
you
must
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
be
married
unless
you
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Even
this
,
however
,
was
impossible
.
<EOS>
He
must
go
on
Sunday
,
and
must
return
no
more
.
<EOS>
Then
he
made
his
little
farewell
speech
,
which
he
could
not
deliver
without
some
awkward
stuttering
.
<EOS>
He
would
think
of
her
on
the
day
of
her
marriage
,
and
pray
that
she
might
be
happy
.
<EOS>
And
he
would
send
her
a
little
trifle
before
he
went
,
which
he
hoped
she
would
wear
in
remembrance
of
their
old
friendship
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
shall
wear
it
,
whatever
it
is
,
or
I
'll
know
the
reason
<EOS>
why
,
"
said
Chiltern
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
,
you
rough
bear
!
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
'll
wear
it
.
<EOS>
And
of
course
I
'll
think
of
the
giver
.
<EOS>
I
shall
have
many
presents
,
but
few
that
I
will
think
of
so
much
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
left
the
room
,
with
his
throat
so
full
that
he
could
not
speak
another
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
still
broken
-
hearted
about
you
,
"
said
the
favoured
lover
as
soon
as
his
rival
had
left
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
that
,
"
said
Violet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
broken
-
hearted
about
everything
.
<EOS>
The
whole
world
is
vanishing
away
from
him
.
<EOS>
I
wish
he
could
have
made
up
his
mind
to
marry
that
German
woman
with
all
the
money
.
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
understood
,
however
,
that
Phineas
had
never
spoken
a
word
to
any
one
as
to
the
offer
which
the
German
woman
had
made
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
on
the
morning
of
the
Sunday
on
which
he
was
to
leave
London
that
he
saw
Lady
Laura
.
<EOS>
He
had
asked
that
it
might
be
so
,
in
order
that
he
might
then
have
nothing
more
upon
his
mind
.
<EOS>
He
found
her
quite
alone
,
and
he
could
see
by
her
eyes
that
she
had
been
weeping
.
<EOS>
As
he
looked
at
her
,
remembering
that
it
was
not
yet
six
years
since
he
had
first
been
allowed
to
enter
that
room
,
he
could
not
but
perceive
how
very
much
she
was
altered
in
appearance
.
<EOS>
Then
she
had
been
three
-
and
-
twenty
,
and
had
not
looked
to
be
a
day
older
.
<EOS>
Now
she
might
have
been
taken
to
be
nearly
forty
,
so
much
had
her
troubles
preyed
upon
her
spirit
,
and
eaten
into
the
vitality
of
her
youth
.
"
<EOS>
So
you
have
come
to
say
good
-
bye
,
"
she
said
,
smiling
as
she
rose
to
meet
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Lady
Laura
;
 
to
say
good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
Not
for
ever
,
I
hope
,
but
probably
for
long
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
for
ever
.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
we
will
not
think
so
.
<EOS>
"
Then
she
paused
;
but
he
was
silent
,
sitting
with
his
hat
dangling
in
his
two
hands
,
and
his
eyes
fixed
upon
the
floor
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
know
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
she
continued
,
"
that
sometimes
I
am
very
angry
with
myself
about
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
it
must
be
because
you
have
been
too
kind
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
because
I
fear
that
I
have
done
much
to
injure
you
.
<EOS>
From
the
first
day
that
I
knew
you
,
 
do
you
remember
,
when
we
were
talking
here
,
in
this
very
room
,
about
the
beginning
of
the
Reform
Bill
;
 
from
that
day
I
wished
that
you
should
come
among
us
and
be
one
of
us
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
with
you
,
to
my
infinite
satisfaction
,
 
while
it
lasted
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
has
not
lasted
,
and
now
I
fear
that
it
has
done
you
harm
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
can
say
whether
it
has
been
for
good
or
evil
?
<EOS>
But
of
this
I
am
sure
you
will
be
certain
,
 
that
I
am
very
grateful
to
you
for
all
the
goodness
you
have
shown
me
.
"
<EOS>
Then
again
he
was
silent
.
  
<EOS>
She
did
not
know
what
it
was
that
she
wanted
,
but
she
did
desire
some
expression
from
his
lips
that
should
be
warmer
than
an
expression
of
gratitude
.
<EOS>
An
expression
of
love
,
 
of
existing
love
,
 
she
would
have
felt
to
be
an
insult
,
and
would
have
treated
it
as
such
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
she
knew
that
from
him
no
such
insult
could
come
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
in
that
morbid
,
melancholy
state
of
mind
which
requires
the
excitement
of
more
than
ordinary
sympathy
,
even
though
that
sympathy
be
all
painful
;
and
I
think
that
she
would
have
been
pleased
had
he
referred
to
the
passion
for
herself
which
he
had
once
expressed
.
<EOS>
If
he
would
have
spoken
of
his
love
,
and
of
her
mistake
,
and
have
made
some
half
-
suggestion
as
to
what
might
have
been
their
lives
had
things
gone
differently
,
 
though
she
would
have
rebuked
him
even
for
that
,
 
still
it
would
have
comforted
her
.
<EOS>
But
at
this
moment
,
though
he
remembered
much
that
had
passed
between
them
,
he
was
not
even
thinking
of
the
Braes
of
Linter
.
<EOS>
All
that
had
taken
place
four
years
ago
;
 
and
there
had
been
so
many
other
things
since
which
had
moved
him
even
more
than
that
!
<EOS>
"
You
have
heard
what
I
have
arranged
for
myself
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
at
last
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
father
has
told
me
that
you
are
going
to
Dresden
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;
 
he
will
accompany
me
,
 
coming
home
of
course
for
Parliament
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
sad
break
-
up
,
is
it
not
?
<EOS>
But
the
lawyer
says
that
if
I
remain
here
I
may
be
subject
to
very
disagreeable
attempts
from
Mr.
Kennedy
to
force
me
to
go
back
again
.
<EOS>
It
is
odd
,
is
it
not
,
that
he
should
not
understand
how
impossible
it
is
?
"
  
"
He
means
to
do
his
duty
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
so
.
<EOS>
But
he
becomes
more
stern
every
day
to
those
who
are
with
him
.
<EOS>
And
then
,
why
should
I
remain
here
?
<EOS>
What
is
there
to
tempt
me
?
<EOS>
As
a
woman
separated
from
her
husband
I
can
not
take
an
interest
in
those
things
which
used
to
charm
me
.
<EOS>
I
feel
that
I
am
crushed
and
quelled
by
my
position
,
even
though
there
is
no
disgrace
in
it
.
"
  
"
No
disgrace
,
certainly
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
nobody
,
 
or
worse
than
nobody
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
also
am
going
to
be
a
nobody
,
"
said
Phineas
,
laughing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
;
you
are
a
man
and
will
get
over
it
,
and
you
have
many
years
before
you
will
begin
to
be
growing
old
.
<EOS>
I
am
growing
old
already
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
am
.
<EOS>
I
feel
it
,
and
know
it
,
and
see
it
.
<EOS>
A
woman
has
a
fine
game
to
play
;
but
then
she
is
so
easily
bowled
out
,
and
the
term
allowed
to
her
is
so
short
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
man
's
allowance
of
time
may
be
short
too
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
can
try
his
hand
again
.
<EOS>
"
Then
there
was
another
pause
.
<EOS>
"
I
had
thought
,
Mr.
Finn
,
that
you
would
have
married
,
"
she
said
in
her
very
lowest
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
knew
all
my
hopes
and
fears
about
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
that
you
would
have
married
Madame
Goesler
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
made
you
think
that
,
Lady
Laura
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Because
I
saw
that
she
liked
you
,
and
because
such
a
marriage
would
have
been
so
suitable
.
<EOS>
She
has
all
that
you
want
.
<EOS>
You
know
what
they
say
of
her
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
they
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
the
Duke
of
Omnium
offered
to
make
her
his
wife
,
and
that
she
refused
him
for
your
sake
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
that
people
wo
n't
say
;
 
nothing
on
earth
,
"
said
Phineas
.
<EOS>
Then
he
got
up
and
took
his
leave
of
her
.
<EOS>
He
also
wanted
to
part
from
her
with
some
special
expression
of
affection
,
but
he
did
not
know
how
to
choose
his
words
.
<EOS>
He
had
wished
that
some
allusion
should
be
made
,
not
to
the
Braes
of
Linter
,
but
to
the
close
confidence
which
had
so
long
existed
between
them
;
but
he
found
that
the
language
to
do
this
properly
was
wanting
to
him
.
<EOS>
Had
the
opportunity
arisen
he
would
have
told
her
now
the
whole
story
of
Mary
Flood
Jones
;
but
the
opportunity
did
not
come
,
and
he
left
her
,
never
having
mentioned
the
name
of
his
Mary
or
having
hinted
at
his
engagement
to
any
one
of
his
friends
in
London
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
better
so
,
"
he
said
to
himself
.
<EOS>
"
My
life
in
Ireland
is
to
be
a
new
life
,
and
why
should
I
mix
two
things
together
that
will
be
so
different
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
to
dine
at
his
lodgings
,
and
then
leave
them
for
good
at
eight
o'clock
.
<EOS>
He
had
packed
up
everything
before
he
went
to
Portman
Square
,
and
he
returned
home
only
just
in
time
to
sit
down
to
his
solitary
mutton
chop
.
<EOS>
But
as
he
sat
down
he
saw
a
small
note
addressed
to
himself
lying
on
the
table
among
the
crowd
of
books
,
letters
,
and
papers
,
of
which
he
had
still
to
make
disposal
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
small
note
in
an
envelope
of
a
peculiar
tint
of
pink
,
and
he
knew
the
handwriting
well
.
<EOS>
The
blood
mounted
all
over
his
face
as
he
took
it
up
,
and
he
hesitated
for
a
moment
before
he
opened
it
.
<EOS>
It
could
not
be
that
the
offer
should
be
repeated
to
him
.
<EOS>
Slowly
,
hardly
venturing
at
first
to
look
at
the
enclosure
,
he
opened
it
,
and
the
words
which
it
contained
were
as
follows
:
    
<EOS>
I
learn
that
you
are
going
to
-
day
,
and
I
write
a
word
which
you
will
receive
just
as
you
are
departing
.
<EOS>
It
is
to
say
merely
this
,
 
that
when
I
left
you
the
other
day
I
was
angry
,
not
with
you
,
but
with
myself
.
<EOS>
Let
me
wish
you
all
good
wishes
and
that
prosperity
which
I
know
you
will
deserve
,
and
which
<EOS>
I
think
you
will
win
.
  
<EOS>
Yours
very
truly
,
  
M.
M.
G.
  
Sunday
morning
.
  
<EOS>
Should
he
put
off
his
journey
and
go
to
her
this
very
evening
and
claim
her
as
his
friend
?
<EOS>
The
question
was
asked
and
answered
in
a
moment
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
would
not
go
to
her
.
<EOS>
Were
he
to
do
<EOS>
so
there
would
be
only
one
possible
word
for
him
to
say
,
and
that
word
should
certainly
never
be
spoken
.
<EOS>
But
he
wrote
to
her
a
reply
,
shorter
even
than
her
own
short
note
.
  
<EOS>
Thanks
,
dear
friend
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
doubt
but
that
you
and
I
understand
each
other
thoroughly
,
and
that
each
trusts
the
other
for
good
wishes
and
honest
intentions
.
  
<EOS>
Always
yours
,
  
<EOS>
P.
F.
  
I
write
these
as
I
am
starting
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
had
written
this
,
he
kept
it
till
the
last
moment
in
his
hand
,
thinking
that
he
would
not
send
it
.
<EOS>
But
as
he
slipped
into
the
cab
,
he
gave
the
note
to
his
late
landlady
to
post
.
  
<EOS>
At
the
station
Bunce
came
to
him
to
say
a
word
of
farewell
,
and
Mrs.
Bunce
was
on
his
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
done
,
Mr.
Finn
,
well
done
,
"
said
Bunce
.
<EOS>
"
I
always
knew
there
was
a
good
drop
in
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
always
told
me
I
should
ruin
myself
in
Parliament
,
and
so
I
have
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
.
<EOS>
It
takes
a
deal
to
ruin
a
man
if
he
's
got
the
right
sperrit
.
<EOS>
I
've
better
hopes
of
you
now
than
ever
I
had
in
the
old
days
when
you
used
to
be
looking
out
for
Government
place
;
 
and
Mr.
Monk
has
tried
that
too
.
<EOS>
I
thought
he
would
find
the
iron
too
heavy
for
him
.
"
<EOS>
"
God
bless
you
,
Mr.
Finn
,
"
said
Mrs.
Bunce
with
her
handkerchief
up
to

.
<EOS>
"
There
's
not
one
of
'em
<EOS>
I
ever
had
as
lodgers
<EOS>
I
've
cared
about
half
as
much
as
I
did
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
Then
they
shook
hands
with
him
through
the
window
,
and
the
train
was
off
.
   
<EOS>
Conclusion
 
<EOS>
We
are
told
that
it
is
a
bitter
moment
with
the
Lord
Mayor
when
he
leaves
the
Mansion
House
and
becomes
once
more
Alderman
Jones
,
of
No
.
75
,
Bucklersbury
.
<EOS>
Lord
Chancellors
going
out
of
office
have
a
great
fall
though
they
take
pensions
with
them
for
their
consolation
.
<EOS>
And
the
President
of
the
United
States
when
he
leaves
the
glory
of
the
White
House
and
once
more
becomes
a
simple
citizen
<EOS>
must
feel
the
change
severely
.
<EOS>
But
our
hero
,
Phineas
Finn
,
as
he
turned
his
back
upon
the
scene
of
his
many
successes
,
and
prepared
himself
for
permanent
residence
in
his
own
country
,
was
,
I
think
,
in
a
worse
plight
than
any
of
the
reduced
divinities
to
whom
I
have
alluded
.
<EOS>
They
at
any
rate
had
known
that
their
fall
would
come
.
<EOS>
He
,
like
Icarus
,
had
flown
up
towards
the
sun
,
hoping
that
his
wings
of
wax
would
bear
him
steadily
aloft
among
the
gods
.
<EOS>
Seeing
that
his
wings
were
wings
of
wax
,
we
must
acknowledge
that
they
were
very
good
.
<EOS>
But
the
celestial
lights
had
been
too
strong
for
them
,
and
now
,
having
lived
for
five
years
with
lords
and
countesses
,
with
Ministers
and
orators
,
with
beautiful
women
and
men
of
fashion
,
he
must
start
again
in
a
little
lodging
in
Dublin
,
and
hope
that
the
attorneys
of
that
litigious
city
might
be
good
to
him
.
<EOS>
On
his
journey
home
he
made
but
one
resolution
.
<EOS>
He
would
make
the
change
,
or
attempt
to
make
it
,
with
manly
strength
.
<EOS>
During
his
last
month
in
London
he
had
allowed
himself
to
be
sad
,
depressed
,
and
melancholy
.
<EOS>
There
should
be
an
end
of
all
that
now
.
<EOS>
Nobody
at
home
should
see
that
he
was
depressed
.
<EOS>
And
Mary
,
his
own
Mary
,
should
at
any
rate
have
no
cause
to
think
that
her
love
and
his
own
engagement
had
ever
been
the
cause
to
him
of
depression
.
<EOS>
Did
he
not
value
her
love
more
than
anything
in
the
world
?
<EOS>
A
thousand
times
he
told
himself
that
he
did
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
there
in
the
old
house
at
Killaloe
to
greet
him
.
<EOS>
Her
engagement
was
an
affair
known
to
all
the
county
,
and
she
had
no
idea
that
it
would
become
her
to
be
coy
in
her
love
.
<EOS>
She
was
in
his
arms
before
he
had
spoken
to
his
father
and
mother
,
and
had
made
her
little
speech
to
him
,
 
very
inaudibly
indeed
,
 
while
he
was
covering
her
sweet
face
with
kisses
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Phineas
,
I
am
so
proud
of
you
;
and
I
think
you
are
so
right
,
and
I
am
so
glad
you
have
done
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Again
he
covered
her
face
with
kisses
.
<EOS>
Could
he
ever
have
had
such
satisfaction
as
this
had
he
allowed
Madame
Goesler
's
hand
to
remain
in
his
?
  
<EOS>
On
the
first
night
of
his
arrival
he
sat
for
an
hour
downstairs
with
his
father
talking
over
his
plans
.
<EOS>
He
felt
,
 
he
could
not
but
feel
,
 
that
he
was
not
the
hero
now
that
he
had
been
when
he
was
last
at
Killaloe
,
 
when
he
had
come
thither
with
a
Cabinet
Minister
under
his
wing
.
<EOS>
And
yet
his
father
did
his
best
to
prevent
the
growth
of
any
such
feeling
.
<EOS>
The
old
doctor
was
not
quite
as
well
off
as
he
had
been
when
Phineas
first
started
with
his
high
hopes
for
London
.
<EOS>
Since
that
day
he
had
abandoned
his
profession
and
was
now
living
on
the
fruits
of
his
life
's
labour
.
<EOS>
For
the
last
two
years
he
had
been
absolved
from
the
necessity
of
providing
an
income
for
his
son
,
and
had
probably
allowed
himself
to
feel
that
no
such
demand
upon
him
would
again
be
made
.
<EOS>
Now
,
however
,
it
was
necessary
that
he
should
do
so
.
<EOS>
Could
his
son
manage
to
live
on
two
hundred
a
-
year
?
<EOS>
There
would
then
be
four
hundred
a
-
year
left
for
the
wants
of
the
family
at
home
.
<EOS>
Phineas
swore
that
he
could
fight
his
battle
on
a
hundred
and
fifty
,
and
they
ended
the
argument
by
splitting
the
difference
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
paying
exactly
the
same
sum
of
money
for
the
rooms
he
had
just
left
in
London
;
but
then
,
while
he
held
those
rooms
,
his
income
had
been
two
thousand
a
-
year
.
<EOS>
Tenant
-
right
was
a
very
fine
thing
,
but
could
it
be
worth
such
a
fall
as
this
?
  
<EOS>
"
And
about
dear
Mary
?
"
said
the
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
may
not
be
very
long
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
spoken
to
her
about
it
,
but
your
mother
says
that
Mrs.
Flood
Jones
is
very
averse
to
a
long
engagement
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
can
I
do
?
<EOS>
She
would
not
wish
me
to
marry
her
daughter
with
no
other
income
than
an
allowance
made
by
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
mother
says
that
she
has
some
idea
that
you
and
she
might
live
together
;
 
that
if
they
let
Floodborough
you
might
take
a
small
house
in
Dublin
.
<EOS>
Remember
,
Phineas
,
I
am
not
proposing
it
myself
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
Phineas
bethought
himself
that
he
was
not
even
yet
so
low
in
the
world
that
he
need
submit
himself
to
terms
dictated
to
him
by
Mrs.
Flood
Jones
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
that
you
do
not
propose
it
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
so
,
Phineas
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
should
have
been
obliged
to
oppose
the
plan
even
if
it
had
come
from
you
.
<EOS>
Mothers
-
in
-
law
are
never
a
comfort
in
a
house
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
tried
it
myself
,
"
said
the
doctor
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
never
will
try
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
quite
sure
that
Mary
does
not
expect
any
such
thing
,
and
that
she
is
willing
to
wait
.
<EOS>
If
I
can
shorten
the
term
of
waiting
by
hard
work
,
I
will
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
The
decision
to
which
Phineas
had
come
on
this
matter
was
probably
made
known
to
Mrs.
Flood
Jones
after
some
mild
fashion
by
old
Mrs.
Finn
.
<EOS>
Nothing
more
was
said
to
Phineas
about
a
joint
household
;
but
he
was
quite
able
to
perceive
from
the
manner
of
the
lady
towards
him
that
his
proposed
mother
-
in
-
law
wished
him
to
understand
that
he
was
treating
her
daughter
very
badly
.
<EOS>
What
did
it
signify
?
<EOS>
None
of
them
knew
the
story
of
Madame
Goesler
,
and
of
course
none
of
them
would
know
it
.
<EOS>
None
of
them
would
ever
hear
how
well
he
had
behaved
to
his
little
Mary
.
  
<EOS>
But
Mary
did
know
it
all
before
he
left
her
to
go
up
to
Dublin
.
<EOS>
The
two
lovers
allowed
themselves
,
 
or
were
allowed
by
their
elders
,
one
week
of
exquisite
bliss
together
;
and
during
this
week
,
Phineas
told
her
,
I
think
,
everything
.
<EOS>
He
told
her
everything
as
far
as
he
could
do
so
without
seeming
to
boast
of
his
own
successes
.
<EOS>
How
is
a
man
not
to
tell
such
tales
when
he
has
on
his
arm
,
close
to
him
,
a
girl
who
tells
him
her
little
everything
of
life
,
and
only
asks
for
his
confidence
in
return
?
<EOS>
And
then
his
secrets
are
so
precious
to
her
and
so
sacred
,
that
he
feels
as
sure
of
her
fidelity
as
though
she
were
a
very
goddess
of
faith
and
trust
.
<EOS>
And
the
temptation
to
tell
is
so
great
.
<EOS>
For
all
that
he
has
to
tell
she
loves
him
the
better
and
still
the
better
.
<EOS>
A
man
desires
to
win
a
virgin
heart
,
and
is
happy
to
know
,
 
or
at
least
to
believe
,
 
that
he
has
won
it
.
<EOS>
With
a
woman
every
former
rival
is
an
added
victim
to
the
wheels
of
the
triumphant
chariot
in
which
she
is
sitting
.
<EOS>
"
All
these
has
he
known
and
loved
,
culling
sweets
from
each
of
them
.
<EOS>
But
now
he
has
come
to
me
,
and
I
am
the
sweetest
of
them
all
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
Mary
was
taught
to
believe
of
Laura
and
of
Violet
and
of
Madame
Goesler
,
 
that
though
they
had
had
charms
to
please
,
her
lover
had
never
been
so
charmed
as
he
was
now
while
she
was
hanging
to
his
breast
.
<EOS>
And
I
think
that
she
was
right
in
her
belief
.
<EOS>
During
those
lovely
summer
evening
walks
along
the
shores
of
Lough
Derg
,
Phineas
was
as
happy
as
he
had
ever
been
at
any
moment
of
his
life
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
be
impatient
,
 
never
,
"
she
said
to
him
on
the
last
evening
.
<EOS>
"
All
I
want
is
that
you
should
write
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
want
more
than
that
,
Mary
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
must
come
down
and
see
me
.
<EOS>
When
you
do
come
they
will
be
happy
,
happy
days
for
me
.
<EOS>
But
of
course
we
can
not
be
married
for
the
next
twenty
years
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Say
forty
,
Mary
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
say
anything
that
you
like
;
 
you
will
know
what
I
mean
just
as
well
.
<EOS>
And
,
Phineas
,
I
must
tell
you
one
thing
,
 
though
it
makes
me
sad
to
think
of
it
,
and
will
make
me
sad
to
speak
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
have
you
sad
on
our
last
night
,
Mary
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
say
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
beginning
to
understand
how
much
you
have
given
up
for
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
given
up
nothing
for
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
not
been
at
Killaloe
when
Mr.
Monk
was
here
,
and
if
we
had
not
,
 
had
not
,
 
oh
dear
,
if
I
had
not
loved
you
so
very
much
,
you
might
have
remained
in
London
,
and
that
lady
would
have
been
your
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Never
!
"
said
Phineas
stoutly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Would
she
not
?
<EOS>
She
must
not
be
your
wife
now
,
Phineas
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
going
to
pretend
that
I
will
give
you
up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
unkind
,
Mary
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
well
;
you
may
say
what
you
please
.
<EOS>
If
that
is
unkind
,
I
am
unkind
.
<EOS>
It
would
kill
me
to
lose
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Had
he
done
right
?
<EOS>
How
could
there
be
a
doubt
about
it
?
<EOS>
How
could
there
be
a
question
about
it
?
<EOS>
Which
of
them
had
loved
him
,
or
was
capable
of
loving
him
as
Mary
loved
him
?
<EOS>
What
girl
was
ever
so
sweet
,
so
gracious
,
so
angelic
,
as
his
own
Mary
?
<EOS>
He
swore
to
her
that
he
was
prouder
of
winning
her
than
of
anything
he
had
ever
done
in
all
his
life
,
and
that
of
all
the
treasures
that
had
ever
come
in
his
way
<EOS>
she
was
the
most
precious
.
<EOS>
She
went
to
bed
that
night
the
happiest
girl
in
all
Connaught
,
although
when
she
parted
from
him
she
understood
that
she
was
not
to
see
him
again
till
Christmas
-
Eve
.
  
<EOS>
But
she
did
see
him
again
before
the
summer
was
over
,
and
the
manner
of
their
meeting
was
in
this
wise
.
<EOS>
Immediately
after
the
passing
of
that
scrambled
Irish
Reform
Bill
,
Parliament
,
as
the
reader
knows
,
was
dissolved
.
<EOS>
This
was
in
the
early
days
of
June
,
and
before
the
end
of
July
the
new
members
were
again
assembled
at
Westminster
.
<EOS>
This
session
,
late
in
summer
,
was
very
terrible
;
but
it
was
not
very
long
,
and
then
it
was
essentially
necessary
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
of
the
year
's
business
which
must
yet
be
done
,
and
the
country
would
require
to
know
who
were
to
be
the
Ministers
of
the
Government
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
needed
that
the
reader
should
be
troubled
any
further
with
the
strategy
of
one
political
leader
or
of
another
,
or
that
more
should
be
said
of
Mr.
Monk
and
his
tenant
-
right
.
<EOS>
The
House
of
Commons
had
offended
Mr.
Gresham
by
voting
in
a
majority
against
him
,
and
Mr.
Gresham
had
punished
the
House
of
Commons
by
subjecting
it
to
the
expense
and
nuisance
of
a
new
election
.
<EOS>
All
this
is
constitutional
,
and
rational
enough
to
Englishmen
,
though
it
may
be
unintelligible
to
strangers
.
<EOS>
The
upshot
on
the
present
occasion
was
that
the
Ministers
remained
in
their
places
and
that
Mr.
Monk
's
bill
,
though
it
had
received
the
substantial
honour
of
a
second
reading
,
passed
away
for
the
present
into
the
limbo
of
abortive
legislation
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
would
not
concern
us
at
all
,
nor
our
poor
hero
much
,
were
it
not
that
the
great
men
with
whom
he
had
been
for
two
years
<EOS>
so
pleasant
a
colleague
,
remembered
him
with
something
of
affectionate
regret
.
<EOS>
Whether
it
began
with
Mr.
Gresham
or
with
Lord
Cantrip
,
I
will
not
say
;
 
or
whether
Mr.
Monk
,
though
now
a

enemy
,
may
have
said
a
word
that
brought
about
the
good
deed
.
<EOS>
Be
that
as
it
may
,
just
before
the
summer
session
was
brought
to
a
close
Phineas
<EOS>
received
the
following
letter
from
Lord
Cantrip
:
    
Downing
Street
,
August
4
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
MY
DEAR
MR
.
<EOS>
FINN
,
    
<EOS>
Mr.
Gresham
has
been
talking
to
me
,
and
we
both
think
that
possibly
a
permanent
Government
appointment
may
be
acceptable
to
you
.
<EOS>
We
have
no
doubt
,
that
should
this
be
the
case
,
your
services
would
be
very
valuable
to
the
country
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
vacancy
for
a
poor
-
law
inspector
at
present
in
Ireland
,
whose
residence
I
believe
should
be
in
Cork
.
<EOS>
The
salary
is
a
thousand
a
-
year
.
<EOS>
Should
the
appointment
suit
you
,
Mr.
Gresham
will
be
most
happy
to
nominate
you
to
the
office
.
<EOS>
Let
me
have
a
line
at
your
early
convenience
.
  
<EOS>
Believe
me
,
  
Most
sincerely
yours
,
  
CANTRIP
.
  
<EOS>
He
received
the
letter
one
morning
in
Dublin
,
and
within
three
hours
he
was
on
his
route
to
Killaloe
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
would
accept
the
appointment
,
but
he
would
not
even
do
that
without
telling
Mary
of
his
new
prospect
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
would
accept
the
appointment
.
<EOS>
Though
he
had
been
as
yet
barely
two
months
in
Dublin
,
though
he
had
hardly
been
long
enough
settled
to
his
work
to
have
hoped
to
be
able
to
see
in
which
way
there
might
be
a
vista
open
leading
to
success
,
still
he
had
fancied
that
he
had
seen
that
success
was
impossible
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
know
how
to
begin
,
 
and
men
were
afraid
of
him
,
thinking
that
he
was
unsteady
,
arrogant
,
and
prone
to
failure
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
seen
his
way
to
the
possibility
of
a
guinea
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
thousand
a
-
year
!
"
said
Mary
Flood
Jones
,
opening
her
eyes
wide
with
wonder
at
the
golden
future
before
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
nothing
very
great
for
a
perpetuity
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Phineas
;
surely
a
thousand
a
-
year
will
be
very
nice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
certain
,
"
said
Phineas
,
"
and
then
we
can
be
married
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
been
making

my

to
wait
ever
so
long
,
"
said
Mary
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
your
mind
must
be
unmade
,
"
said
Phineas
.
  
<EOS>
What
was
the
nature
of
the
reply
to
Lord
Cantrip
the
reader

imagine
,
and
thus
we
will
leave
our
hero
an
Inspector

County

Cork
.
